description: Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The MCSA: Windows Server 2012 is designed to be a mid-tier certification for someone who has been working in the field for several years and has had exposure to large and enterprise size deployments of Microsoft Windows and covers topics that are a “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows Server 2012 servers in a corporate or enterprise environment. Server systems often form a critical piece of the day-to-day operations for any business. The MCSA 70-410 Installing and Configuring Windows Server 2012 exam covers topics like how to install Windows server 2012, how to add roles to it so that your server can perform customized functions and other areas that will help the viewer to ensure their computing environment is functional and stable.

Server systems often form a critical piece of the day-to-day operations for any business. The MCSA 70-410 Installing and Configuring Windows Server 2012 exam covers topics like how to install Windows server 2012, how to add roles to it so that your server can perform customized functions and other areas that will help the viewer to ensure their computing environment is functional and stable.
name: MCSA Windows Server 2012 - 70-410 (UPDATED 2017)
subtitle: Installing and Configuring Windows Server 2012

episodes.description: The MCSA 70-410 Installing and Configuring Windows Server 2012 exam covers topics like how to install Windows server 2012, how to add roles to it so that your server can perform customized functions and other areas that will help the viewer to ensure their computing environment is functional and stable.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.207 --> 00:00:04.650
[MUSIC]
Welcome to Installing and

2
00:00:04.650 --> 00:00:10.054
Configuring Server 2012.

3
00:00:10.054 --> 00:00:13.873
In this overview, I'm going to explain
kind of what this series looks like,

4
00:00:13.873 --> 00:00:17.221
what to expect and just walk through
a little bit of the exam taking,

5
00:00:17.221 --> 00:00:18.940
test taking process.

6
00:00:18.940 --> 00:00:22.930
So, if we can take a look at my screen,
I wanna share a page that Microsoft

7
00:00:22.930 --> 00:00:26.900
has some details provided
surrounding this particular exam.

8
00:00:26.900 --> 00:00:30.590
So, maybe you are a server admin, or

9
00:00:30.590 --> 00:00:34.120
maybe you're just looking to
obtain a particular certification.

10
00:00:34.120 --> 00:00:37.331
Well this exam is going
to be part of a track for

11
00:00:37.331 --> 00:00:42.580
certification such as your MCP, or
Microsoft Certified Professional.

12
00:00:42.580 --> 00:00:45.826
It's a great place to
start with your MCSA,

13
00:00:45.826 --> 00:00:49.687
your Microsoft Certified
Solutions Associate, or

14
00:00:49.687 --> 00:00:54.620
even your MCSE, for
your Microsoft Certified Solutions Expert.

15
00:00:54.620 --> 00:00:58.320
Now currently,
at the point of this recording,

16
00:00:58.320 --> 00:01:02.210
it's $165 U.S. to take the exam.

17
00:01:02.210 --> 00:01:05.020
Microsoft exams are a little
funny in the sense they don't

18
00:01:05.020 --> 00:01:09.120
outright tell you exactly how many
questions are gonna be on the exam.

19
00:01:09.120 --> 00:01:13.720
The number could fluctuate, usually
between 40 to 60 questions per exam.

20
00:01:13.720 --> 00:01:17.875
And if we scroll down,
we can see there are six domain

21
00:01:17.875 --> 00:01:22.325
objectives underneath this
Skills measured portion.

22
00:01:22.325 --> 00:01:26.287
So what that means, those are six
categories for the exam topics,

23
00:01:26.287 --> 00:01:27.080
if you will.

24
00:01:27.080 --> 00:01:31.370
And if we take a look at those, you can
even see how they break them down into

25
00:01:31.370 --> 00:01:36.550
percentage as far as an overall
weighted percentage per category.

26
00:01:36.550 --> 00:01:40.700
So in the first domain,
we'll see install and configure servers.

27
00:01:40.700 --> 00:01:43.380
And if you hit the plus button
the left-hand side here,

28
00:01:43.380 --> 00:01:49.420
it'll expand out to just give you a little
more detail on really what to expect for

29
00:01:49.420 --> 00:01:51.810
a domain objective or topic here.

30
00:01:53.240 --> 00:01:57.280
So, the other five remaining topics
are going to be configure server roles and

31
00:01:57.280 --> 00:01:57.790
features.

32
00:01:57.790 --> 00:02:00.230
We'll definitely take
a look at all of those.

33
00:02:00.230 --> 00:02:03.880
We'll also spend quite a good amount
of time just looking at, well,

34
00:02:03.880 --> 00:02:07.160
how to configure Hyper-V with
the advent of virtualization.

35
00:02:07.160 --> 00:02:11.750
It's very important to understand how
those virtualized machines work in today's

36
00:02:11.750 --> 00:02:13.130
environments here in Windows.

37
00:02:14.130 --> 00:02:18.960
We'll also take a look at deploying and
configuring core network services,

38
00:02:18.960 --> 00:02:23.180
as well as installing and
administering active directory.

39
00:02:23.180 --> 00:02:28.840
And lastly, we'll specifically be looking
at how to create and manage group policy.

40
00:02:28.840 --> 00:02:33.366
So there is quite a bit here, I think its
a great place for you to go ahead and

41
00:02:33.366 --> 00:02:34.250
get started.

42
00:02:34.250 --> 00:02:37.063
So good luck, and I'll see you soon.

43
00:02:37.063 --> 00:02:42.530
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee look at the planning considerations for using Windows Server 2012 R2.  Cherokee reviews some of the different editions: Datacenter, Standard, Essentials and Foundation.  She also provides a scenario to consider when choosing which edition to pick.  Lastly, Cherokee provides us with the different hardware requirements when performing a basic installation of Server 2012 R2.
episodes.title: Planning a Server Installation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:07.257
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host Do Pezet [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:07.257 --> 00:00:11.015
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.015 --> 00:00:15.350
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.350 --> 00:00:23.100
You're watching the MCSA Windows Server
2012 R2 show for Exam 70-410.

5
00:00:23.100 --> 00:00:24.590
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong,

6
00:00:24.590 --> 00:00:29.520
and today we're gonna jump into
planning for a Server installation.

7
00:00:29.520 --> 00:00:32.570
And here to help us is going to
be of course, Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:32.570 --> 00:00:34.390
Cherokee, welcome back to the show,
how are you doing?

9
00:00:34.390 --> 00:00:35.960
>> Thanks, I'm doing great,
how are you today, Ronnie?

10
00:00:35.960 --> 00:00:37.020
>> I am doing fine.

11
00:00:37.020 --> 00:00:41.870
Now Cherokee, as we take a look
at this idea of planning for

12
00:00:41.870 --> 00:00:46.750
a Server installation in 2012 R2,
we want to make

13
00:00:46.750 --> 00:00:51.210
sure that we understand the purpose behind
the planning and why this is important.

14
00:00:51.210 --> 00:00:54.520
So take us back a little bit when
we start talking about like,

15
00:00:54.520 --> 00:00:59.490
even 2008 a little bit, and why this
actually is different or is it different?

16
00:00:59.490 --> 00:01:03.710
>> Okay, so planning is a large,
just like any big major project,

17
00:01:03.710 --> 00:01:07.240
you always want to spend good amount of
time to make sure you're ready, but for

18
00:01:07.240 --> 00:01:09.600
you just a head and dive into something.

19
00:01:09.600 --> 00:01:14.000
It's extremely important because there are
a lot of different aspects to think about

20
00:01:14.000 --> 00:01:18.760
just not only within network design, but
you also have things like licensing and

21
00:01:18.760 --> 00:01:21.560
additions that you need
to consider as well.

22
00:01:21.560 --> 00:01:26.170
And 2012 brings a lot of
new concepts to the table.

23
00:01:26.170 --> 00:01:29.940
They've done things differently
than Server 2008 and

24
00:01:29.940 --> 00:01:32.160
even Server 2016 has their
own details as well.

25
00:01:32.160 --> 00:01:34.660
So, it's important to
understand the differences,

26
00:01:34.660 --> 00:01:37.590
you are expected to know that for
the exam.

27
00:01:37.590 --> 00:01:39.590
So let's go ahead, and like Ronnie said,

28
00:01:39.590 --> 00:01:43.500
let's think about some of you may have
already been working with Server 2008.

29
00:01:43.500 --> 00:01:47.470
And you'll notice there you had,
originally with the 2008 version,

30
00:01:47.470 --> 00:01:51.310
you had the option still to go
with that 32 bit or 64 bit.

31
00:01:51.310 --> 00:01:57.521
And with 2008 R2,
you only had that 64 bit option.

32
00:01:57.521 --> 00:02:01.513
So 2012 kind of adopted that, and most,
I mean we're not probably gonna be

33
00:02:01.513 --> 00:02:04.032
regressing anytime soon
back to those 32 bits.

34
00:02:04.032 --> 00:02:08.517
So that simplifies things
in some way there.

35
00:02:08.517 --> 00:02:13.421
So moving forward,
we're not gonna be working with those 32

36
00:02:13.421 --> 00:02:17.120
bit systems anymore, so that helps.

37
00:02:17.120 --> 00:02:20.405
And if we look at the different
types of additions,

38
00:02:20.405 --> 00:02:22.300
so they have tried to streamline that.

39
00:02:22.300 --> 00:02:23.630
If we take a look at my screen,

40
00:02:23.630 --> 00:02:27.350
we don't see the same additions
that we saw in Server 2008.

41
00:02:27.350 --> 00:02:30.090
And a slight difference
here with the name change.

42
00:02:31.090 --> 00:02:34.840
We'll talk about each one of our four
main additions here in a moment,

43
00:02:34.840 --> 00:02:41.780
which in 2008 they were foundation,
standard, enterprise, and data centers.

44
00:02:41.780 --> 00:02:44.270
So the names have changed slightly.

45
00:02:44.270 --> 00:02:50.320
I will alert you to that, but
we do not see our web server anymore,

46
00:02:50.320 --> 00:02:55.090
our HPC, the high performance cuting,
or our itanium based, for

47
00:02:55.090 --> 00:02:57.820
the itanium processors for
those servers as well.

48
00:02:57.820 --> 00:02:59.340
So, those are going to
be some differences,

49
00:02:59.340 --> 00:03:02.770
but if you think about it in
even the most generic way.

50
00:03:02.770 --> 00:03:09.180
And, Ronnie, I know we were talking
about kind of describing it as a car,

51
00:03:09.180 --> 00:03:13.770
like if we talk about the make being
Cadillac, the model of the car

52
00:03:13.770 --> 00:03:18.550
is almost alikened to the version of
this particular operating system.

53
00:03:18.550 --> 00:03:21.593
So let's take a look at bits and
think about okay,

54
00:03:21.593 --> 00:03:26.210
well what's the big mack daddy,
the escalate here, right?

55
00:03:26.210 --> 00:03:28.660
So that would be your
data center additions.

56
00:03:28.660 --> 00:03:32.090
So data center additions
is going to be designed for

57
00:03:32.090 --> 00:03:34.440
highly virtualized environments.

58
00:03:34.440 --> 00:03:35.910
So with the data center addition,

59
00:03:35.910 --> 00:03:40.828
you can have an unlimited amount
of virtual instances running.

60
00:03:40.828 --> 00:03:43.080
You are gonna see that
reflected in the cost, so

61
00:03:43.080 --> 00:03:46.280
we're talking about the most
expensive addition, but

62
00:03:46.280 --> 00:03:50.570
it's going to be necessary in
a highly virtualized environment.

63
00:03:50.570 --> 00:03:55.320
You have up to 64 processor support
including fault tolerance and

64
00:03:55.320 --> 00:03:58.880
the ability for hot add processors,
which is pretty cool for

65
00:03:58.880 --> 00:04:03.540
that redundancy and that stability
in a larger enterprise there.

66
00:04:03.540 --> 00:04:07.750
I will note that the way you
can obtain your data center

67
00:04:07.750 --> 00:04:11.520
edition is gonna be through
Microsoft Volume Licensing only.

68
00:04:11.520 --> 00:04:14.889
And so we'll talk about licensing
here a few moments, but

69
00:04:14.889 --> 00:04:19.580
just know that data center, virtualized
environments, that's the way to go.

70
00:04:19.580 --> 00:04:22.110
Now, if you wanna go ahead and
take a step down.

71
00:04:22.110 --> 00:04:26.210
So maybe you want all the features
that the data center has to offer but

72
00:04:26.210 --> 00:04:28.650
you don't need all those
virtualized instances.

73
00:04:28.650 --> 00:04:31.810
You may only need a few or
maybe more beneficial,

74
00:04:31.810 --> 00:04:34.770
maybe you only had four virtual
instance you wanted to run.

75
00:04:34.770 --> 00:04:36.560
So looking at the cost for

76
00:04:36.560 --> 00:04:41.020
the full blown unlimited really doesn't
warrant you spending that much money.

77
00:04:41.020 --> 00:04:45.180
So you could go ahead and take a step
down, and when I say step down you're not

78
00:04:45.180 --> 00:04:49.800
losing out on any of those great features,
you're just gonna be limited in

79
00:04:49.800 --> 00:04:54.560
the amount of instances that you have
running for that particular edition.

80
00:04:54.560 --> 00:04:59.670
So with your standard edition,
you're gonna be limited to two per for

81
00:04:59.670 --> 00:05:03.685
each license,
it's gonna be two virtual instances.

82
00:05:03.685 --> 00:05:07.420
So just to clarify,
that's not a software limitation,

83
00:05:07.420 --> 00:05:11.580
that's gonna be a licensing limitation or
you would need to buy additional licenses.

84
00:05:11.580 --> 00:05:14.100
>> All right, so Cherokee,
before we move on there and

85
00:05:14.100 --> 00:05:16.340
you now moved into the realm of standard.

86
00:05:16.340 --> 00:05:19.430
What we were seeing earlier in the graphic
that you showed us is that there was

87
00:05:19.430 --> 00:05:21.400
an enterprise edition, as well.

88
00:05:21.400 --> 00:05:23.750
So what happened to
the enterprise edition?

89
00:05:23.750 --> 00:05:30.440
>> So Microsoft has a propensity to
kind of rename things after a while.

90
00:05:30.440 --> 00:05:36.070
So It's kind of the same concept as
far as levels of versions there,

91
00:05:36.070 --> 00:05:38.160
but they changed the name to standard.

92
00:05:38.160 --> 00:05:40.900
So if we take a look at my screen,
this is a PDF.

93
00:05:40.900 --> 00:05:44.460
And do, this PDF is going to be
their commercial licensing reference

94
00:05:44.460 --> 00:05:48.540
guide which will explain the licensing
model that they have to offer for

95
00:05:48.540 --> 00:05:50.798
this particular operating system.

96
00:05:50.798 --> 00:05:54.720
I do wanna point out that it is
different with Sever 2016, so

97
00:05:54.720 --> 00:05:59.645
you will need to be aware of that and
understand that when, if you are in charge

98
00:05:59.645 --> 00:06:03.675
of the acquisition for these particular
license within your environment.

99
00:06:03.675 --> 00:06:07.615
And if we scroll down here, so
that document we were just looking at,

100
00:06:07.615 --> 00:06:11.135
that chart to show the different
additions, this is and

101
00:06:11.135 --> 00:06:15.715
I wanna say this is from,
as you can see here, May of 2017.

102
00:06:15.715 --> 00:06:21.900
So these prices reflect
that particular time frame.

103
00:06:21.900 --> 00:06:25.287
And when I say these prices,
I'm talking about this chart right here.

104
00:06:25.287 --> 00:06:29.070
And you can see the different
editions that I'm talking about and

105
00:06:29.070 --> 00:06:31.250
that we will continue to cover right here.

106
00:06:31.250 --> 00:06:37.440
So this is your standard which replaced
that enterprise edition, and like I said

107
00:06:37.440 --> 00:06:43.340
you can have your two virtual OSE and
let me clarify what OSE stands for.

108
00:06:43.340 --> 00:06:46.420
OSE stands for
operating system environment.

109
00:06:46.420 --> 00:06:49.720
And you have now,
with the advent of virtualization,

110
00:06:49.720 --> 00:06:55.690
the ability to have a virtual operating
system environment, which is a VOSE or

111
00:06:55.690 --> 00:06:59.634
a physical operating system environment,
which is a POSE.

112
00:06:59.634 --> 00:07:00.592
>> [LAUGH] Well, there you go.
[LAUGH] So

113
00:07:00.592 --> 00:07:04.280
I know, it's such a strange word,
and I don't come up with this stuff.

114
00:07:04.280 --> 00:07:06.810
But that's something that you'll need to

115
00:07:06.810 --> 00:07:10.130
understand those terms if you're trying
to sift to this documentation and

116
00:07:10.130 --> 00:07:15.190
sort out and choose the correct licensing
for your organization, or your needs.

117
00:07:15.190 --> 00:07:18.420
So it's also important to
note that they do restrict,

118
00:07:18.420 --> 00:07:20.890
like I mentioned with
the processors as well.

119
00:07:20.890 --> 00:07:24.340
So with that standard edition,

120
00:07:24.340 --> 00:07:28.320
you get your two VOSEs, you can have
up to two virtual instances there.

121
00:07:28.320 --> 00:07:33.675
And it's really designed for those
highly non virtualized environments and

122
00:07:33.675 --> 00:07:38.710
that's really gonna be the main
difference there between datacenter.

123
00:07:38.710 --> 00:07:42.400
You're not losing out on those features,
so it is important to know that.

124
00:07:42.400 --> 00:07:48.149
But taking a step down, if we take a look,
oops, here at our essentials, all right?

125
00:07:48.149 --> 00:07:52.431
With essentials, you have the ability to
have one operating system environment.

126
00:07:52.431 --> 00:07:55.770
So, this could be physical or
virtual there.

127
00:07:55.770 --> 00:07:59.552
Now for your server, you still can
have up to those two processors.

128
00:07:59.552 --> 00:08:03.180
There is a 25 user limit here.

129
00:08:03.180 --> 00:08:07.640
So that's pretty important to note,
we're not talking large organizations.

130
00:08:07.640 --> 00:08:09.410
So that's definitely
something to consider,

131
00:08:09.410 --> 00:08:13.530
but you can see right here the price
will definitely reflected, as well.

132
00:08:13.530 --> 00:08:17.050
So if you're smaller business,
you wanna have some of those features, but

133
00:08:17.050 --> 00:08:20.670
you don't wanna go ahead or
you can't spend the price tag

134
00:08:20.670 --> 00:08:25.105
that's associated with that Datacenter
Edition and that would be a good solution.

135
00:08:25.105 --> 00:08:29.285
Now, the Foundation Edition is
not always a viable option for

136
00:08:29.285 --> 00:08:33.835
a lot of organizations especially
because you can only have that

137
00:08:33.835 --> 00:08:37.270
Foundation Edition installed
on a physical machine.

138
00:08:37.270 --> 00:08:38.840
And as a matter of fact,

139
00:08:38.840 --> 00:08:43.170
you won't even be the one installing
it when you received that.

140
00:08:43.170 --> 00:08:48.280
What I mean is, it comes by OEM only,
original equipment manufacturer.

141
00:08:48.280 --> 00:08:52.270
So it's usually pre-installed on a system,
on a physical machine.

142
00:08:52.270 --> 00:08:59.360
And you also have a significant
limitation of up to 15 users as well.

143
00:08:59.360 --> 00:09:01.740
So those are some things to consider.

144
00:09:01.740 --> 00:09:06.940
And it's kind of interesting when
you look at this model, just

145
00:09:06.940 --> 00:09:12.454
to know the difference, you may encounter
some type of scenario based question.

146
00:09:12.454 --> 00:09:17.730
And in this PDF that you will have
access to here in the attached files,

147
00:09:17.730 --> 00:09:19.990
you might wanna really just
sift through and look at it.

148
00:09:19.990 --> 00:09:25.940
There's a lot to understand and looking
even at that processor limitation here.

149
00:09:25.940 --> 00:09:28.360
Let me just spend a second
to kind of explain

150
00:09:28.360 --> 00:09:31.920
what I would talk about in a scenario
based type of environment.

151
00:09:31.920 --> 00:09:34.251
So, here you have licensing examples and

152
00:09:34.251 --> 00:09:38.390
they tell you about the One 1-processor
and non-virtualized server.

153
00:09:38.390 --> 00:09:42.820
They're giving you different solutions or
scenarios that you need to understand

154
00:09:42.820 --> 00:09:46.330
which licenses would work best for
that particular scenario.

155
00:09:46.330 --> 00:09:49.110
Down here at the bottom,
let's take a look at this one.

156
00:09:49.110 --> 00:09:55.607
It says, if you have One 2-processor
server with 12 virtual OSEs,

157
00:09:55.607 --> 00:10:00.590
how many datacenter
licenses would be required.

158
00:10:00.590 --> 00:10:04.580
So the big difference here, like I was
trying to point out between datacenter and

159
00:10:04.580 --> 00:10:07.425
standard, would be the number
of virtual machines.

160
00:10:07.425 --> 00:10:10.350
Processor-wise, that part's
going to be the same.

161
00:10:10.350 --> 00:10:15.390
So you'd only need one data center
license for this particular scenario.

162
00:10:15.390 --> 00:10:20.510
However, you would need
six standard licenses for

163
00:10:20.510 --> 00:10:24.015
the same scenario because
you are limited to that two,

164
00:10:24.015 --> 00:10:30.140
two virtual operating system environments
and here they're requesting 12.

165
00:10:30.140 --> 00:10:32.700

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee look at the planning considerations for using Windows Server 2012 R2.  Cherokee reviews some of the different editions: Datacenter, Standard, Essentials and Foundation.  She also provides a scenario to consider when choosing which edition to pick.  Lastly, Cherokee provides us with the different hardware requirements when performing a basic installation of Server 2012 R2.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee look at the planning considerations for using Windows Server 2012 R2.  Cherokee reviews some of the different editions: Datacenter, Standard, Essentials and Foundation.  She also provides a scenario to consider when choosing which edition to pick.  Lastly, Cherokee provides us with the different hardware requirements when performing a basic installation of Server 2012 R2.

That's right.

So we might have to come back for a little

00:29:47.050 --> 00:29:54.298

00:30:01.404 --> 00:30:03.914
>> Thank you for watching It Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee dive into the installation of Server Core 2012 R2.  Cherokee picks up from the previous episode by removing the GUI events to Server 2012 R2 leaving us with Server Core.  She demonstrates the quickness of the installation process when choosing the Server Core type and shows some of the configuration utilities that will help an admin do initial configuration on Server 2012 R2.
episodes.title: Install and Configure Server Core

So, let's see if I can pull up

it is still working at this point in time.

182
00:11:22.670 --> 00:11:27.380
And then we'll also look at a menu-driven
option, which is called sconfig

183
00:11:27.380 --> 00:11:30.690
to configure, which is a little bit
easier than what we're gonna start with.

184
00:11:30.690 --> 00:11:33.510
But I wanted you to know that
there are options out there.

185
00:11:33.510 --> 00:11:36.160
So let's start with netdom.

186
00:11:36.160 --> 00:11:38.870
And one of the things that
we wanna do is change the IP

187
00:11:38.870 --> 00:11:41.210
address of that particular machine.

188
00:11:41.210 --> 00:11:45.560
So I might not know how many adapters
are on this particular machine.

189
00:11:45.560 --> 00:11:51.110
So what we can do is first,
type in Get-NetAdapter.

190
00:11:51.110 --> 00:11:56.019
And this is going to display the different
physical NICs that are installed on

191
00:11:56.019 --> 00:11:57.010
that machine.

192
00:11:57.010 --> 00:11:58.210
And just give it a second here.

193
00:11:58.210 --> 00:12:01.400
And then it'll display that information

194
00:12:01.400 --> 00:12:04.980
that is pertinent to the next
commandlet that I will run.

195
00:12:04.980 --> 00:12:07.570
So it's checking the system,
then it says, hey,

196
00:12:07.570 --> 00:12:11.108
look, I found an Ethernet adapter here.

197
00:12:11.108 --> 00:12:16.330
Now, my ifIndex here is going to be 12 and
that's really what I was looking for

198
00:12:16.330 --> 00:12:21.200
because I'm using that numerical
numbering, that name, to go ahead and

199
00:12:21.200 --> 00:12:23.800
input it into my next command.

200
00:12:23.800 --> 00:12:31.750
So what I want to type
is New-NetIPAddress,

201
00:12:31.750 --> 00:12:36.120
and here we're just creating
our static IP address here.

202
00:12:36.120 --> 00:12:38.260
I do need to specify that interface.

203
00:12:38.260 --> 00:12:41.040
So we'll say interface index.

204
00:12:41.040 --> 00:12:44.560
And this is where we'll put that 12.

205
00:12:44.560 --> 00:12:48.170
And then I need to choose an IP address.

206
00:12:48.170 --> 00:12:53.450
So if I just stick with
my naming convention.

207
00:12:53.450 --> 00:12:54.960
Oops, sorry, hold on.

208
00:12:56.510 --> 00:12:57.170
Had a typo there.

209
00:12:57.170 --> 00:13:03.870
Okay, so 10.1.0, and we'll just say,
.23 and let's say I chose that IP address.

210
00:13:03.870 --> 00:13:08.516
And then I'll need to specify my prefix
length which is just going to be my

211
00:13:08.516 --> 00:13:09.744
subnet mask here.

212
00:13:09.744 --> 00:13:15.162
So my prefix length is
going to be slash 24,

213
00:13:15.162 --> 00:13:19.303
so I'm just going to type in 24.

214
00:13:19.303 --> 00:13:23.458
And if you recall, we didn't set
a default gateway for this demo, but

215
00:13:23.458 --> 00:13:26.768
you do have the option to set
a default gateway here, and

216
00:13:26.768 --> 00:13:30.370
then that would just be
followed with the numerical IP.

217
00:13:30.370 --> 00:13:32.810
We'll hit Enter and give it a second.

218
00:13:32.810 --> 00:13:37.880
And now it'll automatically show our
information here, our network information.

219
00:13:37.880 --> 00:13:42.380
We can see that our IP address
is now set at 10.1.0.23.

220
00:13:42.380 --> 00:13:44.130
So that's pretty cool,

221
00:13:44.130 --> 00:13:49.560
I didn't need to utilize the graphical
interface to go ahead and set that.

222
00:13:49.560 --> 00:13:54.380
That's not the only option, I just
wanted to show you that particular tool.

223
00:13:54.380 --> 00:13:58.750
But let's go ahead and think about what
else we might want to do on this machine.

224
00:13:58.750 --> 00:14:01.620
Let me just clear this real quick so
we get a fresh start.

225
00:14:01.620 --> 00:14:04.750
But one of the initial configurations,
like we joined that

226
00:14:04.750 --> 00:14:09.650
other machine to a domain, we can also
do that here with a different tool.

227
00:14:09.650 --> 00:14:11.422
It's called your netdom tool.

228
00:14:11.422 --> 00:14:14.750
So netdom is one way to
go about doing this.

229
00:14:14.750 --> 00:14:17.430
It's a little bit of typing involved but
that's okay,

230
00:14:17.430 --> 00:14:20.090
you guys get the luxury
of watching me type here.

231
00:14:20.090 --> 00:14:24.330
So if we go ahead and do an ipconfig/all,

232
00:14:24.330 --> 00:14:28.860
what I'm doing is just getting
the current Windows assigned name, so

233
00:14:28.860 --> 00:14:32.230
that I can copy and paste this here,
make it a little bit easy.

234
00:14:33.370 --> 00:14:38.100
So, it's actually, we'll hit mark, and
then highlight it, and then go back here

235
00:14:38.100 --> 00:14:43.170
to our edit, and then copy, and
just hold on to that information.

236
00:14:43.170 --> 00:14:46.580
We're gonna plug it into
our netdom command here.

237
00:14:46.580 --> 00:14:49.700
So we've got netdom and
then it's renamed computer.

238
00:14:51.270 --> 00:14:54.450
And here I'm going to go ahead and
paste that.

239
00:14:54.450 --> 00:14:57.525
So just go up here, edit, paste.

240
00:14:57.525 --> 00:15:01.650
And the name of that machine,
the new name,

241
00:15:01.650 --> 00:15:06.632
we want to specify that, so we go ahead
and put forward /NewName, and we can say,

242
00:15:06.632 --> 00:15:13.040
svr01core to let us remember
that this is that core instance.

243
00:15:13.040 --> 00:15:14.080
And I think that's it.

244
00:15:14.080 --> 00:15:15.380
We'll go ahead and hit Enter.

245
00:15:15.380 --> 00:15:18.360
And it gives us a notification saying,
hey,

246
00:15:18.360 --> 00:15:21.310
you're going to be changing
the name of this computer.

247
00:15:21.310 --> 00:15:26.760
It could disrupt services if it relies
on that association with that name,

248
00:15:26.760 --> 00:15:28.400
so especially domain controllers.

249
00:15:28.400 --> 00:15:31.300
You don't want to be changing their
names once you go ahead and set that up.

250
00:15:31.300 --> 00:15:32.810
Do you want to proceed?

251
00:15:32.810 --> 00:15:34.360
We'll hit yes and Enter.

252
00:15:34.360 --> 00:15:37.589
Now, it says that we need to go ahead and
restart.

253
00:15:37.589 --> 00:15:42.631
>> All right, so, Cherokee, we can use
that netdom command but it seems like

254
00:15:42.631 --> 00:15:47.448
a fairly kind of complex type of commands
that you have to be able to use.

255
00:15:47.448 --> 00:15:49.705
But you did mention that there was
something easier that we could use.

256
00:15:49.705 --> 00:15:52.595
>> Yes, so, Ronnie,
let's take a look at my screen and

257
00:15:52.595 --> 00:15:54.732
I'll introduce the Sconfig utility.

258
00:15:54.732 --> 00:16:00.413
So if I simply type Sconfig,
C-O-N F-I-G, hit Enter.

259
00:16:00.413 --> 00:16:03.624
We're now looking at
a menu-driven interface.

260
00:16:03.624 --> 00:16:06.630
I have a couple of numerical options for
us.

261
00:16:06.630 --> 00:16:10.565
And we've already changed
the name of this machine,

262
00:16:10.565 --> 00:16:14.210
which is reflected here as SVR 01 core.

263
00:16:14.210 --> 00:16:16.389
But we haven't yet joined it to a domain.

264
00:16:16.389 --> 00:16:21.282
There are some important networking
configurations that we need to specify in

265
00:16:21.282 --> 00:16:26.114
order for this machine to be able to
communicate with our domain controller.

266
00:16:26.114 --> 00:16:29.425
And that's going to be relying on DNS.

267
00:16:29.425 --> 00:16:34.373
So we do need to specify our DNS server
here, so just looking at this menu

268
00:16:34.373 --> 00:16:38.590
you might look at this and
say hey, where's our DNS option?

269
00:16:38.590 --> 00:16:42.430
Well, it's hidden a little bit and it's
going to be under your network settings.

270
00:16:42.430 --> 00:16:46.520
Because we've already changed the IP
address, you could go in here to 8 and

271
00:16:46.520 --> 00:16:47.850
change that as well.

272
00:16:47.850 --> 00:16:50.586
So I'm just gonna go ahead and
type in 8 and

273
00:16:50.586 --> 00:16:53.482
then use my little scroll
bar to scroll down.

274
00:16:53.482 --> 00:16:56.174
And here you can see that adapter and

275
00:16:56.174 --> 00:17:01.360
the index number here is going to be 10 so
we'll just type in 10.

276
00:17:01.360 --> 00:17:08.896
You hit Enter and now you can go ahead and
specify the DNS server here.

277
00:17:08.896 --> 00:17:11.250
So currently, let's see what we've got.

278
00:17:11.250 --> 00:17:13.710
We've got our IP address that we've set,

279
00:17:13.710 --> 00:17:18.800
we have our subnet mask, and
preferred DNS is not set.

280
00:17:18.800 --> 00:17:20.614
So let's see, set network after address.

281
00:17:20.614 --> 00:17:26.456
Number 2 is set DNS server, so what we
do is type 2 in here and hit Enter.

282
00:17:26.456 --> 00:17:31.564
Now I kinda have to remember the IP
address of my DNS server here.

283
00:17:31.564 --> 00:17:35.118
I wanna say,
enter new prefered DNS server.

284
00:17:35.118 --> 00:17:41.892
So yes, and I wanna say it was 10.1.0.10,
could be wrong.

285
00:17:41.892 --> 00:17:46.827
But here you do see some of those
remnants of the graphical user interface.

286
00:17:46.827 --> 00:17:49.080
We'll hit OK.

287
00:17:49.080 --> 00:17:55.060
And if I had an alternate DNS server,
I would go ahead and provide that as well.

288
00:17:55.060 --> 00:17:59.784
If I wanted to go back to the main menu, I
would go ahead and select 4 and hit Enter.

289
00:17:59.784 --> 00:18:03.100
The DNS server could not be set.

290
00:18:03.100 --> 00:18:05.752
Let me just check my notes real quick,
I think-

291
00:18:05.752 --> 00:18:06.750
>> It went back to the menu.

292
00:18:06.750 --> 00:18:08.978
It just said you need to do none
if you didn't have an alternate.

293
00:18:08.978 --> 00:18:10.198
>> For the alternate there, that's fine.

294
00:18:10.198 --> 00:18:13.112
I only have one set up in
this environment anyways.

295
00:18:13.112 --> 00:18:16.398
So let's go back to 4 to my main menu.

296
00:18:16.398 --> 00:18:17.536
Did I select that?

297
00:18:17.536 --> 00:18:20.410
Now there are a lot of other things
that we could configure here.

298
00:18:20.410 --> 00:18:22.710
We could,
like we had joined the domain before,

299
00:18:22.710 --> 00:18:25.030
you could do that right
within this interface.

300
00:18:25.030 --> 00:18:28.786
It is important to know what you can and
cannot do within this interface.

301
00:18:28.786 --> 00:18:32.641
So if I were you, I would take some
time getting acclimated with this tool.

302
00:18:32.641 --> 00:18:35.637
You may see this type
of information again.

303
00:18:35.637 --> 00:18:38.843
You could go ahead and log off,
I'm trying to think what else is cool.

304
00:18:38.843 --> 00:18:41.982
Like we had set the times in and
everything before,

305
00:18:41.982 --> 00:18:43.811
this is kind of interesting.

306
00:18:43.811 --> 00:18:47.838
If you do hit number 9 here and
hit Enter to set that time zone,

307
00:18:47.838 --> 00:18:53.192
you have again little remnants of that GUI
and I think even some of these concepts.

308
00:18:53.192 --> 00:18:57.713
They're not fully functional
because you don't have

309
00:18:57.713 --> 00:19:00.569
the ability to go ahead and set it.

310
00:19:00.569 --> 00:19:03.414
But here you can use
the graphical components.

311
00:19:03.414 --> 00:19:11.508
But let's see here, just hit Cancel and,
We have our computer name.

312
00:19:11.508 --> 00:19:14.283
I'm trying to think if there's
anything else really important here.

313
00:19:14.283 --> 00:19:17.905
I would just go ahead and
play again with your network setting.

314
00:19:17.905 --> 00:19:21.918
That's probably going to be the most
important component, because you wanna set

315
00:19:21.918 --> 00:19:25.828
your IP address, your subnet mask,
your default gateway, your DNS servers.

316
00:19:25.828 --> 00:19:30.451
And then you're able to do everything that
we were able to do within the GUI there to

317
00:19:30.451 --> 00:19:32.997
go ahead and
get this server up and running and

318
00:19:32.997 --> 00:19:37.960
get it prepared to run whatever role it is
that you have planned for this machine.

319
00:19:37.960 --> 00:19:40.410
And I think that's about it for
this show, Ronnie.

320
00:19:40.410 --> 00:19:41.500
We've covered quite a bit.

321
00:19:41.500 --> 00:19:43.030
So I think we're good there.

322
00:19:43.030 --> 00:19:43.890
>> All right, Cherokee.

323
00:19:43.890 --> 00:19:48.190
Well, thank you again for
helping us get started in installing,

324
00:19:48.190 --> 00:19:52.036
of course,
the Server 2012 R2 Server Core edition.

325
00:19:52.036 --> 00:19:55.822
Remember that this is gonna be the default
install that when you first put in your

326
00:19:55.822 --> 00:19:58.887
source files that's the one it's
gonna naturally default to.

327
00:19:58.887 --> 00:20:01.987
So if you're a habitual somebody
like I am, you just click, click,

328
00:20:01.987 --> 00:20:03.276
click through everything.

329
00:20:03.276 --> 00:20:03.996
You get click happy.

330
00:20:03.996 --> 00:20:06.340
You're gonna end up
installing the Server Core.

331
00:20:06.340 --> 00:20:08.386
It shouldn't frighten you.

332
00:20:08.386 --> 00:20:12.362
You should be able now to have the at
least, some of the tools that you can use

333
00:20:12.362 --> 00:20:16.640
to do some basic configuration and
keep it that way, if you choose to.

334
00:20:16.640 --> 00:20:21.250
But also, Cherokee helped us out by
reminding us that, if we wanted to,

335
00:20:21.250 --> 00:20:25.515
we could also switch back and
add in that GUI as well.

336
00:20:25.515 --> 00:20:28.548
But if you're gonna do that, you also
need access to the source files as well.

337
00:20:28.548 --> 00:20:32.499
So just like what we saw in the server
GUI edition and where we could or server

338
00:20:32.499 --> 00:20:36.781
GUI interface, where we could actually do
that, we can also do it the other way.

339
00:20:36.781 --> 00:20:38.859
So we can flip backward and
forward with that.

340
00:20:38.859 --> 00:20:40.241
All right, Cherokee, any last words?

341
00:20:40.241 --> 00:20:44.036
>> Yeah, so Ronnie, in addition to
the options that we did see in this show,

342
00:20:44.036 --> 00:20:47.589
I just wanna remind you guys that
even if you are running Server Core,

343
00:20:47.589 --> 00:20:50.118
you're not completely
abandoned with the GUI.

344
00:20:50.118 --> 00:20:53.824
Because you do have the option for
remote administration so

345
00:20:53.824 --> 00:20:58.492
you could from another machine be using
Server Manager as well as your MMC or

346
00:20:58.492 --> 00:21:00.732
Snap-ins from another computer.

347
00:21:00.732 --> 00:21:05.260
So you'll have those graphical tools even
if you choose to install Server Core for

348
00:21:05.260 --> 00:21:07.107
the actual production machine.

349
00:21:07.107 --> 00:21:08.848
Just keep that in mind as well.

350
00:21:08.848 --> 00:21:11.475
>> And believe or not,
that's gonna be a great way for

351
00:21:11.475 --> 00:21:15.387
you to learn more about Server is doing
that because inside of Microsoft as of

352
00:21:15.387 --> 00:21:17.649
the recording of this particular episode,

353
00:21:17.649 --> 00:21:21.900
you're gonna see a big push towards
that remote server administration.

354
00:21:21.900 --> 00:21:23.933
So get used to actually seeing it as well.

355
00:21:23.933 --> 00:21:26.557
All right, well, that's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

356
00:21:26.557 --> 00:21:30.412
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

357
00:21:30.412 --> 00:21:31.328
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

358
00:21:31.328 --> 00:21:36.518
>> Stay tuned right here for
more MCSA 70-410 shows.

359
00:21:36.518 --> 00:21:42.463
[MUSIC]

360
00:21:42.463 --> 00:21:45.424
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee discuss and show installing roles and features to make Windows Server 2012 R2 more fit for purpose.  Cherokee shows the standard way of installing a feature using the wizard driven system.  She also demonstrates installing a role using powershell.  Once complete she verifies the installation succeeded.
episodes.title: Features and Roles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.489
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.489 --> 00:00:06.413
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.413 --> 00:00:08.277
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.277 --> 00:00:12.209
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.209 --> 00:00:15.090
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:15.090 --> 00:00:20.185
You're watching the MCSA for
Windows Server 12 R2, for exam

7
00:00:20.185 --> 00:00:24.950
70-410, now that's a mouthful, but that is
practically what we are covering today.

8
00:00:24.950 --> 00:00:27.740
Now we're diving into roles and features,

9
00:00:27.740 --> 00:00:30.550
and here to help us out today is
going to be Ms. Cherokee Boose.

10
00:00:30.550 --> 00:00:31.710
Cherokee, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:31.710 --> 00:00:33.690
>> Thanks for having me Ronnie,
how are you today?

12
00:00:33.690 --> 00:00:38.140
>> I'm doing well now, Cherokee,
as we get started, just go ahead and

13
00:00:38.140 --> 00:00:43.150
remind us a little bit of what we had just
recently covered in our previous episode.

14
00:00:43.150 --> 00:00:46.330
And then, let's talk about the roles and
features as we get to it.

15
00:00:46.330 --> 00:00:51.700
>> Sure, so Ronnie, in the last show we
really wrapped up talking about Sconfig or

16
00:00:51.700 --> 00:00:55.170
server configuration,
that menu driven utility.

17
00:00:55.170 --> 00:00:59.860
And we were really looking at the benefits
as to why one would want to use a core

18
00:00:59.860 --> 00:01:05.480
installation versus a graphical user
interface install, and we talked about,

19
00:01:05.480 --> 00:01:10.560
the reduced footprint, security issues,
maximizing our hardware.

20
00:01:10.560 --> 00:01:14.050
But, remember that
because we are forfeiting

21
00:01:14.050 --> 00:01:17.550
some of those features to
obtain some of those benefits.

22
00:01:17.550 --> 00:01:20.330
So when we're talking about our roles and
features,

23
00:01:20.330 --> 00:01:25.210
we do see a limited amount when we're
talking about that core installation.

24
00:01:25.210 --> 00:01:29.450
And this show is really gonna be featuring
focused on those roles and features and

25
00:01:29.450 --> 00:01:31.830
how we can use them and manage them.

26
00:01:31.830 --> 00:01:35.356
If we can take a look at my screen, I'd
like to show you some of the differences

27
00:01:35.356 --> 00:01:37.494
here and
you can screenshot these if you want.

28
00:01:37.494 --> 00:01:40.434
But just knowing and
being aware the fact that,

29
00:01:40.434 --> 00:01:45.359
hey, when I'm talking about the roles
that are available in Server Core versus

30
00:01:45.359 --> 00:01:48.889
the roles that are unavailable,
just be aware of those so

31
00:01:48.889 --> 00:01:53.671
that as you're planning and continuing
to plan throughout your environment

32
00:01:53.671 --> 00:01:57.450
you don’t get kind of blindsided
by any of these ideas here.

33
00:01:57.450 --> 00:02:00.930
So, that's just something
to consider there,

34
00:02:00.930 --> 00:02:05.685
but one of the really cool
things about Microsoft, and

35
00:02:05.685 --> 00:02:10.385
they have this concept,
this notion called features on demand.

36
00:02:10.385 --> 00:02:16.235
And it goes with that same ideology
like utilizing the core installed.

37
00:02:16.235 --> 00:02:20.270
They're saying hey, and you think back
like principle of least privilege, right?

38
00:02:20.270 --> 00:02:24.430
Or I'm only gonna be using what's
necessary to perform my job function.

39
00:02:24.430 --> 00:02:28.700
So why should I have all this extra
code and all this extra script here, and

40
00:02:28.700 --> 00:02:30.730
this interface if I'm not using it?

41
00:02:30.730 --> 00:02:35.160
So with features on demand we really
have the ability to selectively pick and

42
00:02:35.160 --> 00:02:39.300
choose what we want installed
on that operating system.

43
00:02:39.300 --> 00:02:45.370

00:17:37.293 --> 00:17:42.242
oops, if I spelled get right

00:19:33.911 --> 00:19:34.750

00:20:01.581 --> 00:20:06.402

but it's IncludeAllSubFeature-

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee dive into using powershell for remote installation of roles and features.  Cherokee demonstrates how get a server role installed to another domain joined computer.  She also discusses with Ronnie some of the key elements and benefits of migrating server roles.  This includes when to use them, any major considerations and when it wouldn’t help to do so.
episodes.title: Features and Roles Part 2

00:21:37.917 --> 00:21:42.390
let me downgrade this I don't need as
many licenses for this particular server.

334
00:21:42.390 --> 00:21:47.508
Well then, that's when migration is going
to be the best solution for us there.

335
00:21:47.508 --> 00:21:51.997
>> All right, Cherokee, In terms of this
idea of migrating these, any gotchas,

336
00:21:51.997 --> 00:21:54.283
any concerns that we should be aware of?

337
00:21:54.283 --> 00:21:59.573
>> Yeah, great observation there Ronnie
because we do need to be aware that

338
00:21:59.573 --> 00:22:06.264
the actual, the server migration tool does
utilize TCP and UTP ports 7000 by default.

339
00:22:06.264 --> 00:22:11.045
So if you're having any problems with
the steps that Microsoft has provided then

340
00:22:11.045 --> 00:22:14.010
you might want and
check your Firewall settings.

341
00:22:14.010 --> 00:22:16.960
Because like I said, these steps
have worked for a lot of people and

342
00:22:16.960 --> 00:22:19.980
I'm not saying that, you know,
every environment is different.

343
00:22:19.980 --> 00:22:23.063
But that's definitely one of
the main things to check if for

344
00:22:23.063 --> 00:22:27.329
any kind of troubleshooting there, but
otherwise, yes there are workarounds.

345
00:22:27.329 --> 00:22:29.777
But stick to, at least for now,

346
00:22:29.777 --> 00:22:35.041
stick to the Microsoft methodology
here and what else is nice because

347
00:22:35.041 --> 00:22:40.440
like I showed you right there on
TechNet they have those steps.

348
00:22:40.440 --> 00:22:45.154
You can also delegate rather easily, so
maybe like a junior technician can follow

349
00:22:45.154 --> 00:22:49.867
those steps and be able to go ahead and
perform that function while you're working

350
00:22:49.867 --> 00:22:52.616
on another project,
which is really cool too.

351
00:22:52.616 --> 00:22:53.797
>> All right Cherokee,

352
00:22:53.797 --> 00:22:57.798
we were actually in the middle when
we started talking about migration,

353
00:22:57.798 --> 00:23:02.471
you were just finishing up something, do
you wanna verify that everything is good?

354
00:23:02.471 --> 00:23:06.167
>> Yeah, so I actually kind of typed
something on that PowerShell screen,

355
00:23:06.167 --> 00:23:10.002
so what we can do here to verify that
that worked, and to check our work now.

356
00:23:10.002 --> 00:23:16.010
Remember we were trying to remove all of
those available feat rules and features.

357
00:23:16.010 --> 00:23:19.728
So, what we can do now,
like we did at the beginning

358
00:23:19.728 --> 00:23:23.889
of the show is we'll just
type in get/windowsfeature.

359
00:23:23.889 --> 00:23:28.202
And at this point in time,
it will list everything here but

360
00:23:28.202 --> 00:23:33.610
note that the status in that right
column here they're saying removed.

361
00:23:33.610 --> 00:23:36.240
So there's nothing that
should say available.

362
00:23:36.240 --> 00:23:39.740
Because remember when we piped out
that information, we were looking for

363
00:23:39.740 --> 00:23:42.458
that term available to remove
it to change it to removed.

364
00:23:42.458 --> 00:23:46.323
So the only two options
should be installed or

365
00:23:46.323 --> 00:23:50.020
remove in that far right hand column here.

366
00:23:50.020 --> 00:23:52.540
And I mean if we scroll through the list,

367
00:23:52.540 --> 00:23:54.680
you'll see that that's
actually what happens.

368
00:23:54.680 --> 00:23:56.380
So that's pretty cool right there.

369
00:23:56.380 --> 00:24:01.077
Now you could go back and use that DISM
tool from the that was the very first

370
00:24:01.077 --> 00:24:03.476
command that I typed into this show.

371
00:24:03.476 --> 00:24:05.673
If you, really wanted to check and see,

372
00:24:05.673 --> 00:24:09.945
well how much storage did we actually
save by going through and doing all that.

373
00:24:09.945 --> 00:24:13.473
So that would be one way to check
your work there as well but

374
00:24:13.473 --> 00:24:17.306
I think that's about it for
roles and features for this show.

375
00:24:17.306 --> 00:24:19.077
You're gonna be working with Roles and

376
00:24:19.077 --> 00:24:22.030
Features throughout the duration
of this series anyways.

377
00:24:22.030 --> 00:24:27.820
That's kind of the whole focus
of Server 2012 and 2012 R2.

378
00:24:27.820 --> 00:24:31.567
But I think that's a good place
to go ahead and get started with.

379
00:24:31.567 --> 00:24:32.570
>> All right, Cherokee.

380
00:24:32.570 --> 00:24:33.380
Thank you again for

381
00:24:33.380 --> 00:24:37.200
helping us to understand a little bit more
about installing Roles and Features as

382
00:24:37.200 --> 00:24:41.730
well as uninstalling them talking a little
bit about migration here as well.

383
00:24:41.730 --> 00:24:45.270
Being able to do it not only in the GUI
which is actually good in terms of

384
00:24:45.270 --> 00:24:46.980
the installation and removal.

385
00:24:46.980 --> 00:24:50.100
But also of course in the PowerShell
something that we're all gonna need to

386
00:24:50.100 --> 00:24:51.090
get used to.

387
00:24:51.090 --> 00:24:52.390
So don't run away from it and

388
00:24:52.390 --> 00:24:55.480
you'll probably see issues

389
00:24:55.480 --> 00:24:56.520
So pay attention.

390
00:24:56.520 --> 00:24:58.260
Make sure you go back

00:24:58.260 --> 00:25:03.710
Maybe even a couple of times as you start

392
00:25:03.710 --> 00:25:06.300
But that's a great place for

Signing off for ITPro.TV,

episodes.title: Additional Installation Configurations
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.999
Welcome to ITPro TV, I'm your host,

00:00:10.430 --> 00:00:14.215
episode right here on ITPro TV.

5
00:00:14.215 --> 00:00:18.640
You're watching the MCSA for
Windows Server 2012 R2,

6
00:00:18.640 --> 00:00:23.770
specifically for exam 70-410,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:23.770 --> 00:00:28.395
And today we're also gonna be diving into
the topic of additional installation

00:00:28.395 --> 00:00:29.510
configurations.

00:00:29.510 --> 00:00:32.430
And here to help us out is

>> Thanks for having me, Ronnie.

11
00:00:34.850 --> 00:00:35.680
You sounded so

12
00:00:35.680 --> 00:00:40.780
excited about our extra additional
installation configurations here.

13
00:00:40.780 --> 00:00:44.142
And I know it's crazy, it seems like
we've been talking about installation and

14
00:00:44.142 --> 00:00:45.880
configurations for a while now, right?

15
00:00:45.880 --> 00:00:50.248
But the truth of the matter is most
system admins are not performing

16
00:00:50.248 --> 00:00:54.850
installations every single day, so
that is something to consider but

17
00:00:54.850 --> 00:01:00.154
because most of you are prepping for an
exam here, it is important to know those,

18
00:01:00.154 --> 00:01:05.905
because they're specifically called out
by Microsoft on those exam objectives.

19
00:01:05.905 --> 00:01:08.805
So I don't wanna skip over any of these.

20
00:01:08.805 --> 00:01:11.415
One that I really would like
to focus on today, Ronnie,

21
00:01:11.415 --> 00:01:14.110
is going to be something
called the DISM tool.

22
00:01:14.110 --> 00:01:19.140
DISM is what we're gonna be looking
here and it's part of a tool kit.

23
00:01:19.140 --> 00:01:23.746
It used to be called AIK but
the new name here is going to be

24
00:01:23.746 --> 00:01:28.161
Windows Assessment and

25

And this particular tool that
we'll look at allows us to modify

00:01:33.090 --> 00:01:35.610
images that are offline.

And previously, there was a tool available

00:01:40.522 --> 00:01:45.630
With the advent of Server 2012,
Image X has been deprecated,

29
00:01:45.630 --> 00:01:49.600
meaning that's not the tool that
Microsoft recommends to use anymore.

30
00:01:49.600 --> 00:01:53.853
They want you to be using the DISM

31
00:01:53.853 --> 00:01:57.832
Now, adding and removing features is
not the only thing you can do with

32
00:01:57.832 --> 00:02:02.284
the DISM tool, but because it's
specifically called out by the objectives,

33
00:02:02.284 --> 00:02:06.214
that's what we'll be taking a look at for

34
00:02:06.214 --> 00:02:07.732
>> All right so, Cherokee,

35
00:02:07.732 --> 00:02:12.286
when we start working with this idea of
DISM, we wanna begin to make sure that we

00:02:12.286 --> 00:02:16.150
understand where we launch it from,
and how do we get access to it?

37
00:02:16.150 --> 00:02:21.230
I don't remember actually seeing it very
often as far as the GUI interface, so

38
00:02:21.230 --> 00:02:23.620
how do I get to it?
>> Okay, so

39
00:02:23.620 --> 00:02:28.130
let me just log in to this machine

00:02:28.130 --> 00:02:30.730
give you a little bit of background
history of what I did on this system.

41
00:02:35.590 --> 00:02:36.750
Let me delete this feature list,

42
00:02:36.750 --> 00:02:39.650
this is something we'll be
generating in a few moments.

43
00:02:39.650 --> 00:02:44.800
I placed a folder called offline
right here on the root of my C drive.

44
00:02:44.800 --> 00:02:49.190
This folder will be utilized as
just a temporary placeholder for

45
00:02:49.190 --> 00:02:52.110
us to mount our particular image.

46
00:02:52.110 --> 00:02:57.080
I extracted this .win file from
an ISO that I had downloaded

00:02:57.080 --> 00:03:01.350
from Microsoft's site and placed them
under my C drive just for easy access.

48
00:03:01.350 --> 00:03:04.990
This probably isn't where you'd wanna be

00:03:04.990 --> 00:03:09.940
less typing for me means less

00:03:09.940 --> 00:03:12.200
So that's why I chose to do that.

51
00:03:12.200 --> 00:03:16.870
Now, where I'm gonna be really

00:03:16.870 --> 00:03:19.530
You can also use the command prompt here.

Actually, a lot of people, just by habit,

00:03:23.860 --> 00:03:26.450

they will be using the command prompt.

00:03:26.450 --> 00:03:29.940
But the more that we're interacting in
PowerShell, I'm just gonna go ahead and

00:03:29.940 --> 00:03:31.760
run this tool straight

57
00:03:32.770 --> 00:03:37.490
Now, the first thing I want to

And this is going to be something that

Because essentially I'm invoking

Now, we'll type in DISM /Get-ImageInfo.

And, the reason I'm doing this

I showed you may actually contain

before I go through all my work and

00:04:10.520 --> 00:04:15.670
So I need to specify the path here,

00:04:15.670 --> 00:04:18.580
my location, that's just going to be

00:04:18.580 --> 00:04:28.150
imagefile:c:\install the name

so that is why I am typing this here,

00:04:33.360 --> 00:04:37.030
As you can see I have more than one

00:04:38.220 --> 00:04:40.410
Actually I have four listed here.

00:04:40.410 --> 00:04:43.330
I have my standard edition

00:04:43.330 --> 00:04:47.810
I have a standard core option,

00:04:47.810 --> 00:04:52.090
center edition as well as the server
data center core edition.

75
00:04:52.090 --> 00:04:56.410
So I really need to make sure I'm
looking at our particular name here.

76
00:04:56.410 --> 00:05:01.930
So name Windows server 2012
R2 Standard is what l need to specify,

77
00:05:01.930 --> 00:05:06.310
but let me just clear the screen, there is
a lot of typing with this particular tool,

78
00:05:06.310 --> 00:05:09.570
it's a command line tool so
l wanna keep things clean for us.

79
00:05:11.250 --> 00:05:16.850
Okay, so next l need to mount this image,
so what does mounting even mean, Ronnie?

80
00:05:16.850 --> 00:05:20.400
Well, I don't have to put this
image in a virtual machine and

00:05:20.400 --> 00:05:24.480
spin up that virtual machine to add and
remove features, or roles,

82
00:05:24.480 --> 00:05:27.310
or any other changes that I may want to.

83
00:05:27.310 --> 00:05:31.360
What this system is doing is allowing
me to really use that place holder,

84
00:05:31.360 --> 00:05:37.230
that offline folder, to serve as a service
point to mount those individual files.

85
00:05:37.230 --> 00:05:40.480
So the operating system has a way
to really get in that back door and

86
00:05:40.480 --> 00:05:43.280
manipulate this operating system,

87
00:05:43.280 --> 00:05:48.710
my offline image, and allows me to do so

88
00:05:48.710 --> 00:05:51.120
So that's great for
production environments,

89
00:05:51.120 --> 00:05:53.590
because maybe I am using this image, and

90
00:05:53.590 --> 00:05:57.340
it's not something that I really wanna

91
00:05:57.340 --> 00:06:02.780
A lot of times you will be using this

00:06:02.780 --> 00:06:04.410
the system centering utilities,

00:06:04.410 --> 00:06:08.620
so it's a really nice tool to

00:06:08.620 --> 00:06:13.395
And you'll learn about those a little

00:06:13.395 --> 00:06:17.768
if you continue to really focus in on

96
00:06:17.768 --> 00:06:21.898
All right, so to go ahead and mount this,

00:06:21.898 --> 00:06:26.146
let's take a look here

we'll just type in DISM /mount,

00:06:29.568 --> 00:06:35.050
and then here we'll type in -Image /Image.

100
00:06:35.050 --> 00:06:40.541
And we need to specify
the image file location,

101
00:06:40.541 --> 00:06:47.830
so ImageFile:C:\Install.wim,
same as before space /.

102
00:06:47.830 --> 00:06:53.335
Now that we know the name, we can type
a name, Colon, now because our name had

00:06:53.335 --> 00:06:59.280
spaces in it, we need to use quotation

104
00:06:59.280 --> 00:07:06.364
So let's type in,
"windows Server", All right,

105
00:07:06.364 --> 00:07:11.620
and that is going to be 2012.

106
00:07:11.620 --> 00:07:13.712
My Num locks wasn't on, R2.

107
00:07:13.712 --> 00:07:17.720
Now, we're not finished yet.

108
00:07:17.720 --> 00:07:22.174
They had server standard was also,
S-T-A-N-A-R-D,

109
00:07:22.174 --> 00:07:26.100
I just want to make sure they
have it typed right here,

110
00:07:26.100 --> 00:07:29.970
otherwise it's going to be problems for
us.

111
00:07:29.970 --> 00:07:32.540
The spelling really does matter.

112
00:07:32.540 --> 00:07:37.160
We're gonna type in / and then we
need to specify that mount directory.

113
00:07:37.160 --> 00:07:41.680
So mountDir and this is just
straight there on our C Drive.

114
00:07:41.680 --> 00:07:46.269
So I'm gonna put, again, my :C:\offline.

115
00:07:46.269 --> 00:07:50.880
Now this is that offline
folder that I had showed you.

116
00:07:50.880 --> 00:07:52.640
I'm just going to hit Enter.

117
00:07:52.640 --> 00:07:57.301
And I have some form of, that error 87
is a generic error that tells me look,

118
00:07:57.301 --> 00:07:59.905
Cherokee, you probably have a typo here.

119
00:07:59.905 --> 00:08:02.412
So let me just check my syntax real quick.

120
00:08:02.412 --> 00:08:08.490
This is going to be Dism /Mount-Image

121
00:08:08.490 --> 00:08:16.227
/ImageFile:C:\install.wim /Name:",

122
00:08:16.227 --> 00:08:20.470
did I put an end quotation?

123
00:08:22.240 --> 00:08:27.578
Let's see.
Let me hit my up arrow on my over,

00:08:27.578 --> 00:08:29.070
To check.

125
00:08:30.480 --> 00:08:32.092
I did put it in quotation, okay.

126
00:08:32.092 --> 00:08:36.010
Space /,
I might not have the space right here.

127
00:08:36.010 --> 00:08:38.900
It's hard to tell, but
that really will make a difference.

128
00:08:38.900 --> 00:08:43.750
So let me try that,
that's what it looks like, and hit Enter.

129
00:08:43.750 --> 00:08:45.078
All right, and that's what it was.

130
00:08:45.078 --> 00:08:46.027
[LAUGH]
>> Space.

131
00:08:46.027 --> 00:08:48.230
>> Space, yeah for spaces.

132
00:08:48.230 --> 00:08:53.538
So just give it a second here, it's going
to be mounting that particular image.

133
00:08:53.538 --> 00:08:54.295
>> All right, so

134
00:08:54.295 --> 00:08:58.270
Cherokee as it's mounting, what are we
actually hoping to end up seeing as

135
00:08:58.270 --> 00:09:03.279
a result here, once it's mounted.
>> So whenever this particular image is

136
00:09:03.279 --> 00:09:08.251
mounted, this is going to put in
a state from E2 for us to modify it.

137
00:09:08.251 --> 00:09:11.729
And it's going to remain in that state
until I explicitly tell the operating

138
00:09:11.729 --> 00:09:13.210
system, hey, I'm finished.

139
00:09:13.210 --> 00:09:19.089
At that point in time, I will need to make
that administrative decision to keep and

140
00:09:19.089 --> 00:09:21.890
retain the changes that I have made.

141
00:09:21.890 --> 00:09:27.596
Or if I feel like they were made in error,
then I may wanna discard those changes and

142
00:09:27.596 --> 00:09:32.080
unmount the particular, ISO and
then remounted to fix things.

143
00:09:32.080 --> 00:09:33.880
So that's the option there.

144
00:09:33.880 --> 00:09:37.323
It's not anything that's going
to be happening in real time.

145
00:09:37.323 --> 00:09:42.016
It's just kind of in this strange
little uncommitted relationship

146
00:09:42.016 --> 00:09:45.380
until we verify that.
>> Yeah, there is no doubt Cherokee right

147
00:09:45.380 --> 00:09:48.746
here and when we start to see that
mounting process and we were prior ending

148
00:09:48.746 --> 00:09:52.770
up seeing here, this is the first time
you've kind of looked at this, right?

149
00:09:52.770 --> 00:09:57.131
Is that we're taking whatever was in that
WIN file underneath that server standard

150
00:09:57.131 --> 00:09:58.760
that Cherokee typed in there.

151
00:09:58.760 --> 00:10:03.131
And we're really putting it
to a place on her computer,

152
00:10:03.131 --> 00:10:07.400
which is that C offline,
I was trying to remember.

153
00:10:07.400 --> 00:10:11.690
That folder, and that gives us
the access point into just that image.

154
00:10:11.690 --> 00:10:16.043
Without Cherokee having to install that
computer we will now have access to

155
00:10:16.043 --> 00:10:17.156
the system files.

156
00:10:17.156 --> 00:10:20.893
And that means we can also at
the point do what Cherokee's gonna

00:10:20.893 --> 00:10:24.998
help us do next which of course

158
00:10:24.998 --> 00:10:29.019
So Cherokee, let' talk about what we're
actually going to to end up trying to see

159
