will be the same for this offline part.

383
00:24:36.982 --> 00:24:37.899
But we will need to change.

384
00:24:37.899 --> 00:24:42.150
Here, we're going to add a dash,
forward slash I should say.

385
00:24:42.150 --> 00:24:45.120
And this is going to be an applied dash,
I think.

386
00:24:45.120 --> 00:24:46.195
Let me just check, yep.

387
00:24:46.195 --> 00:24:48.130
That's a dash and then unattend.

388
00:24:48.130 --> 00:24:53.170
So here,
we're gonna type in apply dash unattend.

389
00:24:56.050 --> 00:25:00.436
The next thing is to specify where that,
geez,

390
00:25:00.436 --> 00:25:07.270
my finger wants to put a semi-colon there,
it needs to be a colon.

391
00:25:07.270 --> 00:25:11.470
I need to specify where that
XML file is residing, so

392
00:25:11.470 --> 00:25:14.342
that's what I'm doing right now.

393
00:25:14.342 --> 00:25:19.669
So if I had a folder named XML files,
or something like that,

394
00:25:19.669 --> 00:25:23.650
sitting there on the root
of my C drive there.

395
00:25:23.650 --> 00:25:29.200
And then I would just need to also say,

396
00:25:29.200 --> 00:25:32.328
thisismyxml.xml.

397
00:25:32.328 --> 00:25:35.160
Not like you will ever have
a file name that ridiculous.

398
00:25:35.160 --> 00:25:37.811
But I am just specifying that's the path.
>> Traditionally right,

399
00:25:37.811 --> 00:25:39.600
they were using this idea as answer file.

400
00:25:39.600 --> 00:25:42.530
We normally call it
unattend of some sort and

401
00:25:42.530 --> 00:25:44.760
that is because of what
Cherokee mentioned.

402
00:25:44.760 --> 00:25:48.994
It is because we want to actually make
that install go without any human

403
00:25:48.994 --> 00:25:49.935
interaction.

404
00:25:49.935 --> 00:25:52.652
And that's probably kinda the most
intuitive way to do so, but

405
00:25:52.652 --> 00:25:54.200
you can place it wherever you want.

406
00:25:54.200 --> 00:25:56.720
The key, though,
is to remember where you place it.

407
00:25:56.720 --> 00:25:58.399
I know I've created many of these and

408
00:25:58.399 --> 00:26:01.820
then I just said I don't even remember
where I actually created that file.

409
00:26:01.820 --> 00:26:03.180
Then you have to go and look for it, or

410
00:26:03.180 --> 00:26:06.860
if you're like me you just recreate it
to actually know where to look for it.

411
00:26:06.860 --> 00:26:11.131
So these files are very important,
especially if you are actually assigned

412
00:26:11.131 --> 00:26:14.019
the task of doing an unattended install.
>> All right,

413
00:26:14.019 --> 00:26:16.452
now here comes the if you're
a commitment-phobe and

414
00:26:16.452 --> 00:26:19.816
you don't wanna ever commit to anything,
you might have a problem here.

415
00:26:19.816 --> 00:26:21.784
This is our last step.

416
00:26:21.784 --> 00:26:24.304
[LAUGH] Because we need to commit.

417
00:26:24.304 --> 00:26:28.659
Otherwise, the operating system thinks
we're still modifying this image and,

418
00:26:28.659 --> 00:26:30.120
well, it won't unmount.

419
00:26:30.120 --> 00:26:33.360
So let's type in DISM, then let's see.

420
00:26:33.360 --> 00:26:36.416
The actual command is space,

421
00:26:36.416 --> 00:26:41.940
forward slash unmount,
and image, dash image.

422
00:26:41.940 --> 00:26:44.750
However, let's see.

423
00:26:44.750 --> 00:26:46.575
We have to specify the mount directory.

424
00:26:46.575 --> 00:26:52.185
So /MountDir:C: and
this is still in my same place.

425
00:26:52.185 --> 00:26:55.312
We have to specify that location for
offline.

426
00:26:55.312 --> 00:26:58.615
Now this is where the big
conundrum comes in.

427
00:26:58.615 --> 00:26:59.740
>> You have three Fs there.

428
00:26:59.740 --> 00:27:03.586
[LAUGH] That's not gonna work.
>> [LAUGH] No, that's not gonna work.

429
00:27:03.586 --> 00:27:10.270
All right, so here my options are either
going to be to commit or to discard.

430
00:27:10.270 --> 00:27:15.148
So I could type in forward slash commit,
if I wanted to commit, and

431
00:27:15.148 --> 00:27:19.067
save these changes, so
that it would be ready to go for

432
00:27:19.067 --> 00:27:22.218
me whenever I actually wanted to use that.

433
00:27:22.218 --> 00:27:27.787
Or I would have some kind of
commitment issue and hit discard,

434
00:27:27.787 --> 00:27:32.960
and that's all she wrote.
>> All right Cherokee,

435
00:27:32.960 --> 00:27:37.940
well, thank you again for helping us to
understand a little bit more about using

436
00:27:37.940 --> 00:27:42.046
the DISM tool to help us to be able
to modify these offline images.

437
00:27:42.046 --> 00:27:45.253
This is an important process that
you'll have to make sure you understand

438
00:27:45.253 --> 00:27:46.290
for the exam.

439
00:27:46.290 --> 00:27:49.567
There are many different ways
that you can think about this,

440
00:27:49.567 --> 00:27:53.304
one make sure you pay attention to
the sequencing of things, right?

441
00:27:53.304 --> 00:27:56.653
You can't really modify an image,
offline or even online,

442
00:27:56.653 --> 00:27:59.030
unless you've already got it somewhere.

443
00:27:59.030 --> 00:28:03.401
So make sure you pay attention to the fact
that you have to mount the image first,

444
00:28:03.401 --> 00:28:05.164
then you can make the changes and

445
00:28:05.164 --> 00:28:08.117
then commit those changes at
the end if you choose to.

446
00:28:08.117 --> 00:28:11.824
The other thing to also remember that
what you saw here is that Cherokee showed

447
00:28:11.824 --> 00:28:15.830
us how we could enable a feature, as well
as disable it and also remove a feature.

448
00:28:15.830 --> 00:28:17.181
Those two are different.

449
00:28:17.181 --> 00:28:20.930
Disabling and remove,
make sure you pay attention there as well.

450
00:28:20.930 --> 00:28:25.377
These are all scenario like bases that
you're likely to see on the exam, so

451
00:28:25.377 --> 00:28:26.868
don't gloss over this.

452
00:28:26.868 --> 00:28:31.005
And even if the typing is a little bit
complex or challenging, it's worth you

453
00:28:31.005 --> 00:28:35.480
taking the time to go through, because
you're gonna see this over and over again.

454
00:28:35.480 --> 00:28:39.704
This tool is kind of a major part of us
creating images and getting them ready for

455
00:28:39.704 --> 00:28:40.480
deployment.

456
00:28:40.480 --> 00:28:44.307
And also, I forgot, but Cherokee, you
had mentioned the idea of the unattend.

457
00:28:44.307 --> 00:28:47.486
Make sure you actually know where
that's gonna also be saved, and

458
00:28:47.486 --> 00:28:49.375
why we would choose to use that as well.

459
00:28:49.375 --> 00:28:53.358
So that is a great place for
us to also sign off for this episode, but

460
00:28:53.358 --> 00:28:55.630
there are more features to come.

461
00:28:55.630 --> 00:28:59.376
So signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

462
00:28:59.376 --> 00:29:00.042
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

463
00:29:00.042 --> 00:29:03.827
>> Stay tuned right here for

464
00:29:03.827 --> 00:29:09.601
more of the MCSA 70-410 shows.

465
00:29:09.601 --> 00:29:11.823
[MUSIC]

466
00:29:11.823 --> 00:29:14.343
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee dive into delegating administration and services.  Cherokee demonstrates and explains the purpose of delegating administrative functionality.  She also demonstrates how to do this on an OU in ADDS.  Cherokee also describes the use of services and how to get them configured through the console and a through powershell
episodes.title: Additional Installation Configurations Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:01.537
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.537 --> 00:00:02.873
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.873 --> 00:00:06.466
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.466 --> 00:00:08.274
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.274 --> 00:00:12.343
You're watching IT Pro TV.

6
00:00:12.343 --> 00:00:15.939
Welcome to another great
episodes right here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.939 --> 00:00:20.087
You're watching the MCSA for
Windows Server 2012 R-2,

8
00:00:20.087 --> 00:00:22.599
specifically on exam 70-410.

9
00:00:22.599 --> 00:00:26.174
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and
we're taking a look at well

10
00:00:26.174 --> 00:00:29.606
some additional installation
configurations here.

11
00:00:29.606 --> 00:00:33.424
[LAUGH] We're gonna take a look at one
which was using of course the DISM

12
00:00:33.424 --> 00:00:37.389
tool and now we've got a couple of
other that we've also want to tackle.

13
00:00:37.389 --> 00:00:40.475
And here to help us out of course is
continuing with us Cherokee Boose.

14
00:00:40.475 --> 00:00:41.562
Cherokee, how are you doing?

15
00:00:41.562 --> 00:00:42.819
I'm doing great, Ronnie.

16
00:00:42.819 --> 00:00:46.275
And you say it like there's no
indent site, but there really is.

17
00:00:46.275 --> 00:00:51.137
I promise there's only two additional
installation configurations that we'll be

18
00:00:51.137 --> 00:00:52.578
looking at in this show.

19
00:00:52.578 --> 00:00:57.665
And this is going to be wrapping up
that first section of the objectives for

20
00:00:57.665 --> 00:00:58.411
the exam.

21
00:00:58.411 --> 00:01:01.785
So we just wanna make sure that we are
taking the time to cover each one of these

22
00:01:01.785 --> 00:01:03.800
and make sure you have
a good understanding.

23
00:01:03.800 --> 00:01:09.112
The first concept I'd like to introduce
is something called Delegation and

24
00:01:09.112 --> 00:01:10.697
delegation is great.

25
00:01:10.697 --> 00:01:16.718
If we're in a working environment it's
nice to be able to delegate things, right?

26
00:01:16.718 --> 00:01:20.090
So we don't rely on Cherokee or
Ronnie to do everything,

27
00:01:20.090 --> 00:01:21.861
we can give some delegation.

28
00:01:21.861 --> 00:01:26.820
And this is really nice if we have someone
who has some sort of IT background,

29
00:01:26.820 --> 00:01:29.698
especially for working with remote sites.

30
00:01:29.698 --> 00:01:33.178
And we're not always able to be
there assisting and guiding them,

31
00:01:33.178 --> 00:01:35.239
we can actually give some delegation.

32
00:01:35.239 --> 00:01:37.648
So let's take a look at
how we would do that.

33
00:01:37.648 --> 00:01:39.173
If we take a look at my screen,

34
00:01:39.173 --> 00:01:41.919
I'm just going to be pulling
up some server manager.

35
00:01:41.919 --> 00:01:45.079
Now, it is important to note
that I've pre-installed

36
00:01:45.079 --> 00:01:47.972
Active Directory Domain Services
on this system,

37
00:01:47.972 --> 00:01:51.281
otherwise I'm not gonna be
able to utilize this feature.

38
00:01:51.281 --> 00:01:55.656
So under my Tools I will
select my Users and Computers.

39
00:01:58.021 --> 00:01:59.914
Let's just make that
a little bit larger and

40
00:01:59.914 --> 00:02:02.794
expand this out so we can really
see what we're working with here.

41
00:02:02.794 --> 00:02:06.926
I've already created my
ITProdemo.com domain.

42
00:02:06.926 --> 00:02:11.963
So from here you can see the different
components that I already have.

43
00:02:11.963 --> 00:02:17.477
I have all of my users listed
here over on the right hand side.

44
00:02:17.477 --> 00:02:21.170
And whenever I create an OU,
an Organizational Unit,

45
00:02:21.170 --> 00:02:24.701
it looks like a folder but
let me see if I can zoom in and

46
00:02:24.701 --> 00:02:27.616
show you here from my domain controllers.

47
00:02:27.616 --> 00:02:31.592
There's a tiny little,
I don't even know what that is, Ronnie,

48
00:02:31.592 --> 00:02:34.226
it just looks like
a darker rectangle to me.

49
00:02:34.226 --> 00:02:38.585
But that's really signifying what
an organizational unit is there.

50
00:02:38.585 --> 00:02:43.636
And an organizational unit will allow
more granular administration for me.

51
00:02:43.636 --> 00:02:48.540
So, something that I may wanna do
here is to actually just to create

52
00:02:48.540 --> 00:02:50.480
an organizational unit.

53
00:02:50.480 --> 00:02:56.038
But it really depends on what you want
to be allowing that delegation for.

54
00:02:56.038 --> 00:03:00.674
So let's see,
maybe if there's a particular computer or

55
00:03:00.674 --> 00:03:03.520
something that I wanted to create.

56
00:03:03.520 --> 00:03:05.226
There's nothing in here currently.

57
00:03:05.226 --> 00:03:08.905
So just from our domain here,
I will right click and

58
00:03:08.905 --> 00:03:13.541
I will select New and
I'll select an Organizational Unit here.

59
00:03:13.541 --> 00:03:18.464
So let's say Ronnie was the HR manager but
he used to work in IT.

60
00:03:18.464 --> 00:03:25.084
So he got fired from ITProTV and he's
now the HR person here at this company.

61
00:03:25.084 --> 00:03:29.056
So we'll just say Human Resources for
this particular,

62
00:03:29.056 --> 00:03:31.880
not humus or whatever I'm typing here.

63
00:03:31.880 --> 00:03:32.664
Humus?

64
00:03:32.664 --> 00:03:33.346
[LAUGH] It looks like it.

65
00:03:33.346 --> 00:03:35.814
I think you're hungry.

66
00:03:35.814 --> 00:03:38.227
I think I am too.

67
00:03:38.227 --> 00:03:42.126
They won't feed me until I finish this
show so I'm hoping all goes well.

68
00:03:42.126 --> 00:03:46.932
[LAUGH] All right, so I'm creating
this Organizational Unit that I can

69
00:03:46.932 --> 00:03:50.197
then at this point give
control over to Ronnie.

70
00:03:50.197 --> 00:03:52.535
Something to note here,
this kind of hangs,

71
00:03:52.535 --> 00:03:55.364
gets people caught up with
this little tick mark here,

72
00:03:55.364 --> 00:03:59.315
because maybe I did type in Humus and
I didn't realize it until afterwards.

73
00:03:59.315 --> 00:04:02.251
I'm like, Humus Resources,
what does that even mean?

74
00:04:02.251 --> 00:04:03.763
But if I unchecked this,

75
00:04:03.763 --> 00:04:08.668
it means I can delete this organizational
unit easily by just right-clicking.

76
00:04:08.668 --> 00:04:11.232
So Microsoft said, hey, you know what?

77
00:04:11.232 --> 00:04:12.954
Maybe they had a lot of complaints or
something,

78
00:04:12.954 --> 00:04:14.472
I don't know why they added this feature.

79
00:04:14.472 --> 00:04:18.675
But it's a little option to protect
this container from accidental deletion.

80
00:04:18.675 --> 00:04:20.277
So we'll hit OK.

81
00:04:20.277 --> 00:04:24.801
And now I just wanted to point that
out because it can be troublesome to

82
00:04:24.801 --> 00:04:27.297
some admins here because if you know,

83
00:04:27.297 --> 00:04:31.901
and if I really try to right-click and
delete this and select delete.

84
00:04:31.901 --> 00:04:34.656
I get a little notification,
hey are you sure you want to delete it?

85
00:04:34.656 --> 00:04:36.157
And I think everything is going great.

86
00:04:36.157 --> 00:04:37.755
And I'm like, yeah, sure, delete it.

87
00:04:37.755 --> 00:04:41.946
And then it tells me I do not have
sufficient privileges to delete human

88
00:04:41.946 --> 00:04:42.734
resources.

89
00:04:42.734 --> 00:04:45.320
So I start scratching my
head here a little bit.

90
00:04:45.320 --> 00:04:50.284
And it's kind of a process the way that
they have you go through additional steps

91
00:04:50.284 --> 00:04:54.600
to even be able to uncheck that little
tick box that I just showed you.

92
00:04:54.600 --> 00:04:58.315
So what you would need
to do is select View.

93
00:04:58.315 --> 00:05:02.348
And there's this option here, let me
zoom in so you can really see this, and

94
00:05:02.348 --> 00:05:04.945
this magnifier's getting
right in my way here.

95
00:05:04.945 --> 00:05:11.208
It's called,
open of course my Action menu.

96
00:05:11.208 --> 00:05:14.542
Advanced Features right here,
this is what you would need to select.

97
00:05:14.542 --> 00:05:18.647
So by selecting Advanced Features,
it gives me more information and

98
00:05:18.647 --> 00:05:23.121
I'm really able to now see additional
options that I didn't have before.

99
00:05:23.121 --> 00:05:29.114
So if I right click Human Resources and
select Properties, I have a few extra tabs

100
00:05:29.114 --> 00:05:34.768
by selecting that additional parameter
there under my View drop down menu.

101
00:05:34.768 --> 00:05:39.606
So under this particular tab,
it's the Object tab.

102
00:05:39.606 --> 00:05:45.459
This is where you see that little check
mark, box, I can't even talk right now.

103
00:05:45.459 --> 00:05:46.038
Yeah, box?

104
00:05:46.038 --> 00:05:48.577
It is clear, I'm like starving,
and my brain is withering away.

105
00:05:48.577 --> 00:05:50.808
But no,
this is where you would change that.

106
00:05:50.808 --> 00:05:53.502
I really don't wanna delete it, but
I just wanted to show you that,

107
00:05:53.502 --> 00:05:54.744
since we were already in here.

108
00:05:54.744 --> 00:05:58.465
We do have an entire Active Directory
section coming up so

109
00:05:58.465 --> 00:06:00.258
we won't get too in depth.

110
00:06:00.258 --> 00:06:05.058
I know I'm going off on a tangent but,
[LAUGH] the main thing I wanted to show

111
00:06:05.058 --> 00:06:08.170
you, it's so
easy how to delegate right here.

112
00:06:08.170 --> 00:06:11.507
Is to right-click and
select Delegate Control, and

113
00:06:11.507 --> 00:06:14.781
it brings up a little
Delegation of Control Wizard.

114
00:06:14.781 --> 00:06:17.482
We'll just hit Next to start this process.

115
00:06:17.482 --> 00:06:21.459
And I can add an individual user,
I could add Ronnie.

116
00:06:21.459 --> 00:06:24.086
Honestly, I don't think I've added
him into Active Directory, but

117
00:06:24.086 --> 00:06:25.164
that's not a big deal here.

118
00:06:25.164 --> 00:06:29.255
Maybe I had a group, and
my group was IT Staff or Help Desk, and

119
00:06:29.255 --> 00:06:32.564
I was allowing them to
perform certain changes and

120
00:06:32.564 --> 00:06:36.530
modifications to this OU,
that would be just as fine here.

121
00:06:36.530 --> 00:06:41.320
I can add my user or group, so we hit this
Add button and I'm just gonna be adding,

122
00:06:41.320 --> 00:06:42.242
you know what?

123
00:06:42.242 --> 00:06:43.998
I think I put Zach in here.

124
00:06:43.998 --> 00:06:48.456
Let me see if Zach is
in my Active Directory.

125
00:06:48.456 --> 00:06:49.438
Nothing came up here.

126
00:06:49.438 --> 00:06:50.402
Let me hit Cancel here.

127
00:06:50.402 --> 00:06:54.170
Let's just go with something that I
know and the administrative group so

128
00:06:54.170 --> 00:06:56.161
let's type in Admin and Check Names.

129
00:06:56.161 --> 00:07:00.102
And we'll select our Administrator and
just hit OK.

130
00:07:00.102 --> 00:07:04.597
So we'll allow the administrator to
modify this OU, not Ronnie, sorry Ronnie.

131
00:07:04.597 --> 00:07:07.328
We will hit OK.

132
00:07:07.328 --> 00:07:11.669
And, Next, now this is kinda cool.

133
00:07:11.669 --> 00:07:16.217
You have some pre-configured options that
Microsoft has provided us in this wizard.

134
00:07:16.217 --> 00:07:20.557
So maybe I want someone to be able to
create, delete and manage groups and

135
00:07:20.557 --> 00:07:23.134
to be able to modify the group membership.

136
00:07:23.134 --> 00:07:26.631
But I don't want them performing any
other functions and deleting policies.

137
00:07:26.631 --> 00:07:30.760
If I'm using group policy to
manage this organizational unit.

138
00:07:30.760 --> 00:07:33.959
I could also create a custom task
to delegate, but I think for

139
00:07:33.959 --> 00:07:36.171
now this is good and we'll just hit Next.

140
00:07:36.171 --> 00:07:39.838
Now before you hit Next there, when you
start to take a look at some of these

141
00:07:39.838 --> 00:07:42.279
options especially something like HR,
right?

142
00:07:42.279 --> 00:07:44.512
So always think about scenarios
here when it comes down to it.

143
00:07:44.512 --> 00:07:45.024

00:21:35.050 --> 00:21:38.550
we'll do not S, dollar sign,
underscore, period.

370
00:21:38.550 --> 00:21:42.289
So I'm saying where the status,
so where status

371
00:21:44.320 --> 00:21:49.130
space -eq, so that just means
where the status is equal to.

372
00:21:49.130 --> 00:21:52.640
And then I'll put that status,
and so maybe I wanna check and

373
00:21:52.640 --> 00:21:56.440
look for everything that has
been stopped here in quotation.

374
00:21:56.440 --> 00:21:59.590
I will have to close that
curly bracket and hit enter.

375
00:21:59.590 --> 00:22:04.810
And at this point, the system will
render me all of the information for

376
00:22:04.810 --> 00:22:07.355
those stopped services there.

377
00:22:07.355 --> 00:22:13.631
So, the skies the limit here when you're
using PowerShell to apply filters.

378
00:22:13.631 --> 00:22:15.476
Most commonly, you might want to check.

379
00:22:15.476 --> 00:22:18.057
Let me clear this real quick,
cuz it's hard to look at.

380
00:22:18.057 --> 00:22:22.072
But if I hit my up arrow again,
I could even go back and

381
00:22:22.072 --> 00:22:26.560
just make it real easy for us,
change stopped to running.

382
00:22:28.260 --> 00:22:31.380
Maybe that's the type of service that
I have in question, I wanna see hey,

383
00:22:31.380 --> 00:22:34.090
what's running on this system,
or what's not running?

384
00:22:34.090 --> 00:22:36.570
So there's a lot of different things
that we could think about here, but

385
00:22:36.570 --> 00:22:38.150
I think that's a good place.

386
00:22:38.150 --> 00:22:40.550
I know we've been talking about
configuration options for

387
00:22:40.550 --> 00:22:44.380
a long time now, but that's it for
this particular objective.

388
00:22:44.380 --> 00:22:48.190
Moving forward, we'll be looking
at more of those management and

389
00:22:48.190 --> 00:22:50.210
maintenance type functions.

390
00:22:50.210 --> 00:22:52.656
But that's it for now Ronnie.

391
00:22:52.656 --> 00:22:54.600
All right Cherokee,
well thank you again for

392
00:22:54.600 --> 00:22:57.170
helping us out here and
understanding a little bit more

393
00:22:57.170 --> 00:23:01.140
about delegating administrative types of
things that we have to be able to do.

394
00:23:01.140 --> 00:23:05.410
So Cherokee showed us that inside
of course of the Active Directory

395
00:23:05.410 --> 00:23:06.520
structure that we saw.

396
00:23:06.520 --> 00:23:10.510
And also of course being able to configure
and manipulate some of these services.

397
00:23:10.510 --> 00:23:15.642
Understanding these are actually a big
part of helping others to ensure that they

398
00:23:15.642 --> 00:23:20.708
get what they need to during the regular
network functions that need to happen.

399
00:23:20.708 --> 00:23:23.082
But that's also a great place for
us to sign off.

400
00:23:23.082 --> 00:23:25.989
For ITPRO.TV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

401
00:23:25.989 --> 00:23:27.055
And I'm Cherokee Boose.

402
00:23:27.055 --> 00:23:32.505
Stay tuned right here for
more the MCSA 70-410 shows.

403
00:23:32.505 --> 00:23:38.489
[MUSIC]

404
00:23:38.489 --> 00:23:41.517
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee discuss the difference between Basic and Dynamic Disks.  Cherokee mentions the reasons to use each disk types.  She also shows configuring the MBR and GPT disk and the hardware requirements.  Lastly, she shows the use of the Disk Management tool to convert to GPT and then convert back to MBR.
episodes.title: Configuring Disks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.536
Welcome to ITProTV I'm your host Tom.

2
00:00:02.536 --> 00:00:07.665
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.665 --> 00:00:12.310
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.310 --> 00:00:17.160
>> Welcome to another right here on
ITProTV you're watching the MCSA for

5
00:00:17.160 --> 00:00:21.990
Windows Server 2012 show specially for
exam 70-410.

6
00:00:21.990 --> 00:00:22.570
I'm your host,

7
00:00:22.570 --> 00:00:27.530
Ronnie Wong and we're gonna be taking
a look at configuring disks today.

8
00:00:27.530 --> 00:00:29.630
And here to help us to
understand what we need to know,

9
00:00:29.630 --> 00:00:32.380
especially in getting ready for
the exam is gonna be Ms. Cherokee Boose.

10
00:00:32.380 --> 00:00:33.620
Cherokee, welcome to the show.

11
00:00:33.620 --> 00:00:34.790
>> Hi Ronnie, how's it going?

12
00:00:34.790 --> 00:00:36.170
>> It is going well, Cherokee.

13
00:00:36.170 --> 00:00:40.800
As we begin, as we take a look
here about working hard drives, or

14
00:00:40.800 --> 00:00:43.220
discs, let's put it that way instead.

15
00:00:43.220 --> 00:00:47.740
And that is because a lot of people
that are now beginning their MCSA track.

16
00:00:47.740 --> 00:00:50.600
As they start to look and
go hey I wanna get this.

17
00:00:50.600 --> 00:00:53.750
Most of them may actually been
working on just desktop systems.

18
00:00:53.750 --> 00:00:57.420
And they've really only been working with
what they have on their own machines.

19
00:00:57.420 --> 00:01:02.150
So Cherokee, what do we need to know as we
start to move into the realm of server and

20
00:01:02.150 --> 00:01:03.900
the idea here of configuring disks?

21
00:01:03.900 --> 00:01:06.650
>> Okay Ronnie, great question
because according to Microsoft,

22
00:01:06.650 --> 00:01:10.670
there are some specific objectives that
we're gonna actually covered here.

23
00:01:10.670 --> 00:01:14.064
So when you're talking about, like you
said, if you're familiar with client-side

24
00:01:14.064 --> 00:01:17.430
operating systems,
server-side storage is quite complex.

25
00:01:17.430 --> 00:01:19.240
There's a lot of different layers here.

26
00:01:19.240 --> 00:01:24.530
So I'm gonna cover as much as we can but,
specifically, I wanna call out,

27
00:01:24.530 --> 00:01:28.070
we'll be looking at basic
versus dynamic disks first.

28
00:01:28.070 --> 00:01:32.690
We'll also take a look at different
types of partitioning schemas or styles.

29
00:01:32.690 --> 00:01:35.140
Specifically MBR and GPT,

30
00:01:35.140 --> 00:01:40.110
we'll also look at how virtual hard
disc drives fit into that picture.

31
00:01:40.110 --> 00:01:44.310
And if we have time, Ronnie,
we'll also look at how to manage volumes.

32
00:01:44.310 --> 00:01:46.650
We'll start with the GUI and
then work our way into PowerShell,

33
00:01:46.650 --> 00:01:50.040
just like we have with everything
else here, so that's the plan.

34
00:01:50.040 --> 00:01:51.380
>> All right, so Cherokee,

35
00:01:51.380 --> 00:01:55.290
where do we need to get started as we move
into server and as we start taking a look.

36
00:01:55.290 --> 00:01:56.030
Because a lot of times,

37
00:01:56.030 --> 00:01:58.970
one of the scariest things that I
remember, when I first got into it,

38
00:01:58.970 --> 00:02:03.740
was I realized that had to deal
with more than one particular disk.

39
00:02:03.740 --> 00:02:06.720
And then the terminology was also
a little bit challenging too.

40
00:02:06.720 --> 00:02:09.080
>> I know,
the terminology is a little overwhelming.

41
00:02:09.080 --> 00:02:11.500
I don't want you guys
to get hung up on that.

42
00:02:11.500 --> 00:02:16.140
Ronnie we did some shows for server 101
before and we kind of broke it down really

43
00:02:16.140 --> 00:02:20.970
in that way but if you guys want you
can go back in and check those out.

44
00:02:20.970 --> 00:02:24.140
There's some intro into
disk management as well,

45
00:02:24.140 --> 00:02:27.270
will try my best to call out
what we really need to know.

46
00:02:27.270 --> 00:02:29.610
So I think starting with
the terminology for

47
00:02:29.610 --> 00:02:33.600
disks, like I said we'll be talking
about virtual disks and physical disks.

48
00:02:33.600 --> 00:02:38.160
And it's kind of a moot point when
we're talking server side storage

49
00:02:38.160 --> 00:02:42.160
because nowadays it's so
common to have virtualized disks, and

50
00:02:42.160 --> 00:02:46.850
what I think Microsoft wants to
convey in this particular section of

51
00:02:46.850 --> 00:02:51.650
objectives is to really understand
that the management side of

52
00:02:51.650 --> 00:02:55.220
things is gonna be the same, the way that
we handle and treat those disks once

53
00:02:55.220 --> 00:02:59.210
recognized by that operating system, we're
gonna go ahead and treat them the same.

54
00:02:59.210 --> 00:03:02.340
Regardless if it's physical, or
if it's going to be virtualized.

55
00:03:03.380 --> 00:03:05.320
When we get to Hyper-V section,

56
00:03:05.320 --> 00:03:08.270
there will be additional
information called out there.

57
00:03:08.270 --> 00:03:11.880
That we'll look at to explore
virtual discs a little further.

58
00:03:11.880 --> 00:03:16.030
So, I think the best place to start here
would be looking at the difference between

59
00:03:16.030 --> 00:03:18.930
basic and dynamic disks, so what is that?

60
00:03:18.930 --> 00:03:20.520
If we take a look at my screen,
we'll go ahead and

61
00:03:20.520 --> 00:03:22.380
cover some of these high points here.

62
00:03:22.380 --> 00:03:26.430
A basic disk is just that,
like it sounds, it's pretty basic.

63
00:03:26.430 --> 00:03:29.240
There's not a whole lot
you can do with it.

64
00:03:29.240 --> 00:03:34.350
You can create partitions and volumes that
are configured, they're really confined

65
00:03:34.350 --> 00:03:39.560
to a single disk, so whether that
disk be physical or virtualized,

66
00:03:39.560 --> 00:03:45.280
you can't take those partitions and
create, you know, a spanned volumes.

67
00:03:45.280 --> 00:03:48.490
That would go ahead and be a dynamic disk,
and we'll take a look at that and

68
00:03:48.490 --> 00:03:52.190
kind of compare and contrast the two
there, even setting them up.

69
00:03:52.190 --> 00:03:55.340
I think that's where you'll get the most
benefit from this, is actually getting in

70
00:03:55.340 --> 00:04:00.570
the operating system and seeing how it
reacts, and handles these different disks.

71
00:04:00.570 --> 00:04:04.450
Now why would someone want to
use a disk that is so basic?

72
00:04:04.450 --> 00:04:09.290
Well basic disks allow for
operating systems to boot from them,

73
00:04:09.290 --> 00:04:13.900
so there's also a lot of backwards
compatibility with that as well now,

74
00:04:14.990 --> 00:04:18.000
there is several limitations here.

75
00:04:18.000 --> 00:04:22.730
One of the most notorious limitations
would be the amount of partitions

76
00:04:22.730 --> 00:04:25.370
that you can have, so

77
00:04:25.370 --> 00:04:30.310
you can have up to four partitions,
three primary and one extended.

78
00:04:30.310 --> 00:04:34.600
Now there are some workarounds
where you can create logical

79
00:04:35.850 --> 00:04:40.700
drives to create additional storage
spaces, so units of storage with those

80
00:04:40.700 --> 00:04:46.220
extended partitions but
if that's really your cup of tea and you

81
00:04:46.220 --> 00:04:51.020
want to have multiple volumes then dynamic
disks is going to be the way to go.

82
00:04:51.020 --> 00:04:53.920
As a matter of fact dynamic
disks is even phasing out and

83
00:04:53.920 --> 00:04:56.050
we'll take a look at that as well.

84
00:04:56.050 --> 00:05:01.660
So Basic Disks do not provide any kind of
integrated software resistance to damage.

85
00:05:01.660 --> 00:05:06.410
We do have utilities that have been around
for a very long time like chkdsk, fdisk,

86
00:05:07.610 --> 00:05:12.775
fix disk and we will need to use those
types of utilities to manage and

87
00:05:12.775 --> 00:05:15.085
maintain the health of these disks.

88
00:05:15.085 --> 00:05:19.345
And it also allows us to boot various
systems from various partitions.

89
00:05:19.345 --> 00:05:20.860
We could have multi boot.

90
00:05:20.860 --> 00:05:24.230
Now when we take a look at dynamic discs,
if you're ever in a, you know,

91
00:05:24.230 --> 00:05:26.870
a conundrum and
you're not sure which one to choose.

92
00:05:26.870 --> 00:05:30.030
If you for
sure want to have that disk be bootable,

93
00:05:30.030 --> 00:05:32.830
dynamic discs cannot boot
in every configuration.

94
00:05:32.830 --> 00:05:34.060
So this is a safe bet here.

95
00:05:34.060 --> 00:05:36.680
So it's probably one of the reasons why,
and of course for

96
00:05:36.680 --> 00:05:41.950
that backwards compatibility, it's pretty
common to still utilize basic disks here,

97
00:05:41.950 --> 00:05:45.140
so when we're talking about functionality,
we're somewhat limited here.

98
00:05:45.140 --> 00:05:49.440
We can perform some basic functions
such as create and delete primary and

99
00:05:49.440 --> 00:05:51.150
extended partitions.

100
00:05:51.150 --> 00:05:56.460
You can create and delete logical
drives within an extended partition.

101
00:05:56.460 --> 00:05:58.930
And you can format and mark it as active.

102
00:05:58.930 --> 00:06:04.030
The good news is, look, we're not married
to this concept, if I wanted to later

103
00:06:04.030 --> 00:06:09.160
on decide I wanted to convert to a dynamic
disk I do have that capability as well.

104
00:06:09.160 --> 00:06:12.200
There is a caveat to that,
because the way,

105
00:06:12.200 --> 00:06:14.680
actually let's just start
talking about Dynamic Disks.

106
00:06:14.680 --> 00:06:21.220
But because the way that dynamic disks
add additional integrated checksums and

107
00:06:21.220 --> 00:06:25.790
it maintains and stores information
about disks, you will need at least one

108
00:06:25.790 --> 00:06:29.830
megabyte worth of free space on that
disk before you convert it to dynamic.

109
00:06:29.830 --> 00:06:31.440
So that's the only thing
to keep in mind there.

110
00:06:31.440 --> 00:06:33.960
But I mean it's so
small by today's standards,

111
00:06:33.960 --> 00:06:35.700
it shouldn't be an issue for you.

112
00:06:35.700 --> 00:06:40.750
When we look at dynamic disks,
the main reason why someone would want

113
00:06:40.750 --> 00:06:44.460
to use one is because it really
does expand the functionality and

114
00:06:44.460 --> 00:06:47.770
allows us to utilize multiple disks.

115
00:06:47.770 --> 00:06:51.160
And when we start talking about
volumes and how we can manage them.

116
00:06:51.160 --> 00:06:54.530
It's almost as if we're, well, it is.

117
00:06:54.530 --> 00:06:58.790
It's like we're implementing
software-based RAID configurations.

118
00:06:58.790 --> 00:07:01.640
If you don't know what
RAID configurations are,

119
00:07:01.640 --> 00:07:05.890
it is implied that you do have that prior
knowledge at this point in the game.

120
00:07:05.890 --> 00:07:09.890
So, if not, the good news is,
Ryan and I we did that in Server 101.

121
00:07:09.890 --> 00:07:14.490
There are plenty of shows in our course
library that explain rate configurations.

122
00:07:14.490 --> 00:07:17.360
And we'll look at the volume
side of things, but

123
00:07:17.360 --> 00:07:20.930
we're not gonna cover
those actual configs here.

124
00:07:20.930 --> 00:07:25.180
So, now another thing is
that it can be composed of

125
00:07:25.180 --> 00:07:29.610
a set of noncontinuous spaces or
multiple physical disks.

126
00:07:29.610 --> 00:07:33.600
So I can take that concept of RAID and
I can

127
00:07:35.290 --> 00:07:39.570
bring these drives together either for
panned with aggregation.

128
00:07:39.570 --> 00:07:42.760
I can do it for speed improvements.

129
00:07:42.760 --> 00:07:47.410
So whether fault tolerance and, or really
if you can utilize it for both of those.

130
00:07:47.410 --> 00:07:51.540
So it really is just gonna be dependent
on how you wanna configure those disks.

131
00:07:53.090 --> 00:07:58.735
Now, Dynamic Disks do have integrated
damage resistance which is pretty cool.

132
00:07:58.735 --> 00:08:01.874
And actually these two
bullet points kind of go

133
00:08:01.874 --> 00:08:06.796
together here because the database
provides management flexibility.

134
00:08:06.796 --> 00:08:10.140
What that means with that
management flexibility,

135
00:08:10.140 --> 00:08:12.500
there's a database that is stored.

136
00:08:12.500 --> 00:08:18.110
So if you look at the way that
dynamic disks are really broken down,

137
00:08:18.110 --> 00:08:21.440
and Microsoft, I'll show you in a moment
here, they really have a good job of

138
00:08:21.440 --> 00:08:24.022
breaking that down for
you if you don't know how that works.

139
00:08:24.022 --> 00:08:28.740
But there's an actual database that's
stored within dynamic discs and it

140
00:08:28.740 --> 00:08:33.580
contains information about that disc, and
about other dynamic discs in that system.

141
00:08:33.580 --> 00:08:38.074
So if there's any kind of fault, it will
automatically try, especially if you have

142
00:08:38.074 --> 00:08:41.873
any kind of special configuration,
like a mirrored volume set up, and

143
00:08:41.873 --> 00:08:44.815
it will automatically try to
repair that disc for you.

144
00:08:44.815 --> 00:08:48.215
So that's one of the main reasons
why someone would want to use them,

145
00:08:48.215 --> 00:08:51.380
is to take advantage of
those functions there.

146
00:08:51.380 --> 00:08:55.850
Now, I did say that dynamic disks
were kinda on their way out.

147
00:08:55.850 --> 00:08:59.400
Dynamic disks are definitely
an improvement, they provide more

148
00:08:59.400 --> 00:09:04.050
functionality than a basic disk, but
with the advent of storage spaces,

149
00:09:04.050 --> 00:09:09.590
Microsoft is really trying to push that
from server side storage management.

150
00:09:09.590 --> 00:09:13.000
We have a lot of really cool new and
improved technologies.

151
00:09:13.000 --> 00:09:17.943
So, in my opinion, dynamic discs,
it's not like they're going to be extinct,

152
00:09:17.943 --> 00:09:22.457
but you're really going to start
utilizing storage pools to manage server

153
00:09:22.457 --> 00:09:23.404
side storage.

154
00:09:23.404 --> 00:09:26.335
And that just what we'll focus on
that also a little bit later down

155
00:09:26.335 --> 00:09:27.850
the road here.

156
00:09:27.850 --> 00:09:30.510
Now, when we walk about
the functionalities that dynamic

157
00:09:30.510 --> 00:09:34.880
disks are able to perform,
we can create and delete simple spanned,

158
00:09:34.880 --> 00:09:37.640
striped, mirrored, and RAID-5 volumes.

159
00:09:37.640 --> 00:09:42.030
We'll cover those and walk through, in the
GUI, how you would actually create those.

160
00:09:42.030 --> 00:09:46.290
We can extend a simple or spanned volume.

161
00:09:46.290 --> 00:09:48.880
We can remove a mirror
from a mirrored volume or

162
00:09:48.880 --> 00:09:51.500
break the mirror volume into two volumes.

163
00:09:51.500 --> 00:09:58.070
So if you about with our mirror RAID,
that's what we're really talking about

164
00:09:58.070 --> 00:10:04.720
here, is having disks to have an exact
duplicate of the data that you're storing.

165
00:10:04.720 --> 00:10:07.815
You can also repair mirrored or
RAID-5 volumes like I said,

166
00:10:07.815 --> 00:10:11.800
that all goes back to that database
there and how that disk is managed.

167
00:10:11.800 --> 00:10:18.259
And you can also reactivate a missing or
offline disk.

168
00:10:18.259 --> 00:10:22.880
So the system will be able
to notice if a disk has some

169
00:10:22.880 --> 00:10:26.541
kind of health issue, or if it missing.

170
00:10:26.541 --> 00:10:31.485
And then bring it online, especially
if you have one sitting there as

171
00:10:31.485 --> 00:10:35.295
a reserve in standby and
then it just uses that disk.

172
00:10:35.295 --> 00:10:40.240
To bring it back rebuild the functionality
of your configuration, and

173
00:10:40.240 --> 00:10:46.150
there's even ways we can automate this
to make it all happen behind the scenes.

174
00:10:46.150 --> 00:10:47.800
I don't need to be present to do that.

175
00:10:47.800 --> 00:10:49.870
The operating system handles if for me.

176
00:10:49.870 --> 00:10:51.510
So that's really cool.

177
00:10:51.510 --> 00:10:53.830
I think the big takeaway here.

178
00:10:53.830 --> 00:11:00.910
Remember, basic discs, you can only
have basic discs on one individual disc.

179
00:11:00.910 --> 00:11:03.725
So one sole or one single disc.

180
00:11:03.725 --> 00:11:05.220
So you can't span them.

181
00:11:05.220 --> 00:11:09.560
If you do, then that bumps it into that
category of a dynamic disc, you have to.

182
00:11:09.560 --> 00:11:12.060
And we'll look at how to
configure that in a few moments.

183
00:11:12.060 --> 00:11:17.060
But Microsoft also has some
great information online.

184
00:11:17.060 --> 00:11:18.830
I just want to show you the link here.

185
00:11:18.830 --> 00:11:25.345
So they say, basic and dynamic disks, tons

it really is that simple.

408
00:25:09.360 --> 00:25:13.500
You just select Convert to MBR,
and voila, that's it.

409
00:25:13.500 --> 00:25:16.800
So, we will be performing
additional configurations.

410
00:25:16.800 --> 00:25:19.184
It's a good place for
us to start, but Ronnie,

411
00:25:19.184 --> 00:25:21.523
I think we're gonna have
a multi parter here.

412
00:25:21.523 --> 00:25:23.778
>> All right Cherokee,
well thank you again for

413
00:25:23.778 --> 00:25:27.929
helping us to understand a little bit more
about the idea here of working with disk,

414
00:25:27.929 --> 00:25:29.849
at least at the Windows Server level.

415
00:25:29.849 --> 00:25:34.846
Remember that Cherokee showed us how
to differentiate the idea of basic and

416
00:25:34.846 --> 00:25:35.884
dynamic disk.

417
00:25:35.884 --> 00:25:40.670
And we also emphasize the need of course
to say, hey, when do we actually use it?.

418
00:25:40.670 --> 00:25:45.270
As well as taking a look at the GPT and
MBR, as well.

419
00:25:45.270 --> 00:25:47.820
There's a couple of different options that
are there that you wanna make sure that

420
00:25:47.820 --> 00:25:51.260
you also pay attention to, depending
on the need for your environment.

421
00:25:51.260 --> 00:25:53.350
But we are actually holding off for
a part two,

422
00:25:53.350 --> 00:25:56.360
then, so we're gonna sign off right now.

423
00:25:56.360 --> 00:25:58.920
For ITPRO.TV, I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

424
00:25:58.920 --> 00:26:00.050
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

425
00:26:00.050 --> 00:26:05.180
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the MCSA 70-410 shows.

426
00:26:05.180 --> 00:26:11.159
[MUSIC]

427
00:26:11.159 --> 00:26:14.476
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee look at configuring basic and dynamic disks in Window Server 2012 R2.  Cherokee uses the Disk Management tool to configure a spanned volume and striped volume.  She also demonstrates creating a mounted folder too.
episodes.title: Configuring Disks Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.112
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.112 --> 00:00:06.011
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.011 --> 00:00:08.458
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.458 --> 00:00:12.095
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.095 --> 00:00:15.117
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.117 --> 00:00:19.320
You're watching the MCSA for
Windows Server 2012 R2.

7
00:00:19.320 --> 00:00:22.895
We're specifically focusing
in on the exam 70-410.

8
00:00:22.895 --> 00:00:26.366
We'll be taking look at
Configuring Disk Part 2 right now, and

9
00:00:26.366 --> 00:00:29.530
here to help us out of course
is gonna be Cherokee Boose.

10
00:00:29.530 --> 00:00:30.590
Cherokee, welcome to the show.

11

>> Thanks for having me back, Ronnie.

12

>> All right Cherokee, so here we are,
we've already talked about some of

13
