the basics of our disk configuration,
we understand a little bit more.

14
00:00:38.530 --> 00:00:41.990
And now, you're actually gonna show
us a lot more in the lab, aren't we?

15
00:00:41.990 --> 00:00:44.860
>> Yeah, so we're gonna hop back
into our lab environment here.

16
00:00:44.860 --> 00:00:46.950
There was one thing I wanted to show you,

17
00:00:46.950 --> 00:00:51.660
first of all, before we get in
depth with our volumes here.

18
00:00:51.660 --> 00:00:54.785
And that was just how to
create a virtual disk.

19
00:00:54.785 --> 00:00:58.125
And like I had mentioned before,
when it comes to management,

20
00:00:58.125 --> 00:01:01.955
at this point in the game,
we're really not differentiating too much.

21
00:01:01.955 --> 00:01:04.115
You'll see some slight differences there.

22
00:01:04.115 --> 00:01:07.175
But let's take a look at how
we would actually create one.

23
00:01:07.175 --> 00:01:11.175
If I pull disk manager,
on the left hand pane here,

24
00:01:11.175 --> 00:01:16.958
I just right click on top of disk
management, and then select create VHD.

25
00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:21.265
And Microsoft specifically calls this out
in their objectives, so I would definitely

26
00:01:21.265 --> 00:01:25.890
make sure you know how to create and mount
and detached and we'll do that right here.

27
00:01:25.890 --> 00:01:27.350
It's really simple, guys.

28
00:01:27.350 --> 00:01:32.233
So, you need to specify a location as to
where you're gonna store the information

29
00:01:32.233 --> 00:01:33.734
for that virtual drive.

30
00:01:33.734 --> 00:01:38.984
So here let's say, C; and
I'm gonna put this under plab,

31
00:01:38.984 --> 00:01:42.920
b for my name just under my C drive there.

32
00:01:42.920 --> 00:01:45.915
You also need to specify a size.

33
00:01:45.915 --> 00:01:49.678
So remember by default,
there it is gonna be megabyte,

34
00:01:49.678 --> 00:01:53.770
so we'll just specify 2 gig
drive here if I'm even typing.

35
00:01:53.770 --> 00:01:54.839
My num locks wasn't on.

36
00:01:56.650 --> 00:01:59.740
Let's see, gotta love it.

37
00:01:59.740 --> 00:02:02.220
And now that would not be 2 gigs.

38
00:02:02.220 --> 00:02:03.980
All right, there we go.

39
00:02:03.980 --> 00:02:07.310
So at this point in time,
let me just zoom in a little bit so

40
00:02:07.310 --> 00:02:09.333
you can see some of
the other options we have.

41
00:02:09.333 --> 00:02:13.955
We're not gonna go too far in
depth here discussing VHD versus

42
00:02:13.955 --> 00:02:16.575
VHDX versus fixed versus dynamic.

43
00:02:16.575 --> 00:02:20.295
That's a conversation that's reserved for
our Hyper-V section,

44
00:02:20.295 --> 00:02:23.705
so just keep that in mind,
we will cover that though.

45
00:02:23.705 --> 00:02:30.265
We'll hit OK and, must be fully qualified,
what did I name it as?

46
00:02:30.265 --> 00:02:31.725
Let me try one more time here.

47
00:02:32.750 --> 00:02:34.030
Let's see, create VHD.

48
00:02:34.030 --> 00:02:38.898
I told you how simple it was, so
simple that Cherokee can't even do that.

49
00:02:38.898 --> 00:02:45.760
All righ C:\ is what I forgot,
plab, that's what I did.

50
00:02:45.760 --> 00:02:48.870
So don't make my mistakes,
ladies and gentlemen, all right.

51
00:02:48.870 --> 00:02:52.319
We'll hit OK, and
it really should be that simple here.

52
00:02:53.440 --> 00:02:54.850
And you can see it, Disk 4.

53
00:02:54.850 --> 00:02:57.950
This is our new little baby disk.

54
00:02:57.950 --> 00:03:03.000
And, there is a color difference,
so that's one thing that could

55
00:03:03.000 --> 00:03:07.850
denote that it's a virtual hard disk drive
just from that visual inspection there.

56
00:03:07.850 --> 00:03:11.040
Both of these disks
are down at the moment.

57
00:03:11.040 --> 00:03:13.620
That's what that little red tab indicates,
so

58
00:03:13.620 --> 00:03:18.140
you can see this one that's online
doesn't have that red down arrow.

59
00:03:18.140 --> 00:03:21.540
But there we have
a virtual hard disk drive.

60
00:03:21.540 --> 00:03:26.472
Currently, the space on this drive, these
are our two gigs that we had specify here

61
00:03:26.472 --> 00:03:29.233
for the size, it's currently unallocated.

62
00:03:29.233 --> 00:03:32.471
I would just right-click,
and well first of all,

63
00:03:32.471 --> 00:03:36.310
I would have to initialize that
just to be able to manage it.

64
00:03:36.310 --> 00:03:37.610
But then after that,

65
00:03:37.610 --> 00:03:43.820
I would just manage it like I would
a physical disk in that aspect there.

66
00:03:43.820 --> 00:03:46.230
Now, Let's go ahead and do that.

67
00:03:46.230 --> 00:03:48.690
Let's initialize this disk.

68
00:03:48.690 --> 00:03:53.283
Let's just say, hey, Disk 4 initializing
here with NBR, that's fine.

69
00:03:55.482 --> 00:04:00.810
And, if I wanted to create a simple
volume, I could, it's the same process.

70
00:04:00.810 --> 00:04:07.155
I'll just show you here, you walk
through the path and that's it, finish.

71
00:04:09.151 --> 00:04:12.900
But, what about formatting
this particular drive?

72
00:04:12.900 --> 00:04:15.490
Hold on,
I got a notification here it says,

73
00:04:15.490 --> 00:04:19.160
you need to format the disk drive
in drive E before you can use it.

74
00:04:19.160 --> 00:04:20.340
Do you wanna format it?

75
00:04:20.340 --> 00:04:21.370
Yes, we do.

76
00:04:21.370 --> 00:04:22.680
So, let's just hit format.

77
00:04:23.810 --> 00:04:28.620
Okay, Let me just close out of here for
one second.

78
00:04:28.620 --> 00:04:31.360
I have to verify that my
files are not read-only

79
00:04:31.360 --> 00:04:34.970
when we created that virtual disk,
I kinda went through it fast.

80
00:04:34.970 --> 00:04:39.464
You can create virtual disk
drives that are read-only there.

81
00:04:39.464 --> 00:04:43.940
But I just wanna show you how easy it is
to go ahead and detach this virtual hard

82
00:04:43.940 --> 00:04:47.470
disk drive because that is something
that they do call out in the objectives.

83
00:04:47.470 --> 00:04:50.030
And you just right-click on that
particular virtual drive and

84
00:04:50.030 --> 00:04:51.920
select detach.

85
00:04:51.920 --> 00:04:55.630
And it says, detaching this virtual hard
disk will make it unavailable when it is

86
00:04:55.630 --> 00:04:58.930
attached again,
until it is attached again.

87
00:04:58.930 --> 00:05:02.150
Let me just hit Cancel and show you where
it's actually located because we had

88
00:05:02.150 --> 00:05:05.160
specified under our C drive there.

89
00:05:05.160 --> 00:05:10.720
If I zoom in, you can see that this
drive is sitting there under C drive,

90
00:05:10.720 --> 00:05:17.140
so when I do detach it, it's not gonna
be accessible by any end users there.

91
00:05:17.140 --> 00:05:18.513
So that's something to reference.

92
00:05:18.513 --> 00:05:22.856
So let me get back into
our disk management, and

93
00:05:22.856 --> 00:05:28.294
we'll just go ahead and
detach it, and then we'll say OK.

94
00:05:28.294 --> 00:05:34.360
Now, That particular drive,
you don't see it here anymore.

95
00:05:34.360 --> 00:05:39.890
If we hop back into our interface,
I'll just hit

96
00:05:39.890 --> 00:05:44.430
refresh here to make sure that I'm
showing you the correct information.

97
00:05:44.430 --> 00:05:46.328
But that drive is still there.

98
00:05:46.328 --> 00:05:50.630
If I right-click on this drive,
you see this option to go ahead and mount.

99
00:05:50.630 --> 00:05:53.449
So whenever you look at the objectives and
they say,

100
00:05:53.449 --> 00:05:56.334
mounting virtual hard disk drives,
unmounting, so

101
00:05:56.334 --> 00:06:00.007
in the operating system,
we can see attaching, detaching there.

102
00:06:00.007 --> 00:06:01.360
And that's what they're referencing.

103
00:06:01.360 --> 00:06:05.720
So if I go ahead and
right click and mount, all right.

104
00:06:05.720 --> 00:06:07.320
Let me just minimize this.

105
00:06:07.320 --> 00:06:12.304
I can see that, that disk does
appear back in my disk management

106
00:06:12.304 --> 00:06:15.701
console here to further manage that disk.

107
00:06:15.701 --> 00:06:19.615
So I just wanted to show you how easy it
is to create one and how to mount and

108
00:06:19.615 --> 00:06:20.650
unmount it.

109
00:06:20.650 --> 00:06:24.510
But we also need to talk
about managing volumes.

110
00:06:24.510 --> 00:06:27.390
So, when we have our disks,

111
00:06:27.390 --> 00:06:32.470
whether they be physical or virtual, and
then we select our partitions schemas,

112
00:06:32.470 --> 00:06:36.520
so if we wanna use NBR or
GPT, well what's next?

113
00:06:36.520 --> 00:06:42.220
Well we need to think about what kind of
file system we wanna use for those disks.

114
00:06:42.220 --> 00:06:46.454
So let me pull up diagram here,
and get to the right page.

115
00:06:49.121 --> 00:06:51.630
Different types of file systems here.

116
00:06:51.630 --> 00:06:56.005
We have FAT, which is going to be, for

117
00:06:56.005 --> 00:07:00.355
file allocation table, this is an older,
hopefully, you're not utilizing it but

118
00:07:00.355 --> 00:07:04.875
if you have, for this file system here, if
you have a folder systems, or if you have

119
00:07:04.875 --> 00:07:08.155
a mixed environment and you need that
additional backwards compatibility or

120
00:07:08.155 --> 00:07:11.635
just compatibility in general,
this may be an option to you.

121
00:07:11.635 --> 00:07:17.525
This really is not a, there are several
limitations with our FAT file system,

122
00:07:17.525 --> 00:07:23.620
so I wouldn't recommend using this file
system only on an as needed basis.

123
00:07:23.620 --> 00:07:25.700
If we look at the two, now remember,

124
00:07:25.700 --> 00:07:28.667
there are tons of different
file systems out there.

125
00:07:28.667 --> 00:07:33.976
But really we're talking, specifically,
about Windows Server operating

126
00:07:33.976 --> 00:07:39.460
systems here, and specifically,
Windows Server 2012 and 2012 R2.

127
00:07:39.460 --> 00:07:43.575
So with 2012 and 2012 R2,

128
00:07:43.575 --> 00:07:47.147
it's best to use NTFS or ReFS.

129
00:07:47.147 --> 00:07:51.691
So with NTFS, New Technology File System,
it includes metadata,

130
00:07:51.691 --> 00:07:56.554
it provides inspections, you can
set disk quotas, you can implement,

131
00:07:56.554 --> 00:08:00.960
utilize access control lists and
implement permissions there.

132
00:08:00.960 --> 00:08:05.405
You can utilize encryption, right,
integrated with encrypting file system.

133
00:08:05.405 --> 00:08:09.077
And NTFS also provides compression,

134
00:08:09.077 --> 00:08:14.180
now NTFS allows us to
create a bootable drive.

135
00:08:14.180 --> 00:08:17.160
ReFS, resilient file system,

136
00:08:17.160 --> 00:08:22.060
is a newer type of file system
that has additional improvements.

137
00:08:22.060 --> 00:08:27.600
It is backwards compatible with NTFS,
it has increased data verification and

138
00:08:27.600 --> 00:08:30.120
error correction, so what does that mean?

139
00:08:30.120 --> 00:08:35.330
If we look at NTFS,
does not handle unexpected

140
00:08:35.330 --> 00:08:39.180
power failures or any kind of
unexpected shut downs very well.

141
00:08:39.180 --> 00:08:43.860
A lot of times, you'll see data corruption
associated with those abrupt shutdowns.

142
00:08:43.860 --> 00:08:49.620
ReFS has a self healing property and,
as a matter of fact,

143
00:08:49.620 --> 00:08:54.470
you don't even see some of those command
line basis disk checking utilities that

144
00:08:54.470 --> 00:08:59.012
you have with NTFS systems
because it automatically heals.

145
00:08:59.012 --> 00:09:03.690
So that's pretty cool there,
it supports larger files, directories, and

146
00:09:03.690 --> 00:09:11.260
volumes by an exponential amounts here,
used in larger in environments.

147
00:09:11.260 --> 00:09:15.040
It does have lower functionality
compared to NTFS and

148
00:09:15.040 --> 00:09:20.580
what I mean by that is there is no
integrated encrypting file systems.

149
00:09:20.580 --> 00:09:25.250
So currently, there's not a way for
ReFS to encrypt those files natively.

150
00:09:25.250 --> 00:09:29.049
It does not provide compression,
it really doesn't need to,

151
00:09:29.049 --> 00:09:31.421
the way that it handles the disk there.

152
00:09:31.421 --> 00:09:36.411
And it doesn't provide assignments either,
so we're not currently,

153
00:09:36.411 --> 00:09:41.398
at the time of this recording,
able to boot from ReFS formatted disks but

154
00:09:41.398 --> 00:09:46.258
who knows in the future, I think
that's the way Microsoft is headed.

155
00:09:46.258 --> 00:09:51.242
But it's really great,
they've configured ReFS to be

156
00:09:51.242 --> 00:09:55.600
able almost at like an API
functionality level.

157
00:09:55.600 --> 00:09:59.900
So certain business
applications can work well and

158
00:09:59.900 --> 00:10:02.540
be backwards compatible with NTFS there.

159
00:10:02.540 --> 00:10:06.660
So you're still able to,
if you're running NTFS or ReFS,

160
00:10:06.660 --> 00:10:08.740
you're able to access those files.

161
00:10:08.740 --> 00:10:13.890
But just remember it's not bootable
at this moment in time, so

162
00:10:13.890 --> 00:10:15.340
those are some differences.

163
00:10:15.340 --> 00:10:21.025
And there's actually,
if you run a particular fsutil for

164
00:10:21.025 --> 00:10:24.585
comparison, you can actually see
here in the operating system,

165
00:10:24.585 --> 00:10:29.575
the ones in the yellow that NTFS
provides that ReFS currently does not.

166
00:10:29.575 --> 00:10:31.825
So that's just a little bit there.

167
00:10:31.825 --> 00:10:39.120
Now, this is important because,
it's going to be depending or

168
00:10:39.120 --> 00:10:42.840
contingent upon what we wanna do with
these disks later on down the road, right?

169
00:10:42.840 --> 00:10:45.458
I mentioned that when
we use dynamic disks,

170
00:10:45.458 --> 00:10:49.433
there may be a reason why we're
configuring them in certain ways.

171
00:10:49.433 --> 00:10:53.289
And if you think back to those older,
well, I say older but

172
00:10:53.289 --> 00:10:57.564
they're still being used but
a physical read implementation.

173
00:10:57.564 --> 00:10:59.087
Right?

174
00:10:59.087 --> 00:11:03.730
We can create that here within software,
so it's pretty simple actually.

175
00:11:03.730 --> 00:11:09.150
Let's go ahead and
take a look at my screen and

176
00:11:09.150 --> 00:11:12.100
let's acknowledge what kind of
disks we have available to us.

177
00:11:12.100 --> 00:11:17.110
We have a 10 gig disk, a 15 gig disk and
a 20 gig disk that we can work and

178
00:11:17.110 --> 00:11:20.600
manipulate to perform how we want it to.

179
00:11:20.600 --> 00:11:26.810
When we create our volumes here,
a basic volume is just that basic,

180
00:11:26.810 --> 00:11:30.860
you don't even see an option for it here
on the list, because it's already basic.

181
00:11:30.860 --> 00:11:35.660
So basic or simple volumes is a volume
where the free space on a single disk or

182
00:11:35.660 --> 00:11:38.060
partition is used for storage space.

183
00:11:38.060 --> 00:11:42.810
It can be extended on the same disk,
but if you move it past that disc,

184
00:11:42.810 --> 00:11:46.662
if you're trying to store information on,
let's say, disk two or

185
00:11:46.662 --> 00:11:51.700
disk three, then it's not a basic disk
anymore, that would be a spanned disk.

186
00:11:51.700 --> 00:11:56.380
So you see our first option here
is to create a new spanned volume.

187
00:11:56.380 --> 00:11:58.390
So what does that mean?

188
00:11:58.390 --> 00:12:02.005
If I created a new span volume and
we'll just, we'll click Next here,

189
00:12:02.005 --> 00:12:05.880
this'll launch for each one of those
types of volumes in the interface here,

190
00:12:05.880 --> 00:12:07.660
you'll get a, well, wizard which is nice.

191
00:12:07.660 --> 00:12:09.820
They're pretty similar but
there are some slight differences.

192
00:12:11.820 --> 00:12:17.700
Now, currently I have disk one selected
and I can also utilize disk two here for

193
00:12:17.700 --> 00:12:21.540
my spanned configuration, and
disk three is not popping up.

194
00:12:21.540 --> 00:12:22.651
Why?
Let's see,

195
00:12:22.651 --> 00:12:24.850
it's because disk three is offline.

196
00:12:24.850 --> 00:12:28.819
If we had brought disk three online,
it would also be in this list as well and

197
00:12:28.819 --> 00:12:33.030
you'll see you need to move them over,
just highlighting it isn't enough.

198
00:12:33.030 --> 00:12:35.945
Here you'll need to hit Add and
move it over to the right side and

199
00:12:35.945 --> 00:12:39.180
you'll see that now we're working
with both of those disks.

200
00:12:39.180 --> 00:12:40.476
But that's okay,

201
00:12:40.476 --> 00:12:45.500
I just need at least a minimum of two
disks here to create a spanned volume.

202
00:12:45.500 --> 00:12:46.524
And what does that mean?

203
00:12:46.524 --> 00:12:51.443
Well, the way that the data is actually
stored when you're using spanned volumes,

204
00:12:51.443 --> 00:12:54.492
it doesn't stripe or
right to them in equal parts and

205
00:12:54.492 --> 00:12:59.412
equal amounts that'll will actually fill
them up kind of like just continuously and

206
00:12:59.412 --> 00:13:03.180
then once one disk is full it'll
start working on the other one.

207
00:13:03.180 --> 00:13:08.470
There is something to be said
about spanned volumes here.

208
00:13:08.470 --> 00:13:13.040
We're not implementing any kind
of resiliency or redundancy, so

209
00:13:13.040 --> 00:13:19.250
if disk two were to fail, I would lose all
the data that's in this particular volume.

210
00:13:19.250 --> 00:13:22.000
If disk one were to fail,
I would lose all the data, so

211
00:13:22.000 --> 00:13:23.970
that's definitely something
to consider there.

212
00:13:23.970 --> 00:13:28.530
It's probably not the most
beneficial implementation here but

213
00:13:28.530 --> 00:13:31.770
we'll just hit Next and
you can assign it a drive letter.

214
00:13:31.770 --> 00:13:35.130
We'll just keep this default as G and
hit Next,

215
00:13:35.130 --> 00:13:39.510
you're also able to configure it.

216
00:13:39.510 --> 00:13:44.390
We'll keep the default set as perfect but
I do wanna click perform a quick format

217
00:13:44.390 --> 00:13:47.170
and that's simply because I don't
want you guys to have to wait.

218
00:13:47.170 --> 00:13:49.600
In a production environment,
I wouldn't select this,

219
00:13:49.600 --> 00:13:53.970
I would want it to go ahead and make sure
that that disk was fully formatted there.

220
00:13:53.970 --> 00:14:00.450
We'll hit Next, Finish,
now it's giving me a notification here.

221
00:14:00.450 --> 00:14:03.870
Like I said, what's great about the GUI,
just letting me know, hey,

222
00:14:03.870 --> 00:14:06.900
we're gonna be converting our basic disks.

223
00:14:06.900 --> 00:14:13.210
Remember we said basic disks can not be,
well, on more than one disk.

224
00:14:13.210 --> 00:14:16.030
We've just combined two disks
together to create that volume.

225
00:14:16.030 --> 00:14:20.400
So my volume, now that's it's spanning
across two disks, is not basic anymore.

226
00:14:20.400 --> 00:14:24.160
It's just letting you know, hey now, your
disks are gonna be dynamic, we hit OK.

227
00:14:24.160 --> 00:14:29.450
And the way that the operating system sees

228
00:14:29.450 --> 00:14:33.470
our disks here is kind of interesting,
we'll give it a second to propagate.

229
00:14:33.470 --> 00:14:38.160
We see the color change here and
both of these disks, disk one and

230
00:14:38.160 --> 00:14:43.010
disk two, are now joined together,
they're creating volume G.

231
00:14:43.010 --> 00:14:45.170
So from an operating system standpoint,

232
00:14:45.170 --> 00:14:49.380
if we look up here,
we can get that detailed information.

233
00:14:49.380 --> 00:14:52.850
You don't see additional drives, okay?

234
00:14:52.850 --> 00:14:58.610
You just see it as one, so the end
user would see that as one particular

235
00:14:58.610 --> 00:15:00.750
unit of storage there for that volume.

236
00:15:02.120 --> 00:15:04.980
That's going to be a span drive,
what do we have next?

237
00:15:04.980 --> 00:15:08.274
We have a striped volume and
we can go ahead and

238
00:15:08.274 --> 00:15:12.110
right-click here and
we can just delete this volume.

239
00:15:12.110 --> 00:15:14.280
And like I said though, remember,

240
00:15:14.280 --> 00:15:18.440
if you delete this volume, any information
that's on here is going to be removed,

241
00:15:18.440 --> 00:15:20.720
any information that's on
either one of those drives.

242
00:15:20.720 --> 00:15:24.990
So if you delete either one of
those in this management interface,

243
00:15:24.990 --> 00:15:26.460
you do need to be aware of that.

244
00:15:26.460 --> 00:15:30.370
And it was just prompting us to
remember that little factoid.

245
00:15:30.370 --> 00:15:34.100
Now, let's talk about a striped volume,
all right?

246
00:15:34.100 --> 00:15:37.376
A striped volume,
also sometimes called RAID 0,

247
00:15:37.376 --> 00:15:42.110
simply because it's providing zero
redundancy in this configuration.

248
00:15:42.110 --> 00:15:47.740
We're just striping and
we are striping in an equal manner,

249
00:15:47.740 --> 00:15:53.300
so let's use both or all three of these
disks for our particular stripe here.

250
00:15:53.300 --> 00:15:59.786
Let's bring this one online, and notice
how these disks are different sizes.

251
00:15:59.786 --> 00:16:02.518
And if you think back
to RAID configurations,

252
00:16:02.518 --> 00:16:06.791
if I'm talking about RAID configs,
I need to be using hard disk drives,

253
00:16:06.791 --> 00:16:09.192
physical drives, all of the same size.

254
00:16:09.192 --> 00:16:11.243
Otherwise, I'll be wasting storage.

255
00:16:11.243 --> 00:16:14.332
So if I look at this one 10 gig,
15, and 20 gig,

256
00:16:14.332 --> 00:16:17.300
my common denominator here
is going to be 10 gig.

257
00:16:17.300 --> 00:16:20.000
So that's going to be the most

258
00:16:20.000 --> 00:16:23.940
amount of storage that I can
add to my striped volume here.

259
00:16:23.940 --> 00:16:26.700
And you'll see how we go through and
configure that.

260
00:16:26.700 --> 00:16:30.466
So let's go ahead and
set up a new striped volume.

261
00:16:30.466 --> 00:16:33.050
And again, it will launch our wizard here.

262
00:16:33.050 --> 00:16:37.235
So now you see that we have
brought disk 3 online, and

263
00:16:37.235 --> 00:16:41.152
you can bring both of those
on over to add them too.

264
00:16:41.152 --> 00:16:44.517
And look at this size as well,
you can see how that's increasing here for

265
00:16:44.517 --> 00:16:46.410
the amount that's available.

266
00:16:46.410 --> 00:16:52.000
We'll just keep that as G again,
like from our previous demonstration.

267
00:16:52.000 --> 00:16:55.652
Perform a quick format.

268
00:16:55.652 --> 00:16:58.960
All right, we are good, and finish.

269
00:17:00.180 --> 00:17:01.600
Yes, we're converting to dynamic.

270
00:17:02.950 --> 00:17:03.730
And give it a second.

271
00:17:03.730 --> 00:17:06.100
And you'll notice how
the operating system handles.

272
00:17:06.100 --> 00:17:09.500
I didn't really granularly
specify my sizes there.

273
00:17:09.500 --> 00:17:12.640
So we'll see how it handles it for
us, which is nice.

274
00:17:12.640 --> 00:17:15.445
Notice how for my 15 gig drive here for

275
00:17:15.445 --> 00:17:19.707
disk two I still have five
remaining of unallocated space.

276
00:17:19.707 --> 00:17:24.210
And then for my 20 gig, remember disc
three here was originally 20 gig.

277
00:17:24.210 --> 00:17:28.573
So now I have 10 gigs as my
remainder of unallocated space.

278
00:17:28.573 --> 00:17:36.163
So again, with a striped volume,
all of these drives are necessary for

279
00:17:36.163 --> 00:17:40.602
having and retaining that information.

280
00:17:40.602 --> 00:17:43.752
If one of these drives
were to physically fail,

281
00:17:43.752 --> 00:17:48.478
to have some kind of hardware failure,
I would lose all the information

282
00:17:48.478 --> 00:17:52.210
that's striped here across
all three of these drives.

283
00:17:52.210 --> 00:17:54.270
So that's something to consider, as well.

284
00:17:54.270 --> 00:17:57.580
If you wanted to implement
any kind of resiliency there,

285
00:17:57.580 --> 00:18:00.220
you would need to also add parody.

286
00:18:00.220 --> 00:18:03.190
So we have the ability to do that as well.

287
00:18:03.190 --> 00:18:05.350
Let's just go ahead and
delete this volume so

288
00:18:05.350 --> 00:18:08.930
we can get back to our
unallocated drives here.

289
00:18:08.930 --> 00:18:12.480
And I'll show you how to
create a software RAID-5.

290
00:18:12.480 --> 00:18:17.747
If we right click on one of these drives
and we'll select New RAID-5 Volume.

291
00:18:18.960 --> 00:18:21.423
We'll hit Next.

292
00:18:21.423 --> 00:18:24.980
Minimum of at least three physical
drives for this configuration.

293
00:18:24.980 --> 00:18:26.340
Good thing I have three!

294
00:18:26.340 --> 00:18:29.680
We'll hit add, and next.

295
00:18:29.680 --> 00:18:31.890
Again, the same thing with the storage.

296
00:18:31.890 --> 00:18:35.220
We're only going to be able to effectively
utilize ten gigs of storage in this

297
00:18:35.220 --> 00:18:36.490
configuration.

298
00:18:36.490 --> 00:18:40.670
And we'll hit perform a correct format so
we're not waiting all day and finish.

299
00:18:42.090 --> 00:18:43.760
It's really that easy, guys.

300
00:18:43.760 --> 00:18:44.850
Now remember,

301
00:18:44.850 --> 00:18:48.670
with our RAID-5 configurations,
we do have that parody bit, so we may see

302
00:18:48.670 --> 00:18:52.220
a bit of performance degradation because
we're performing that algorithm there.

303
00:18:52.220 --> 00:18:56.060
But we also reap the benefit
of having that resiliency.

304
00:18:56.060 --> 00:19:02.710
So that would be dependent on why we
would want to go ahead and do that.

305
00:19:02.710 --> 00:19:06.750
And so it's pretty cool that the operating
system will actually be able to detect and

306
00:19:06.750 --> 00:19:12.000
alert you and then go ahead and rebuild
any failed drive that you may have there

307
00:19:12.000 --> 00:19:17.610
as long as you have physically
a replacement drive available as well.

308
00:19:19.050 --> 00:19:23.810
There is one that I don't have here on my
notes but I did see from that drop down

309
00:19:23.810 --> 00:19:26.650
action menu, and it's just gonna
take a little minute to go ahead and

310
00:19:26.650 --> 00:19:29.630
resync and to get these drives configured.

311
00:19:29.630 --> 00:19:30.410
But remember,

312
00:19:31.640 --> 00:19:36.340
it's very simple just like we saw in
these other wizards, how easy it was.

313
00:19:36.340 --> 00:19:39.980
You also have the ability to
create mirroring as well.

314
00:19:39.980 --> 00:19:44.530
And so remember mirroring is just
an exact replication, an exact duplicate.

315
00:19:44.530 --> 00:19:48.520
And when you create a mirrored volume,
it doesn't matter if one of those physical

316
00:19:48.520 --> 00:19:52.650
drives has a failure, because that
information is retained in two spaces.

317
00:19:52.650 --> 00:19:55.361
So there are pros and cons to each, so

318
00:19:55.361 --> 00:20:00.182
the pros being that data resiliency
there with mirrored drives.

319
00:20:00.182 --> 00:20:05.496
Your cons would be the fact that
you're getting 50% of your expense for

320
00:20:05.496 --> 00:20:11.339
your storage there, because you're
only utilizing 50% of that disk space.

321
00:20:11.339 --> 00:20:14.935
Cuz you're paying for two drives and
you're only getting to save to one for

322
00:20:14.935 --> 00:20:15.918
that storage size.

323
00:20:15.918 --> 00:20:19.754
So that would be something
to consider there.

324
00:20:19.754 --> 00:20:22.849
And just a couple other side notes
here when we're talking about volumes.

325
00:20:22.849 --> 00:20:25.315
I have some little tidbits.

326
00:20:25.315 --> 00:20:30.249
In TFS volumes can be expanded and shrunk.

327
00:20:30.249 --> 00:20:34.201
Now, REFSS volumes can only be expanded.

328
00:20:34.201 --> 00:20:37.083
And when we're looking at
our FAT configurations,

329
00:20:37.083 --> 00:20:39.253
those partitions cannot be modified.

330
00:20:39.253 --> 00:20:44.201
And I think that's about it for now,
working in the graphical user interface.

331
00:20:44.201 --> 00:20:50.002
Whenever we come back, I'd like to
introduce some command line tools.

332
00:20:50.002 --> 00:20:53.978
And we'll look at how we can use different
tools to be able to perform the same

333
00:20:53.978 --> 00:20:58.220
functions, and manage and shrink and
expand, but from a different interface.

334
00:20:59.350 --> 00:21:00.150
>> All right, Cherokee.

335
00:21:00.150 --> 00:21:02.410
Well thank you again for
helping us out here.

336
00:21:02.410 --> 00:21:04.330
Taking a look at Disk Management and

337
00:21:04.330 --> 00:21:08.660
the way we can create some of the
different rays that we have right there.

338
00:21:08.660 --> 00:21:13.960
Cherokee showed us how to do the stripe as
well as the span volume and the mirror.

339
00:21:13.960 --> 00:21:14.832
No, did you do the mirror?

340
00:21:14.832 --> 00:21:17.110
>> We didn't show the mirror,
but we could.

341
00:21:17.110 --> 00:21:18.080
But I'm just still waiting.

342
00:21:18.080 --> 00:21:19.981
I was re-syncing here at 70%.

343
00:21:19.981 --> 00:21:21.420
So it's really that easy.

344
00:21:21.420 --> 00:21:22.670
>> Yeah, it's pretty easy.

345
00:21:22.670 --> 00:21:24.100
It's still the same thing.

346
00:21:24.100 --> 00:21:27.760
And the key here also is, especially
in the ones that Cherokee showed you,

347
00:21:27.760 --> 00:21:32.830
is to remember that those disc sizes
pretty much have to be the same size.

348
00:21:32.830 --> 00:21:35.280
The spanned one is probably
the only one where you can actually

349
00:21:35.280 --> 00:21:39.180
take more in one and
less in another if you actually chose to.

350
00:21:39.180 --> 00:21:41.580
But overall though,
you do tend to see that.

351
00:21:41.580 --> 00:21:43.280
>> Ronnie,
I do want to point out one other thing.

352
00:21:43.280 --> 00:21:44.680
The reason we're covering this,

353
00:21:44.680 --> 00:21:49.540
obviously, is because it was called out in
the objectives and this is an exam series.

354
00:21:49.540 --> 00:21:53.960
So I will note that in real life,
yes, you do have these abilities.

355
00:21:53.960 --> 00:21:57.090
Microsoft provided you the ability
to create these configurations

356
00:21:57.090 --> 00:21:58.590
in the operating system.

357
00:21:58.590 --> 00:22:03.010
But in my opinion, it's always better
to perform a physical hardware RAID

358
00:22:03.010 --> 00:22:10.160
configuration and use separate hardware to
go ahead and off-load those computations.

359
00:22:10.160 --> 00:22:15.100
That's my opinion but this is
a Microsoft certification series so

360
00:22:15.100 --> 00:22:16.880
we are covering it that way.

361
00:22:16.880 --> 00:22:18.900
All right, Cherokee,
well that sounds great but

362
00:22:18.900 --> 00:22:21.380
are you sure there's nothing
else you wanna show us?

363
00:22:21.380 --> 00:22:25.940
>> How did you know Ronnie I actually just
had that RAID-5 configuration complete.

364
00:22:25.940 --> 00:22:32.280
So what I can do is I deleted that and
I'll show you here one last little tidbit.

365
00:22:32.280 --> 00:22:37.169
What I wanted to do is show
you how to mount a drive.

366
00:22:37.169 --> 00:22:38.347
So if we right click and

367
00:22:38.347 --> 00:22:42.564
select, just let's say, New Simple Volume
and it will run through the wizard.

368
00:22:42.564 --> 00:22:46.454
I really didn't specify here one of
the options that we do have, and

369
00:22:46.454 --> 00:22:48.470
I just wanna plan that to you.

370
00:22:48.470 --> 00:22:51.138
It's not something that you'll
be doing on a daily, well,

371
00:22:51.138 --> 00:22:52.512
probably not on a daily basis.

372
00:22:52.512 --> 00:22:54.813
But something that may be beneficial,

373
00:22:54.813 --> 00:22:59.208
especially if you wanted to create like
a shared folder and have people from

374
00:22:59.208 --> 00:23:03.550
one department centrally store
informations and we can do that this way.

375
00:23:03.550 --> 00:23:07.850
So, you could select,
Mount the following empty NTFS folder.

376
00:23:09.050 --> 00:23:12.050
You do have to have
a completely empty folder.

377
00:23:12.050 --> 00:23:17.350
You can't mount a drive to a folder
that has other information,

378
00:23:17.350 --> 00:23:18.530
other objects in it.

379
00:23:18.530 --> 00:23:21.930
So I've created a blank
folder called sales, and

380
00:23:21.930 --> 00:23:24.540
we'll just navigate to that sales folder.

381
00:23:24.540 --> 00:23:29.093
i just dropped it straight under my c
drive to make it easy for us here and

382
00:23:29.093 --> 00:23:33.817
you can see that Sales folder that had
been created, and you just hit OK.

383
00:23:33.817 --> 00:23:36.949
And then Next, and
you have all the same options

384
00:23:36.949 --> 00:23:41.268
that we saw previously when we're
running through this wizard.

385
00:23:41.268 --> 00:23:45.025
But the operating system
handles it differently, and

386
00:23:45.025 --> 00:23:48.380
it appears differently to
the end users as well.

387
00:23:48.380 --> 00:23:51.060
So let's go ahead and format that disk.

388
00:23:51.060 --> 00:23:55.000
And, again I've got that notification,
but don't worry about that now.

389
00:23:55.000 --> 00:23:59.960
I wanna show you how the operating
system is actually handling that.

390
00:23:59.960 --> 00:24:06.220
So, if I drilled down to my C drive,
I can actually see that the Sales,

391
00:24:06.220 --> 00:24:10.620
the folder that I had created
is being used as a drive now.

392
00:24:10.620 --> 00:24:15.060
So it's mounted, so you could go ahead and
treat that like a shared folder,

393
00:24:15.060 --> 00:24:16.260
if I wanted to as well.

394
00:24:16.260 --> 00:24:18.910
So that's just one other
option we have there.

395
00:24:18.910 --> 00:24:21.700
And, Ronnie, I promise that's it.

396
00:24:21.700 --> 00:24:22.814
>> All right.
>> For this show.

397
00:24:22.814 --> 00:24:24.710
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right, Cherokee.

398
00:24:24.710 --> 00:24:27.080
Well, once again, thank you for
helping us out and

399
00:24:27.080 --> 00:24:30.110
taking a look at more of the details
inside of disk management.

400
00:24:30.110 --> 00:24:34.207
Showing us the options that we available
to configure the disc in the ways that

401
00:24:34.207 --> 00:24:36.866
we've talked about the spanned and
the striped.

402
00:24:36.866 --> 00:24:40.300
Now even those mount points
that we have available to us.

403
00:24:40.300 --> 00:24:42.940
But that's not all that there
is to this configuration.

404
00:24:42.940 --> 00:24:45.150
Just like everything else in Microsoft.

405
00:24:45.150 --> 00:24:48.830
It also means that there's
a lot of PowerShell to come.

406
00:24:48.830 --> 00:24:53.500
And that is probably what Cherokee's
gonna be showing us as well in

407
00:24:53.500 --> 00:24:55.810
probably the next episode here or so.

408
00:24:55.810 --> 00:24:58.610
So you wanna stay tuned for that as well.

409
00:24:58.610 --> 00:25:02.290
So signing off for ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

410
00:25:02.290 --> 00:25:03.370
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

411
00:25:03.370 --> 00:25:07.655
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the MCSA 70-410 shows.

412
00:25:10.124 --> 00:25:12.173
[MUSIC]

413
00:25:12.173 --> 00:25:18.554
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.title: Storage Spaces
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.133
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.133 --> 00:00:03.427
I'm you host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:03.427 --> 00:00:07.927
[MUSIC]
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:07.927 --> 00:00:12.295
>> Welcome to another great episode right

5
00:00:12.295 --> 00:00:14.551
here on ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:14.551 --> 00:00:19.500
You're watching the MCSA for
Windows Server 2012 R2.

7
00:00:19.500 --> 00:00:22.990
We're specifically going to be
taking a look at exam 70-410.

8
00:00:22.990 --> 00:00:26.800
And we're also going to be taking
a look into storage spaces as well.

9
00:00:26.800 --> 00:00:29.390
And here to help us out, of course,
is going to be miss Cherokee Boose.

10
00:00:29.390 --> 00:00:31.590
Cherokee, welcome back to the show.
>> Thanks for having me.

11
00:00:31.590 --> 00:00:33.540
I'm surprised you haven't
kicked me out yet,

12
00:00:33.540 --> 00:00:36.670
because I know we've been talking
about storage for a long time.

13
00:00:36.670 --> 00:00:38.730
But it's super important, guys.

14
00:00:38.730 --> 00:00:40.760
I wouldn't be stressing it if it wasn't.

15
00:00:40.760 --> 00:00:45.000
Businesses today are relying
on data retention.

16
00:00:45.000 --> 00:00:49.790
There are entire subsets of fields out
there just for this specific purpose,

00:08:25.893 --> 00:08:30.790

00:08:38.726 --> 00:08:43.230

00:08:43.230 --> 00:08:47.427
If you select automatic allocation for

00:08:47.427 --> 00:08:51.776

00:08:51.776 --> 00:08:54.690
the operating system actually sees it.

00:08:54.690 --> 00:08:56.730
It organizes it in two different ways.

148
00:08:56.730 --> 00:09:02.629
So for those configurations like three-way

149
00:09:02.629 --> 00:09:08.610

00:09:08.610 --> 00:09:13.450

So you really need to choose whether

00:09:17.817 --> 00:09:20.550

153
00:09:20.550 --> 00:09:25.223
Automatic allocation is allowing
the operating system to choose how those

154
00:09:25.223 --> 00:09:26.936

155
00:09:26.936 --> 00:09:29.020
And it happens all in the background.

156
00:09:29.020 --> 00:09:33.728
Manual allocation says, I'm going

157
00:09:33.728 --> 00:09:38.528

158
00:09:38.528 --> 00:09:43.322
So out of these three,
perhaps one of them were faster,

00:09:43.322 --> 00:09:46.190
newer, larger than the others.

160
00:09:46.190 --> 00:09:52.090
Maybe that would be the drive that I

161
00:09:52.090 --> 00:09:54.337

162
00:09:54.337 --> 00:09:57.930
So I would have to go in and

00:09:57.930 --> 00:10:00.343
So best practice, pick one, stick with it.

You can configure configurations

00:10:10.490 --> 00:10:11.713
But dual parity and

172
00:10:27.468 --> 00:10:34.580
Now the differences between server 2012
and server 2012 r2 are not always glaring.

173
00:10:34.580 --> 00:10:37.943
When we're talking about storage
pools there are some significant

174
00:10:37.943 --> 00:10:38.950
differences here.

175
00:10:38.950 --> 00:10:41.586
So I would like to go ahead and
call those out.

176
00:10:41.586 --> 00:10:46.186
Storage tiers is a new feature,
storage tiers is really cool.

177
00:10:46.186 --> 00:10:52.799
What I'm doing with storage tiers,
I have the ability to properly,

178
00:10:52.799 --> 00:10:59.426
or I guess I can utilize my hard disk
drives to the best optimization.

179
00:10:59.426 --> 00:11:01.572
I'm basically saying, okay,

180
00:11:01.572 --> 00:11:05.710
what's the smartest way to
work with these drives here?

181
00:11:05.710 --> 00:11:10.001
So in every situation,
like over here on the right-hand side,

182
00:11:10.001 --> 00:11:14.060
I have four spindle drives and
I have two solid state drives.

183
00:11:14.060 --> 00:11:19.127
And maybe that's all my
budget will allow for.

184
00:11:19.127 --> 00:11:22.458
So in comparing apples to apples and
oranges to oranges here, solid state

185
00:11:22.458 --> 00:11:26.128
drives are gonna have higher performance,
faster read and write performance.

186
00:11:26.128 --> 00:11:29.026
So why would I not want
to use my hot data,

187
00:11:29.026 --> 00:11:33.736
the data that I am accessing most
frequently for the solid state?

188
00:11:33.736 --> 00:11:38.909
So I can aggregate and
tell the operating system which drives

189
00:11:38.909 --> 00:11:44.395
are my solid state drives, and
then create a tier, a gold tier.

190
00:11:44.395 --> 00:11:46.611
And there are different naming schemes out
there, you can choose whatever you want.

191
00:11:46.611 --> 00:11:48.905
I just chose these colors here.

192
00:11:48.905 --> 00:11:51.399
But the hot data and those reads and

193
00:11:51.399 --> 00:11:54.850
writes will be happening
on your faster drive.

194
00:11:54.850 --> 00:11:58.194
So data at rest or
data that's not accessed as much,

195
00:11:58.194 --> 00:12:01.086
the operating system
will use a silver tier.

196
00:12:01.086 --> 00:12:05.829
And you can configure those optical
drives to belong as a part of

197
00:12:05.829 --> 00:12:07.540
the silver tier here.

198
00:12:07.540 --> 00:12:09.197
So that's really a cool feature.

199
00:12:09.197 --> 00:12:11.529
Now the second one, write back cache, so

200
00:12:11.529 --> 00:12:14.540
you would have to manually
configure storage tiers.

201
00:12:14.540 --> 00:12:17.977
I'll show you here in a little bit.

202
00:12:17.977 --> 00:12:21.040
But right back cache is something
that happens automatically.

203
00:12:21.040 --> 00:12:23.836
By default the operating
system implements this.

204
00:12:23.836 --> 00:12:28.585
And it's really cool because it
really complements storage tiers.

205
00:12:28.585 --> 00:12:33.080
It takes the vat idea, that concept, but
brings it up a notch to the next level.

206
00:12:33.080 --> 00:12:40.130
So here we're looking at it
on a per type of drive basis.

207
00:12:40.130 --> 00:12:43.259
When you're talking
about right back cache,

208
00:12:43.259 --> 00:12:46.156
you're looking at it on a per drive basis.

209
00:12:46.156 --> 00:12:51.708
So the reads and
writes that are on each individual drive,

210
00:12:51.708 --> 00:12:56.241
they're gonna be creating a buffer there,
and

211
00:12:56.241 --> 00:12:59.540
on that drive, creating a cache.

212
00:12:59.540 --> 00:13:02.763
And those small random rates
are gonna be stored there

213
00:13:02.763 --> 00:13:07.575
before they're moved off to more permanent
storage on each individual drive.

214
00:13:07.575 --> 00:13:11.580
And that works both with mechanical and
solid state drives.

215
00:13:11.580 --> 00:13:16.079
So utilizing both of those
together is a really smart way

216
00:13:16.079 --> 00:13:18.387
to optimize your hardware.

217
00:13:18.387 --> 00:13:22.931
Okay, so with parity it's
like a Rave5 configuration

218
00:13:22.931 --> 00:13:27.572
which utilizes erasure encoding
that really plays off of

219
00:13:27.572 --> 00:13:32.760
that arithmetic there, so
it uses bit-wise arithmetic.

220
00:13:32.760 --> 00:13:35.596
Now with dual parity,
it's more like a Rave6.

221
00:13:35.596 --> 00:13:40.518
And it uses something called read
Solomon error correcting codes

222
00:13:40.518 --> 00:13:43.420
to keep two bitwise parity symbols.

223
00:13:43.420 --> 00:13:48.405
So you're able to suffer from two hard
drive failures instead of just one.

224
00:13:48.405 --> 00:13:50.806
So that's a really cool feature as well.

225
00:13:50.806 --> 00:13:56.620
And the last new feature that I wanted to
cover here, something called auto-rebuild.

226
00:13:56.620 --> 00:13:57.577
And this is pretty cool, too.

227
00:13:57.577 --> 00:14:01.516
And this is another thing
that's happening here behind

228
00:14:01.516 --> 00:14:06.280
the scenes if you have enough
physical space available to you.

229
00:14:06.280 --> 00:14:08.893
So if we could just go full screen for
a moment so

230
00:14:08.893 --> 00:14:11.037
we can look at this portion over here.

231
00:14:11.037 --> 00:14:16.440
So let's say I had disk 1,
disk 2, disk 3 and disk 4.

232
00:14:16.440 --> 00:14:20.026
Perhaps I had a disk failure here for

233
00:14:20.026 --> 00:14:24.700
Well, if I had specified a hot spare,
then all the information, and

234
00:14:24.700 --> 00:14:29.868
we'll just say that the red is what is
currently being used on these drives.

235
00:14:29.868 --> 00:14:35.076
So all of this information would
need to be rebuilt on my hot spare,

236
00:14:35.076 --> 00:14:40.939
which could take some time, depending
on how much information was there.

237
00:14:40.939 --> 00:14:45.148
However, with the advent of auto rebuild,

238
00:14:45.148 --> 00:14:50.153
the information that was
lost here with the disk 2 is

239
00:14:50.153 --> 00:14:55.865
simultaneously dispersed to disk 1,
disk 3 and disk 4.

240
00:14:55.865 --> 00:14:58.621
So you have a faster rebuild time, but

241
00:14:58.621 --> 00:15:04.062
this only happens behind the scenes
if there is enough available storage.

242
00:15:04.062 --> 00:15:08.555
So that's pretty cool to think about that,
yeah.

243
00:15:08.555 --> 00:15:09.871
And I think that's about it for

00:15:09.871 --> 00:15:12.979
the new features here.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue with storage spaces configurations.  Cherokee demonstrates how to configure additional storage spaces types using the GUI.  She uses powershell to configure storage tiers.   Also she shows how to set the media type so that storage spaces can effectively differentiate between HDD and SSDs.  Storage Tiers can use this to optimize the use of disks dependent upon the media.

episodes.description: In this show, Ronnie and Cherokee observe issues that may arise post configuration. Ronnie explains what configuration drift is and explains how Desired State Configuration can help combat it. He also explains the two deployment types, push and pull.

It's because it is a standards based type

00:20:26.080 --> 00:20:30.630

00:20:30.630 --> 00:20:32.580

And the world is heading

00:20:35.590 --> 00:20:38.150
in which Desired State Configuration

Is really making a big change

00:20:42.531 --> 00:20:45.607
doing this because it does actually

00:20:45.607 --> 00:20:50.006
It simplifies the idea here of being

00:20:50.006 --> 00:20:54.900

Configuration, standardization is

00:21:41.869 --> 00:21:45.741

00:22:08.890 --> 00:22:11.710
There's two real configuration modes for

00:22:11.710 --> 00:22:14.526
There's what we call a pull
configuration mode and

00:22:14.526 --> 00:22:17.678
there's what we call a push

00:22:17.678 --> 00:22:23.080
And if my computer didn't just

00:22:23.080 --> 00:22:25.660
Let's go ahead and

this will,

00:22:37.400 --> 00:22:43.086
Let's take for an example that we have

00:22:43.086 --> 00:22:49.110
A pull configuration mode allows me to

And in that particular mode, there's two

Either it is set up as an SMB server.

An SMB server for a Desired State is just

00:23:14.970 --> 00:23:17.440
I mean, that's what it comes down to.

00:23:17.440 --> 00:23:22.020
You make those configurations that you

00:23:22.020 --> 00:23:26.900
And then, the computers over

00:23:26.900 --> 00:23:28.990
they all go ahead and
go all right, let's go ahead and

00:23:28.990 --> 00:23:32.880
check that, let's make it what

00:23:32.880 --> 00:23:38.320

00:23:38.320 --> 00:23:44.480

00:23:44.480 --> 00:23:48.690
So normally you choose one or the other

00:23:48.690 --> 00:23:53.773
So if you setup IIS,

00:23:53.773 --> 00:23:57.526
Well, this gives us that ability

Ideally, if you do this, you'll also

00:24:06.984 --> 00:24:12.100
your public key infrastructure to

00:24:12.100 --> 00:24:15.180
And you might be wondering,

Well, you don't have to have it, but

These configurations can contain,

00:24:26.340 --> 00:24:27.690
So in that sense,

You also wanna make sure that

00:24:39.880 --> 00:24:43.070
Okay, so that's what you

00:24:43.070 --> 00:24:46.540
Now notice over here, they're all

So in other words, just check it so

00:24:52.420 --> 00:24:55.150
Normally, for us,
the whole idea behind this and

So that's where that term simplifying

00:25:18.450 --> 00:25:22.000
hey, I don't have to do anything,

Along with this, there's really

episodes.description: In this show, Ronnie and Cherokee complete the DSC push deployment. Ronnie demonstrates how to run it and even performs a simulation to mimic a user modifying the operating system. However, DSC proves to be most helpful by auto adjusting the settings back to what was configured in the configuration files.

00:29:41.089 --> 00:29:44.895
look at the way that the screen looks
much more plain than what we see.

513
00:29:44.895 --> 00:29:46.720
But we'll see here okay.

514
00:29:46.720 --> 00:29:51.350
So let me select your icon, and
nothing's even appearing as the graphic.

515
00:29:51.350 --> 00:29:56.427
So to me that's actually a good indication
that everything is actually working here.

516
00:29:58.601 --> 00:30:01.636
And let's see, there it is, Cherokee!

517
00:30:01.636 --> 00:30:05.465
>> I couldn't thwart your evil policies!

518
00:30:05.465 --> 00:30:09.013
[LAUGH]
>> So the Desired State Configuration does

519
00:30:09.013 --> 00:30:10.470
work for us.

520
00:30:10.470 --> 00:30:13.894
Now something like this is
a bit more complex, because

521
00:30:13.894 --> 00:30:18.817
I did tell it to remove a roll-in feature
and I actually told her to remove two.

522
00:30:18.817 --> 00:30:22.051
So if I was smarter,
a smarter man would have actually said

523
00:30:22.051 --> 00:30:25.417
let's just remove one thing
instead of actually doing two.

524
00:30:25.417 --> 00:30:28.336
It might have actually kind of
been a little bit quicker and

525
00:30:28.336 --> 00:30:29.834
everything that it had to do.

526
00:30:29.834 --> 00:30:31.990
But it still carried
through it's still able to-

527
00:30:31.990 --> 00:30:34.295
>> Still able to cross yes.

528
00:30:34.295 --> 00:30:35.300
>> Yup, to help us out.

529
00:30:35.300 --> 00:30:40.407
So you will now see that a push type of
configuration setting fairly easy and

530
00:30:40.407 --> 00:30:41.390
successful.

531
00:30:41.390 --> 00:30:42.812
Now you're saying, easy?

532
00:30:42.812 --> 00:30:47.271
Well, by comparison remember I can
run this against 10 computers,

533
00:30:47.271 --> 00:30:50.381
20 computers, 100 computers if I need to.

534
00:30:50.381 --> 00:30:53.370
And it will do the same thing and
keep that desired state.

535
00:30:53.370 --> 00:30:56.250
If you do something like that though
ideally you would use the pull

536
00:30:56.250 --> 00:30:57.200
method instead.

537
00:30:57.200 --> 00:30:59.671
And then you'd have to
set up a little bit more.

538
00:30:59.671 --> 00:31:03.456
But the concept and
the idea is pretty much the same and

539
00:31:03.456 --> 00:31:06.074
you got to see that here in this show.

540
00:31:06.074 --> 00:31:08.440
So don't overlook this process.

541
00:31:08.440 --> 00:31:12.565
Make sure you always think about scenarios
in which it would be good to use desired

542
00:31:12.565 --> 00:31:15.979
state configuration,
because you're gonna see it from here on.

543
00:31:15.979 --> 00:31:20.352
And, probably all the way though until
the time when Windows Server is no longer

544
00:31:20.352 --> 00:31:21.992
actually out there anymore.

545
00:31:21.992 --> 00:31:26.978
>> Very true, Ronnie, I think just this
past week Microsoft officially announced

546
00:31:26.978 --> 00:31:32.500
the deprecation of what, SCM, so Security
Compliance Manager, I think is the, yeah.

547
00:31:32.500 --> 00:31:35.121
So that tool is not
being supported anymore.

548
00:31:35.121 --> 00:31:40.190
So you're gonna see DSC really step up
to the plate and fill in for SCM, there.

549
00:31:40.190 --> 00:31:42.477
So pretty cool good stuff to know.

550
00:31:42.477 --> 00:31:45.850
It was a little bit of a journey here,
three episodes but we made it.

551
00:31:45.850 --> 00:31:49.312
So thank you for your time Ronnie,
I surely appreciate that, and I appreciate

552
00:31:49.312 --> 00:31:53.270
you being here as well, but stay tuned,
we have more information headed your way.

553
00:31:53.270 --> 00:31:54.784
For this show we'll go ahead and sign out.

554
00:31:54.784 --> 00:31:57.730
Remember I'm your host Cherokee Boise,
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

555
00:31:57.730 --> 00:31:59.600
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

556
00:31:59.600 --> 00:32:05.927
[MUSIC]

557
00:32:05.927 --> 00:32:08.866
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee discuss the use of NIC Teaming in Server 2012.  Cherokee helps us by describing the purpose and use cased for nic teaming in Server 2012.  She also discusses some of the options available that must considered when choosing to do nic teaming.  She differentiates the difference between switch independent and switch dependent teaming and the use of load balancing choices.
episodes.title: NIC Teaming
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.170
Welcome, to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.170 --> 00:00:04.057
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:04.057 --> 00:00:06.626
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.626 --> 00:00:08.467
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.467 --> 00:00:10.670
>> You're watching, ITProTV.

6
00:00:10.670 --> 00:00:15.125
>> Welcome to another,
great episode right here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.125 --> 00:00:19.114
You're watching, the MCSA,
for Windows Server 2012.

8
00:00:19.114 --> 00:00:24.042
Specifically taking a look at exam 70-410,
and I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

9
00:00:24.042 --> 00:00:28.294
today we're gonna be taking a look and
diving into NIC Teaming, and here to

10
00:00:28.294 --> 00:00:32.849
help us to understand the concept of
NIC Teaming better is Ms. Cherokee Boose.

11
00:00:32.849 --> 00:00:34.540
Cherokee, welcome to the show.

12
00:00:34.540 --> 00:00:35.622
>> Thanks for having me Ronnie,
how's it going?

13
00:00:35.622 --> 00:00:36.581
>> It is going well.

14
00:00:36.581 --> 00:00:41.443
Now, Cherokee we're now going into the
realm here of talking about the idea of

15
00:00:41.443 --> 00:00:42.338
NIC Teaming.

16
00:00:42.338 --> 00:00:47.240
First, explain to us why do we, what it
is, and then of course, why do we care?

17
00:00:47.240 --> 00:00:51.280
>> Okay, so NIC Teaming is the ability
to make more than one network

18
00:00:51.280 --> 00:00:55.705
interface card and go ahead and
use it for a couple of different reasons.

19
00:00:55.705 --> 00:00:59.406
You have the option to go ahead and
aggregate band with and or

20
00:00:59.406 --> 00:01:03.342
you can utilize it for
any kind of redundancy fault tolerance.

21
00:01:03.342 --> 00:01:06.325
As a matter of fact,
it goes by several different names.

22
00:01:06.325 --> 00:01:10.245
You may even hear it being
referenced as bandwidth aggregation,

23
00:01:10.245 --> 00:01:14.795
link aggregation, NIC bonding,
NIC teaming, I'm trying to think,

24
00:01:14.795 --> 00:01:18.180
but that's essentially what
we'll be looking at here today.

25
00:01:18.180 --> 00:01:21.318
All right, so Cherokee what is the main
goal behind doing something like that?

26
00:01:21.318 --> 00:01:25.047
So why would I care about bonding the NICs
together or aggregating the bandwidth?

27
00:01:25.047 --> 00:01:26.241
Why is that so important?

28
00:01:26.241 --> 00:01:28.826
>> Okay, so
we have a lot of flexibility here.

29
00:01:28.826 --> 00:01:33.118
We have the ability to use up
to 32 network interface cards-

30
00:01:33.118 --> 00:01:33.720
>> Well there you go.

31
00:01:33.720 --> 00:01:34.624
>> With a physical machine.

32
00:01:34.624 --> 00:01:39.048
So if you think about that for a second
Ronnie, if we have like 1 gigabit per

33
00:01:39.048 --> 00:01:42.351
second network interface cards,
if I can aggregate and

34
00:01:42.351 --> 00:01:46.352
bond them together to work as a unit or
to work as a team essentially,

35
00:01:46.352 --> 00:01:50.872
theoretically I could have,
in that situation, a 32 gigabit pipeline.

36
00:01:50.872 --> 00:01:54.695
So my system will see and
recognize that link as 32 gigs,

37
00:01:54.695 --> 00:01:56.810
instead of just having one gig.

38
00:01:56.810 --> 00:02:01.630
So you could use that for a benefit of
having increased speeds and bandwidth,

39
00:02:01.630 --> 00:02:06.601
however, you can also set it even in a
more simplistic fashion where we just have

40
00:02:06.601 --> 00:02:11.230
one extra network interface card using
it as a backup or standby adapter.

41
00:02:11.230 --> 00:02:13.608
So there's a lot of
different options here.

42
00:02:13.608 --> 00:02:16.840
As a matter of fact,
you have so many options.

43
00:02:16.840 --> 00:02:18.031
I found a book for you.

44
00:02:18.031 --> 00:02:21.609
It is through Microsoft,
if we take a look my screen right here,

45
00:02:21.609 --> 00:02:26.410
there's a link in the show notes, and
they even have two separate books for you.

46
00:02:26.410 --> 00:02:29.814
They're really just Word documents,
but you can see here,

47
00:02:29.814 --> 00:02:34.621
there's a Windows Server 2012 R2 Version,
a guide to go ahead and explain, and

48
00:02:34.621 --> 00:02:39.359
then also a 2012 version, and I would
highly encourage you, if you plan on using

49
00:02:39.359 --> 00:02:43.833
NIC teaming in your environment to go
through their really helpful documents,

50
00:02:43.833 --> 00:02:48.974
and so I have the 2012 version pulled up,
2012 R2 version pulled up right here that

51
00:02:48.974 --> 00:02:53.968
we're looking at, and so throughout this
show I'll be referencing revision 2 here.

52
00:02:53.968 --> 00:02:58.406
So just to give you an idea, and you can
see they go ahead and outline it, and

53
00:02:58.406 --> 00:03:02.916
on the left hand column this is just
a table of contents and everything over on

54
00:03:02.916 --> 00:03:06.745
the left hand side and you can see
that there is really a lot to it.

55
00:03:06.745 --> 00:03:10.971
So I'll be introducing you to these topics
but if you are working in a production

56
00:03:10.971 --> 00:03:14.819
environment I would definitely
encourage you, if you're using some of

57
00:03:14.819 --> 00:03:18.667
the fringe configurations,
the really specific ones, you might wanna

58
00:03:18.667 --> 00:03:22.733
spend a little extra time to really dive
in there and get all the details out.

59
00:03:22.733 --> 00:03:27.571
>> Now Cherokee, actually taking a look
at that list that you see right there

60
00:03:27.571 --> 00:03:31.083
where it says,
what this guide actually addresses,

61
00:03:31.083 --> 00:03:36.154
one of the key points that as you see is
like that third bullet point I believe,

62
00:03:36.154 --> 00:03:40.787
which is also the idea of fail over
algorithms that you actually have.

63
00:03:40.787 --> 00:03:43.506
So underneath that where it says
the following section addresses.

64
00:03:43.506 --> 00:03:45.001
>> Yeah.
>> So that third one, so

65
00:03:45.001 --> 00:03:49.101
not only can we use it of course to
aggregate bandwidth, but for fail over,

66
00:03:49.101 --> 00:03:53.332
and that might be something that if we're
just really coming into the MCSA and

67
00:03:53.332 --> 00:03:57.824
trying to figure out why this is actually
important, failover is a big one because

68
00:03:57.824 --> 00:04:01.858
it can be where you end up buying a single
server, and the NIC goes bad, and

69
00:04:01.858 --> 00:04:05.101
how does this NIC teaming help
us out on that one Cherokee?

70
00:04:05.101 --> 00:04:08.058
>> So what we're trying to do is
eliminate single points of failure.

71
00:04:08.058 --> 00:04:12.384
So by introducing multiple network
interface card you're adding additional

72
00:04:12.384 --> 00:04:13.045
hardware.

73
00:04:13.045 --> 00:04:16.793
So as we go through, and I have some
diagrams that I want to show you, we

74
00:04:16.793 --> 00:04:21.372
should also be aware of additional single
points of failure because that's really,

75
00:04:21.372 --> 00:04:22.152
the endgame.

76
00:04:22.152 --> 00:04:24.908
We're trying to reduce
those points of failure so

77
00:04:24.908 --> 00:04:27.080
we can maintain business continuity.

78
00:04:27.080 --> 00:04:28.634
We don't have any downtime,

79
00:04:28.634 --> 00:04:33.051
especially if we're in an environment,
they're talking high availability, and

80
00:04:33.051 --> 00:04:36.677
some of these configurations
are exactly what that is designed for.

81
00:04:36.677 --> 00:04:39.182
Some of those fringed ones
I was talking about for

82
00:04:39.182 --> 00:04:43.104
really large enterprise environments that,
you may or may not encounter.

83
00:04:43.104 --> 00:04:45.833
A lot of companies may not
have the need for that, but

84
00:04:45.833 --> 00:04:48.007
when we're talking high availability,

85
00:04:48.007 --> 00:04:52.292
this is extremely important when we're
talking about having that hardware up and

86
00:04:52.292 --> 00:04:56.514
running, we can't afford time to have
Cherokee go run to the hardware closet and

87
00:04:56.514 --> 00:04:59.405
grab a different work interface card,
switch it out.

88
00:04:59.405 --> 00:05:02.754
That's just not acceptable in today's age.

89
00:05:02.754 --> 00:05:06.930
So yeah,
we'll talk about those algorithms also.

90
00:05:06.930 --> 00:05:10.580
That's a little more involved,
a little more in depth.

91
00:05:10.580 --> 00:05:13.464
But that information is there
in the document for you, so

92
00:05:13.464 --> 00:05:16.230
if you are trying to decide
which algorithm to choose,

93
00:05:16.230 --> 00:05:19.557
because you do have all that
flexibility all those options here.

94
00:05:19.557 --> 00:05:22.565
>> All right, so Cherokee,
what are we gonna end up taking look at,

95
00:05:22.565 --> 00:05:24.331
as you show us more about NIC Teaming?

96
00:05:24.331 --> 00:05:27.209
>> Okay, let's see here,
let we pull up this up.

97
00:05:27.209 --> 00:05:28.414
If we can take a look at my screen here.

98
00:05:28.414 --> 00:05:32.055
So, NIC Teaming is a feature that
was introduced with Server 2012,

99
00:05:32.055 --> 00:05:33.079
it's really cool.

100
00:05:33.079 --> 00:05:37.573
That doesn't mean that it wasn't
existing prior to Server 2012

101
00:05:37.573 --> 00:05:39.587
operating system, however,

102
00:05:39.587 --> 00:05:45.018
at that point in time it would have been
provided by independent hardware vendors.

103
00:05:45.018 --> 00:05:49.480
So it would have been a third party
solution, but here Microsoft just said,

104
00:05:49.480 --> 00:05:53.380
hey let's go ahead and
integrate this concept right into the OS.

105
00:05:53.380 --> 00:05:57.456
So everything we'll be looking at here
is just straight out of the box sort to

106
00:05:57.456 --> 00:06:00.832
speak, we're not adding any
kind of additional software, so

107
00:06:00.832 --> 00:06:02.058
that's pretty cool.

108
00:06:02.058 --> 00:06:08.025
We're really gonna be taking a look here
about the idea of NIC Teaming, however,

109
00:06:08.025 --> 00:06:14.179
we're not focusing so much on the use in
Hyper-V in a virtualization environment.

110
00:06:14.179 --> 00:06:17.618
Later on the series, there is a section
that really focuses on Hyper-V

111
00:06:17.618 --> 00:06:21.320
configurations, and so
we'll spend a little bit more time there.

112
00:06:21.320 --> 00:06:23.940
So I just want you to be aware that,
like I said,

113
00:06:23.940 --> 00:06:28.347
you can have up to 32 network interface
cards on a physical host, two for VMs.

114
00:06:28.347 --> 00:06:30.724
There are some limitations there.

115
00:06:30.724 --> 00:06:36.018
Microsoft does not support utilizing
any kind of nested teaming structure,

116
00:06:36.018 --> 00:06:41.320
not to say that it can't work, but
they definitely do not recommend that.

117
00:06:41.320 --> 00:06:45.410
They do not recommend having more
than one team per server as well.

118
00:06:46.410 --> 00:06:48.996
The OS is not just gonna recognize
those independent teams and

119
00:06:48.996 --> 00:06:50.694
there could be serious problems there.

120
00:06:50.694 --> 00:06:52.584
It's not recommended, but

121
00:06:52.584 --> 00:06:57.000
there are a couple different ways
that we can actually set this up.

122
00:06:57.000 --> 00:06:59.262
It's really not difficult to set up
at all and you guys will see that,

123
00:06:59.262 --> 00:06:59.972
we'll run through.

124
00:06:59.972 --> 00:07:02.024
We have a couple options there.

125
00:07:02.024 --> 00:07:06.722
Just like everything else you've seen
within this series you have the ability to

126
00:07:06.722 --> 00:07:11.005
set it up via the GUI right there within
server manager or you can set it up,

127
00:07:11.005 --> 00:07:15.082
and manage it, and maintain it as
well right through PowerShell, and

128
00:07:15.082 --> 00:07:16.772
here's a command for that.

129
00:07:16.772 --> 00:07:18.209
I had to put it in quotations.

130
00:07:18.209 --> 00:07:20.635
I can't get the font color to change
here without changing everything.

131
00:07:20.635 --> 00:07:27.250
So just so you see that this is gonna be
the particular commandlit to go ahead and

132
00:07:27.250 --> 00:07:34.283
create a new, and you'll see here it
says NETlbfo, so that's another name.

133
00:07:34.283 --> 00:07:40.268
That's gonna be Microsoft's terminology
here for load balancing fail over.

134
00:07:40.268 --> 00:07:43.169
So, that's what LBFO stands for.

135
00:07:43.169 --> 00:07:46.909
So, when you see that command and you're
like, I told you it has a lot of names and

136
00:07:46.909 --> 00:07:48.676
that's just another example there.

137
00:07:48.676 --> 00:07:51.319
So, it really depends on which
vendor you're speaking to.

138
00:07:51.319 --> 00:07:53.653
So, I'll try to incorporate
that here as well.

139
00:07:53.653 --> 00:07:56.559
So, okay This is maybe
an industry standard name and

140
00:07:56.559 --> 00:07:58.484
this is a Microsoft terminology.

141
00:07:58.484 --> 00:08:02.232
>> Now Cherokee looking at the idea of
this command and the idea of PowerShell

142
00:08:02.232 --> 00:08:06.646
again, I know that we've emphasized this,
and we're probably gonna be emphasizing

143
00:08:06.646 --> 00:08:10.410
the use of PowerShell, why is it so
important that we actually know both?

144
00:08:11.470 --> 00:08:16.142
>> So, just like everything else we've
mentioned Microsoft's heading that way

145
00:08:16.142 --> 00:08:20.116
towards a more command line interface
driven management option and

146
00:08:20.116 --> 00:08:21.455
this is no exception.

147
00:08:21.455 --> 00:08:25.938
Here with NIC teaming,
we're able to go ahead and manage other,

148
00:08:25.938 --> 00:08:29.199
utilising power show and
even server manager,

149
00:08:29.199 --> 00:08:33.927
we have the ability to remote manage,
and from an exam perspective,

150
00:08:33.927 --> 00:08:39.091
I don't know what else to tell you here
[LAUGH] without really cluing you in.

151
00:08:39.091 --> 00:08:43.635
It's very important to know these cmdlets
and not just isolate it here to NIC

152
00:08:43.635 --> 00:08:48.690
teaming, but in everything that we've
covered so far, and will cover so.

153
00:08:48.690 --> 00:08:52.238
>> So the example that you showed us right
there on the screen where it actually

154
00:08:52.238 --> 00:08:55.728
does have that, what you have right
there right is the cmdlet itself, and

155
00:08:55.728 --> 00:08:59.479
then that first one in team one, that's
just an example of a name you can make.

156
00:08:59.479 --> 00:09:02.880
>> Yeah I just have some generic names
here, not anything too creative.

157
00:09:02.880 --> 00:09:05.770
So if I had had a team created,
this would be the name.

158
00:09:05.770 --> 00:09:09.450
I just put team one, and then for your
different adapters that you have in your

159
00:09:09.450 --> 00:09:12.670
system, and I just had two here,
Ethernet and Ethernet 2, but

160
00:09:12.670 --> 00:09:16.700
if you wanted to be a little more
creative you could even specify by that

161
00:09:16.700 --> 00:09:20.800
particular manufacturer or something,
or the speed even if you wanted to.

162
00:09:22.000 --> 00:09:24.850
We do have two different modes
that I'd like to explain here.

163
00:09:24.850 --> 00:09:28.090
We have one called active active and
active passive.

164
00:09:28.090 --> 00:09:31.750
If we could go fullscreen for one moment,
it's kind of right there behind my head.

165
00:09:31.750 --> 00:09:35.290
Because this is the Microsoft's
terminology that you'll see

166
00:09:35.290 --> 00:09:38.040
even in the GUI, it's called standby mode.

167
00:09:38.040 --> 00:09:42.171
So, let's go ahead and
take a look at active active first and

168
00:09:42.171 --> 00:09:44.520
then we'll get to standby there.

169
00:09:44.520 --> 00:09:48.186
So in this particular
example I have a switch here,

170
00:09:48.186 --> 00:09:51.779
and I have two physical
network interface cards.

171
00:09:51.779 --> 00:09:55.517
So let's say these were inside
of a server right here, and

172
00:09:55.517 --> 00:09:59.486
each one of those network
interface cards had a 1Gbps speed,

managed by that operating system.

00:24:03.181 --> 00:24:07.355
So you're gonna be presented with the
option to choose, well, how do you want

399
00:24:07.355 --> 00:24:11.640
the operating system to handle load
balancing for that egress traffic?

400
00:24:11.640 --> 00:24:13.750
So let's take a look here
on my screen again, and

401
00:24:13.750 --> 00:24:17.620
l wanna show you some of the balancing
modes that you would be presented with.

402
00:24:17.620 --> 00:24:22.200
So this is going to provide you balancing
modes to provide the operating system

403
00:24:22.200 --> 00:24:27.040
control of outgoing traffic
regardless of using a software or

404
00:24:27.040 --> 00:24:30.870
hard based solution, and they're just
talking about a virtual NIC versus

405
00:24:30.870 --> 00:24:33.370
an actual physical network
interface card here.

406
00:24:33.370 --> 00:24:37.601
So you have a couple different options,
and this is like what Ronnie had mentioned

407
00:24:37.601 --> 00:24:40.257
and pointed out in the very
beginning of this show.

408
00:24:40.257 --> 00:24:43.839
Those different load
balancing algorithm options.

409
00:24:43.839 --> 00:24:47.753
So address hashing, so this can be
done a couple of different ways.

410
00:24:47.753 --> 00:24:50.854
Which you really don't need
to go this far into it and

411
00:24:50.854 --> 00:24:54.180
know the different hash
algorithms that are utilized.

412
00:24:54.180 --> 00:24:58.285
But it divides traffic based by
the IP address port and more.

413
00:24:58.285 --> 00:25:01.164
And what that means is, so for instance,

414
00:25:01.164 --> 00:25:05.540
there are three different
types here that we can use.

415
00:25:05.540 --> 00:25:10.740
There's a transport ports option that
utilizes the TCP port and the UDP port,

416
00:25:10.740 --> 00:25:15.240
plus the destination IP address
to go ahead and create that hash.

417
00:25:15.240 --> 00:25:18.779
And that hash is used to separate the load
balancing there, there's a couple others,

418
00:25:18.779 --> 00:25:20.147
let me just look at my notes here.

419
00:25:20.147 --> 00:25:23.335
IP address.

420
00:25:23.335 --> 00:25:28.053
It creates less streams, but
it's less balanced because the way

421
00:25:28.053 --> 00:25:33.290
that it's configured there,
it just utilizes the IP addresses.

422
00:25:33.290 --> 00:25:34.600
And then there's also one for

423
00:25:34.600 --> 00:25:38.670
MAC addressing that uses MAC
addresses to create those hashes.

424
00:25:38.670 --> 00:25:41.950
But it's really not recommended for
IP traffic.

425
00:25:41.950 --> 00:25:44.696
You would use that for
Layer 2 transmissions as well.

426
00:25:44.696 --> 00:25:48.083
So, like I said, you don't really need
to know those, but just know that there

427
00:25:48.083 --> 00:25:51.570
are different options here for
your address hashes for that algorithm.

428
00:25:51.570 --> 00:25:56.380
Now the last two are going to be, I
mentioned them on another previous slide,

429
00:25:56.380 --> 00:26:01.190
these two options for load balancing
are only going to be available if you're

430
00:26:01.190 --> 00:26:06.751
utilizing virtual network interface cards,
so if you're using a virtual option here.

431
00:26:06.751 --> 00:26:10.906
So you have Hyper-V Port, which divides
traffic based on that virtual machine.

432
00:26:10.906 --> 00:26:13.362
And this last option here, Dynamic,

433
00:26:13.362 --> 00:26:18.440
you're only gonna see this if you're
running server 2012 R2 or higher.

434
00:26:18.440 --> 00:26:21.360
It's not available on just regular 2012,
so

435
00:26:21.360 --> 00:26:25.200
you won't even see that option available.

436
00:26:25.200 --> 00:26:28.261
Which is nice if you're running
through the wizard, and you'll see

437
00:26:28.261 --> 00:26:31.864
in a few moments when we get into that
option, it's not even gonna be available.

438
00:26:31.864 --> 00:26:34.606
It's not gonna allow you to select
it because it just says hey,

439
00:26:34.606 --> 00:26:38.930
you don't have a system or an environment
and configuration that will support this.

440
00:26:38.930 --> 00:26:44.083
Now, when you look at Dynamic here,
load balancing, it takes

441
00:26:44.083 --> 00:26:50.319
the best of both worlds, these two
prior modes and combines them together.

442
00:26:50.319 --> 00:26:54.685
So it's recommended that if you
are running 2012 R2 or later,

443
00:26:54.685 --> 00:26:59.980
that you go ahead and use dynamic load
balancing for your virtual machines there.

444
00:26:59.980 --> 00:27:03.650
So it can move the actual network
streams between network cards and

445
00:27:03.650 --> 00:27:08.050
choose which path is gonna
be the fastest for you and

446
00:27:08.050 --> 00:27:11.490
the best path, so it provides
that extra load balancing there.

447
00:27:11.490 --> 00:27:16.270
So those are gonna be your main
options when it comes to configuring.

448
00:27:16.270 --> 00:27:18.535
And I think that's what we should do next,

449
00:27:18.535 --> 00:27:21.540
is actually get in there,
show you how it's done.

450
00:27:21.540 --> 00:27:26.090
>> All right, Cherokee, we definitely want
to make sure that we understand as well as

451
00:27:26.090 --> 00:27:30.340
configure the idea of NIC teaming, but
we are out of time for this episode.

452
00:27:30.340 --> 00:27:33.494
So we'll actually make that up
in another episode as well.

453
00:27:33.494 --> 00:27:36.504
And that way we can show you all the stuff
that we've been talking about here.

454
00:27:36.504 --> 00:27:40.597
Remember that what we took a look at here,
right, is understanding the idea behind

455
00:27:40.597 --> 00:27:44.581
NIC teaming and why we would choose to do
it, as well as the options that you have.

456
00:27:44.581 --> 00:27:46.995
Whether it's active-active or
active-passive and

457
00:27:46.995 --> 00:27:50.404
depending on whether you're actually
needing to do load balancing one way or

458
00:27:50.404 --> 00:27:53.580
another way or link aggregation one way or
another way as well.

459
00:27:53.580 --> 00:27:56.931
Those are some of the options that
you have to consider when you

460
00:27:56.931 --> 00:27:58.547
are getting ready to do this.

461
00:27:58.547 --> 00:28:01.376
Some of those options include whether you
want the operating system to handle it or

462
00:28:01.376 --> 00:28:03.280
whether you want
the switches to handle it.

463
00:28:03.280 --> 00:28:08.150
All of these are actually things that
you just, at least in getting ready for

464
00:28:08.150 --> 00:28:08.660
the exam,

465
00:28:08.660 --> 00:28:12.640
make sure you have a solid understanding
of the options that are available to you.

466
00:28:12.640 --> 00:28:16.290
But we do have the configuration to go and
that means we are actually going to end

467
00:28:16.290 --> 00:28:19.740
this episode and
start on another one very soon.

468
00:28:19.740 --> 00:28:24.190
So signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

469
00:28:24.190 --> 00:28:25.340
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

470
00:28:25.340 --> 00:28:31.036
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the MCSA 70-410 shows.

471
00:28:31.036 --> 00:28:36.950
[MUSIC]

472
00:28:36.950 --> 00:28:40.101
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee show us how to get nic teaming configured.  Cherokee demonstrates configuring the nic teaming using the server manager graphical interface as well as how to change the options.  She also take the time to demonstrate the configuration using powershell too, showing how to configure, change and verify nic teaming.
episodes.title: NIC Teaming Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee discuss and show configure NTFS permissions.  Cherokee explains that permissions are normally inherited from the root of the file system to subfolders below it.  Also, she explains and demonstrates what happens to permissions when you create a new subfolder and add a group to it.  When using NTFS permissions with users and a groups, these permissions may be cumulative if the user is a member of multiple groups, with the exception of denies, says Cherokee.  Lastly, she demonstrates how to disable inheritance and remove a group from the DACL.
episodes.title: Configure NTFS Permissions

that you want to pay attention to,
