00:21:32.410 --> 00:21:36.730
depending on where this object actually
is and what ends up happening here.

342
00:21:36.730 --> 00:21:42.010
Because if you remove this and you have
a user that really needs to access this,

343
00:21:42.010 --> 00:21:44.300
and you just do the disable inheritance.

344
00:21:44.300 --> 00:21:49.740
You're literally removing that group and
that inheritance part where

345
00:21:49.740 --> 00:21:53.930
that person that's not gonna be attached
to that host group or whatever it is.

346
00:21:53.930 --> 00:21:55.558
Well, they won't get any access at all.

347
00:21:55.558 --> 00:21:57.459
So, you wanna be careful before
you go ahead and just go,

348
00:21:57.459 --> 00:21:59.135
let me just disable the inheritance and
go [LAUGH].

349
00:21:59.135 --> 00:22:01.220
>> That's right, yeah.

350
00:22:01.220 --> 00:22:05.340
And that's the thing is because you have
to think about any sub folders that may be

351
00:22:05.340 --> 00:22:08.470
included in that particular folder
that you're modifying here.

352
00:22:08.470 --> 00:22:14.140
So That's definitely something to think
about when modifying these permissions.

353
00:22:14.140 --> 00:22:18.470
So for us because we know we are not
dependent on these users group and

354
00:22:18.470 --> 00:22:21.725
we have created our own groups
within Active Directory.

355
00:22:21.725 --> 00:22:25.075
We're gonna go ahead and
jump off the edge here.

356
00:22:25.075 --> 00:22:26.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> And we'll hit Remove.

357
00:22:27.600 --> 00:22:28.410
And it's saying that,

358
00:22:28.410 --> 00:22:32.730
I can't remove this because the object is
inheriting permissions from it's parent.

359
00:22:32.730 --> 00:22:36.020
>> Yeah you'll have to disable
inheritance first. >> So, yeah.

360
00:22:36.020 --> 00:22:37.495
Let's go ahead and do that.

361
00:22:37.495 --> 00:22:41.470
Now, this is kind of interesting, I have
two options here and let's take a look at

362
00:22:41.470 --> 00:22:44.110
those because that's kind of what
Ronnie was referencing right there.

363
00:22:44.110 --> 00:22:47.620
It kinds of reminds you, it says,
hey, you have the ability to convert

364
00:22:47.620 --> 00:22:52.820
those inherited permissions into
explicit permissions on this object.

365
00:22:52.820 --> 00:22:53.830
What does that mean?

366
00:22:53.830 --> 00:22:59.190
Well, those explicit permissions
equate to those block check boxes,

367
00:22:59.190 --> 00:23:02.370
meaning I have the ability to modify them.

368
00:23:02.370 --> 00:23:04.730
With those inherited, I can't modify them.

369
00:23:04.730 --> 00:23:07.450
Those gray check boxes,
I can't change those.

370
00:23:07.450 --> 00:23:10.980
So those are inherited versus
explicit are going to be

371
00:23:10.980 --> 00:23:13.320
assigned to that object directly.

372
00:23:13.320 --> 00:23:16.550
They're block checks,
and I can modify them.

373
00:23:16.550 --> 00:23:18.930
And this is what Ronnie
was saying right here.

374
00:23:18.930 --> 00:23:22.520
Hey, do you wanna remove all inherited
permissions from this object?

375
00:23:22.520 --> 00:23:25.220
So that's something that you
should think about because

376
00:23:25.220 --> 00:23:28.580
you may end up losing some
of that access capability.

377
00:23:30.300 --> 00:23:34.330
Either way here, because we plan on
deleting them, it's not a big deal.

378
00:23:34.330 --> 00:23:40.191
But my best practice would be to
convert the inherited permissions and

379
00:23:40.191 --> 00:23:43.181
then you have the option to choose.

380
00:23:43.181 --> 00:23:48.660
So like I said, you're not just
jumping off the edge there.

381
00:23:48.660 --> 00:23:52.280
You do have a little bit more control
whenever you select this first option.

382
00:23:52.280 --> 00:23:54.220
And I'll show you what
I'm talking about here.

383
00:23:54.220 --> 00:23:58.590
So if we do select that then
the permissions still exists and

384
00:23:58.590 --> 00:24:02.170
I have the ability to go back in and
configure them if I chose to do so.

385
00:24:03.330 --> 00:24:06.000
And then for
the special permission, same thing.

386
00:24:08.170 --> 00:24:12.770
Okay, we can see that this information
has already been blocked by inheritance.

387
00:24:12.770 --> 00:24:14.790
So I'm gonna hit Apply.

388
00:24:14.790 --> 00:24:16.944
>> And now look at that
fourth column again, right?

389
00:24:16.944 --> 00:24:19.060
It's no longer listed to see, yeah.
>> Where is it inherited from?

390
00:24:19.060 --> 00:24:19.920
Exactly.

391
00:24:19.920 --> 00:24:21.890
So it doesn't have that inheritance here.

392
00:24:23.130 --> 00:24:24.653
We'll hit OK.

393
00:24:24.653 --> 00:24:28.650
And now because we selected
that first option there.

394
00:24:28.650 --> 00:24:34.060
And these are explicit, if I go into Edit,
I do have the ability to actually change

395
00:24:34.060 --> 00:24:37.840
and remove these at this particular, if I
click on the right group, that'll help.

396
00:24:37.840 --> 00:24:39.000
But now you can see,

397
00:24:39.000 --> 00:24:44.780
look I can deselect these objects whereas
before I didn't have that option.

398
00:24:44.780 --> 00:24:47.146
And if I were to select Apply.

399
00:24:47.146 --> 00:24:49.815
And now because those
permissions have been removed,

400
00:24:49.815 --> 00:24:52.900
I'm able to actually remove
that access control entry.

401
00:24:52.900 --> 00:24:58.220
So it's a lot of work to go ahead and
remove that but once you get

402
00:24:58.220 --> 00:25:02.920
your groups setup within Active Directory
and have a good solid understanding.

403
00:25:02.920 --> 00:25:07.690
In most companies, they usually use
departments or geographical locations but

404
00:25:07.690 --> 00:25:09.940
that's up to you on how
you wanna configure that.

405
00:25:09.940 --> 00:25:12.100
Now, I should be able to go ahead and

406
00:25:12.100 --> 00:25:17.460
remove these users and
there you have it, it's gone.

407
00:25:17.460 --> 00:25:18.850
So at this point in time,

408
00:25:18.850 --> 00:25:22.980
we really need to focus on how we're
managing our host and manger's group.

409
00:25:22.980 --> 00:25:24.680
And I'll show you when we come back,

410
00:25:24.680 --> 00:25:28.870
I know we're getting close on time,
logging in and out with different users.

411
00:25:28.870 --> 00:25:31.890
And how these permissions
that we just set are gonna be

412
00:25:31.890 --> 00:25:33.429
affecting our individual users.

413
00:25:34.942 --> 00:25:38.380
All right Cherokee, well thank you again
for helping us to understand a little bit

414
00:25:38.380 --> 00:25:41.580
about the configuration
of NTFS permissions.

415
00:25:41.580 --> 00:25:45.830
There is a lot more for us to see, but
at least we got the beginnings here.

416
00:25:45.830 --> 00:25:48.310
We understand that those permissions
are set either at the file or

417
00:25:48.310 --> 00:25:51.370
the folder level, but
when you do have users and

418
00:25:51.370 --> 00:25:55.240
groups that are combined, you need to
be careful in the way that they're set.

419
00:25:55.240 --> 00:25:57.820
So, here Cherokee is
getting that setup for us.

420
00:25:57.820 --> 00:26:01.760
And we are looking forward to
seeing another part of the NTFS

421
00:26:01.760 --> 00:26:03.290
configuration as well.

422
00:26:03.290 --> 00:26:05.990
Well, this is a great place for
us to end this episode then.

423
00:26:05.990 --> 00:26:09.520
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

424
00:26:09.520 --> 00:26:10.540
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

425
00:26:10.540 --> 00:26:15.858
>> Stay tune right here, for
more of the MCSA 70-410 shows.

426
00:26:15.858 --> 00:26:21.797
[MUSIC]

427
00:26:21.797 --> 00:26:27.800
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee show an example of configuring ntfs permissions.  Cherokee demonstrates adding the groups and explains the permissions that should control access to a folder.  She uses different users to log in with different permissions to demonstrate how it works.
episodes.title: Configure NTFS Permissions Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.099
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.099 --> 00:00:06.195
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.195 --> 00:00:08.498
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.498 --> 00:00:12.610
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.610 --> 00:00:16.195
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.195 --> 00:00:20.130
You're watching the MCSA for
Windows Server 2012 R2.

7
00:00:20.130 --> 00:00:23.680
And we're specifically
addressing exam 70-410.

8
00:00:23.680 --> 00:00:28.560
Right in the middle of a little mini
series on configuring NTFS permissions and

9
00:00:28.560 --> 00:00:30.990
here to continue with us is gonna be Ms.
Cherokee Boose.

10
00:00:30.990 --> 00:00:32.390
Cherokee, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:32.390 --> 00:00:34.919
>> Thanks for
having me in this mini series here Ronnie.

12
00:00:34.919 --> 00:00:38.753
>> [LAUGH] All right Cherokee, so
as we took a look at it last time,

13
00:00:38.753 --> 00:00:41.880
we did address kind of
some of the major issues.

14
00:00:41.880 --> 00:00:45.480
But we were in the middle of
configuring a few things, as well.

15
00:00:45.480 --> 00:00:49.840
So Cherokee, take us through what we
kind of basically talked about but

16
00:00:49.840 --> 00:00:51.330
what we're gonna be picking up on now.

17
00:00:51.330 --> 00:00:54.627
>> Okay, Ronnie, so let's just recap
because we did cover quite a bit.

18
00:00:54.627 --> 00:00:57.520
And I know there's a lot to think about
when we're talking about permissions.

19
00:00:57.520 --> 00:00:58.870
So if we could take a look at my screen.

20
00:00:58.870 --> 00:01:03.620
I'll show you a very simple way
that we can just review information

21
00:01:03.620 --> 00:01:06.270
associated with a particular object.

22
00:01:06.270 --> 00:01:08.870
So if you Right Click > Properties,

23
00:01:08.870 --> 00:01:12.700
this will bring up the ability
to access our Security tab.

24
00:01:14.680 --> 00:01:19.880
From here, I can select Advanced, and
this is where I'll be able to identify

25
00:01:19.880 --> 00:01:26.540
the effective access on a per user,
per group or per device basis.

26
00:01:26.540 --> 00:01:32.200
So let's see here for effective access,
we'll go ahead and click on this tab.

27
00:01:32.200 --> 00:01:35.510
This is where you see that per user or
group option and

28
00:01:35.510 --> 00:01:38.230
this is that device option there, so

29
00:01:38.230 --> 00:01:42.860
what we wanna check is Ronnie's status
with his effective permissions.

30
00:01:42.860 --> 00:01:47.507
So what the operating system does is
identify what groups Ronnie as a part of,

31
00:01:47.507 --> 00:01:52.439
and they don't really tell me which groups
Ronnie as a part of in this screen here,

32
00:01:52.439 --> 00:01:56.314
you would need to look in
Active Directory users and computers.

33
00:01:56.314 --> 00:01:58.650
But that's really not what
we're trying to check here.

34
00:01:58.650 --> 00:02:01.340
We're really trying to check what
permissions does Ronnie have.

35
00:02:01.340 --> 00:02:06.811
And because remember, they are cumulative,
the operating system is going to take

36
00:02:06.811 --> 00:02:12.297
that information that higher precedence
and then deliver that information to us.

37
00:02:12.297 --> 00:02:18.578
So let's select a user and
here I'll put in Ronnie's login name.

38
00:02:18.578 --> 00:02:22.103
We'll select check names and
I just have to authenticate.

39
00:02:28.302 --> 00:02:29.842
I can remember my password.

40
00:02:29.842 --> 00:02:33.000
All right, so here we have Ronnie,
right there as our domain member and

41
00:02:33.000 --> 00:02:34.215
we'll just select OK.

42
00:02:36.480 --> 00:02:40.930
And now because we can Ronnie
has been selected here,

43
00:02:40.930 --> 00:02:45.970
we're going to select view
effective access and scroll down.

44
00:02:45.970 --> 00:02:49.380
Let me just full screen this and.

45
00:02:50.410 --> 00:02:53.330
So, Ronnie has got quite
a bit of permissions here.

46
00:02:53.330 --> 00:02:57.980
We can look at those really granular
components that we have here.

47
00:02:57.980 --> 00:03:02.430
And see what Ronnie does have access to,
these green check marks.

48
00:03:02.430 --> 00:03:09.030
And if you look really closely, you can,
gosh, maybe if you can see that.

49
00:03:09.030 --> 00:03:12.170
You can see that these permissions,
they have the little symbol for

50
00:03:12.170 --> 00:03:16.320
the group next to them, so
that's implying where these permissions

51
00:03:16.320 --> 00:03:18.880
are coming from for
Ronnie's account there.

52
00:03:20.220 --> 00:03:24.200
However, we have some permissions that
are not allowed as far as deleting and

53
00:03:24.200 --> 00:03:28.020
taking ownership which is another
thing that I would like to point out.

54
00:03:28.020 --> 00:03:31.920
If I were to assign Ronnie full control,
he would have

55
00:03:31.920 --> 00:03:36.920
the ability to take ownership and
delete those sub folders and files.

56
00:03:36.920 --> 00:03:44.150
Currently, the owner of this show ideas
folder, we can see is the administrator.

57
00:03:44.150 --> 00:03:45.690
Here, all right?

58
00:03:45.690 --> 00:03:49.890
For the local machine, SVR 02,
that's my server here.

59
00:03:49.890 --> 00:03:54.380
If Ronnie had the ability, the full
control permission, he could change it and

60
00:03:54.380 --> 00:03:56.960
make himself, in fact,
the owner if he choose to do so.

61
00:03:56.960 --> 00:04:02.220
So that's also another perk of
having that full control permission.

62
00:04:02.220 --> 00:04:06.650
So if we wanted to check someone else out,
let's see, we'll just hit Cancel here.

63
00:04:06.650 --> 00:04:10.760
Oops, I probably should have
just not backed out completely.

64
00:04:10.760 --> 00:04:13.170
But we can check another user like Zach.

65
00:04:13.170 --> 00:04:18.130
So we'll just put his information
in here and select check names.

66
00:04:20.560 --> 00:04:24.050
And hit OK and
view Zach's effective permissions.

67
00:04:24.050 --> 00:04:25.970
Scroll down and
again we'll full screen that.

68
00:04:27.590 --> 00:04:32.020
And notice how Zack has
significantly less permissions here.

69
00:04:32.020 --> 00:04:36.960
We have that he's able to create files and
write, as well as creating folders and

70
00:04:36.960 --> 00:04:40.650
append it with data,
as well as writing attributes, and

71
00:04:40.650 --> 00:04:42.360
writing extended attributes.

72
00:04:42.360 --> 00:04:47.610
So we see, Zack is more limited and that's
what we wanna verify here with our test.

73
00:04:47.610 --> 00:04:50.720
But I do wanna show you
another tab that we have here.

74
00:04:50.720 --> 00:04:53.000
And this is called the Auditing tab.

75
00:04:53.000 --> 00:04:57.590
Because we haven't really
accessed this folder as of yet,

76
00:04:57.590 --> 00:04:59.790
there's nothing in this Auditing tab.

77
00:04:59.790 --> 00:05:04.640
This is going to be our log and it
should contain information about who was

78
00:05:04.640 --> 00:05:08.630
able to access that, and
what time have that user's name.

79
00:05:08.630 --> 00:05:13.410
So this is something that we could use for
well, auditing purposes just to make sure

80
00:05:13.410 --> 00:05:17.530
that the right individuals are actually
accessing this information.

81
00:05:17.530 --> 00:05:18.460
So who knows?

82
00:05:18.460 --> 00:05:21.793
We might come back and
take a look at this just to verify once

83
00:05:21.793 --> 00:05:25.689
we've logged in as Ronnie and Zach,
so let's go ahead and do that.

84
00:05:25.689 --> 00:05:29.900
I'll close out of here and
just back out and go ahead and log off.

85
00:05:31.230 --> 00:05:36.350
So first,
I would like to log on as Zack and

86
00:05:36.350 --> 00:05:40.100
if I can get logged in here.

87
00:05:41.368 --> 00:05:44.080
All right, [LAUGH] so
let's go ahead and log in as Zack and

88
00:05:44.080 --> 00:05:47.010
see if we can perform
the functions that we need to.

89
00:05:47.010 --> 00:05:51.700
So I need to make sure I'm
logging on as our ITPro demo

90
00:05:51.700 --> 00:05:56.190
domain backslash, and
his login is Z-M-E-M-O-S.

91
00:05:56.190 --> 00:05:59.750
And then we'll put in his super
secret password and log in.

92
00:06:02.300 --> 00:06:06.700
Now, the first thing we wanna do
is actually create a document.

93
00:06:06.700 --> 00:06:11.399
So let's just create
a simple text file here and

94
00:06:11.399 --> 00:06:14.817
say, hey these are my show ideas.

95
00:06:14.817 --> 00:06:16.710
Did I go too fast, is that what happened?

96
00:06:16.710 --> 00:06:17.810
Let me slow down.

97
00:06:17.810 --> 00:06:21.480
New, all right, Text Document.

98
00:06:21.480 --> 00:06:26.030
So we'll name this Zack,
and we'll say ideas.

99
00:06:28.330 --> 00:06:33.630
And we'll go in there and
say these are my ideas, ta da.

100
00:06:35.820 --> 00:06:39.665
Okay, so this is Zack's document here, and

101
00:06:39.665 --> 00:06:43.723
we'll just save that to make sure,
all right.

102
00:06:47.473 --> 00:06:52.497
Now, when we take a look at
the permissions that we've assigned

103
00:06:52.497 --> 00:06:57.440
to Zack and we see our Show ideas
folder and we try to click on it.

104
00:06:57.440 --> 00:06:59.278
We get this notification here that says,

105
00:06:59.278 --> 00:07:02.760
you don't currently have
permissions to access this folder.

106
00:07:02.760 --> 00:07:07.190
And if you can recall, one of the options
was to be able to list the contents.

107
00:07:07.190 --> 00:07:11.310
One of the permissions was to be able to
view the contents inside of this folder,

108
00:07:12.390 --> 00:07:15.540
and we didn't assign that to Zack or
to our host group.

109
00:07:15.540 --> 00:07:18.960
We're not just calling him
out individually here.

110
00:07:18.960 --> 00:07:22.000
But we wanted to be able to write
to this folder and nothing else.

111
00:07:22.000 --> 00:07:24.160
So that's pretty
restrictive in that aspect.

112
00:07:24.160 --> 00:07:29.750
So we'll hit Cancel, and see if Zack can
place his Show ideas within this folder.

113
00:07:31.470 --> 00:07:35.760
We are able to drag and drop and
it appears that Zack was able to put his

114
00:07:35.760 --> 00:07:41.330
information in there but we can't really
tell for sure until we log in as Ronnie

115
00:07:41.330 --> 00:07:45.350
because we gave Ronnie those permissions
to manage those individual documents.

116
00:07:45.350 --> 00:07:51.529
So let's go ahead and log off,
and then log in as Ronnie.

117
00:07:51.529 --> 00:07:56.335
>> So we know that from taking a look
at what Cherokee just showed us, right.

118
00:07:56.335 --> 00:07:59.409
Is this ability to have Zack be
able to write to that folder, but

119
00:07:59.409 --> 00:08:01.845
without actually being
able to look inside that.

120
00:08:01.845 --> 00:08:05.783
That provides a basic security, so
that Zack can drop off his ideas but

121
00:08:05.783 --> 00:08:09.990
instead of opening that folder up and
getting access to other files that may

122
00:08:09.990 --> 00:08:13.440
be in there that we don't
want Zach to get access to.

123
00:08:13.440 --> 00:08:16.860
He's not able to even look inside that
folder without advanced permissions or

124
00:08:16.860 --> 00:08:19.060
somebody giving him permissions to do so.

125
00:08:19.060 --> 00:08:21.610
>> That's right, Ronnie, so
what we should be able to do

126
00:08:21.610 --> 00:08:25.870
now is check to verify that you
are able to manage those show ideas.

127
00:08:25.870 --> 00:08:28.220
So let's take a look at my screen.

128
00:08:28.220 --> 00:08:30.230
If I double click on this folder,

129
00:08:30.230 --> 00:08:33.260
I'm really hoping that Ronnie does
not receive an error message here.

130
00:08:33.260 --> 00:08:35.500
So we'll double click and

131
00:08:35.500 --> 00:08:39.220
there we go we've seen that a couple of
hosts have submitted some show ideas.

132
00:08:39.220 --> 00:08:42.450
We've got Cherokee's ideas and
Zack ideas in there.

133
00:08:42.450 --> 00:08:47.137
And that's just one way where we can set
permissions to really restrict access

134
00:08:47.137 --> 00:08:48.780
within our environments.

135
00:08:48.780 --> 00:08:50.585
But that's not all folks,

136
00:08:50.585 --> 00:08:54.676
we have other ways that we can
implement permissions as well.

137
00:08:54.676 --> 00:08:58.934
But I think we'll have to come back
because there are a lot of different ways

138
00:08:58.934 --> 00:09:03.652
to configure shared permissions that would
be a great place to go ahead and start.

139
00:09:03.652 --> 00:09:07.000
>> All right Cherokee, well thank you for
helping us to understand and

140
00:09:07.000 --> 00:09:08.940
see the demonstration there.

141
00:09:08.940 --> 00:09:12.520
Where we could take those permissions and
show the granularity to them.

142
00:09:12.520 --> 00:09:16.890
Restricting access to one user while
actually allowing another user get access

143
00:09:16.890 --> 00:09:18.740
to that same folder as well.

144
00:09:18.740 --> 00:09:22.630
There are a lot of different examples
of this that you will also be able to

145
00:09:22.630 --> 00:09:26.470
make sure that Josh encounter everyday
in a real productive environment.

146
00:09:26.470 --> 00:09:29.740
Now if this is your first time configuring
something like this complexity

147
00:09:29.740 --> 00:09:34.720
that we're talking about, don't think that
it's gonna be done perfectly every time.

148
00:09:34.720 --> 00:09:37.720
You may end up finding out where
you create something like this

149
00:09:37.720 --> 00:09:41.482
where you change those permissions and
you don't get access to those files.

150
00:09:41.482 --> 00:09:43.487
And so
you have to kinda back track a little bit,

151
00:09:43.487 --> 00:09:46.450
then you have to figure out
where all those permissions are.

152
00:09:46.450 --> 00:09:51.577
So take some time, make sure you do
learn and get those NTFS permissions

153
00:09:51.577 --> 00:09:56.883
packed before you go in and sit for
any particular Microsoft exam as well.

154
00:09:56.883 --> 00:09:59.050
All right, Cherokee,
any last words for our viewers?

155
00:09:59.050 --> 00:10:01.030
>> Yeah, Ronnie,
I think you had a pretty good point there.

156
00:10:01.030 --> 00:10:04.568
Just really getting in hands on and
checking especially after you have set

157
00:10:04.568 --> 00:10:08.170
permissions, you might wanna go back and
double check them.

158
00:10:08.170 --> 00:10:12.820
We will also be having an entire
section on just group policy.

159
00:10:12.820 --> 00:10:20.050
So in larger environments, group policy is
a more popular option, a way to go there.

160
00:10:20.050 --> 00:10:22.468
So we'll also be taking a look at that.

161
00:10:22.468 --> 00:10:28.285
But understanding NTFS permissions and
how they apply and propagate downward and

162
00:10:28.285 --> 00:10:32.365
the different accounts that are generated
by the system like the every one group.

163
00:10:32.365 --> 00:10:38.477
Just looking at those and understanding
that's probably a good place to start.

164
00:10:38.477 --> 00:10:40.977
>> All right Cherokee, thank you again but
that's a great place for

165
00:10:40.977 --> 00:10:42.597
us to end this episode.

166
00:10:42.597 --> 00:10:45.417
For ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

167
00:10:45.417 --> 00:10:46.467
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

168
00:10:46.467 --> 00:10:50.389
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the MCSA 70-410 shows.

169
00:10:50.389 --> 00:10:51.346
>> Bye.

170
00:10:51.346 --> 00:10:59.097
[MUSIC]

171
00:10:59.097 --> 00:11:01.633
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee discuss the use of share permissions in Windows.  Cherokee explains the use of shares and how to configure them.  She also explains that we must be careful account for NTFS and Share Permission when configuring them for use.  Lastly, she also demonstrates some of the methods used to configure shares on a Windows machine.
episodes.title: Configure Share Permissions
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:06.550
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.550 --> 00:00:08.210
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.210 --> 00:00:11.915
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.915 --> 00:00:15.350
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.350 --> 00:00:19.008
You're watching the MCSA for
Windows Server 2012,

6
00:00:19.008 --> 00:00:21.912
it's specifically for exam 70-410.

7
00:00:21.912 --> 00:00:27.110
Today, we're gonna be taking a look at
configuring, well, Share Permissions.

8
00:00:27.110 --> 00:00:29.646
And here to help us understand this
concept better is gonna be Ms.

9
00:00:29.646 --> 00:00:30.280
Cherokee Boose.

10
00:00:30.280 --> 00:00:32.190
Cherokee, welcome back to the show,
how are you doing?

11
00:00:32.190 --> 00:00:34.590
>> Thanks for having me, Ronnie,
I'm doing great today, how are you?

12
00:00:34.590 --> 00:00:35.488
>> I am doing fine.

13
00:00:35.488 --> 00:00:40.510
Now, Cherokee, we've already talked
about the idea of the NTFS permissions,

14
00:00:40.510 --> 00:00:42.770
we've gone through that,
and talked about that.

15
00:00:42.770 --> 00:00:47.210
Now we're adding in another level of,
well, permissions it sounds like.

16
00:00:47.210 --> 00:00:49.960
So, Cherokee, help us out here,
when do we tend to deal with this.

17
00:00:49.960 --> 00:00:55.500
>> So, Ronnie, we're definitely not at a
lack of ways we can implement permissions.

18
00:00:55.500 --> 00:00:58.355
Yes, we have spoke about NTFS permissions.

19
00:00:58.355 --> 00:00:59.775
And you know what, as a matter of fact,

20
00:00:59.775 --> 00:01:03.935
I wanted to mention one thing about that,
we are gonna be taking a look

21
00:01:03.935 --> 00:01:07.285
at group policy a little bit later
because there is an order of precedence.

22
00:01:07.285 --> 00:01:10.625
When you look at all these different
types of permissions that we have,

23
00:01:10.625 --> 00:01:15.645
you really need to understand also,
which permissions will override.

24
00:01:15.645 --> 00:01:18.380
So we'll look at that when
we talk about group policy.

25
00:01:18.380 --> 00:01:23.650
But one thing I specifically wanted to
call out for exam test takers out there.

26
00:01:23.650 --> 00:01:26.950
In the real life it doesn't matter so
much with the verbiage, but

27
00:01:26.950 --> 00:01:31.670
prior to Server 2012, and 2012 R2,

28
00:01:31.670 --> 00:01:36.690
there was some terminology that I
think I used in the last show that on

29
00:01:36.690 --> 00:01:40.156
the exam it's just important to know that
they might be called something different.

30
00:01:40.156 --> 00:01:45.460
So, when we looked at
our basic permissions.

31
00:01:45.460 --> 00:01:50.179
And those were the six
permission styles that Microsoft

32
00:01:51.730 --> 00:01:54.160
ordered or they put together for us.

33
00:01:54.160 --> 00:01:59.110
And a read or execute, the list
folder contents, things like that.

34
00:01:59.110 --> 00:02:01.450
So that used to be called standard.

35
00:02:01.450 --> 00:02:06.126
And so, 2012 and 2012 R2 and
moving forward, those are called basic.

36
00:02:06.126 --> 00:02:09.641
And then those special
permissions that we spoke about,

37
00:02:09.641 --> 00:02:14.380
those were gonna be the really fine tuned,
granular type permissions.

38
00:02:14.380 --> 00:02:16.450
Those used to be called special and

39
00:02:16.450 --> 00:02:19.960
I think they're still even listed
in the operation system as special.

40
00:02:19.960 --> 00:02:24.190
But if you see it on the exam,
the term advanced permissions,

41
00:02:24.190 --> 00:02:25.650
that's all that they're referencing there.

42
00:02:25.650 --> 00:02:27.010
So just FYI.

43
00:02:27.010 --> 00:02:30.570
But, the type of permissions that
we're going to be talking about today

44
00:02:30.570 --> 00:02:33.080
are called share permissions.

45
00:02:33.080 --> 00:02:37.780
So share permissions are interesting
because if I were to share

46
00:02:37.780 --> 00:02:42.960
a resource such as a folder or
a volume, then I am

47
00:02:42.960 --> 00:02:48.170
able to set permissions for
that particular object that I've shared.

48
00:02:48.170 --> 00:02:52.628
The thing with share permissions
is that they're only effective if

49
00:02:52.628 --> 00:02:57.820
the individual or

50
00:02:57.820 --> 00:03:03.010
the security principle is accessing
that resource across the wire.

51
00:03:03.010 --> 00:03:04.050
What does that mean?

52
00:03:04.050 --> 00:03:09.470
Well, that means if I were to,
maybe Ronnie had shared something out,

53
00:03:09.470 --> 00:03:13.830
a folder out to me on his computer and
maybe he set certain share

54
00:03:13.830 --> 00:03:18.560
permissions that restricted some sort
of access in a particular way for me.

55
00:03:18.560 --> 00:03:22.230
But if he had not restricted

56
00:03:22.230 --> 00:03:27.370
to match the access via NTFS permissions,
the ones we just spoke about.

57
00:03:27.370 --> 00:03:34.730
Then, theoretically, I could go log on to
Ronnie's computer, if I was able to, and

58
00:03:34.730 --> 00:03:40.910
access that same resource but
without those share permissions.

59
00:03:40.910 --> 00:03:42.960
So that is something that
you have to think about.

60
00:03:42.960 --> 00:03:46.510
These share permissions
are only going to be applied

61
00:03:46.510 --> 00:03:49.630
when accessing that
resource over the network.

62
00:03:49.630 --> 00:03:50.470
And then you're thinking, well,

63
00:03:50.470 --> 00:03:55.070
if I just applied those NTFS permissions,
why do I even need share permission?

64
00:03:55.070 --> 00:03:57.020
So I can't give you that answer.

65
00:03:57.020 --> 00:03:58.400
That's gonna be up to Microsoft.

66
00:03:58.400 --> 00:04:00.830
But just know that they do exist and

67
00:04:00.830 --> 00:04:03.660
we did say that NTFS
permissions were cumulative.

68
00:04:03.660 --> 00:04:08.270
Meaning, they built upon each other
if I were a part of multiple groups.

69
00:04:08.270 --> 00:04:10.350
However, when you take
NTFS permissions and

70
00:04:10.350 --> 00:04:14.450
share permissions and really compare
those two and put them together,

71
00:04:14.450 --> 00:04:19.750
it's always going to be the most
restricted is going to override here.

72
00:04:19.750 --> 00:04:22.574
So there is a little bit of difference
in the way that they do apply.

73
00:04:22.574 --> 00:04:28.265
And if you do not have any NTFS
permissions configured on a resource but

74
00:04:28.265 --> 00:04:32.907
you have shared it out,
then access will not be granted.

75
00:04:32.907 --> 00:04:37.220
So just because you set share permissions,
you can't assume, I don't need to worry

76
00:04:37.220 --> 00:04:40.941
about NTFS, because they still need to
be in existence and be present there.

77
00:04:40.941 --> 00:04:43.249
So that's just something to think about,
and

78
00:04:43.249 --> 00:04:47.048
I'm sure there will be a lot more as we
continue to look throughout the show.

79
00:04:47.048 --> 00:04:51.779
Because Microsoft has an abundant
methods of how I may be able

80
00:04:51.779 --> 00:04:55.030
to share a resource to someone.

81
00:04:55.030 --> 00:04:57.980
>> Now, Cherokee, the other thing I
understand about share positions, and

82
00:04:57.980 --> 00:05:01.070
correct me if I'm wrong here on this,
is that with NTFS permissions,

83
00:05:01.070 --> 00:05:04.300
I can apply those to folders like
we did in previous episodes.

84
00:05:04.300 --> 00:05:05.400
Or I can even go down and

85
00:05:05.400 --> 00:05:09.472
apply them to individual objects within
folders like files if I choose to.

86
00:05:09.472 --> 00:05:13.090
So NTFS file and
folder permissions do allow me to do that.

87
00:05:13.090 --> 00:05:15.230
But I don't think,
if I remember correctly,

88
00:05:15.230 --> 00:05:19.380
Cherokee, that I can apply share
permissions to files, right?

89
00:05:19.380 --> 00:05:22.100
>> No, so when we're really
talking about share permissions,

90
00:05:22.100 --> 00:05:24.580
that's going to be either a folder or
a volume.

91
00:05:24.580 --> 00:05:26.790
If I wanted to share an entire
volume I could as well.

92
00:05:26.790 --> 00:05:29.780
So if you wanted to share out,
Ronnie, just a file,

93
00:05:29.780 --> 00:05:32.930
then you could put a file in a folder, but
then you need to share that folder out.

94
00:05:32.930 --> 00:05:34.900
So that's just kind of a work around for
that, so.

95
00:05:36.580 --> 00:05:40.350
That's actually a good segue into
something like, what if we just have

96
00:05:40.350 --> 00:05:43.720
an end user that wants to share something,
a very basic share?

97
00:05:43.720 --> 00:05:46.720
Maybe you did just want one file
that you wanted to share with me,

98
00:05:46.720 --> 00:05:48.700
so how would you go about doing that?

99
00:05:48.700 --> 00:05:53.220
Well, if we take a look at my computer and
we'll set up a couple of folders, and

100
00:05:53.220 --> 00:05:57.580
let's pull up our C drive, I'm just
on the server here and let's do that.

101
00:05:57.580 --> 00:06:00.790
Let's create a new folder
to place your object in.

102
00:06:00.790 --> 00:06:04.740
So we'll say New Folder and
we'll say Ronnie's folder.

103
00:06:05.980 --> 00:06:09.705
And inside Ronnie's folder,
let's create a text document here.

104
00:06:13.165 --> 00:06:16.160
And we'll just say test text.

105
00:06:16.160 --> 00:06:21.071
All right, now let me back up out of here.

106
00:06:21.071 --> 00:06:25.097
And when I'm just hovering
over Ronnie's folder,

107
00:06:25.097 --> 00:06:29.500
I could simply right-click and
then select Share with.

108
00:06:29.500 --> 00:06:31.640
And I don't know if you can see that one,
let me zoom in a bit.

109
00:06:33.150 --> 00:06:36.210
And then select Specific people.

110
00:06:36.210 --> 00:06:40.630
So I actually don't have myself
in Active Directory here,

111
00:06:40.630 --> 00:06:43.280
I had put you in Active Directory for
this example.

112
00:06:43.280 --> 00:06:48.200
So it would be a little silly to share
with yourself because of the name of our

113
00:06:48.200 --> 00:06:51.770
folder, but let's I had created folder and
it was Cherokee's folder.

114
00:06:51.770 --> 00:06:53.110
And I wanted to share it with Ronnie.

115
00:06:53.110 --> 00:06:55.590
I know Ronnie is in Active Directory here.

116
00:06:55.590 --> 00:06:58.250
So let me just start typing his name in.

117
00:06:58.250 --> 00:06:59.910
And let me zoom out a little bit so

118
00:06:59.910 --> 00:07:01.950
you can see what this
actual window looks like.

119
00:07:01.950 --> 00:07:04.930
So I just right clicked on it and
selected share with.

120
00:07:04.930 --> 00:07:08.160
Now I don't have to just choose one user,

121
00:07:08.160 --> 00:07:12.390
I can also share it with a group
if I had one configured as well.

122
00:07:12.390 --> 00:07:15.680
But let's just start typing in Ronnie and
hit Add.

123
00:07:17.930 --> 00:07:19.460
Unable to find Ronnie.

124
00:07:19.460 --> 00:07:24.540
Let's see if it'll find
you by your Aactual name.

125
00:07:24.540 --> 00:07:29.750
Okay, so here we have his account and
we'll select OK.

126
00:07:29.750 --> 00:07:32.170
And it's actually pretty simple,
that's all you have to do.

127
00:07:33.660 --> 00:07:36.600
The options for permissions here

128
00:07:36.600 --> 00:07:41.590
are somewhat limited with this very
rudimentary type of sharing process.

129
00:07:41.590 --> 00:07:45.560
I have the ability to select read,
read and write, or

130
00:07:45.560 --> 00:07:48.050
just remove him completely here.

131
00:07:48.050 --> 00:07:52.934
Now, when I select share,
this is what we have.

132
00:07:52.934 --> 00:07:57.135
I can either email someone
the links to be shared items, or

133
00:07:57.135 --> 00:07:59.378
I can copy and paste this link.

134
00:07:59.378 --> 00:08:04.156
So this is gonna be my
Particular UNC path.

135
00:08:04.156 --> 00:08:08.691
And this is very easy, I don't need
to really explain this to anyone.

136
00:08:08.691 --> 00:08:11.980
People know how to copy and
paste, so it works for end users.

137
00:08:11.980 --> 00:08:12.855
That's great.

138
00:08:12.855 --> 00:08:17.815
But there may be lacking some
desired configurations with this

139
00:08:17.815 --> 00:08:22.410
very basic share type here,
so let's just hit Done here.

140
00:08:22.410 --> 00:08:24.240
So that was Ronnie's folder.

141
00:08:24.240 --> 00:08:27.532
So let's go ahead and
create a second folder and

142
00:08:27.532 --> 00:08:32.110
look at a second method to be
able to share this resource out.

143
00:08:32.110 --> 00:08:35.106
So let's just name this folder second.

144
00:08:35.106 --> 00:08:36.657
I'm being super creative today.

145
00:08:36.657 --> 00:08:40.099
>> [LAUGH]
>> And right-click on this Resource, and

146
00:08:40.099 --> 00:08:41.879
then select Properties.

147
00:08:43.330 --> 00:08:47.854
So, if we go to the second tab here,
this is going to be our sharing tab.

148
00:08:47.854 --> 00:08:52.171
On our sharing tab,
if we notice this first option right here,

149
00:08:52.171 --> 00:08:53.885
this Share button, hm.

150
00:08:53.885 --> 00:08:55.690
This looks a little familiar, right?

151
00:08:55.690 --> 00:08:59.612
This looks just like that window
that we launched a few moments ago.

152
00:08:59.612 --> 00:09:01.292
So this isn't gonna help me.

153
00:09:01.292 --> 00:09:04.690
This isn't going to allow me any
kind of additional configurations.

154
00:09:04.690 --> 00:09:06.697
Let's hit Cancel.

155
00:09:06.697 --> 00:09:11.820
If I select Advanced Sharing,
I do see some more options here.

156
00:09:11.820 --> 00:09:18.344
So, I first have to select, tick this
box right here to share this folder,

157
00:09:18.344 --> 00:09:23.523
and then the folder,
that name that we had selected is going

158
00:09:23.523 --> 00:09:28.305
to be second by default,
unless I decide to change it.

159
00:09:28.305 --> 00:09:30.969
So maybe I wanna change
it to the number two,

160
00:09:30.969 --> 00:09:35.860
because this is folder number two
that we've created or whatever.

161
00:09:35.860 --> 00:09:39.253
You may want to change the name of this
folder, well, let me rephrase that.

162
00:09:39.253 --> 00:09:41.485
You're not actually changing
the name of the folder,

163
00:09:41.485 --> 00:09:43.650
you're just changing
the name of the share.

164
00:09:43.650 --> 00:09:48.134
So on your side or the back end
side the folder name is the same.

165
00:09:48.134 --> 00:09:52.350
So if it's a really long name or something
that may not be easy for your end users or

166
00:09:52.350 --> 00:09:55.388
clients to understand,
then you might want to go ahead and

167
00:09:55.388 --> 00:09:57.935
create something different here for
that name.

168
00:09:57.935 --> 00:10:01.422
So that's an extra option
that we didn't have before.

169
00:10:01.422 --> 00:10:05.634
And if you look at this
portion right here,

170
00:10:05.634 --> 00:10:13.019
it says limit the number of
simultaneous users to 16,777,216.

171
00:10:13.019 --> 00:10:15.090
So that's quite a bit.

172
00:10:15.090 --> 00:10:19.963
And if you only had 20 users in your
environment, you might wanna go

173
00:10:19.963 --> 00:10:25.019
ahead in and limit that,
perhaps down to not 0.20, but just 20.

174
00:10:25.019 --> 00:10:29.696
You might wanna change that to prevent
any kind of unauthorized access or

175
00:10:29.696 --> 00:10:34.617
even potentially some kind of distributed
denial of service attack there.

176
00:10:34.617 --> 00:10:38.106
But, it really is just up to
you how you wanna do that.

177
00:10:38.106 --> 00:10:42.212
>> And that's actually about limiting
the number of simultaneous people that can

178
00:10:42.212 --> 00:10:43.322
connect at one time.

179
00:10:43.322 --> 00:10:45.962
So, in previous editions,
if I remember, and

180
00:10:45.962 --> 00:10:48.670
again this is going back a long time ago.

181
00:10:48.670 --> 00:10:50.002
It used to be limited to ten,

182
00:10:50.002 --> 00:10:53.229
where only ten people could connect
at one particular point in time.

183
00:10:53.229 --> 00:10:55.797
But at some point Microsoft decided-
>> I know, it's crazy [LAUGH].

184
00:10:55.797 --> 00:11:00.664
>> Decided to go to 2 to the 24th power
instead of number of connections that

185
00:11:00.664 --> 00:11:01.604
you can have.

186
00:11:01.604 --> 00:11:04.286
And that's because the idea of shares,
right?

187
00:11:04.286 --> 00:11:06.695
That's it usually is a network wide and

188

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue with configuring share permissions.  Cherokee reminds us that these share permissions will not work without Network Discovery.  She also demonstrates how to configure share through the File and Storage Services.  Lastly, she demonstrates how to configure an SMB share through powershell.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce offline files.  Cherokee describes this as an option to consider when  low bandwidth considerations are in play or when the internet connection back to the network folders is not available.  She shows how to configure it and explains the options  you must consider before implementation.

episodes.description: {Description}In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce Work Folders.  Cherokee explains the purpose and use of work folders and the scenario you’re likely to see it used.  She also discusses the elements involve in making it work.  She demonstrates setting up the environment for work folders by configuring a CA for Work Folders.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee begin to setup the for Work Folders.  Cherokee configures the CA and the web enrollment.  She also demonstrates the additional configuration in DNS and Group Policy that needs to be performed for this to work.  Lastly, she retrieves a certificate for her Work Folders server.

the arrow's looking like this and

00:21:03.750 --> 00:21:06.940
you just have to push them out
to kind of pull everything out.

00:21:06.940 --> 00:21:11.060
Well, the one you wanna be looking for
is underneath User Configuration, and

00:21:11.060 --> 00:21:13.630
we're gonna be modifying the Preferences.

361
00:21:13.630 --> 00:21:18.740
We do have two options here,
Policies is going to be required.

362
00:21:19.860 --> 00:21:23.210
Preferences is like the name implies,
it's just a preference, but

that's what we'll be configuring and
setting up here.

364
00:21:26.090 --> 00:21:30.890
Because we're using that web base

click on Control Panel Settings here and

00:21:36.140 --> 00:21:38.930
So once you left-click,
there's a couple different ways,

00:21:38.930 --> 00:21:41.770
you could even expand this out and

00:21:41.770 --> 00:21:45.050
So you could right-click either

00:21:45.050 --> 00:21:47.400

00:21:47.400 --> 00:21:51.780
When you get on top of Internet Settings,

00:21:51.780 --> 00:21:55.600
and we're going to be pulling

00:21:55.600 --> 00:22:00.355
Okay, and
let me zoom out a little bit so, too far.

00:22:00.355 --> 00:22:04.160
All right, I just want you guys

00:22:04.160 --> 00:22:09.921
It's important that you see the tabs and
know which tab to click on, when you're

00:22:09.921 --> 00:22:15.191
configuring these things, especially
when it comes time for that exam.

376
00:22:15.191 --> 00:22:18.690
Now, the first thing I want to do here,
a couple of different things.

377
00:22:18.690 --> 00:22:23.350
I want to check over on the far right
corner, there's a Connections tab.

378
00:22:23.350 --> 00:22:25.889
I need to modify my
Local Area Network settings.

379
00:22:25.889 --> 00:22:30.328
So click the LAN settings button,
and this will bring me up to a new

00:22:30.328 --> 00:22:35.210
window here where I can configure

00:22:35.210 --> 00:22:39.090
Let's make sure that this check box is,
in fact, enabled and

00:22:39.090 --> 00:22:41.850
we're gonna specify the address and
that address is proxy.

383
00:22:41.850 --> 00:22:45.662
So, let's just type in proxy and
the default port number for

384
00:22:45.662 --> 00:22:47.469
proxy servers is 8080.

385
00:22:47.469 --> 00:22:52.289
Now that doesn't mean you can't have
a different port number in use, but

386
00:22:52.289 --> 00:22:56.504
for our situation,
we are using that default of 8080 here.

387
00:22:56.504 --> 00:23:02.160
And we'll click this button that says
Bypass proxy server for local addresses.

388
00:23:02.160 --> 00:23:04.230
We need it to do a little bit more here.

389
00:23:04.230 --> 00:23:09.304
We'll hit this Advance button and
we need to specify a wild card,

390
00:23:09.304 --> 00:23:13.652
by utilizing asterisks,
that's such a strange word.

391
00:23:13.652 --> 00:23:19.827
All right, so this is our wild card,
so we'll type in *workfolders* and

392
00:23:19.827 --> 00:23:23.845
then we'll put another
one at the very end here,

393
00:23:23.845 --> 00:23:29.347
the reason we're doing this is to
help allow that communication.

394
00:23:29.347 --> 00:23:34.298
We could have, in DNS,
set up wild card DNS records,

395
00:23:34.298 --> 00:23:37.940
but that's just a little less secure.

396
00:23:37.940 --> 00:23:41.470
So that's why this configuration
is gonna be chosen over the other.

397
00:23:41.470 --> 00:23:45.650
It's not that this is the only way you can
set that up, but just letting you know.

398
00:23:45.650 --> 00:23:48.369
We are prompted with a bit

399
00:23:48.369 --> 00:23:52.352
This is one of those things that just kind
of make you wonder whenever they were

400
00:23:52.352 --> 00:23:55.002
designing it,
it's a little bit of a work around.

401
00:23:55.002 --> 00:23:58.487
But I'll walk you through this so
you don't have to go through that trouble.

402
00:23:58.487 --> 00:24:03.489
If you read carefully it says,
proxy override values require that

403
00:24:03.489 --> 00:24:09.310
the bypass proxy server for local address
also be enabled on the next screen.

404
00:24:10.500 --> 00:24:12.136
That was at the previous screen.

405
00:24:12.136 --> 00:24:17.444
So, we'll hit OK, and we did enable it
on the screen But notice how I still

406
00:24:17.444 --> 00:24:22.940
have the red, so that configuration
didn't take in the operating system.

407
00:24:22.940 --> 00:24:27.182
And because I'm working on a virtual
machine, Microsoft sometimes allows

408
00:24:27.182 --> 00:24:30.971
function keys to be used to push
these configuration settings out.

409
00:24:30.971 --> 00:24:35.940
I can't use my function keys from
my laptop to configure this.

410
00:24:35.940 --> 00:24:41.838
So one thing that I can do is to use
the integrated on screen keyboard.

411
00:24:41.838 --> 00:24:45.103
So if I just right-click on top
of my Start button here and

412
00:24:45.103 --> 00:24:49.400
select Run, I'll type in osk and
this will bring up my on screen keyboard.

413
00:24:50.980 --> 00:24:58.590
Now, you may get frustrated if you don't
follow this part step by step here.

414
00:24:58.590 --> 00:25:02.880
So you wanna make sure that this window
is highlighted blue, because that's how

415
00:25:02.880 --> 00:25:06.260
the keyboard knows where I'm sending
these function key commands.

416
00:25:06.260 --> 00:25:11.230
The second thing you're supposed to do
is uncheck this bypass proxy server for

417
00:25:11.230 --> 00:25:13.130
local address portion.

418
00:25:13.130 --> 00:25:17.827
And then check it again, trust me,
you don't have to do that, but.

419
00:25:17.827 --> 00:25:21.031
[LAUGH] Believe me, all right,
I'm just saving you some time,

420
00:25:21.031 --> 00:25:24.190
then you're gonna go ahead and
hit your function key.

421
00:25:24.190 --> 00:25:29.444
You'll hit F5 to refresh, and let's oops
I didn't have it highlighted in blue.

422
00:25:29.444 --> 00:25:31.434
You definitely need that so
you can send that command,

423
00:25:31.434 --> 00:25:33.035
you'll see what I'm talking about.

424
00:25:33.035 --> 00:25:35.115
But now, those red lines, and

425
00:25:35.115 --> 00:25:37.655
I can close out my keyboard,
that's all I needed that for.

426
00:25:37.655 --> 00:25:40.355
If I zoom in, you'll see that

427
00:25:40.355 --> 00:25:44.000
those function commands were pushed
into the actual operating system here.

428
00:25:44.000 --> 00:25:48.590
So, we should be good to go at that
point and time, I think that's it.

429
00:25:48.590 --> 00:25:51.710
>> All right so, Cherokee let's make
sure we understand what we did here,

430
00:25:51.710 --> 00:25:56.150
because we went to the trouble of actually
getting this proxy and setting it up.

431
00:25:56.150 --> 00:25:58.088
But all that we're really
doing here right is that,

432
00:25:58.088 --> 00:26:00.611
because what Cherokee was showing you,
at the edge of the network.

433
00:26:00.611 --> 00:26:05.289
And there's a proxy server, what she's
doing is making an exception for

434
00:26:05.289 --> 00:26:06.503
her work folders.

435
00:26:06.503 --> 00:26:10.555
So, when she went to the advanced,
and she typed in that asterisk

436
00:26:10.555 --> 00:26:14.913
work folders asterisk, saying
anything that has the word asterisk.

437
00:26:14.913 --> 00:26:15.689
>> Work folders.

438
00:26:15.689 --> 00:26:16.544
>> Work folders.

439
00:26:16.544 --> 00:26:18.953
>> [LAUGH]
>> Anything that has the word work folders

440
00:26:18.953 --> 00:26:21.893
in it, go ahead and
don't use the proxy server.

441
00:26:21.893 --> 00:26:24.662
So, everything else we still
wanna use the proxy server.

442
00:26:24.662 --> 00:26:29.963
But if you're sending up work folders and
you are actually creating that,

443
00:26:29.963 --> 00:26:34.605
it means and you have a proxy server,
you've got to by-pass it.

444
00:26:34.605 --> 00:26:36.421
And that's what Cherokee
is showing you here.

445
00:26:36.421 --> 00:26:41.024
It is very important that those red lines
go away, because it's easy to assume that

446
00:26:41.024 --> 00:26:45.658
just because you typed it in and you click
OK, or you click Apply, that it's done.

447
00:26:45.658 --> 00:26:48.540
And then when it doesn't work and
you come back and go wait a minute,

448
00:26:48.540 --> 00:26:51.740
I put those words in there, and
it's just not working, well that's why.

449
00:26:51.740 --> 00:26:54.858
So, make sure you do pay attention
at least to this setting,

450
00:26:54.858 --> 00:26:58.908
cuz if not that means that for you to do
work folders it's gonna hit your proxy.

451
00:26:58.908 --> 00:27:00.193
It's never gonna get to the work folders.

452
00:27:00.193 --> 00:27:02.436
>> Exactly, and thanks for
just noting that Ronnie,

453
00:27:02.436 --> 00:27:04.063
because it is super important here.

454
00:27:04.063 --> 00:27:06.067
And actually,
I just wanted to back out and

455
00:27:06.067 --> 00:27:09.420
show you the last couple of things to do,
and it's nothing major here.

456
00:27:09.420 --> 00:27:12.840
All we're doing is hitting those you know,
backing out of the Windows,

457
00:27:12.840 --> 00:27:14.238
hitting okay and okay.

458
00:27:14.238 --> 00:27:17.105
And I think that's about it for this show,

459
00:27:17.105 --> 00:27:20.860
because that's a good point for
us to go ahead and stop.

460
00:27:20.860 --> 00:27:23.800
I've been mentioning this
concept of utilizing names.

461
00:27:23.800 --> 00:27:25.790
But I think in the next show,
we'll go ahead and

462
00:27:25.790 --> 00:27:29.540

463
00:27:29.540 --> 00:27:34.580
Because Ronnie, remember not only

00:27:34.580 --> 00:27:36.930
systems to be able to
connect to work folders.

465
00:27:36.930 --> 00:27:41.511
We're also allowing non-domain,
because you know people want to do work on

466
00:27:41.511 --> 00:27:45.320
the beach and in their home or
wherever they are, I don't know.

467
00:27:45.320 --> 00:27:47.918
But we have that flexibility so,
I think that'll be a good place for

468
00:27:47.918 --> 00:27:49.680
us to come back and check out.

469
00:27:49.680 --> 00:27:51.860
>> All right,
sounds like a great idea Cherokee.

470

So remember that in this episode you
did see Cherokee just go ahead and

00:27:55.290 --> 00:27:59.170
give us the setup of what we need to
get started in making sure that we have

472
00:27:59.170 --> 00:28:01.350
all of the different things in place for

473
00:28:01.350 --> 00:28:06.320
work folders to be able to work
in the way that we want them to.

474
00:28:06.320 --> 00:28:07.968
And getting this stuff set up and

475
00:28:07.968 --> 00:28:10.358
understanding all
the little options there.

476
00:28:10.358 --> 00:28:13.570
They're gonna be important,
especially when it comes down to the exam.

477
00:28:13.570 --> 00:28:17.160
So make sure you pay attention right here,

478
00:28:17.160 --> 00:28:20.510
All these are actually elements
that's gonna be highly testable, so

479
00:28:20.510 --> 00:28:23.730
make sure you watch this

480
00:28:23.730 --> 00:28:26.585
So there's a lot more for

481
00:28:26.585 --> 00:28:28.430
this is a great place for us to end.

00:28:28.430 --> 00:28:32.233
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue to setup the Work Folder Server Environment. Cherokee demonstrates how to configure the Server for use. In her environment she is configuring also for a proxy server.  She completes the certificate request from the CA.
episodes.title: Configure File and Share Access Part 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:01.073
Welcome to ITPro TV.

2
00:00:01.073 --> 00:00:06.303
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

3

[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.287 --> 00:00:12.264
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

5
00:00:12.264 --> 00:00:14.766
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro TV.

6
00:00:14.766 --> 00:00:19.310
You're watching the MCSA for
Windows Server 2012 R2.

7
00:00:19.310 --> 00:00:22.550
More specifically covering exam 70-410 and

8
00:00:22.550 --> 00:00:26.430

of configuring work folders here.

9
00:00:26.430 --> 00:00:27.740
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

10
00:00:27.740 --> 00:00:30.520
here to help us out is gonna
be of course Cherokee Boose.

Cherokee welcome back.

13

Super excited to go ahead and

we've got a lot of work ahead of us.

15
00:00:37.260 --> 00:00:39.270
So I think we'll just dive right in.

16

The first thing that I want to do is
pick right back up where we left off.

17
00:00:42.700 --> 00:00:46.630
We were going to set that user
principal name for our administrator.

18
00:00:46.630 --> 00:00:49.920
So in order to do that,
if you could join me in my screen,

19

we're gonna be pulling up
Active Directory users and computers.

20
00:00:53.070 --> 00:00:56.898
So I just have Server Manager

21
00:00:56.898 --> 00:00:59.890
From the right-hand pane
drop down menu Tools and

00:00:59.890 --> 00:01:02.880
then select Active Directory Users and
Computers.

23
00:01:04.370 --> 00:01:06.030
From my Active Directory Users and

24
00:01:06.030 --> 00:01:11.530
Computers window I wanna make sure I
expand out my users container here and

25
00:01:11.530 --> 00:01:15.270
I'm looking for my administrator,
all the way down at the bottom.

26
00:01:15.270 --> 00:01:20.480
Let's right click and
select Properties My screen's a little,

27
00:01:20.480 --> 00:01:22.230
I don't wanna go too far but there we go.

28
00:01:22.230 --> 00:01:25.380
All right, so
once we have our Properties pulled

29
00:01:25.380 --> 00:01:30.340
up we need to modify our
account information.

30
00:01:30.340 --> 00:01:32.960
So make sure you're clicking
on that Account tab there.

31
00:01:32.960 --> 00:01:37.565
And this is where we're going to specify
that user principal name because remember

32
00:01:37.565 --> 00:01:40.470
we can also support that
non-domain joined login.

33
00:01:40.470 --> 00:01:45.120
So what we're gonna type
in here is Administrator.

34
00:01:45.120 --> 00:01:46.990
Make sure it's spelled correctly.

35
00:01:46.990 --> 00:01:51.020
And from this right section over here,
we have a drop-down, because we're only

36
00:01:51.020 --> 00:01:54.000
working with one domain, and
that's what we're gonna select here.

37
00:01:54.000 --> 00:01:56.320
And I'll zoom out and
just hit OK for that.

38
00:01:56.320 --> 00:01:59.320
I don't think there's anything
else we need to set here for

39
00:01:59.320 --> 00:02:02.290
sessions or
specific log-on hours or anything.

40
00:02:02.290 --> 00:02:02.940
We'll just hit OK.

41
00:02:04.520 --> 00:02:05.700
And that should be it.

42
00:02:05.700 --> 00:02:09.531
We do need to hop on over
to our PLABDMO1 machine.

43
00:02:09.531 --> 00:02:12.980
That's the machine that's housing
the work folders feature.

44
00:02:12.980 --> 00:02:14.030
So let's do that.

45
00:02:14.030 --> 00:02:15.990
I'm just going to minimize this one.

46
00:02:15.990 --> 00:02:19.010
And I think I have it
pulled up right over here.

47
00:02:19.010 --> 00:02:24.097
And you can see right here this is,
in fact, my PLABDMO1 machine.

48
00:02:24.097 --> 00:02:28.410
Now, what we need to do is create
a custom- oops, and I'm going crazy here.

49
00:02:28.410 --> 00:02:33.890
What we need to do is create
a custom tool bar with our snap-ins.

50
00:02:33.890 --> 00:02:36.570
So, in order to do that,
the easiest way for me,

51
00:02:36.570 --> 00:02:41.570
just right click on your Start menu and
select Run, and all the way

52
00:02:41.570 --> 00:02:46.140
down here in the bottom corner, I'm
just going to type in mmc and hit enter.

53
00:02:46.140 --> 00:02:48.729
And this'll bring my
Microsoft management console.

54
00:02:50.130 --> 00:02:55.380
From my Microsoft Management Console,
I can create a toolbox here.

55
00:02:55.380 --> 00:03:00.556
And under the File menu, I'm going to
be selecting Add or Remove Snap-in.

56
00:03:00.556 --> 00:03:02.869
Don't know if you can see that,
but this is where we're headed.

57
00:03:04.488 --> 00:03:09.710
Now we wanna be managing our
certificates that we created our

58
00:03:09.710 --> 00:03:14.060
CA on our domain controller and
we are going to be issuing

59
00:03:14.060 --> 00:03:18.080
that certificate to be housed
here on our domain member.

60
00:03:18.080 --> 00:03:21.930
So that the clients can bring that down
and install it on their systems so

61
00:03:21.930 --> 00:03:26.490
that they can trust the server and
trust that this information that

62
00:03:26.490 --> 00:03:31.960
they're getting is accurate, original,
and has not been modified in any way.

63
00:03:31.960 --> 00:03:36.030
So what we need to do on the left-hand
side, select Certificates, and

64
00:03:36.030 --> 00:03:37.657
then hit Add to bring it on over.

65
00:03:38.710 --> 00:03:44.290
Now, remember, that a security
principle can either be a user account,

66
00:03:44.290 --> 00:03:47.030
a service account here,
a computer account,

67
00:03:47.030 --> 00:03:51.340
because we are wanting to vouch and
verify the authenticity of this server.

68
00:03:51.340 --> 00:03:53.060
Let's make sure we
select computer account,

69
00:03:53.060 --> 00:03:55.240
this is not something that
can be changed later on.

70
00:03:55.240 --> 00:03:57.710
So we wanna make sure we
do it right the first time.

71
00:03:57.710 --> 00:04:00.090
And we'll hit Next,
right behind my head, but that's okay.

72
00:04:00.090 --> 00:04:02.513
Just a Next button.

73
00:04:02.513 --> 00:04:06.170
Local computer we're not setting
this up for another system.

74
00:04:06.170 --> 00:04:09.250
We are on the machine that we're
generating that certificate for so

75
00:04:09.250 --> 00:04:14.240
let's just verify that this radio button
is selected and we will hit Finish.

76
00:04:16.210 --> 00:04:18.790
All right, so we can see that
certificate right there for

77
00:04:18.790 --> 00:04:21.320
the local computer but that's not it yet.

78
00:04:21.320 --> 00:04:24.920
We need to request for
an SSL web certificate, all right,

79
00:04:24.920 --> 00:04:27.720
we will just say OK to that.

80
00:04:27.720 --> 00:04:33.930
And now, if I expand out on my left-hand
side ever here, Certificates, Local.

81
00:04:33.930 --> 00:04:35.660
I wanna select on Personal.

82
00:04:35.660 --> 00:04:41.210
And currently I have no items to show in
this view so we wanna change that here.

83
00:04:41.210 --> 00:04:45.360
So what I'm gonna do is right-click And
select All Tasks and

84
00:04:45.360 --> 00:04:47.210
then Request New Certificate.

85
00:04:48.960 --> 00:04:51.680
All right, so that's gonna bring up
my little Enrolment Wizard here.

86
00:04:51.680 --> 00:04:55.150
This is just the intro page to
help us get that certificate.

87
00:04:56.450 --> 00:05:00.850
And the certificate type that we
want to bring in is going to be that

88
00:05:00.850 --> 00:05:06.054
SSL Web Server that we had created
previously, we'll just hit Next for now.

89
00:05:06.054 --> 00:05:08.872
We're gonna be seeing
this on the next page,

90
00:05:08.872 --> 00:05:13.990
that SSL web server certificate, but

Obviously, we just created that,

00:18:20.360 --> 00:18:22.580
If we zoom in there's

00:18:22.580 --> 00:18:26.460
to create a link sync share for

So let's click that and

00:18:29.750 --> 00:18:32.280
I can kind of move on over so
we can see what we're doing.

323
00:18:32.280 --> 00:18:36.310
So this is just the introduction

324
00:18:38.038 --> 00:18:42.562
Now because I can utilize this concept and
share out an entire volume,

00:18:42.562 --> 00:18:46.690
that's what this first option

00:18:46.690 --> 00:18:48.990
But because I already have

00:18:48.990 --> 00:18:51.380
we have created it on our C

00:18:51.380 --> 00:18:53.380
That's what I wanna specify here.

329
00:18:53.380 --> 00:18:55.840
So let's just go ahead and
type that location in.

330
00:18:55.840 --> 00:18:58.604
So I wanna make sure I hit c:\workfolders.

331
00:18:59.672 --> 00:19:01.330
I'll remove my arrow so

332
00:19:01.330 --> 00:19:06.251
Folders, and we'll hit Next.

333
00:19:06.251 --> 00:19:12.470
Now, on this page, it says, Specify

00:19:12.470 --> 00:19:16.790
So I could leave this first option
selected here because I'm only

00:19:18.450 --> 00:19:20.660
But the problem that may happen is,
you know what Ronnie,

what if we wanna grow our organization and

And maybe there is another CBoose in

00:19:28.484 --> 00:19:32.412
There would be conflicts there,
so if I select the second option,

00:19:32.412 --> 00:19:36.553
that's going to eliminate conflicts
between identical user aliases

00:19:36.553 --> 00:19:39.940
within different domains

00:19:39.940 --> 00:19:42.270
So that's the option I wanna choose here.

00:19:42.270 --> 00:19:44.150
Now, I do have other options.

00:19:44.150 --> 00:19:46.750
Because we just created that

there's nothing in

00:19:51.150 --> 00:19:53.110
I do have the ability to pick and

choose different components that I

00:19:57.870 --> 00:20:00.832
So maybe I'm already implementing

00:20:00.832 --> 00:20:06.278
And it would be redundant for me to have

00:20:06.278 --> 00:20:11.737
and if I wanted to, I could select that

00:20:11.737 --> 00:20:15.140
But we'll hit Next.

352
00:20:15.140 --> 00:20:18.698
And let me just zoom out

00:20:25.269 --> 00:20:25.900
There we go.

00:20:27.030 --> 00:20:28.710
Trying to get everything on this screen.

355
00:20:28.710 --> 00:20:31.650
I'm gonna leave mine with

00:20:31.650 --> 00:20:35.260
And then you can just put any kind of
description you wanted to for that

00:20:35.260 --> 00:20:38.060
production environment there, but I'll

358
00:20:39.590 --> 00:20:41.090
Now this is kind of interesting.

359
00:20:41.090 --> 00:20:44.309
You might wanna pay attention this as

360
00:20:45.340 --> 00:20:47.950
We are going to modify it a bit.

361
00:20:47.950 --> 00:20:52.590
But I wanted to point out while I remember

00:20:52.590 --> 00:20:55.090
It says Disable inherited permissions and

00:20:55.090 --> 00:20:58.820
grant users exclusive

00:20:58.820 --> 00:21:00.060
So what does that mean?

Well, that means the admin can view and

00:21:09.150 --> 00:21:15.346
But their actual data

368
00:21:15.346 --> 00:21:19.886
So there's going to be a policy

00:21:19.886 --> 00:21:22.890

370
00:21:22.890 --> 00:21:26.000
So like I said, we want to be completely

371
00:21:26.000 --> 00:21:29.800
So that they know, hey, Ronnie has

372
00:21:29.800 --> 00:21:34.170
so you just wanna make sure that
you are in compliance there.

373
00:21:34.170 --> 00:21:34.970
All right, so

once we have that set we also need to

And then, let's hit Next.

379
00:21:56.098 --> 00:21:58.040
Now we also have another option here.

So again,
according to your network access control

policy which you should have one in place

00:22:06.940 --> 00:22:12.760
It should clearly define the requirements
set forth before these devices

383
00:22:12.760 --> 00:22:17.100
are gonna be pulling down business related
information, sensitive information.

384
00:22:17.100 --> 00:22:21.990
So this one's kind of a given
I mean even I think every

386
00:22:26.870 --> 00:22:31.780
So your mobile devices, you just wanna

387
00:22:31.780 --> 00:22:36.460
But if you wanted to enable encryption,
you have the ability to do so as well.

388
00:22:36.460 --> 00:22:38.480
So it's just another

389
00:22:38.480 --> 00:22:41.444
So let's select that and
then we'll go ahead and

390
00:22:41.444 --> 00:22:44.568

391
00:22:44.568 --> 00:22:48.452
You might wanna save this information,
screen shot it to document as well and

392
00:22:48.452 --> 00:22:50.390
let's hit Create.

393
00:22:50.390 --> 00:22:51.690
This'll just take a few seconds.

394
00:22:51.690 --> 00:22:54.550
We can see here that the status

395
00:22:55.790 --> 00:22:56.750
And we'll go ahead and close out.

396
00:22:57.850 --> 00:23:04.270
All right, now this is where we see that
new work that SyncShare listed right here.

397
00:23:04.270 --> 00:23:07.290
And underneath, these are my domain users.

398
00:23:07.290 --> 00:23:10.220
So I didn't fill these in individually.

399
00:23:10.220 --> 00:23:11.770
They're all right here.

400
00:23:11.770 --> 00:23:15.990
And I could go ahead and

401
00:23:15.990 --> 00:23:21.950
So you know maybe Elizabeth just

403
00:23:26.030 --> 00:23:31.225
So we have the ability even here

00:23:31.225 --> 00:23:34.255
they're not able to access those folders

00:23:34.255 --> 00:23:37.295
hey this is our sensitive work
information that is being stored here.

406

Also there is information about

00:23:43.270 --> 00:23:45.190

00:23:45.190 --> 00:23:47.880
You can set NTFS quotas and so forth.

00:23:47.880 --> 00:23:50.500
But at least this gives

That's not it for work folders though,

412
00:23:58.351 --> 00:24:00.910
But I think for

00:24:00.910 --> 00:24:02.540

Well thank you again for

Remember that this is a process but

So, there is more to come in and that

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee complete the Work Folders setup.  Cherokee configures remaining items needed.  Lastly, she completes the client side configuration and verifies the Work Folder operations.

And let me just do a bit of editing

Now we're gonna be using the Netsh

So we'll type in that sh, and the next

00:03:44.090 --> 00:03:45.110

69
00:03:46.470 --> 00:03:52.000
Now we're gonna use the calling to specify

HTTPS although we didn't type

00:03:56.990 --> 00:04:01.705
So to make sure we type in port 443 for

00:04:05.120 --> 00:04:09.970
Remember that show one hash that we

00:04:09.970 --> 00:04:12.350

And this is where we're gonna pull up

00:04:16.677 --> 00:04:17.400

00:04:17.400 --> 00:04:23.100
So let's highlight and then just Copy,

Now when you're back in your command

down menu and then select Edit and

80
00:04:31.935 --> 00:04:35.990
Ooh, and I didn't completely get

00:04:35.990 --> 00:04:38.910
If you can see, let me zoom in.

00:04:38.910 --> 00:04:41.110
There's like a little square.

83

Sometimes it comes in as a question mark,

84
00:04:45.610 --> 00:04:48.080
And that's what I was trying to
prevent by hitting that space there.

85
00:04:48.080 --> 00:04:51.730
Sometimes, I guess if you hit like

86
00:04:51.730 --> 00:04:54.910
But anyway, so you just want to make sure
that you only have the thumbprint and

00:04:54.910 --> 00:04:56.829
not any random characters here.

88
00:04:57.910 --> 00:05:00.310
We're gonna hit the space bar after that.

89

And then we're gonna be

00:05:06.285 --> 00:05:07.088
All right?

So, our appId is going to

So when I set my appId,

00:05:22.054 --> 00:05:26.080
Whatever I put inside this curly bracket

So just kind of note it and write it down.

Now practice labs gives us
a really easy one to remember so

00:05:34.198 --> 00:05:35.984
I'm gonna stick with theirs.

00:05:35.984 --> 00:05:38.480
It's just

101
00:05:38.480 --> 00:05:48.480
00112233-4455-6677-8899-AABBCCDDEEFF.

102
00:05:55.684 --> 00:05:58.640
Let's make sure we end that curly bracket.

103
00:05:58.640 --> 00:06:01.590
Hit a Space, and
then specify the cert store.

104
00:06:01.590 --> 00:06:04.270
And we are choosing this

00:06:04.270 --> 00:06:06.660
So, and again you can select

00:06:06.660 --> 00:06:08.790
you would just need to

So for us,

00:06:09.310 --> 00:06:13.630
we'll just keep it as that default,

So certstore equals.

>> Sor, you'd think that as

00:06:22.450 --> 00:06:25.860
All right, equals-
>> Sor is a different location.

113
00:06:25.860 --> 00:06:28.050
>> Yeah, definitely not in the store.

114
00:06:28.050 --> 00:06:29.970
So let's hit Enter here.

115
00:06:29.970 --> 00:06:34.860
And we wanna verify that our SSL
Certificate has been successfully added.

116
00:06:34.860 --> 00:06:36.429
So now we've binded.

117
00:06:36.429 --> 00:06:37.333
Bound.

118
00:06:37.333 --> 00:06:38.237
>> Bound.

119
00:06:38.237 --> 00:06:42.730
>> [LAUGH]
>> We've bound it to our work folder here.

120
00:06:42.730 --> 00:06:43.790
All right.

121

The next thing we need to do is take

So that it's easily accessible by our end
users and then we'll import it from there.

124
00:06:54.450 --> 00:06:58.780
So let me just close out of our command
