That's about it, Ronnie.

352
00:19:41.394 --> 00:19:42.940
I mean it's pretty simple
on the client's side.

353
00:19:42.940 --> 00:19:45.580
We've already done all
of the work previously.

354
00:19:45.580 --> 00:19:49.757
>> All right Cherokee, well thank you
again for helping us to make sure that we

355
00:19:49.757 --> 00:19:54.601
understand the steps and the configuration
of work folders, getting the certificate

356
00:19:54.601 --> 00:19:59.042
authority set up, making sure that we
have the proper certificate to hand out,

357
00:19:59.042 --> 00:20:01.660
setting up the work folder
on the server side.

358
00:20:01.660 --> 00:20:05.561
Remember that if you are running a proxy,
you've gotta go in those group policy

359
00:20:05.561 --> 00:20:08.430
settings, make sure you get
that set up the way we need to.

360
00:20:08.430 --> 00:20:12.380
All that's actually gonna be a very
important part of what we have here to do.

361
00:20:12.380 --> 00:20:16.079
So make sure you watch these episodes a
couple of times because there are a lot of

362
00:20:16.079 --> 00:20:18.937
steps, but you do see that the end
user is fairly seamless and

363
00:20:18.937 --> 00:20:21.650
actually is easy for
them to get started in work folders.

364
00:20:21.650 --> 00:20:24.480
Well that's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

365
00:20:24.480 --> 00:20:28.170
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

366
00:20:28.170 --> 00:20:28.970
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

367
00:20:28.970 --> 00:20:33.630
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the MCSA 70-410 shows.

368
00:20:34.682 --> 00:20:40.497
[MUSIC]

369
00:20:40.497 --> 00:20:43.857
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee dive into Volume Shadow Copy Service.  Cherokee shows how to configure it and explains that the configuration  is not difficult to set up but there are many configuration items that must be set.  She also demonstrates creating a file and then changing it to show the previous versioning working.  She describes the use of vssadmin to verify it is setup and verified to run the way we expect.
episodes.title: Configure File and Share Access Part 6
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.096
Welcome to ITProTV.
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:01.096 --> 00:00:08.297
[CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:08.297 --> 00:00:12.249
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:12.249 --> 00:00:17.152
>> Welcome to another great episode here
on ITProTV you're watching the MCSA for

5
00:00:17.152 --> 00:00:19.560
Windows Server 2012 r2.

6
00:00:19.560 --> 00:00:23.236
We're specifically taking
a look at exam 70-410 and

7
00:00:23.236 --> 00:00:27.240
today's topic though is
actually gonna be a part six.

8
00:00:27.240 --> 00:00:30.830
Talking about the idea of file and
of course folder access here.

9
00:00:30.830 --> 00:00:34.090
And here to help us out in this part
six is gonna be Cherokee Boose herself.

10
00:00:34.090 --> 00:00:35.470
Cherokee, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:35.470 --> 00:00:36.410
>> Thanks for having me Ronnie.

12
00:00:36.410 --> 00:00:37.510
How are you today?

13
00:00:37.510 --> 00:00:38.140
>> I am doing fine.

14
00:00:38.140 --> 00:00:39.140
Now Cherokee here we are.

15
00:00:39.140 --> 00:00:43.930
We are in a part six which is for
our sake here unprecedented.

16
00:00:43.930 --> 00:00:47.360
So Cherokee,
what do we really have left to go over?

17
00:00:47.360 --> 00:00:50.642
>> So Ronnie, we actually have three
technologies left because we were just

18
00:00:50.642 --> 00:00:53.130
kind of wrapping up our file and
share access, so

19
00:00:53.130 --> 00:00:54.220
we'll just piggyback off of that.

20
00:00:54.220 --> 00:00:58.150
A lot of the concepts we've already
talked about, you probably already know.

21
00:00:58.150 --> 00:01:02.690
So we'll just expand upon that because
really that's a pretty big task when we

22
00:01:02.690 --> 00:01:05.370
talk about different types
of things that a network or

23
00:01:05.370 --> 00:01:08.480
system admin is responsible for.

24
00:01:08.480 --> 00:01:11.470
They have to make sure that
that information is stored and

25
00:01:11.470 --> 00:01:13.150
managed appropriately.

26
00:01:13.150 --> 00:01:16.020
So the first thing we'll talk
about is something called

27
00:01:16.020 --> 00:01:17.900
Volume Shadow Service or VSS.

28
00:01:19.070 --> 00:01:20.580
And if we take a look at my screen,

29
00:01:20.580 --> 00:01:25.670
I'd like to share with you just
the simple TechNet page here.

30
00:01:25.670 --> 00:01:30.780
VSS is actually an underpinning
technology that's associated

31
00:01:30.780 --> 00:01:35.580
with other services such as,
let me zoom in and you can see this.

32
00:01:37.730 --> 00:01:39.680
Whoa, not that far.

33
00:01:39.680 --> 00:01:44.650
We've got Windows Backup Server
utilizes components with VSS.

34
00:01:44.650 --> 00:01:47.210
We will skip this one because we're
gonna be talking about this one.

35
00:01:47.210 --> 00:01:51.160
We've got System Center Data
Protection Manager, System Restore.

36
00:01:51.160 --> 00:01:55.290
But according to the objectives, and since
we're talking about file and share access.

37
00:01:55.290 --> 00:01:59.680
This is where we are really going to
be focusing in on is going to be shadow

38
00:01:59.680 --> 00:02:01.800
copies of shared folders.

39
00:02:01.800 --> 00:02:05.970
So you guys can find
that information online.

40
00:02:05.970 --> 00:02:10.300
But we'll just kind of talk about it and
explain what it is and

41
00:02:10.300 --> 00:02:11.390
why we would wanna use it.

42
00:02:11.390 --> 00:02:15.400
As a matter of fact, Ronnie,
because we are working here in a part six,

43
00:02:15.400 --> 00:02:18.200
I was a little bit confused cuz I
normally don't get to a part six, and

44
00:02:18.200 --> 00:02:20.910
I thought I was at a earlier show.

45
00:02:20.910 --> 00:02:23.630
And so the file name when I
was typing up my notes for

46
00:02:23.630 --> 00:02:26.060
the show, I think I overwrote them.

47
00:02:26.060 --> 00:02:31.010
I'll have to check on that, but what
happens if you do overwrite some files.

48
00:02:31.010 --> 00:02:33.120
Or if some files are accidentally deleted,

49
00:02:33.120 --> 00:02:35.900
I mean people make mistakes all the time,
right.

50
00:02:35.900 --> 00:02:39.650
So that's exactly what
VSS was created for,

51
00:02:39.650 --> 00:02:44.100
was to go back to
a previous point in time,

52
00:02:44.100 --> 00:02:50.280
previous version of a particular file,
and let us access it in that way.

53
00:02:50.280 --> 00:02:56.850
So let's see, let me just pull
up some considerations here.

54
00:02:56.850 --> 00:02:59.438
Got a couple different
things going on there.

55
00:03:02.260 --> 00:03:04.130
Is that the right screen?

56
00:03:04.130 --> 00:03:05.290
Nope there we go, all right..

57
00:03:05.290 --> 00:03:07.810
There are some things to consider
when we're talking about VSS.

58
00:03:10.140 --> 00:03:13.780
Microsoft recommends to store
shadow copies on a separate disk.

59
00:03:13.780 --> 00:03:16.980
So if I have a lot of IO
on that particular drive.

60
00:03:16.980 --> 00:03:20.320
It would just be better if I could
offset that to a separate disk for

61
00:03:20.320 --> 00:03:22.470
performance optimization.

62
00:03:22.470 --> 00:03:26.000
Now we'll see this when we walk
through the actual steps here.

63
00:03:27.010 --> 00:03:32.620
But this particular back up,
it's a type of back up it's not a back up.

64
00:03:32.620 --> 00:03:35.100
So let me be clear on my terminology here.

65
00:03:35.100 --> 00:03:39.630
But this process can be
processor intensive.

66
00:03:39.630 --> 00:03:42.990
So, we don't want to be
trying to back up or

67
00:03:42.990 --> 00:03:47.390
create our shadows during
a time of high utilization.

68
00:03:47.390 --> 00:03:50.620
So, we wanna adjust the schedule
to fit our organization's needs.

69
00:03:50.620 --> 00:03:52.140
That's pretty important there.

70
00:03:52.140 --> 00:03:59.420
Now by default,VSS is scheduled to
run 7:00 AM Monday through Friday.

71
00:03:59.420 --> 00:04:01.500
So I think Microsoft was assuming, hey,

72
00:04:01.500 --> 00:04:03.630
that's probably before
most companies start.

73
00:04:03.630 --> 00:04:07.160
But if you have an unusual schedule,
or if you just wanna change it,

74
00:04:07.160 --> 00:04:11.650
then you also have the option
to do that as well.

75
00:04:11.650 --> 00:04:15.080
All right, it's also recommended to not
enable shadow copies on volumes using

76
00:04:15.080 --> 00:04:16.350
mount points.

77
00:04:16.350 --> 00:04:18.910
And that's going by what
Microsoft recommends.

78
00:04:18.910 --> 00:04:24.090
And it's not that you can't,
but the mount points create,

79
00:04:24.090 --> 00:04:28.600
kind of like if you think about, we've
talked about permissions and inheritance,

80
00:04:28.600 --> 00:04:31.110
and how that propagation filters downward.

81
00:04:31.110 --> 00:04:34.200
And if you have mount points
inside of a mount point,

82
00:04:34.200 --> 00:04:38.650
then it kind of stops that propagation,
and it can just be unusual or

83
00:04:38.650 --> 00:04:42.509
cause strange anomalies or problems,
that's why they recommend not using it.

84
00:04:44.400 --> 00:04:47.980
Now, note here,
this is not a replacement for backups.

85
00:04:47.980 --> 00:04:53.940
This is a good enhancement or
it works well with backups.

86
00:04:53.940 --> 00:04:58.730
Really good for quick access, easy access

87
00:04:58.730 --> 00:05:04.000
without having to pull in an entire
backup or get IT involved.

88
00:05:04.000 --> 00:05:07.350
So its pretty simple in that way but
it's not a replacement.

89
00:05:09.130 --> 00:05:10.450
And there is also a note here,

90
00:05:10.450 --> 00:05:15.030
do not schedule copies to occur
more often than once per hour.

91
00:05:15.030 --> 00:05:16.000
So here is the thing,

92
00:05:16.000 --> 00:05:19.560
when we're setting these up you'll see
that we have the ability to select

93
00:05:19.560 --> 00:05:24.250
the amount of storage that is
going to be utilized with VSS.

94
00:05:24.250 --> 00:05:29.230
Because when we enable VSS on a per
volume level, we have to think

95
00:05:29.230 --> 00:05:33.690
about the additional storage because we're
really saving copies of all of our work.

96
00:05:33.690 --> 00:05:37.958
So we have to accommodate with
the storage but here's the deal.

97
00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:43.740
If I have more than adequate storage,

98
00:05:43.740 --> 00:05:50.270
the software will only allow up to
64 versions of a particular file.

99
00:05:50.270 --> 00:05:54.920
So, if I schedule VSS to run every hour,

100
00:05:54.920 --> 00:05:59.600
I'm potentially harming myself
by reducing the history.

101
00:05:59.600 --> 00:06:04.910
Okay, going back in time, if they're
just continually I could hit that 64.

102
00:06:04.910 --> 00:06:07.650
And, then what happens then is the older

103
00:06:07.650 --> 00:06:10.476
copies will start to delete
as the new ones come in.

104
00:06:10.476 --> 00:06:13.000
So just kind of be aware of that.

105
00:06:14.030 --> 00:06:17.990
Also you just wanna kind of check
before deleting a volume that is being

106
00:06:17.990 --> 00:06:22.530
shadow copied, delete the scheduled
task for creating shadow copies.

107
00:06:22.530 --> 00:06:25.790
And the reason being is you would receive,

108
00:06:25.790 --> 00:06:28.910
I think it's like an error 1700 and
it'll just fill your log.

109
00:06:28.910 --> 00:06:31.820
Otherwise, it's not gonna
cause any kind of instability.

110
00:06:31.820 --> 00:06:34.660
But you just want to be cognizant
of those error logs there.

111
00:06:36.140 --> 00:06:39.520
Now there are a few things to note here.

112
00:06:39.520 --> 00:06:41.880
It is important to use
an allocation unit size.

113
00:06:41.880 --> 00:06:45.638
And we're talking about our hard
disk drive configuration with

114
00:06:45.638 --> 00:06:47.037
the formatting there.

115
00:06:47.037 --> 00:06:50.550
16KB or
larger when formatting a source volume.

116
00:06:51.880 --> 00:06:55.700
There are some issues with compression.

117
00:06:55.700 --> 00:06:59.570
Compression I think they max it at 4KB.

118
00:06:59.570 --> 00:07:02.630
And that has to do with the way
disk defragmentor works.

119
00:07:02.630 --> 00:07:07.802
And some of those older copies
can be corrupt if you don't at

120
00:07:07.802 --> 00:07:13.090
least pay attention to that
16KB recommendation as well.

121
00:07:14.230 --> 00:07:16.770
Now, there's also another thing
to note here at the very bottom,

122
00:07:16.770 --> 00:07:21.030
it says, after backing up a volume
that contains shadow copies,

123
00:07:21.030 --> 00:07:26.280
do not restore the volume to a different
volume on the same computer.

124
00:07:26.280 --> 00:07:31.680
So what that means is you can restore to

125
00:07:33.090 --> 00:07:37.690
the same volume on that computer or
a separate computer.

126
00:07:37.690 --> 00:07:40.650
But don't restore to a different
volume on the same computer.

127
00:07:40.650 --> 00:07:45.930
You'll have discrepancies and
potential corruption there as well.

128
00:07:45.930 --> 00:07:51.110
So now that we've talked about what
VSS is, let's go ahead and set it up.

129
00:07:51.110 --> 00:07:52.260
It's pretty easy.

130
00:07:52.260 --> 00:07:53.519
Let me just pull up my lab here.

131
00:07:58.317 --> 00:08:02.431
Okay, so on my domain controller Let's
just verify we've got a connection here,

132
00:08:02.431 --> 00:08:05.770
all right,
that's my lab making sure it's connected.

133
00:08:05.770 --> 00:08:14.015
So what I've done is I've set a, hold on
let me just move this around a little bit.

134
00:08:14.015 --> 00:08:20.010
Okay, I have set a folder and the folder
if we take a look on my C drive here,

135
00:08:20.010 --> 00:08:24.200
the folder that we wanna work with
us called shownotes, all right?

136
00:08:24.200 --> 00:08:27.740
And, because this is
a per volume technology,

137
00:08:27.740 --> 00:08:32.930
and I only have one volume configured
on this drive, my C drive.

138
00:08:32.930 --> 00:08:38.010
So what I need to do I need to enable

139
00:08:38.010 --> 00:08:42.780
this on a per volume level, so right-click
and then I select Configure Shadow Copies.

140
00:08:44.130 --> 00:08:45.790
And let me zoom out so
you can see that a little bit.

141
00:08:49.144 --> 00:08:51.140
Currently, I can see that it's disabled.

142
00:08:51.140 --> 00:08:54.120
You can also see the numbers of
shares that are listed here.

143
00:08:54.120 --> 00:08:58.980
So, I have that show notes share,
I have my administrative shares, and

144
00:08:58.980 --> 00:09:01.290
from there, I will select Enable.

145
00:09:04.474 --> 00:09:08.360
All right, so whenever we,
this is just the information page.

146
00:09:08.360 --> 00:09:13.960
It's kinda of telling us what VSS is or
our shadow copy is here.

147
00:09:13.960 --> 00:09:15.990
And it says,
do you wanna enable shadow copies?

148
00:09:15.990 --> 00:09:17.059
And we're gonna select, Yes.

149
00:09:20.691 --> 00:09:24.229
From this particular screen I have
the ability, give it a second here and

150
00:09:24.229 --> 00:09:25.860
it will go ahead and turn that on.

151
00:09:25.860 --> 00:09:28.275
It'll create one automatically,
you see that right there.

152
00:09:28.275 --> 00:09:31.270
Now, if I wanted to create more, I could.

153
00:09:31.270 --> 00:09:33.600
As a matter of fact, let's do that.

154
00:09:33.600 --> 00:09:36.890
Let's create a file inside of shownotes.

155
00:09:36.890 --> 00:09:42.370
So let's just select new and
we'll just do a text document here.

156
00:09:42.370 --> 00:09:44.821
Oops, not that one.

157
00:09:49.760 --> 00:09:53.930
And we'll just say, TestDoc.

158
00:09:53.930 --> 00:09:56.110
And let's add something
to this document so

159
00:09:56.110 --> 00:09:58.170
we can actually see who
that versioning works.

160
00:10:00.320 --> 00:10:05.191
So inside of our TestDoc,
let's just type in original.

161
00:10:05.191 --> 00:10:08.900
So we can type,
this is our original document.

162
00:10:08.900 --> 00:10:12.680
And let's go ahead and
save that, all right?

163
00:10:12.680 --> 00:10:13.980
Right there inside of shownotes.

164
00:10:16.180 --> 00:10:21.100
And now I just created one copy,
let's create another copy here,

165
00:10:21.100 --> 00:10:23.740
so you just select,
I can move that over, maybe it'll.

166
00:10:23.740 --> 00:10:28.250
You select this option right
here to go ahead and create now.

167
00:10:30.640 --> 00:10:34.390
And you can force this
shadow copy to happen.

168
00:10:34.390 --> 00:10:37.260
Now we can also set up
our schedule as well, so

169
00:10:37.260 --> 00:10:39.539
we'll take a look at that as
soon as this is finished here.

170
00:10:41.180 --> 00:10:45.966
And again, because this is enabled on a
per volume basis, you do have to be aware

171
00:10:45.966 --> 00:10:50.770
of how many files are on that volume and
how much storage you have on that volume.

172
00:10:50.770 --> 00:10:52.470
So, that's definitely a consideration.

173
00:10:54.097 --> 00:10:58.753
Okay, so here I have the ability
to note which volume I'm

174
00:10:58.753 --> 00:11:02.750
going to be creating the shadow copy on.

175
00:11:02.750 --> 00:11:04.380
The storage area, for instance,

176
00:11:04.380 --> 00:11:08.280
if I wanted to save
the actual copies elsewhere.

177
00:11:08.280 --> 00:11:12.710
Now I currently have a limitation here,
so that's in megabytes.

178
00:11:12.710 --> 00:11:18.440
I could set it to no limit if I had
a large significant amount of storage.

179
00:11:18.440 --> 00:11:23.200
But just keep in mind that we are still
going to have that 64 copy limitation.

180
00:11:24.940 --> 00:11:28.500
If I click on schedule, this is where
I can go ahead, and you can see that

181
00:11:28.500 --> 00:11:32.740
the default here is that 7 AM every
Monday, Tuesday, so Monday through Friday.

182
00:11:34.650 --> 00:11:37.070
And you have the option on the weekends,

183
00:11:37.070 --> 00:11:40.070
you can even have some
advanced features here.

184
00:11:40.070 --> 00:11:43.050
So, repeat the tasks, set it in date.

185
00:11:43.050 --> 00:11:49.345
But you should, I think, either morning or
afternoon but it really just depends on

186
00:11:49.345 --> 00:11:52.835
your organization just as long as there's
not a lot of read and writes happening.

187
00:11:52.835 --> 00:11:56.505
But the cool thing is that
volume shadow service does

188
00:11:56.505 --> 00:12:00.240
work if that particular file is open,
so that's kind of neat as well.

189
00:12:00.240 --> 00:12:06.126
All right, we'll just hit OK,

190
00:12:06.126 --> 00:12:09.180
and OK, and OK.

191
00:12:11.440 --> 00:12:18.090
Now, if I wanted to right click or let me
just open this and let's change something.

192
00:12:18.090 --> 00:12:23.200
So we'll just say modification or
we'll just say modified or mod, all right?

193
00:12:23.200 --> 00:12:25.100
If I can type there.

194
00:12:25.100 --> 00:12:28.895
All right, so now let's go ahead and
hit File > Save.

195
00:12:28.895 --> 00:12:33.494
If I right-click on the properties for
this particular document,

196
00:12:33.494 --> 00:12:35.840
I'll see an additional tab here.

197
00:12:37.190 --> 00:12:39.780
This tab is not available,

198
00:12:39.780 --> 00:12:44.050
it is not present,
unless a VSS is enabled for that volume.

199
00:12:44.050 --> 00:12:47.921
So because it is, I have the option
to look at the different versions.

200
00:12:47.921 --> 00:12:52.656
So let's go ahead and let's see,

201
00:12:52.656 --> 00:12:56.911
double click that and zoom in.

202
00:12:56.911 --> 00:13:01.192
And we can see here that that previous
version was the original document.

203
00:13:01.192 --> 00:13:04.926
So you could see how helpful
this could be if, for instance,

204
00:13:04.926 --> 00:13:08.600
you overwrote your shownotes or
something to that nature.

205
00:13:09.850 --> 00:13:11.460
People make mistakes all the time.

206
00:13:11.460 --> 00:13:12.410
It's a great utility.

207
00:13:13.650 --> 00:13:16.630
VSS can be enabled on a per DFS for

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee dive into Access Based Enumeration and NTFS Quotas.  Cherokee demonstrates how to configure ABE and the situations you might find the need to use them.  She describes some of the additional considerations when implementing it.  Also Cherokee implements NTFS Quota on volumes and even per folder quotas through File Resource Server Manager.

00:30:44.400 --> 00:30:47.190
is not super difficult to configure.

528
00:30:47.190 --> 00:30:50.000
But that means for
you as you prepare for the exam

529

you need to study some those individual
components such Cherokee pointed out.

530
00:30:53.860 --> 00:30:57.670
And understand which ones you're going
to use and how to get them set up.

531
00:30:57.670 --> 00:31:00.256
It is very important that
you actually get that ready.

532
00:31:00.256 --> 00:31:01.710
Especially as you go on to the exam.

533

Because you're more than likely
to face scenario based questions

as well as some configuration
questions about where and

535

what needs to be actually
configured as you move forward.

536
00:31:11.290 --> 00:31:15.640
But there's more to come in 70-410,
but that is for another episode.

537
00:31:15.640 --> 00:31:19.860
So signing off for ITProTV,

>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

>> Stay tuned right here for

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue with printer configuration.  Cherokee explores the printer permissions and the results.  She explains the use and configuration of print priorities.

Cherokee, welcome back to the show.

>> Thanks for having me, Ronnie,

everybody's favorite topic and

I joke but all kidding aside,

they are such an integral part of

15

That's why we hear a lot about it

00:00:47.060 --> 00:00:50.278
So, a lot of you probably

are already familiar with just
the basic configuration of printers.

So here we're just gonna be taking
it a little bit further and

19
00:00:57.130 --> 00:00:59.700
look at it from
an enterprise side of thing.

20
00:00:59.700 --> 00:01:02.870
When we're talking about
configuring our printers.

21
00:01:02.870 --> 00:01:07.377
Now let's take a look at my screen real
quick and talk about some of those terms.

22
00:01:07.377 --> 00:01:12.343
Microsoft is a little picky, I guess picky
I don't know if that's the right word, but

23
00:01:12.343 --> 00:01:16.645
they just wanna make sure that you
understand where they're coming from.

24
00:01:16.645 --> 00:01:21.505
Because predominantly Microsoft has
been a software manufacturer for

25
00:01:21.505 --> 00:01:23.692
the majority of its life there.

26

So if we look at my screen here I
want to explain some of these terms.

27
00:01:29.150 --> 00:01:36.810
So if we think about printers, and
the way that we use it in conversation for

00:01:36.810 --> 00:01:41.250
the most part, when we say printers,
Ronnie, I don't know how you think of it.

29
00:01:41.250 --> 00:01:45.510
But a lot of people think of a printer as
being the hardware device, something that

30
00:01:45.510 --> 00:01:49.910
you can touch and put the paper in, and
that's where you get your print out from.

31
00:01:49.910 --> 00:01:52.380
But in Microsoft terminology

32
00:01:52.380 --> 00:01:55.940
the printer is actually the software
that resides on the system.

33
00:01:55.940 --> 00:02:01.010
So that's why I have some printer
sitting here inside of my print server.

34
00:02:01.010 --> 00:02:05.295
So a print server is simply
going to be a machine,

35
00:02:05.295 --> 00:02:09.025
here I have 2012 R2 running our Print and
Documents Services.

36
00:02:10.035 --> 00:02:13.375
There are a couple of different
ways that I can share

37
00:02:13.375 --> 00:02:14.772
printers out on my network, right.

38
00:02:16.085 --> 00:02:24.265
So if I have like a client with a print
device, the physical print device,

39
00:02:24.265 --> 00:02:28.495
attached to that computer
that's called direct printing.

40
00:02:28.495 --> 00:02:33.950
Okay, and so this end user can print
directly to that print device.

41
00:02:33.950 --> 00:02:38.938
This may be helpful in situations like
in the human resource department where

42
00:02:38.938 --> 00:02:43.935
you don't want sensitive documents
resting on a centrally shared printer.

43
00:02:43.935 --> 00:02:47.239
Of course there are other ways you
can configure and set that up, so

44
00:02:47.239 --> 00:02:48.537
users have to input a pin or

45
00:02:48.537 --> 00:02:52.439
something like that to print when they're
standing in line for that printer.

46
00:02:52.439 --> 00:02:55.950
But security is something that should
always be in the back of our minds.

47
00:02:55.950 --> 00:02:59.990
But what if I wanted
to share this printer,

48
00:02:59.990 --> 00:03:04.470
print device excuse me, and
I probably am gonna mess up throughout

49
00:03:04.470 --> 00:03:07.810
this series when we're talking about
printers and print devices here.

50
00:03:07.810 --> 00:03:09.330
Simply just from habit but

51
00:03:09.330 --> 00:03:13.130
I do wanna let you know the difference
between those terms there.

52
00:03:13.130 --> 00:03:15.640
So what if I want to share this

53
00:03:15.640 --> 00:03:19.550
directly attached print device
to others within my network?

54
00:03:19.550 --> 00:03:21.680
Well I have the ability to do so.

55
00:03:21.680 --> 00:03:26.010
So that would be a shared printer or
shared print device, right.

56
00:03:26.010 --> 00:03:30.690
Now you also see this term, a Network
Print Device or a network printer,

57
00:03:31.740 --> 00:03:36.040
what if that particular print device
was not directly attached to any PC and

58
00:03:36.040 --> 00:03:38.000
it was utilizing wireless technology?

59
00:03:38.000 --> 00:03:42.100
Wireless is so common nowadays,
maybe I have users connecting,

60
00:03:42.100 --> 00:03:46.470
multiple users connecting to a wireless

61
00:03:46.470 --> 00:03:51.180
You can also have Network Print Devices
that have network interface

62
00:03:51.180 --> 00:03:56.700
cards that plug directly in via Ethernet
and other types of connections as well.

63
00:03:56.700 --> 00:03:59.480
But what are some other
things that we can do here?

64
00:03:59.480 --> 00:04:04.690
If I look over at my print server,
I see more than one machine set up.

65

Well, if I'm talking about scalability and

00:04:08.500 --> 00:04:14.180
And I want to have more than just one
printer available for my end users.

67
00:04:14.180 --> 00:04:18.430
Maybe I have high volume printing,
I can create a printer pool.

68
00:04:18.430 --> 00:04:21.215
And over here on the left hand side,
I just kind of made this

69
00:04:22.375 --> 00:04:26.475
little drawing here because you want
to have some logic involved whenever

70
00:04:26.475 --> 00:04:30.085
your designing in the placement of
actually setting up a printer pool.

71
00:04:30.085 --> 00:04:31.355
So what is a printer pool?

72
00:04:31.355 --> 00:04:37.815
A printer pool is the ability to take
printers, that utilize the same drivers,

73
00:04:37.815 --> 00:04:42.030
and then set them up in
alternating fashion.

74
00:04:42.030 --> 00:04:45.488
So you'll have,
let me think about the terminology here,

75
00:04:45.488 --> 00:04:47.157
I wanna make sure I clarify.

76
00:04:47.157 --> 00:04:52.661
So from the end user side, they'll see
one printer, the software printer.

77
00:04:52.661 --> 00:04:59.500
But you'll have two or more of those print
devices, so that it can round robin and

78
00:04:59.500 --> 00:05:04.850
circulate through whichever
print device is available.

79
00:05:04.850 --> 00:05:08.180
So you don't wanna place
those print devices

80
00:05:09.590 --> 00:05:14.440
in really just separate areas of your
building, especially on multiple floors.

81
00:05:14.440 --> 00:05:17.063
Because that end users not able to,

82
00:05:17.063 --> 00:05:21.444
specify which print device
they're sending their job to.

83
00:05:21.444 --> 00:05:26.073
And we don't want our end users running
around the buildings, looking for

84
00:05:26.073 --> 00:05:27.919
their printer output there.

85
00:05:27.919 --> 00:05:29.969
So just something to think about.

86
00:05:31.050 --> 00:05:35.791
We have this concept called a print
spooler, and print spooler is

87
00:05:35.791 --> 00:05:40.715
going to be the idea of, okay,
where are we caching this print job?

88
00:05:40.715 --> 00:05:42.898
So if I go to send
something to the spooler,

89
00:05:42.898 --> 00:05:45.642
I'm not gonna be caching it
here on my local machine.

90
00:05:45.642 --> 00:05:51.701
And then once it's completely ready
to go send it on to that printer,

91
00:05:51.701 --> 00:05:55.774
or am I gonna send the information,
the data,

92
00:05:55.774 --> 00:05:59.650
to that printer and
have it print directly.

93
00:06:00.800 --> 00:06:05.760
If I am going to be sending my
information to a printer and

94
00:06:05.760 --> 00:06:10.430
have it completely render and
before I initiate that print job,

95
00:06:10.430 --> 00:06:13.680
I have to think about how
much RAM that printer has.

96
00:06:13.680 --> 00:06:17.380
So you don't wanna overwhelm
that particular print device.

97
00:06:18.990 --> 00:06:21.585
So those are just a couple

98
00:06:21.585 --> 00:06:26.100
This term print queue,
print queue is going to be,

Like if you're standing in a line, waiting

00:06:34.050 --> 00:06:38.750
Your print queue can determine and it
houses those jobs that are queued up and

00:06:38.750 --> 00:06:41.846
ready to go, right, and
we'll see that as well.

>> Now just as you pointed

I'll tell you that.

>> [LAUGH] Also, virtual printers, virtual

virtual printers are gonna be like if

So just be aware of the terminology

It'll just help you understand,

00:26:43.960 --> 00:26:46.514
pulling its operating system down.

436
00:26:46.514 --> 00:26:49.536
And now if we have
Remote Desktop Services,

437
00:26:49.536 --> 00:26:54.113
if it's being utilized when we're
accessing systems remotely,

438
00:26:54.113 --> 00:26:58.390
we weren't always able to
print to our local machines.

439
00:26:58.390 --> 00:27:02.990
So if I was connecting out to
a remote system, I do now have

440
00:27:02.990 --> 00:27:07.740
the ability with the Easy Print driver to
go ahead and print to my local device.

441
00:27:07.740 --> 00:27:10.300
So that's just something
else to configure.

442
00:27:10.300 --> 00:27:16.170
We looked at drivers, we talked about
printer spooling and how that is handled.

443
00:27:16.170 --> 00:27:17.212
I do have a couple options.

444
00:27:17.212 --> 00:27:19.531
I have the option to print immediately.

445
00:27:19.531 --> 00:27:23.310
So as soon as I'm sending that job,
it's printing right away.

446
00:27:23.310 --> 00:27:27.270
I have the option to start printing
after the last page is spooled.

447
00:27:28.400 --> 00:27:32.160
I have the ability to hold
mismatched documents.

448
00:27:32.160 --> 00:27:38.600
So let's just say you had
sent an A4-sized print job

449
00:27:38.600 --> 00:27:43.870
to a printer that was handling larger
pieces of paper, so it was an accident.

450
00:27:43.870 --> 00:27:48.500
So that printer has the ability with
that spooler setting to go ahead and

451
00:27:48.500 --> 00:27:52.060
hold that mismatched job and
let the administrator handle it.

452
00:27:52.060 --> 00:27:53.490
You may want to consider that for

453
00:27:53.490 --> 00:27:56.570
security purposes as well any
time information is being cached,

454
00:27:56.570 --> 00:28:00.750
it may be against your security policy but
just keep that in mind.

455
00:28:02.080 --> 00:28:05.470
You have the option to print
spooled documents first, and

456
00:28:05.470 --> 00:28:09.680
then you also have the option to keep
documents after they were printed.

457
00:28:09.680 --> 00:28:14.309
So you keep that information there
stored on that printer, so again,

458
00:28:14.309 --> 00:28:17.220
just something to think about for
you guys.

459
00:28:17.220 --> 00:28:19.107
Now, I'm looking at the clock,
I don't know,

460
00:28:19.107 --> 00:28:21.097
do you think I have time
to cover print priorities?

461
00:28:21.097 --> 00:28:26.201
No, Ronnie's giving me the no here,
so we have a lot to cover still,

462
00:28:26.201 --> 00:28:31.750
so this will be a good place to go ahead
and just break, maybe for a part two.

463
00:28:31.750 --> 00:28:34.689
Hopefully we won't have
an extreme multi series here.

464
00:28:34.689 --> 00:28:37.840
But there's a lot with printing, and it's
definitely worth covering all of that.

465
00:28:37.840 --> 00:28:40.235
So I think that's about it for now.

466
00:28:40.235 --> 00:28:43.081
>> All right, Cherokee, thank you
again for helping us out here and

467
00:28:43.081 --> 00:28:46.020
learning a little bit more
about configuring printers.

468
00:28:46.020 --> 00:28:50.700
Configuring printers is one of the things
that you will have to be able to do.

469
00:28:50.700 --> 00:28:53.690
And on the exam,
it is going to be heavily tested.

470
00:28:53.690 --> 00:28:58.000
And the reason why is that, in businesses
if you can't get the email working,

471
00:28:58.000 --> 00:29:03.240
if you can't get printers going, that's
gonna be harsh of an environment for

472
00:29:03.240 --> 00:29:04.140
you to work in.

473
00:29:04.140 --> 00:29:06.310
So understanding the basics of printers,
and

474
00:29:06.310 --> 00:29:09.481
understanding the configurations
that they're in, all of this is

475
00:29:09.481 --> 00:29:12.832
a good piece of information that you
should review over and over again.

476
00:29:12.832 --> 00:29:16.749
And put yourself in the scenarios in
which somebody does need a printer and

477
00:29:16.749 --> 00:29:18.341
here's where it needs to be.

478
00:29:18.341 --> 00:29:21.347
Or somebody needs this but
it's too slow, whatever it might be,

479
00:29:21.347 --> 00:29:25.620
these are different scenarios you need to
think about before heading into the exam.

480
00:29:25.620 --> 00:29:28.100
As well as what may need
to be configured for

481
00:29:28.100 --> 00:29:31.070
you to make them work the way
that we want them to as well.

482
00:29:31.070 --> 00:29:33.670
But there is a lot more to come on
printing and we are saving that for

483
00:29:33.670 --> 00:29:35.050
another show then.

484
00:29:35.050 --> 00:29:38.250
So signing off for ITProTV.

485
00:29:38.250 --> 00:29:39.740
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

486
00:29:39.740 --> 00:29:40.760
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

487
00:29:40.760 --> 00:29:46.826
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the MCSA 70-410 shows.

488
00:29:46.826 --> 00:29:52.774
[MUSIC]

489
00:29:52.774 --> 00:29:55.804
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee configure enterprise printing.  Cherokee configures group policy to deploy a printer to user accounts in active directory.  She also shows some of the powershell commands that server admins must know when working with printers.
episodes.title: Configuring Printers Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:01.230
Welcome back to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.230 --> 00:00:04.945
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.945 --> 00:00:08.265
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.265 --> 00:00:12.292
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.292 --> 00:00:15.030
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:15.030 --> 00:00:19.482
You're watching the MCSA for
Windows Server 2012 R2.

7
00:00:19.482 --> 00:00:23.887
We are specifically going to, of course,
be focusing in on exam 70-410, and

8
00:00:23.887 --> 00:00:27.873
we are now also configuring printers
right now in this particular episode.

9
00:00:27.873 --> 00:00:31.627
And we are on part two, and here to help
us complete the ideas on printing and

10
00:00:31.627 --> 00:00:34.320
configuring is going to be,
well, Cherokee Boost.

11
00:00:34.320 --> 00:00:35.730
Cherokee, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:35.730 --> 00:00:37.020
>> Hey, thanks for having me, Ronnie.

13
00:00:37.020 --> 00:00:38.140
How are you doing today?

14
00:00:38.140 --> 00:00:40.110
>> I am doing fine.
Now Cherokee, printers, of course,

15
00:00:40.110 --> 00:00:46.010
is a big area that we have to consider
as we start to prepare for the MCSA.

16
00:00:46.010 --> 00:00:48.480
Everybody essentially needs emails and
printers.

17
00:00:48.480 --> 00:00:51.790
And we've already talked about
the idea of adding in printers.

18
00:00:51.790 --> 00:00:54.870
Seems simple enough, but
in an enterprise environment,

19
00:00:54.870 --> 00:00:57.020
it may get a little bit
more complicated than that.

20
00:00:57.020 --> 00:00:58.940
So, Cherokee, where are we picking up now?

21
00:00:58.940 --> 00:01:01.740
>> All right, Ronnie, so
we did cover a lot in the first show.

22
00:01:01.740 --> 00:01:04.960
And I just kinda wanna reiterate and
just refresh on some of those terms, and

23
00:01:04.960 --> 00:01:09.340
actually show you where those would
be located in an operating system, so

24
00:01:09.340 --> 00:01:10.630
it makes a little bit more sense.

25
00:01:10.630 --> 00:01:12.910
So let's take a look at my screen here.

26
00:01:12.910 --> 00:01:17.560
Now in our print management console that
I've pulled up, this is going to be that

27
00:01:17.560 --> 00:01:22.050
same printer that we were working with
before right here, Sales Third floor.

28
00:01:22.050 --> 00:01:25.120
So let's just right click, and
examine the Print properties,

29
00:01:26.230 --> 00:01:31.560
because it is extremely important to
know all the individual tabs, and

30
00:01:31.560 --> 00:01:33.930
where we would go and
access these components.

31
00:01:33.930 --> 00:01:35.049
So let me zoom out a little bit.

32
00:01:37.010 --> 00:01:41.810
Some of the UI here is very
similar to what you may

33
00:01:41.810 --> 00:01:46.940
already be familiar with for client
side configuration, so that's a plus.

34
00:01:48.270 --> 00:01:49.940
We've got the name of our printer here,

35
00:01:49.940 --> 00:01:52.410
the location,
any kind of additional comments.

36
00:01:52.410 --> 00:01:56.950
Now this part right here, the model,
and then any kind of features will

37
00:01:56.950 --> 00:02:00.670
be contingent upon the features that
that model does have available.

38
00:02:00.670 --> 00:02:01.930
Our 600 dpi there,

39
00:02:01.930 --> 00:02:07.070
different types of paper trays
that are supported for our paper.

40
00:02:07.070 --> 00:02:09.410
Formats that are supported, all right?

41
00:02:11.020 --> 00:02:13.250
That's just the general, now sharing.

42
00:02:13.250 --> 00:02:17.100
Sharing, again we've talked
about sharing before.

43
00:02:17.100 --> 00:02:19.860
We could share the printer,
you could change the name of the printer,

44
00:02:19.860 --> 00:02:26.260
just like we could have changed any
kind of folder or volume shares as well.

45
00:02:26.260 --> 00:02:31.950
Now this is going to be whether we want to
render the jobs on either client side or

46
00:02:31.950 --> 00:02:37.930
on the printer, we spoke about
that on the memory considerations,

47
00:02:37.930 --> 00:02:42.670
if you are gonna be rendering or
even spooling to that printer.

48
00:02:42.670 --> 00:02:44.480
And then listing in active directory,

49
00:02:44.480 --> 00:02:48.420
we also looked at that when we
created our printers walls.

50
00:02:48.420 --> 00:02:49.780
So that's going to go ahead and

51
00:02:49.780 --> 00:02:54.890
added into that giant phonebook
of active directory essentially.

52
00:02:58.260 --> 00:03:02.770
Now, with ports, so
we have our different types of ports.

53
00:03:02.770 --> 00:03:05.160
You guys have probably
learned about this in A plus.

54
00:03:05.160 --> 00:03:07.840
When we set this particular printer up,

55
00:03:07.840 --> 00:03:12.700
we just chose our prompt port
to go ahead and print to file.

56
00:03:12.700 --> 00:03:18.840
So, it will prompt us to select a location
where we want to go ahead and save that.

57
00:03:18.840 --> 00:03:25.450
Notice though, if I wanted to change the
port on this particular printer I could.

58
00:03:25.450 --> 00:03:29.380
But I cannot have more
than one port selected,

59
00:03:29.380 --> 00:03:32.230
and that is because,
if you think about it logically,

60
00:03:32.230 --> 00:03:37.200
that port is what is binding or
marrying us to the physical print device.

61
00:03:38.990 --> 00:03:44.200
Let's take a pause from looking at
this real quick, and let's look at

62
00:03:44.200 --> 00:03:48.510
a diagram that I wanna show you,
just to explain a couple of concepts.

63
00:03:48.510 --> 00:03:49.890
Here, let me go back one,

64
00:03:49.890 --> 00:03:53.870
nope, and my printer queue is
spelled wrong there as well, Ronnie.

65
00:03:53.870 --> 00:03:56.125
I must have copied and paste.

66
00:03:56.125 --> 00:03:59.170
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's talk about a couple different

67
00:03:59.170 --> 00:04:01.010
configurations here.

68
00:04:01.010 --> 00:04:07.650
So with printer pooling,
let's see what that really means, okay.

69
00:04:07.650 --> 00:04:12.700
This little tiny yellow printer
is set up on that print server,

70
00:04:12.700 --> 00:04:18.530
because remember, Printer is that printer
software from Microsoft terminology.

71
00:04:18.530 --> 00:04:21.350
And these are my print devices.

72
00:04:21.350 --> 00:04:23.410
I can only have one port.

73
00:04:23.410 --> 00:04:28.650
Let's just theoretically say that these
lines are referencing those ports for

74
00:04:28.650 --> 00:04:29.430
that printer.

75
00:04:31.230 --> 00:04:38.380
But what if I had one logical printer, one
software printer, two physical printers,

76
00:04:38.380 --> 00:04:42.580
and I can print to it in a round robin
style fashion, so that's printer pooling.

77
00:04:42.580 --> 00:04:48.730
We talked about that a little bit,
but if I go back to that lab here.

78
00:04:48.730 --> 00:04:51.620
That's gonna be in Edge.

79
00:04:51.620 --> 00:04:58.290
We can enable printer pooling simply
by enabling this check box right here.

80
00:04:59.380 --> 00:05:04.550
So what that means, now I could select
an additional port to go ahead and

81
00:05:04.550 --> 00:05:08.230
bind to another physical print device.

82
00:05:08.230 --> 00:05:11.490
So what that means is,
from the client side,

83
00:05:11.490 --> 00:05:14.600
they only see that one software printer.

84
00:05:14.600 --> 00:05:16.730
But they're two physical print devices.

85
00:05:16.730 --> 00:05:22.290
So if I have a high volume amount
of printing happening, then that

86
00:05:22.290 --> 00:05:27.190
print job will be sent to a printer, if
it's available, whichever one's available.

87
00:05:27.190 --> 00:05:28.957
So that's print pooling, all right?

88
00:05:31.514 --> 00:05:32.630
Pretty cool concept.

89
00:05:34.400 --> 00:05:39.350
And, you know, sometimes in documents,
Ronnie, if I can even talk today.

90
00:05:39.350 --> 00:05:40.118
>> Documentation?

91
00:05:40.118 --> 00:05:43.660
>> Documentation, yeah,
that, it'll say hey,

92
00:05:43.660 --> 00:05:48.440
you have to have the exact same
printer to set up printer pooling.

93
00:05:48.440 --> 00:05:51.020
But that's not necessarily true.

94
00:05:51.020 --> 00:05:52.810
With newer printers nowadays,

95
00:05:52.810 --> 00:05:57.520
the manufacturers have made kind of,
it's not as bad as it used to be.

96
00:05:57.520 --> 00:06:00.620
Printer drivers used to be very picky,
and wouldn't

97
00:06:00.620 --> 00:06:05.480
work very well at all across different
makes within that manufacturer's line.

98
00:06:05.480 --> 00:06:11.340
But nowadays,
a lot of print devices can share drivers.

99
00:06:11.340 --> 00:06:16.810
So if you have multiple print
devices that use the same driver,

100
00:06:16.810 --> 00:06:20.700
then print pooling will work, but that's
just something that you may need to test.

101
00:06:20.700 --> 00:06:25.700
If you're plan on, kind of, not getting
the exact same make and model, FYI.

102
00:06:25.700 --> 00:06:27.250
All right.

103
00:06:27.250 --> 00:06:32.230
Now if we look at my screen again, I just
wanna go through the remaining tabs here.

104
00:06:32.230 --> 00:06:35.940
So Advanced is going to offer
your some advanced options.

105
00:06:37.290 --> 00:06:41.590
Currently this printer is always
available, but let's say I had a very

106
00:06:41.590 --> 00:06:45.220
rigid or strict policy, as to when
people were allowed in the building, so

107
00:06:45.220 --> 00:06:48.800
why would I need to have this printer on,
if no one is even in the building.

108
00:06:48.800 --> 00:06:51.930
You could restrict that
by time restrictions.

109
00:06:51.930 --> 00:06:53.670
And we'll get to priority
here in a minute.

110
00:06:53.670 --> 00:06:57.200
I want to go back to that diagram,
before I continue with that concept.

111
00:06:57.200 --> 00:06:59.700
We also spoke about print pooling, right?

112
00:06:59.700 --> 00:07:04.560
So print spoiling,

113
00:07:04.560 --> 00:07:08.840
I can spool documents, so
that the program finishes printing faster.

114
00:07:08.840 --> 00:07:10.830
So we just need to kind
of think about that,

115
00:07:10.830 --> 00:07:14.910
because I will also show you a scenario.

116
00:07:14.910 --> 00:07:18.690
So all of these factors come into play,

117
00:07:18.690 --> 00:07:22.920
when we're talking about which job is
getting sent to that printer first, okay?

118
00:07:22.920 --> 00:07:25.000
So looking at these configurations here.

119
00:07:26.430 --> 00:07:30.230
Now remember, so on this particular
options, start printing immediately.

120
00:07:30.230 --> 00:07:34.710
That means that the job does not have
to be completely spooled on that

121
00:07:34.710 --> 00:07:39.410
print device in order for
it to begin that print job.

122
00:07:39.410 --> 00:07:40.890
So, it's just gonna start printing.

123
00:07:40.890 --> 00:07:43.417
So, it's happening really fast,

124
00:07:43.417 --> 00:07:46.962
but nothing is cached there
on that print device.

125
00:07:46.962 --> 00:07:52.931
We have the ability, like we spoke about,
to hold those mismatched documents,so for

126
00:07:52.931 --> 00:07:58.572
whatever reason that printer is not able
to facilitate the job you sent, it will go

127
00:07:58.572 --> 00:08:05.390
ahead and hold that so It's not just lost,
and you can go in and adjust if necessary.

128
00:08:05.390 --> 00:08:08.150
All right,
just a couple other options here.

129
00:08:08.150 --> 00:08:11.470
You even see additional
advanced options here.

130
00:08:11.470 --> 00:08:15.360
Next we have a color management tab, and

131
00:08:15.360 --> 00:08:21.170
this is where I said sometimes you may
need to go in and modify this information.

132
00:08:21.170 --> 00:08:24.890
You can set up profiles,
even looking at your advanced information.

133
00:08:24.890 --> 00:08:27.200
But just know that that's where
you would go to go in and

134
00:08:27.200 --> 00:08:29.009
modify those color options.

135
00:08:31.550 --> 00:08:34.250
All right,
let's go back to this idea right here.

136
00:08:34.250 --> 00:08:37.161
I said I wanted to talk
about this priority before

137
00:08:37.161 --> 00:08:39.520
we move too far down the list here.

138
00:08:39.520 --> 00:08:41.730
So let me pull back up
this simple diagram, and

139
00:08:41.730 --> 00:08:44.610
hopefully this will put it
into perspective for you.

140
00:08:44.610 --> 00:08:48.300
If we take a look at our printer
priorities here at the bottom,

141
00:08:49.350 --> 00:08:52.210
I have two clients here, right?

142
00:08:52.210 --> 00:08:55.001
I have one physical print device.

143
00:08:55.001 --> 00:08:58.380
Now this is just an example of
a configuration that would be used with

144
00:08:58.380 --> 00:09:00.080
printer priorities.

145
00:09:00.080 --> 00:09:06.570
But let's say this client over here
is my CEO or something like that.

146
00:09:06.570 --> 00:09:09.416
And maybe this is, I don't know,

147
00:09:09.416 --> 00:09:14.334
I always hate trivializing
someone's role or something.

148
00:09:14.334 --> 00:09:15.276
>> Just say Ronnie.

149
00:09:15.276 --> 00:09:17.299
>> Ronnie, okay [LAUGH].

150
00:09:17.299 --> 00:09:19.762
>> [LAUGH]
>> Here's Ronnie over here.

151
00:09:19.762 --> 00:09:26.300
Okay, so our CEO wants to always
have their documents printed first.

152
00:09:26.300 --> 00:09:30.310
They don't want to wait on Ronnie's
500 page document to finish

153
00:09:30.310 --> 00:09:31.630
out in this printer.

154
00:09:31.630 --> 00:09:36.225
So each one of these clients is
installed with a logical printer,

155
00:09:36.225 --> 00:09:40.135
because that's how they communicate
with that physical print device.

156
00:09:40.135 --> 00:09:43.665
But the settings on each one
of these logical printers,

157
00:09:43.665 --> 00:09:44.655
when you're installing them.

158
00:09:44.655 --> 00:09:46.445
And I should say software printer,

159
00:09:46.445 --> 00:09:50.795
the software printer can
be set with a priority.

160
00:09:50.795 --> 00:09:53.815
And that's exactly what we
are looking at over here.

161
00:09:53.815 --> 00:09:58.517
So this particular field right here,
if I were to go ahead and

162
00:09:58.517 --> 00:10:03.327
enter in right here,
this is going to set my priority levels.

163
00:10:03.327 --> 00:10:06.320
However, it's kind of strange here,
all right?

164
00:10:06.320 --> 00:10:10.731
So you might think, hey Ronnie,
Ronnie's number one, right?

165
00:10:10.731 --> 00:10:11.810
That's not how it works.

166
00:10:11.810 --> 00:10:12.381
>> Nope.

167
00:10:12.381 --> 00:10:18.606
>> [LAUGH] So the way that I think
about it is the higher the number,

168
00:10:18.606 --> 00:10:23.650
the higher the priority,
and that's what it is.

169
00:10:23.650 --> 00:10:27.777
So if I put a 99 in here,
if my numlocks is on.

170
00:10:27.777 --> 00:10:32.170
There we go, 99 is the highest priority.

171
00:10:32.170 --> 00:10:37.830
So 99 would be essentially numero
uno in this configuration setting.

172
00:10:37.830 --> 00:10:39.679
>> Yeah, that makes sense.

173
00:10:39.679 --> 00:10:41.371
>> I know, but it is what it is.

174
00:10:41.371 --> 00:10:43.330
I can't make this stuff up, guys.

175
00:10:43.330 --> 00:10:47.750
So any time you want a number, and

176
00:10:47.750 --> 00:10:52.980
it really doesn't matter if,
let's say I put 89 in here.

177
00:10:52.980 --> 00:10:58.832
If I had 89 versus 1, then 89 is gonna
print before 1, that's how it works.

178
00:10:58.832 --> 00:11:03.609
Now, if I had three printers,
or three clients with one

179
00:11:03.609 --> 00:11:08.400
physical printer, and
I had a 99, an 89, and a 1.

180
00:11:08.400 --> 00:11:14.545
Then it would be in descending order for
that triage or that priority there.

181
00:11:14.545 --> 00:11:19.351
So the client configured with
a 99 priority would always

182
00:11:19.351 --> 00:11:22.008
have precedence over the 89.

183
00:11:22.008 --> 00:11:26.660
And the 89 would always have precedence
over the 1, if that makes sense.

184
00:11:26.660 --> 00:11:31.456
But it is important to know, because again
that does effect the overall outcome of

185
00:11:31.456 --> 00:11:36.248
how that printing order works, and you may
see scenarios like that in the future if

186
00:11:36.248 --> 00:11:38.281
you are planning to take the exam.

187
00:11:38.281 --> 00:11:41.241
All right, moving on here.

188
00:11:41.241 --> 00:11:43.688
I do wanna take a look
at security as well.

189
00:11:43.688 --> 00:11:47.330
We've talked about security and
permissions in other episodes.

190
00:11:47.330 --> 00:11:52.569
And we do have this same tab here,
because we can apply security to printers.

191
00:11:52.569 --> 00:11:56.419
We were kind of joking in the last show
about not letting Ronnie have access to

192
00:11:56.419 --> 00:11:57.450
the color printer.

193
00:11:57.450 --> 00:12:01.555
But in real life, this is something
that you really may wanna consider,

194
00:12:01.555 --> 00:12:03.700
because it happens.

195
00:12:03.700 --> 00:12:08.920
When you install a printer,
by default the everyone group

196
00:12:08.920 --> 00:12:13.370
allows, you get to the security principle
right here, the everyone group.

197
00:12:13.370 --> 00:12:18.910
And so by default,
everyone is allowed to print, all right?

198
00:12:18.910 --> 00:12:21.650
However, we do see a couple
different options here, and

199
00:12:21.650 --> 00:12:24.140
lets just cover those real quick.

200
00:12:24.140 --> 00:12:27.150
So manage the printer, like it sounds.

201
00:12:27.150 --> 00:12:32.980
We're able to utilize management
utilities such as deleting print jobs,

202
00:12:32.980 --> 00:12:36.950
setting priorities, setting availability,
and that's what that means.

203
00:12:36.950 --> 00:12:40.380
If you wanted to go ahead and
delegate any kind of management functions,

204
00:12:40.380 --> 00:12:42.960
then you would select that option.

205
00:12:42.960 --> 00:12:46.282
Now to manage documents,
this gives the right to go ahead and

206
00:12:46.282 --> 00:12:47.728
manage those print jobs.

207
00:12:47.728 --> 00:12:51.536
So if you had documents kinda clogging
up in the print queue and something

208
00:12:51.536 --> 00:12:55.860
wasn't working and you were trying to
go through rudimentary troubleshooting.

209
00:12:55.860 --> 00:12:58.372
Clearing out that print queue, pausing or

210
00:12:58.372 --> 00:13:03.128
restarting a job, then you would be able
to do that with this particular rights.

211
00:13:03.128 --> 00:13:08.070
And then again, we also see the ability
to set special permissions if you

212
00:13:08.070 --> 00:13:12.608
wanted to granularly set those
unique permissions such as print,

213
00:13:12.608 --> 00:13:15.780
manage printers, read, and so forth there.

214
00:13:15.780 --> 00:13:18.430
So that's something to
think about as well.

215
00:13:18.430 --> 00:13:21.910
>> Now this is kind of an unusual
situation here when you start looking at

216
00:13:21.910 --> 00:13:26.160
the idea of the managed printers and
the idea of the managed documents.

217
00:13:26.160 --> 00:13:29.763
Very easy to get them confused,
but do pay attention especially

218
00:13:29.763 --> 00:13:33.041
to what permissions that
the managed documents give you.

219
00:13:33.041 --> 00:13:35.350
Cherokee, if we go back to you screen for
a moment.

220
00:13:35.350 --> 00:13:37.170
Let's kind of just do this.

221
00:13:37.170 --> 00:13:40.800
Just go ahead and click on where it
says Manage Printers for right now.

222
00:13:40.800 --> 00:13:43.795
Manage this printer, and
put a check box in the, yep.

223
00:13:45.180 --> 00:13:49.320
It's not actually showing up, but usually
what you end up getting, of course,

224
00:13:49.320 --> 00:13:51.780
is the ability to print,
as well as manage a printer and

225
00:13:51.780 --> 00:13:53.980
even documents that's actually there.

226
00:13:53.980 --> 00:13:57.820
But if you were just to kind of remove
everything, you'd end up seeing that if

227
00:13:57.820 --> 00:14:02.350
you selected the Manage Documents,
you don't really get the ability to print.

228
00:14:02.350 --> 00:14:06.860
So let's take from example
that I am a supervisor and

229
00:14:06.860 --> 00:14:09.140
Cherokee assigned me Manage Documents.

230
00:14:09.140 --> 00:14:13.260
It sounds great, sounds like a great
idea here, because now I can actually

231
00:14:13.260 --> 00:14:17.940
manage the documents of other people that
may be working for me as a supervisor.

232
00:14:17.940 --> 00:14:22.610
But I go and try and print,
and then I can't print myself.

233
00:14:22.610 --> 00:14:26.840
And so if you don't think about it,
with that idea of the Manage Documents,

234
00:14:26.840 --> 00:14:30.450
you may find yourself with the ability
to manage Cherokee's documents, but

235
00:14:30.450 --> 00:14:31.810
not the ability to print yourself.

236
00:14:31.810 --> 00:14:35.663
So that's kind of something that can get
you if you're not paying attention there,

237
00:14:35.663 --> 00:14:37.081
so make sure you realize that.

238
00:14:37.081 --> 00:14:40.879
Usually on the everyone group, everybody
gets the ability to print, which is great.

239
00:14:40.879 --> 00:14:42.300
But Manage Printers, of course,

240
00:14:42.300 --> 00:14:45.300
gives you that ability to print as
well as manage other documents.

241
00:14:45.300 --> 00:14:48.150
But Manage Documents, though,
you don't get the ability to print.

242
00:14:48.150 --> 00:14:50.360
>> [LAUGH] So
make sure that's selected as well, yeah.

243
00:14:50.360 --> 00:14:51.500
>> Yeah, make sure you check it.

244
00:14:51.500 --> 00:14:52.499
>> And you have to think about that, too.

245
00:14:52.499 --> 00:14:56.374
So if I only gave Ronnie that Manage
Documents permission and then I said

246
00:14:56.374 --> 00:15:01.200
to him, hey, I need you to go and change
that priority, like we just talked about.

247
00:15:01.200 --> 00:15:04.130
Well, he wouldn't be able to do
that because that's a printer

248
00:15:04.130 --> 00:15:07.020
management function,
not a document management function.

249
00:15:07.020 --> 00:15:11.590
So that's something to consider
also when you're doling those out.

250
00:15:11.590 --> 00:15:15.840
And you also need to make sure that
whomever you're assigning those positions

251
00:15:15.840 --> 00:15:19.920
to is a part of one of these three groups,
all right?

252
00:15:19.920 --> 00:15:24.090
We have the print operators group,
we have the server operators, and

253
00:15:24.090 --> 00:15:25.780
then we also have the local admins,

254
00:15:25.780 --> 00:15:29.300
which also include the domain admins
if you're in a domain environment.

255
00:15:29.300 --> 00:15:33.380
So whomever you're delegating
those permissions to

256
00:15:33.380 --> 00:15:37.889
should also be a part of one of those
three groups, just so you know that.

257
00:15:39.070 --> 00:15:43.198
And let's see here, for device settings,
again this is just gonna be some of

258
00:15:43.198 --> 00:15:46.961
the basic settings that you guys
are probably already familiar with.

259
00:15:46.961 --> 00:15:49.218
I wanted to walk through those steps,

260
00:15:49.218 --> 00:15:52.260
because I know we spoke
about them in the last show.

261
00:15:52.260 --> 00:15:54.833
But seeing exactly where
everything is located,

262
00:15:54.833 --> 00:15:58.087
I can't even explain how important
this is for you on the exam.

263
00:15:58.087 --> 00:16:02.754
Because setting up printers is
something that I wanna say,

264
00:16:02.754 --> 00:16:07.698
I was, I hate using those terms
like everyone, and always, or

265
00:16:07.698 --> 00:16:12.040
never, but
I mean it's hard to get out of printer/s.

266
00:16:12.040 --> 00:16:17.980
So we'll just hit Okay for
now, and let's see.

267
00:16:17.980 --> 00:16:20.690
I wanna talk about the easy print driver,

268
00:16:20.690 --> 00:16:25.640
I've mentioned it before, but
the easy print driver as a matter of fact.

269
00:16:25.640 --> 00:16:29.000
So my labs, Ronnie,
weren't working 100% this morning, and

270
00:16:29.000 --> 00:16:32.600
yet you suggested here that I go ahead and
remote into them, so

271
00:16:32.600 --> 00:16:35.790
we've got them up and running so
we could do this show for you guys.

272
00:16:35.790 --> 00:16:40.920
But if you note here on my screen,
I have some printers that are actually on

273
00:16:40.920 --> 00:16:45.900
a different server, and
this printer 1, 2 and 3.

274
00:16:45.900 --> 00:16:51.690
So these printers are actually
on a server named PLABDML1,

275
00:16:51.690 --> 00:16:54.706
and you can see how it
says redirected here.

276
00:16:54.706 --> 00:16:59.780
So easy print drivers are essentially
a way that we can redirect

277
00:16:59.780 --> 00:17:04.170
printers to print to a local machine, and

278
00:17:04.170 --> 00:17:08.290
you'll see that easy print
driver option available,

279
00:17:08.290 --> 00:17:14.390
if it is configured in an environment
that is utilizing remote desktop.

280
00:17:14.390 --> 00:17:18.220
So if I'm not utilizing any kind of
remote desktop per terminal services,

281
00:17:18.220 --> 00:17:20.910
then I'm not gonna really be too
worried about the Easy Print driver.

282
00:17:20.910 --> 00:17:26.870
Now by default,
it is enabled from 2008 and beyond.

283
00:17:26.870 --> 00:17:30.730
But let me just show you, also,
and I have it in the show notes.

284
00:17:30.730 --> 00:17:34.900
A URL here, for

285
00:17:34.900 --> 00:17:39.900
where you would go in through group
policy management and modify that,

286
00:17:39.900 --> 00:17:45.260
if for some reason you wanted the driver
behavior to act in a specific way.

287
00:17:45.260 --> 00:17:49.320
They have a couple different configuration
options here, that you could go ahead and

288
00:17:49.320 --> 00:17:50.550
manipulate that.

289
00:17:50.550 --> 00:17:54.920
And this is the actual location for that
policy, as to where you would go ahead and

290
00:17:54.920 --> 00:17:59.870
grab that under computer configuration,
and then here just some examples of,

291
00:17:59.870 --> 00:18:00.700
you know?

292
00:18:00.700 --> 00:18:04.489
For instance, if I follow this
particular path right here,

293
00:18:05.780 --> 00:18:10.360
if I use this policy and I set it to
Disabled, then the terminal server first

294
00:18:10.360 --> 00:18:14.320
will try to find a suitable printer
driver to install the client printer.

295
00:18:14.320 --> 00:18:17.920
But if that terminal server does not
have a printer driver that matches with

296
00:18:17.920 --> 00:18:22.600
the client, then the server tries to use
the terminal service's easy print driver

297
00:18:22.600 --> 00:18:24.400
to install to the client printer.

298
00:18:24.400 --> 00:18:26.030
So that's just something
to think about as well.

299
00:18:26.030 --> 00:18:27.160
Ron, have you got a question?

300
00:18:27.160 --> 00:18:31.420
>> Yeah, now Cherokee, we do have to be
careful here on this particular link.

301
00:18:31.420 --> 00:18:34.742
You do show it's going to 2008, but
remember that there was kind of a rename

302
00:18:34.742 --> 00:18:38.229
of Terminal Services after 2008
[CROSSTALK] you've been working in 2008.

303
00:18:38.229 --> 00:18:39.913
[CROSSTALK]
>> Here we go.

304
00:18:39.913 --> 00:18:43.930
>> That means that instead of the terminal
services, you're gonna look for

305
00:18:43.930 --> 00:18:46.394
remote desktop services as normally

306
00:18:46.394 --> 00:18:47.464
end up [CROSSTALK]
>> And

307
00:18:47.464 --> 00:18:50.710
all those supporting [CROSSTALK]
>> And that can be important because when

308
00:18:50.710 --> 00:18:54.801
you start to see this, it's easy like for
me You know my mind automatically went

309
00:18:54.801 --> 00:18:59.650
to look for terminal services, because I'd
been setting up terminal services in 2008.

310
00:18:59.650 --> 00:19:01.120
>> Yeah we're showing our age, right?

311
00:19:01.120 --> 00:19:05.130
>> And
then when you actually go to 2012 and

00:19:05.130 --> 00:19:09.250
R2 and some remote desktop services,
you kind of get lost when you go hey,

313
00:19:09.250 --> 00:19:12.500
terminal services,
that setting has disappeared.

314
00:19:12.500 --> 00:19:17.190
So just kinda be aware that that may
actually show something different instead,

315
00:19:17.190 --> 00:19:19.160
which is gonna be remote desktop services,
and

316
00:19:19.160 --> 00:19:22.423
then you can do the printer redirection
the way that you want to there.

317
00:19:23.540 --> 00:19:26.960
>> All right, and you know,
group policy is really the way to go here,

318
00:19:26.960 --> 00:19:30.670
there is a couple specific methods
that we really need to focus on,

319
00:19:30.670 --> 00:19:33.585
when we're looking at that from
the exam perspective side.

320
00:19:33.585 --> 00:19:35.430
Ronnie, I don't know if we're
gonna have enough time to,

00:19:35.430 --> 00:19:39.120
I want to do that in one big chunk,
so it makes sense to us.

322
00:19:39.120 --> 00:19:44.270
We still need to set that up via our
active directory group policy, and

323
00:19:44.270 --> 00:19:48.380
then we also need to take a look at just
a handful of PowerShell commandlets, so

324
00:19:48.380 --> 00:19:52.779
that we can, you know, deploy, and
we talked about this before Powershell,

325
00:19:52.779 --> 00:19:56.660
just being used more often and
making things easier for us.

326
00:19:56.660 --> 00:19:59.040
So I think that's about it for right now.

327
00:19:59.040 --> 00:20:01.830
But don't go anywhere,
because we are going to look at those

00:20:01.830 --> 00:20:05.670
other two deployment methods for
enterprise use as well.

329
00:20:05.670 --> 00:20:08.880
>> All right Cherokee, thank you again for
at least helping us get to

330
00:20:08.880 --> 00:20:12.920
this particular point, and taking a look
at the idea of configuring printers.

331
00:20:12.920 --> 00:20:17.340
We know that this is an important element
in the life of an MCSA for Window Server

332
00:20:17.340 --> 00:20:22.985
2012, and don't over look it thinking
that, it's really not that difficult.

333
00:20:22.985 --> 00:20:26.040
It's not difficult when you
think about it logically, but

334
00:20:26.040 --> 00:20:30.250
all the little minor pieces once again
is where you're gonna be tested on.

335
00:20:30.250 --> 00:20:31.390
So make sure you go in there and

336
00:20:31.390 --> 00:20:34.610
you explore these options,
if you don't have familiarity with them.

337
00:20:34.610 --> 00:20:37.280
If you do, it's a little bit

338
00:20:37.280 --> 00:20:41.100
But remember some of the tricky things,

339
00:20:41.100 --> 00:20:45.670
Me, a one sounds like a higher priority
than a 99, but remember what Cherokee

340
00:20:45.670 --> 00:20:49.710
said, it's not gonna be that way,
when it goes down to the idea of printing.

341
00:20:49.710 --> 00:20:51.630
Pay attention to those
permissions as well.

342
00:20:51.630 --> 00:20:54.170
That can also kind of
trip you up a little bit.

343
00:20:54.170 --> 00:20:57.680
Make sure you understand how those work,
and the idea that you might

344
00:20:57.680 --> 00:21:01.320
be able to manage somebody else's
documents, but not your own.

345
00:21:01.320 --> 00:21:03.770
There's a lot more that's actually right
there, and we're going to have that,

346
00:21:03.770 --> 00:21:08.400
of course, coming up in a part three,

00:21:08.400 --> 00:21:12.543

I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

348
00:21:12.543 --> 00:21:13.526
>> And I'm Cherokee Boost.

349
00:21:13.526 --> 00:21:18.445
>> Stay tuned right here for

350
00:21:20.042 --> 00:21:25.979
[MUSIC]

00:21:25.979 --> 00:21:29.160
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee configure enterprise printing.  Cherokee configures group policy to deploy a printer to user accounts in active directory.  She also shows some of the powershell commands that server admins must know when working with printers.
episodes.title: Configuring Printers Part 3

And here to help us understand more about

How are you?

12
00:00:33.340 --> 00:00:34.000

13

Now, Cherokee, we've talked
a lot about the idea, of course,

of configuring printers and

So what do we really have left to discover

00:00:45.010 --> 00:00:48.040

So something I wanna take a look at is, I

So let's take a look at one

All right, so from Server Manager,

00:01:49.361 --> 00:01:51.812
Now, I already have some printers

I'd like to create a new one.

We haven't really done that from our

So let's take a look at how we would

It's relatively easy, we just right-click
