A lot of different ways you can set up
printing in an enterprise environment.

273
00:16:07.246 --> 00:16:09.994
So, I guess my best advice would
be just to get in there and

274
00:16:09.994 --> 00:16:13.739
practice around with it, because it's
not really something you can avoid.

275
00:16:13.739 --> 00:16:15.224
Although you may try to,

276
00:16:15.224 --> 00:16:18.850
I dont know if you'll have much
success with avoiding that.

277
00:16:18.850 --> 00:16:22.160
So, I think that's about it for
this show, Ronnie.

278
00:16:22.160 --> 00:16:25.804
>> All right, Cherokee, well, thank
you again for helping us out here and

279
00:16:25.804 --> 00:16:29.887
completing our basic knowledge for
the 70-410 on configuring printers.

280
00:16:29.887 --> 00:16:33.425
Remember that we did take a look at
the idea of using group policy to deploy

281
00:16:33.425 --> 00:16:34.590
the printer.

282
00:16:34.590 --> 00:16:37.194
And Cherokee showed us, of course,
how to get that set up and

283
00:16:37.194 --> 00:16:38.277
verify that it did work.

284
00:16:38.277 --> 00:16:42.537
As well as learning about some of these
different PowerShell commands that will

285
00:16:42.537 --> 00:16:46.620
really help us out as well when we do need
to deploy a lot of things at one time.

286
00:16:46.620 --> 00:16:50.553
And be able to verify that those
printers are where they need to be,

287
00:16:50.553 --> 00:16:52.680
as well as renaming them.

288
00:16:52.680 --> 00:16:55.190
All right, well,
that's gonna end our show for now.

289
00:16:55.190 --> 00:16:56.680
There is more to come.

290
00:16:56.680 --> 00:17:00.390
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

291
00:17:00.390 --> 00:17:01.270
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

292
00:17:01.270 --> 00:17:09.300
>> Stay tuned for
more of the MCSA 70-410 shows.

293
00:17:09.300 --> 00:17:12.753
[MUSIC]

294
00:17:12.753 --> 00:17:15.508
>> Thank you for watching ITPROTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee dive into the basic remote management of Windows Server 2012.  Cherokee discusses the need for remote management and discusses the features and that is is enabled by default on Windows Server 2012 R2.  She demonstrates checking the services that must be enabled before establishing Remote Management.  Cherokee uses the `winRM quickconfig` to configure it.  she then uses `winRS` to verify it working.
episodes.title: Configure Servers for Remote Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:06.349
Welcome to ITPRO TV, I'm your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.349 --> 00:00:08.429
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.429 --> 00:00:12.518
>> You're watching ITPROTV.

4
00:00:12.518 --> 00:00:15.652
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPROTV.

5
00:00:15.652 --> 00:00:19.071
You're watching the MCSA for
Windows Server 2012.

6
00:00:19.071 --> 00:00:22.854
We're specifically covering,
of course, exam 70-410, and

7
00:00:22.854 --> 00:00:24.860
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:24.860 --> 00:00:29.540
Today, we're gonna be diving into
configuring servers for remote management.

9
00:00:29.540 --> 00:00:32.380
And here to help us understand it
better is gonna be Ms. Cherokee Boose.

10
00:00:32.380 --> 00:00:33.710
Cherokee, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:33.710 --> 00:00:34.940
>> Well, thank you for having me, Ronnie.

12
00:00:34.940 --> 00:00:36.090
How are you doing today?

13
00:00:36.090 --> 00:00:37.110
>> I'm doing fine.

14
00:00:37.110 --> 00:00:41.660
As we get started here, Cherokee, we have
to ask that kind of big question, why do

15
00:00:41.660 --> 00:00:45.910
we need to configure for remote management
if I can gain access to the servers?

16
00:00:45.910 --> 00:00:48.130
>> Well, actually that's a pretty
invalid question, Ronnie.

17
00:00:48.130 --> 00:00:49.930
And it's not like it's new.

18
00:00:51.170 --> 00:00:54.280
We've had remote desktop protocol,
RDP, around for a while.

19
00:00:54.280 --> 00:00:56.567
So why wouldn't we just use
RDP to go ahead and remote,

20
00:00:56.567 --> 00:00:57.628
if I wanted to remote in?

21
00:00:57.628 --> 00:01:01.269
Because we all know that sitting
in my chair and being relaxed and

22
00:01:01.269 --> 00:01:05.870
comfortable there is a lot easier than
going to an offsite location or whatever.

23
00:01:05.870 --> 00:01:08.600
So let's just think about that for
a second.

24
00:01:08.600 --> 00:01:13.930
If I'm connecting to your system remotely,
utilizing RDP, I still have access.

25
00:01:13.930 --> 00:01:18.196
When I have that session established,
I have all those graphical components and

26
00:01:18.196 --> 00:01:18.830
elements.

27
00:01:18.830 --> 00:01:23.452
But I just am viewing them through like
a little magic looking glass here,

28
00:01:23.452 --> 00:01:27.940
but all that work, all that load is
still happening on your PC, right?

29
00:01:27.940 --> 00:01:30.778
So we're running all those
graphical components and

30
00:01:30.778 --> 00:01:32.930
all that additional processing power.

31
00:01:32.930 --> 00:01:37.523
And Microsoft came up with
a better way to do that.

32
00:01:37.523 --> 00:01:41.495
So we're gonna be looking at different
ways that we can leverage something

33
00:01:41.495 --> 00:01:45.295
here called WinRM for
Windows Remote Management.

34
00:01:45.295 --> 00:01:50.200
And it's kind of interesting, if we take a
look at my screen, the way that WinRM was

35
00:01:50.200 --> 00:01:53.791
developed, it actually piggybacks
off of a protocol here.

36
00:01:53.791 --> 00:01:56.858
So let me scroll right here.

37
00:01:56.858 --> 00:02:00.823
The DWS management protocol was
developed by group of hardware and

38
00:02:00.823 --> 00:02:05.002
software manufacturers as a public
standard for remotely exchanging

39
00:02:05.002 --> 00:02:10.130
management data without any computer
device that implements the protocol.

40
00:02:10.130 --> 00:02:11.730
So here's the thing.

41
00:02:11.730 --> 00:02:14.980
It never really took off as
large as they thought it would.

42
00:02:14.980 --> 00:02:20.192
There are about four large realms that
are utilizing this WS management protocol,

43
00:02:20.192 --> 00:02:21.760
one of them being WinRM.

44
00:02:21.760 --> 00:02:25.480
So that's what we'll start talking
about here in this show today.

45
00:02:25.480 --> 00:02:30.240
So WinRM is gonna be
processing those requests for

46
00:02:30.240 --> 00:02:32.540
remote management over your network.

47
00:02:32.540 --> 00:02:38.270
And it's using http and https, but not the
normal ports that you would expect it to.

48
00:02:38.270 --> 00:02:44.939
So when we're looking at the ports here
we're talking about port 5985 and 5986.

49
00:02:44.939 --> 00:02:47.151
And thinking about, okay,

50
00:02:47.151 --> 00:02:51.180
what do I have to do to remember
all these ports to set this up.

51
00:02:51.180 --> 00:02:53.770
Setting those exclusions
on our firewall list.

52
00:02:53.770 --> 00:02:54.920
Well, here's the thing.

53
00:02:54.920 --> 00:02:59.880
Microsoft really wanted to
streamline this process for us, so

54
00:02:59.880 --> 00:03:03.150
they've also developed some tools
that are pretty handy to help.

55
00:03:04.960 --> 00:03:06.810
Like I said,
streamline that process for us.

56
00:03:06.810 --> 00:03:11.070
So instead of going through and creating
all of our different components and

57
00:03:11.070 --> 00:03:12.620
prerequisites, it's like
a little checklist,

58
00:03:12.620 --> 00:03:15.060
such as some things that I wanna do.

59
00:03:15.060 --> 00:03:17.290
Number one, okay, so
I do need to check those firewalls.

60
00:03:17.290 --> 00:03:21.176
But, hey, Microsoft's got some tools,
I'll show you how we can do that.

61
00:03:21.176 --> 00:03:27.321
Also, talking about receiving those
remote communications over the network,

62
00:03:27.321 --> 00:03:32.484
we need a way to hear and listen for
those session requests, right?

63
00:03:32.484 --> 00:03:33.920
So we need listeners.

64
00:03:33.920 --> 00:03:36.940
So that's not something that
we have to configure manually

65
00:03:36.940 --> 00:03:38.870
with the use of these tools,
so it's pretty cool.

66
00:03:38.870 --> 00:03:42.650
We have a couple different ways
that we can actually access them

67
00:03:42.650 --> 00:03:45.410
by using Windows Remote Management.

68
00:03:45.410 --> 00:03:48.030
Windows Remote Management is
actually a service, Ronnie.

69
00:03:48.030 --> 00:03:50.160
And we can take a look at
that in a few moments,

70
00:03:50.160 --> 00:03:54.820
right within services.msc, just to make
sure that it's running, of course.

71
00:03:54.820 --> 00:03:56.410
We can't utilize it if it's not running.

72
00:03:57.420 --> 00:04:04.176
So by default, in Server 2012 and
2012 R2, it is enabled by default.

73
00:04:04.176 --> 00:04:06.862
Also, server 2016.

74
00:04:06.862 --> 00:04:12.130
We'll also talk about different ways
that we can manage down-level servers.

75
00:04:12.130 --> 00:04:13.517
If you think about it,

76
00:04:13.517 --> 00:04:19.284
not every single network in this world is
only using 2012 2012 R2 and above, right?

77
00:04:19.284 --> 00:04:22.363
So there's a little bit of
configuration you do there.

78
00:04:22.363 --> 00:04:26.410
But it sure is an improvement over
some of those older methodology,

79
00:04:26.410 --> 00:04:29.823
especially with a DCOM which
was not firewall friendly.

80
00:04:29.823 --> 00:04:32.270
So that's what we'll be
talking about today.

81
00:04:32.270 --> 00:04:33.559
>> All right, Cherokee, so

82
00:04:33.559 --> 00:04:37.146
what are we really accessing when we
use this idea of remote management?

83
00:04:37.146 --> 00:04:39.028
What protocol or
what is it that we're doing here?

84
00:04:39.028 --> 00:04:41.730
>> So
we're actually gonna be hooking into WMI,

85
00:04:41.730 --> 00:04:44.581
which is
Windows Management Instrumentation.

86
00:04:44.581 --> 00:04:47.162
So that's what we'll be hooking into.

87
00:04:47.162 --> 00:04:48.420
There are a couple different ways.

88
00:04:48.420 --> 00:04:51.050
Actually, if we take a look at my screen,

89
00:04:51.050 --> 00:04:54.250
I can pull up a diagram I've got here,
just to kinda cover.

90
00:04:54.250 --> 00:04:57.920
And we'll look at each one of these
in depth, these methodologies here.

91
00:04:57.920 --> 00:05:01.860
But there are different ways that
we can hook into WMI here, so

92
00:05:01.860 --> 00:05:04.030
number one being the GUI, right?

93
00:05:04.030 --> 00:05:06.539
So if you watch some of the other shows,
and

94
00:05:06.539 --> 00:05:11.004
we've kind of got into the server manager,
you've already seen that we can

95
00:05:11.004 --> 00:05:14.315
manage servers remotely from
within server managers.

96
00:05:14.315 --> 00:05:18.239
So that's one way that we
could do that using WinRM.

97
00:05:18.239 --> 00:05:21.925
You can also use some other
graphical components as well,

98
00:05:21.925 --> 00:05:27.290
like those management tools, when we were
discussing different roles and features.

99
00:05:27.290 --> 00:05:32.213
If I have the Microsoft Management
Console, so my MMC and my snap-ins,

100
00:05:32.213 --> 00:05:37.237
that's a graphical element that I'm
just gonna bundle in this GUI here.

101
00:05:37.237 --> 00:05:41.184
Because the underpinning technology,
we're still using WinRM and

102
00:05:41.184 --> 00:05:44.260
hooking into the WMI there,
so pretty cool.

103
00:05:44.260 --> 00:05:49.040
And we also have the ability to
use command line tools to execute

104
00:05:49.040 --> 00:05:51.060
commands remotely as well.

105
00:05:51.060 --> 00:05:55.186
We'll take a look at those, and we have
the ability to use PowerShell as well.

106
00:05:55.186 --> 00:05:58.210
Of course,
PowerShell's gonna be a great way for

107
00:05:58.210 --> 00:06:02.510
us to also manage multiple
computers at one time here.

108
00:06:02.510 --> 00:06:07.400
So, just to really simplify
administration for remote management.

109
00:06:07.400 --> 00:06:12.070
>> All right, so Cherokee, if we wanna get
this idea of remote management set up and

110
00:06:12.070 --> 00:06:16.210
configured to go, what do we need
to get started with as we do this?

111
00:06:16.210 --> 00:06:17.950
>> Okay, so first, let's take a look here.

112
00:06:17.950 --> 00:06:21.148
I just wanna show you in a machine here.

113
00:06:21.148 --> 00:06:22.169
Which one can I pull up?

114
00:06:22.169 --> 00:06:23.720
I've got a couple going on.

115
00:06:23.720 --> 00:06:26.890
You always wanna make
sure that it is enabled.

116
00:06:26.890 --> 00:06:29.260
Like I said, it is enabled by default.

117
00:06:29.260 --> 00:06:33.400
But if you're having issues, and we'll get
to troubleshooting in a little bit and

118
00:06:33.400 --> 00:06:35.380
where you can get help for that.

119
00:06:35.380 --> 00:06:40.110
You can see right here in the Graphical
User Interface Writing Server Manager,

120
00:06:40.110 --> 00:06:42.690
it says remote management enabled.

121
00:06:42.690 --> 00:06:46.073
So that's what it would
like look like by default.

122
00:06:46.073 --> 00:06:49.517
You could also check here,
let me just pull up a run line.

123
00:06:49.517 --> 00:06:53.119
Oops, gotta login.

124
00:06:53.119 --> 00:06:53.752
>> You're not typing.

125
00:06:53.752 --> 00:06:58.829
>> Yeah, I do that all the time.

126
00:06:58.829 --> 00:07:01.390
[LAUGH] All right, [LAUGH] so let me
go ahead and pull up my run line here.

127
00:07:02.540 --> 00:07:05.068
So it's already in here, and
I'll just zoom in so you can see that.

128
00:07:05.068 --> 00:07:09.620
We've got services.msc, and we'll go
ahead and pull up our services page and

129
00:07:09.620 --> 00:07:12.090
take a look at that.

130
00:07:12.090 --> 00:07:14.530
Let's take a full screen,

131
00:07:14.530 --> 00:07:18.830
and it's going to be all the way
down here at the bottom of our list.

132
00:07:20.270 --> 00:07:23.350
And let's see, all right, so right here.

133
00:07:24.840 --> 00:07:29.779
Windows Remote Management, so
WS Management is going to be the service

134
00:07:29.779 --> 00:07:33.826
that we wanna enable,
to verify that it's running here.

135
00:07:33.826 --> 00:07:38.712
Now, right behind my head there,
if you look at the actual status,

136
00:07:38.712 --> 00:07:40.790
it is set to be automatic.

137
00:07:40.790 --> 00:07:45.061
Which is really important because you
wanna make sure that if that system

138
00:07:45.061 --> 00:07:50.117
reboots or whatever, you're still gonna
have that service start upon that reboot.

139
00:07:50.117 --> 00:07:53.613
Because obviously the service has to
be running in order to utilize that.

140
00:07:53.613 --> 00:07:58.125
And you can even see WMI here
as well running as automatic.

141
00:07:58.125 --> 00:07:59.664
Because that's, like I said,

142
00:07:59.664 --> 00:08:03.717
that's what we're gonna be hooking in
that Windows Management instrumentation.

143
00:08:03.717 --> 00:08:09.442
Of course you could always check
the status of a service within PowerShell,

144
00:08:09.442 --> 00:08:11.330
but that's just great.

145
00:08:11.330 --> 00:08:13.950
But what if someone were to go ahead and
disable that, so

146
00:08:13.950 --> 00:08:15.490
what do we do in that situation?

147
00:08:15.490 --> 00:08:19.970
How do we bring the system back
up to that default configuration?

148
00:08:19.970 --> 00:08:22.152
So we'll take a look at that also.

149
00:08:22.152 --> 00:08:25.640
>> All right, Cherokee, so where are we
gonna end up getting started here?

150
00:08:25.640 --> 00:08:33.070
Now that we've verified that we have the
remote management enabled there, now that

151
00:08:33.070 --> 00:08:36.790
we've also talked about the service and we
see it started, those are the things that

152
00:08:36.790 --> 00:08:39.310
we have to get ready on the machines
that we're gonna do this with.

153
00:08:39.310 --> 00:08:40.130
So what's next?

154
00:08:40.130 --> 00:08:40.880
>> Okay, so

155
00:08:40.880 --> 00:08:44.400
let's go ahead and take a look at,
I have a couple different machines here.

156
00:08:44.400 --> 00:08:47.461
I've got DC01,
that's my domain controller.

157
00:08:47.461 --> 00:08:50.780
I had DM01, so domain number one and
domain number two.

158
00:08:50.780 --> 00:08:54.340
I also have a client over here,
Windows 10 client, which is really cool.

159
00:08:54.340 --> 00:08:59.540
Because, Ronnie, if you think about it,
maybe I have like a limited budget.

160
00:08:59.540 --> 00:09:05.240
And I don't have like
a machine to just dedicate to

161
00:09:05.240 --> 00:09:10.320
management like a server side with all
the hardware, the robustness of that.

162
00:09:10.320 --> 00:09:14.068
So what if I just have a client operating
system, so I don't have to spend so

163
00:09:14.068 --> 00:09:15.500
much for licensing.

164
00:09:15.500 --> 00:09:20.550
I can actually utilize these tools to
manage from a client operating system.

165
00:09:20.550 --> 00:09:24.090
So it's not just network operating
system to network operating system.

166
00:09:24.090 --> 00:09:26.790
That's another really cool
feature that we have here.

167
00:09:26.790 --> 00:09:28.460
But we'll get into that in a little bit,

168
00:09:28.460 --> 00:09:32.670
because you would need to take a look
at some configuration as well.

169
00:09:32.670 --> 00:09:36.790
So first thing's first,
let's go into DM01.

170
00:09:36.790 --> 00:09:39.300
Okay, so
PowerShell's already pulled up here.

171
00:09:39.300 --> 00:09:43.097
Oops, again, logon.

172
00:09:43.097 --> 00:09:45.749
And-
>> And

173
00:09:45.749 --> 00:09:47.584
you have to actually click and type in.

174
00:09:47.584 --> 00:09:54.700
>> [LAUGH] Right, you gotta love
the controls with my VM here.

175
00:09:54.700 --> 00:09:58.420
Okay, cool, and
let me just move this over.

176
00:09:59.660 --> 00:10:06.199
So the first tool that I wanna take a look
at here, this is going to be winrm.exe.

177
00:10:06.199 --> 00:10:10.459
I would like to note that,
although I do have PowerShell pulled up,

178
00:10:10.459 --> 00:10:14.610
you can utilize winrm.exe in
an elevated command prompt.

179
00:10:14.610 --> 00:10:19.510
So it's not a cmdlet per se,
it's a command line utility here.

180
00:10:19.510 --> 00:10:24.630
Now there's a quick config option
that we'll be taking a look at here.

181
00:10:24.630 --> 00:10:28.390
So what this quick config
will allow us to do

182
00:10:28.390 --> 00:10:33.310
is to allow us to utilize another tool for
WinRS, for remote shell.

183
00:10:34.610 --> 00:10:39.770
Instead of manually going
through the process and

184
00:10:39.770 --> 00:10:45.360
implementing all the different firewall
rules and setting up a listener,

185
00:10:45.360 --> 00:10:49.650
this tool that we're about to look at
will automate that process for us.

186
00:10:49.650 --> 00:10:51.310
So pretty cool, Ronnie.

187
00:10:51.310 --> 00:10:52.734
>> Sounds good.
>> All right, so

188
00:10:52.734 --> 00:10:55.132
the first thing I wanna just check.

189
00:10:55.132 --> 00:10:56.292
Okay, so we did check,

190
00:10:56.292 --> 00:11:00.100
I don't remember if we checked on this
machine if it was running or not.

191
00:11:00.100 --> 00:11:00.938
>> Yeah, I don't think we have.

192
00:11:00.938 --> 00:11:02.170
>> All right, so we can just check here.

193
00:11:02.170 --> 00:11:05.270
So let's just say check-service.

194
00:11:05.270 --> 00:11:08.180
And this is our WinRM service.

195
00:11:08.180 --> 00:11:13.069
Okay, so it stopped here and
I think we had even before the show, oops,

196
00:11:13.069 --> 00:11:14.220
disabled that.

197
00:11:14.220 --> 00:11:16.148
Yep, so this one, we are on DM01.

198
00:11:16.148 --> 00:11:16.990
It is disabled.

199
00:11:16.990 --> 00:11:17.530
It's stopped.

200
00:11:17.530 --> 00:11:20.277
So let's go ahead and
see how we can fix that.

201
00:11:20.277 --> 00:11:24.830
All right, now, I do wanna show you one
other way you can check on that, also.

202
00:11:24.830 --> 00:11:27.420
Let's type in WinRM.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue with remote management using powershell.  Cherokee demonstrates different powershell commands to enable PS remoting.  She also demonstrates how to use the Server Manager and MMC to connect and do remote management of Server 2012 R2.
episodes.title: Configure Servers for Remote Management Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee look at the Windows Firewall rules for Remote Management.  Cherokee shows how to configure them using the GUI and using netsh.   She also configures SMRemoting and multi-server management for remote management using powershell

00:00:27.232 --> 00:00:27.972
How are you doing today, Cherokee?

>> Hey, I'm doing great, and recently

I've heard a lot about

So it definitely seems to be

00:00:39.550 --> 00:00:40.596

What's so great about virtualization and

>> So, virtualization is something
that's been around for a while.

19
00:00:46.310 --> 00:00:50.830
A matter of fact, there were
projects seeking started by MIT and

20
00:00:50.830 --> 00:00:55.200
different organizations as early
as the 1960s, the late 60s.

21
00:00:55.200 --> 00:00:59.490
So it wasn't until IBM really brought
it out into the commercial use,

22
00:00:59.490 --> 00:01:02.330
but we see this all over the place,
especially in cloud computing,

23
00:01:02.330 --> 00:01:04.320
it's such a common thing nowadays.

24
00:01:04.320 --> 00:01:07.460
So it's kind of a strange concept, Wes.

25
00:01:07.460 --> 00:01:12.850
It's taking something that's really not

26
00:01:12.850 --> 00:01:15.720
We can interact with it and

27
00:01:15.720 --> 00:01:17.370
So if we had a physical machine,

28
00:01:17.370 --> 00:01:21.340
we can allocate those physical
resources to our virtual machines.

29
00:01:21.340 --> 00:01:25.249
Things like our network interface cards,
we can go ahead and

30
00:01:25.249 --> 00:01:28.403

31

We can take disk space and
actually create different ISO images and

32

running as operating systems there.

33
00:01:40.100 --> 00:01:41.220
Memory's kind of different.

34
00:01:41.220 --> 00:01:42.350
Memory is memory.

35
00:01:42.350 --> 00:01:46.070
We can't kind of fudge those numbers
there with our virtual environments.

36
00:01:46.070 --> 00:01:48.680
They really do love to use that memory so
we'll talk about

37
00:01:48.680 --> 00:01:53.760
that a little later as well because a
virtualization has come a really long way.

38
00:01:53.760 --> 00:01:56.985
And it's not what it use to
be with just virtual PC or

39
00:01:56.985 --> 00:02:02.140
what were some of the earlier
implementations, Microsoft Virtual Server.

40
00:02:02.140 --> 00:02:05.440
We actually see some pretty cool
improvements over the years in Server

00:02:05.440 --> 00:02:10.960
2012, and 2012 R2 definitely bring

00:02:10.960 --> 00:02:13.636

So aside from your normal prerequisites

00:02:33.290 --> 00:02:37.854

00:02:37.854 --> 00:02:40.762
So let's go ahead and

00:02:40.762 --> 00:02:44.957
So you can see a couple of steps, just to

50
00:02:44.957 --> 00:02:48.801
to run Hyper-V, bringing up machines and
we'll talk about all of that.

51
00:02:48.801 --> 00:02:52.568
But let's just click on this
option here to install Hyper-V.

00:02:52.568 --> 00:02:56.552
And I mean, we can see here we've

And again we are gonna be really focusing
on the Hyper-V role in Server 2012 or

55
00:03:08.232 --> 00:03:09.180
2012 R2.

00:03:23.110 --> 00:03:25.730
We can use on the client side

00:03:25.730 --> 00:03:31.600
So we can actually run Hyper-V right

00:03:31.600 --> 00:03:35.021
Pretty easy to go ahead and

Just remember that this

00:03:46.111 --> 00:03:49.430
But it's always a possibility to go

67
00:03:49.430 --> 00:03:51.459
>> Speaking of availability
there Cherokee,

00:03:51.459 --> 00:03:55.015
one of the things that I think of is if
we can run client side Hyper-V, right,

69
00:03:55.015 --> 00:03:58.493
I've had to install things like .NET
Framework for different programs.

70
00:03:58.493 --> 00:04:01.570
So I've had to go into that program and
feature role and turn on things like that.

71
00:04:01.570 --> 00:04:03.720
If I can go into programs and features and

00:04:03.720 --> 00:04:07.310
I can turn on Client Hyper-V,
why wouldn't I just run Client Hyper-V?

73
00:04:07.310 --> 00:04:11.130
Why would I go through the process of
installing the role on a server product,

74
00:04:11.130 --> 00:04:12.960

75
00:04:12.960 --> 00:04:14.620
Just go ahead and stay with the client.

76

>> That's a really great question, Wes,

77
00:04:16.380 --> 00:04:19.225
because if we think about the logic
behind that, you're like, hey.

78
00:04:19.225 --> 00:04:22.990
Client operating systems, the licensing's

00:08:51.059 --> 00:08:51.961

00:08:51.961 --> 00:08:57.737
So in earlier versions of virtualization,
and even the server 2008,

150
00:08:57.737 --> 00:09:02.360
it wasn't called Gen 1 because
there wasn't a Gen 2 yet.

151
00:09:02.360 --> 00:09:05.002
So with the advent of Gen 2 then we

152
00:09:05.002 --> 00:09:09.690
retroactively name those
older systems Gen 1.

153
00:09:09.690 --> 00:09:12.120
So we have two options,

154
00:09:12.120 --> 00:09:16.795
and when we create our virtual machines
we'll need to make that decision.

155
00:09:16.795 --> 00:09:21.370
Because this is not, a lot of different
options that we see we can easily change,

156
00:09:21.370 --> 00:09:22.840
but this isn't one of them.

157
00:09:22.840 --> 00:09:28.440
I won't say it's impossible to change,
but Microsoft,

158
00:09:28.440 --> 00:09:31.480
if you're taking the exam that's
something that you need to be aware of,

159
00:09:31.480 --> 00:09:34.020
they do say that it's
something you cannot change.

160
00:09:34.020 --> 00:09:37.680
So it's something you'll need to choose
wisely when you're making this decision of

161
00:09:37.680 --> 00:09:40.270
hey, am I gonna create Gen 1 or Gen 2?

162
00:09:40.270 --> 00:09:43.500
And here's the deal,
Gen 1 is really good for

163
00:09:43.500 --> 00:09:47.059
environments if you have older systems,

164
00:09:48.480 --> 00:09:55.190
you can't even use Vista or previous
operating systems as Gen 2 machines.

165
00:09:55.190 --> 00:10:00.266
So if you kind of have a mixed
environment, or even anticipate needing

166
00:10:00.266 --> 00:10:05.955
an older system for that particular
machine, then definitely go with Gen 1.

167
00:10:05.955 --> 00:10:09.835
It's not a huge performance
any kind of lack there,

168
00:10:09.835 --> 00:10:13.550
they're pretty comparable
Gen 1 versus Gen 2.

169
00:10:13.550 --> 00:10:19.156
But the hardware components you'll
see a big change there if we note Gen

170
00:10:19.156 --> 00:10:25.270
1 is gonna be based off of a BIOS platform
whereas Gen 2 is gonna be with UEFI.

171
00:10:25.270 --> 00:10:29.210
So again back to the operating system
that will be running on that machine, for

172
00:10:29.210 --> 00:10:34.340
instance if I'm talking about our newer
operating systems they're based on UEFI so

173
00:10:34.340 --> 00:10:36.830
I wouldn't even be able to
install them on a Gen 1.

174
00:10:36.830 --> 00:10:40.510
So really looking at your environment
that's what's gonna determine what's

175
00:10:40.510 --> 00:10:43.700
better for you, not Gen 1 is
better than Gen 2 or whatever.

176
00:10:44.760 --> 00:10:49.230
Just the way that it's designed,
for instance Gen 1 machines and

177
00:10:49.230 --> 00:10:52.310
the way that they're configured and
that they boot they're gonna be booting

178
00:10:52.310 --> 00:10:56.400
off of IDE drives,
whereas we would use IDE for

179
00:10:56.400 --> 00:11:01.880
the ISO images that we're booting to
as well as for the HD and VHDX files.

180
00:11:01.880 --> 00:11:07.970
Gen 2 utilizes SCSI drives for those VHD
and VHDX files, as well as those ISOs.

181
00:11:09.210 --> 00:11:16.540
You can use SCSI, but strictly for storage
in Gen 1, so there are some issues there,

182
00:11:16.540 --> 00:11:22.826
you don't have access to older
components such as floppy drives and

183
00:11:22.826 --> 00:11:26.960
comports in your Gen 2
that you do in Gen 1.

184
00:11:26.960 --> 00:11:31.615
So really just looking at those factors
that will be the decision when you're

00:11:31.615 --> 00:11:34.626

virtual machine wizard or

00:22:57.562 --> 00:23:01.200

00:23:01.200 --> 00:23:05.728

00:23:05.728 --> 00:23:09.143
So think about, remember, we're pulling
our memory from a physical machine.

380
00:23:09.143 --> 00:23:12.507
We're talking about one virtual machine,

381
00:23:12.507 --> 00:23:17.477
I might be sharing that physical
machine with 100 other machines.

382
00:23:17.477 --> 00:23:20.700
So if I'm not using that memory,
then why don't I share?

00:23:20.700 --> 00:23:23.723
Because sharing is caring and I can
allow another machine to go ahead, and

384
00:23:23.723 --> 00:23:24.466

00:23:24.466 --> 00:23:29.844

00:23:29.844 --> 00:23:35.003

00:23:35.003 --> 00:23:38.711
So for instance,
if I'm using a gig of memory,

00:23:38.711 --> 00:23:45.180
my buffer would be sitting there at

00:23:48.603 --> 00:23:53.108

How can I kind of ensure that hey, when

403
00:24:28.926 --> 00:24:32.953
is going to make sure that I have this
kind of memory ready to go when I need it?

404
00:24:32.953 --> 00:24:36.814
So that I don't get like a memory
exhaustion on one of these machines that

405
00:24:36.814 --> 00:24:40.655

00:24:40.655 --> 00:24:41.895
>> Sure, well, that's a great question.

00:24:41.895 --> 00:24:44.185
It's valid and it does happen,

00:24:44.185 --> 00:24:47.501
So what we can do actually,
it's right in that same section there.

I don't know if my head's
kind of covering it.

00:24:50.158 --> 00:24:54.209
But if you see right here, there's
a sliding option where it starts over on

411
00:24:54.209 --> 00:24:58.900

that section is called memory weight.

00:24:58.900 --> 00:25:02.119
So if I wanted to grant
you a higher priority,

413
00:25:02.119 --> 00:25:06.634
then I can give you a higher
weight on that particular machine.

414
00:25:06.634 --> 00:25:10.260
And basically saying, you're more
important, give you the higher precedence.

00:25:10.260 --> 00:25:14.087
So that if there was that
contention occurring in that event,

00:25:14.087 --> 00:25:18.516

for our comparison operators here.

241
00:13:25.840 --> 00:13:28.420
So if you've never seen these before.

242
00:13:28.420 --> 00:13:30.860
And I'm typing them out, and you're like,
well, what the heck is Cherokee typing?

243
00:13:30.860 --> 00:13:34.553
Well, this is where I'm getting
this information, okay?

244
00:13:34.553 --> 00:13:39.352
So for my -eq, that means equals,
like equals, and

245
00:13:39.352 --> 00:13:44.698
then you can also use less than,
greater than, so gt, lt.

246
00:13:44.698 --> 00:13:48.898
So just to kind of get an idea and
a feel for where you could go ahead and

247
00:13:48.898 --> 00:13:50.466
find those components.

248
00:13:50.466 --> 00:13:52.568
All right, so let's use them.

249
00:13:52.568 --> 00:13:56.642
Let me pull PowerShell back up here and
just clear the screen.

250
00:13:56.642 --> 00:13:57.983
What do we wanna do here?

251
00:13:57.983 --> 00:14:00.463
Okay, so
right now the machine that I'm on,

252
00:14:00.463 --> 00:14:03.157
I'm actually on the machine
running Hyper-V.

253
00:14:03.157 --> 00:14:06.614
So I have everything already set up,
installed.

254
00:14:06.614 --> 00:14:08.980
Actually let me just minimize that so
you can see that.

255
00:14:08.980 --> 00:14:11.800
I'll go ahead and
pull up my Hyper-V Manager.

256
00:14:13.280 --> 00:14:17.610
Okay, so
I have some virtual machines right here.

257
00:14:18.630 --> 00:14:21.678
None of them area actually on,
so let me just put a couple on.

258
00:14:21.678 --> 00:14:23.227
We'll say Connect.

259
00:14:23.227 --> 00:14:25.840
And then just turn on our
domain controller here.

260
00:14:25.840 --> 00:14:26.790
That should be good for now.

261
00:14:26.790 --> 00:14:30.827
I just kind of want to give
some variations there.

262
00:14:30.827 --> 00:14:33.386
We may be using that in a moment.

263
00:14:33.386 --> 00:14:35.506
All right, so let's pull back PowerShell.

264
00:14:35.506 --> 00:14:38.568
Now, we're gonna be using a command here.

265
00:14:38.568 --> 00:14:43.730
This is going to be a command that will
return machines that are powered on.

266
00:14:43.730 --> 00:14:47.342
And you'll get to see how we can
use that comparison operator here.

267
00:14:47.342 --> 00:14:52.711
So we'll say Get-vm and then we'll
take the output of that command and

268
00:14:52.711 --> 00:14:55.231
pipe it into something, where.

269
00:14:55.231 --> 00:15:03.888
And then we'll use our curly brackets to
declare a variable here for our variable.

270
00:15:03.888 --> 00:15:06.860
It's going to be where the state
is going to be equal to, so eq.

271
00:15:06.860 --> 00:15:11.148
And we'll go ahead and say off.

272
00:15:11.148 --> 00:15:16.472
And, oops, I used a double quote, so we'll
go ahead and put a single quote here.

273
00:15:16.472 --> 00:15:22.374
And don't forget to end that curly bracket
there, you always have to do that.

274
00:15:22.374 --> 00:15:23.870
And we'll hit Enter.

275
00:15:23.870 --> 00:15:26.650
And you can see in a table format

276
00:15:26.650 --> 00:15:30.490
that the operating system was able
to provide that information to me.

277
00:15:30.490 --> 00:15:34.714
The hypervisor was able to say hey look,
these are the virtual machines that you

278
00:15:34.714 --> 00:15:37.360
have on this system that
are in an off state.

279
00:15:37.360 --> 00:15:42.938
And it's really simple to go ahead and
change that value here, instead of off.

280
00:15:42.938 --> 00:15:48.974
You'd think it would say on but that's not
the case here, it's going to be running.

281
00:15:48.974 --> 00:15:54.004
All right, so if we just go ahead and
hit running, we can see PLABDCO1,

282
00:15:54.004 --> 00:15:57.469
that domain controller
that we just turned on so,

283
00:15:57.469 --> 00:16:01.839
This can be helpful in a crunch,
just to go ahead and set those,

284
00:16:01.839 --> 00:16:06.070
declare those aliases and
set those comparison operators.

285
00:16:07.560 --> 00:16:12.322
Also, if I wanted to,
I'm not gonna do this right now, but

286
00:16:12.322 --> 00:16:17.205
I could, let's say,
take the output of this last command.

287
00:16:17.205 --> 00:16:20.952
I could also pipe that into something
where, hey, maybe I wanna shut down,

288
00:16:20.952 --> 00:16:23.840
power down or power on my machines,
I could also go ahead.

289
00:16:23.840 --> 00:16:28.936
Since this one is running,
we could just say stop,

290
00:16:28.936 --> 00:16:32.380
and then go ahead and type in -VM.

291
00:16:32.380 --> 00:16:36.648
And then that would be a quick way, oops,
not with a bracket there, all right,

292
00:16:36.648 --> 00:16:40.852
to go ahead and say, hey, I'm gonna go
ahead and power up all of the machines or

293
00:16:40.852 --> 00:16:42.480
power down all the machines.

294
00:16:42.480 --> 00:16:49.740
And you could also selectively choose one
where you add the name parameter also.

295
00:16:49.740 --> 00:16:52.150
So a couple different ways
you could use that there.

296
00:16:54.040 --> 00:16:58.880
Let's see, I kinda wanna pull this
down a little bit and clear it off so

297
00:16:58.880 --> 00:17:01.370
we can see what we're doing here,
give ourselves a little bit of space.

298
00:17:04.853 --> 00:17:08.346
Don't mind me.

299
00:17:08.346 --> 00:17:12.842
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Okay, all right, so

300
00:17:12.842 --> 00:17:14.890
as long as we can see.

301
00:17:14.890 --> 00:17:17.850
It might be a little bit difficult to see,
but I kinda wanna have both of these

302
00:17:17.850 --> 00:17:20.575
windows up so you can see what's
happening in the background as well.

303
00:17:20.575 --> 00:17:25.300
Wes, we kind of mentioned,
we were talking about snapshots,

304
00:17:25.300 --> 00:17:29.810
checkpoints, whatever you wanna call them
nowadays, and how helpful they can be.

305
00:17:29.810 --> 00:17:32.580
So yes, we can create them in
the graphical user interface, but

306
00:17:32.580 --> 00:17:36.800
I also wanted to just show you how we can
create them here in PowerShell as well.

307
00:17:36.800 --> 00:17:37.710
Pretty helpful tool.

308
00:17:37.710 --> 00:17:41.420
So what we'll do is we'll type get-VM.

309
00:17:41.420 --> 00:17:44.561
And here, we'll go ahead and
specify the name for this machine.

310
00:17:44.561 --> 00:17:46.698
And we'll just use PLABDC01,

311
00:17:46.698 --> 00:17:51.220
since that one is the one that
we have powered on right now.

312
00:17:51.220 --> 00:17:54.630
And we'll take the output of that, so once
we get that machine, we'll go ahead and

313
00:17:54.630 --> 00:17:56.962
pipe that into a checkpoint.

314
00:17:58.520 --> 00:18:00.670
And checkpoint-VM.

315
00:18:00.670 --> 00:18:03.602
We need to name, and it's kind of funny.

316
00:18:03.602 --> 00:18:08.417
Actually, in this syntax, they combined
both the different names here, so

317
00:18:08.417 --> 00:18:13.168
you'll see checkpoint, and
then we actually give it a -snapshot name.

318
00:18:13.168 --> 00:18:13.865
>> That's not confusing.

319
00:18:13.865 --> 00:18:16.355
>> [LAUGH] Never, they never are.

320
00:18:16.355 --> 00:18:20.650
So something that I like
to do with my snapshots,

321
00:18:20.650 --> 00:18:25.020
I always like to include the month,
the date.

322
00:18:25.020 --> 00:18:27.970
And then kind of like, hey,
why are you creating this snapshot?

323
00:18:27.970 --> 00:18:31.220
So maybe I'm gonna name this one update,
and then kb.

324
00:18:31.220 --> 00:18:36.000
So if it was a particular kb number for
that update, I would go ahead and

325
00:18:36.000 --> 00:18:37.540
put that in here.

326
00:18:37.540 --> 00:18:41.880
And whatever kind of month/date
format that your company uses,

327
00:18:41.880 --> 00:18:44.590
it might be the day, month, whatever.

328
00:18:44.590 --> 00:18:49.340
We'll just hit Enter here, and it'll
go ahead and generate that checkpoint.

329
00:18:49.340 --> 00:18:50.780
And you can see right
here in the background,

330
00:18:50.780 --> 00:18:52.040
that's what I wanted you to see,

331
00:18:52.040 --> 00:18:55.410
that that checkpoint is
actually being generated there.

332
00:18:55.410 --> 00:18:59.080
So if we were to check on that,
you just click on the machine,

333
00:18:59.080 --> 00:19:01.040
and then your checkpoints are listed here.

334
00:19:01.040 --> 00:19:04.310
And sometimes It's kinda
folded up like that.

335
00:19:04.310 --> 00:19:07.520
And you would just need to, oops,
right behind me, hit that arrow there, and

336
00:19:07.520 --> 00:19:08.340
then right here.

337
00:19:08.340 --> 00:19:09.270
And you could see that,

338
00:19:09.270 --> 00:19:13.060
hey, look, this is that particular
checkpoint that we just created.

339
00:19:14.210 --> 00:19:16.620
That I could revert to it if,
for whatever reason,

340
00:19:16.620 --> 00:19:19.530
that update were to crash my system or
something like that.

341
00:19:19.530 --> 00:19:22.284
>> And would you recommend that if
you do have a naming convention,

342
00:19:22.284 --> 00:19:25.395
cuz you mentioned the way you like to
name it, and that keeps it in check.

343
00:19:25.395 --> 00:19:29.280
Checkpoint, all pun intended right here,
hall of blame here.

344
00:19:29.280 --> 00:19:31.451
Whatever naming convention you start with,
just keep it consistent so

345
00:19:31.451 --> 00:19:32.763
you can come back and see what's going on.

346
00:19:32.763 --> 00:19:35.150
>> So we're in the United States,
and it's pretty common.

347
00:19:35.150 --> 00:19:39.259
A lot of Americans will type it like this,
but in all the other parts of the world,

348
00:19:39.259 --> 00:19:41.200
they go ahead and use it the other way.

349
00:19:41.200 --> 00:19:45.019
And in a lot of programming languages,
you'll see it that way, too, so yeah,

350
00:19:45.019 --> 00:19:47.590
it just depends, and
then stay consistent, right?

351
00:19:47.590 --> 00:19:48.210
>> Mm-hm.

352
00:19:48.210 --> 00:19:51.500
>> Now, that was it for
this particular show, Wes.

353
00:19:51.500 --> 00:19:55.550
I just wanted to really round out how to
go ahead and get those machines up and

354
00:19:55.550 --> 00:19:57.270
running, those virtual machines.

355
00:19:57.270 --> 00:20:00.530
But we still have a lot of configuration
to do, so I think we'll come back and

356
00:20:00.530 --> 00:20:02.260
show that in the next shows.

357
00:20:02.260 --> 00:20:04.060
>> All right, sounds good,
a lot of great information.

358
00:20:04.060 --> 00:20:05.160
I know I love PowerShell.

359
00:20:05.160 --> 00:20:06.780
We hope you like PowerShell out there.

360
00:20:06.780 --> 00:20:10.243
And keep in mind, it's not necessarily
that they're gonna want you to know every

361
00:20:10.243 --> 00:20:11.155
command on the exam.

362
00:20:11.155 --> 00:20:14.257
But they're definitely gonna want you
to know what Cherokee's showing you.

363
00:20:14.257 --> 00:20:17.260
And then some of those basic commands,
commandlets, I guess we should say.

364
00:20:17.260 --> 00:20:20.750
Get them under your belt so
that you'll pass that 7410 exam.

365
00:20:20.750 --> 00:20:23.110
Now, it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

366
00:20:23.110 --> 00:20:25.890
But before we do, any final words
that maybe you'd like to impart to

367
00:20:25.890 --> 00:20:28.490
the viewers when it comes to using
PowerShell and working with Hyper-V?

368
00:20:28.490 --> 00:20:29.810
>> Can I give them
another cliffhanger here?

369
00:20:29.810 --> 00:20:30.854
>> Absolutely, you can.

370
00:20:30.854 --> 00:20:32.814
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I tell you what, we'll go ahead and

371
00:20:32.814 --> 00:20:34.440
we'll end it right there then.

372
00:20:34.440 --> 00:20:37.040
And you'll just have to stick
around here and come back and

373
00:20:37.040 --> 00:20:38.320
see some of the other shows.

374
00:20:38.320 --> 00:20:39.660
Cherokee, we appreciate,
as always, you being here.

375
00:20:39.660 --> 00:20:40.540
>> Thank you, Wes.

376
00:20:40.540 --> 00:20:42.620
>> And we appreciate you,
the viewer, watching.

377
00:20:42.620 --> 00:20:45.140
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

378
00:20:45.140 --> 00:20:46.000
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

379
00:20:46.000 --> 00:20:46.925
>> And we'll see you next time.

380
00:20:46.925 --> 00:20:53.450
[MUSIC]

00:20:53.450 --> 00:20:56.555
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Cherokee focus on a feature enhancement in the form a software package within Hyper-v called Guest Integration Services. They explain what it is and how it can be used to help optimize the guest OS experience. Tune in for a demo showing how to enable it.
episodes.title: Configure Guest Integration Services
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:00.946
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:00.946 --> 00:00:02.484
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.484 --> 00:00:05.897
Coming to you live from [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.897 --> 00:00:07.953
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.953 --> 00:00:11.835
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:11.835 --> 00:00:14.781
>> Hello, and welcome back to another
great episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.781 --> 00:00:16.720
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and

8
00:00:16.720 --> 00:00:21.060
in today's episode we are continuing
through our series in the 70-410 exam.

9
00:00:21.060 --> 00:00:23.770
That's right, the MCSA and
Windows Server 2012.

10
00:00:23.770 --> 00:00:26.610
And joining us back in the studio is
none other than Ms. Cherokee Boose.

11
00:00:26.610 --> 00:00:27.590
Cherokee, how you doing today?

12
00:00:27.590 --> 00:00:28.160
>> I'm doing great.

13
00:00:28.160 --> 00:00:28.870
How are you?

14
00:00:28.870 --> 00:00:29.510
>> I'm doing great.

15
00:00:29.510 --> 00:00:30.340
Wonderful to be here.

16
00:00:30.340 --> 00:00:33.740
So we've been looking at things
like our virtualization services,

17
00:00:33.740 --> 00:00:35.370
more specifically Hyper-V.

18
00:00:35.370 --> 00:00:38.580
And you've taken us through a pretty good
gamut of just different things that we can

19
00:00:38.580 --> 00:00:39.890
do with our virtual machines.

20
00:00:39.890 --> 00:00:41.980
What are we looking at in this episode?

21
00:00:41.980 --> 00:00:46.046
>> So I think now we should really start
focusing on configuring our virtual

22
00:00:46.046 --> 00:00:46.850
machines.

23
00:00:46.850 --> 00:00:49.960
There are a lot of different
options that we have.

24
00:00:49.960 --> 00:00:53.320
And like we talked about before,
virtualization really has come a long way.

25
00:00:53.320 --> 00:00:57.090
So let's not leverage and take
advantage of all those great features.

26
00:00:57.090 --> 00:00:59.197
So the first thing I'd like to talk about,

27
00:00:59.197 --> 00:01:02.883
well really the only thing that we're
gonna be focusing on this show here,

28
00:01:02.883 --> 00:01:06.280
is going to be something called
guest integration services.

29
00:01:06.280 --> 00:01:10.910
And you may also be seeing it
noted as just integration services

30
00:01:10.910 --> 00:01:13.040
in different verbage.

31
00:01:13.040 --> 00:01:17.060
We even saw that in other technology and
terms here, Microsoft does that sometimes.

32
00:01:17.060 --> 00:01:21.310
But that's okay,
either way it's kind of a cool concept.

33
00:01:21.310 --> 00:01:27.170
It's going to be a software package that
will actually enhance the functionality

34
00:01:27.170 --> 00:01:32.660
of the communication and the drivers and

35
00:01:32.660 --> 00:01:38.430
everything within our guest operating
systems and the host operating system.

36
00:01:38.430 --> 00:01:42.110
So what it does is it just
helps fuse that integration,

37
00:01:42.110 --> 00:01:46.790
or enhance it between the guest and
the host operating systems.

38
00:01:46.790 --> 00:01:49.750
Wes, I know you've been
working with computers for

39
00:01:49.750 --> 00:01:52.700
a long time, and
I don't wanna show our age here.

40
00:01:52.700 --> 00:01:56.290
But back in the day,
when you were to go ahead and,

41
00:01:56.290 --> 00:02:00.785
let's say, blow out a computer and
perform a clean install, and

42
00:02:00.785 --> 00:02:05.460
you'd have to go and get all the drivers,
and it was a manual process.

43
00:02:05.460 --> 00:02:08.110
And usually you'd try to the get
like the ethernet driver first so

44
00:02:08.110 --> 00:02:10.160
that you could get that machine
connected to the internet so

45
00:02:10.160 --> 00:02:13.865
you could download the other drivers and
install them.

46
00:02:13.865 --> 00:02:17.570
And Windows has really made it easier for
us nowadays, and

47
00:02:17.570 --> 00:02:20.620
it'll provide a lot of those drivers for
us.

48
00:02:20.620 --> 00:02:25.300
But with virtualization, you've seen
when we've created those machines,

49
00:02:25.300 --> 00:02:31.090
Microsoft is able to note the operating
system that you're creating when you

50
00:02:31.090 --> 00:02:32.402
generate that virtual machine.

51
00:02:32.402 --> 00:02:38.920
And they're kinda providing a real
generic package of drivers for you.

52
00:02:38.920 --> 00:02:44.090
So sometimes you won't have the best
functionality in your virtual machine.

53
00:02:44.090 --> 00:02:48.260
I mean, Hyper-V does support a lot
of different virtual machines, or

54
00:02:48.260 --> 00:02:50.216
operating systems I should say.

55
00:02:50.216 --> 00:02:54.219
Even Linux operating systems.

56
00:02:54.219 --> 00:02:59.720
Let's say this, they don't claim all
operating systems, but it's possible.

57
00:02:59.720 --> 00:03:04.650
I mean, if your operating system that you
wanna use as a guest, here within Hyper-V,

58
00:03:04.650 --> 00:03:07.560
isn't on their list, then you can just
Google the list and they have that.

59
00:03:07.560 --> 00:03:10.660
Or being the list,
we are on a Microsoft show.

60
00:03:10.660 --> 00:03:13.660
But yeah,
that doesn't mean that you can't use it.

61
00:03:13.660 --> 00:03:16.900
It just means that they haven't tested it,
they don't support it in any way.

62
00:03:16.900 --> 00:03:18.760
So just throwing that out there.

63
00:03:18.760 --> 00:03:19.810
But it's pretty cool.

64
00:03:19.810 --> 00:03:25.180
If we take a look at it from the server
side, because if you think about it, guest

65
00:03:25.180 --> 00:03:31.160
integration services has to be both on
the host and the guest operating systems.

66
00:03:31.160 --> 00:03:38.090
So server side 2012 and later,
it's something that's already built in.

67
00:03:38.090 --> 00:03:43.360
And then client side Windows 8 and
later, it's already built in.

68
00:03:43.360 --> 00:03:48.390
So older machines, Windows 7 machines,
some machines may have it, but you just

69
00:03:48.390 --> 00:03:54.450
need to upgrade or update the integration
services package, which you can do.

70
00:03:54.450 --> 00:03:57.950
They provide a lot of really
good documentation for that, and

71
00:03:57.950 --> 00:04:00.710
then some operating systems
may not have it at all and

72
00:04:00.710 --> 00:04:04.400
you will need to go ahead and reach
out to the Internet, to the interwebs.

73
00:04:04.400 --> 00:04:06.600
But again,
if you take a look at my screen,

74
00:04:06.600 --> 00:04:10.500
they do a great job of providing
a ton of information for us here.

75
00:04:12.240 --> 00:04:15.440
Just showing you how to integrate
it with the server side and

76
00:04:15.440 --> 00:04:17.220
using it with Hyper-V here.

77
00:04:17.220 --> 00:04:22.020
Also on the guest, remember so the client
side here, a lot of good hyperlinks that

78
00:04:22.020 --> 00:04:27.590
you can use, and syntax as well
using it here with PowerShell.

79
00:04:27.590 --> 00:04:30.700
And I'll show you how to go ahead and
get that set up with PowerShell and

80
00:04:30.700 --> 00:04:31.805
in the GUI.

81
00:04:31.805 --> 00:04:36.190
Wwe can also take a look at
this when we jump in the demo.

82
00:04:36.190 --> 00:04:40.430
It is services that we're seeing here,

So this is going to be

00:19:46.900 --> 00:19:49.620

Because we've got the typical

Just remember the last

00:22:30.795 --> 00:22:33.340
It can make it a little bit easier

00:26:06.645 --> 00:26:09.204
>> Yeah, a lot of interesting information

And kind of enhance

take advantage of those features, so those

00:26:17.067 --> 00:26:20.030

Because this was just one of the many

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes begin explaining how to configure SmartPaging to help ensure enough memory is allocated to a VM in a time of need, such as a reboot. They also introduce resource metering and show how to use it.
episodes.title: Additional VM Configurations
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:02.858
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.858 --> 00:00:08.252
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.252 --> 00:00:11.664
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.664 --> 00:00:14.600
>> Hello and welcome to another
great episode here at ITProTV.

5
00:00:14.600 --> 00:00:18.650
I'm your host Wes Bryan and in today's
episode we're continuing through our

6
00:00:18.650 --> 00:00:22.890
series in the 7410, that's right,
the MCSA in Windows Server 2012.

7
00:00:22.890 --> 00:00:26.620
And joining us back in the studios is
none other than Ms. Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:26.620 --> 00:00:27.620
Cherokee, how are you doing today?

9
00:00:27.620 --> 00:00:29.570
>> I'm doing great, thank you for
having me today, Wes.

10
00:00:29.570 --> 00:00:33.490
>> All right, it's been great being here,
we've been talking about Hyper V,

11
00:00:33.490 --> 00:00:34.760
virtual machines, right,

12
00:00:34.760 --> 00:00:38.250
we've been talking about how to manage
them through the graphical user interface.

13
00:00:38.250 --> 00:00:41.500
We even have some episodes on how
to work with them in Powershell.

14
00:00:41.500 --> 00:00:43.790
So what are we going to be
looking at in this episode?

15
00:00:43.790 --> 00:00:46.430
Are we going to continue along
the path that leads to, well,

16
00:00:46.430 --> 00:00:47.935
virtual machine configuration?

17
00:00:47.935 --> 00:00:52.750
>> [LAUGH] We most definitely are,
Wes and yeah, hopefully that path

18
00:00:52.750 --> 00:00:56.440
will lead you to a certification or maybe
even a raise in your job, but who knows.

19
00:00:56.440 --> 00:00:59.351
For this show,
I think a good place for us to start

20
00:00:59.351 --> 00:01:04.122
will be with a feature enhancement of
Hyper V, something called Smart Paging.

21
00:01:04.122 --> 00:01:08.659
And [LAUGH] it's kind of funny,
because I've done something,

22
00:01:08.659 --> 00:01:12.182
the opposite of smart,
I guess, [LAUGH] before.

23
00:01:12.182 --> 00:01:15.559
And hopefully,
you guys don't ever make that mistake.

24
00:01:15.559 --> 00:01:18.151
If you're managing machines remotely and

25
00:01:18.151 --> 00:01:22.615
you ever powered them down, or
they shut down, you always wanna make sure

26
00:01:22.615 --> 00:01:27.910
that someone at that remote location has
access to power that machine back on.

27
00:01:27.910 --> 00:01:31.150
Well, with virtualization we've
already talked about different

28
00:01:31.150 --> 00:01:33.480
types of memory contention that may occur.

29
00:01:33.480 --> 00:01:39.000
So, what if, and we also talked about
utilizing this memory, sometimes

30
00:01:39.000 --> 00:01:43.620
we need that extra burst of memory
to go ahead and reboot that machine.

31
00:01:43.620 --> 00:01:48.040
So during the situation of a reboot,
what if for

32
00:01:48.040 --> 00:01:52.950
some reason there's not enough memory
available to that virtual machine that

33
00:01:52.950 --> 00:01:57.390
got powered down or performed a reboot and
it's not powering back on, what do you do?

34
00:01:57.390 --> 00:02:00.260
And with physical machines,
yeah, you'd have to drive or

35
00:02:00.260 --> 00:02:03.200
get someone to go there and
you'd say, hey, guess what?

36
00:02:04.350 --> 00:02:07.200
I shut this machine down,
I need you to go turn it on.

37
00:02:07.200 --> 00:02:10.400
With virtual machines,
a little different here and

38
00:02:10.400 --> 00:02:11.810
especially if you're working remotely.

39
00:02:11.810 --> 00:02:16.580
Smart Paging is a smart way
that we can go ahead and

40
00:02:16.580 --> 00:02:19.260
hopefully prevent that
issue from happening.

41
00:02:19.260 --> 00:02:24.140
Now, Smart Paging is going to be
an extension of our dynamic memory.

42
00:02:24.140 --> 00:02:27.030
We've already taken a look at
how to configure dynamic memory,

43
00:02:27.030 --> 00:02:32.200
which will give us the option to
set the triage, the wait there,

44
00:02:32.200 --> 00:02:37.560
as well as, modify our buffer and
set our minimum and maximum amount of RAM.

45
00:02:37.560 --> 00:02:39.210
And it could even be something, Wes,

46
00:02:39.210 --> 00:02:43.770
as simple as setting that minimum

episodes.description: In this show, Wes and Cherokee continue to discuss features of Hyper-V. First, they explain a way to leverage local peripherals through a technology called enhanced session mode. Next, they explore RemoteFX another feature of Hyper-V that leverages the use of a physical GPU.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Wes introduce Hyper-v storage options. First, they explain the difference between .VDH and .VHDX file types. They also compare and contrast fixed, dynamically expanding and differencing drives. Cherokee demonstrates how to crceate and use these drives with the GUI.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes continue to discuss storage within Hyper-V however, they shift focus from GUI management to working within PowerShell. Cherokee demonstrates how to create, edit, attach, convert and delete virtual drives.
episodes.title: Working with VHDs in Powershell

in other episodes,

233
00:13:30.658 --> 00:13:32.380
when we were looking at memory, right?

234
00:13:32.380 --> 00:13:36.284
We have dynamic memory, we can configure
things like memory weight, you showed us

235
00:13:36.284 --> 00:13:40.329
where we can give a little more priority
to, maybe a more mission-critical server.

236
00:13:40.329 --> 00:13:44.140
Now, is that something that
we can tailor to storage?

237
00:13:44.140 --> 00:13:47.116
Can we bring some of those concepts
over to storage and say hey, well,

238
00:13:47.116 --> 00:13:50.556
I've got this one machine, I know it's
gonna need a certain amount of storage.

239
00:13:50.556 --> 00:13:54.312
And I wanna kinda make sure that
it doesn't get over subscribed.

240
00:13:54.312 --> 00:13:59.665
>> Yes, and so luckily we do have that
option, Wes, because that is true.

241
00:13:59.665 --> 00:14:03.780
Different machines do have different
varying levels of importance there.

242
00:14:03.780 --> 00:14:07.344
So let's just go ahead and go to the
settings of that virtual machine we had

243
00:14:07.344 --> 00:14:09.999
created before, and
we had created different disks.

244
00:14:09.999 --> 00:14:14.770
Let's see if we still have any
just kind of sitting there.

245
00:14:14.770 --> 00:14:19.322
Let's take a look at this hard drive
attached to that virtual machine.

246
00:14:19.322 --> 00:14:22.621
So on the left hand side,
you can see a plus arrow.

247
00:14:22.621 --> 00:14:24.420
Now, if you click on that,

248
00:14:24.420 --> 00:14:28.508
it'll expand out to a subsection
called advanced features.

249
00:14:28.508 --> 00:14:32.997
And this is where we could actually
enable our quality of service for

250
00:14:32.997 --> 00:14:34.975
the storage of those drives.

251
00:14:34.975 --> 00:14:37.925
So I could go ahead and
check this tick box.

252
00:14:37.925 --> 00:14:41.838
And this is where you would need
to know specific information for

253
00:14:41.838 --> 00:14:45.981
that machine referencing those IOPS,
for those reads and writes.

254
00:14:45.981 --> 00:14:48.925
Especially if you are running
certain applications.

255
00:14:48.925 --> 00:14:53.431
But once you are able to monitor and use
some kind of metric to get those numbers,

256
00:14:53.431 --> 00:14:57.331
you could go ahead and set your upper and
lower thresholds there, for

257
00:14:57.331 --> 00:14:59.162
your minimum and maximum IOPS.

258
00:14:59.162 --> 00:15:03.684
And that is definitely how you would
just set that, not too difficult.

259
00:15:03.684 --> 00:15:07.232
Again, you would need some kind of
monitoring utility to create your

260
00:15:07.232 --> 00:15:10.728
baseline, so you could input that
according to your environment.

261
00:15:10.728 --> 00:15:12.877
But that's really it.

262
00:15:12.877 --> 00:15:16.174
And so it's just yelling at me here,
because I didn't set anything there,

263
00:15:16.174 --> 00:15:18.143
but that's okay,
I just wanted to show you.

264
00:15:18.143 --> 00:15:21.603
>> Lot of great information, we've got
additional options that we can configure,

265
00:15:21.603 --> 00:15:24.414
and things that we just need to
take into consideration when we're

266
00:15:24.414 --> 00:15:25.430
configuring storage.

267
00:15:25.430 --> 00:15:29.121
Now, again Cherokee, I know little
bit shorter of an episode here.

268
00:15:29.121 --> 00:15:32.915
But we just had some loose ends
that you wanted to tie off, right?

269
00:15:32.915 --> 00:15:35.530
Make sure that your shoelaces are tied and
that you're covered for that exam.

270
00:15:35.530 --> 00:15:36.557
But before we do sign off,

271
00:15:36.557 --> 00:15:39.746
do you have any additional words that
maybe you'd like to impart to our viewers?

272
00:15:39.746 --> 00:15:43.263
>> Sure, so that was actually, yeah,
those were a few stragglers there,

273
00:15:43.263 --> 00:15:47.144
that I wanted to wrap up when we were
talking about our virtualization storage.

274
00:15:47.144 --> 00:15:51.051
But don't go anywhere, because we still
need to take a look at networking from

275
00:15:51.051 --> 00:15:52.720
a virtualization perspective.

276
00:15:52.720 --> 00:15:53.790
So you don't wanna miss that.

277
00:15:53.790 --> 00:15:56.099
>> All right, well that's a great
stopping point there, Cherokee.

278
00:15:56.099 --> 00:15:57.152
I know it's been great here.

279
00:15:57.152 --> 00:15:59.484
I'm gonna grab me some coffee and
Stop by the HR department,

280
00:15:59.484 --> 00:16:01.418
we're gonna send Cherokee
to anger management.

281
00:16:01.418 --> 00:16:02.932
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because she definitely picked on

282
00:16:02.932 --> 00:16:03.472
me alive here.

283
00:16:03.472 --> 00:16:07.330
But until we see you again, signing
out for ITProTV, I've been your host,

284
00:16:07.330 --> 00:16:07.943
Wes Bryan.

285
00:16:07.943 --> 00:16:08.742
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

286
00:16:08.742 --> 00:16:11.047
>> And we'll see you next time.

287
00:16:11.047 --> 00:16:17.223
[MUSIC]

288
00:16:17.223 --> 00:16:20.688
Thank you for watching, ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Cherokee explain how networking plays out in a virtual environment. Cherokee demonstrates how to create a virtual switch and differentiate between the different configuration options. Tune in for all this and more!
episodes.title: Hyper-V Networking
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:01.989
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:01.989 --> 00:00:06.768
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.768 --> 00:00:08.234
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.234 --> 00:00:11.993
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.993 --> 00:00:14.467
>> Hello to all our viewers out
there thanks for tuning in.

6
00:00:14.467 --> 00:00:17.880
We got a great show in store for
you today, I'm your show host Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:17.880 --> 00:00:22.191
And in today's episode, we're continuing
through our series in the 74-10 exam.

8
00:00:22.191 --> 00:00:25.540
That's right and we're gonna be
looking at Hyper V networking today.

9
00:00:25.540 --> 00:00:28.550
And joining us back in the studios,
none other than Ms. Cherokee Boose.

10
00:00:28.550 --> 00:00:29.570
Cherokee, how are you doing today?

11
00:00:29.570 --> 00:00:31.720
>> I'm doing great thank you for
asking Wes, how are you?

12
00:00:31.720 --> 00:00:34.950
>> I'm doing great, so we've been
talking about Hyper V pretty much

13
00:00:34.950 --> 00:00:38.760
a virtualization platform and one of
the things that we haven't talked about.

14
00:00:38.760 --> 00:00:42.157
We've talked about memory and CPU
utilizations, we haven't talked about how

15
00:00:42.157 --> 00:00:44.399
they communicated with
the rest of the world right?

16
00:00:44.399 --> 00:00:47.117
The rest of the network and I think that's
what we're gonna be looking at today.

17
00:00:47.117 --> 00:00:48.356
So where do we start?

18
00:00:48.356 --> 00:00:51.317
>> So we need to think about,
just like we would in a physical

19
00:00:51.317 --> 00:00:54.600
networking environment,
what kind of components are there?

20
00:00:54.600 --> 00:00:56.821
How does this communication transpire?

21
00:00:56.821 --> 00:00:58.870
What layer are we operating?

22
00:00:58.870 --> 00:01:00.450
Just kind of things like that.

23
00:01:00.450 --> 00:01:04.100
And it maybe a little bit strange because
yeah, in a virtualized environment.

24
00:01:04.100 --> 00:01:06.550
We don't have those tangible components.

25
00:01:06.550 --> 00:01:07.980
So how is all of this happening?

26
00:01:09.110 --> 00:01:12.040
It's kind of interesting but
if we take a look at my screen,

27
00:01:12.040 --> 00:01:17.030
I just wanna start out with the idea of
layer two, switching technology here.

28
00:01:17.030 --> 00:01:21.750
So, in networking we have switches
that provide that communication

29
00:01:21.750 --> 00:01:23.880
looking at that layer two information.

30
00:01:23.880 --> 00:01:29.600
And we can implement things VLANs and
we utilize MAC addresses,

31
00:01:29.600 --> 00:01:33.570
and what are some terms you might
have heard for MAC addresses?

32
00:01:33.570 --> 00:01:35.641
Well, just think about
that physical address and

33
00:01:35.641 --> 00:01:38.808
we're in a virtual we don't have
physical and it's just getting strange.

34
00:01:38.808 --> 00:01:40.794
So I think breaking it down and

35
00:01:40.794 --> 00:01:45.095
taking it piece by piece is what
we'll be looking at here today.

36
00:01:45.095 --> 00:01:47.904
And I think switches
are a great place to start.

37
00:01:47.904 --> 00:01:50.733
It is a little bit different Wes,
it's not gonna

38
00:01:50.733 --> 00:01:54.743
be the same as our traditional
switch in a virtualized environment.

39
00:01:54.743 --> 00:01:58.840
We have a couple of different ways
that we can configure them and

40
00:01:58.840 --> 00:02:04.273
Microsoft expects us to be able to know
the difference between their terminology.

41
00:02:04.273 --> 00:02:07.330
And the ways that these switches
can be configured here.

42
00:02:07.330 --> 00:02:08.068
>> All right.
Now,

43
00:02:08.068 --> 00:02:10.903
I'm not too familiar with some
of the terminology here, but

44
00:02:10.903 --> 00:02:14.637
one thing that I know that is kinda common
in virtualization platforms is that.

45
00:02:14.637 --> 00:02:18.111
There are different types of
communications that your virtual

46
00:02:18.111 --> 00:02:19.099
machines can do.

47
00:02:19.099 --> 00:02:23.109
And what I mean more specifically
by that is that you have ways and

48
00:02:23.109 --> 00:02:27.641
other virtualization techniques where
your hosts can communicate with

49
00:02:27.641 --> 00:02:29.510
the guest operating system.

50
00:02:29.510 --> 00:02:33.536
The guest operating system sometimes they
can communicate just amongst themselves or

51
00:02:33.536 --> 00:02:35.366
maybe with the host operating system.

52
00:02:35.366 --> 00:02:39.026
Then we have certain types of
communications where our virtual machine

53
00:02:39.026 --> 00:02:41.955
they act like any other physical
machine on our network.

54
00:02:41.955 --> 00:02:44.746
Is that something that we're gonna
see inside Hyper V different kind of

55
00:02:44.746 --> 00:02:46.170
communications like that.

56
00:02:46.170 --> 00:02:48.190
>> You know Wes,
you hit the nail right on the head there.

57
00:02:48.190 --> 00:02:51.400
That's exactly what we'll
see here in Hyper V and

58
00:02:51.400 --> 00:02:54.550
Microsoft's virtualization solution.

59
00:02:54.550 --> 00:02:58.220
Now, if you've already been working
with some other virtualization solution,

60
00:02:58.220 --> 00:03:01.360
then you may have the concept,
the fundamentals there but

61
00:03:01.360 --> 00:03:03.280
you just might call it
something slightly different.

62
00:03:03.280 --> 00:03:07.156
So knowing the terminology is
gonna be key here, especially for

63
00:03:07.156 --> 00:03:08.820
you exam takers out there.

64
00:03:08.820 --> 00:03:11.050
So let's take a look at my screen and

65
00:03:11.050 --> 00:03:15.140
we'll walk through the process of how
we can actually create a virtual switch

66
00:03:15.140 --> 00:03:19.350
right here, I have already
pulled up my Hyper V Manager.

67
00:03:19.350 --> 00:03:24.074
So, on the right hand side, a couple of
different ways you can get here actually,

68
00:03:24.074 --> 00:03:27.921
in the right hand pane over here it says,
Virtual Switch Manager.

69
00:03:27.921 --> 00:03:32.092
Alternatively, on
the left hand side if you

70
00:03:32.092 --> 00:03:36.161
are managing multiple hyper V hosts here.

71
00:03:36.161 --> 00:03:39.945
You could also just right click
on your selected host and

72
00:03:39.945 --> 00:03:42.530
then select Virtual Switch Manager.

73
00:03:42.530 --> 00:03:44.410
So either way it takes
you to the same place.

74
00:03:44.410 --> 00:03:47.260
This is the Virtual Switch Manager

75
00:03:47.260 --> 00:03:50.340
interface that you see right
here that we'll be working with.

76
00:03:50.340 --> 00:03:54.173
I'm trying to get a good spot for
it, so you can see it well.

77
00:03:54.173 --> 00:03:58.484
Now, you'll notice I have a couple that
are already here that had been created and

78
00:03:58.484 --> 00:04:01.859
so I'm using practice labs and
you guys have access to this too,

79
00:04:01.859 --> 00:04:04.640
and can follow along if you'd like.

80
00:04:04.640 --> 00:04:09.482
I have my actual physical network
interface card represented here

81
00:04:09.482 --> 00:04:10.438
that Intel.

82
00:04:10.438 --> 00:04:12.950
And then they've had a couple
that are already created.

83
00:04:12.950 --> 00:04:18.140
We've got PLAB, PLAB private and
we'll be creating our own here as well.

84
00:04:18.140 --> 00:04:22.377
You can click on each one of these to
look more extensively at the properties

85
00:04:22.377 --> 00:04:24.811
associated with that individual switch.

86
00:04:24.811 --> 00:04:28.978
But this first option up here at
the top is where we're going to

87
00:04:28.978 --> 00:04:31.270
be creating a new switch.

88
00:04:31.270 --> 00:04:36.130
Now, the first thing you'll notice once
I highlight this new virtual switch

89
00:04:36.130 --> 00:04:40.080
option over here on my left,
I've got a couple different.

90
00:04:40.080 --> 00:04:43.690
It says, what type of virtual
switch do you want to create?

91
00:04:43.690 --> 00:04:45.940
Now this is exactly what
Wes was talking about.

92
00:04:45.940 --> 00:04:50.260
We have the option to create external,
internal and private.

93
00:04:50.260 --> 00:04:53.130
Now if you've never heard
those terms before,

94
00:04:53.130 --> 00:04:57.720
Microsoft does an actually a pretty
good job right down here of specifying

95
00:04:57.720 --> 00:04:59.270
what each one of those terms means.

96
00:04:59.270 --> 00:05:02.570
So it says hey, If you click on external,

97
00:05:02.570 --> 00:05:07.800
it creates a virtual switch that binds
to the physical network adapter so

98
00:05:07.800 --> 00:05:11.610
that virtual machines can
access a physical network.

99
00:05:11.610 --> 00:05:14.190
And so what that means is binding, or

100
00:05:14.190 --> 00:05:19.200
marrying our virtual switch to that
physical network interface card.

101
00:05:19.200 --> 00:05:24.254
I'm able to leverage and utilize that
hardware and traverse it, meaning I'm

102
00:05:24.254 --> 00:05:29.480
able to leave my little hypervised
bubble here, my virtual environment.

103
00:05:29.480 --> 00:05:34.470
I can actually get onto the wire and
go through that network interface card and

104
00:05:34.470 --> 00:05:38.110
out to my land,
out to the Internet if I choose to do so.

105
00:05:38.110 --> 00:05:42.010
So I'm actually leveraging
that hardware there.

106
00:05:42.010 --> 00:05:44.830
And I don't know,
here in the United States,

107
00:05:44.830 --> 00:05:46.970
polygamy I still don't think that's legal.

108
00:05:46.970 --> 00:05:51.040
So when you marry to that physical
network interface card per switch.

109
00:05:51.040 --> 00:05:56.735
You're not allowed to marry that physical
network interface card to another switch.

110
00:05:56.735 --> 00:05:59.515
So for
every external switch that you create,

111
00:05:59.515 --> 00:06:04.777
you have to have to have a corresponding
physical network interface card there.

112
00:06:04.777 --> 00:06:08.397
>> Now Cherokee, I know this episode
really isn't about security but

113
00:06:08.397 --> 00:06:10.837
that you say leaving
that virtualized bubble.

114
00:06:10.837 --> 00:06:14.939
Does that mean that if the communications
can happen like any other physical machine

115
00:06:14.939 --> 00:06:17.376
does that mean that we do
have a security concern?

116
00:06:17.376 --> 00:06:20.983
And we gotta watch what we're doing
because with those machines being

117
00:06:20.983 --> 00:06:22.947
able to talk to the physical network.

118
00:06:22.947 --> 00:06:24.830
Anything that happens to those machines,

119
00:06:24.830 --> 00:06:27.870
can also reflect the physical
machines on our network as well.

120
00:06:27.870 --> 00:06:30.264
>> You know, Wes when we talk,
look at it from that perspective,

121
00:06:30.264 --> 00:06:31.447
from a security perspective.

122
00:06:31.447 --> 00:06:36.096
If you are using virtualization in
a production environment you always wanna

123
00:06:36.096 --> 00:06:41.330
take that into consideration, yeah if this
machine is extending my local realm here.

124
00:06:41.330 --> 00:06:45.340
I do need to treat it just as I would
any other physical machine on my network

125
00:06:45.340 --> 00:06:46.290
and you know what?

126
00:06:46.290 --> 00:06:47.000
Maybe you're right.

127
00:06:47.000 --> 00:06:51.000
Maybe there's a reason why I don't want
that machine to have any kind of external

128
00:06:51.000 --> 00:06:52.170
communication.

129
00:06:52.170 --> 00:06:55.420
And I'd like to chose one of these other
options, I may opt for an internal.

130
00:06:55.420 --> 00:06:58.410
So, let's take at look at
what that entails here.

131
00:06:58.410 --> 00:07:03.146
Internals are great for like your just
mentioning there maybe I want to set up

132
00:07:03.146 --> 00:07:07.740
a test environment before actually
deploy and roll it out to production.

133
00:07:07.740 --> 00:07:10.123
So let's read the description and

134
00:07:10.123 --> 00:07:15.547
I'll give a little bit of a use case here
it says, creates a virtual switch that

135
00:07:15.547 --> 00:07:20.825
can be used only by the virtual machines
that run on this physical computer.

136
00:07:20.825 --> 00:07:24.730
And between the virtual machines and
the physical computer.

137
00:07:24.730 --> 00:07:28.830
An internal switch does not provide
connectivity to a physical switch

138
00:07:28.830 --> 00:07:30.450
network connection.

139
00:07:30.450 --> 00:07:31.850
So what does that mean?

140
00:07:31.850 --> 00:07:36.910
So, I'm not able to communicate with
virtual machines on another physical box,

141
00:07:36.910 --> 00:07:40.540
I'm only able to communicate
with virtual machines residing

142
00:07:40.540 --> 00:07:43.900
on one physical entity that host there.

143
00:07:43.900 --> 00:07:46.740
I can also communicate with
the host operating system.

144
00:07:46.740 --> 00:07:50.718
So maybe I'm running from
my host operating system.

145
00:07:50.718 --> 00:07:52.415
Managing all these virtual machines.

146
00:07:52.415 --> 00:07:55.595
Testing a new piece of software,
seeing how that interacts and

147
00:07:55.595 --> 00:07:58.905
how they communicate with each other and
what those results are.

148
00:07:58.905 --> 00:08:01.099
And I have a good test pilot environment.

149
00:08:01.099 --> 00:08:03.259
Before I roll it out into production.

150
00:08:03.259 --> 00:08:06.830
So, internal would be good for that.

151
00:08:06.830 --> 00:08:12.300
It's communication between the virtual
machines on that physical entity and

152
00:08:12.300 --> 00:08:14.390
the host operating system
communication there.

153
00:08:15.570 --> 00:08:17.060
And then, lastly we have private and

154
00:08:17.060 --> 00:08:20.210
again private is good for
testing purposes as well.

155
00:08:20.210 --> 00:08:22.930
Maybe you have specific
scenarios where you

156
00:08:22.930 --> 00:08:26.600
do not want those virtual machines to
be able to communicate with that host.

157
00:08:26.600 --> 00:08:30.470
So, if we look at the description here it
just says it creates a virtual switch that

158
00:08:30.470 --> 00:08:36.140
can be used only by the virtual machines
that run on this physical computer.

159
00:08:36.140 --> 00:08:38.420
So, we do see a bit more isolation and

160
00:08:38.420 --> 00:08:41.190
specifically Microsoft
will call out isolation.

161
00:08:41.190 --> 00:08:43.770
We'll look in the next episode,
I think, or

162
00:08:43.770 --> 00:08:46.830
a little bit later other ways
we can implement isolation.

163
00:08:46.830 --> 00:08:49.480
But this is definitely one
way we could do that here.

164
00:08:49.480 --> 00:08:52.920
>> So, kind of even just to go
in the list backwards, right?

165
00:08:52.920 --> 00:08:54.570
The last one you talked
about was the private.

166
00:08:54.570 --> 00:08:56.970
So, that would be VM to
VM communication only.

167
00:08:56.970 --> 00:08:59.360
Completely isolated in Sandbox.

168
00:08:59.360 --> 00:09:04.860
We got the internal one,
which is VM to host, we're kinda steering

169
00:09:04.860 --> 00:09:08.780
outside of that bubble, cuz now, we could
potentially affect the host as well.

170
00:09:08.780 --> 00:09:13.470
And last, but not least like you said,
we've got not only VM to VM,

171
00:09:13.470 --> 00:09:18.700
VM to host and VM to the physical Network,

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes continue to discuss networking within Hyper-V. They look at ways to increase performance by enabling technologies such as Single Root Input-Output Virtualization, Virtual Machine Device Queues, and IPsec task offloading.

89
00:04:48.090 --> 00:04:51.720
So it sounds like a lot to get

90
00:04:51.720 --> 00:04:55.900

side comparison with just a straight

00:07:57.493 --> 00:08:01.149

00:08:01.149 --> 00:08:04.742

00:08:04.742 --> 00:08:08.072

00:08:08.072 --> 00:08:13.540

00:08:13.540 --> 00:08:20.560

00:08:20.560 --> 00:08:23.680

00:08:23.680 --> 00:08:28.100

00:08:28.100 --> 00:08:33.190

those packets to transmissions.

154
00:08:33.190 --> 00:08:39.350
So what we see here is dedicated channels
for each one of those virtual machines.

155
00:08:39.350 --> 00:08:43.463

at the actual physical NIC,

00:08:43.463 --> 00:08:48.451

00:08:48.451 --> 00:08:52.234

00:08:52.234 --> 00:08:56.789

00:08:56.789 --> 00:08:58.350

00:09:04.160 --> 00:09:09.510

00:09:09.510 --> 00:09:11.150
So we do see performance.

We're bypassing that software.
