00:18:31.196 --> 00:18:34.102
So we're gonna be denying incoming and

322
00:18:34.102 --> 00:18:39.570
outgoing traffic from that particular
IP address to our PLABWIN 801.

323
00:18:39.570 --> 00:18:41.390
Nothing major happened here.

324
00:18:41.390 --> 00:18:42.710
I'm not really sure if it worked.

325
00:18:42.710 --> 00:18:46.520
But let's try to go ahead and
block from one more IP address.

326
00:18:46.520 --> 00:18:51.416
I'm just gonna filter back and
change that last octet there.

327
00:18:51.416 --> 00:18:53.170
We'll change that from a 1 to a 3.

328
00:18:53.170 --> 00:18:54.310
We'll hit Enter.

329
00:18:55.640 --> 00:18:57.450
And again not a lot of notifications.

330
00:18:57.450 --> 00:19:01.976
So one way we can check this is to use

331
00:19:01.976 --> 00:19:06.982
the Get-VMNetwork not adapter Acl.

332
00:19:06.982 --> 00:19:09.920
And then we'll specify again that VMName.

333
00:19:10.940 --> 00:19:16.396
All right, I'll just tab one through

334
00:19:16.396 --> 00:19:20.665
that for our PLABWIN802.

335
00:19:20.665 --> 00:19:22.483
Enter.

336
00:19:22.483 --> 00:19:26.410
So what we see here is going to
be the access control list for

337
00:19:26.410 --> 00:19:31.000
that particular virtual machine adapter,
I should specify here.

338
00:19:31.000 --> 00:19:34.670
So we see that inbound and
outbound communication for

339
00:19:34.670 --> 00:19:39.200
our specific IP addresses here and
you can see in the far right hand column.

340
00:19:39.200 --> 00:19:42.730
We do have that deny action, so
that's an additional way to isolate.

341
00:19:42.730 --> 00:19:47.060
And that is important because you know
specifically Microsoft does call out

342
00:19:47.060 --> 00:19:49.320
isolation techniques for that exam.

343
00:19:50.340 --> 00:19:53.630
Looking at the clock I see we have
about five minutes or so left, so

344
00:19:53.630 --> 00:19:56.190
I do wanna take a look at one more thing.

345
00:19:56.190 --> 00:19:58.630
Let me just minimize PowerShell here.

346
00:19:58.630 --> 00:20:01.190
You know we've talked about
a lot of different concepts.

347
00:20:01.190 --> 00:20:06.603
We've looked at our switches, we've seen
how to create virtual adapters here,

348
00:20:06.603 --> 00:20:11.440
but let's see, I think I have
all gen one machines right here.

349
00:20:11.440 --> 00:20:13.010
So let's do something real quick.

350
00:20:13.010 --> 00:20:14.680
Let's just create a gen
two machine [COUGH].

351
00:20:16.470 --> 00:20:22.330
Let's see, so actions here what am I doing
new, I'm just going to go over here.

352
00:20:22.330 --> 00:20:25.190
Virtual machine and
let's go through that wizard.

353
00:20:25.190 --> 00:20:25.990
I'll be real quick.

354
00:20:25.990 --> 00:20:27.770
We've already seen this.

355
00:20:27.770 --> 00:20:34.720
I'm just going to name this Demo2 and
change this to a gen two machine.

356
00:20:35.745 --> 00:20:37.400
And go through all the defaults.

357
00:20:37.400 --> 00:20:38.370
We don't need a ton of memory.

358
00:20:38.370 --> 00:20:39.900
We're not gonna spin it up.

359
00:20:39.900 --> 00:20:45.550
We'll just throw it right on to our
private network and finish that.

360
00:20:46.870 --> 00:20:49.760
All I really wanna show you is
the difference between the settings here.

361
00:20:49.760 --> 00:20:54.190
So for our demo too if I right click and
go to Settings.

362
00:20:54.190 --> 00:20:59.014
Notice on my Ad Hardware option,
that default option that comes up.

363
00:20:59.014 --> 00:21:00.780
Let me move this over so
we can see it a little better.

364
00:21:02.250 --> 00:21:07.536
I have Scuzzy Controller, Network Adapter,
and a Fiber Channel Adapter.

365
00:21:07.536 --> 00:21:12.590
All right,
now I don't have a legacy adapter.

366
00:21:12.590 --> 00:21:17.700
All right this is just a limitation
of our gent two machines,

367
00:21:17.700 --> 00:21:20.480
I'm not able to create a legacy adapter,
all right?

368
00:21:20.480 --> 00:21:24.410
If I wanted to have a legacy adapter
usually the biggest reason I

369
00:21:24.410 --> 00:21:28.230
would opt to have one is if I
wanted to utilize PXE boot.

370
00:21:29.800 --> 00:21:33.534
Gen two machines can PXE boot with
just a regular network adapter, but

371
00:21:33.534 --> 00:21:36.360
if I had a gen one machine and
let's see here.

372
00:21:36.360 --> 00:21:39.177
Any one of these other machines
are gonna be gen one's.

373
00:21:39.177 --> 00:21:41.040
And we'll just go to
they're Settings here.

374
00:21:42.580 --> 00:21:46.790
And notice here, I have the ability
to create a Network Adapter,

375
00:21:46.790 --> 00:21:50.280
as well as a Legacy Network Adapter.

376
00:21:50.280 --> 00:21:55.000
So, if I'm running a generation one
machine and I wanna utilize PXE boot,

377
00:21:55.000 --> 00:21:59.240
this is the option that I would select
here, is the Legacy Network Adapter.

378
00:21:59.240 --> 00:22:03.141
So that's kind of an important
again from the exam respective,

379
00:22:03.141 --> 00:22:07.261
just looking at the differences
there between a regular adapter and

380
00:22:07.261 --> 00:22:10.749
a legacy adapter,
is to be able to utilize that PXE boot.

381
00:22:10.749 --> 00:22:15.283
So if you wanted to do that boot strapped
install operating systems or if you're

382
00:22:15.283 --> 00:22:19.772
using thin clients, then that's something
in a gen one machine just to note.

383
00:22:19.772 --> 00:22:22.880
>> All right, that's a lot of great
information there Cherokee and

384
00:22:22.880 --> 00:22:25.748
we do appreciate as always you
stopping by and letting us know,

385
00:22:25.748 --> 00:22:29.870
it does look like you mentioned that
we're out of time for this episode.

386
00:22:29.870 --> 00:22:31.190
So that's a great stopping point.

387
00:22:31.190 --> 00:22:32.800
We appreciate you being here.

388
00:22:32.800 --> 00:22:34.330
We appreciate you the viewer watching.

389
00:22:34.330 --> 00:22:38.250
Remember that you can see this episode,
thousands of hours of additional great

390
00:22:38.250 --> 00:22:41.620
content by jumping over to our
library till we see you again.

391
00:22:41.620 --> 00:22:44.400
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

392
00:22:44.400 --> 00:22:45.340
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

393
00:22:45.340 --> 00:22:50.230
>> We'll see you next time.

394

395
00:22:53.212 --> 00:22:56.216
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

WEBVTT

1

3

>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.153 --> 00:00:08.559
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.559 --> 00:00:11.224
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:11.224 --> 00:00:14.360
>> Hello to all our viewers out there,
thanks for tuning in,

7
00:00:14.360 --> 00:00:16.200
we got a great show in store for
you today.

8
00:00:16.200 --> 00:00:17.853
I'm your show host Wes Bryan, and

9
00:00:17.853 --> 00:00:21.680
in today's episode we are continuing
through our series in the 7410 exam.

10
00:00:21.680 --> 00:00:24.118
That's right the MSCA and
Windows Server 2012 and

11
00:00:24.118 --> 00:00:27.520
joining us back in the studios today
is none other than Ms. Cherokee Boose.

12
00:00:27.520 --> 00:00:28.510
Cherokee how are you doing today?

13
00:00:28.510 --> 00:00:30.570
>> I'm doing excellent thank you for
asking Wes, how are you?

14
00:00:30.570 --> 00:00:33.886
>> I'm doing great over the past couple of
episodes we've been talking about Hyper V

15
00:00:33.886 --> 00:00:36.880
networking and some of the the features
and components that you'll see.

16
00:00:36.880 --> 00:00:41.500
Remember this is a part three so if you've
missed one and two, you might have to

17
00:00:41.500 --> 00:00:45.281
jump back and watch those and
then join us back in the third part.

18
00:00:45.281 --> 00:00:48.070
But we didn't cover everything
in the first two parts,

19
00:00:48.070 --> 00:00:50.100
so yes we're back here with part three.

20
00:00:50.100 --> 00:00:51.155
Where are we gonna start Cherokee?

21
00:00:51.155 --> 00:00:54.240
>> [LAUGH] Actually that's a great place
to start Wes because if we think about

22
00:00:54.240 --> 00:00:56.030
where we left off in that prior episode,

23
00:00:56.030 --> 00:01:01.660
we were talking about virtual machine
adapters and we had created a few.

24
00:01:01.660 --> 00:01:06.026
We were also talking about ways that we
can optimize that network traffic and

25
00:01:06.026 --> 00:01:10.461
different configurations settings that
we could leverage such as SR-IOV to

26
00:01:10.461 --> 00:01:13.479
increase and
perform that hard work acceleration.

27
00:01:13.479 --> 00:01:15.286
So let's take a look at my screen and

28
00:01:15.286 --> 00:01:18.478
I'd like to show you a few other
things that we can do to just make

29
00:01:18.478 --> 00:01:21.933
our networks a little bit better
in this virtualized environment.

30
00:01:21.933 --> 00:01:25.111
All right, so first,
if you recall, just as a recap,

31
00:01:25.111 --> 00:01:29.200
we did point out the differences
between Gen one and Gen two machines.

32
00:01:29.200 --> 00:01:31.070
It's very important to know that.

33
00:01:31.070 --> 00:01:35.660
Remember with our Gen one machines we
would see, have the ability to create

34
00:01:35.660 --> 00:01:39.075
two different type of network adapters,
just a regular network adapter and

35
00:01:39.075 --> 00:01:45.200
then also a legacy adapter for enabling
Pxe boot on those Gen one machines.

36
00:01:45.200 --> 00:01:46.470
And then when we solve Gen2.

37
00:01:46.470 --> 00:01:50.755
We only solve that network
adapter option because Gen2

38
00:01:50.755 --> 00:01:55.494
machines had developed and
evolved to be able to go ahead in Pxe

39
00:01:55.494 --> 00:02:00.161
boot without relying on that
older legacy network adapter.

40
00:02:00.161 --> 00:02:04.431
So I just want to remind you of that In
my lab environment here I have Gen one

41
00:02:04.431 --> 00:02:05.621
machines running.

42
00:02:05.621 --> 00:02:09.344
So if I just right click and
then select settings,

43
00:02:09.344 --> 00:02:14.220
you can see that I have the ability
to go ahead and add either that,

44
00:02:14.220 --> 00:02:17.607
network adapter which
is the newer version.

45
00:02:17.607 --> 00:02:21.929
Which we sometimes hear the term
synthetic adapter associated

46
00:02:21.929 --> 00:02:26.740
with this because they're going to
be these newer network adapters,

47
00:02:26.740 --> 00:02:32.870
synthetic adapters perform better because
they're not emulating physical hardware.

48
00:02:32.870 --> 00:02:34.420
And what does that mean?

49
00:02:34.420 --> 00:02:38.985
So when you hear that term emulating,
they're an emulated adapter.

50
00:02:38.985 --> 00:02:43.720
You'll be referencing a Legacy network
adapter and the operating system has

51
00:02:43.720 --> 00:02:47.490
a harder time recreating that
physical adapter than utilizing

52
00:02:47.490 --> 00:02:51.800
a synthetic version, the newer version,
the network adapter, that's just built in.

53
00:02:51.800 --> 00:02:54.500
And so
I just wanted to remind you of that.

54
00:02:54.500 --> 00:02:59.350
And then also remind you of the fact that,
here, this particular machine, PLABDC01,

55
00:02:59.350 --> 00:03:02.050
if I go ahead and close.

56
00:03:02.050 --> 00:03:05.210
Or here, let me just move this so
we can see it a little better.

57
00:03:05.210 --> 00:03:09.660
In the background here, you can see
the state of this machine is off.

58
00:03:09.660 --> 00:03:16.216
So if I wanted to go ahead and
add a new adapter, I could.

59
00:03:16.216 --> 00:03:21.158
If I compare that to a machine that's
running like our PLAB Win 802 machine and

60
00:03:21.158 --> 00:03:22.769
I go to our settings here.

61
00:03:22.769 --> 00:03:25.633
And then I take a look at that
same section to go ahead and

62
00:03:25.633 --> 00:03:28.450
add that hardware and
let zoom in a little bit for you.

63
00:03:33.680 --> 00:03:34.699
And move this over.

64
00:03:34.699 --> 00:03:35.426
And move this over.

65
00:03:35.426 --> 00:03:39.760
[LAUGH] You'll notice that these options
here are grayed out because this machine

66
00:03:39.760 --> 00:03:44.930
is running, so I'm not actually
able to add that hardware in

67
00:03:44.930 --> 00:03:49.580
if you will, such as creating that
network adapter, either versions here.

68
00:03:49.580 --> 00:03:53.490
So I just wanted to point that out for
you, before we move forward.

69
00:03:53.490 --> 00:03:57.760
And now that I've got my zoom all,
out of filter here,

70
00:03:57.760 --> 00:04:00.200
let me just close that up here.

71
00:04:00.200 --> 00:04:04.458
And let's go back into that DC01, so
we can modify those settings here.

72
00:04:04.458 --> 00:04:06.349
All right.

73
00:04:09.228 --> 00:04:13.225
One thing that I'd like to show you, and
if I just go over to the left hand side

74
00:04:13.225 --> 00:04:15.850
here on my network adapter,
and I'll zoom in.

75
00:04:15.850 --> 00:04:19.530
I have one that's preexisting,
you can see that right here.

76
00:04:19.530 --> 00:04:23.670
My network adapter attached to PLAB,
private,

77
00:04:23.670 --> 00:04:28.758
that's gonna be the switch that it's
attached to or bound to, I should say.

78
00:04:28.758 --> 00:04:33.230
So I'm gonna go ahead and click on this
plus symbol here and expand that out.

79
00:04:33.230 --> 00:04:38.160
Now, we were looking at our hardware
acceleration and advanced features

80
00:04:38.160 --> 00:04:43.850
in the last show, but I do wanna just,
like I said expand on that a little bit.

81
00:04:43.850 --> 00:04:45.980
So one thing that I
don't think I mentioned,

82
00:04:45.980 --> 00:04:49.800
that I would like to is something called,
bandwidth management.

83
00:04:49.800 --> 00:04:54.760
And you can see that option's right
here and the graphical user interface.

84
00:04:54.760 --> 00:04:58.220
And let me just scroll down
a little bit so we can see that.

85
00:04:58.220 --> 00:05:03.700
Notice how I can specify how this network
adapter utilizes network bandwidth.

86
00:05:03.700 --> 00:05:08.520
So basically I can implement
a type of priority here,

87
00:05:08.520 --> 00:05:12.460
and I can set upper and
lower control limits here,

88
00:05:12.460 --> 00:05:17.950
with my minimum bandwidth and
maximum bandwidth.

89
00:05:17.950 --> 00:05:23.080
So, by really defining those upper and
lower control limits,

90
00:05:23.080 --> 00:05:28.008
I can set priorities if I had multiple
adapters for any kind of reason there.

91
00:05:28.008 --> 00:05:32.170
So that's where I could specify
here in megabits per second.

92
00:05:32.170 --> 00:05:36.701
And then also, let me just, hold on,

93
00:05:36.701 --> 00:05:41.090
minimise, you know what?

94
00:05:41.090 --> 00:05:44.590
I'll pull a PowerShell real quick,
but because this machine is off,

95
00:05:44.590 --> 00:05:47.630
I don't wanna log into that machine,
I'll just show you here on the host

96
00:05:47.630 --> 00:05:52.430
what that commandlet would be, if you
wanted to set it here in PowerShell.

97
00:05:52.430 --> 00:05:54.910
You don't need to, oops.

98
00:05:54.910 --> 00:05:58.720
Go through that entire boot process,
just to show that one commandlet.

99
00:05:58.720 --> 00:05:59.590
I'll change the color.

100
00:06:05.338 --> 00:06:08.410
All right,
I'm just going to shorten this line here.

101
00:06:08.410 --> 00:06:13.460
And so that particular commandlet
is going to be set-VMnetwork, and

102
00:06:14.760 --> 00:06:18.700
this is going to be my network adapter,
and I can tab on through.

103
00:06:18.700 --> 00:06:22.160
And then I'm going to
specify the virtual machine.

104
00:06:22.160 --> 00:06:25.920
So, I could actually go ahead and
set this here within my host.

105
00:06:25.920 --> 00:06:29.921
Because the host is hosting
that virtual machine here and

106
00:06:29.921 --> 00:06:32.598
I can just use this VM name parameter.

107
00:06:32.598 --> 00:06:35.448
So VM name and
then I'm gonna specify what was that one?

108
00:06:35.448 --> 00:06:37.170
PLABDC01.

109
00:06:37.170 --> 00:06:41.770
We really won't run this, but
I'm just showing you the syntax here for

110
00:06:41.770 --> 00:06:43.940
you to go ahead and specify that.

111
00:06:43.940 --> 00:06:48.656
And the parameter here
is going to be maximum.

112
00:06:48.656 --> 00:06:53.250
All right and I don't know if I can
tap through quite yet, let's see.

113
00:06:53.250 --> 00:06:58.613
No so this is gonna be maximum
bandwidth and then the number,

114
00:06:58.613 --> 00:07:04.308
the units of measurement that they
use here is gonna be in bytes.

115
00:07:04.308 --> 00:07:07.533
So it's kind of crazy if you think
about typing it out like this, but

116
00:07:07.533 --> 00:07:09.295
you're gonna go ahead and specify.

117
00:07:09.295 --> 00:07:13.946
So here if I add that's eight zeros,
one two three four five six seven eight.

118
00:07:13.946 --> 00:07:18.570
That's gonna be setting a maximum band
with a 200 megabytes per second there.

119
00:07:18.570 --> 00:07:22.490
So, that's how you would go ahead and
you can use also that other

120
00:07:22.490 --> 00:07:27.330
parameter right here, to go ahead and
set that low bandwidth as well.

121
00:07:27.330 --> 00:07:30.380
So you can go ahead and
obviously modify that in PowerShell.

122
00:07:30.380 --> 00:07:31.400
I just wanted to show you.

123
00:07:33.388 --> 00:07:37.760
All right, so what else do we have here
in the GUI, that I wanted to cover?

124
00:07:37.760 --> 00:07:41.830
And of course, like with everything else,
you can set and specify these parameters.

125
00:07:41.830 --> 00:07:43.956
That's syntax, and we'll take a look,

126
00:07:43.956 --> 00:07:46.340
a little bit more in
PowerShell as well later.

127
00:07:48.000 --> 00:07:52.157
Okay, if I go under my
advanced features here.

128
00:07:52.157 --> 00:07:54.694
We've already spoke about MAC address and

129
00:07:54.694 --> 00:07:59.215
where we can change that and how we can
set those ranges on the switch as well.

130
00:07:59.215 --> 00:08:02.478
But we really didn't
talk about DHCP Guard, so

131
00:08:02.478 --> 00:08:07.954
let me just kind of zoom in here, and
we'll look at each of these individually.

132
00:08:12.388 --> 00:08:18.966
All right, so DHCP guard is going to be,
it's a stop gap mechanism.

133
00:08:18.966 --> 00:08:21.663
Or fail safe mechanism, I should say,

134
00:08:21.663 --> 00:08:26.830
to prevent any kind of rogue virtual
machines from acting as a DHCP server.

135
00:08:26.830 --> 00:08:32.719
So Microsoft recommends to go ahead and
enable DHCP Guard,

136
00:08:32.719 --> 00:08:37.211
if that machine in fact
is not a DHCP machine.

137
00:08:37.211 --> 00:08:42.206
If it is going to be a machine, a server
that you want to run as a DHCP machine,

138
00:08:42.206 --> 00:08:45.575
then go ahead and
just leave that unchecked there.

139
00:08:45.575 --> 00:08:50.288
Because what it will do is it will prevent
those messages associated with our DHCP

140
00:08:50.288 --> 00:08:51.412
communications.

141
00:08:51.412 --> 00:08:56.457
So that's something to think about
as well from a security perspective.

142
00:08:56.457 --> 00:08:59.883
If an attacker were to go ahead and
hijack one of these machines they could

143
00:08:59.883 --> 00:09:02.371
potentially spoof those
types of communications.

144
00:09:02.371 --> 00:09:07.856
So that's one way we can go ahead and
mitigate those types of attacks here and

145
00:09:07.856 --> 00:09:11.728
similarly Router guard,
same concept, all right?

146
00:09:11.728 --> 00:09:13.526
Oops, I just clicked on it and
it moved around on me.

147
00:09:13.526 --> 00:09:16.246
But you guys can see here
that it's going to be,

148
00:09:16.246 --> 00:09:18.831
Router guard drops
router advertisement and

149
00:09:18.831 --> 00:09:23.815
redirection messages from unauthorized

00:22:31.135 --> 00:22:36.653
let's see, I've got a link here, and
I've put this link in the show notes.

372
00:22:36.653 --> 00:22:38.435
Let me just zoom in for us,

373
00:22:38.435 --> 00:22:44.045
this is actually gonna be a Microsoft Word
document that Microsoft put together.

374
00:22:44.045 --> 00:22:48.629
And you can download it straight from
this link that I've got for you,

375
00:22:48.629 --> 00:22:52.366
and it's just,
it's a nice user guide for NIC teaming.

376
00:22:52.366 --> 00:22:56.133
So not only does it cover
how to set up NIC teaming,

377
00:22:56.133 --> 00:23:00.910
leveraging it in regular
instances without virtualization.

378
00:23:00.910 --> 00:23:05.067
But it also covers specific details
that are pertinent to virtualization

379
00:23:05.067 --> 00:23:06.147
configurations.

380
00:23:06.147 --> 00:23:11.245
So let me just show you what that
looks like, and it's a lot here.

381
00:23:11.245 --> 00:23:16.086
So we're scratching the surface, but
if you really wanted to delve deeper, so

382
00:23:16.086 --> 00:23:18.843
we're covering the objectives on the exam.

383
00:23:18.843 --> 00:23:22.671
But if you were to set this up in
your own environment for production,

384
00:23:22.671 --> 00:23:26.573
there might be different configurations
that you want to implement.

385
00:23:26.573 --> 00:23:29.317
And you're not sure how they
would interact together, so

386
00:23:29.317 --> 00:23:30.665
you can just read up on that.

387
00:23:30.665 --> 00:23:34.445
There are also a list of definitions
here that I want to point out.

388
00:23:34.445 --> 00:23:38.599
Now I'm not gonna read all of these
to you, but I do wanna cover them,

389
00:23:38.599 --> 00:23:41.477
this is something that we
do need to be aware of.

390
00:23:41.477 --> 00:23:45.588
Because when we're dealing with
these intangible concepts,

391
00:23:45.588 --> 00:23:48.621
I want to put it in a way
that makes sense to you.

392
00:23:48.621 --> 00:23:50.843
I don't know if that always comes across,
so

393
00:23:50.843 --> 00:23:54.537
I'm gonna try to rehash it throughout
this show, as well as the next show.

394
00:23:54.537 --> 00:23:56.689
We'll see how we can
actually implement it, and

395
00:23:56.689 --> 00:23:58.905
then I'll show you what
I'm talking about here.

396
00:23:58.905 --> 00:24:02.242
So just a couple of things
to think about here,

397
00:24:02.242 --> 00:24:06.093
you'll notice LACP,
this is actually a protocol And

398
00:24:06.093 --> 00:24:10.816
this is another one of those terms
that are kind of industry wide.

399
00:24:10.816 --> 00:24:14.776
You'll hear these umbrella terms and
you're not gonna get frowned upon if you

400
00:24:14.776 --> 00:24:17.424
use, there's a couple
different protocols here.

401
00:24:17.424 --> 00:24:20.960
And let me just make sure I'm
calling out the right ones for you.

402
00:24:20.960 --> 00:24:25.045
This is going to be 802.1, I know it,

403
00:24:25.045 --> 00:24:30.550
we've got ax and
aq are gonna be the newer protocols.

404
00:24:30.550 --> 00:24:33.837
Sometimes people will say 802.3ad,

405
00:24:33.837 --> 00:24:40.050
which is the older protocol that was
associated with the same concept here.

406
00:24:40.050 --> 00:24:44.679
And so here within Microsoft's options,
you'll see lock p for link aggregation

407
00:24:44.679 --> 00:24:49.320
protocol, will be the option that you
have when you're studying up NIC teaming.

408
00:24:50.570 --> 00:24:54.410
NIC, it is what it is, it's just that
physical network interface card.

409
00:24:55.870 --> 00:24:59.050
Receive side scaling, this is going
to be an integration feature,

410
00:24:59.050 --> 00:25:02.390
just how the operating system's
dealing with those incoming packets,

411
00:25:02.390 --> 00:25:06.520
and taking advantage of utilizing
multiple processors there.

412
00:25:06.520 --> 00:25:09.395
Now TNIC, now this is an interesting one,

413
00:25:09.395 --> 00:25:14.610
TNIC is going to be where we're actually
creating a team, and then that outward

414
00:25:14.610 --> 00:25:18.145
facing adapter that's bound to that team,
that's what we're talking about here.

415
00:25:18.145 --> 00:25:23.010
VLAN, hopefully we know what VLAN is at
this point, if not, it's right there,

416
00:25:23.010 --> 00:25:25.840
and we've got tons of shows on that.

417
00:25:25.840 --> 00:25:30.210
VM, you guys know what VM is, so let me
just go to the more important one here.

418
00:25:30.210 --> 00:25:34.627
This is gonna be a VMnet, and this is
gonna be the port on the Hyper-V switch

419
00:25:34.627 --> 00:25:38.590
that's exposed as a networking
interface inside that virtual machine.

420
00:25:40.270 --> 00:25:41.600
Virtual machine cues, again,

421
00:25:41.600 --> 00:25:45.250
this is another way that we can
aggregate all that incoming traffic.

422
00:25:45.250 --> 00:25:48.800
And really, there's this term,
it's called affinity,

423
00:25:48.800 --> 00:25:53.137
and so the way that those traffic,
those TCP flows are gonna be handled.

424
00:25:53.137 --> 00:25:55.939
Affinities mean that they
have a preference for

425
00:25:55.939 --> 00:25:59.730
different ways that that traffic
is going to be dispersed.

426
00:25:59.730 --> 00:26:02.060
And we'll take a look at that
a little bit more in depth as well.

427
00:26:03.290 --> 00:26:05.719
The last one I really want to
note out here is gonna be a VNIC.

428
00:26:05.719 --> 00:26:10.372
Which is a port on the Hyper-V switch
exposed as the networking interface in

429
00:26:10.372 --> 00:26:12.470
the host partition.

430
00:26:12.470 --> 00:26:15.010
All right, so Cherokee,
what does that really mean?

431
00:26:15.010 --> 00:26:19.850
I know I'm reading it to you, but
let me try to put it in a visual way.

432
00:26:19.850 --> 00:26:23.210
Because I'm a visual learner, and so
maybe this will help you, as well.

433
00:26:23.210 --> 00:26:25.420
And just looking at these
different components here,

434
00:26:25.420 --> 00:26:28.280
right, we can look at the hardware.

435
00:26:28.280 --> 00:26:31.220
This is the host machine,
the physical hardware, right?

436
00:26:31.220 --> 00:26:34.779
And just like we saw in that previous
diagram, here we have two switches.

437
00:26:34.779 --> 00:26:37.900
Which, like Wes and I spoke about, this
isn't really a smart way to go ahead and

438
00:26:37.900 --> 00:26:38.422
set that up.

439
00:26:38.422 --> 00:26:42.910
But that's switch independent,
I'm not dependent on just that one switch.

440
00:26:44.110 --> 00:26:46.720
And then that machine, that server, and

441
00:26:46.720 --> 00:26:50.810
out here, we have two physical network
interface cards, those are just our NICs.

442
00:26:50.810 --> 00:26:53.950
And in a production environment,

443
00:26:53.950 --> 00:26:58.170
we would never want to have
just one NIC in that server.

444
00:26:58.170 --> 00:27:03.191
As a matter of fact, in NIC teaming,
without virtualization, when I

445
00:27:03.191 --> 00:27:09.250
create those teams there in the host, I
can have up to 32 network interface cards.

446
00:27:09.250 --> 00:27:13.990
So two is kinda of on the low end here,
but we want to at least have two here for

447
00:27:13.990 --> 00:27:15.980
that redundancy.

448
00:27:15.980 --> 00:27:20.073
Now if we look at the way that these
other components are configured, right.

449
00:27:20.073 --> 00:27:24.103
So inside of our host operating system,
we can create virtual machines, and

450
00:27:24.103 --> 00:27:27.270
that's what this yellow
rectangle is representing, a VM.

451
00:27:28.310 --> 00:27:33.935
Now, inside of my VM,
I have VM NICs, and whether

452
00:27:33.935 --> 00:27:39.172
you recognized it or not, you guys have
just seeing how we can create VM NICs.

453
00:27:39.172 --> 00:27:41.776
And that was through
generating those adapters,

454
00:27:41.776 --> 00:27:44.693
so those adapters are associated
with those machines.

455
00:27:44.693 --> 00:27:49.193
Whether it be a legacy adapter, or
just an option there, the newer option for

456
00:27:49.193 --> 00:27:53.410
the network adapter,
those are called your VM NICs, right?

457
00:27:53.410 --> 00:27:59.720
Now if I take two or more of those
adapters and bind them together to create

458
00:27:59.720 --> 00:28:05.310
a team, then essentially the operating
system is going to see that as a whole.

459
00:28:05.310 --> 00:28:09.110
So now, I would call that a TNIC,
for that adapter,

460
00:28:09.110 --> 00:28:11.390
so that's where that term
comes into play here.

461
00:28:13.090 --> 00:28:17.352
Your vNIC is a little different, your
vNIC is going to be the adapter that's

462
00:28:17.352 --> 00:28:21.097
actually creating a bond to
the physical network interface card.

463
00:28:21.097 --> 00:28:24.715
So you don't wanna include that
vNIC in any of your teams there,

464
00:28:24.715 --> 00:28:29.071
because the virtual switch relies on
that to associate it with the physical.

465
00:28:29.071 --> 00:28:35.397
So that you could essentially get out to
the wire there, the physical equipment,

466
00:28:35.397 --> 00:28:40.970
so you could leave the shell of
that hardware enclosure there.

467
00:28:40.970 --> 00:28:42.482
So just looking at the list,

468
00:28:42.482 --> 00:28:45.891
I think we've covered about
everything to really get started.

469
00:28:45.891 --> 00:28:48.465
But we haven't actually
created any of these teams, so

470
00:28:48.465 --> 00:28:52.203
if you're wondering how the heck do we
do that, you're gonna wanna stay tuned.

471
00:28:52.203 --> 00:28:54.380
>> All right, well,
that's a perfect place to stop.

472
00:28:54.380 --> 00:28:56.840
Cherokee, as always,
we do appreciate you being here.

473
00:28:56.840 --> 00:28:59.400
Keep in mind, though,
we're gonna have to go into a part four.

474
00:28:59.400 --> 00:29:02.080
That's right, we can get this stuff
online, get it configured, and

475
00:29:02.080 --> 00:29:03.050
show you how it works.

476
00:29:03.050 --> 00:29:06.500
But Cherokee, great job as always, we
appreciate you stopping by in the studios,

477
00:29:06.500 --> 00:29:08.765
and we appreciate you,
the viewer, watching.

478
00:29:08.765 --> 00:29:12.090
Remember, you can watch this show and
thousands of hours of additional content

479
00:29:12.090 --> 00:29:13.937
by just jumping over
to our course library.

480
00:29:13.937 --> 00:29:16.236
But until we see you again,
signing out for ITProTV,

481
00:29:16.236 --> 00:29:17.628
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

482
00:29:17.628 --> 00:29:18.228
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

483
00:29:18.228 --> 00:29:19.385
>> And we'll see you next time.

484
00:29:19.385 --> 00:29:25.928
[MUSIC]

485
00:29:25.928 --> 00:29:28.006
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Tune in to see Cherokee and Wes demonstrate the creation of NIC Teams inside of a virtual machine. First, Cherokee walks through the steps needed to configure a team within the GUI followed by the process of creating one via PowerShell as well.
episodes.title: Hyper-V Networking Part 4

So, we did kind of start with a couple of

So, if you don't remember

NIC teaming gear withing

So, let's go ahead and take a look

this if you will.

I did say that there is a configuration
that needs to be enabled in order for

30

a virtual machine to allow the adaptors
to participate in this wonderful feature,

and that's going to be

00:01:20.546 --> 00:01:24.281
So remember, I did show you here,

35
00:01:33.914 --> 00:01:39.074
So if you just look at the syntax,

37

So for our demonstration, we're gonna
be using virtual machine PLABDM, for

domain member 01, and then we use
the parameter -AllowTeaming, and

then you have that on or

40
00:01:55.258 --> 00:02:00.892
So let's just go ahead and

00:02:00.892 --> 00:02:05.166
let me go ahead and

00:02:05.166 --> 00:02:08.373
I'll just borrow the settings here for

00:02:08.373 --> 00:02:13.360

That was going to be on
this particular machine,

00:02:16.769 --> 00:02:20.439
I only have one adapter for

46
00:02:20.439 --> 00:02:22.800
Remember, in real life,
when we spoke about this,

00:02:22.800 --> 00:02:25.323
you wanna have more than one
adapter in production, but

48
00:02:25.323 --> 00:02:28.180
I'm just showing you exactly
where this setting was located.

49
00:02:28.180 --> 00:02:29.952
That's what I really wanna point out here.

50
00:02:29.952 --> 00:02:33.754
If I expand out this arrow,
under our advanced features,

00:02:33.754 --> 00:02:36.859
remember that was all
the way at the bottom, and

00:02:36.859 --> 00:02:41.680
let me kind of move my scroll bar so

53
00:02:43.950 --> 00:02:44.750
A little bit more.

54
00:02:44.750 --> 00:02:45.844
All right.

55
00:02:45.844 --> 00:02:50.160
So this portion right here, and
I can zoom in a little more if we need to.

56
00:02:50.160 --> 00:02:51.634
Yeah, that's better.

57
00:02:54.276 --> 00:02:55.630
NIC Teaming.

58
00:02:55.630 --> 00:02:57.631
So this is where I would go ahead and

59
00:02:57.631 --> 00:03:02.272
enable that on the per machine basis here
within the graphical user interface.

60
00:03:02.272 --> 00:03:07.525
So one of those ways, whatever you choose,
but I just wanted to remind you that

61
00:03:07.525 --> 00:03:13.116
has to be done before that machine will
actually participate and create that team.

62
00:03:13.116 --> 00:03:19.044
Now, I have my domain member up and

63
00:03:19.044 --> 00:03:23.721
and I've pulled my server manager up.

64
00:03:23.721 --> 00:03:27.350
So, couple different ways
we could do this here.

65
00:03:27.350 --> 00:03:29.659
I've added two different

66
00:03:29.659 --> 00:03:35.846
So like I said, in Hyper-V Microsoft
says they will only support teams.

67
00:03:35.846 --> 00:03:39.679
If you're creating a team
inside of a virtual machine,

68
00:03:39.679 --> 00:03:45.239
let's think about this for a second,
Microsoft will only support teams of two.

69
00:03:45.239 --> 00:03:48.262
It doesn't mean you can't have more teams,
and like Wes and

70
00:03:48.262 --> 00:03:52.174
I had mentioned in the previous show,
teaming has been around for a long time,

71
00:03:52.174 --> 00:03:53.800
and other vendors do offer it.

72
00:03:53.800 --> 00:03:58.772
So it's not that it's not possible, it's
just that you're going to be on your own

73
00:03:58.772 --> 00:04:03.410
if you do decide to set up multiple
adapters inside of that actually machine.

74
00:04:03.410 --> 00:04:05.393
That rule doesn't apply
to the actual hardware.

75
00:04:05.393 --> 00:04:08.815
So if I remove Hyper-V from the equation,
and

76
00:04:08.815 --> 00:04:13.816
I'm just doing NIC Teaming on a hardware,
a box with my equipment,

77
00:04:13.816 --> 00:04:18.300
my physical equipment,
I can have up to 32 within a team.

78
00:04:18.300 --> 00:04:21.566
So just kind of be aware
of the differences there.

79
00:04:21.566 --> 00:04:24.499
But I've created some adapters here.

80
00:04:24.499 --> 00:04:28.546
I've got two that we're gonna be working
with, and I'll just show you real quick,

81
00:04:28.546 --> 00:04:31.852
you wanna make sure that you're
dealing with static IP addresses for

82
00:04:31.852 --> 00:04:34.820
these adapters,
otherwise things could get a little fuzzy.

83
00:04:34.820 --> 00:04:39.632
So what I'm going to do here is, let's
pull up PowerShell inside of our machine,

84
00:04:39.632 --> 00:04:41.885
and let me just change the font for us.

85
00:04:45.044 --> 00:04:49.906
Let's go to 20,

86
00:04:49.906 --> 00:04:53.902
and change that screen text to white.

87
00:04:53.902 --> 00:04:57.118
It just makes it a little
bit easier to read.

88
00:04:57.118 --> 00:05:04.530
And then also I'll just back
on out whoops not CS, CD.

89
00:05:06.270 --> 00:05:08.497
Okay.

90
00:05:08.497 --> 00:05:12.274
Just clearing my screen, sorry it's
a little like OCD going on here,

91
00:05:12.274 --> 00:05:15.554
not totally, but just like to
have it nice and clean for you.

92
00:05:15.554 --> 00:05:20.362
Okay, so what I'm gonna be
using here is my netsh command.

93
00:05:20.362 --> 00:05:23.443
So netsh has been around for
a long time, and

94
00:05:23.443 --> 00:05:26.620
this is gonna allow me
to set a static IP here.

95
00:05:26.620 --> 00:05:34.880
So I'm gonna set my interface, and
this is going to be ip set address, and

96
00:05:34.880 --> 00:05:40.050
the adapter that I'm gonna be setting this
address for, is going to be "Ethernet2",

97
00:05:41.330 --> 00:05:45.420
and because there's a space here,
I'm using these quotation marks.

98
00:05:45.420 --> 00:05:49.040
If you have the name of your adapter
without quotation, or without a space,

99
00:05:49.040 --> 00:05:52.902
then you don't have to use the quotation
marks, but I'm just letting you know.

100
00:05:52.902 --> 00:05:57.890
All right, so my static IP address here,
what do they want us to use?

101
00:05:57.890 --> 00:06:02.372
This is gonna be 192.168.0.30
with a Class C subnet mask.

102
00:06:04.580 --> 00:06:06.740
I'll go ahead and hit Enter here.

103
00:06:06.740 --> 00:06:12.354
Now, we don't have any kind of glaring
remarks saying good job, you did it.

104
00:06:12.354 --> 00:06:15.030

00:15:56.780 --> 00:16:01.847
And if you think about that,

00:16:01.847 --> 00:16:06.960
I'm creating a team for that aggregation,
that increased bandwidth.

257
00:16:06.960 --> 00:16:11.830
So thinking about that traffic coming in
and the operating system's like, okay,

258
00:16:11.830 --> 00:16:13.260
so where do I send this packet?

259
00:16:13.260 --> 00:16:15.350
And where do I send that packet?

260
00:16:15.350 --> 00:16:21.962
So it makes sense to take time and
understand why you're gonna be using this.

261
00:16:21.962 --> 00:16:25.800
How you're gonna be using this
configuration, for example, HyperV.

262
00:16:25.800 --> 00:16:30.420
Each virtual machine NIC,
VM NICnet has it's own MAC address.

263
00:16:30.420 --> 00:16:34.420
So the MAC address is actually gonna
be the identifying factor here

264
00:16:34.420 --> 00:16:37.160
to establish those flows.

265
00:16:37.160 --> 00:16:42.720
And When you take a look at something like
address hash, which is what we see here,

266
00:16:42.720 --> 00:16:47.140
the default, address hash is
going to be taking information.

267
00:16:47.140 --> 00:16:51.610
Information such as IP address,
source, and or destination.

268
00:16:51.610 --> 00:16:53.490
And, mAC addresses.

269
00:16:53.490 --> 00:16:57.340
So they take all that info, they go ahead
and if you're familiar with hashes and

270
00:16:57.340 --> 00:16:58.410
how they worked,

271
00:16:58.410 --> 00:17:03.510
a hash is going to be like an algorithm
that is applied to a string of data.

272
00:17:03.510 --> 00:17:06.140
And then that output should be unique.

273
00:17:06.140 --> 00:17:09.830
So, when the system
looks at an identifier,

274
00:17:09.830 --> 00:17:13.620
it's assuming that that hash is unique
because well, hashes should be.

275
00:17:13.620 --> 00:17:18.760
And then it knowS which virtual machine
to actually send that information to.

276
00:17:18.760 --> 00:17:24.040
So what happens is it creates a static
affinity from that virtual machine

277
00:17:24.040 --> 00:17:29.950
based upon the default here is going to
be the TCP ports and the IP addresses.

278
00:17:29.950 --> 00:17:32.060
But that can be configured
slightly differently,

279
00:17:32.060 --> 00:17:34.600
like I said if you have a reason
why you can change that as well.

280
00:17:34.600 --> 00:17:35.997
But that's the default
just to let you know.

281
00:17:35.997 --> 00:17:39.431
And then lastly we have this
option called Dynamic and

282
00:17:39.431 --> 00:17:43.475
again you can't see it here in
the graphical user interface but

283
00:17:43.475 --> 00:17:47.670
when we create our machine or
when we create a team in PowerShell,

284
00:17:47.670 --> 00:17:52.610
that's actually the default if
we don't specify anything other.

285
00:17:52.610 --> 00:17:54.514
And dynamic is a feature,

286
00:17:54.514 --> 00:17:59.371
it's going to be a load balancing
mode new to Server 2012 R2.

287
00:17:59.371 --> 00:18:02.521
And it's a little bit
different the way it works,

288
00:18:02.521 --> 00:18:06.429
so it actually the best of both
of those the two other options.

289
00:18:06.429 --> 00:18:11.402
So for instance inbound traffic is
going to look at that information based

290
00:18:11.402 --> 00:18:15.651
upon like we spoke about like
the IPv4 using the MAC address for

291
00:18:15.651 --> 00:18:17.750
the inbound communications.

292
00:18:17.750 --> 00:18:21.250
But for
outbound it actually uses the hash.

293
00:18:21.250 --> 00:18:23.815
So it's kind of different
the way that that works there.

294
00:18:23.815 --> 00:18:27.980
And then it also leverages
a new concept called flowlets.

295
00:18:29.150 --> 00:18:33.572
And flowlets are kind of logical
ways like someone, Wes and I,

296
00:18:33.572 --> 00:18:38.005
when we're talking and
we have these kind of pauses or breaks.

297
00:18:38.005 --> 00:18:41.604
Or if you're writing a story or
an essay, and

298
00:18:41.604 --> 00:18:45.440
you could use a period or
maybe even a comma.

299
00:18:45.440 --> 00:18:47.320
Just some kind of logical
division like hey,

300
00:18:47.320 --> 00:18:49.306
my thought is complete
I'm rounding this out.

301
00:18:49.306 --> 00:18:53.446
So the flowlets act as a logical
division of packet for

302
00:18:53.446 --> 00:18:58.599
transmission so that it really
helps with our packet placement and

303
00:18:58.599 --> 00:19:01.554
they come in the correct order there.

304
00:19:01.554 --> 00:19:05.193
So I'm evenly distributing and
load balancing and

305
00:19:05.193 --> 00:19:08.753
looking at hey,
where's the good cut off point?

306
00:19:08.753 --> 00:19:13.137
So that's what those flowlets allow us to
do with our dynamic load balancing mode.

00:20:17.573 --> 00:20:20.442
You'll see it scrolling there at the top,

328
00:20:20.442 --> 00:20:23.560
doesn't take too long to go ahead and
create.

329
00:20:25.470 --> 00:20:29.670
You do wanna be mindful of network
connectivity when you are setting up your

330
00:20:29.670 --> 00:20:32.020
team for obvious reason here.

331
00:20:32.020 --> 00:20:35.348
You will have some disconnects.

332
00:20:35.348 --> 00:20:39.535
You saw how quick it was here so
it might not be too disruptive.

333
00:20:39.535 --> 00:20:43.169
But it's always a good idea to kind of
perform this during our maintenance

334
00:20:43.169 --> 00:20:45.116
windows, our downtime, if you will.

335
00:20:45.116 --> 00:20:47.970
Another thing that's kind of interesting.

336
00:20:47.970 --> 00:20:52.579
And a lot of different configurations that
we see in Microsoft environments, and

337
00:20:52.579 --> 00:20:54.046
we see this more and more,

338
00:20:54.046 --> 00:20:58.217
like we had spoke about before as our
operating systems are progressing.

339
00:20:58.217 --> 00:21:02.736
We're able to change more things in
real time and a lot more hot swappable

340
00:21:02.736 --> 00:21:06.884
components, but if you go ahead and
change your NIC team and name,

341
00:21:06.884 --> 00:21:11.182
either through PowerShell, or
the GUI, you'll also see a moment of

342
00:21:11.182 --> 00:21:15.739
disruption there, so it's just kind
of nice to know that ahead of time.

343
00:21:15.739 --> 00:21:20.395
Now, I do see that particular
configuration is down here

344
00:21:20.395 --> 00:21:22.930
from the notifications.

345
00:21:22.930 --> 00:21:25.650
Number one, because I'm working
in a lab environment and

346
00:21:25.650 --> 00:21:28.430
I don't have those physical adapters.

347
00:21:28.430 --> 00:21:32.420
I only have one physical adapter
in this lab environment, but

348
00:21:32.420 --> 00:21:34.610
that's how you would go ahead and
set it up.

349
00:21:34.610 --> 00:21:37.110
One thing I do wanna show you here,
let's go back,

350
00:21:37.110 --> 00:21:41.240
open our Network and Sharing Center so
you can kind of associate that from

351
00:21:41.240 --> 00:21:45.330
a graphical perspective of
what this looks like for us.

352
00:21:45.330 --> 00:21:47.860
I've just changed the view here,
but you can see,

353
00:21:47.860 --> 00:21:52.410
these are the adapters that I have, I had
done that when we were fumbling through

354
00:21:52.410 --> 00:21:57.060
all the site resizing here, but
I've got my Ethernet and Ethernet 2.

355
00:21:57.060 --> 00:21:58.890
And now you can see my team.

356
00:21:58.890 --> 00:22:03.430
And notice that there's a red x here.

357
00:22:03.430 --> 00:22:06.240
Okay, that's stated as being down.

358
00:22:06.240 --> 00:22:09.730
So if I just right-click on that and
select Disable.

359
00:22:11.320 --> 00:22:11.957
Give it a second.

360
00:22:13.474 --> 00:22:16.690
Once I re-enable that,
it will go ahead and enable that team.

361
00:22:16.690 --> 00:22:20.290
So right click, Enable, all right?

362
00:22:20.290 --> 00:22:24.207
And you can see here, it happened
really quick, but it said enabling.

363
00:22:24.207 --> 00:22:29.114
So now that that is enabled,
something else I wanna show you.

364
00:22:29.114 --> 00:22:33.744
Remember we set the IP address
of Ethernet 2 as static, so

365
00:22:33.744 --> 00:22:36.770
let's check that real quick.

366
00:22:36.770 --> 00:22:42.381
If we go into properties, Notice

367
00:22:42.381 --> 00:22:46.960
here how nothing is bound to
those IP protocols, right?

368
00:22:46.960 --> 00:22:48.194
So what's happening?

369
00:22:48.194 --> 00:22:51.754
Well now this is
essentially what happened.

370
00:22:51.754 --> 00:22:56.198
We went from having a VM NIC, right?

371
00:22:56.198 --> 00:23:02.550
Well two VM NICs, Ethernet and
Ethernet 2, to now having a T NIC.

372
00:23:02.550 --> 00:23:06.280
So if you recall that diagram that
we had looked at in the last show

373
00:23:06.280 --> 00:23:11.130
I said that's something that changes
whenever we create our teams.

374
00:23:11.130 --> 00:23:15.553
So, if we look at the properties here for
our actual t-nick,

375
00:23:15.553 --> 00:23:17.945
okay and let me just scroll down.

376
00:23:21.561 --> 00:23:22.307
We'll get there.

377
00:23:22.307 --> 00:23:30.862
We can see here that our actual IP
Properties are bound here to our T NIC's.

378
00:23:30.862 --> 00:23:33.838
So this is where that interface,
that adaptor is,

379
00:23:33.838 --> 00:23:36.688
that relationship is transpiring,
all right?

380
00:23:36.688 --> 00:23:39.551
So hopefully that makes sense for you,

381
00:23:39.551 --> 00:23:43.818
taking a look at the different
terms that may be new to you.

382
00:23:43.818 --> 00:23:48.986
All right, now that we've
created our team let's do this.

383
00:23:48.986 --> 00:23:52.926
Let's get into PowerShell and
see what we can do because PowerShell is

384
00:23:52.926 --> 00:23:56.751
definitely gonna be something that
we need to know moving forward.

385
00:23:56.751 --> 00:24:01.434
I'm just backing out of the multiple
windows that I have opened here.

386
00:24:01.434 --> 00:24:08.580
And you'll need to refresh or close out
of and relaunch that NIC Teaming window.

387
00:24:08.580 --> 00:24:12.390
If you do disable and re-enable
that to get that most up to date,

388
00:24:12.390 --> 00:24:13.190
I'm sure you know that.

389
00:24:13.190 --> 00:24:14.340
But I'm just kind of reminding you.

390
00:24:15.550 --> 00:24:17.740
So let's go ahead and pull up PowerShell.

391
00:24:17.740 --> 00:24:22.370
And take a look at what we can do here,
let me clear this out.

392
00:24:22.370 --> 00:24:24.950
This is from what we had earlier,
so I just clear the screen.

393
00:24:25.960 --> 00:24:30.952
Now, the first thing I
want to do is run my

394
00:24:30.952 --> 00:24:38.690
Get-NetAdapter to take
a look at what we just saw.

395
00:24:38.690 --> 00:24:42.322
This is essentially the exact same
information that we were looking at there

396
00:24:42.322 --> 00:24:45.566
in the graphical user interface
under Network and Sharing center.

397
00:24:45.566 --> 00:24:50.102
But I just wanna show you, look,
we have those two adapters, Ethernet and

398
00:24:50.102 --> 00:24:53.740
Ethernet 2,
as well as our NICTeam that we had named.

399
00:24:53.740 --> 00:24:56.360
And it puts it in a table type format, so

400
00:24:56.360 --> 00:25:00.480
you can see well, I say you can see but
eventually we'll get there.

401
00:25:00.480 --> 00:25:04.830
If I were to go ahead and scroll over
you could see information such as

402
00:25:04.830 --> 00:25:09.840
your speeds and things like that if,
that interface index as well.

403
00:25:09.840 --> 00:25:13.740
So you could also use that as an
identifier to set certain configurations.

404
00:25:13.740 --> 00:25:17.200
And because of the status of this
being that virtual environment,

405
00:25:17.200 --> 00:25:21.500
you'll notice that it says disconnected,
but that's okay for now.

406
00:25:21.500 --> 00:25:23.680
Those are the steps of how to go ahead and
create it, and

407
00:25:23.680 --> 00:25:24.690
that's what we're gonna be looking at.

408
00:25:26.210 --> 00:25:30.660
All right, let's get back into
position here to actually,

409
00:25:30.660 --> 00:25:32.510
let me just clear the screen again.

410
00:25:32.510 --> 00:25:34.070
We'll create that team.

411
00:25:34.070 --> 00:25:35.910
All right, in order to create a new theme,

412
00:25:35.910 --> 00:25:41.880
we're gonna be using
the cmdlet New-NetLBFOTeam and

413
00:25:41.880 --> 00:25:46.220
we can tab through there to make
sure I'm spelling things correctly.

414
00:25:46.220 --> 00:25:50.410
Now let's specify the name that we
want to call this particular team.

415
00:25:50.410 --> 00:25:53.474
We'll go ahead and call this one DemoTeam.

416
00:25:53.474 --> 00:25:58.050
And the next thing that we need
to add is well, our team members.

417
00:25:58.050 --> 00:26:02.450
So the team members we have, and
we just have to check on for

418
00:26:02.450 --> 00:26:06.325
the words members because my brain
always want to spell in members,

419
00:26:06.325 --> 00:26:09.830
[LAUGH] must be a Southern thing,
I don't know.

420
00:26:09.830 --> 00:26:14.810
Anyway, so my team members for
this particular team are going to be,

421
00:26:14.810 --> 00:26:18.020
well we have Ethernet,
that was the first one.

422
00:26:18.020 --> 00:26:21.650
And because Ethernet like I said,
one word, I don't have a space there,

423
00:26:21.650 --> 00:26:24.900
you don't have to put
the quotation marks around it, but

424
00:26:24.900 --> 00:26:29.710
I will need to do that here for
Ethernet 2, end quotation.

425
00:26:29.710 --> 00:26:32.360
And I'm kind of wrapping
up this screen here,

426
00:26:32.360 --> 00:26:34.970
I'll go ahead and
scroll over here to show you that.

427
00:26:34.970 --> 00:26:39.820
Now, unintentionally omitting
particular parameters

428
00:26:39.820 --> 00:26:43.220
from the syntax to go ahead show
you what those defaults are.

429
00:26:43.220 --> 00:26:45.230
So if I just specified the name and

430
00:26:45.230 --> 00:26:49.750
the members of a team here in PowerShell,
let's see what happens.

431
00:26:49.750 --> 00:26:53.110
Okay, so again I didn't use that
confirmed parameter, so it's asking me,

432
00:26:53.110 --> 00:26:54.140
do you want to do this?

433
00:26:54.140 --> 00:27:00.670
So I'll say, Yes I do, and we look at
those default configuration options here,

434
00:27:00.670 --> 00:27:06.750
the default configurations that
we get if we don't specify.

435
00:27:06.750 --> 00:27:10.754
So I see the two variables
that I did set there for

436
00:27:10.754 --> 00:27:14.920
my DemoTeam, Ethernet 2 and Ethernet.

437
00:27:14.920 --> 00:27:19.310
But notice here for my TeamingMode,
it's still SwitchIndependent.

438
00:27:19.310 --> 00:27:24.480
That's the same option that we saw within
the graphical user interface here because

439
00:27:24.480 --> 00:27:29.260
again, that just makes the most sense
using an inter-virtualized environment.

440
00:27:29.260 --> 00:27:34.250
But notice for our LoadBalancingAlgorithm,
by not specifying, remember that

441
00:27:34.250 --> 00:27:37.730
our address hash was a default
within the graphical user interface.

442
00:27:37.730 --> 00:27:40.690
But now it's dynamic for that default.

443
00:27:40.690 --> 00:27:43.320
So just kinda pointing that out for you.

444
00:27:43.320 --> 00:27:49.160
And the other default that's not
really listed in this output here,

445
00:27:49.160 --> 00:27:53.250
but if I were to check and
individually on a specific team member,

446
00:27:53.250 --> 00:27:58.747
I could do that by using the Get- NetLBFO,

447
00:27:58.747 --> 00:28:01.660
and we'll tab through, no.

448
00:28:01.660 --> 00:28:06.236
That's because I didn't
spell things correctly,

449
00:28:06.236 --> 00:28:09.884
it sure does help, NetLBFOTeamMember.

450
00:28:09.884 --> 00:28:11.949
Not team, TeamMember.

451
00:28:11.949 --> 00:28:16.295
And here, again if I omit the actual
name of the team member, so

452
00:28:16.295 --> 00:28:19.170
I could specify Ethernet or Ethernet 2.

453
00:28:19.170 --> 00:28:23.692
If I leave that blank and just hit Enter,
this is gonna show me the information for

454
00:28:23.692 --> 00:28:25.480
both of those team members.

455
00:28:25.480 --> 00:28:31.390
So I can see that here,
first we have Ethernet 2 and if you recall

456
00:28:31.390 --> 00:28:35.630
that configuration we were talking about
with active active or active passive.

457
00:28:35.630 --> 00:28:41.020
In this configuration I can see that
Ethernet 2 is set for active, okay?

458
00:28:41.020 --> 00:28:46.830
Scrolling down, looking at Ethernet,
Ethernet is also active, right here.

459
00:28:46.830 --> 00:28:51.970
So if they're both active, that's going
to be that active-active configuration.

460
00:28:53.340 --> 00:28:57.960
Let me clear the screen and
show you how you can change that.

461
00:28:57.960 --> 00:29:02.850
So in order to set one into,
one adapter here,

462
00:29:02.850 --> 00:29:06.200
to be in standby mode,
we would use the SET cmdlet.

463
00:29:06.200 --> 00:29:11.950
So I would say, Set-NetLBFO and

464
00:29:11.950 --> 00:29:15.370
then this is gonna be TeamMember.

465
00:29:15.370 --> 00:29:19.300
And then you would specify
the actual team member name.

466
00:29:19.300 --> 00:29:23.970
So I'm going to go ahead and
use that name parameter.

467
00:29:23.970 --> 00:29:26.520
Again here,
this one I'll use my quotations.

468
00:29:26.520 --> 00:29:28.639
We'll say Ethernet 2 and

469
00:29:28.639 --> 00:29:33.657
then we'll add the parameter here for
administrative mode.

470
00:29:36.489 --> 00:29:42.630
The administrative mode is going to
be standby, And we'll hit Enter.

471
00:29:42.630 --> 00:29:47.150
Again, not a whole lot, so in order
to just verify real quick let's get

472
00:29:47.150 --> 00:29:52.190
that LBFOT member cmdlet
to help us check that.

473
00:29:52.190 --> 00:29:55.790
And you can see now for Ethernet 2,

474
00:29:55.790 --> 00:29:59.870
the administrative mode is
noted here with standby.

475
00:29:59.870 --> 00:30:02.390
So if you wanted to take
advantage of that active/passive,

476
00:30:02.390 --> 00:30:04.800
that's how you could
here within PowerShell.

477
00:30:04.800 --> 00:30:06.000
But, like I said,

478
00:30:06.000 --> 00:30:10.770
just knowing the default so you're not
configuring something incorrectly,

479
00:30:10.770 --> 00:30:14.400
you're assuming that it's a certain way
because it was a certain way in the GUI.

480
00:30:14.400 --> 00:30:17.910
But PowerShell it's a little different and
I just wanted to note that.

481
00:30:17.910 --> 00:30:22.590
And that's how you create NICTeams
here within Virtual Machines.

482
00:30:22.590 --> 00:30:24.120
>> All right, a lot of great information.

483
00:30:24.120 --> 00:30:26.360
I know it took us a while to
get through there cuz remember,

484
00:30:26.360 --> 00:30:28.060
we've got quite a few parts here.

485
00:30:28.060 --> 00:30:31.430
Keep in mind, go back and
watch all those parts in totality.

486
00:30:31.430 --> 00:30:34.400
Cherokee, I think you did a great job,
thank you as always for being here in

487
00:30:34.400 --> 00:30:37.560
the studios with us, and thank you to
the viewer for watching out there.

488
00:30:37.560 --> 00:30:41.200
Remember, you can watch this episode and
thousands of hours of additional content,

489
00:30:41.200 --> 00:30:44.310
but you'll have to jump over to our
course library to take a benefit there.

490
00:30:44.310 --> 00:30:47.927
Until we see you again, signing off for
ITPro TV, I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

491
00:30:47.927 --> 00:30:48.730
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

492
00:30:48.730 --> 00:30:50.625
>> We'll see you next time.

493
00:30:50.625 --> 00:30:56.645
[MUSIC]

494
00:30:56.645 --> 00:30:59.592
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee demonstrate how to install and configure DHCP.  Cherokee describes the DHCP process.  She also installs the DHCP role through powershell and indicates that we can do the whole process through this.  She demonstrates creating scopes in the GUI  using the wizard.
episodes.title: Deploy and Configure DHCP
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:02.690
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.690 --> 00:00:06.266
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.266 --> 00:00:08.225
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.225 --> 00:00:12.226
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.226 --> 00:00:15.464
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.464 --> 00:00:19.290
You're watching the MCSA for
Windows Server 2012 R2.

7
00:00:19.290 --> 00:00:21.300
More specifically focusing
in on exam 70-410.

8
00:00:21.300 --> 00:00:27.810
And today, we're covering deploying and
configuring DHCP servers.

9
00:00:27.810 --> 00:00:30.410
And here to help us to understand
this process a bit better is gonna be

10
00:00:30.410 --> 00:00:31.470
Miss Cherokee Boose.

11
00:00:31.470 --> 00:00:32.650
Cherokee, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:32.650 --> 00:00:34.790
>> Well, thank you for
having me as always, Ronnie.

13
00:00:34.790 --> 00:00:35.810
How are you today?

14
00:00:35.810 --> 00:00:36.830
>> I am doing fine.

15
00:00:36.830 --> 00:00:38.560
Now, Cherokee, as we begin and

16
00:00:38.560 --> 00:00:43.110
talk about the idea of DHCP,
it is one of these main processes

17
00:00:43.110 --> 00:00:46.470
that we tend to have running in just
about every network that I've ever seen.

18
00:00:46.470 --> 00:00:49.960
So, it's a big part of our
lives as system administrators.

19
00:00:49.960 --> 00:00:51.860
So, where are we gonna begin today?

20
00:00:51.860 --> 00:00:55.890
>> Yeah so, Ronnie, DHCP,
dynamic host configuration protocol,

21
00:00:55.890 --> 00:00:59.770
is a core network service,
it's very important.

22
00:00:59.770 --> 00:01:02.835
Microsoft at this level assumes
you have some base knowledge.

23
00:01:02.835 --> 00:01:05.415
So let's just talk about that for
a moment,

24
00:01:05.415 --> 00:01:08.565
some things that we already
know about DHCP, right?

25
00:01:08.565 --> 00:01:11.360
So we should know at this
point what DHCP does.

26
00:01:11.360 --> 00:01:15.220
DHCP provides information to
my clients on the network.

27
00:01:15.220 --> 00:01:17.670
So, for instance, mainly,

28
00:01:17.670 --> 00:01:21.090
probably the most popular thing
being those IP addresses.

29
00:01:21.090 --> 00:01:24.490
It can provide information
such as the subnet mask.

30
00:01:24.490 --> 00:01:28.630
It can provide our default gateway,
the router IP address there.

31
00:01:28.630 --> 00:01:29.530
But that's not it.

32
00:01:29.530 --> 00:01:32.560
It can provide up to 50 different options.

33
00:01:32.560 --> 00:01:34.550
We may not use all those options.

34
00:01:34.550 --> 00:01:37.200
Usually, those three
are probably the most popular.

35
00:01:37.200 --> 00:01:42.130
But just knowing that our DHCP servers
can provide that information to our

36
00:01:42.130 --> 00:01:45.050
clients on our network, so
that everyone's on the same page.

37
00:01:45.050 --> 00:01:47.480
And they know where to
obtain certain resources and

38
00:01:47.480 --> 00:01:49.720
how to communicate with each other.

39
00:01:49.720 --> 00:01:52.900
>> Now, Cherokee,
the advantage of this, though, and

40
00:01:52.900 --> 00:01:57.105
the reason why we want to emphasize
this is because of the D part of DHTP,

41
00:01:57.105 --> 00:02:00.770
the dynamic host configuration protocol.

42
00:02:00.770 --> 00:02:04.250
Which means that you and
I don't have to manually do this.

43
00:02:04.250 --> 00:02:07.870
So, for example, Cherokee, one of the
things that I have actually dealt with on

44
00:02:07.870 --> 00:02:10.320
network are things like IP phones, right?

45
00:02:10.320 --> 00:02:11.890
The idea of using VOIP.

46
00:02:11.890 --> 00:02:14.040
Well, when they get their configuration,

47
00:02:14.040 --> 00:02:19.100
I actually have FTP server in which
the phone when I plug it in has to go and

48
00:02:19.100 --> 00:02:23.640
talk to the FTP server to bring down the
information that needs to on that phone.

49
00:02:23.640 --> 00:02:27.140
Well, if I had to do that for every
single phone, wait for it to plug in and

50
00:02:27.140 --> 00:02:28.880
then manually have to go,
all right, now go and

51
00:02:28.880 --> 00:02:31.700
retrieve the files that
it needs to do that?

52
00:02:31.700 --> 00:02:35.900
Well, that would become a hefty, hefty
process if every single phone needs that.

53
00:02:35.900 --> 00:02:39.080
But with DHCP, though, if we set it up and
using some of the options that

54
00:02:39.080 --> 00:02:43.970
you're talking about, Cherokee, it means I
just plug in the phone and what happens?

55
00:02:43.970 --> 00:02:44.990
It does it for me, right?

56
00:02:44.990 --> 00:02:47.720
>> Right, I mean, could you imagine
going to all of those different phones?

57

00:16:48.430 --> 00:16:50.550
to authorize that DHCP.

281
00:16:50.550 --> 00:16:53.210
Unless delegation is otherwise specified,
so

282
00:16:53.210 --> 00:16:55.790
that it is important to note,
thank you for that.

00:16:55.790 --> 00:16:57.936
Now if we can take a look

this is going to be our

For now we're just gonna
be talking about IPv4 and

this is where you will manually input

And in production you probably wanna

be utilizing Scope1 to

help organize your

00:17:54.370 --> 00:17:57.690
Now for Scope1, let's see here-

The IP addresses that I have here,

00:18:08.238 --> 00:18:14.580
I want to make sure,

I think that's going to be 192.168, and

We need to specify the end

00:18:37.682 --> 00:18:40.192
We're gonna keep it here with

00:18:40.192 --> 00:18:42.876
all that information is correct,

We're gonna come back to this but

So exclusions are simply excluding

00:19:23.250 --> 00:19:27.160
>> Now, Cherokee, this is a good

00:19:27.160 --> 00:19:30.560
So at the very beginning, as Cherokee

00:19:30.560 --> 00:19:34.610
the ranges there where she skipped 1.1,

00:19:38.020 --> 00:19:40.860

So in here, she might actually have set

00:19:59.378 --> 00:20:03.096
as well, or 1.10, or 1.50,
whatever she wanted to exclude.

337
00:20:03.096 --> 00:20:03.975
And that way,

00:20:03.975 --> 00:20:09.220
even though it included the whole range

00:20:09.220 --> 00:20:11.770
She would set this exclusion up so
that DHCP would say,

00:20:11.770 --> 00:20:13.810
hey, we're gonna just kind of delay that.

341
00:20:13.810 --> 00:20:16.120
And that way those addresses
will not be handed out.

342
00:20:16.120 --> 00:20:17.860
So you have two different versions.

343
00:20:17.860 --> 00:20:20.616
Most of the time in production, I've
always done it the way that Cherokee just

344
00:20:20.616 --> 00:20:22.812
showed you, which is let's just
not include it in the scope.

00:20:22.812 --> 00:20:25.320
And then we'll manually worry about it.

346
00:20:25.320 --> 00:20:26.850
And here they're saying, no.

347
00:20:26.850 --> 00:20:29.360
Microsoft, like I said,
in older documentation usually says,

00:20:29.360 --> 00:20:31.679
include the whole thing and
just make an exclusion for it.

00:20:32.720 --> 00:20:33.360
Six one way,

00:20:33.360 --> 00:20:36.370
half a dozen the other, in terms of
the way that it ends up working out.

351
00:20:36.370 --> 00:20:38.360
>> Right.
>> So it doesn't really matter.

00:20:38.360 --> 00:20:41.780
But if you see something like

00:20:41.780 --> 00:20:43.990
Take the whole range and
then make the exclusions for

00:20:45.820 --> 00:20:46.570
But I would have done it

00:20:46.570 --> 00:20:48.862
the exact same way in production

>> And Ronnie,

But let's just say,

00:21:01.386 --> 00:21:05.376
You also want to think about, when you're

That first IP address is going

00:21:15.648 --> 00:21:17.488
So the numbers that you're inputting,

00:21:17.488 --> 00:21:21.179
the addresses that you're inputting
right here, are the usable IP addresses.

00:21:21.179 --> 00:21:25.226
So you'll just want to remove and
omit the first and last here, so

368
00:21:25.226 --> 00:21:27.520
you have to account for that as well.

369
00:21:29.330 --> 00:21:32.810
All right, so moving right along,

00:21:32.810 --> 00:21:35.880
Let me zoom in a little bit more and

00:21:35.880 --> 00:21:37.760
That is the number 8 here.

00:21:37.760 --> 00:21:41.210
You can see it,

00:21:41.210 --> 00:21:44.172

The idea there is not that

00:21:56.350 --> 00:21:59.000

And these are things you

If you're doing it where
something like a coffee shop.

00:22:10.495 --> 00:22:13.830
8 days is a long time to hand out

00:22:13.830 --> 00:22:15.460

00:22:28.273 --> 00:22:33.017
Then that means that IP address is

00:22:33.017 --> 00:22:38.200

00:22:38.200 --> 00:22:41.640
Cherokee actually has that

That's pretty harsh, so

If you have devices coming in and

If we were just to right click here,
and let's see, defined user classes.

That's what we wanna select for

248

Now, let's think about the scenario

For instance, if we just created

00:15:49.921 --> 00:15:52.419

But maybe I have one department,

00:16:06.911 --> 00:16:12.660
So I might need to have a faster

00:16:12.660 --> 00:16:15.340
I could go ahead and

00:16:15.340 --> 00:16:16.610
There are a couple defaults, but

00:16:16.610 --> 00:16:20.530
I'm gonna select Add,
we're gonna create a new class.

00:16:20.530 --> 00:16:25.312
So for this Display Name, let's go ahead

00:16:27.604 --> 00:16:32.549
All right, now you have to specify
the ASCII characters down here and

00:16:32.549 --> 00:16:35.882
the name that you will use for
configuration.

00:16:35.882 --> 00:16:39.388
It is case-sensitive so I'm just going

262
00:16:42.850 --> 00:16:44.900
So keep that in mind.

263
00:16:44.900 --> 00:16:46.000
And we're gonna hit OK.

264
00:16:48.230 --> 00:16:52.931
Now, in earlier versions of the server
operating system, you could go ahead and

00:16:52.931 --> 00:16:57.791
define all the additional configurations
right here from this little interface.

00:16:57.791 --> 00:17:00.047
But with 2012,
it's a little bit different.

267
00:17:00.047 --> 00:17:01.688
So we're gonna hit Close.

268
00:17:01.688 --> 00:17:07.171
And then we need to go ahead and set up
a policy associated with that user class,

269
00:17:07.171 --> 00:17:11.673
let's see here actually,
if I'm getting in my right section.

270
00:17:11.673 --> 00:17:15.341
>> All right, so Cherokee,
now that you've said that we're gonna set

00:17:15.341 --> 00:17:19.820
this idea of those class options, which of
these nodes are we gonna end up picking?

272
00:17:19.820 --> 00:17:21.930
We're not gonna pick one inside the scope.

00:17:21.930 --> 00:17:23.367
And so what are we actually gonna do here?

274
00:17:23.367 --> 00:17:27.840
>> Right, we have the ability to
set individual scope policies.

275
00:17:27.840 --> 00:17:30.720
But we wanna make sure that
we're in the IPv4 section here.

276
00:17:30.720 --> 00:17:33.950
So you could select from right here.

277
00:17:33.950 --> 00:17:37.290
Or in the right-hand pane
there's also an option.

278
00:17:37.290 --> 00:17:42.050
As long as you make sure you're
configuring this for the, I don't

279
00:17:43.050 --> 00:17:47.390
wanna use the word scope, but
for exactly what you're doing.

280
00:17:47.390 --> 00:17:50.806
If it's at a smaller level for
the scope options,

281
00:17:50.806 --> 00:17:54.150
larger level for
the entire IPv4 section here.

282
00:17:54.150 --> 00:17:57.392
So let's just right-click and
select New Policy.

283
00:17:57.392 --> 00:17:59.690
Then I'll go ahead and
launch this wizard here.

284
00:17:59.690 --> 00:18:05.575
So for the name of our policy, let's go
ahead and name it High-Speed-Gateway here.

285
00:18:10.739 --> 00:18:14.285
All right, and in production of course,
I would want to go ahead and

286
00:18:14.285 --> 00:18:16.229
give that some kind of description.

287
00:18:16.229 --> 00:18:21.394
Maybe we could even say production
team users, something like that, or

00:18:21.394 --> 00:18:26.742
maybe the model of the actual router

289
00:18:26.742 --> 00:18:31.839
All right, for our configuration
options here, we need to,

00:18:31.839 --> 00:18:36.837
let's see, we want to set this
to go ahead and be equal to, so

291
00:18:36.837 --> 00:18:43.420
we wanna say that our user class is equal
to here, so let's go ahead and hit Add.

292
00:18:43.420 --> 00:18:48.844
Drop down from vendor class,
let's select User Class, and then Equals.

293
00:18:48.844 --> 00:18:53.772
And then we wanna choose that policy that
we just created right here from this

00:18:53.772 --> 00:18:54.850
dropdown menu.

295
00:18:54.850 --> 00:18:57.220
There it is, High-Speed-Gateway.

296
00:18:57.220 --> 00:18:59.393
And we wanna make sure that
we hit the Add button so

00:18:59.393 --> 00:19:01.200
it adds it into this section right here.

298
00:19:02.240 --> 00:19:03.650
And we should be good there.

299
00:19:03.650 --> 00:19:05.670
Hit OK.

300
00:19:05.670 --> 00:19:09.555
And then Next.

301
00:19:09.555 --> 00:19:13.440
Because we want to specify a different
router, this is the command, or

302
00:19:13.440 --> 00:19:16.770
the option, the DHCP option,
that we'll be configuring.

303
00:19:16.770 --> 00:19:20.240
And again, remember, there are a lot
of different things that you could set

304
00:19:20.240 --> 00:19:22.940
from within this option here,
this option menu.

305
00:19:22.940 --> 00:19:27.195
But we're gonna choose 003 here for

306
00:19:27.195 --> 00:19:33.749
All right, so for that, we're gonna,
let's just say the IP address for

00:19:33.749 --> 00:19:37.779
that super fast router was 192.168.

308
00:19:37.779 --> 00:19:39.158
>> 1.254.

309
00:19:39.158 --> 00:19:41.218
>> 1.254.

310
00:19:41.218 --> 00:19:41.997
>> Sure, why not.

311
00:19:41.997 --> 00:19:47.790
>> Okay, we'll hit Add and
go ahead and add that in there.

312
00:19:47.790 --> 00:19:50.770
And hit Next and then Finish.

313
00:19:50.770 --> 00:19:54.820
So, I could go ahead and wait for

314
00:19:54.820 --> 00:20:00.520
If I was in a rush and I wanted I was
working with a client on a client

00:20:00.520 --> 00:20:03.870
system and I wanted to push that out
right away, there are a couple different.

316
00:20:03.870 --> 00:20:08.901
You can use ipconfig to help push

00:20:08.901 --> 00:20:09.954
client side.

00:20:09.954 --> 00:20:14.237
So you would just specify the name of your

00:20:14.237 --> 00:20:18.469
So you might want to check and see what

00:20:18.469 --> 00:20:20.127
Otherwise, you would

321
00:20:20.127 --> 00:20:24.166
But that's about it as far as

322
00:20:24.166 --> 00:20:29.970
So any one that I'm specifying there for

00:20:29.970 --> 00:20:34.240
they would be using that faster router

00:20:34.240 --> 00:20:35.730
the option in my network.

325
00:20:35.730 --> 00:20:40.497
>> All right, so Cherokee, you just

00:20:40.497 --> 00:20:45.432
few minutes here in terms of the scope

00:20:45.432 --> 00:20:46.749
>> We created scopes.

328
00:20:46.749 --> 00:20:49.165
I know, and there's still so
much more to do, Ronnie.

329
00:20:49.165 --> 00:20:50.037
So, let's see.

330
00:20:50.037 --> 00:20:53.480
>> Remember that you said that certain
things override certain things.

331
00:20:53.480 --> 00:20:54.732
>> Yes.
>> So, go ahead and review that for us.

332
00:20:54.732 --> 00:20:56.090
>> Review that one, okay.

333
00:20:56.090 --> 00:20:59.370
>> And also, the idea of the class options
that you were just talking about and

334
00:20:59.370 --> 00:21:00.800
the server options.

335
00:21:00.800 --> 00:21:02.896
Make sure we have a good
understanding of that.

336
00:21:02.896 --> 00:21:07.288
So, tell us the order again, and
what it is that we're doing.

337
00:21:07.288 --> 00:21:11.231
>> Scope options take
precedence over server options.

338
00:21:11.231 --> 00:21:16.079
Meaning that whatever you configure for
an individual scope is gonna override what

339
00:21:16.079 --> 00:21:20.320
you may have already configured
server-wide for those options.

340
00:21:20.320 --> 00:21:23.880
However, if you create a specific,
like we just we did,

341
00:21:23.880 --> 00:21:25.685
we defined a user class option.

342
00:21:25.685 --> 00:21:30.100
That user class option is gonna
override both this server and

343
00:21:30.100 --> 00:21:32.960
the scope options for
that particular setting.

344
00:21:32.960 --> 00:21:37.820
>> All right, so that's actually going to
be important for the exam, once again.

345
00:21:37.820 --> 00:21:40.929
Because there are times when
you will end up seeing,

00:21:40.929 --> 00:21:45.532

maybe all three of the options set here.

347
00:21:45.532 --> 00:21:49.510
And say, hey, which one of

00:21:49.510 --> 00:21:51.920
You've got to understand
that order of precedence and

349
00:21:51.920 --> 00:21:53.260
the way that ends up working.

350
00:21:53.260 --> 00:21:55.540
Especially with the way that
these options are set up.

351
00:21:55.540 --> 00:21:57.650
If not,
you're gonna configure the wrong thing.

352
00:21:57.650 --> 00:22:00.550
Or you're not gonna actually have
the right one selected there.

353
00:22:00.550 --> 00:22:04.120
Cherokee showed us both where it was,
as well as that order and

354
00:22:04.120 --> 00:22:05.920
understanding of what's gonna be there.

355
00:22:05.920 --> 00:22:08.700
All right, so Cherokee,
we have just a few minutes left.

356
00:22:08.700 --> 00:22:10.520
What else are we taking a look at here?

00:22:10.520 --> 00:22:13.616
>> Ronnie, I think let's save it for

358

because we still have some extra

359
00:22:18.205 --> 00:22:20.912
And I think that would be a great

360
00:22:20.912 --> 00:22:21.739
>> All right, Cherokee.
Well,

361
00:22:21.739 --> 00:22:25.420
thank you again by helping us to

362
00:22:25.420 --> 00:22:28.439
Remember that what you took
a look at in this episode, right,

363
00:22:28.439 --> 00:22:32.348
is that we saw the different ways that
we can add in, well, additional scopes.

364
00:22:32.348 --> 00:22:35.300
Not only in the first episode
did we pick up on a GUI,

365
00:22:35.300 --> 00:22:39.700
where we could walk through the menu and

366
00:22:39.700 --> 00:22:42.757
Cherokee showed us in PowerShell,

00:22:42.757 --> 00:22:46.076
She also talked about the different

as well as understanding difference

369
00:22:49.017 --> 00:22:53.760
And even the idea of using these class

370

Pay attention,

371

00:23:02.170 --> 00:23:04.520

374
00:23:04.520 --> 00:23:09.082
So signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

375
00:23:09.082 --> 00:23:10.004

376
00:23:10.004 --> 00:23:15.755
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the MCSA 70-410 shows.

377
00:23:15.755 --> 00:23:21.422
[MUSIC]

378
00:23:21.422 --> 00:23:25.211
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: {Description}In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee take a look at configuring DHCP reservations, superscopes and backups.  Cherokee shows how to configure reservations using the GUI, powershell and netsh commands.  She also shows how to backup DHCP and restore the backup of the DHCP database.  Cherokee demonstrates how to configure a superscope for management.
episodes.title: Deploy and Configure DHCP Part 3

we're right in the middle of DHCP now, so-

The server doesn't maintain any

But with reservations there

So I wanted to show you a couple different

48

So let's see, if I just go ahead and

But I can put it in,

Yeah, so our unique identifier you

So in real life, of course,

I'd wanna make sure that that was that

And really, that's it and you just hit.

57
00:02:57.263 --> 00:03:00.538
Oops, excuse me, I hit,

Hit Close, and now you can see that that

Microsoft does give us some options here,

70
00:03:43.446 --> 00:03:47.320
If you're utilizing dynamic addressing for

71
00:03:47.320 --> 00:03:49.180
And we've already talked about printers.

72
00:03:49.180 --> 00:03:53.000
And if I set that up, and
the end users are trying to connect and

73
00:03:53.000 --> 00:03:56.580

with a configured printer.

74
00:03:56.580 --> 00:03:58.200
And the IP address is
changing all the time, well,

75
00:03:58.200 --> 00:03:59.449
they're not gonna be able to connect.

76
00:03:59.449 --> 00:04:03.605
You'll have to run around and reconfigure
all those printers all the time, and

77
00:04:03.605 --> 00:04:04.742
who wants to do that?

78
00:04:04.742 --> 00:04:06.420
That just sounds like a nightmare.

79
00:04:06.420 --> 00:04:10.210
So, hey, why don't we set
those IP addresses statically?

80
00:04:10.210 --> 00:04:11.790
Go ahead, create those reservations.

81
00:04:11.790 --> 00:04:15.810
We know what the IP address is and
we just have a better handle on things.

82
00:04:15.810 --> 00:04:20.920
As a matter of fact, really, talking about
printers, I love to simplify things.

83
00:04:22.110 --> 00:04:23.510
And I know this isn't a printer show,

84
00:04:23.510 --> 00:04:26.300

85
00:04:26.300 --> 00:04:31.270
Using DHCP to your advantage,
reducing the amount of variables, I guess,

86
00:04:31.270 --> 00:04:32.130

87
00:04:32.130 --> 00:04:36.470
So reduce a lot of different, if you have
the ability to a lot of different mix and

88
00:04:36.470 --> 00:04:39.280
models, keep it the same so
you have less driver issues.

89
00:04:39.280 --> 00:04:44.750
And even using DHCP, to number those

90
00:04:44.750 --> 00:04:49.150
So maybe one through ten from my
