00:18:52.015 --> 00:18:55.780
Any kind of reservations or
leases that you've set,

319
00:18:55.780 --> 00:18:58.670
all of those options that we've
talked about like that router,

320
00:18:58.670 --> 00:19:01.780
that special configuration and
that we had set there.

321
00:19:01.780 --> 00:19:04.810
And also registry keys and
other configuration examples.

322
00:19:04.810 --> 00:19:08.540
So, all that information is going to be
enclosed whenever you create that backup.

323
00:19:08.540 --> 00:19:09.900
So, that's pretty nice.

324
00:19:09.900 --> 00:19:13.020
If we wanted to perform
a test of that real quick,

325
00:19:13.020 --> 00:19:15.410
we could do that as well, let's see.

326
00:19:15.410 --> 00:19:18.430
If I go back into my
DHCP management console.

327
00:19:18.430 --> 00:19:22.763
And, lets just say, I was feeling crazy,
and I wasn't sure what I was doing and

328
00:19:22.763 --> 00:19:24.979
I just wanted to delete this scope here.

329
00:19:24.979 --> 00:19:26.290
I could do that, all right?

330
00:19:26.290 --> 00:19:28.860
So we're gonna delete scope number three.

331
00:19:28.860 --> 00:19:31.805
It asks me if I'm wanna go and
create that scope, I say yes.

332
00:19:31.805 --> 00:19:34.524
But then I realized,
Ronnie I made a mistake,

333
00:19:34.524 --> 00:19:37.880
I really didn't wanna
delete scope number three.

334
00:19:37.880 --> 00:19:41.669
So not a big deal,
as long as I created that backup,

335
00:19:41.669 --> 00:19:47.147
then all I have to do here, let me just
clear my screen I can hit my up arrow.

336
00:19:47.147 --> 00:19:50.580
And the only difference is
going to be instead of backup,

337
00:19:50.580 --> 00:19:53.450
let's just change that
to restore right here.

338
00:19:54.810 --> 00:19:56.620
And it should pull that change back in.

339
00:19:56.620 --> 00:19:57.762
And then we can test it, also.

340
00:20:00.431 --> 00:20:02.774
All right, now when it asks you,

341
00:20:02.774 --> 00:20:07.520
think about this from a production
environment perspective.

342
00:20:07.520 --> 00:20:09.326
We never really wanna be stopping and

343
00:20:09.326 --> 00:20:13.533
restarting coordinate work services within
an environment especially if I have to.

344
00:20:13.533 --> 00:20:16.510
Okay, let's see here.

345
00:20:16.510 --> 00:20:21.160
I'm gonna hit Yes, it's just asking me,
do I want to perform this restoration.

346
00:20:21.160 --> 00:20:23.510
But it's going to say, please restart.

347
00:20:23.510 --> 00:20:25.430
This is the one I was really looking for
here.

348
00:20:25.430 --> 00:20:27.934
Please restart the DHCP server.

349
00:20:27.934 --> 00:20:32.145
Now, restarting servers in
the production environment is something

350
00:20:32.145 --> 00:20:35.798
you really have to think about
to maintain with your up time.

351
00:20:35.798 --> 00:20:38.678
And you really don't have to restart,

352
00:20:38.678 --> 00:20:42.875
you just have to stop and
restart that DHCP service here.

353
00:20:42.875 --> 00:20:47.985
Because if you think about what if
maybe really it's not best practice,

354
00:20:47.985 --> 00:20:53.290
like we mentioned, to have a multi
function sever here running your DHCP.

355
00:20:53.290 --> 00:20:57.917
But maybe you're not financially
available to do that and

356
00:20:57.917 --> 00:21:00.661
have multiple dedicated severs.

357
00:21:00.661 --> 00:21:05.120
So you don't wanna disrupt any kind
of services that may be running.

358
00:21:05.120 --> 00:21:08.520
So let's check that before we
actually stop and restart there.

359
00:21:10.320 --> 00:21:11.874
Actually we need to do this first.

360
00:21:11.874 --> 00:21:13.582
Let's check the current state.

361
00:21:13.582 --> 00:21:18.264
So let's just do a get-service,
to get this DHCP service and

362
00:21:18.264 --> 00:21:21.154
see what's happening with it so far.

363
00:21:24.860 --> 00:21:26.527
All right, so
we can see that it's running.

364
00:21:26.527 --> 00:21:29.430
That's our current state
of our DHCP service.

365
00:21:29.430 --> 00:21:33.170
So what I wanna do is just instead
of performing a full restart,

366
00:21:33.170 --> 00:21:39.320
I'm gonna do Stop-Service and
again, that's going to be my DHCP.

367
00:21:39.320 --> 00:21:41.381
So we're just gonna
type in our DHCP server

368
00:21:47.092 --> 00:21:50.872
All right, you could also do the get
just to verify if you're, oops!

369
00:21:53.978 --> 00:21:58.410
If you're paranoid like me,
you can see that it is stopped right here.

370
00:21:58.410 --> 00:22:02.770
All right, and then again,
the next one to restart it is very simple.

371
00:22:02.770 --> 00:22:06.860
It's just Start-Service.

372
00:22:06.860 --> 00:22:09.390
Again you specify that DHCP server.

373
00:22:11.010 --> 00:22:14.060
All right and then again,
if you wanna double check that.

374
00:22:14.060 --> 00:22:16.504
Okay, so
it's waiting to go ahead and start.

375
00:22:16.504 --> 00:22:20.575
And then in the GUI, you just see
that little ancient clock that starts

376
00:22:20.575 --> 00:22:24.381
going through if you were to go
ahead stop and restart it that way.

377
00:22:27.486 --> 00:22:28.463
Let's just check it.

378
00:22:31.989 --> 00:22:33.765
We can see that it's running.

379
00:22:33.765 --> 00:22:37.640
So, I just like to check it to make
sure that what we're doing is actually

380
00:22:37.640 --> 00:22:38.490
working here.

381
00:22:38.490 --> 00:22:43.282
But if we go back into the graphical user
interface, you can see right from within

382
00:22:43.282 --> 00:22:47.596
that console and of course we will need
to go ahead and hit Refresh again.

383
00:22:50.206 --> 00:22:54.520
Let's expand out, or
zoom in, I should say.

384
00:22:54.520 --> 00:22:58.110
So there's that Superscope, but
look, there's Scope number 3.

385
00:22:58.110 --> 00:23:01.110
And that's the scope
that we had just deleted.

386
00:23:01.110 --> 00:23:06.438
By utilizing backups,
we were able to pull that scope right back

387
00:23:06.438 --> 00:23:12.271
in averting any kind of disaster or
potential firing type situation.

388
00:23:12.271 --> 00:23:15.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So, there you have it.

389
00:23:15.120 --> 00:23:18.840
Just a few quick things I wanted to
show at the end of this episode.

390
00:23:18.840 --> 00:23:22.660
But there are a couple other configuration
options that I would like to cover, so

391
00:23:22.660 --> 00:23:23.850
please stay tuned for them.

392
00:23:24.860 --> 00:23:28.949
All right, Cherokee, thank you again by
helping us out here and taking a look at

393
00:23:28.949 --> 00:23:32.854
some of these other options that we might
want to think about as we go ahead and

394
00:23:32.854 --> 00:23:34.399
continue to configure DHCP.

395
00:23:34.399 --> 00:23:38.457
There is more to come, but there's a lot
of great exam elements that we've just

396
00:23:38.457 --> 00:23:41.080
looked at, especially in this episode.

397
00:23:41.080 --> 00:23:44.180
So slow down and make sure you understand
those different components and

398
00:23:44.180 --> 00:23:48.660
those pieces to them, because you will
find them to be pretty much tested

399
00:23:48.660 --> 00:23:51.200
in more ways than you can actually think.

400
00:23:51.200 --> 00:23:55.110
All right, that's a great place for
us to go ahead and end this episode then.

401
00:23:55.110 --> 00:23:58.890
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong,

402
00:23:58.890 --> 00:23:59.950
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose

403
00:23:59.950 --> 00:24:01.424
>> Stay tuned right here for

404
00:24:01.424 --> 00:24:03.675
more of the MCSA 70-410 shows.

405
00:24:03.675 --> 00:24:11.243
[MUSIC]

406
00:24:11.243 --> 00:24:14.648
>> Thank you for watching ITPro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee examine some of the remaining DHCP configurations to be considered.  Cherokee reminds viewers of the order of precedence for options (Server, Scope, Class and Reserved), She describes the usage of PXE boot options in DHCP.  Lastly, she demonstrates and describes how to configure Server 2102 R2 for a DHCP Relay Agent.
episodes.title: Deploy and Configure DHCP Part 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.133
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.133 --> 00:00:05.883
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.883 --> 00:00:08.357
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.357 --> 00:00:12.432
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.432 --> 00:00:15.685
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:15.685 --> 00:00:19.690
You're watching the MCSA for
Windows Server 2012 R2.

7
00:00:19.690 --> 00:00:25.060
We're specifically focusing in on Exam
70-410, and I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:25.060 --> 00:00:28.759
Today, we're actually gonna part
four on configuring and, of course,

9
00:00:28.759 --> 00:00:30.680
making sure that we understand DHCP.

10
00:00:30.680 --> 00:00:33.720
You might be wondering how we're
actually going to do a little bit more.

11
00:00:33.720 --> 00:00:36.350
But here to explain what we're actually
gonna be doing is gonna be Ms.

12
00:00:36.350 --> 00:00:37.130
Cherokee Boose.

13
00:00:37.130 --> 00:00:38.370
Cherokee, welcome back to the show.

14
00:00:38.370 --> 00:00:39.680
>> Well, thank you for having me Ronnie.

15
00:00:39.680 --> 00:00:41.960
I know it seems like we've been
covering a lot here with DHCP,

16
00:00:41.960 --> 00:00:44.870
but that's because there's a lot to DHCP.

17
00:00:44.870 --> 00:00:45.810
And you know what?

18
00:00:45.810 --> 00:00:50.302
I think that for this show,
maybe this will be our last DHCP episode.

19
00:00:50.302 --> 00:00:52.768
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm not sure but either way,

20
00:00:52.768 --> 00:00:54.840
I wanted to do a quick recap.

21
00:00:54.840 --> 00:00:58.000
And then I wanted to introduce a couple of
more options that we can configure, and

22
00:00:58.000 --> 00:01:00.430
if you remember,
we did speak about options before.

23
00:01:00.430 --> 00:01:03.540
But I just wanna kinda go over those
one more time because I know it can be

24
00:01:03.540 --> 00:01:06.420
a little confusing if
it's brand new to you.

25
00:01:06.420 --> 00:01:11.280
And lastly there's a cool concept called
DHCP relay that I want to introduce and

26
00:01:11.280 --> 00:01:12.630
then show you how to configure it.

27
00:01:12.630 --> 00:01:14.200
So we do have a lot to do.

28
00:01:14.200 --> 00:01:15.840
Let's go ahead and get started.

29
00:01:15.840 --> 00:01:18.520
If you would mind joining
me here right in my screen.

30
00:01:18.520 --> 00:01:21.663
I have server one pulled up.

31
00:01:21.663 --> 00:01:23.669
And l have couple of
different scopes set up for

32
00:01:23.669 --> 00:01:26.460
the demonstration that we'll be
getting into in a few moments.

33
00:01:26.460 --> 00:01:29.840
But l just wanted to remind
you of the order of precedence

34
00:01:29.840 --> 00:01:32.550
that we were talking about
with our scope options here.

35
00:01:32.550 --> 00:01:35.004
So if you can recall,
we had four different levels.

36
00:01:35.004 --> 00:01:39.960
We had the server level, we had our scope
level, and then we also had our class and

37
00:01:39.960 --> 00:01:41.470
vendor level.

38
00:01:41.470 --> 00:01:44.990
Followed then by our
reserved client level,

39
00:01:44.990 --> 00:01:48.160
which is only achieved whenever
you create a reservation.

40
00:01:48.160 --> 00:01:50.160
And I can't remember if we covered that or
not.

41
00:01:50.160 --> 00:01:52.400
But it's okay if we look
at it one more time.

42
00:01:52.400 --> 00:01:55.000
So we'll look at it here
in this show as well.

43
00:01:55.000 --> 00:01:59.770
Because that order that I just said is
going to be the order of precedence.

44
00:01:59.770 --> 00:02:05.030
So what that means, Ronnie, if I start
up here with my server level, scope,

45
00:02:05.030 --> 00:02:09.370
and then I go down to those classes,
vendor or, all right, a client.

46
00:02:09.370 --> 00:02:11.280
And then I go down to the reservation.

47
00:02:11.280 --> 00:02:15.170
So if I have three
conflicting options prior to

48
00:02:15.170 --> 00:02:18.300
that fourth option down at the bottom for
my reserved client level.

49
00:02:19.350 --> 00:02:23.710
Those other three are gonna just be
washed out because it always goes down to

50
00:02:23.710 --> 00:02:26.910
the bottom there of that hierarchy,
if you think of it that way.

51
00:02:27.960 --> 00:02:30.010
If we ever have conflicting options,

52
00:02:30.010 --> 00:02:33.350
then the last one in that order is
going to go ahead and rule out.

53
00:02:33.350 --> 00:02:36.400
And if I can show you where those
options here are on the screen, just so

54
00:02:36.400 --> 00:02:37.700
that you are familiar.

55
00:02:37.700 --> 00:02:39.860
So the first one there for
the server level, so

56
00:02:39.860 --> 00:02:41.670
this is going to be your server options.

57
00:02:41.670 --> 00:02:45.040
And I'll just zoom in a little
bit there so you could see that.

58
00:02:45.040 --> 00:02:48.990
Whoa, that's huge, but
those are your Server Options there.

59
00:02:48.990 --> 00:02:53.430
And then, if we remember,
I'll try to zoom out a little bit.

60
00:02:53.430 --> 00:02:54.920
For our Scope Options,

61
00:02:54.920 --> 00:02:58.000
that will be next right here behind
my little magnifying glass there.

62
00:02:58.000 --> 00:02:59.960
But that's for the second order.

63
00:02:59.960 --> 00:03:06.850
And then remember if we right-click
on top of IPv4, this is that section.

64
00:03:06.850 --> 00:03:10.980
In the last show I think it is,
we actually, let's see,

65
00:03:10.980 --> 00:03:14.710
defined user class and
defined vendor class.

66
00:03:14.710 --> 00:03:18.170
Those are gonna be the, that is
the section where you will configure

67
00:03:18.170 --> 00:03:20.860
that tertiary, I said that right, yeah?

68
00:03:20.860 --> 00:03:24.068
>> Sure.
>> [LAUGH] That's the third level of

69
00:03:24.068 --> 00:03:25.880
precedence there.

70
00:03:25.880 --> 00:03:28.930
So that's where you'll go ahead and
set that, if that makes sense.

71
00:03:28.930 --> 00:03:33.570
And then the last one is
going to be reserved for

72
00:03:33.570 --> 00:03:35.850
reservations, no pun intended there.

73
00:03:35.850 --> 00:03:41.240
But if we can take a look here,
I have a scope and my ten dots go up here.

74
00:03:41.240 --> 00:03:44.110
I created a reservation for Ronnie's PC.

75
00:03:44.110 --> 00:03:46.420
And then if I right-click
on top of Ronnie's PC,

76
00:03:47.490 --> 00:03:51.460
this is going to be the section where
I can configure those options which

77
00:03:51.460 --> 00:03:55.360
ultimately override any of those previous
options that we just mentioned there.

78
00:03:55.360 --> 00:03:57.020
So just kind of keep that in mind.

79
00:03:57.020 --> 00:03:59.235
And that order of precedence
is pretty important there.

80
00:03:59.235 --> 00:04:02.128
There's a lot to think about with DHCP.

81
00:04:02.128 --> 00:04:06.873
But I wanted to talk about some
additional options that can really affect

82
00:04:06.873 --> 00:04:09.690
the way that the system Is running.

83
00:04:09.690 --> 00:04:11.424
And, Ronnie, with PXE boot,

84
00:04:11.424 --> 00:04:15.719
have you ever had to work with that in
a working environment setting that up?

85
00:04:15.719 --> 00:04:19.446
>> I have, in terms of PXE boot
there's a lot of times where when

86
00:04:19.446 --> 00:04:23.285
you're trying to do the idea
of Windows Deployment Servers.

87
00:04:23.285 --> 00:04:23.930
>> Right.
>> And

88
00:04:23.930 --> 00:04:25.790
you need to actually be able to do that,

89
00:04:25.790 --> 00:04:28.980
PXE boot is one of the best
ways to get that all set up.

90
00:04:28.980 --> 00:04:31.910
If you don't have an operating
system existing on the machines

91
00:04:31.910 --> 00:04:34.070
that you want to deploy
an operating system to.

92
00:04:34.070 --> 00:04:37.050
>> It's pretty convenient, a lot of
companies are using it these days.

93
00:04:37.050 --> 00:04:38.690
So if we just look at the acronym there,

94
00:04:38.690 --> 00:04:41.410
that's going to be your
pre-execution environment.

95
00:04:41.410 --> 00:04:45.390
Meaning I can have a computer, a laptop,

96
00:04:45.390 --> 00:04:50.385
a VOIP phone, some device that does not
require any kind of integrated hardware,

97
00:04:50.385 --> 00:04:53.520
well, some hardware but
not like a hard drive.

98
00:04:53.520 --> 00:04:56.600
I'm getting my boot information
from another source.

99
00:04:56.600 --> 00:04:58.480
So in that situation that you explained,
Ronnie,

100
00:04:58.480 --> 00:05:00.080
you were using
a Windows Deployment Server,

101
00:05:00.080 --> 00:05:03.130
which is a really common
Microsoft implementation.

102
00:05:03.130 --> 00:05:06.420
But there is something that we do need to
configure in order to set that up, and

103
00:05:06.420 --> 00:05:09.170
it's right here within our DHCP options.

104
00:05:09.170 --> 00:05:12.690
Now depending on exactly
how you set that up.

105
00:05:12.690 --> 00:05:16.600
So for instance, if I just go under my
Server Options here, there may be a couple

106
00:05:16.600 --> 00:05:20.770
different instances where you
need to select different options.

107
00:05:20.770 --> 00:05:22.330
But for right now,

108
00:05:22.330 --> 00:05:27.260
what I want to show is just how to
set this up in a normal situation.

109
00:05:27.260 --> 00:05:32.432
Because if I'm gonna be configuring with
my PXE boot and DHCP to be on separate

110
00:05:32.432 --> 00:05:38.336
servers, then we have to configure remote
boot servers to communicate with port 67.

111
00:05:38.336 --> 00:05:42.504
The DHCP server must not
include server option 60,

112
00:05:42.504 --> 00:05:46.890
if your PXE boot and
your DHCP are on the same server.

113
00:05:46.890 --> 00:05:48.680
So that just might be a slight difference.

114
00:05:48.680 --> 00:05:52.180
If you're setting it up a little bit
differently, it just depends on where your

115
00:05:52.180 --> 00:05:57.870
DHCP is residing versus the actual
PXE server, that PXE point there.

116
00:05:57.870 --> 00:05:59.680
So in my situation,

117
00:05:59.680 --> 00:06:03.210
what I wanna make sure I have configured,
there are two options here.

118
00:06:03.210 --> 00:06:05.615
And the first is going to be option 66.

119
00:06:05.615 --> 00:06:08.530
And let me just scroll down and
find that one.

120
00:06:08.530 --> 00:06:11.660
And I'll need to put a little
bit of information in

121
00:06:11.660 --> 00:06:12.780
in order to go ahead and do that.

122
00:06:12.780 --> 00:06:13.850
We're getting there here.

123
00:06:13.850 --> 00:06:16.540
All right, I didn't wanna go
too far past and miss it.

124
00:06:16.540 --> 00:06:20.150
So what I could put here, and
let me zoom in so you can see that.

125
00:06:20.150 --> 00:06:24.260
For our string value I'm gonna
need to put in the name of

126
00:06:24.260 --> 00:06:26.920
my Windows Deployment Server or
the IP address here.

127
00:06:26.920 --> 00:06:32.421
So if I just put in something random,
we could say .100,

128
00:06:32.421 --> 00:06:35.550
all right, and then hit OK.

129
00:06:35.550 --> 00:06:39.940
The next option that I would also
need to configure here will be 67.

130
00:06:39.940 --> 00:06:42.071
So let me just go ahead and
pull that up and

131
00:06:42.071 --> 00:06:44.336
show you what that would
look like as well.

132
00:06:46.459 --> 00:06:48.987
Scrolling, there we go.

133
00:06:48.987 --> 00:06:50.345
Now for the string value for

134
00:06:50.345 --> 00:06:54.910
this particular one we're gonna be putting
something a little more specific here.

135
00:06:54.910 --> 00:06:58.780
I need to really reference
that actual image file for

136
00:06:58.780 --> 00:07:01.470
whatever operating system or
image that I'm using here.

137
00:07:01.470 --> 00:07:04.131

left click it and then right click.

359
00:20:31.800 --> 00:20:33.120
Let's see here.

360
00:20:33.120 --> 00:20:37.610
That is just going to be under,
one more thing I forgot to do first.

361
00:20:37.610 --> 00:20:43.350
We do need to go ahead, and expand out,
and create that actual protocol.

362
00:20:43.350 --> 00:20:44.759
So expand out IPv4.

363
00:20:44.759 --> 00:20:48.660
That's all I did right here was just
click that little arrow or caret.

364
00:20:48.660 --> 00:20:52.635
So on our General option underneath IPv4,
let's go ahead and

365
00:20:52.635 --> 00:20:55.944
right click and
then specify New Routing Protocol.

366
00:20:55.944 --> 00:21:02.750
We wanna ensure that we have
DHCP Relay Agent selected here.

367
00:21:02.750 --> 00:21:05.630
This is the routing protocol
we'll be adding and we'll hit OK.

368
00:21:06.630 --> 00:21:12.230
Now note over on the left hand pane,
my DHCP Relay Agent option appeared,

369
00:21:12.230 --> 00:21:16.650
so let's left click on that and
then right click and select New Interface.

370
00:21:19.100 --> 00:21:22.710
Now from the Options, you can see
the Interfaces that this machine,

371
00:21:22.710 --> 00:21:24.780
the server currently has enabled, and

372
00:21:24.780 --> 00:21:28.630
if you think back to the diagram
that we had spoke about before,

373
00:21:28.630 --> 00:21:34.600
the inside interface, that pink interface
is what we're gonna be selecting here.

374
00:21:34.600 --> 00:21:40.080
And just thinking about that logic, with
the client calling out trying to connect

375
00:21:40.080 --> 00:21:46.330
to the DHCP server, and the other, the ten
dot network, this is the listening or

376
00:21:46.330 --> 00:21:51.150
the interface that would be
receiving those DHCP packets.

377
00:21:51.150 --> 00:21:53.320
So that's what we wanna
make sure is selected here.

378
00:21:54.448 --> 00:21:59.254
We'll hit OK and
if we take a look at this option,

379
00:21:59.254 --> 00:22:05.603
you always wanna make sure that
the DHCP packets box is enabled.

380
00:22:05.603 --> 00:22:08.127
I mean, that's what we're
really working with here, so

381
00:22:08.127 --> 00:22:10.530
we need to make sure
that that is selected.

382
00:22:10.530 --> 00:22:14.822
And then we also have the ability to
increase or decrease our hop-counts.

383
00:22:14.822 --> 00:22:18.200
So hop-counts, if you recall
back when you were learning or

384
00:22:18.200 --> 00:22:22.930
even working with routing,
when we're traversing either interface,

385
00:22:22.930 --> 00:22:25.420
router, those are considered
our hops there.

386
00:22:25.420 --> 00:22:29.300
So depending on the topology of your
network, you may want to increase or

387
00:22:29.300 --> 00:22:33.940
decrease depending on how many hops that
packet will need to go through before it

388
00:22:33.940 --> 00:22:35.840
eventually reaches that DHCP server.

389
00:22:36.960 --> 00:22:40.220
As well as our boot threshold
listed here in seconds, but

390
00:22:40.220 --> 00:22:41.566
I'm just going to keep the defaults.

391
00:22:41.566 --> 00:22:44.160
And we'll hit OK.

392
00:22:44.160 --> 00:22:48.000
And the next thing you need to
do is specify the IP address

393
00:22:48.000 --> 00:22:52.510
of the DHCP server/servers that
you're trying to communicate with.

394
00:22:52.510 --> 00:22:57.130
So let's right click on top of DHCP
Relay Agent, and then go to Properties.

395
00:22:58.230 --> 00:23:02.600
In this diagram,
I only have one DHCP server running and

396
00:23:02.600 --> 00:23:05.900
offering that service, so
let's go ahead and put that IP address in.

397
00:23:05.900 --> 00:23:07.477
That is going to be 10.1.0.10.

398
00:23:07.477 --> 00:23:09.895
We'll make sure we hit Add, so

399
00:23:09.895 --> 00:23:15.300
it moves down to the second portion
right here and then we'll hit OK.

400
00:23:17.000 --> 00:23:18.700
And really that's it, Ronnie.

401
00:23:18.700 --> 00:23:21.690
I mean, it's not too difficult
to go ahead and set up.

402
00:23:21.690 --> 00:23:26.120
But let's hop on over to our client to
just verify that we can obtain the correct

403
00:23:26.120 --> 00:23:30.630
IP address from the scope,
the 192 scope there, so.

404
00:23:30.630 --> 00:23:31.240
>> Sounds good.

405
00:23:31.240 --> 00:23:32.590
>> All right.

406
00:23:32.590 --> 00:23:36.110
Let's go over to our
Windows 10 Client here, and

407
00:23:36.110 --> 00:23:37.570
I'll just pull up a Command prompt.

408
00:23:40.380 --> 00:23:45.360
And let's see what we've
got here currently.

409
00:23:45.360 --> 00:23:51.058
All right, so It's already got a 192,
and we can even do a release and a renew

410
00:23:51.058 --> 00:23:57.410
with IP configure to verify that this is,
in fact, getting the proper IP address.

411
00:23:57.410 --> 00:23:59.755
But let me just zoom in so
you guys can see that.

412
00:23:59.755 --> 00:24:02.660
This is 192.168.43.128, and

413
00:24:02.660 --> 00:24:06.800
that is within the specified
scope that we were looking for.

414
00:24:06.800 --> 00:24:11.810
Now, what we really don't wanna see
in this situation obviously would be

415
00:24:11.810 --> 00:24:14.730
that good old APIPA address because
then we would know something with our

416
00:24:14.730 --> 00:24:18.490
configuration didn't go according to plan,
and that we need to kind of retrace steps.

417
00:24:18.490 --> 00:24:20.360
>> Now Cherokee, look, let's verify this.

418
00:24:20.360 --> 00:24:22.930
Let's do an IP config on,
that way we get this stamp.

419
00:24:22.930 --> 00:24:23.579
>> Okay.
>> And

420
00:24:23.579 --> 00:24:25.837
then that way when we
actually do the release and

421
00:24:25.837 --> 00:24:28.020
renew we'll actually see it come in for
us.

422
00:24:28.020 --> 00:24:29.120
>> With the timestamp?

423
00:24:29.120 --> 00:24:30.180
>> Right, yeah.

424
00:24:30.180 --> 00:24:32.800
>> All right,
let's make that a little bit bigger here.

425
00:24:34.690 --> 00:24:36.350
>> So if you'll scroll up towards the top.

426
00:24:36.350 --> 00:24:38.948
>> I see.

427
00:24:38.948 --> 00:24:39.935
>> Little bit, there you go.

428
00:24:39.935 --> 00:24:40.640
>> There we go.

429
00:24:40.640 --> 00:24:44.735
>> August, there it is,
Tuesday August 15th, and there you go and

430
00:24:44.735 --> 00:24:47.680
there's your sticker note and time.

431
00:24:47.680 --> 00:24:49.518
>> So you know it's fresh and
new and it's not [INAUDIBLE].

432
00:24:49.518 --> 00:24:51.130
>> Right, so let's try it again.

433
00:24:51.130 --> 00:24:52.700
>> Okay.
>> And see what happens.

434
00:24:52.700 --> 00:24:55.580
Okay, so at this point right?

435
00:24:55.580 --> 00:24:59.320
What Cherokee's actually gonna do for
us is just an IP config release and renew,

436
00:24:59.320 --> 00:25:02.920
and that will disconnect her
from the DHCP server and

437
00:25:02.920 --> 00:25:06.675
manually start the DORA process over
again, or at least we think it will.

438
00:25:06.675 --> 00:25:08.362
[LAUGH]
>> That's the goal here.

439
00:25:08.362 --> 00:25:09.012
>> So here we go yeah.

440
00:25:09.012 --> 00:25:09.671
>> All right.

441
00:25:09.671 --> 00:25:10.894
>> Cherokee.

442
00:25:10.894 --> 00:25:12.051
>> What did I say?

443
00:25:12.051 --> 00:25:13.984
>> Let's see, did you use-
>> ipconfig /renew,

444
00:25:13.984 --> 00:25:15.538
let's go to second here.

445
00:25:15.538 --> 00:25:22.127
Let's specify network NBC block is in use.

446
00:25:22.127 --> 00:25:23.325
Let's try that one more time.

447
00:25:25.600 --> 00:25:26.423
>> Let's see.

448
00:25:29.771 --> 00:25:31.020
There we go.

449
00:25:31.020 --> 00:25:33.297
I think you were faster
than the actual computer.

450
00:25:33.297 --> 00:25:35.080
>> Yeah,
I have to give it a second there, but-

451
00:25:35.080 --> 00:25:35.857
>> There you go.

452
00:25:35.857 --> 00:25:37.892
>> But we can see the IP address, and

453
00:25:37.892 --> 00:25:42.280
if I were to do the space forward
slash all again, oops it's not renew.

454
00:25:42.280 --> 00:25:45.901
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH] That way we get the timestamp and

455
00:25:45.901 --> 00:25:47.416
should update.

456
00:25:47.416 --> 00:25:48.290
>> Right, yeah.
>> And there goes yup,

457
00:25:48.290 --> 00:25:51.690
it updated about a few minutes later,
is what we see.

458
00:25:51.690 --> 00:25:53.090
Just a couple of minutes later.

459
00:25:53.090 --> 00:25:55.630
So we see it's actually
working in real time.

460
00:25:55.630 --> 00:25:58.866
And this is an important concept when you
do have those multiple sub-nests, but

461
00:25:58.866 --> 00:26:02.790
you only have a single DHCP server,
and it's got to be able to reply to

462
00:26:02.790 --> 00:26:06.600
all of those different DHCP
requests that are out there.

463
00:26:06.600 --> 00:26:08.870
So it's a handy technology to understand,
and

464
00:26:08.870 --> 00:26:11.480
it is something that you'll
see tested on the exam.

465
00:26:11.480 --> 00:26:15.240
So it's something that you definitely
need to at least experience, and

466
00:26:15.240 --> 00:26:17.900
get into labs, and
be able to set up for us too.

467
00:26:17.900 --> 00:26:20.218
>> All right,
I think that's about it, Ronnie.

468
00:26:20.218 --> 00:26:22.520
That's the end of our DHCP journey.

469
00:26:22.520 --> 00:26:23.355
It's been a long one.

470
00:26:23.355 --> 00:26:26.101
Hopefully, you guys have enjoyed it,
but we do have some more information in

471
00:26:26.101 --> 00:26:28.790
the upcoming shows that
you don't want to miss.

472
00:26:28.790 --> 00:26:31.630
>> All right, Cherokee thank you again for
helping us to understand a few more of

473
00:26:31.630 --> 00:26:34.630
the ideas of the options that
we have to deal with, and

474
00:26:34.630 --> 00:26:38.100
of course even setting up
the idea of the DHCP real agent.

475
00:26:38.100 --> 00:26:40.910
These are all important concepts
that you'll see tested, so

476
00:26:40.910 --> 00:26:44.360
do not just go,
hey I'm not gonna worry about this.

477
00:26:44.360 --> 00:26:47.540
You'll be surprised that DHCP is one of
those core technologies that you need to

478
00:26:47.540 --> 00:26:49.850
learn about for Windows Server 2012.

479
00:26:49.850 --> 00:26:54.190
Well there's more to come on the course
exam 70-410, but that ends it for

480
00:26:54.190 --> 00:26:55.560
this episode.

481
00:26:55.560 --> 00:26:59.600
Signing off for ItProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

482
00:26:59.600 --> 00:27:00.660
>> And I'm Cherokee Boost.

483
00:27:00.660 --> 00:27:03.875
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the exam 70-410 shows.

484
00:27:03.875 --> 00:27:11.679
[MUSIC].

485
00:27:11.679 --> 00:27:14.523
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.003 --> 00:00:07.916
[INAUDIBLE]

2
00:00:07.916 --> 00:00:10.896

3
00:00:10.896 --> 00:00:11.894
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:11.894 --> 00:00:14.530
>> Welcome ladies and
gentlemen to your 70-410 series.

5
00:00:14.530 --> 00:00:17.680
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.680 --> 00:00:21.030
In this episode we'll be taking
a look at how to install DNS.

7
00:00:21.030 --> 00:00:23.810
One of our core network services.

8
00:00:23.810 --> 00:00:27.370
And back with us today in the studios
we have Mr Mike Rodrick, thank you for

9
00:00:27.370 --> 00:00:28.530
joining us Mike how is it going?

10
00:00:28.530 --> 00:00:30.810
>> It's going fantastic
Cherokee glad to back and

11
00:00:30.810 --> 00:00:33.970
glad to be here on our great topic too.

12
00:00:33.970 --> 00:00:37.210
>> I know you are like on a roll
here with some really good topics.

13
00:00:37.210 --> 00:00:40.120
>> We are yes you do all my favorites
they invite me here to do that.

14
00:00:40.120 --> 00:00:42.440
The active directory and
now to do the DNS.

15
00:00:42.440 --> 00:00:44.162
Hopefully I'll get OUs and group policy.

16
00:00:44.162 --> 00:00:46.859
>> [LAUGH]
>> And just round out my week, I love it.

17
00:00:46.859 --> 00:00:50.510
All right so yes we are going
to be talking about DNS today or

18
00:00:50.510 --> 00:00:55.040
domain name service or domain name
system depending on who you talk to.

19
00:00:55.040 --> 00:00:59.870
And it is, it truly is one of my
favorites because it's again one

20
00:00:59.870 --> 00:01:04.560
of those core services that
really everything else relies on,

21
00:01:04.560 --> 00:01:07.985
when you talk about all these other
services that people get excited about.

22
00:01:07.985 --> 00:01:12.450
>> [LAUGH]
>> Exchange and SQL and SharePoint or

23
00:01:12.450 --> 00:01:13.660
all of that stuff.

24
00:01:13.660 --> 00:01:14.915
>> Things we can do without perhaps.

25
00:01:14.915 --> 00:01:17.490
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah things we can do without,

26
00:01:17.490 --> 00:01:22.000
things we are always working
on ends up relying on DNS.

27
00:01:22.000 --> 00:01:26.790
Alright, I mean, everything we do from
checking your email to buying products at

28
00:01:26.790 --> 00:01:30.490
your favorite online retailer-
>> Yay!

29
00:01:30.490 --> 00:01:35.280
>> To logging in [LAUGH] to your computer
at work to connecting to a file share,

30
00:01:35.280 --> 00:01:37.900
I mean, everything relies on DNS.

31
00:01:37.900 --> 00:01:41.440
And so it's a very important service
to make sure that we have running,

32
00:01:41.440 --> 00:01:45.710
and to make sure it's performing well and
it's fun.

33
00:01:45.710 --> 00:01:48.540
I think that's probably why I like it.

34
00:01:48.540 --> 00:01:50.550
And its been around for
a long time and its not new, and

35
00:01:50.550 --> 00:01:52.730
its not a Microsoft thing.

36
00:01:52.730 --> 00:01:56.560
Microsoft calls their service DNS Service,
but DNS is a,

37
00:01:56.560 --> 00:02:00.845
domain name services is a-
>> Universally accepted it's just,

38
00:02:00.845 --> 00:02:01.613
it's out there.

39
00:02:01.613 --> 00:02:06.620
>> Microsoft has a habit of doing that,
you like to brand their stuff with

40
00:02:06.620 --> 00:02:11.610
some of the key terms like the,
SQL is not a Microsoft thing,

41
00:02:11.610 --> 00:02:15.080
it's structured query language, but
they have their SQL server which is here.

42
00:02:15.080 --> 00:02:18.950
So just so we understand, there
are other choices, like we have Bind.

43
00:02:18.950 --> 00:02:23.360
Gosh now I can't remember,
Berkeley internet name daemon.

44
00:02:23.360 --> 00:02:26.540
Yeah, so blanked there for a second.

45
00:02:26.540 --> 00:02:27.660
You know, for another-
>> For

46
00:02:27.660 --> 00:02:30.930
the Nicks base system's
an alternative to DNS.

47
00:02:30.930 --> 00:02:31.530
>> Probably.

48
00:02:31.530 --> 00:02:33.360
>> Well, it's not an alternative to DNS.

49
00:02:33.360 --> 00:02:34.040
It is DNS.

50
00:02:34.040 --> 00:02:36.440
It's just a different
implementation style.

51
00:02:36.440 --> 00:02:37.540
>> Exactly.
>> Not Microsoft.

52
00:02:37.540 --> 00:02:40.820
>> And it's probably more common on the
web than Microsoft, honestly, you know,

53
00:02:40.820 --> 00:02:46.370
because a lot of our internet services
are using Linux and they're running fine.

54
00:02:46.370 --> 00:02:50.690
But in corporate environments where we're
running a Microsoft world, very, very,

55
00:02:50.690 --> 00:02:53.580
common to be using DNS
that comes with Microsoft.

56
00:02:53.580 --> 00:02:58.790
Because it's a role that gets
installed free, and it works.

57
00:02:58.790 --> 00:03:02.250
That's what we're here
to talk about today.

58
00:03:02.250 --> 00:03:04.620
So we're gonna start just
by getting it installed.

59
00:03:04.620 --> 00:03:05.970
I'm gonna kind of switch things up.

60
00:03:05.970 --> 00:03:10.050
Normally I would talk all about DNS and
give you all this back ground and

61
00:03:10.050 --> 00:03:12.090
break everything down for you and
then we take a look at it.

62
00:03:12.090 --> 00:03:14.330
We're gonna try something
a little different today.

63
00:03:14.330 --> 00:03:15.145
>> Shaking it up.
>> We are.

64
00:03:15.145 --> 00:03:17.280
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're gonna live on the edge here and

65
00:03:17.280 --> 00:03:20.750
we're gonna get it installed so
that we can see what we have and

66
00:03:20.750 --> 00:03:25.930
then talk about it, cuz I think sometimes
with DNS that might be a little easier

67
00:03:25.930 --> 00:03:30.260
than talking about zones and caching and
forwarding and all those other stuff.

68
00:03:30.260 --> 00:03:34.890
Without really even seeing DNS, which
some of you might not have seen DNS yet.

69
00:03:34.890 --> 00:03:37.510
So that's what we're going to do.

70
00:03:37.510 --> 00:03:42.210
So let's talk about, first and foremost,
let's do some basic terminology though.

71
00:03:42.210 --> 00:03:45.010
We do need to understand what it is and
why we're doing it, right?

72
00:03:45.010 --> 00:03:49.620
So DNS is a name resolution service.

73
00:03:49.620 --> 00:03:54.550
It resolves, for the most part,
names into IP addresses.

74
00:03:54.550 --> 00:03:55.470
Now when I say names,

75
00:03:55.470 --> 00:04:00.320
we do want to make sure we're clear
it's fully qualified domain names.

76
00:04:00.320 --> 00:04:03.980
And remember what that is, hopefully
we remember this from Network Plus,

77
00:04:03.980 --> 00:04:06.580
when we talk about a computer,
the computer has a name,

78
00:04:06.580 --> 00:04:10.125
like my computer's name is I wanna
tell you what my laptop's name is?

79
00:04:10.125 --> 00:04:13.190
>> [LAUGH]
>> See?

80
00:04:13.190 --> 00:04:17.000
>> It's Dagobah, so if you're a Star Wars
fan, you'll know where I'm coming from.

81
00:04:17.000 --> 00:04:19.480
Otherwise, you're going, what a geek.

82
00:04:19.480 --> 00:04:22.530
But my computer's name is Dagobah,
so it has a name.

83
00:04:22.530 --> 00:04:24.360
But that's not it's full name.

84
00:04:24.360 --> 00:04:29.420
If it belongs to a domain,
like here we have ITPro.TV.

85
00:04:29.420 --> 00:04:35.690
And so when my computer's part of that
domain I have Dagobah as its hostname,

86
00:04:35.690 --> 00:04:41.650
and then I have the .itpro.tv
as its DNS suffix.

87
00:04:41.650 --> 00:04:46.510
And when we plug those two together,
we get what's called the FQDN, or

88
00:04:46.510 --> 00:04:49.710
fully qualified domain name, right?

89
00:04:49.710 --> 00:04:52.270
You can almost think of it
like first name and last name.

90
00:04:52.270 --> 00:04:54.250
Like we do in humans.

91
00:04:54.250 --> 00:04:58.164
You have Dagobah would be his first name.

92
00:04:58.164 --> 00:05:02.110
.ITpro.itv would be its
last name if you will.

93
00:05:02.110 --> 00:05:06.740
And I like that analogy because
all of the computers in my domain

94
00:05:06.740 --> 00:05:07.766
share the same last name.

95
00:05:07.766 --> 00:05:11.930
Just like all the people in my
household share the same last name, but

96
00:05:11.930 --> 00:05:15.510
we each have a unique first name
to differentiate between us.

97
00:05:15.510 --> 00:05:19.540
And computers typically have to
have a unique name on the network.

98
00:05:19.540 --> 00:05:21.280
And then we plug those together.

99
00:05:21.280 --> 00:05:23.000
My first name is Mike.

100
00:05:23.000 --> 00:05:26.000
But my full name is,
do I say that on camera?

101
00:05:26.000 --> 00:05:27.960
Michael Darren Rodrick.

00:14:01.390 --> 00:14:03.510
That's a forward look up.

00:14:03.510 --> 00:14:06.601
A reverse look up then

00:14:06.601 --> 00:14:09.627
I know the IP address, I need the name.

00:14:35.280 --> 00:14:36.910

In computer worlds, sometimes services use

00:14:41.260 --> 00:14:46.170

When DNS receives this question,

If the name that I'm asking about

But the primary ones we're gonna start
with are A records and quad A records.

331
00:16:45.610 --> 00:16:50.360
An A record is an IPV for
name to IP address mapping.

00:16:50.360 --> 00:16:53.760
It's a primary DNS resource record type.

333
00:16:53.760 --> 00:16:55.640
It's typically what we want.

Although now we're dealing with IPv6,
we have quad a.

The name drives me crazy,
Cherokee, I don't know about you.

A-A-A-A records?

reasoning behind that, and

I can't remember off

It has to do with the bits, yeah.

00:17:11.905 --> 00:17:17.077

00:17:17.077 --> 00:17:17.725

>> You get four As.

>> I have to go A-A-A-A record?

All right, so there's only two As in

00:18:04.505 --> 00:18:08.584
All right, so in our database,
we're gonna create these resource records.

00:18:08.584 --> 00:18:10.376
A records for IPv4 addresses.

00:18:10.376 --> 00:18:14.972
They would map
dagaba.itpro.tv To 10.1.2.3.

368
00:18:14.972 --> 00:18:21.584
There would be a quad A record that
says hey, .itpro.tv is actually,

369
00:18:21.584 --> 00:18:26.928
gosh if I could even make up one,
FE80ABC12341234.

370
00:18:26.928 --> 00:18:30.720
An IPv6 address, 128 bits.

371
00:18:30.720 --> 00:18:33.670
There, so
those are the two main resource records.

372
00:18:33.670 --> 00:18:36.570
But, when we create those, and there's
lots more, we're gonna talk about them.

373
00:18:36.570 --> 00:18:38.230
But when we create those resource records,

374
00:18:38.230 --> 00:18:43.420
they're stored in DNS in what's
called a zone file, all right.

375
00:18:43.420 --> 00:18:50.145
A zone file is a portion of the overall
name space of the internet, all right.

376
00:18:50.145 --> 00:18:53.626
And, while we'll, kind of,
come back to that concept in a minute, for

377
00:18:53.626 --> 00:18:55.840
now, let's just focus on our company.

378
00:18:55.840 --> 00:19:01.860
Right, my company in my brand
machines here is lab.itpro.tv.

379
00:19:01.860 --> 00:19:07.090
So, if we go and look at my domain
controller that we installed and

380
00:19:07.090 --> 00:19:10.740
I take a look, I'm gonna open
up my DNS console, right, so

381
00:19:10.740 --> 00:19:16.110
DNS, and
if I look at my forward look up zones.

382
00:19:16.110 --> 00:19:20.884
I will see a zone file for lab.itpro.tv.

383
00:19:20.884 --> 00:19:26.769
All right, this is a database where I
can store all the resource records for

384
00:19:26.769 --> 00:19:32.281
all the computers and other devices
that need these kind of records for

385
00:19:32.281 --> 00:19:35.848
anybody whose name ends in lab.itpro.tv.

386
00:19:35.848 --> 00:19:39.946
Right, that's what a zone file is for,
a specific portion of the name space.

387
00:19:39.946 --> 00:19:41.974
In this case lab.itpro.tv.

388
00:19:41.974 --> 00:19:42.987
So when we look in here,

389
00:19:42.987 --> 00:19:45.593
I can see the different computers
that make up this network.

390
00:19:45.593 --> 00:19:52.403
DC01.lab.itpro.tv, DC08,
Serv01, Core01, Client01.

391
00:19:52.403 --> 00:19:55.761
Now there's other records, we'll talk
about those in just a minute, but

392
00:19:55.761 --> 00:19:57.209
these you notice are A records.

393
00:19:57.209 --> 00:20:02.396
And if I double click on this A record for
DC01 and I can see there's his name,

394
00:20:02.396 --> 00:20:07.273
there's the fully qualified domain
name easywand.lab.itpro.tv and

395
00:20:07.273 --> 00:20:09.460
there's the IP address.

396
00:20:09.460 --> 00:20:11.450
So if someone calls up this DNS server and

397
00:20:11.450 --> 00:20:16.630
says hey what's the IP
address of dc01.lab.itpro.tv?

398
00:20:16.630 --> 00:20:21.353
All he has to do is look at this
a record and go it's 10.10.8.200 and

399
00:20:21.353 --> 00:20:23.655
he can return the response, all right.

400
00:20:23.655 --> 00:20:26.830
Well that is how we're
going to resolve names and

401
00:20:26.830 --> 00:20:28.927
this is what we call a zone five.

402
00:20:28.927 --> 00:20:32.456
>> So Mike, some of us may be sitting here
wondering well where did these records

403
00:20:32.456 --> 00:20:33.010
come from?

404
00:20:33.010 --> 00:20:34.742
Is this something that's
automatically generated?

405
00:20:34.742 --> 00:20:36.366
Can I create new records?

406
00:20:36.366 --> 00:20:37.270
How does that work?

407
00:20:37.270 --> 00:20:39.102
>> That's a greay question, let's look.

408
00:20:39.102 --> 00:20:44.840
We can create them or they can be created
dynamically, which is really what we want.

409
00:20:44.840 --> 00:20:48.028
All of these you see in here
with these time stamps,

410
00:20:48.028 --> 00:20:50.189
these were created dynamically.

411
00:20:50.189 --> 00:20:53.896
My two domain controllers do have
static ones, we don't like changing

412
00:20:53.896 --> 00:20:57.252
the IP address of domain controllers,
usually not a good idea.

413
00:20:57.252 --> 00:21:01.418
But the time-stamped ones,
those were created dynamically.

414
00:21:01.418 --> 00:21:06.034
So, when this server joined the domain,
the second thing he did

415
00:21:06.034 --> 00:21:10.668
after joining the domain,
was call the DNS, and say, hey DNS.

416
00:21:10.668 --> 00:21:14.042
You're responsible for
lab.itpro.tv, right?

417
00:21:14.042 --> 00:21:16.308
You've got one of those own files for
them.

418
00:21:16.308 --> 00:21:18.920
Well, I'm a new member of lab.itpro.tv.

419
00:21:18.920 --> 00:21:23.982
My name is Server01, and
my IP address is 10.10.8.201.

420
00:21:23.982 --> 00:21:25.698
Can you make an A record for me so

421
00:21:25.698 --> 00:21:28.810
that other people can find me
if they are looking for me?

422
00:21:28.810 --> 00:21:30.550
That's name registration.

423
00:21:30.550 --> 00:21:34.800
The machine is automatically
registering his IP address with DNS,

424
00:21:34.800 --> 00:21:40.720
which is really what we want but there are
times we need to create our own records.

425
00:21:40.720 --> 00:21:44.970
Like we could manually create
alias records for example.

426
00:21:44.970 --> 00:21:48.220
So before we do that,
well let's go ahead and create one and

427
00:21:48.220 --> 00:21:49.790
then we'll come back to it.

428
00:21:49.790 --> 00:21:56.754
All right, just for giggles, I'm going to
take a look at server one is 10.10.8.201.

429
00:21:56.754 --> 00:22:01.161
That is this guy right over here
that we'd just installed DNS on.

430
00:22:01.161 --> 00:22:06.033
I'm gonna open up the command prompt
on this domain controller and

431
00:22:06.033 --> 00:22:07.948
I'm gonna ping svr01.

432
00:22:07.948 --> 00:22:11.800
And notice what it did
a couple of things here.

433
00:22:11.800 --> 00:22:15.224
The first thing it did was it took
that name that I typed in and

434
00:22:15.224 --> 00:22:17.911
turned it into a fully
qualified domain name.

435
00:22:17.911 --> 00:22:21.984
Because you can't just ask DNS what's
the IP address of Mike, right?

436
00:22:21.984 --> 00:22:23.543
Or what's the IP address of Server01?

437
00:22:23.543 --> 00:22:25.133
You can't use just the first name.

438
00:22:25.133 --> 00:22:31.350
You have to include the full name, because
there might be a Server 1 in lab.itpro.tv.

439
00:22:31.350 --> 00:22:35.830
But there also might be
a server01 in training.itpro.tv.

440
00:22:35.830 --> 00:22:40.113
And if you just say server01, how does
it know which one you're referring to?

441
00:22:40.113 --> 00:22:44.559
So you have to use a fully qualified
domain name so it can find the DNS server

442
00:22:44.559 --> 00:22:49.520
that holds the zone file for that
namespace so it can look up that name.

443
00:22:49.520 --> 00:22:54.426
That server that holds that zone file is
known as the authoritative server for

444
00:22:54.426 --> 00:22:58.364
that zone because he is the one
that actually has the records.

445
00:22:58.364 --> 00:23:03.482
He can look in his database and
say this is the IP address of Server01.

446
00:23:03.482 --> 00:23:06.538
I know that because I'm looking
at the record right now, right?

447
00:23:06.538 --> 00:23:11.091
So he is considered authoritative if he
holds the zone file, the DNS server is.

448
00:23:11.091 --> 00:23:13.725
So we turned it into a fully
qualified domain name, and

449
00:23:13.725 --> 00:23:17.408
then it resolved in the name
into an IP address, 10.10.8.201.

450
00:23:17.408 --> 00:23:20.999
And then it pinged That IP address
because we didn't ping the name,

451
00:23:20.999 --> 00:23:24.152
computers can't connect to names,
only to IP addresses.

452
00:23:24.152 --> 00:23:28.546
>> Which is a great way if you remember
from like those COMPTIA classes or

453
00:23:28.546 --> 00:23:31.442
any kind of other
fundamental type courses.

454
00:23:31.442 --> 00:23:34.221
And you're looking at that and
if you didn't get that return,

455
00:23:34.221 --> 00:23:37.737
that IP address then it would be a good
indication that something within your DNS

456
00:23:37.737 --> 00:23:39.011
wasn't working properly.

457
00:23:39.011 --> 00:23:42.519
And you could continue to troubleshoot
by trying to ping that IP address

458
00:23:42.519 --> 00:23:43.340
specifically.

459
00:23:43.340 --> 00:23:44.360
And if you got a response,

460
00:23:44.360 --> 00:23:47.740
you knew that machine was up,
the communication was happening, and

461
00:23:47.740 --> 00:23:51.222
that would be a clue as to go ahead and
investigate a little bit further.

462
00:23:51.222 --> 00:23:54.381
>> Yeah it could be DNS is not working,
if you can ping it by IP address but

463
00:23:54.381 --> 00:23:54.989
not by name.

464
00:23:54.989 --> 00:23:56.814
>> Right.
>> Something is preventing you from

465
00:23:56.814 --> 00:24:00.053
resolving that into a name, either on
your client end or On the DNS end, or

466
00:24:00.053 --> 00:24:02.423
in a network in between,
but definitely something.

467
00:24:02.423 --> 00:24:07.476
All right, so let's make a record,
cuz that's what Cherokee wanted to do.

468
00:24:07.476 --> 00:24:11.647
So we are gonna right click on here,
when you right click in the zone, so

469
00:24:11.647 --> 00:24:15.204
I've gone to lab.ITPro.TV,
and I'm gonna right click.

470
00:24:15.204 --> 00:24:19.794
You'll see that I have a few options
right here on my menu, New Host (A or

471
00:24:19.794 --> 00:24:24.632
AAAA) New Alias, Mail Exchanger, but
that's the only three I get there.

472
00:24:24.632 --> 00:24:27.666
Let's talk about the other
records as well while we're here,

473
00:24:27.666 --> 00:24:29.620
at least the ones they cover on the exam.

474
00:24:29.620 --> 00:24:34.231
So we talked about A and AAAA,
those are named IP address,

475
00:24:34.231 --> 00:24:36.970
IPv4 and IPv6, respectively.

476
00:24:38.330 --> 00:24:41.680
NS records, which I don't see on this
list, let's go away from this list for

477
00:24:41.680 --> 00:24:43.300
a second, here's a couple.

478
00:24:43.300 --> 00:24:47.513
NS are name server records,
these are how you find

479
00:24:47.513 --> 00:24:53.249
the authoritative DNS server,
who is the DNS server for this zone?

480
00:24:53.249 --> 00:24:56.770
That's an NS record, or
a name server record.

481
00:24:56.770 --> 00:25:02.830
There's also MX records, which I don't
have here, MX are mail exchanger records.

482
00:25:02.830 --> 00:25:07.000
So when you're trying to find your
mailbox server, you would query DNS for

483
00:25:07.000 --> 00:25:08.130
the MX records.

484
00:25:09.640 --> 00:25:12.715
SRV records are service locator records,

485
00:25:12.715 --> 00:25:17.260
now those, we talked about when
we did our Active Directory.

486
00:25:17.260 --> 00:25:22.232
But SRV records, and notice I'm still
in my zone, I'm gonna go down to TCP.

487
00:25:22.232 --> 00:25:26.090
They're in several places,
I'm just using TCP as an example.

488
00:25:26.090 --> 00:25:29.065
SRV records are service locator records,
and

489
00:25:29.065 --> 00:25:33.090
these allow me to find what computer
is running a particular service.

490
00:25:33.090 --> 00:25:34.610
I might wanna log in, so

491
00:25:34.610 --> 00:25:38.876
I call up DNS and I say, hey,
which servers are running Kerberos, right?

492
00:25:38.876 --> 00:25:42.981
Cuz that's my authentication
protocol that I wanna use.

493
00:25:42.981 --> 00:25:47.841
And DNS will look for an SRV record,
Keberos, Keberos, here's two.

494
00:25:47.841 --> 00:25:50.561
Let's see who's running Kerberos,

495
00:25:50.561 --> 00:25:56.010
it looks like DC08 is running Kerberos,
and DC01 is running Kerberos.

496
00:25:56.010 --> 00:25:58.620
So I've got two servers that have SRV

497
00:25:58.620 --> 00:26:01.120
records saying that
they're running Kerberos.

498
00:26:01.120 --> 00:26:05.862
Important thing to note right here,
when we look at this record,

499
00:26:05.862 --> 00:26:10.883
notice that this SRV record says,
this server is running Kerberos.

500
00:26:10.883 --> 00:26:17.932
What do you not see in this dialogue box,
think about it for a second.

501
00:26:17.932 --> 00:26:19.666
>> Time stamp information.

502
00:26:19.666 --> 00:26:22.380
>> No,
I don't see time stamp information, but

503
00:26:22.380 --> 00:26:26.150
the other thing I don't see
is an IP address, right?

504
00:26:26.150 --> 00:26:32.640
There's no IP address in here,
SRV records do not map IP addresses.

505
00:26:32.640 --> 00:26:37.160
SRV records map services to
fully qualified domain names.

506
00:26:37.160 --> 00:26:39.260
So when you look up an SRV record,

507
00:26:39.260 --> 00:26:42.220
it returns a host that's
offering the service.

508
00:26:42.220 --> 00:26:45.060
It says, if you're looking for Kerberos,
here's the guy that's running Kerberos.

509
00:26:45.060 --> 00:26:48.274
That still doesn't do me any good,
I can't connect to a name,

510
00:26:48.274 --> 00:26:50.080
I have to have an IP address.

511
00:26:50.080 --> 00:26:53.760
So once I get that response,
I then have to query DNS and say, okay,

512
00:26:53.760 --> 00:26:58.740
you told me DC01 is running Kerberos,
what's DC01's IP address?

513
00:26:58.740 --> 00:27:01.615
And then DNS says, well,
if you want the IP address,

514
00:27:01.615 --> 00:27:05.168
let me just do a standard lookup,
DC01 is 10.10.8.200.

515
00:27:05.168 --> 00:27:09.310
So SRV records point me to the name of
the server that's offering the service.

516
00:27:09.310 --> 00:27:13.350
But then I still have to take that
name and turn it into an IP address.

517
00:27:13.350 --> 00:27:17.529
Just make sure you understand that,
that's an easy test question gotcha.

518
00:27:17.529 --> 00:27:21.615
Cuz when we talk about DNS, we're normally
talking about name to IP address.

519
00:27:21.615 --> 00:27:25.774
SRV records are a little different,
they map service to name, and

520
00:27:25.774 --> 00:27:28.460
then we still have to
go name to IP address.

521
00:27:28.460 --> 00:27:32.575
[COUGH] All right,
last type of record I wanna point out, and

522
00:27:32.575 --> 00:27:35.080
this is by far not all-inclusive.

523
00:27:35.080 --> 00:27:39.480
There are dozens of other record types we
can work with, but those are the main ones

524
00:27:39.480 --> 00:27:42.090
we wanna focus on while we're
getting started in Windows here.

525
00:27:43.260 --> 00:27:47.530
The last one I wanna talk about is
something known as PTR records.

526
00:27:47.530 --> 00:27:50.560
I don't have any in here cuz I
don't have a reverse lookup zone.

527
00:27:50.560 --> 00:27:53.556
Remember, I told you, reverse lookup
zones are actually optional, and

528
00:27:53.556 --> 00:27:54.583
I haven't created one.

529
00:27:54.583 --> 00:27:58.601
Although we will here in just a minute,
I keep saying that, why don't we do it?

530
00:27:58.601 --> 00:28:03.690
Because we don't know anything about new
zones yet, let's not jump too far ahead.

531
00:28:03.690 --> 00:28:08.090
So reverse lookup zones would
map IP addresses back to names.

532
00:28:08.090 --> 00:28:11.977
So it's gonna look very similar to
an A record, except it's opposite, right.

533
00:28:11.977 --> 00:28:15.745
You're gonna have an IP address, and
you're gonna map it back to a name.

534
00:28:15.745 --> 00:28:18.531
The IP address is listed reverse,
though, and

535
00:28:18.531 --> 00:28:20.976
I'll show you what I mean in a little bit.

536
00:28:20.976 --> 00:28:25.456
Because it goes from most specific,
well, the network address is at the end.

537
00:28:25.456 --> 00:28:27.048
>> Yeah, it's definitely different, and

538
00:28:27.048 --> 00:28:29.514
it's definitely a good thing to
look at and be able to identify.

539
00:28:29.514 --> 00:28:31.786
Because you might see that again
in something in the future too.

540
00:28:31.786 --> 00:28:35.786
>> Absolutely, and so
we'll create one here, in just a minute,

541
00:28:35.786 --> 00:28:38.890
I know we're getting
a little bit short on time.

00:28:38.890 --> 00:28:41.566
Let me just make sure, so
we've talked about zones,

543
00:28:41.566 --> 00:28:44.365
we've talked about forward and
reverse lookup zones.

544
00:28:44.365 --> 00:28:47.992
We've talked about our resource records,
and

00:28:47.992 --> 00:28:51.264
we installed DNS, we saw that over there.

546
00:28:51.264 --> 00:28:54.855
I wanna finish this off talking

00:28:54.855 --> 00:29:00.230
Because I said that a zone is

00:29:00.230 --> 00:29:04.120
it's a part of a database, if you will.

00:29:04.120 --> 00:29:07.649
But there's more than one type

550
00:29:07.649 --> 00:29:09.890
when we create a new zone within DNS.

551
00:29:09.890 --> 00:29:15.472
I'm gonna flip over to my brand new
installed server that we just did.

552
00:29:15.472 --> 00:29:19.413
I'm gonna right click on forward lookup
zones, and I'm gonna choose New Zone.

553
00:29:19.413 --> 00:29:22.810
One, notice I don't have
any zones by default, okay,

554
00:29:22.810 --> 00:29:27.672
that's something you wanna keep in mind
[COUGH] with a non-domain controller.

555
00:29:27.672 --> 00:29:30.620
And we'll kind of see what I
mean by that as we go here.

556
00:29:30.620 --> 00:29:35.923
So here's my New Zone Wizard, I'm gonna
click Next, and then I get this choice.

557
00:29:35.923 --> 00:29:41.230
Do I want primary, do I want secondary,
or do I want stub zones?

558
00:29:41.230 --> 00:29:45.740
And grayed out is,
store this zone in Active Directory,

559
00:29:45.740 --> 00:29:51.328
available only if the DNS server is on
a writable domain controller, all right?

560
00:29:51.328 --> 00:29:53.907
So that one's out of
the question in this case,

561
00:29:53.907 --> 00:29:57.851
because it's not on a domain controller,
this is just a member server.

562
00:29:57.851 --> 00:30:01.120
So let's talk about these first three
here, well, at least the first two.

563
00:30:01.120 --> 00:30:04.233
We'll probably come back to stub zones
cuz that's a little bit of an oddball.

564
00:30:04.233 --> 00:30:09.030
But it's a very cool zone, but
it's not what we normally deal with.

565
00:30:09.030 --> 00:30:15.510
So a primary zone is a what we call
a read/write copy of a zone file.

566
00:30:15.510 --> 00:30:16.408
So all that means is,

567
00:30:16.408 --> 00:30:20.280
it's a zone file, just like you saw for
ITPro.tv on my other server.

568
00:30:20.280 --> 00:30:25.023
And it can store resource records, and
we can make changes, it's a writable copy.

569
00:30:25.023 --> 00:30:28.948
So we can update existing records,
we can create new records,

570
00:30:28.948 --> 00:30:33.181
we can delete records,
it's a writable copy, so let's make one.

571
00:30:33.181 --> 00:30:37.676
Let's right click on here,
we'll go primary,

572
00:30:37.676 --> 00:30:43.660
I'll click Next, and
we'll call this dev.lab.itpro.tv.

573
00:30:43.660 --> 00:30:46.660
We'll just get really crazy with
the name here, or let's not go that far,

574
00:30:46.660 --> 00:30:51.220
let's just go dev.itpro.tv.

575
00:30:51.220 --> 00:30:56.902
We'll click Next, and then do I want to
create a new file with this file name?

576
00:30:56.902 --> 00:30:59.271
Well, yes, I need somewhere, the database,

577
00:30:59.271 --> 00:31:03.830
I need somewhere to actually store these
records that we're going to be creating.

578
00:31:03.830 --> 00:31:08.090
If I already had a file, if I was
rebuilding a DNS server and I had a backup

579
00:31:08.090 --> 00:31:11.400
of the old zone file, I could have
copied that over to this machine.

580
00:31:11.400 --> 00:31:14.530
And then said, no, use an existing file,
and just pointed to it.

581
00:31:14.530 --> 00:31:17.182
But I don't have one yet, so
we're gonna create a new one.

582
00:31:17.182 --> 00:31:21.331
Notice it adds the .dns to the end of it,
all right.

583
00:31:21.331 --> 00:31:26.921
We'll click Next, and then here,
do I want to allow both nonsecure and

584
00:31:26.921 --> 00:31:31.591
secure dynamic updates, or
do not allow dynamic updates?

585
00:31:31.591 --> 00:31:36.317
Notice my option for secure only is grayed
out, that's only available on domain

586
00:31:36.317 --> 00:31:39.952
controllers, but
we'll come back to that concept, right?

587
00:31:39.952 --> 00:31:42.410
Both nonsecure and

588
00:31:42.410 --> 00:31:46.240
secure, only reason I get to chose this
is because nonsecure is an option.

589
00:31:46.240 --> 00:31:49.570
I can't do secure updates
with a standard primary,

590
00:31:49.570 --> 00:31:52.580
or I could not allow dynamic updates.

591
00:31:52.580 --> 00:31:55.515
There are times when you want to
use that option, like if you've got

592
00:31:55.515 --> 00:31:59.139
an Internet-facing DNS server, you might
be creating all the records manually.

593
00:31:59.139 --> 00:32:03.058
And you don't want anybody attempting to
connect to it, and make their own records.

594
00:32:03.058 --> 00:32:06.111
Cuz they could be using that as
a form of an attack against you or

595
00:32:06.111 --> 00:32:08.650
your organization or somebody else.

596
00:32:08.650 --> 00:32:11.630
So there are times when you choose
do not allow dynamic updates.

597
00:32:11.630 --> 00:32:12.580
More often than not, though,

598
00:32:12.580 --> 00:32:16.686
if it's internal I want the clients to
be able to register their own records.

599
00:32:16.686 --> 00:32:20.510
I don't wanna have to manually create
records because that's when typos occur,

600
00:32:20.510 --> 00:32:23.050
duplication occurs, this causes problems.

601
00:32:23.050 --> 00:32:26.060
We have human related errors and
we don't like those.

602
00:32:26.060 --> 00:32:26.840
>> Dang those humans.

603
00:32:26.840 --> 00:32:28.072
>> Yeah I know, we're so crazy.

604
00:32:28.072 --> 00:32:29.210
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so

605
00:32:29.210 --> 00:32:33.350
I'm gonna choose Allow both nonsecure and
secure, I'll click Next, and

606
00:32:33.350 --> 00:32:37.690
Finish, and there we go,
I have a new zone dev.itpro.tv.

607
00:32:37.690 --> 00:32:41.080
We'll talk about the records
we find in here in a minute.

608
00:32:41.080 --> 00:32:42.810
And I know Cherokee is giving me the eye.

609
00:32:42.810 --> 00:32:44.640
It looks like I can't go any faster.

610
00:32:44.640 --> 00:32:45.780
We're just gonna have to come back.

611
00:32:45.780 --> 00:32:48.170
>> It's okay, I forgot to give
you like the five minute warning.

612
00:32:48.170 --> 00:32:50.122
So I have to give him
like an extra five here.

613
00:32:50.122 --> 00:32:52.784
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Okay, do [CROSSTALK].

614
00:32:52.784 --> 00:32:53.356
>> Yeah.

615
00:32:53.356 --> 00:32:54.990
[LAUGH]
>> All right, all right.

616
00:32:54.990 --> 00:32:57.230
Let's keep waking these zones then.

617
00:32:57.230 --> 00:32:59.350
So here's our standard primary.

618
00:32:59.350 --> 00:33:00.590
This is our read, write copy.

619
00:33:00.590 --> 00:33:05.680
And just to show you I could come in
here and create a new A record test.

620
00:33:05.680 --> 00:33:09.820
Notice it fills in the DEV.IT.PROTV
because that's the zone I'm in.

621
00:33:09.820 --> 00:33:12.100
So everything in here has to end in that.

622
00:33:12.100 --> 00:33:13.030
So there's no choice.

623
00:33:13.030 --> 00:33:16.960
You just type in the host name and
then it fills in the rest for you.

624
00:33:16.960 --> 00:33:21.180
And I'll just make up something,
10, 10, 8, 155.

625
00:33:21.180 --> 00:33:22.450
I don't think that's any use.

626
00:33:22.450 --> 00:33:26.110
I could create a PTR record
automatically right here,

627
00:33:26.110 --> 00:33:27.970
if I had a reverse lookup zone.

628
00:33:27.970 --> 00:33:32.880
It would make a record that says,
this IP address maps back to this FQDN.

629
00:33:32.880 --> 00:33:38.050
But I don't, so I'm gonna click Add Host,
I'll click OK, and then Done.

630
00:33:38.050 --> 00:33:41.690
And now we'll see that I have
a new a record in there.

631
00:33:41.690 --> 00:33:45.270
So this is the writeable copy of the zone.

632
00:33:45.270 --> 00:33:48.730
All right, now I'm gonna create a,

633
00:33:48.730 --> 00:33:54.210
how can I do this without getting
too far ahead of you guys?

634
00:33:55.720 --> 00:33:57.490
Let's create a secondary.

635
00:33:57.490 --> 00:33:59.990
It's not gonna let me without a master.

636
00:33:59.990 --> 00:34:02.140
We haven't really talked about that.

637
00:34:02.140 --> 00:34:04.290
Let me go over my domain controller.

638
00:34:07.150 --> 00:34:11.360
And I'll make another zone over here
cuz eventually we'll make this work.

639
00:34:11.360 --> 00:34:14.480
It's not gonna work at first for
certain reasons, but

640
00:34:14.480 --> 00:34:15.740
we'll come back and we'll explain why.

641
00:34:15.740 --> 00:34:19.730
So I'm gonna say New Zone, Next.

642
00:34:19.730 --> 00:34:22.270
This time, I'm gonna choose Secondary.

643
00:34:23.380 --> 00:34:25.490
And I'll click Next.

644
00:34:25.490 --> 00:34:31.166
And my zone name is gonna be dev.itpro.tv.

645
00:34:31.166 --> 00:34:34.730
I'll click Next.

646
00:34:34.730 --> 00:34:37.230
And then my master 10.10.8.201.

647
00:34:37.230 --> 00:34:43.390
I'll talk about what the heck
this is in just a minute.

648
00:34:43.390 --> 00:34:44.430
Well, I hate doing that.

649
00:34:44.430 --> 00:34:47.310
How much time did you say I had?

650
00:34:47.310 --> 00:34:50.960
>> I'm gonna have to be
the Debbie Downer now, yeah.

651
00:34:50.960 --> 00:34:52.610
>> No, okay.

652
00:34:52.610 --> 00:34:54.960
All right, we'll leave you right there.

653
00:34:54.960 --> 00:34:56.430
>> It's a cliff hanger, yeah.

654
00:34:56.430 --> 00:34:57.080
>> A cliff hanger.

655
00:34:57.080 --> 00:34:57.640
I like it.

656
00:34:57.640 --> 00:34:59.270
>> Okay, all right, Mike.

657
00:34:59.270 --> 00:35:00.309
Thank you for joining us today.

658
00:35:00.309 --> 00:35:04.228
And thank you for joining us as well, but
you definitely don't want to miss this

659
00:35:04.228 --> 00:35:07.811
upcoming episode because then you'll
never know what that was, yeah.

660
00:35:07.811 --> 00:35:08.316
[LAUGH]
>> That's right.

661
00:35:08.316 --> 00:35:09.100
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] But for

662
00:35:09.100 --> 00:35:12.120
now we'll go ahead and sign out,
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

663
00:35:12.120 --> 00:35:12.920
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

664
00:35:12.920 --> 00:35:17.854
>> See you next time here on ITPRO.TV.

665
00:35:17.854 --> 00:35:21.650
[MUSIC]

666
00:35:21.650 --> 00:35:24.638
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.title: Install DNS Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.480 --> 00:00:04.030
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:04.030 --> 00:00:06.340
I am you host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.340 --> 00:00:08.038
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.038 --> 00:00:11.699
>> You are watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.699 --> 00:00:13.693
>> Welcome to your 70-410 series.

6
00:00:13.693 --> 00:00:16.700
I am your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:16.700 --> 00:00:20.600
This is a part two, in the last episode,
Mike was in the studios with us,

8
00:00:20.600 --> 00:00:23.740
he showed how to go ahead and
install and start configuring, and

9
00:00:23.740 --> 00:00:28.080
looking at different types of records
within the DNS management console.

10
00:00:28.080 --> 00:00:33.050
And we're able to get him back in studios
today to help cover this topic and, well,

11
00:00:33.050 --> 00:00:35.700
you left us with a cliffhanger, Mike,
so what are we looking at there?

12
00:00:35.700 --> 00:00:38.530
>> Hopefully, everybody came back
to see what the heck is gonna

13
00:00:38.530 --> 00:00:40.010
happen with that wizard.

14
00:00:40.010 --> 00:00:42.270
Yes, and thank you for having me back.

15
00:00:42.270 --> 00:00:43.070
>> Yeah.

16
00:00:43.070 --> 00:00:45.240
>> And yes,
we're gonna just dive right back in.

17
00:00:45.240 --> 00:00:47.830
We left off at part one,

18
00:00:47.830 --> 00:00:52.710
we had created a standard primary zone,
which was a read, write zone.

19
00:00:52.710 --> 00:00:54.470
We were able to create new records.

20
00:00:54.470 --> 00:00:56.020
And now I'm on a different DNS server,

21
00:00:56.020 --> 00:01:00.140
actually, the domain controller,
creating a standard secondary zone.

22
00:01:00.140 --> 00:01:01.760
And we're going through the wizard, and so

23
00:01:01.760 --> 00:01:05.780
if you look at my screen here, I'll just
back up real quick to refresh this, right?

24
00:01:05.780 --> 00:01:09.420
All we did was say, I created a standard,
or a secondary zone.

25
00:01:09.420 --> 00:01:14.800
I'm going to click next,
I give it a zone name.

26
00:01:14.800 --> 00:01:17.750
Now, I think, and then I click next and

27
00:01:17.750 --> 00:01:20.860
then we put the IP address
of what the master is.

28
00:01:20.860 --> 00:01:22.020
I'll go ahead and finish it and

29
00:01:22.020 --> 00:01:25.540
then I'm going to explain all this
stuff that we're looking at here.

30
00:01:25.540 --> 00:01:30.170
I'll click Next and
Finish and now I have a zone.

31
00:01:30.170 --> 00:01:33.840
And it tells me the zone is
not loaded by DNS server.

32
00:01:33.840 --> 00:01:36.600
It encountered a problem while
attempting to load the zone.

33
00:01:36.600 --> 00:01:39.990
So let's talk about this
secondary zone for a second.

34
00:01:39.990 --> 00:01:42.060
I'm gonna pull up the Properties here.

35
00:01:42.060 --> 00:01:45.400
Actually I think we can
look at some of this,

36
00:01:45.400 --> 00:01:47.300
actually it's not going to help us at all.

37
00:01:47.300 --> 00:01:51.270
So I'm going to close properties, but
here's the thing, with standard primaries,

38
00:01:51.270 --> 00:01:54.260
and understand that, gosh when was it?

39
00:01:54.260 --> 00:01:58.150
2003, I think that we got active
directory integrated zones.

40
00:01:58.150 --> 00:02:01.940
There's a third type of zone known as
active directory integrated zones.

41
00:02:01.940 --> 00:02:04.960
But before we had those
standard primary and secondary.

42
00:02:04.960 --> 00:02:08.760
As you see in the wizard, they're actually
just called primary and secondary.

43
00:02:08.760 --> 00:02:12.420
A lot of us refer to him
as standard zones cuz,

44
00:02:12.420 --> 00:02:15.260
once we got Active Directory integrated,
we had to differentiate somehow.

45
00:02:15.260 --> 00:02:17.090
So those were just standard zones.

46
00:02:17.090 --> 00:02:20.150
But a primary zone is a read, write copy.

47
00:02:20.150 --> 00:02:21.890
And, this was our main zone file.

48
00:02:21.890 --> 00:02:23.570
This was where we put all
the resource records.

49
00:02:23.570 --> 00:02:28.250
This is where clients dynamically
registered, and when I say client,

50
00:02:28.250 --> 00:02:32.430
keep in mind I'm referring to DNS client,
not client operating system.

51
00:02:32.430 --> 00:02:36.080
Anybody that uses DNS is
a client of that service.

52
00:02:36.080 --> 00:02:40.490
So a member server that needs to look
up a name is a DNS client, right?

53
00:02:40.490 --> 00:02:42.470
It's using a service so it's a client.

54
00:02:42.470 --> 00:02:45.460
So when I say client,
don't think client operating systems.

55
00:02:45.460 --> 00:02:49.280
But a standard primary is where we
put all those resource records.

56
00:02:49.280 --> 00:02:51.310
And when you need to resolve a name,
you call it up.

57
00:02:51.310 --> 00:02:54.860
If you needed to modify a record,
if a client's IP address changed,

58
00:02:54.860 --> 00:02:58.640
if we had dynamic updates, it could call
up DNS and say hey, my name's Server01.

59
00:02:58.640 --> 00:03:03.190
My IP address is now 10.10.8.202,
can you update my record?

60
00:03:03.190 --> 00:03:07.818
Because it's primary, a read,
write copy, we can make those changes.

61
00:03:07.818 --> 00:03:11.110
But the downsides of those primary
zones was I can only have one.

62
00:03:12.210 --> 00:03:13.840
And that's never good, right?

63
00:03:13.840 --> 00:03:16.600
We always talk about fall tolerance and

64
00:03:16.600 --> 00:03:20.160
any time you have one of something that
becomes a single point of failure.

65
00:03:20.160 --> 00:03:23.750
And if that server goes down,
we've said how important DNS is and

66
00:03:23.750 --> 00:03:25.560
how everything relies on it.

67
00:03:25.560 --> 00:03:29.330
Just simply logging in without
DNS isn't gonna work, so

68
00:03:29.330 --> 00:03:34.330
your whole business stops if that
DNS server goes down, right?

69
00:03:34.330 --> 00:03:37.320
So we definitely want more than one, but

70
00:03:37.320 --> 00:03:41.140
the problem is I can only
have one writable copy,

71
00:03:41.140 --> 00:03:46.590
because if I have two writable copies
now I can run into replication issues.

72
00:03:46.590 --> 00:03:51.390
What if I'm on one server updating server
01's resource record to it's new IP

73
00:03:51.390 --> 00:03:56.630
address, Cherokee's on the other writable
DNS server updating the same record?

74
00:03:56.630 --> 00:03:59.340
Now, when those two servers replicate and
she put a different IP address.

75
00:03:59.340 --> 00:04:03.550
She thought they were changing it to do a
3, I thought they were changing it to 202.

76
00:04:03.550 --> 00:04:06.740
So, we've made entries on these two
DNS servers to the same record, but

77
00:04:06.740 --> 00:04:07.840
they don't agree.

78
00:04:07.840 --> 00:04:10.760
When replication occurs,
which one are they gonna keep?

79
00:04:10.760 --> 00:04:11.880
>> The last.

80
00:04:11.880 --> 00:04:12.858
>> Well, so
we gotta throw one of them away.

81
00:04:12.858 --> 00:04:14.886
>> [LAUGH]
>> That means we're losing data, and

82
00:04:14.886 --> 00:04:18.340
most likely it's the last update,
exactly, is gonna win.

83
00:04:18.340 --> 00:04:20.868
So because I work slower than Cherokee,
I win.

84
00:04:20.868 --> 00:04:23.120
>> [LAUGH] Woo hoo.

85
00:04:23.120 --> 00:04:24.980
>> So that’s a problem.

86
00:04:24.980 --> 00:04:29.520
We can only have one, but one leaves
me with a single point of failure, but

87
00:04:29.520 --> 00:04:33.820
that’s the reason we can only have one
because of replication conflicts, and

88
00:04:33.820 --> 00:04:36.220
there was no built in
way to deal with that.

89
00:04:36.220 --> 00:04:41.630
So the solution was, hey I’m going to let
you have more copies of that zone file.

90
00:04:41.630 --> 00:04:45.170
You can have other servers host
copies of the zone file, but

91
00:04:45.170 --> 00:04:46.670
they're going to have
to be read only copies.

92
00:04:46.670 --> 00:04:49.050
That's where the secondary zone is.

93
00:04:49.050 --> 00:04:53.490
A secondary is a read only
copy of a primary zone.

94
00:04:53.490 --> 00:04:56.900
And so now,
I have multiple copies of the zone file.

95
00:04:56.900 --> 00:05:01.480
I can have one secondary,
two secondaries, ten secondaries.

96
00:05:01.480 --> 00:05:05.460
Whatever I needed for performance or
fault tolerance, I could do.

97
00:05:05.460 --> 00:05:09.820
Still only one primary, but
as many secondaries as I wanted, right?

98
00:05:09.820 --> 00:05:11.810
Cuz they are read only.

99
00:05:11.810 --> 00:05:15.590
Now, downside about that,
is if the primary fails,

100
00:05:15.590 --> 00:05:17.050
the secondary is just still there.

101
00:05:17.050 --> 00:05:20.340
And if somebody wants to look up
something, they got a copy of the database

102
00:05:20.340 --> 00:05:23.240
and they can look up the name,
return the IP address, no problem.

103
00:05:23.240 --> 00:05:24.858
Business going on as usual.

104
00:05:24.858 --> 00:05:26.410
>> But what if a change happens?

105
00:05:26.410 --> 00:05:27.223
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

106
00:05:27.223 --> 00:05:28.880
that's going to be an issue, right?

107
00:05:28.880 --> 00:05:31.380
We just said it's a read only copy.

108
00:05:31.380 --> 00:05:32.940
So what if an update needs to be made?

109
00:05:32.940 --> 00:05:34.910
What if a new computer
has joined the domain and

110
00:05:34.910 --> 00:05:37.160
it wants to register its name in DNS?

111
