342
00:17:41.710 --> 00:17:46.146
here's my choice I get to choose
what the replication scope is.

343
00:17:46.146 --> 00:17:50.750
Because we're storing this with Active
Directory, I have more than one domain

344
00:17:50.750 --> 00:17:53.938
controller, always have at least two
domain controller most likely many more.

345
00:17:53.938 --> 00:17:57.270
And domain controllers replicate
that Active Directory database.

346
00:17:57.270 --> 00:18:00.570
Again, there's three partitions they
replicate slightly differently,

347
00:18:00.570 --> 00:18:02.035
there's your domain partition.

348
00:18:02.035 --> 00:18:04.960
Which replicates within the domain,
there's

349
00:18:04.960 --> 00:18:09.430
the schema partition which replicates to
all domain controllers in the domain.

350
00:18:09.430 --> 00:18:10.620
>> You've got, schema.

351
00:18:10.620 --> 00:18:11.690
So that was-
>> No,

352
00:18:11.690 --> 00:18:16.210
it's the domain schema-
>> Directory root, forest root,

353
00:18:16.210 --> 00:18:19.010
directory partition,
configuration directory partition, and-

354
00:18:19.010 --> 00:18:20.363
>> The configuration partition,

355
00:18:20.363 --> 00:18:22.223
that was the third partition, there we go.

356
00:18:22.223 --> 00:18:26.110
The three main partitions, there are more
but the three main partitions schema,

357
00:18:26.110 --> 00:18:27.850
configuration and domain.

358
00:18:27.850 --> 00:18:31.942
Domain stores your domain specific
objects, schema stores the schema,

359
00:18:31.942 --> 00:18:34.054
the definition for all your objects.

360
00:18:34.054 --> 00:18:37.576
And then configuration stores
configuration about the forest,

361
00:18:37.576 --> 00:18:41.186
its biology, what domain controllers
exist, things like that.

362
00:18:41.186 --> 00:18:45.470
[COUGH] Excuse me, when we create
Active Directory integrated,

363
00:18:45.470 --> 00:18:47.422
we're just gonna create another partition.

364
00:18:47.422 --> 00:18:50.340
We're gonna say hey,
let's put some DNS information in here.

365
00:18:50.340 --> 00:18:52.890
Now when we create that partition,
we have to scope it.

366
00:18:52.890 --> 00:18:55.380
We have to decide what
other domain controllers.

367
00:18:55.380 --> 00:18:59.629
This is going in the Active Directory
database, which gets replicated around to

368
00:18:59.629 --> 00:19:03.629
other domain controllers, based on
whether they're part of my domain, or

369
00:19:03.629 --> 00:19:05.831
just part of the force in another domain.

370
00:19:05.831 --> 00:19:09.115
So, we have to decide when we create
this partition where does this partition

371
00:19:09.115 --> 00:19:09.910
replicate?

372
00:19:09.910 --> 00:19:13.950
And our choices are to all DNS
servers running on domain controllers

373
00:19:13.950 --> 00:19:17.460
in this forest, Lab.ITPro.TV.

374
00:19:17.460 --> 00:19:20.900
So, what this is gonna do it's
gonna create a forest DNS zone.

375
00:19:20.900 --> 00:19:23.220
It's actually called forest DNS zone, and

376
00:19:23.220 --> 00:19:27.840
it will replicate all domain controllers
in the forest, if they're running DNS.

377
00:19:27.840 --> 00:19:30.570
If they're not running DNS they
won't get a copy of this partition

378
00:19:30.570 --> 00:19:32.100
because they don't need it, right?

379
00:19:32.100 --> 00:19:35.390
But any domain controller
in the forest that's

380
00:19:35.390 --> 00:19:37.470
running DNS will get a copy of this zone.

381
00:19:38.540 --> 00:19:42.220
I could choose all DNS servers running
on domain controllers in this domain.

382
00:19:42.220 --> 00:19:43.640
So now we're gonna make
the domain DNS cell.

383
00:19:43.640 --> 00:19:47.820
This is gonna replicate to all
domain controllers in my domain

384
00:19:47.820 --> 00:19:51.660
that are running DNS, but
not outside of my domain.

385
00:19:51.660 --> 00:19:54.110
The third one is for
backwards compatibility.

386
00:19:54.110 --> 00:19:57.600
This replicates to all domain controllers,
whether they're running DNS or

387
00:19:57.600 --> 00:19:59.130
not, within my domain.

388
00:19:59.130 --> 00:20:01.000
You can see for
Windows 2000 compatibility,

389
00:20:01.000 --> 00:20:05.440
usually we don't have to worry
about that option anymore.

390
00:20:06.530 --> 00:20:10.000
So the question then becomes,
who needs access to the zone file?

391
00:20:10.000 --> 00:20:14.470
If this is a zone file that has resource
records for something just my domain uses,

392
00:20:14.470 --> 00:20:17.460
I would probably replicate to just
the domain controllers in my domain.

393
00:20:17.460 --> 00:20:21.410
Because domain b and c, their never gonna
look up any resource records in there.

394
00:20:21.410 --> 00:20:24.610
There's no point in wasting
the replication, the storage space for

395
00:20:24.610 --> 00:20:26.430
including a copy of that zone.

396
00:20:26.430 --> 00:20:30.080
But if this zone is something that
everybody in the forest uses,

397
00:20:30.080 --> 00:20:32.570
then I would replicate it to all
domain controllers in the force and

398
00:20:32.570 --> 00:20:35.160
it would create that forest DNS zone,
all right.

399
00:20:35.160 --> 00:20:37.330
Now I'll do just in the domain,

400
00:20:37.330 --> 00:20:40.650
only because I don't have any
other domains in my forest.

401
00:20:40.650 --> 00:20:45.258
And we'll click Next, I'll give it a name,

402
00:20:45.258 --> 00:20:52.440
let's call this one marketing.ITPRO.TV,
and we'll click Next.

403
00:20:52.440 --> 00:20:55.680
Now, unlike when we created
that standard primary,

404
00:20:55.680 --> 00:21:00.650
my secure dynamic updates is available,
use only secure dynamic updates.

405
00:21:02.280 --> 00:21:04.150
We've talked about dynamic updates, right.

406
00:21:04.150 --> 00:21:05.790
>> Yeah.
>> So, we understand what those are,

407
00:21:05.790 --> 00:21:09.140
the client can call up and
create his own resource record.

408
00:21:09.140 --> 00:21:13.360
But there's no security involved
when you choose this option here.

409
00:21:13.360 --> 00:21:16.620
>> Yeah, what if I'm a bad guy and
I wanna tell you fake information.

410
00:21:16.620 --> 00:21:18.530
And say, hey, my information has changed.

411
00:21:18.530 --> 00:21:20.970
But I'm really speaking on behalf,
I'm rogue and

412
00:21:20.970 --> 00:21:23.640
I'm speaking on behalf
of a legitimate client.

413
00:21:23.640 --> 00:21:25.495
>> You're trying to redirect,
spoof somebody.

414
00:21:25.495 --> 00:21:27.806
You're trying to say, hey,
when you look up this name,

415
00:21:27.806 --> 00:21:30.760
which I know you're gonna do,
I'm gonna give you the wrong IP address.

416
00:21:30.760 --> 00:21:35.409
And redirect you to my server where I can
capture all your information or yeah,

417
00:21:35.409 --> 00:21:38.870
do [LAUGH] whatever you want,
evil laugh, evil laugh.

418
00:21:38.870 --> 00:21:42.700
Secure dynamic update says hey,
before your allowed to make that update

419
00:21:42.700 --> 00:21:44.960
I need to know who you are,
I need to trust you.

420
00:21:44.960 --> 00:21:48.330
So if you're part of the domain then
you can do your secure dynamic update.

421
00:21:48.330 --> 00:21:51.970
If your not, you don't get to
do a dynamic update, right.

422
00:21:51.970 --> 00:21:55.380
That's the idea, this prevents things
like what Cherokee was talking about,

423
00:21:55.380 --> 00:22:00.060
people making bogus records
of rogue DNS entries.

424
00:22:00.060 --> 00:22:03.780
Also for vendors, right, what if a vendor,
a legitimate vendor comes in,

425
00:22:03.780 --> 00:22:05.509
they plug there laptop internet network.

426
00:22:06.650 --> 00:22:09.730
They're gonna get an IP
address from your DHCP server.

427
00:22:09.730 --> 00:22:13.342
They're gonna get a DNS IP
address from your DHCP server.

428
00:22:13.342 --> 00:22:17.100
Their laptop's gonna turn around and
try to register with your DNS server, and

429
00:22:17.100 --> 00:22:21.080
there's really no reason for me to have
a record like that on my DNS server.

430
00:22:21.080 --> 00:22:25.710
So it just prevents things like that
from happening, and it keeps me safe.

431
00:22:25.710 --> 00:22:29.072
That's the main thing, right, it keeps the
bad guys from trying to fake something.

432
00:22:29.072 --> 00:22:33.725
>> Yeah, and you might even hear
that term, like that DNS poisoning.

433
00:22:33.725 --> 00:22:38.250
Poisoning being like a general kind
of alteration, not altercation.

434
00:22:38.250 --> 00:22:40.045
>> That too if I find out who did it.

435
00:22:40.045 --> 00:22:46.372
Maybe, [LAUGH] no, peace is the way to go,
violence is always never the answer.

436
00:22:46.372 --> 00:22:53.310
All right, so I'll do secured only, then
I'll do both, nah I'll do secure only.

437
00:22:53.310 --> 00:22:55.310
Decisions, decisions, we'll do the proper.

438
00:22:55.310 --> 00:22:56.300
>> Live on the edge, Mike.

439
00:22:56.300 --> 00:22:58.969
[LAUGH]
>> Right, yes, and remember do not allow

440
00:22:58.969 --> 00:23:02.562
dynamic updates if I'm in this situation
where I wanna manually create all

441
00:23:02.562 --> 00:23:06.330
the records for security reasons,
then that would be the option.

442
00:23:06.330 --> 00:23:10.200
I'll do only secure,
I'll click Next and Finish.

443
00:23:10.200 --> 00:23:14.480
And now we have a new zone,
an Active Directory integrated zone.

444
00:23:14.480 --> 00:23:18.540
And we got to see the options of where
I was gonna allow that to replicate.

445
00:23:18.540 --> 00:23:22.050
So if I set up another domain controller,
which I should do.

446
00:23:22.050 --> 00:23:25.520
Do we have the, I took the,
you know what, we'll go ahead and install

447
00:23:25.520 --> 00:23:29.440
Active Directory real fast on this guy,
while we're talking about other things.

448
00:23:29.440 --> 00:23:31.920
Oops, if I can do it really fast.

449
00:23:31.920 --> 00:23:34.870
>> So what you're doing is you're just
installing the Active Directory so you

450
00:23:34.870 --> 00:23:38.440
could have a secondary or an additional
domain controller here, I should say.

451
00:23:38.440 --> 00:23:39.810
>> Yeah, exactly right.

452
00:23:39.810 --> 00:23:42.720
>> All righty.
>> So we'll add features Next, Next,

453
00:23:42.720 --> 00:23:44.310
Next, and Install.

454
00:23:44.310 --> 00:23:45.511
>> Are we timing you here?

455
00:23:45.511 --> 00:23:48.605
>> Yes, [LAUGH] see how fast we can
get Active Directory installed.

456
00:23:48.605 --> 00:23:49.750
What have we got left on the clock.

457
00:23:49.750 --> 00:23:50.496
>> Yeah.
>> All right,

458
00:23:50.496 --> 00:23:54.815
because what I wanna show you, and
just in case it doesn't pop up in time,

459
00:23:54.815 --> 00:23:59.764
Is that will automatically replicate to
that other domain controller cuz it's part

460
00:23:59.764 --> 00:24:03.178
of the same domain, and
we chose replicate this zone to all

461
00:24:03.178 --> 00:24:06.620
the main controllers in this
domain that are running DNS.

462
00:24:06.620 --> 00:24:10.937
So as soon as I install Active Directory
and install DNS, it will get a copy.

463
00:24:10.937 --> 00:24:14.041
When Active Directory replicates,
it will replicate and

464
00:24:14.041 --> 00:24:16.390
I'll have two servers hosting this.

465
00:24:16.390 --> 00:24:20.120
Now let's talk about the advantages
over primary, right?

466
00:24:20.120 --> 00:24:23.240
Because in primary we've got two servers,
we've got a primary and a secondary.

467
00:24:23.240 --> 00:24:26.720
So two servers hosting the zone,
but one was read only,

468
00:24:26.720 --> 00:24:29.640
which meant no changes, no updates.

469
00:24:29.640 --> 00:24:33.480
I could only have one writable copy,
that's kind of a downer as well.

470
00:24:33.480 --> 00:24:36.970
With Active Directory Integrated
because Active Directory

471
00:24:36.970 --> 00:24:41.300
has a built in mechanism to deal
with replication conflicts.

472
00:24:41.300 --> 00:24:44.830
Active Directory uses what's called,
>> KDC?

473
00:24:44.830 --> 00:24:48.260
>> Well the KDC is part of it, but

474
00:24:48.260 --> 00:24:54.152
the concept is, Gosh,
Doug's gonna get me with this one too.

475
00:24:54.152 --> 00:24:58.400
[LAUGH] Man, it's been too long
since I've talked about this stuff.

476
00:24:58.400 --> 00:25:01.160
Multi master with loose convergence.

477
00:25:01.160 --> 00:25:02.270
There we go.

478
00:25:02.270 --> 00:25:03.740
>> I'm glad you remembered that.

479
00:25:03.740 --> 00:25:06.930
>> Yeah, uses multi master
replication with loose convergence.

480
00:25:06.930 --> 00:25:09.010
And really that's a big fancy term for,

481
00:25:09.010 --> 00:25:12.680
what we need to understand is more
than one writable copy, all right.

482
00:25:12.680 --> 00:25:15.352
Well now, Mike, you told me that
if I have two writable copies,

483
00:25:15.352 --> 00:25:17.149
we can end up with replication conflicts.

484
00:25:17.149 --> 00:25:19.350
>> Right.
>> What if two changes are being made

485
00:25:19.350 --> 00:25:21.520
at the same time on two
different machines?

486
00:25:21.520 --> 00:25:23.145
What are we doing with replicate?
[CROSSTALK] >> It wins, yeah.

487
00:25:23.145 --> 00:25:25.395
>> Well Active Directory has
ways of dealing with this,

488
00:25:25.395 --> 00:25:27.560
we won't go over them in this class.

489
00:25:27.560 --> 00:25:31.950
There's three different things that
it can do with replication conflicts.

490
00:25:31.950 --> 00:25:36.090
The point is,
it has a mechanism to deal with conflicts.

491
00:25:36.090 --> 00:25:39.700
So now that we're putting DNS
in there with Active Directory,

492
00:25:39.700 --> 00:25:42.170
we have a way of dealing with conflicts,
right?

493
00:25:42.170 --> 00:25:44.130
So now I can have more
than one writable copy.

494
00:25:44.130 --> 00:25:46.740
So Active Directory integrated zones,
they're all writable.

495
00:25:46.740 --> 00:25:49.610
It's multi-master, there is no one master.

496
00:25:49.610 --> 00:25:51.410
There's no secondary to set up.

497
00:25:51.410 --> 00:25:54.560
So if I have three dominion controllers,
five dominion controllers,

498
00:25:54.560 --> 00:25:56.365
I have five writable copies of the zone.

499
00:25:56.365 --> 00:25:57.417
[CROSSTALK] Exactly.

500
00:25:57.417 --> 00:26:00.853
And if one of them goes down,
I can still make changes,

501
00:26:00.853 --> 00:26:05.140
I can still create new records,
everything goes on as normal.

502
00:26:05.140 --> 00:26:06.820
So big advantage over primary and

503
00:26:06.820 --> 00:26:10.730
secondary, is the fact that I
have more than one writable copy.

504
00:26:10.730 --> 00:26:14.170
Second big advantage,
is the secure only dynamic updates.

505
00:26:14.170 --> 00:26:17.360
I can't do that with standard
primaries and secondaries, so

506
00:26:17.360 --> 00:26:21.520
that's a big security bonus there, being
able to verify the identity before we

507
00:26:21.520 --> 00:26:27.200
allow them to create those
resource records in DNS.

508
00:26:27.200 --> 00:26:30.000
Third big advantage, when that primary and

509
00:26:30.000 --> 00:26:34.860
secondary DNS server replicate that
zone file, when the secondary says hey,

510
00:26:34.860 --> 00:26:37.960
give me copy of your zone file and
the master says sure, here you go.

511
00:26:37.960 --> 00:26:42.530
It travels across the network, it's
not encrypted, it's plain text, right?

512
00:26:42.530 --> 00:26:45.592
There is no built-in encryption method for
DNS,

513
00:26:45.592 --> 00:26:50.590
it has no way to do it
on its own like this.

514
00:26:50.590 --> 00:26:54.460
So what can happen is, if somebody's on
your network running a pack of capture

515
00:26:54.460 --> 00:26:58.590
utilities like Wireshark or
Message Analyzer from Microsoft or

516
00:26:58.590 --> 00:27:01.120
something like that,
they can capture that data and

517
00:27:01.120 --> 00:27:03.990
read your zone file just like
they got a zone transfer.

518
00:27:03.990 --> 00:27:07.700
So we would have to use maybe IPsec or
something like that

519
00:27:07.700 --> 00:27:11.390
to encrypt the communication
between that primary and secondary.

520
00:27:11.390 --> 00:27:16.090
Active directory replication
is encrypted already, right?

521
00:27:16.090 --> 00:27:18.630
Active Directory encrypts
that replication traffic.

522
00:27:18.630 --> 00:27:23.060
So once we put DNS in there and it's now
replicating the DNS zone to that other

523
00:27:23.060 --> 00:27:25.800
domain controller, it's encrypted also.

524
00:27:25.800 --> 00:27:29.700
>> So it sounds like it's a pretty sweet
deal if we can actually take advantage of

525
00:27:29.700 --> 00:27:32.670
these enhancements that
Active Directory has to offer.

526
00:27:32.670 --> 00:27:35.410
>> Absolutely,
replication topology is another one.

527
00:27:35.410 --> 00:27:38.889
You mentioned I think the the KCC or-
>> Knowledge Consistency Checker, yep.

528
00:27:38.889 --> 00:27:41.820
>> The Knowledge Consistency Checker and
the Intersite Typology Generator,

529
00:27:41.820 --> 00:27:44.430
these are engines that define or

530
00:27:44.430 --> 00:27:48.410
that develop our replication between
domain controllers and they do a very good

531
00:27:48.410 --> 00:27:53.250
job of making sure that there's a minimum
number of hops between domain controllers.

532
00:27:53.250 --> 00:27:57.780
And with standard, primary, and secondary,
we're doing that on our own, right?

533
00:27:57.780 --> 00:28:02.480
I said we should make the primary the
center of the spoke and maybe do, or hub,

534
00:28:02.480 --> 00:28:04.780
and then makes spokes going
out to the secondaries.

535
00:28:04.780 --> 00:28:08.310
But I could do a chain, and
that's not real efficient.

536
00:28:08.310 --> 00:28:12.380
With Active Directory Integrated, we're
taking advantage of the KCC and the ISTG,

537
00:28:12.380 --> 00:28:15.560
and we know we already have
an efficient replication topology.

538
00:28:15.560 --> 00:28:17.960
So we just piggyback on top of that.

539
00:28:17.960 --> 00:28:23.230
So yes, as you were saying,
it's a win-win-win-win situation, right?

540
00:28:23.230 --> 00:28:28.790
I mean I get secure updates, encrypted
replication, efficient replication

541
00:28:28.790 --> 00:28:33.800
topology, the replication is encrypted,
I have multiple writable copies.

542
00:28:33.800 --> 00:28:36.009
I forgot a WIN there, so
that's five wins, right?

543
00:28:36.009 --> 00:28:38.503
>> [LAUGH]
>> It really is and that's why I say,

544
00:28:38.503 --> 00:28:42.129
Active Directory Integrated is
really what you're going to see,

545
00:28:42.129 --> 00:28:46.678
unless you need to install DNS somewhere
where you can not put a domain controller.

546
00:28:46.678 --> 00:28:52.090
And that's definitely something that
we have to do, but internally you're

547
00:28:52.090 --> 00:28:57.788
almost always, I think, going to see
Active Directory Integrated into zones.

548
00:28:57.788 --> 00:29:01.670
You know I started talking and
I never did finish my wizard, did I?

549
00:29:01.670 --> 00:29:04.664
>> Yeah, and we still have things
like stump zones to talk about.

550
00:29:04.664 --> 00:29:05.278
>> Yeah, I know.

551
00:29:05.278 --> 00:29:08.660
>> Also really there's no need to rush
because I mean we're going to have to have

552
00:29:08.660 --> 00:29:09.650
part three here [LAUGH].

553
00:29:09.650 --> 00:29:11.832
>> All right, sounds good.

554
00:29:11.832 --> 00:29:14.380
>> All right Mike, so
hopefully you'll come back and join us for

555
00:29:14.380 --> 00:29:18.180
this wonderful part three that we have and
hopefully you'll join us as well but for

556
00:29:18.180 --> 00:29:19.990
now we'll go ahead and sign out.

557
00:29:19.990 --> 00:29:21.362
I’ve been your host, Cherokee Boose.

348
00:17:55.190 --> 00:17:58.236

00:17:58.236 --> 00:17:59.900

350
00:17:59.900 --> 00:18:03.320

351
00:18:03.320 --> 00:18:07.930
When we create queries, there's two
different kinds of queries we can send.

352
00:18:07.930 --> 00:18:11.900
There's a recursive query and
there's an iterative query.

353
00:18:11.900 --> 00:18:15.760
A recursive query requires an answer.

354
00:18:15.760 --> 00:18:17.300
In other words,
I'm gonna ask you a question,

355
00:18:17.300 --> 00:18:21.840
DNS server, and I'm gonna sit here and
wait, until you give me the answer.

356
00:18:21.840 --> 00:18:23.130
It might not be the answer I want.

357
00:18:23.130 --> 00:18:26.500
It might be a name not found,
or something like that.

358
00:18:26.500 --> 00:18:29.220
But I'm not doing anything
until you respond to me.

359
00:18:29.220 --> 00:18:32.120
I'm asking you a question,
you have to respond to me.

360
00:18:32.120 --> 00:18:34.400
That's a recursive query.

361
00:18:34.400 --> 00:18:37.625
And remember it this way,
I don't know why it sticks in my brain,

362
00:18:37.625 --> 00:18:39.221
recursive requires an answer.

363
00:18:39.221 --> 00:18:40.419
>> That's a good way to-
>> Yes, yeah.

364
00:18:40.419 --> 00:18:40.999
>> Think about it.

365
00:18:40.999 --> 00:18:41.998
>> Recursive requires an answer.

366
00:18:41.998 --> 00:18:46.490
If you can remember that, then you'll
know the other one has to be iterative.

367
00:18:46.490 --> 00:18:52.870
Iterative queries can either
accept an answer or a referral.

368
00:18:52.870 --> 00:18:57.210
So instead of me telling you the answer
to the question you're asking, I can say,

369
00:18:57.210 --> 00:19:01.080
I don't know, but go check with this guy,
maybe he knows, right?

370
00:19:01.080 --> 00:19:02.720
That's an iterative query.

371
00:19:02.720 --> 00:19:05.620
Iterative queries can
either take an answer or

372
00:19:05.620 --> 00:19:08.170
a referral to somebody
else that I can ask.

373
00:19:09.280 --> 00:19:11.960
So now we can a look at
what's going on here.

374
00:19:11.960 --> 00:19:14.524
When your client sends a query
to the local DNS server,

375
00:19:14.524 --> 00:19:16.940
what's the IP address for
www.microsoft.com?

376
00:19:16.940 --> 00:19:20.156
Maybe they've typed that in their

377
00:19:20.156 --> 00:19:22.760
So this is all happening
behind the scenes.

378
00:19:22.760 --> 00:19:26.630
Their client generates a recursive
query that requires an answer.

379
00:19:26.630 --> 00:19:28.808
Sends it to the local DNS server, or

380
00:19:28.808 --> 00:19:33.170
whatever their TCP IP settings
say to use for DNS, all right?

381
00:19:33.170 --> 00:19:35.540
Because my client doesn't want the answer.

382
00:19:35.540 --> 00:19:37.420
Hey, I don't know,
go check somewhere else, buddy.

383
00:19:37.420 --> 00:19:38.200
I'm too busy for you.

384
00:19:38.200 --> 00:19:40.430
Or I don't know, go try this guy.

385
00:19:40.430 --> 00:19:44.200
The client needs the answer,
my browser needs to open microsoft.com, so

386
00:19:44.200 --> 00:19:45.920
referrals not gonna do me any good.

387
00:19:45.920 --> 00:19:49.383
So it sends a recursive query,
says go find out for me, and

388
00:19:49.383 --> 00:19:51.236
don't come back until you do.

389
00:19:51.236 --> 00:19:54.811
This is going to be step number one,

390
00:19:54.811 --> 00:19:58.299
Then my DNS server gets that query,

00:19:58.299 --> 00:20:03.720
I'm not authoritative for microsoft.com so
I don't have the information.

392
00:20:03.720 --> 00:20:06.900
But you sent me a recursive query telling
me I better go get the information, so

393
00:20:06.900 --> 00:20:08.570
that's what I'm going to do.

394
00:20:08.570 --> 00:20:12.040
So he goes out, and
he actually sends a query

00:20:12.040 --> 00:20:16.170
to the very top of the DNS infrastructure,

00:20:16.170 --> 00:20:19.250
And notice this query is blue,

397
00:20:19.250 --> 00:20:23.160
Give me the answer, or
refer me to somebody else.

398
00:20:23.160 --> 00:20:25.270
And he sends that query up to the root.

00:20:25.270 --> 00:20:29.372
The root says,
I don't know who www.microsoft.com is,

guy

I know the guy that

And he sends back a referral, right?

Back to my DNS server,

00:23:11.850 --> 00:23:13.510
>> I just wanted to make
sure we didn't forget that.

461
00:23:13.510 --> 00:23:14.970
>> We haven't talked about that yet.

462
00:23:14.970 --> 00:23:16.780
>> Yeah. Okay. >> Yes, there's definitely.

463
00:23:16.780 --> 00:23:18.591
Let's just pretend we don't
know about cache yet.

464
00:23:18.591 --> 00:23:19.368
>> Okay.

465
00:23:19.368 --> 00:23:21.539
>> This happens every
time you go to a site.

466
00:23:21.539 --> 00:23:23.805
So but we know it doesn't now.

467
00:23:23.805 --> 00:23:25.290
>> [LAUGH]
>> So that's not fair.

468
00:23:25.290 --> 00:23:26.044
>> I'm sorry, Mike.

469
00:23:26.044 --> 00:23:29.462
>> Yes, this is the process that
occurs when we resolve names, and

470
00:23:29.462 --> 00:23:31.373
it's pretty magical if you ask me.

471
00:23:31.373 --> 00:23:34.392
It's a pretty impressive process.

472
00:23:34.392 --> 00:23:36.471
And go to a site you've
never been to before,

473
00:23:36.471 --> 00:23:39.380
that you know nobody else on
your network has been to.

474
00:23:39.380 --> 00:23:41.599
Type in, I dunno, australia.gov, right?

475
00:23:41.599 --> 00:23:44.820
Not to say that many people don't go
to this site, it's a wonderful site.

476
00:23:44.820 --> 00:23:47.280
But what are the odds of
my co-workers going there?

477
00:23:48.300 --> 00:23:51.020
So I can type that into my browser.

478
00:23:51.020 --> 00:23:52.590
And connect to it like that.

479
00:23:52.590 --> 00:23:54.390
And all of this is happening, right?

480
00:23:54.390 --> 00:23:56.690
All of these queries,
these recursive queries,

481
00:23:56.690 --> 00:24:00.330
these iterative queries, are going on
in the background making that happen.

482
00:24:00.330 --> 00:24:03.645
So its, it's really a fantastic thing.

483
00:24:03.645 --> 00:24:04.908
All right?
And you can imagine,

484
00:24:04.908 --> 00:24:06.009
I won't redo the drawing.

485
00:24:06.009 --> 00:24:10.687
But if the name I had originally
requested Requested ended in .Net.

486
00:24:10.687 --> 00:24:13.570
The process would've just been modified,
I would've sent the query to the route.

487
00:24:13.570 --> 00:24:17.320
The route would've said, hey I don't know,
but the name you're looking for

488
00:24:17.320 --> 00:24:21.770
ends in .Net, go check with the .Net TLD,

489
00:24:21.770 --> 00:24:26.120
top level domain DNS server and then
the process would've continued on, right?

490
00:24:27.710 --> 00:24:31.242
So big things we're learning here
are that there are two types of queries.

491
00:24:31.242 --> 00:24:35.160
There is recursive queries that require an
answer, iterative queries that can accept

492
00:24:35.160 --> 00:24:38.550
an answer or
a referral through another DNS server.

493
00:24:38.550 --> 00:24:42.450
The fact that MyDNS server
doesn't know everything, and

494
00:24:42.450 --> 00:24:45.220
there really is no DNS server
that knows everything.

495
00:24:45.220 --> 00:24:50.575
We use a combination, this hierarchical
structure works together to give us

496
00:24:50.575 --> 00:24:55.700
the scalability and
the performance we need to make DNS work.

497
00:24:55.700 --> 00:24:57.950
To support the ever expanding internet,

498
00:24:57.950 --> 00:25:01.880
I mean if you didn't have this the
internet would not be what it is today.

499
00:25:01.880 --> 00:25:06.293
You know, if we are relying on some
systems that didn't work this way,

500
00:25:06.293 --> 00:25:10.140
it just would not work, so
fantastic stuff, all right.

501
00:25:10.140 --> 00:25:13.590
>> Mike, are there any shortcuts
to help with this process.

502
00:25:13.590 --> 00:25:17.650
If I were maybe merging, ITPro.TV and
Microsoft were merging or

503
00:25:17.650 --> 00:25:21.846
something like that and I was expecting
an influx of those types of requests.

504
00:25:21.846 --> 00:25:23.497
>> There are, but
I'm looking at the clock and

505
00:25:23.497 --> 00:25:25.470
I know you're gonna give
me that signal in a second.

506
00:25:25.470 --> 00:25:26.994
>> [LAUGH]
>> That,

507
00:25:26.994 --> 00:25:31.040
Mike you've talked too much again and
we're gonna have to stop you.

508
00:25:31.040 --> 00:25:33.800
So I think what I'll do is I'll
jump over to caching real quick.

509
00:25:33.800 --> 00:25:35.735
>> Okay.
>> Since we hinted at that already.

510
00:25:35.735 --> 00:25:37.482
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I'll save those other stuff,

511
00:25:37.482 --> 00:25:39.550
cuz they're gonna take a few more
minutes than what we've got.

512
00:25:39.550 --> 00:25:41.150
>> Okay, yeah.

513
00:25:41.150 --> 00:25:45.878
I just had to remember which
drawing l had the caching on,

514
00:25:45.878 --> 00:25:48.780
I didn't, did l make changes?

515
00:25:48.780 --> 00:25:50.210
I did make changes to it.

516
00:25:50.210 --> 00:25:52.590
>> You were just moving the numbers so-
>> I was just moving the numbers.

517
00:25:52.590 --> 00:25:54.840
And we don't want the numbers
to save there do we.

518
00:25:54.840 --> 00:25:56.280
Yes we wanna quit.

519
00:25:56.280 --> 00:26:03.360
All right, understanding part one,
let's see here.

520
00:26:03.360 --> 00:26:06.930
So caching, what Cherokee was talking
about, that's the sa- I keep doing that,

521
00:26:06.930 --> 00:26:08.690
opening up the same darn drawings two.

522
00:26:08.690 --> 00:26:10.430
Let's try number two.

523
00:26:10.430 --> 00:26:11.510
Remember that I'm on two Cherokee,
help me out.

524
00:26:11.510 --> 00:26:13.873
>> Magic, okay, all right.

525
00:26:15.496 --> 00:26:16.800
>> Yes, caching.

526
00:26:16.800 --> 00:26:18.030
No, not caching.

527
00:26:18.030 --> 00:26:20.880
So number three has time,
third time is a charm.

528
00:26:22.850 --> 00:26:26.760
So what Cherokee was referring to
earlier is there actually is a way

529
00:26:26.760 --> 00:26:29.000
to speed things a little bit, right?

530
00:26:29.000 --> 00:26:33.660
Because if, that's still a very
fast process, like I said, if you

531
00:26:33.660 --> 00:26:37.000
go to some place you've never been before,
and that nobody else has been before,

532
00:26:37.000 --> 00:26:39.330
you'll most likely see that
it's really pretty quick.

533
00:26:39.330 --> 00:26:42.750
It's almost imperceivable
how fast it goes, right?

534
00:26:42.750 --> 00:26:47.135
But there are days when the traffic is
bad and it takes a little bit longer and

535
00:26:47.135 --> 00:26:50.476
we get the spinning Cherry-O
as it resolves that name and

536
00:26:50.476 --> 00:26:53.066
tries to reach out
an http get that website.

537
00:26:53.066 --> 00:26:58.340
But DNS has something called caching and
all DNS servers cache,

538
00:26:58.340 --> 00:27:05.620
well, unless you tell them not to, and
even your clients cache DNS information.

539
00:27:05.620 --> 00:27:10.380
Cache is spelled C-A-C-H-E, so
not like the cash in your wallet.

540
00:27:10.380 --> 00:27:13.345
But just like the cash-
>> Although it is temporary.

541
00:27:13.345 --> 00:27:14.180
[LAUGH]
>> Just like the cash

542
00:27:14.180 --> 00:27:16.160
in your wallet it is very temporary,
right?

543
00:27:16.160 --> 00:27:19.130
So when you think of cache,
think temporary storage,

544
00:27:19.130 --> 00:27:22.080
temporary memory things like that.

545
00:27:22.080 --> 00:27:26.130
So DNS caches responses, and

546
00:27:26.130 --> 00:27:31.160
that way if I get asked the same question
again, I don't have to go look it up.

547
00:27:31.160 --> 00:27:35.390
I already have the answer, I just
looked up the IP address for User A.

548
00:27:35.390 --> 00:27:37.490
Do you really want me to
go look it up again for

549
00:27:37.490 --> 00:27:39.850
User B that was 10 seconds ago, right?

550
00:27:39.850 --> 00:27:43.100
Has the IP address really
changed in 10 seconds.

551
00:27:43.100 --> 00:27:45.270
Odds are probably good that it hasn't, so

552
00:27:45.270 --> 00:27:48.795
I can use that cached information,
that's known as caching.

553
00:27:48.795 --> 00:27:53.360
And the process here, if we look at this
drawing, we've got a client1, let's just

554
00:27:53.360 --> 00:27:58.600
say, types in Microsoft.com in his
browser, goes through the normal process,

555
00:27:58.600 --> 00:28:03.190
sends a recursive, I'm sorry a, yeah
a recursive query to the local DNS server.

556
00:28:03.190 --> 00:28:07.450
I simplified the steps to just show you
these two, right, but it does the root and

557
00:28:07.450 --> 00:28:12.320
then the .com and then microsoft.com,
finally gets the answer.

558
00:28:12.320 --> 00:28:15.360
Before it gives the answer
back to the client,

559
00:28:15.360 --> 00:28:19.220
it writes the answer down in temporary
storage, in cache, all right?

560
00:28:19.220 --> 00:28:20.880
Then it gives the answer to the client.

561
00:28:20.880 --> 00:28:23.180
The client actually caches it as well.

562
00:28:23.180 --> 00:28:27.280
So that if I close my browser accidentally
or intentionally, and then I open it up

563
00:28:27.280 --> 00:28:31.620
again, I wanna go back to microsoft.com,
I don't even have to do these two steps.

564
00:28:31.620 --> 00:28:35.820
I already have the IP addressed cashed,
so I can just go straight to it.

565
00:28:35.820 --> 00:28:40.210
But how it speeds up name
resolution is that if a second user

566
00:28:40.210 --> 00:28:45.020
wants to go to microsoft.com they don't
know that I have been to microsoft.com.

567
00:28:45.020 --> 00:28:48.830
They send a query over to DNS, DNS says
wait a second, I just looked that up,

568
00:28:48.830 --> 00:28:49.860
hold on a second.

569
00:28:49.860 --> 00:28:53.170
And he pulls it out of the cache and
sends it back to the client.

570
00:28:53.170 --> 00:28:57.160
Client has no idea, and cache is the
response that it gets from the DNS server,

571
00:28:57.160 --> 00:29:00.190
it doesn't know that it
came from his cache.

572
00:29:00.190 --> 00:29:04.280
But he skipped all of these steps, right?

573
00:29:04.280 --> 00:29:08.260
So that whole process, and I can't open
up two drawings at the same time, sorry.

574
00:29:08.260 --> 00:29:13.070
Yeah, so the only thing that's going on
now is, one query gets sent to the DNS

575
00:29:13.070 --> 00:29:16.430
server, he has the answer in the cache,
and he sends it right back to him.

576
00:29:16.430 --> 00:29:22.180
And we get to skip all those other steps,
which is definitely gonna save us time.

577
00:29:22.180 --> 00:29:26.240
Now, there is a downside to caching,
because things change,

578
00:29:26.240 --> 00:29:27.990
IP addresses change.

579
00:29:27.990 --> 00:29:31.220
And that's why we call it cache,
or that's why we use cache,

580
00:29:31.220 --> 00:29:33.630
we don't store those answers permanently.

581
00:29:33.630 --> 00:29:34.310
>> Forever.

582
00:29:34.310 --> 00:29:36.410
>> Because if we kept them forever,

583
00:29:36.410 --> 00:29:41.030
eventually that information might be
bad and I don't wanna use it anymore.

584
00:29:41.030 --> 00:29:43.170
But, I'm never gonna go look it up again.

585
00:29:43.170 --> 00:29:46.890
It's like your friends number changed, but
you don't know because you've got their

586
00:29:46.890 --> 00:29:50.220
number in your contacts, and you keep
calling them and they never answer.

587
00:29:50.220 --> 00:29:52.960
And eventually you get some strange
person go, who the heck is this?

588
00:29:52.960 --> 00:29:53.485
Where is Bob?

589
00:29:53.485 --> 00:29:55.951
And they go,
this isn't Bob's number anymore, right?

590
00:29:55.951 --> 00:29:59.986
It's that kind of thing and so we
eventually need to flush that cash out and

591
00:29:59.986 --> 00:30:01.496
it does it automatically.

592
00:30:01.496 --> 00:30:06.033
Uses something as a TTL or time to live,
that determines how long their cache for

593
00:30:06.033 --> 00:30:10.590
as a whole another conversation which we
don't really have time for right now.

594
00:30:10.590 --> 00:30:15.140
So we'll, when we get into advanced DNS,
we'll look at ways of managing that cache.

595
00:30:15.140 --> 00:30:17.880
I'm going to talk about flushing cache,
cuz that is important.

596
00:30:17.880 --> 00:30:22.190
But as far as who sets the TTL,
that'd be the authoritator server.

597
00:30:22.190 --> 00:30:23.270
Whether I should change it or not, and

598
00:30:23.270 --> 00:30:25.650
a lot of other things we'll
get into in the advanced DNS.

599
00:30:25.650 --> 00:30:28.300
But for now, that's what caching is.

600
00:30:28.300 --> 00:30:30.000
And it definitely speeds the process up.

601
00:30:30.000 --> 00:30:35.780
Think about your ISP, think about
how many customers your ISP handles.

602
00:30:35.780 --> 00:30:40.850
And now what are the odds that some other
customer, I use Cox Communications here.

603
00:30:40.850 --> 00:30:44.540
What are the odds that some
other user in this region

604
00:30:44.540 --> 00:30:47.610
has gone to Newegg.com before me.

605
00:30:47.610 --> 00:30:51.150
Probably pretty good, they probably have
a pretty big cache of all the people that

606
00:30:51.150 --> 00:30:52.500
are browsing the internet.

607
00:30:52.500 --> 00:30:54.270
They've got a lot of IP addresses cached.

608
00:30:54.270 --> 00:30:58.300
So when I go, I typically don't even
have to go through all those steps.

609
00:30:58.300 --> 00:31:02.890
My ISP's DNS server already
has that information cached.

610
00:31:02.890 --> 00:31:05.860
So, caching definitely
speeds up the process.

611
00:31:07.260 --> 00:31:12.320
We'll talk a little bit more about
other ways we can speed up this process

612
00:31:12.320 --> 00:31:13.920
in the next part.

613
00:31:13.920 --> 00:31:17.240
>> All right, so
that brings us up to a part four, so

614
00:31:17.240 --> 00:31:18.570
you definitely don't wanna miss that.

615
00:31:18.570 --> 00:31:20.420
Thank you so much for being with us today.

616
00:31:20.420 --> 00:31:24.670
And I thank you Mike as always, but
we'll go ahead and sign out for this show.

617
00:31:24.670 --> 00:31:26.120
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

618
00:31:26.120 --> 00:31:26.850
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

619
00:31:26.850 --> 00:31:29.694
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

620
00:31:29.694 --> 00:31:35.600
[MUSIC]

621
00:31:35.600 --> 00:31:38.783
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.160 --> 00:00:02.449
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.449 --> 00:00:06.489
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.489 --> 00:00:08.277
>> [MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.277 --> 00:00:11.992
>> You're watching ITPRO TV.

5
00:00:11.992 --> 00:00:16.230
>> Welcome ladies and
gentlemen to your 70-410 series.

6
00:00:16.230 --> 00:00:18.220
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:18.220 --> 00:00:21.946
In this episode, we'll be taking
a look at, well, how to configure DNS.

8
00:00:21.946 --> 00:00:26.207
We've already seen how to set it up and
back with us today in studios, we have Mr.

9
00:00:26.207 --> 00:00:27.040
Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:27.040 --> 00:00:28.120
Thanks for joining us today, Mike.

11
00:00:28.120 --> 00:00:28.640
How's it going?

12
00:00:28.640 --> 00:00:29.580
>> It's going great, Cherokee.

13
00:00:29.580 --> 00:00:30.510
Thanks for having me back.

14
00:00:30.510 --> 00:00:35.400
And yep, excited to continue on with one
of our favorite topics good old DNS.

15
00:00:35.400 --> 00:00:39.280
And I think we talked a little bit about
it, Cherokee, in that last episode or

16
00:00:39.280 --> 00:00:42.240
one of our previous episodes
we had talked about caching.

17
00:00:42.240 --> 00:00:46.160
Or the concept of caching and I'm sorry,
that's where we're gonna start today

18
00:00:46.160 --> 00:00:49.866
is looking at caching, and the settings,
and really what it's all about.

19
00:00:49.866 --> 00:00:52.545
And I think we had talked
about it a little bit,

20
00:00:52.545 --> 00:00:55.100
about how caching can
speed up the process.

21
00:00:55.100 --> 00:00:56.380
>> Yeah, we did a little bit.

22
00:00:56.380 --> 00:01:00.860
So are you gonna explain how that works
and what we need to know about caching?

23
00:01:00.860 --> 00:01:02.050
I mean, that makes sense, right?

24
00:01:02.050 --> 00:01:02.572
>> Absolutely.

25
00:01:02.572 --> 00:01:04.410
>> [LAUGH]
>> So let us talk about.

26
00:01:04.410 --> 00:01:06.110
We said when we resolve queries.

27
00:01:06.110 --> 00:01:08.170
When we query a DNS server,
we're asking yet

28
00:01:08.170 --> 00:01:11.860
a question whether that's a client OS or
a server OS, right?

29
00:01:11.860 --> 00:01:16.670
It's a DNS client sending a query
to a DNS server saying hey,

30
00:01:16.670 --> 00:01:22.722
what is the IP address of whatever,
www.newegg.com or microsoft.com.

31
00:01:22.722 --> 00:01:26.521
And that DNS server goes through
a process to resolve that query,

32
00:01:26.521 --> 00:01:28.390
to answer that question.

33
00:01:28.390 --> 00:01:31.250
And we said, if the server was
authoritative in other words,

34
00:01:31.250 --> 00:01:33.350
if it is Microsoft's DNS server,

35
00:01:33.350 --> 00:01:37.480
it can look in its own file,
we can pull that answer up and return it.

36
00:01:37.480 --> 00:01:39.130
But if it is not authoritative,

37
00:01:39.130 --> 00:01:42.050
it does not have that zone
like my local server here.

38
00:01:42.050 --> 00:01:44.180
Doesn't have a zone for microsoft.com.

39
00:01:44.180 --> 00:01:49.408
It can go through the process,
the root and then the .com tld.

40
00:01:49.408 --> 00:01:52.190
And eventually,
find its way to the Microsoft DNS server,

41
00:01:52.190 --> 00:01:54.100
the authoritative DNS server.

42
00:01:54.100 --> 00:01:55.880
Get the response it wants, and

43
00:01:55.880 --> 00:01:59.840
then return the response to
the originator of that query.

44
00:02:00.930 --> 00:02:04.730
We said that DNS server will
cache that response, right?

45
00:02:04.730 --> 00:02:07.372
And that way if somebody
else asks the same question,

46
00:02:07.372 --> 00:02:09.838
it doesn't have to go
through those hoops again,

47
00:02:09.838 --> 00:02:13.852
it doesn't have to go through the root,
and the top level, and all the way down.

48
00:02:13.852 --> 00:02:16.073
It can just pull the answer
of out its cache say hey,

49
00:02:16.073 --> 00:02:19.260
here I just got that answer 30
seconds ago for somebody else.

50
00:02:19.260 --> 00:02:21.814
Here's the answer I gave them;
it should work for you, right?

51
00:02:21.814 --> 00:02:24.000
That's what we mean by caching.

52
00:02:24.000 --> 00:02:28.510
We'll also have to remember that the DNS
client that's running on the node will

53
00:02:28.510 --> 00:02:30.160
also cache the response.

54
00:02:30.160 --> 00:02:34.060
And once the server gives out
the answer that it was asking for,

55
00:02:34.060 --> 00:02:35.570
it keeps track of that answer and
saves it.

56
00:02:35.570 --> 00:02:38.030
So in that way,
it doesn't have to ask again.

57
00:02:38.030 --> 00:02:41.400
And that is something I don't think we've
mentioned about caching the other day.

58
00:02:41.400 --> 00:02:45.210
The server caches it and
can respond more quickly to DNS clients.

59
00:02:45.210 --> 00:02:49.810
But the DNS clients also cache it which
means, the next time they go to that site,

60
00:02:49.810 --> 00:02:51.460
if they still have that
information cached,

61
00:02:51.460 --> 00:02:53.590
they don't even have to generate a query.

62
00:02:53.590 --> 00:02:56.320
Right, now we're talking
about instant response.

63
00:02:56.320 --> 00:03:01.470
Because I didn't have to ask anybody, I
already had the answer stored in my cache.

64
00:03:01.470 --> 00:03:05.480
So there really are a couple of different
caches that we're gonna be dealing with.

65
00:03:05.480 --> 00:03:09.230
There's the DNS client cache
which is the DNS client.

00:15:17.800 --> 00:15:21.220
It's not gonna go back and

new records that we create,

00:15:57.565 --> 00:16:00.175
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah so it registers it and it creates

00:16:00.175 --> 00:16:04.310
it static so it doesn't have to be updated

00:16:05.470 --> 00:16:06.720

00:16:06.720 --> 00:16:10.110
now the question then is what do

00:16:10.110 --> 00:16:12.570

00:16:12.570 --> 00:16:16.495

00:16:16.495 --> 00:16:18.570

00:16:18.570 --> 00:16:22.520

00:16:26.840 --> 00:16:30.110

00:16:30.110 --> 00:16:31.970

00:16:31.970 --> 00:16:35.740
When we change the TTL,
we're deciding how long

00:16:35.740 --> 00:16:39.810

00:16:39.810 --> 00:16:42.290
So the longer they hold onto it,

00:16:42.290 --> 00:16:45.610

00:16:45.610 --> 00:16:48.426
Because if they only hold it for

00:16:48.426 --> 00:16:51.922

00:16:51.922 --> 00:16:55.189
Because the cache timed out,

00:16:55.189 --> 00:16:57.551

00:16:57.551 --> 00:17:00.113
That means everybody that's coming

00:17:00.113 --> 00:17:01.049

00:17:01.049 --> 00:17:02.067

00:17:02.067 --> 00:17:06.240

00:17:09.274 --> 00:17:12.258
So you might think well good let's

00:17:12.258 --> 00:17:14.850
Well if you set for it eight hours

00:17:14.850 --> 00:17:18.710

00:17:30.410 --> 00:17:33.820
You want people rotating

So we typically use DNS round robining,

00:17:40.620 --> 00:17:44.740

00:17:44.740 --> 00:17:47.875
So that each time you go to their website

00:17:47.875 --> 00:17:49.500
at least you're rotating through.

00:17:49.500 --> 00:17:50.985
Maybe not you in particular, but

348
00:17:50.985 --> 00:17:53.968
each client of theirs each customer

349
00:17:53.968 --> 00:17:57.840
Should be kinda rotating through those web
servers like a poor man load balancing.

00:17:57.840 --> 00:18:02.494
And if that person is caching that server
for eight hours, now my load balancing,

351
00:18:02.494 --> 00:18:03.649
my round robining.

00:18:03.649 --> 00:18:05.078

00:18:05.078 --> 00:18:09.624

00:18:22.813 --> 00:18:24.180

It's easier to change

I wanted to move things around and

00:18:59.442 --> 00:19:03.010
>> Absolutely and you think about

00:19:03.010 --> 00:19:05.211
as new age servers, as they get busy.

00:19:05.211 --> 00:19:08.521
If they're virtual I'm just guessing,
I don't work for Newegg, but

00:19:08.521 --> 00:19:09.910
any organization like that.

373
00:19:09.910 --> 00:19:14.900
If they've got their website set up taking

00:19:14.900 --> 00:19:19.890
As they get busy during their peak times,

00:19:19.890 --> 00:19:23.320

00:19:23.320 --> 00:19:27.520

00:19:48.750 --> 00:19:52.220

00:20:02.810 --> 00:20:06.438
If you're in an organization where

All right so next, ass we've said, so

But what we also have to

00:23:52.325 --> 00:23:56.063
So for as far as the client goes,

518
00:27:32.780 --> 00:27:36.570
even if you don't get a response from
the ping, the fact that it was able to

519
00:27:36.570 --> 00:27:41.170
turn the name into an IP address tells
me that the DNS is working properly.

520
00:27:41.170 --> 00:27:42.880
The whole fact that it
didn't respond the ping,

521
00:27:42.880 --> 00:27:45.410
that's a completely separate thing, right.

522
00:27:45.410 --> 00:27:47.430
That could be a network issue or
something like that but

523
00:27:47.430 --> 00:27:50.160
that's completely separate just
make sure we're clear on that.

524
00:27:50.160 --> 00:27:54.370
>> And you're giving this example here
because I feel like your probably more

525
00:27:54.370 --> 00:27:59.010
comfortable working and being able to show
and demonstrate quickly within a CLI.

526
00:27:59.010 --> 00:28:02.410
But if you're new to this and you're
not sure why is he doing it that way,

527
00:28:02.410 --> 00:28:05.790
it's any time you're trying to create that
or communicate with that other device.

528
00:28:05.790 --> 00:28:07.957
So if you were just to use a browser, but

529
00:28:07.957 --> 00:28:12.053
you normally aren't browsing the web
on a server, but just so you know.

530
00:28:12.053 --> 00:28:13.630
>> Yeah, absolutely, in fact,
that's a great point.

531
00:28:13.630 --> 00:28:15.740
Let's go take a look at
that here in just a second.

532
00:28:15.740 --> 00:28:21.030
So if I go to my cache, I'm gonna have
to refresh my console, expand out cache.

533
00:28:21.030 --> 00:28:24.599
And notice everything is back or, at
least, the sites I have been to recently,

534
00:28:24.599 --> 00:28:26.270
starting to repopulate that cache.

535
00:28:26.270 --> 00:28:29.852
But to Cherokee's point earlier, what
I was saying about clearing the cache,

536
00:28:29.852 --> 00:28:31.992
if you don't know exactly
what the problem is,

537
00:28:31.992 --> 00:28:34.178
nothing wrong with
flushing the entire cache.

538
00:28:34.178 --> 00:28:37.260
Understand that DNS response
will be a little bit slower

539
00:28:37.260 --> 00:28:40.120
until you rebuild that cache, but
we're talking milliseconds, right?

540
00:28:40.120 --> 00:28:43.470
We're not talking hours here so
it's not the end of the world.

541
00:28:44.838 --> 00:28:47.490
But if I do know what
the problem record is,

542
00:28:47.490 --> 00:28:52.740
like in the example I was using earlier
with a particular file server, absolutely.

543
00:28:52.740 --> 00:28:55.850
Go in, find the one record for

544
00:28:55.850 --> 00:28:59.770
that file server, right-click and
delete that one record.

545
00:28:59.770 --> 00:29:02.130
Right, that way I'm not
wiping out the entire cache.

546
00:29:02.130 --> 00:29:04.807
Cuz there wasn't anything
wrong with the other stuff.

547
00:29:04.807 --> 00:29:07.926
But I can at least wipe
out that one record and

548
00:29:07.926 --> 00:29:10.719
then see if that's solved my problem.

549
00:29:10.719 --> 00:29:14.775
But if all of the same TTL,
just like the DNS client resolver,

550
00:29:14.775 --> 00:29:16.810
these are cached the same way.

551
00:29:16.810 --> 00:29:19.990
If I look in here,
there's still a TTL associated with it.

552
00:29:19.990 --> 00:29:24.860
It's slowly ticking down so as far as
the cache process goes, no different.

553
00:29:24.860 --> 00:29:29.960
But definitely two different caches, DNS
client resolver cache, DNS server cache.

554
00:29:29.960 --> 00:29:35.350
We're talking about working with the DNS
server cache from the command prompt,

555
00:29:35.350 --> 00:29:36.700
it's not ipconfig, right?

556
00:29:36.700 --> 00:29:41.570
Ipconfig, displaydns, and flushDNS Athat's
for the DNS client resolver cache.

557
00:29:41.570 --> 00:29:45.356
To work with the DNS server cache,
dnscmd and I probably didn't launch

558
00:29:45.356 --> 00:29:49.411
an administrative command prompt,
we're gonna find out here in a second.

559
00:29:49.411 --> 00:29:56.290
Dnscmd/, really it's weird
to look at the zones here.

560
00:29:56.290 --> 00:30:02.510
We're gonna do enumzones, all right,
and yep, access is denied.

561
00:30:02.510 --> 00:30:09.250
So let's pull up an administrative command
prompt, and try that again, all right.

562
00:30:09.250 --> 00:30:13.702
DNS cmd /enumzones is how I can
list all of the zones and really,

563
00:30:13.702 --> 00:30:17.002
when we're dealing with
the DNS server cache,

564
00:30:17.002 --> 00:30:20.760
the cache is treated like
another zone file, right.

565
00:30:20.760 --> 00:30:23.740
Just like my lab at
ITProTV is a zone file.

566
00:30:23.740 --> 00:30:25.140
That's treated like another zone file and

567
00:30:25.140 --> 00:30:29.570
you can see it right here,
it's represented by a dot, all right?

568
00:30:29.570 --> 00:30:34.636
So I can do a dnscmd /zoneprint if I

569
00:30:34.636 --> 00:30:39.718
can spell that, dot, all right?

570
00:30:39.718 --> 00:30:44.740
And there are my good old
cache records as well.

571
00:30:44.740 --> 00:30:48.960
All right, this also shows you a little
bit of information about the server.

572
00:30:48.960 --> 00:30:51.560
Another command you can do, actually,

573
00:30:51.560 --> 00:30:53.620
I don't know if you can
do that with this one.

574
00:30:53.620 --> 00:30:54.490
Nope, I don't think you can.

575
00:30:54.490 --> 00:30:56.820
All right, so that's how you view it.

576
00:30:56.820 --> 00:31:00.924
I'll tell you, I don't use that often,
although it's definitely could be handy.

577
00:31:00.924 --> 00:31:04.120
I wanna have you several times,
so I was clearing the cache.

578
00:31:04.120 --> 00:31:07.293
Again, the server cache,
not the client cache,

579
00:31:07.293 --> 00:31:12.940
dnscmd /clearcache, all right?

580
00:31:12.940 --> 00:31:16.820
Let's make sure there's something in
our cache, so let me refresh this.

581
00:31:18.444 --> 00:31:23.215
All right, so we got all this stuff
in my cache, gonna go over here and

582
00:31:23.215 --> 00:31:25.714
do a dnscmd /clearcache, Enter.

583
00:31:25.714 --> 00:31:28.617
Says, it .completed successfully.

584
00:31:28.617 --> 00:31:29.490
>> Do we trust it?

585
00:31:29.490 --> 00:31:31.130
>> Well, no, we're gonna verify.

586
00:31:31.130 --> 00:31:33.116
Trust but verify, right?
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, always.

587
00:31:33.116 --> 00:31:36.807
>> [LAUGH] I'm gonna refresh, and
sure enough, everything's gone except for

588
00:31:36.807 --> 00:31:40.162
something known as root hints,
which are coming up in another show.

589
00:31:40.162 --> 00:31:42.535
And I know we're just about out of time,
Cherokee.

590
00:31:42.535 --> 00:31:45.414
Let me show you the PowerShell
commands to do the same thing.

591
00:31:45.414 --> 00:31:50.454
Let's ping Google.com, and we'll ping

592
00:31:50.454 --> 00:31:56.060
microsoft.com, get something in our cache.

593
00:31:57.790 --> 00:32:00.190
Oops, that is not a valid command.

594
00:32:00.190 --> 00:32:01.740
And if we take a look at our cache,

595
00:32:01.740 --> 00:32:05.500
we should see that we now have
some things populated in here.

596
00:32:05.500 --> 00:32:07.180
We got Google.

597
00:32:07.180 --> 00:32:09.080
I don't see Microsoft pop up yet.

598
00:32:10.890 --> 00:32:11.410
That's alright.

599
00:32:11.410 --> 00:32:14.333
We've got some stuff in the cache.

600
00:32:14.333 --> 00:32:15.596
And oops, I'm in PowerShell.

601
00:32:15.596 --> 00:32:17.740
There we go.

602
00:32:17.740 --> 00:32:18.960
Wait, what did we do?

603
00:32:18.960 --> 00:32:24.544
Yeah, we did the DNSCMD from
PowerShell to work with the cache.

604
00:32:24.544 --> 00:32:27.735
All right, we want to be able to get

605
00:32:27.735 --> 00:32:36.460
-dnsservercache, and, again,
helps if you spell it right.

606
00:32:39.070 --> 00:32:42.173
And this command, which you think
might return the cache, doesn't.

607
00:32:42.173 --> 00:32:47.110
[LAUGH] What it's actually giving me is
information about the DNS server cache.

608
00:32:47.110 --> 00:32:51.420
It shows me my TTLs, my replication times,
and locking percent, so

609
00:32:51.420 --> 00:32:53.340
it really didn't show
me what I need to see.

610
00:32:53.340 --> 00:32:54.790
So we don't want to use that command.

611
00:32:54.790 --> 00:32:57.692
But I show you that one, because it

612
00:32:57.692 --> 00:33:00.035
You're thinking, okay,
DNS server cache is the noun.

613
00:33:00.035 --> 00:33:03.213
>> I would probably, yeah, automatically
think of get, cuz that's a very common-

614
00:33:03.213 --> 00:33:04.690
>> Get should be my read command, right.

615
00:33:04.690 --> 00:33:06.060
>> Yeah.
>> I mean, it normally is.

616
00:33:06.060 --> 00:33:11.390
But in this case,
it's actually show-dnsservercache.

617
00:33:11.390 --> 00:33:13.580
And that shows you the actual cache,

618
00:33:13.580 --> 00:33:17.940
so get is showing you properties
about the cache itself.

619
00:33:17.940 --> 00:33:19.640
Whereas DNS server,

620
00:33:19.640 --> 00:33:23.540
show DNS server cache just showed you
the records found within the cache.

621
00:33:23.540 --> 00:33:30.000
All right, and then to flush that,
clear-dnsservercache,

622
00:33:30.000 --> 00:33:33.850
and are you sure you want to do with that?

623
00:33:33.850 --> 00:33:37.459
Yes I am, and
if we take a look at it again,

624
00:33:37.459 --> 00:33:43.400
dnsservercache is still populated.

625
00:33:43.400 --> 00:33:45.380
Sorry, I was like,
wait there's still records in there.

626
00:33:45.380 --> 00:33:47.192
The only thing that's left-
>> Root servers-

00:33:47.192 --> 00:33:48.519
>> Are root servers, right,

which we're gonna talk about

We'll explain what those guys are and

And the last thing,
I know I said that was the last thing.

[LAUGH]

You said something about the client, and

the client, and now I don't remember

Let's go ahead and pause, and

00:34:10.771 --> 00:34:14.870
pick right back up with that part,

I changed the name.

00:34:18.411 --> 00:34:19.877

DNS, so

00:34:23.280 --> 00:34:26.950
And hopefully, Mike will remember what

Yeah we talked about-

37
00:01:28.820 --> 00:01:31.818

38

We talked previously about how DNS works
and how we resolve external names.

39
00:01:36.704 --> 00:01:40.240
We know that we have a DNS server
that we maintain in our organization

40
00:01:40.240 --> 00:01:42.420
that handles all local name resolution.

41
00:01:42.420 --> 00:01:45.370
It's authoritative for our organization.

42
00:01:45.370 --> 00:01:46.870
Right?
ITPRO.TV here.

43
00:01:46.870 --> 00:01:48.560
Your organization wherever you are.

44
00:01:48.560 --> 00:01:51.620
You maintain a DNS server for
your own records.

45
00:01:51.620 --> 00:01:53.640
You might not maintain it in-house, right?

46
00:01:53.640 --> 00:01:56.040
You might pay somebody to host it for you.

47
00:01:56.040 --> 00:01:58.380
But you're still responsible for

48
00:01:58.380 --> 00:02:00.980
making sure those records
are hosted somewhere, all right?

49
00:02:00.980 --> 00:02:04.010
But when I wanna resolve external names,

50
00:02:04.010 --> 00:02:07.560
my DNS server doesn't know about
your organizations IP addresses,

51
00:02:07.560 --> 00:02:11.370
or Microsoft's IP addresses, or,
Newgg's IP addresses, right?

52
00:02:11.370 --> 00:02:16.260
So we saw how we went to the root,
the very top, and then we went, root,

53
00:02:16.260 --> 00:02:21.050
and then TLD, and
we found that authoritative DNS Server.

54
00:02:21.050 --> 00:02:26.210
The question we should be asking ourselves
is, how do we get all that started, right?

55
00:02:26.210 --> 00:02:29.140
We said you can't connect to
a machine without an IP address,

56
00:02:29.140 --> 00:02:30.650
you have to have an IP address.

57
00:02:31.990 --> 00:02:34.972
Yet I connected to root,
where was the DNS query that said,

58
00:02:34.972 --> 00:02:37.030
hey, what's the IP address of root, right?

59
00:02:37.030 --> 00:02:38.440
We didn't see any of that, did we?

60
00:02:38.440 --> 00:02:39.491
>> No.
>> No.

61
00:02:39.491 --> 00:02:41.240
>> And it really does bring
up a good point, though.

62
00:02:41.240 --> 00:02:44.758
Because I remember a very long time ago,
when I was first learning about DNS, and

63
00:02:44.758 --> 00:02:45.863
I thought exactly that.

64
00:02:45.863 --> 00:02:48.526
I thought,
Well if we do have those root servers, and

65
00:02:48.526 --> 00:02:52.727
we kind of alluded to this before how they
can't maintain everything, well why do we

66
00:02:52.727 --> 00:02:54.860
even need our private DNS servers-
>> Right.

67
00:02:54.860 --> 00:02:56.240
>> If they can store all that?

68
00:02:56.240 --> 00:02:57.974
>> Yeah.
>> But in all actuality they really can't.

69
00:02:57.974 --> 00:02:59.146
>> Yeah.
>> So that's why we need that.

70
00:02:59.146 --> 00:03:02.342
>> Yeah, it'd be way too much work.

71
00:03:02.342 --> 00:03:07.525
So, how does my DNS server start that
external name resolution process and

72
00:03:07.525 --> 00:03:10.662
find that route server and
work its way down?

73
00:03:10.662 --> 00:03:12.710
And that's what the route hints are,
right?

74
00:03:12.710 --> 00:03:15.620
Route hints are just that, hints.

75
00:03:15.620 --> 00:03:18.090
Hey, the IP address of the root is, right?

76
00:03:18.090 --> 00:03:20.123
It's a little hint for
my DNS server, it's kinda preloaded.

77
00:03:20.123 --> 00:03:21.828
>> And
you didn't have to manually put that in.

78
00:03:21.828 --> 00:03:24.047
>> No, absolutely not,
let's go check it out.

79
00:03:24.047 --> 00:03:28.060
All right, if we go to Tools and,
evidently I'm not on the right machine,

80
00:03:28.060 --> 00:03:31.712
I'm on server one, so
let's switch over to my domain controller.

81
00:03:31.712 --> 00:03:32.604
>> The one that's running DNS.

82
00:03:32.604 --> 00:03:35.610
>> Yeah, having DNS running makes it
easier to open up the DNS console.

83
00:03:35.610 --> 00:03:39.370
And if we take a look at the properties,
not of my zone right.

84
00:03:39.370 --> 00:03:44.300
Not any one of my zones but of the server
itself this is a server level property.

85
00:03:44.300 --> 00:03:48.270
We're gonna see a tab known
as the root hints, all right?

86
00:03:48.270 --> 00:03:51.060
Or a tab called root hints, known as.

87
00:03:51.060 --> 00:03:54.280
And in here, there they are, I think
Cherokee you mentioned the other day

88
00:03:54.280 --> 00:03:58.520
that there were 13 root servers, right,
A through M is how they're designated.

89
00:03:58.520 --> 00:04:02.463
And there they are, A through M,
and their IP addresses.

90
00:04:02.463 --> 00:04:04.734
Keep in mind, which also I think
Cherokee also pointed out,

91
00:04:04.734 --> 00:04:07.540
that's not thirteen individual
servers sitting out there.

92
00:04:07.540 --> 00:04:10.570
Each one, A, this one IP address,

436
00:20:38.400 --> 00:20:41.809
Forwarding is when I
tell my DNS server to,

437
00:20:41.809 --> 00:20:47.505

438
00:20:47.505 --> 00:20:48.863

439
00:20:48.863 --> 00:20:53.870
Now somebody comes up and asks me,

00:20:53.870 --> 00:20:57.490
And I say, hm, Cherokee,

00:20:57.490 --> 00:20:59.730

00:20:59.730 --> 00:21:03.200
And now, since she's the IPV6 expert,

443
00:21:03.200 --> 00:21:05.450
That's really what's going on with DNS,
right?

444
00:21:05.450 --> 00:21:08.570
You're just forwarding
the query to somebody else.

445
00:21:08.570 --> 00:21:15.468
So like my DNS server, for example, is
authoritative for my domain, lab.itpro.tv.

446
00:21:15.468 --> 00:21:18.955
When it wants to resolve an external name,
it goes to the root and

447
00:21:18.955 --> 00:21:20.064
works its way down.

448
00:21:20.064 --> 00:21:24.240
What I could do though is tell my

00:21:24.240 --> 00:21:26.783
the only thing it knows is lab.itpro.tv.

450
00:21:26.783 --> 00:21:30.413
Anything you don't know,
forward it onto this other DNS server and

451
00:21:30.413 --> 00:21:31.566
let them do the work.

00:22:08.330 --> 00:22:11.604
All right so forwarding,
here's my little domain over here, and

let's just zoom into this area for

471
00:22:13.834 --> 00:22:18.782
So here's my little domain,
right, ITPro.TV's DNS server.

472
00:22:18.782 --> 00:22:22.681
I've got a client, he sends a query
over to my local DNS server,

473
00:22:22.681 --> 00:22:26.890
right with those TCP IP settings,
tell him to send everything here.

474
00:22:26.890 --> 00:22:31.540
And what's going to happen is when
that DNS server gets that query for

475
00:22:31.540 --> 00:22:35.068
an external name and
I've configured forwarding,

476
00:22:35.068 --> 00:22:40.460
it instead of going to the route, like
we did with our externaling resolution.

477
00:22:40.460 --> 00:22:45.080
If you remember over here,
I sent the query to my local DNS server.

478
00:22:45.080 --> 00:22:50.040
My DNS server then went to the route, and
then to the TLD, the top level domain and

479
00:22:50.040 --> 00:22:53.330
then to the authoritative DNS server,
and got the answer.

480
00:22:53.330 --> 00:23:00.140
Remember, my client sent a recursive query
which requires an answer to my DNS server.

481
00:23:00.140 --> 00:23:03.530
My DNS server sent iterative
queries to the root, the TLD,

482
00:23:03.530 --> 00:23:07.210
and Microsoft to either get an answer or

483
00:23:07.210 --> 00:23:11.520
a referral to somebody else that
might know to finally get the answer.

484
00:23:11.520 --> 00:23:15.840
When we look at forwarding my DNS
server now instead of hitting the root

485
00:23:15.840 --> 00:23:19.400
is just going to forward it
on to another DNS server.

486
00:23:19.400 --> 00:23:21.078
And we pick which DNS server,

487
00:23:21.078 --> 00:23:24.175
we tell it what IP address
to forward those queries to.

488
00:23:24.175 --> 00:23:26.014
Notice the arrow is red, right?

489
00:23:26.014 --> 00:23:29.004
And I think my key is up here,
red is recursive, so

490
00:23:29.004 --> 00:23:34.080
it's not just sending an iterative query
saying, hey, do you know the IP address?

491
00:23:34.080 --> 00:23:37.940
Or can you point me to somebody else that
does like DNS normally does when it's

492
00:23:37.940 --> 00:23:41.270
dealing with external DNS servers.

493
00:23:41.270 --> 00:23:44.752
It's saying hey,
here's a question that somebody asked me.

494
00:23:44.752 --> 00:23:48.950
You go deal with it and I'll sit here and
wait until you get the answer.

495
00:23:48.950 --> 00:23:53.306
And the server that you forwarded it to
then goes through the process of going to

496
00:23:53.306 --> 00:23:58.005
the root, the TLD, and finally to the
authoritative server, getting a response.

497
00:23:58.005 --> 00:24:04.022
And then sending it back to my DNS server,
who then replies to my DNS client, right?

498
00:24:04.022 --> 00:24:06.113
So that's the idea behind forwarding.

499
00:24:06.113 --> 00:24:07.733
It's forwarded on to somebody else.

500
00:24:07.733 --> 00:24:12.472
And let them do all the work, that way,
your DNS servers can do what it does best,

501
00:24:12.472 --> 00:24:15.990
resolve local names,
right internal names for my domain.

502
00:24:15.990 --> 00:24:20.680
And that's really one of the big reasons
we would use something like this

503
00:24:20.680 --> 00:24:24.920
is to offload some of the work
from my local DNS server.

504
00:24:24.920 --> 00:24:29.140
And typically we'll use it
like my ISP's DNS server.

505
00:24:29.140 --> 00:24:32.640
You think about your ISP,
your internet service provider, and

506
00:24:32.640 --> 00:24:35.380
they've got thousands and
thousands of clients.

507
00:24:35.380 --> 00:24:37.510
They have the backbone right?

508
00:24:37.510 --> 00:24:39.440
They're probably connected to
the backbone of the internet.

509
00:24:39.440 --> 00:24:41.720
They've got big bad DNS servers.

510
00:24:41.720 --> 00:24:44.080
And those servers
are caching responses for

511
00:24:44.080 --> 00:24:46.930
all of their clients
that they're servicing.

512
00:24:46.930 --> 00:24:50.980
So the cache on those DNS servers is
gonna have a lot of information in there.

513
00:24:50.980 --> 00:24:55.030
So by forwarding it on to them,
I get a couple of benefits.

514
00:24:55.030 --> 00:24:56.250
I let their servers do the work.

515
00:24:56.250 --> 00:24:59.400
My DNS server is not doing
all of the heavy lifting.

516
00:24:59.400 --> 00:25:02.280
Their DNS servers are beefy, hopefully.

517
00:25:02.280 --> 00:25:03.882
I know some ISPs might not be.

518
00:25:03.882 --> 00:25:04.394
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

519
00:25:04.394 --> 00:25:05.640
>> But they've got big,

520
00:25:05.640 --> 00:25:08.430
bad beefy DNS servers that
are connected to the backbone.

521
00:25:08.430 --> 00:25:11.100
And they've got the bandwidth,
and they've got a huge cache.

522
00:25:11.100 --> 00:25:14.020
So there's a good chance that
the DNS server from a ISP

523
00:25:14.020 --> 00:25:15.985
already knows the IP
address I'm looking for.

524
00:25:15.985 --> 00:25:20.540
Because one of their other thousands of
clients has gone to that site recently and

525
00:25:20.540 --> 00:25:21.180
it's cached.

526
00:25:22.710 --> 00:25:24.420
So we'll just forward it onto them, right?

527
00:25:24.420 --> 00:25:27.080
Forward it onto your ISP's DNS.

528
00:25:27.080 --> 00:25:32.590
Another scenario where we might see
forwarding is internally, right?

529
00:25:32.590 --> 00:25:38.730
I might have a scenario like this where I
have multiple servers within my domain.

530
00:25:38.730 --> 00:25:42.580
And I have only one DNS server I wanna

531
00:25:42.580 --> 00:25:44.370
All right, these servers in here,

532
00:25:44.370 --> 00:25:48.650
I want them primarily to support the
thousands of internal clients that I have.

533
00:25:48.650 --> 00:25:52.020
And I wanna make sure my DNS
response times are quick.

534
00:25:52.020 --> 00:25:54.810
So I've said, you know what,
you guys don't worry about

535
00:25:54.810 --> 00:25:58.360
external name resolution,
just do internal name resolution.

536
00:25:58.360 --> 00:26:01.170
Anything that's external
forward it over to

537
00:26:01.170 --> 00:26:03.100
this over DNS server that I maintain,
right?

538
00:26:03.100 --> 00:26:03.890
This is not the ISP.

539
00:26:03.890 --> 00:26:05.710
This is my DNS server.

540
00:26:05.710 --> 00:26:09.410
And let this DNS server do all
the external name resolution.

541
00:26:09.410 --> 00:26:11.100
So now I'm segregating the work, right?

542
00:26:11.100 --> 00:26:14.790
I've got some DNS servers that are
focusing in on internal name resolution.

543
00:26:14.790 --> 00:26:15.520
I've got one or

544
00:26:15.520 --> 00:26:20.440
more DNS servers that I forward to that
are doing my external name resolution.

545
00:26:20.440 --> 00:26:24.840
And in a scenario like this, it might
be maybe the servers not in front but

546
00:26:24.840 --> 00:26:26.420
behind the firewall.

547
00:26:26.420 --> 00:26:29.220
But he might be the only one that's
allowed to go through the firewall to do

548
00:26:29.220 --> 00:26:30.580
external name resolution.

549
00:26:30.580 --> 00:26:31.240
Right?

550
00:26:31.240 --> 00:26:36.000
Or this guy might be out in my DMZ but
either way,

551
00:26:36.000 --> 00:26:40.370
all external name resolution is getting
funneled through that one DNS server.

552
00:26:40.370 --> 00:26:43.720
Which means this cash is gonna
have everything that all my users

553
00:26:43.720 --> 00:26:44.820
are resolving.

554
00:26:44.820 --> 00:26:47.040
And most of my users go to the same sites.

555
00:26:47.040 --> 00:26:50.530
Right, they are using the same kind of
resources connecting to the same business

556
00:26:50.530 --> 00:26:51.530
partners.

557
00:26:51.530 --> 00:26:56.290
So by doing that rather than splitting
cash across two machines you might

558
00:26:56.290 --> 00:26:58.728
be talking of the DNS server
that's cached it, you might not.

559
00:26:58.728 --> 00:27:01.300
All the cache is now
kind of right here and

560
00:27:01.300 --> 00:27:03.435
it becomes that central repository for
the cache.

[COUGH] Excuse me so

00:27:05.430 --> 00:27:11.680
that's another scenario where we
