00:27:16.110 --> 00:27:19.710
So I am on,
let's make sure we're on the right server.

565
00:27:19.710 --> 00:27:23.940
I'm on DCO1 and right now DCO1
can resolves external names.

566
00:27:23.940 --> 00:27:26.954
Right, google.com because we
fixed our root server issue.

567
00:27:26.954 --> 00:27:28.640
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, everything is fine there.

568
00:27:28.640 --> 00:27:29.900
>> Yeah.

569
00:27:29.900 --> 00:27:34.110
>> Right, but at this point my server
is going to the root to the TLD and

570
00:27:34.110 --> 00:27:37.470
doing all the work for
those external resolutions.

571
00:27:37.470 --> 00:27:42.470
So, what I'm gonna do I'm going to come in
here to the properties of my DNS server.

572
00:27:42.470 --> 00:27:43.190
Okay?

573
00:27:43.190 --> 00:27:45.160
And I'm gonna go to the forwarder's tab.

574
00:27:45.160 --> 00:27:48.340
Forwarders or DNS server that the server
can use to resolve DNS queries for

575
00:27:48.340 --> 00:27:50.870
records that this server cannot resolve.

576
00:27:50.870 --> 00:27:52.415
Again, I'm only responsible for

577
00:27:52.415 --> 00:27:56.110
ITPRO.TV that's the only record
I have on this DNS server.

578
00:27:56.110 --> 00:28:01.950
So, we gonna to set up a forwarder we
gonna click edit And then we're gonna

579
00:28:01.950 --> 00:28:05.140
type in an IP address of an external DNS
server, let's forward it out to Google.

580
00:28:06.230 --> 00:28:07.800
They've got big bad beefy DNS servers,

581
00:28:07.800 --> 00:28:10.900
I'm sure they won't mind
a couple extra queries.

582
00:28:10.900 --> 00:28:14.560
And so there we go, I put in the IP
address, it'll attempt to resolve it.

583
00:28:14.560 --> 00:28:17.320
But I've already got my green up,
there it goes, it got the name.

584
00:28:17.320 --> 00:28:19.720
And then we'll click okay.

585
00:28:19.720 --> 00:28:21.850
And now I've got a forwarder, right?

586
00:28:21.850 --> 00:28:24.630
Now once you set up
the forwarder it's gonna work

587
00:28:24.630 --> 00:28:26.150
like I just showed you in that diagram.

588
00:28:26.150 --> 00:28:30.110
External names, anything that this server
does not know it's just gonna forward it

589
00:28:30.110 --> 00:28:33.350
on to the other disk DNS
server that I specified.

590
00:28:33.350 --> 00:28:36.400
And let them do the work and
wait for the response.

591
00:28:36.400 --> 00:28:38.500
What if this server's not responding?

592
00:28:38.500 --> 00:28:39.410
All right.

593
00:28:39.410 --> 00:28:43.180
What if I've tried to forward
the query over to that DNS server, but

594
00:28:43.180 --> 00:28:44.090
the DNS server was not there.

595
00:28:44.090 --> 00:28:44.720
All right.

596
00:28:44.720 --> 00:28:47.360
Because it's down, you know,
whatever the case may be unavailable.

597
00:28:48.750 --> 00:28:52.430
With this check mark,
checked, use root hints if

598
00:28:53.790 --> 00:28:58.090
no forwarders are available, I'll still
be able to resolve external names.

599
00:28:58.090 --> 00:29:02.340
What will happen, is my server will
forward it out, but if we looked at the,

600
00:29:02.340 --> 00:29:04.030
let me edit this.

601
00:29:04.030 --> 00:29:06.650
It's got number of seconds before
forwarded queries times out.

602
00:29:06.650 --> 00:29:08.060
It's got three seconds.

603
00:29:08.060 --> 00:29:11.940
So it will attempt for three seconds
to forward the query to Google, and

604
00:29:11.940 --> 00:29:13.270
let Google do the work.

605
00:29:13.270 --> 00:29:17.540
If that fails, however, it will fall
back to the default behavior and

606
00:29:17.540 --> 00:29:21.270
it will go out to the root and
work it's way down, all right.

607
00:29:21.270 --> 00:29:24.950
Assuming we still have our root hints in
there and we fixed our problem earlier.

608
00:29:24.950 --> 00:29:28.650
If I don't want that to happen,
I can uncheck this.

609
00:29:28.650 --> 00:29:32.260
If I uncheck use routers
of no phones available

610
00:29:32.260 --> 00:29:34.100
What'll happen is it'll forward it.

611
00:29:34.100 --> 00:29:36.550
But if that forwarding
fails the query will fail.

612
00:29:36.550 --> 00:29:39.810
It will not attempt to
resolve the name on its own.

613
00:29:39.810 --> 00:29:41.790
And that might be what you want right?

614
00:29:41.790 --> 00:29:46.090
It depends on the environment that you're
in, how you have your organization set up.

615
00:29:46.090 --> 00:29:47.080
So let's test it out here.

616
00:29:47.080 --> 00:29:48.100
I forwarded everything out.

617
00:29:48.100 --> 00:29:50.850
But I said use root hints if
no forwarder is available.

618
00:29:50.850 --> 00:29:55.940
I'm going to click okay, and let's ping
something that we haven't pinged before.

619
00:29:55.940 --> 00:29:59.150
Cherokee, what's amazon.com?

620
00:29:59.150 --> 00:29:59.650
>> Sure.

621
00:30:00.920 --> 00:30:02.540
>> Maybe, all right, so there we go.

622
00:30:02.540 --> 00:30:04.000
So I've resolved the name.

623
00:30:04.000 --> 00:30:07.330
From here I can't really
tell who I resolved it from.

624
00:30:07.330 --> 00:30:08.920
I mean there are ways
we can go dig in there,

625
00:30:08.920 --> 00:30:13.360
but an easier way to show you that
it's working is gonna be to do this.

626
00:30:13.360 --> 00:30:17.880
If we go back into those forwarders,
I'm gonna pull up the properties.

627
00:30:19.590 --> 00:30:26.600
I'm gonna go to forwarders, and
I'm gonna edit this and I'm gonna put in.

628
00:30:26.600 --> 00:30:27.250
>> Something random.

629
00:30:27.250 --> 00:30:30.180
>> I don't know, 12.1.2.3 yeah something
that I'm for sure not a DNS server.

630
00:30:30.180 --> 00:30:31.643
>> Watch it work [LAUGH], okay yeah.

631
00:30:31.643 --> 00:30:34.410
>> [LAUGH] I'm pretty sure
it's not a DNS server.

632
00:30:34.410 --> 00:30:38.530
And I'll click okay, and
I'll click okay right?

633
00:30:38.530 --> 00:30:41.644
And let's go flush my cache.

634
00:30:41.644 --> 00:30:45.600
So, ipconfig/flushdns.

635
00:30:45.600 --> 00:30:51.040
We'll also flash the cache on the server
so that that Amazon is not cached,

636
00:30:51.040 --> 00:30:55.680
and then we are gonna try to ping Amazon
again, Now, let see what happens.

637
00:30:55.680 --> 00:31:02.590
One, two, three,
common baby you can do it.

638
00:31:04.150 --> 00:31:06.050
It's thinking about it.

639
00:31:06.050 --> 00:31:07.990
Oop, and there you goes it could find,

640
00:31:07.990 --> 00:31:10.965
that is not exactly what
I expected it to do.

641
00:31:10.965 --> 00:31:15.720
What it should have done was,
went ahead and used root hints and

642
00:31:15.720 --> 00:31:17.390
resolved the name anyway.

643
00:31:18.710 --> 00:31:21.070
Interesting, so
let's take a look at my settings and see.

644
00:31:21.070 --> 00:31:25.313
Boy, I'll tell you what,
this is a trouble-shooting episode.

645
00:31:25.313 --> 00:31:28.130
Use root hints if no
forwarders are available.

646
00:31:28.130 --> 00:31:33.870
>> Do you think all your
root hints are healthy now?

647
00:31:33.870 --> 00:31:35.300
>> Yeah, they should be.

648
00:31:36.400 --> 00:31:38.190
There it goes.
It was just a little slow.

649
00:31:38.190 --> 00:31:41.620
So it is still able to resolve amazon.com.

650
00:31:41.620 --> 00:31:43.830
I just did not wait long enough for
it to time out.

651
00:31:43.830 --> 00:31:45.580
>> I never wait long enough for things.

652
00:31:45.580 --> 00:31:47.090
>> I know I am impatient.

653
00:31:47.090 --> 00:31:50.900
So it is still able to resolve names
ever though I put in a fake forwarder.

654
00:31:50.900 --> 00:31:52.490
I go back to those properties.

655
00:31:52.490 --> 00:31:54.510
I do not know if I even
want to test this now.

656
00:31:54.510 --> 00:31:55.380
Click OK.

657
00:31:55.380 --> 00:31:57.390
Do not use root hents, right?

658
00:31:57.390 --> 00:31:58.030
And we'll click OK.

659
00:31:58.030 --> 00:32:00.050
>> So if we clear the cache-
>> We'll flush the cache.

660
00:32:00.050 --> 00:32:02.780
>> Yeah, and then now we should
expect it not to work, right?

661
00:32:02.780 --> 00:32:05.236
>> Yep, and we'll do another flush here.

662
00:32:07.225 --> 00:32:11.580
And now we'll try to ping amazon.com.

663
00:32:11.580 --> 00:32:13.085
And we'll see how patient I can be.

664
00:32:13.085 --> 00:32:14.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

665
00:32:14.120 --> 00:32:17.440
it could not find hostname amazon.com.

666
00:32:17.440 --> 00:32:19.635
Because now it doesn't have a choice,
I tried to forward it.

667
00:32:19.635 --> 00:32:22.541
I've taken away it's ability
to use wood hens and

668
00:32:22.541 --> 00:32:27.950
since the forwarder in this case doesn't
exist, it can't do anything all right.

669
00:32:27.950 --> 00:32:32.080
So let's fix that back if I go back
into the properties of my server and

670
00:32:32.080 --> 00:32:35.450
I edit that forwarder and

671
00:32:35.450 --> 00:32:39.989
I change that back to 8.8.8.8.

672
00:32:41.330 --> 00:32:44.680
Click OK, and OK, and we flush our cache.

673
00:32:46.730 --> 00:32:49.200
And our clear cache, flush cache.

674
00:32:51.452 --> 00:32:54.170
And we ping amazon.com again.

675
00:32:54.170 --> 00:32:56.540
There we go,
we are back in business, right.

676
00:32:56.540 --> 00:33:00.710
So that's how you set up forwarders and
why we would use forwarders.

677
00:33:00.710 --> 00:33:01.620
And we got some more to do.

678
00:33:01.620 --> 00:33:05.760
We've go conditional forwarding we
also have stubs zones to go over.

679
00:33:05.760 --> 00:33:08.560
But I'm getting that signal over
here telling me that I might have

680
00:33:08.560 --> 00:33:09.460
talked a little to long.

681
00:33:09.460 --> 00:33:11.620
>> I know people are probably so
afraid of me now.

682
00:33:11.620 --> 00:33:15.940
Like I'm gonna strangle you or
something if you don't do it on time.

683
00:33:15.940 --> 00:33:17.590
No, but you are right we are out of time.

684
00:33:17.590 --> 00:33:20.770
But that's okay because we can always
come back for another great episode.

685
00:33:20.770 --> 00:33:23.700
So thank you for that today and
thank you for joining us as well.

686
00:33:23.700 --> 00:33:26.030
You don't want to miss
what we have coming next.

687
00:33:26.030 --> 00:33:27.570
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

688
00:33:27.570 --> 00:33:28.360
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

689
00:33:28.360 --> 00:33:30.243
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

690
00:33:30.243 --> 00:33:37.369
[MUSIC]

691
00:33:37.369 --> 00:33:40.024
>> Thank you for watching ITPROTV.

episodes.title: Configure DNS Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.150 --> 00:00:02.640
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.640 --> 00:00:06.048
We're coming at you live from
San Francisco, California.

3
00:00:06.048 --> 00:00:06.570
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.570 --> 00:00:08.195
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.195 --> 00:00:11.980
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.980 --> 00:00:15.317
>> Welcome back to another great
episode here at ITProTV, in this show

7
00:00:15.317 --> 00:00:19.236
specifically, we'll continue on our DNS
journey and we'll take a look at some

8
00:00:19.236 --> 00:00:23.350
different types of forwarders, conditional
forwarding, dynamic forwarding.

9
00:00:23.350 --> 00:00:26.109
I think Mike has quite an assortment
of forwarding for us here in DNS today.

10
00:00:26.109 --> 00:00:29.920
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, I'd like to welcome you back.

11
00:00:29.920 --> 00:00:31.634
Thank you for joining us today, Mike.

12
00:00:31.634 --> 00:00:32.679
>> Thanks for inviting me back.

13
00:00:32.679 --> 00:00:34.604
>> Yeah.
>> And not saying that guy talks too much,

14
00:00:34.604 --> 00:00:36.590
don't put him on any more of your shows.

15
00:00:36.590 --> 00:00:38.420
Yeah, thanks for
having me back and you're right,

16
00:00:38.420 --> 00:00:40.150
we do have some more forwarding to do.

17
00:00:40.150 --> 00:00:44.880
A few different types that we wanna take a
look at as we are configuring our DNS and

18
00:00:44.880 --> 00:00:48.450
making sure that it's running optimally,
and optimized for performance.

19
00:00:48.450 --> 00:00:52.640
Cuz that's really what we want to do, we
want to make sure that the name resolution

20
00:00:52.640 --> 00:00:56.440
is functioning, one, because we need to
resolve those names and IP addresses.

21
00:00:56.440 --> 00:01:00.100
And that it's doing it in, in,
in a decent amount of time, right?

22
00:01:00.100 --> 00:01:03.920
Everybody out there has been in a scenario
where you type in a web address or

23
00:01:03.920 --> 00:01:09.160
a URL, or a share resource location,
a UNC path.

24
00:01:09.160 --> 00:01:13.570
And we get the spinning cheerio or the
flippy floppy hour glass, and you are like

25
00:01:13.570 --> 00:01:15.161
>> The flippy floppy hour glass?

26
00:01:15.161 --> 00:01:17.482
>> Yeah, the flippy floppy hour glass.
>> [LAUGH]

27
00:01:17.482 --> 00:01:18.425
>> There used to be an animated one,

28
00:01:18.425 --> 00:01:19.444
I don't know if it's still there.

29
00:01:19.444 --> 00:01:20.480
>> I remember.

30
00:01:20.480 --> 00:01:22.790
>> But that is annoying, right.

31
00:01:22.790 --> 00:01:26.990
And I tell you, it's enough to make me
close my browser and do something else.

32
00:01:26.990 --> 00:01:27.945
I don't like waiting.

33
00:01:27.945 --> 00:01:29.970
I'm very impatient for things like that.

34
00:01:29.970 --> 00:01:34.350
All right, so and we don't want our users
doing that, we want them succeeding and

35
00:01:34.350 --> 00:01:35.460
making money for our company.

36
00:01:35.460 --> 00:01:36.973
>> Do as I say, not as I do.

37
00:01:36.973 --> 00:01:38.661
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] all right.

38
00:01:38.661 --> 00:01:40.980
so we talked about forwarding.

39
00:01:40.980 --> 00:01:45.480
Forwarding, we said anything this DNS
server does not know on his own, so

40
00:01:45.480 --> 00:01:48.870
anything that he doesn't have a zone
file for and it's not authoritative for.

41
00:01:48.870 --> 00:01:52.170
Just send it onto somebody else,
whoever we've configured, and

42
00:01:52.170 --> 00:01:53.120
let them do the work.

43
00:01:53.120 --> 00:01:57.520
Remember, it's a recursive query, that
we forward on to the other DNS server.

44
00:01:57.520 --> 00:02:00.440
Let them do the work, and
then just give us back the answer.

45
00:02:00.440 --> 00:02:03.130
We'll cache the answer and
we'll send it on to the client.

46
00:02:03.130 --> 00:02:04.600
The client will cache the answer.

47
00:02:04.600 --> 00:02:06.080
None of that part changes.

48
00:02:06.080 --> 00:02:10.025
It's just who's doing the work for
resolving the query, all right?

49
00:02:11.285 --> 00:02:12.805
Next thing we're gonna talk about,

50
00:02:12.805 --> 00:02:16.575
is something known as conditional
forwarding, all right?

51
00:02:16.575 --> 00:02:17.595
Conditional forwarding.

52
00:02:17.595 --> 00:02:18.815
And if we think about the name, right,

53
00:02:18.815 --> 00:02:22.335
we're gonna forward based on a condition,
all right?

54
00:02:22.335 --> 00:02:26.560
And the condition is,
what is the DNS suffix for

55
00:02:26.560 --> 00:02:29.700
the name that you're trying to resolve?

56
00:02:29.700 --> 00:02:33.130
In other words,
if the name ends in xyz.com,

57
00:02:33.130 --> 00:02:37.850
I want you to forward it to
this particular DNS server.

58
00:02:37.850 --> 00:02:40.790
Now we can get a little more
specific with our forwarding.

59
00:02:40.790 --> 00:02:43.470
That's what conditional
forwarding is all about.

60
00:02:43.470 --> 00:02:44.490
All right.

61
00:02:44.490 --> 00:02:47.380
And it allows me,
I'm gonna pull up a drawing here, so

62
00:02:47.380 --> 00:02:48.870
let's take a peek at my screen.

63
00:02:48.870 --> 00:02:50.360
I think I still have it up.

64
00:02:50.360 --> 00:02:52.080
Got our conditional
forwarding set up here.

65
00:02:53.530 --> 00:02:58.465
And with the conditional forwarding,
what do I have here,

66
00:02:58.465 --> 00:03:01.875
I've got a domain, Contoso.com,
sitting over here, right?

67
00:03:01.875 --> 00:03:04.355
Contoso's DNS server,
we're the authoritative for that.

68
00:03:04.355 --> 00:03:06.105
And without conditional forwarding,

69
00:03:06.105 --> 00:03:08.955
I could still connect to
Contoso's DNS server, right?

70
00:03:08.955 --> 00:03:13.200
Because my DNS server,
either using forwarders or

71
00:03:13.200 --> 00:03:16.170
doing it itself, would go to route, and

72
00:03:16.170 --> 00:03:20.060
then the TLD, find the authoritative
server, and get the response.

73
00:03:20.060 --> 00:03:21.280
All right?

74
00:03:21.280 --> 00:03:25.400
What conditional forwarding allows me
to do is shortcut this entire process.

75
00:03:25.400 --> 00:03:29.860
When my DNS server, when my client sends
a query to the DNS server, and says, hey,

76
00:03:29.860 --> 00:03:34.380
what is the IP address of www.contoso.com?

77
00:03:34.380 --> 00:03:37.234
My DNS server says wait a second,
contoso.com.

78
00:03:37.234 --> 00:03:39.160
And it looks at its
conditional forwarding rules.

79
00:03:39.160 --> 00:03:44.250
And it says I know the IP address of
the authoritative server for contoso.com.

80
00:03:44.250 --> 00:03:46.130
I don't have to ask anybody.

81
00:03:46.130 --> 00:03:48.780
I can go straight to the horse's mouth,
if you will, right?

82
00:03:48.780 --> 00:03:51.500
Right to the source and
get the information.

83
00:03:51.500 --> 00:03:53.570
>> So we're just kinda speeding
that process up a bit?

84
00:03:53.570 --> 00:03:55.970
>> Exactly,
we're shortcutting the whole process.

85
00:03:55.970 --> 00:04:00.590
There is no more avenue, started the root,
it's cuz really the goal of going through

86
00:04:00.590 --> 00:04:04.030
the iterative queries is to find
the authoritative DNS server.

87
00:04:04.030 --> 00:04:05.990
That's the whole point of all that.

88
00:04:05.990 --> 00:04:09.550
And so if I can tell my DNS server,
who the authoritative server is,

89
00:04:09.550 --> 00:04:10.869
we can go straight to it.

90
00:04:10.869 --> 00:04:11.982
>> Right past those other steps.

91
00:04:11.982 --> 00:04:13.050
>> Yeah, exactly.

92
00:04:13.050 --> 00:04:15.170
And that's gonna speed up the process.

93
00:04:15.170 --> 00:04:17.460
I'm not gonna do that with everybody,
right?

94
00:04:17.460 --> 00:04:21.800
I could, I could go out, start doing my
research and go, new eggs, DNS server.

95
00:04:21.800 --> 00:04:23.010
Here's their IP address.

96
00:04:23.010 --> 00:04:25.000
I'm gonna put a conditional
forwarding rule in there.

97
00:04:25.000 --> 00:04:26.450
We're not doing that for everybody.

98
00:04:26.450 --> 00:04:28.227
DNS is a pretty quick service as it is.

99
00:04:28.227 --> 00:04:29.280
>> It happens, yeah, I was gonna say.

100
00:04:29.280 --> 00:04:30.275
It happens fast anyway.

101
00:04:30.275 --> 00:04:34.145
So I think it might be beneficial
in a situation like a merger or

102
00:04:34.145 --> 00:04:37.875
acquisition of an organization that hasn't
the infrastructure already built up, and

103
00:04:37.875 --> 00:04:40.285
you're doing a lot of
communication between them but-

104
00:04:40.285 --> 00:04:41.025
>> Exactly right,

105
00:04:41.025 --> 00:04:44.185

And it's never gonna get rid of

The reason that works all the time

not just this cache, but other caches

00:26:46.810 --> 00:26:50.898

But stub zones are another way we can do

I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

785
00:40:01.410 --> 00:40:02.940
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.
>> See you next time.

786
00:40:02.940 --> 00:40:10.963
[MUSIC]

787
00:40:10.963 --> 00:40:13.203
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.title: IPv4 and IPv6 Interoperability
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.340 --> 00:00:03.199
Welcome to IT Pro TV, I'm your host-

2
00:00:03.199 --> 00:00:08.148
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.148 --> 00:00:10.710
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:12.650 --> 00:00:15.260
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:15.260 --> 00:00:19.910
You're watching the NCSA for
Windows Server 2012 show.

6
00:00:19.910 --> 00:00:24.550
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and today
we're gonna be taking a look at IP version

7
00:00:24.550 --> 00:00:28.850
4 and IP version 6 interoperability,
which is kind of a big word here.

8
00:00:28.850 --> 00:00:32.670
So for us, as we get started in
understanding this better, we have Ms.

9
00:00:32.670 --> 00:00:34.360
Cherokee Boose to help us out.

10
00:00:34.360 --> 00:00:35.540
Cherokee, how are you doing?

11
00:00:35.540 --> 00:00:36.680
>> I'm doing great, Ronnie.

12
00:00:36.680 --> 00:00:42.030
Yeah, interoperability's kind of like, hey
we've already talk about IPB 4 and IPB 6.

13
00:00:42.030 --> 00:00:45.820
But specifically in this show, we'll be
taking a look at, well how we can have

14
00:00:45.820 --> 00:00:49.010
machines that are running on different
network types to be able to communicate

15
00:00:49.010 --> 00:00:53.680
with each other because, well, let's face
it, you may come across that situation.

16
00:00:53.680 --> 00:00:56.590
We're in this weird transitional mode

17
00:00:56.590 --> 00:01:01.500
where we're trying to get everyone on
the same page and move forward with IPV6.

18
00:01:01.500 --> 00:01:07.430
Its been happening for over a decade
now but not everyone's quite there yet

19
00:01:07.430 --> 00:01:11.520
so, in the other show when we
were talking about IPV4 and

20
00:01:11.520 --> 00:01:14.865
IPV6, i was trying to stress
to you how important it was.

21
00:01:14.865 --> 00:01:19.485
To familiarize yourself with
those address prefixes.

22
00:01:19.485 --> 00:01:23.735
So if we can begin this show, I just
want to start by reminding you again,

23
00:01:23.735 --> 00:01:27.582
if we take a look at me screen I
want to show some different prefix.

24
00:01:27.582 --> 00:01:30.932
But, specifically, like I said in
this show, we'll be focusing and

25
00:01:30.932 --> 00:01:36.622
narrowing in on a few type of what
are called transitional mechanisms,

26
00:01:36.622 --> 00:01:38.530
transitional technologies-
>> Right.

27
00:01:38.530 --> 00:01:42.477
>> You may hear, so we'll start
with something called six to four.

28
00:01:42.477 --> 00:01:44.982
And we'll also take a look at Teredo.

29
00:01:44.982 --> 00:01:48.330
And we'll take a look at another
technology called ISATAP.

30
00:01:48.330 --> 00:01:52.880
And the reason I'm pointing this out
to you right now is because the prefix

31
00:01:52.880 --> 00:01:56.880
is going to be an integral part
of the address to clue you in and

32
00:01:56.880 --> 00:02:01.710
let you know, give you a clue
about maybe if you're studying, or

33
00:02:01.710 --> 00:02:05.400
you're taking an exam, or
you're just configuring a machine.

34
00:02:05.400 --> 00:02:07.720
When you're looking at output
from some type of tool,

35
00:02:07.720 --> 00:02:11.360
you'll want to be able to just
be able to identify those.

36
00:02:11.360 --> 00:02:15.440
So just knowing the structure, we'll take
a look at that a little more in depth, but

37
00:02:15.440 --> 00:02:17.900
I just wanted to remind you
really how important that is.

38
00:02:19.420 --> 00:02:24.350
Now I've mentioned this weird
state that we're in, right?

39
00:02:24.350 --> 00:02:30.770
So some companies, especially if they have
any kind of regulatory compliance or maybe

40
00:02:30.770 --> 00:02:34.560
it's like dealing with the government and
they say look, I just want everyone to be.

41
00:02:34.560 --> 00:02:38.430
They've issued some types of,
what's the word?

42
00:02:38.430 --> 00:02:41.950
Those federal reserves and
they said, and this was years ago.

43
00:02:41.950 --> 00:02:47.432
They even started doing this your networks
need to be able to support both IPv4 and

44
00:02:47.432 --> 00:02:49.251
IPv6.

45
00:02:49.251 --> 00:02:56.180
So if I have a site here
running IPv6 only and

46
00:02:56.180 --> 00:03:01.270
another branch location also running
IPv6 only well then what's the issue,

47
00:03:01.270 --> 00:03:07.240
how do I communicate running over
a IPv4 network like the Internet?

48
00:03:07.240 --> 00:03:11.500
Well that's where these transitional
mechanisms come into play.

49
00:03:11.500 --> 00:03:15.950
And we need to establish virtual
links with these technologies.

50
00:03:15.950 --> 00:03:20.200
So that's what we'll be
looking at in this show, now.

51
00:03:20.200 --> 00:03:21.850
Don't let these diagrams scare you.

52
00:03:21.850 --> 00:03:23.700
I know there is a lot there.

53
00:03:23.700 --> 00:03:25.870
And I'm gonna try to explain
it as best as I can.

54
00:03:27.120 --> 00:03:32.730
Because you might even if you've tried to
look at these concept independently and

55
00:03:32.730 --> 00:03:36.850
you've done like internet searches,
I mean there's just so

56
00:03:36.850 --> 00:03:38.330
much information out there.

57
00:03:38.330 --> 00:03:39.970
It can get a little overwhelming so

58
00:03:39.970 --> 00:03:43.180
I'll try to break it down
into a more simplistic form.

59
00:03:43.180 --> 00:03:47.160
You don't need to know everything about
it and I'll highlight the most, I guess,

60
00:03:47.160 --> 00:03:50.310
fundamental concepts that
we need to know here.

61
00:03:50.310 --> 00:03:53.790
There are tons of
transition mechanisms and

62
00:03:53.790 --> 00:03:56.150
different types of technologies out there.

63
00:03:56.150 --> 00:04:01.350
I mean every kind of potential
configuration has been thought of,

64
00:04:01.350 --> 00:04:04.750
and people come off with many
variations and variants.

65
00:04:04.750 --> 00:04:08.790
So, don't let that bog you down.

66
00:04:08.790 --> 00:04:13.930
Some key terms that I'd like to cover,
so, if I have my two networks here,

67
00:04:13.930 --> 00:04:17.430
how are we gonna go ahead and
facilitate this virtual link.

68
00:04:17.430 --> 00:04:22.180
I need to go ahead and utilize something
that's called a tunnel broker service.

69
00:04:22.180 --> 00:04:24.350
And what that does, a tunnel broker,

70
00:04:24.350 --> 00:04:30.250
well it is a service that provides that
virtual link, that network tunnel.

71
00:04:30.250 --> 00:04:37.790
And if you wanted to delve a little deeper
into these concepts, I've noted some RFCs.

72
00:04:37.790 --> 00:04:42.420
RFC 3053 is going to be
explaining an IPv6 tunnel broker,

73
00:04:42.420 --> 00:04:46.770
and then you also have a more
generic explanation of

74
00:04:46.770 --> 00:04:50.830
you can really tunnel over anything
in how you go ahead and set it up.

75
00:04:50.830 --> 00:04:54.770
That's going to be noted in RFC 2473.

76
00:04:54.770 --> 00:04:59.340
Now, what I'm looking at
here is this network.

77
00:04:59.340 --> 00:05:02.280
I have regular components,
all my coordinate work services,

78
00:05:02.280 --> 00:05:07.210
just like I would in a regular network,
including things like a firewall.

79
00:05:07.210 --> 00:05:09.540
Security is still important here.

80
00:05:09.540 --> 00:05:14.320
When you establish a tunnel
with a tunnel broker service,

81
00:05:14.320 --> 00:05:17.670
it's not like other types of
tunnels like a VPN tunnel.

82
00:05:17.670 --> 00:05:22.110
You're not gonna have to maintain
any kind of connection section and

83
00:05:22.110 --> 00:05:27.590
termination data so encryption is
not going to be provided here.

84
00:05:27.590 --> 00:05:31.450
This is a more simplistic
configuration that is just allowing

85
00:05:31.450 --> 00:05:34.300
basically encapsulation to occur.

86
00:05:34.300 --> 00:05:37.940
So what I have here is, let's say, a note,

87
00:05:37.940 --> 00:05:41.460
withing this IPV6 network
has generated a packet.

88
00:05:41.460 --> 00:05:43.080
So this is my IPV6 packet.

89
00:05:43.080 --> 00:05:47.160
How do I get it to my other IPV6 network?

90
00:05:47.160 --> 00:05:51.594
Well, what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna take
that original packet with the original

91
00:05:51.594 --> 00:05:55.915
header information and I'm going to
encapsulate it inside of an IPv4 packet.

92
00:05:58.424 --> 00:06:02.460
All right, we're just gonna go ahead and
group those for this demonstration.

93
00:06:02.460 --> 00:06:09.200
Now, whenever I go ahead and encapsulate
the IPv6 packet inside of the IPv4,

94
00:06:10.680 --> 00:06:14.630
you'll see that the actually
protocol field is changed to 41,

95
00:06:14.630 --> 00:06:18.570
to indicate that it is
an encapsulated IPv6 packet.

96
00:06:18.570 --> 00:06:21.470
Sometimes you'll hear protocol 41,
or proto41 tunnel, and

97
00:06:21.470 --> 00:06:24.670
that's just a different
way of explaining this.

98
00:06:24.670 --> 00:06:29.420
So, then I can actually send from my
tunnel entry point or exit point,

99
00:06:29.420 --> 00:06:32.370
which is going to be a tunnel end node.

100
00:06:32.370 --> 00:06:37.090
And go ahead and
send it across that IPv4 network and

101
00:06:37.090 --> 00:06:40.050
then when I get to this other end point,
so,

102
00:06:40.050 --> 00:06:45.520
this actual IPv4 header information,
the source and the destination

103
00:06:45.520 --> 00:06:49.620
addresses are gonna actually be
the addresses of these two endpoints here.

104
00:06:49.620 --> 00:06:53.460
And here, looking at this diagram, I

105
00:06:53.460 --> 00:06:58.490
have entry/exit point because you may just
have a unidirectional communication but

106
00:06:58.490 --> 00:07:01.410
you can also configure it to
be bidirectional as well.

107
00:07:02.560 --> 00:07:05.090
So then over here on
this side we go ahead and

108
00:07:05.090 --> 00:07:10.760
ungroup it Decapsulate
our little IPv6 packet.

109
00:07:10.760 --> 00:07:13.810
And then the local area network,
but go ahead and

110
00:07:13.810 --> 00:07:16.460
route that, just like regular traffic.

111
00:07:16.460 --> 00:07:20.160
So, I think that's the easiest way to
go ahead and explain this concept.

112
00:07:21.500 --> 00:07:22.840
In certain situations,

113
00:07:22.840 --> 00:07:27.640
you may think okay, well,
you just showed us IPv6 running over IPv4.

114
00:07:27.640 --> 00:07:32.340
But like I said you can encapsulate
multiple types of traffic,

115
00:07:32.340 --> 00:07:36.430
so that's why there are so many of these
transitional mechanisms and technologies,

116
00:07:36.430 --> 00:07:40.420
because, well, a lot of different
network configurations exist.

117
00:07:40.420 --> 00:07:45.789
So you may see something like IPv4
networks tunneling through IPv6 as well,

118
00:07:45.789 --> 00:07:50.098
and there are different variations
of that As a matter of fact,

119
00:07:50.098 --> 00:07:53.378
you may even hear something
called six to four.

120
00:07:53.378 --> 00:07:57.408
Looking at the structure
here of our addresses,

121
00:07:57.408 --> 00:08:02.714
six to four is going to be A tunneling
mechanism that we can use and

122
00:08:02.714 --> 00:08:06.570
it's gonna be used for
public IP addresses.

123
00:08:06.570 --> 00:08:10.270
So, it's gonna take those public
IP addresses and tunnel them so

124
00:08:10.270 --> 00:08:12.080
that they can be communicated.

125
00:08:12.080 --> 00:08:16.660
So, if we look at the structure here,
you're gonna see the syntax and it's going

126
00:08:16.660 --> 00:08:22.930
to be based off of the IPv4 address of
the external interface on an IPv6 router.

127
00:08:22.930 --> 00:08:28.200
So just being familiar with the way
these addresses look because if

128
00:08:28.200 --> 00:08:34.787
you're ever presented with an output like
an IP config all or something like that,

129
00:08:34.787 --> 00:08:40.552
you should be able to understand where
these addresses are coming from.

130
00:08:40.552 --> 00:08:44.825
So what you're looking at here
is just a basic structure and

131
00:08:44.825 --> 00:08:49.200
explanation of the structure
of the IP address here.

132
00:08:49.200 --> 00:08:56.451
And Microsoft doesn't
specifically call out 6to4, but

133
00:08:56.451 --> 00:09:03.130
6 over 4 is one of these
core transition mechanisms.

134
00:09:03.130 --> 00:09:06.140
As a matter of fact,
we'll look at something called ISATAP

135
00:09:06.140 --> 00:09:10.580
that is specifically called out that
is a variation that builds upon that.

136
00:09:10.580 --> 00:09:15.657
So I just wanna, again, express how
important it is to understand and

137
00:09:15.657 --> 00:09:17.993
notice those prefixes as well.

138
00:09:17.993 --> 00:09:19.660
So what is ISATAP?

139
00:09:19.660 --> 00:09:21.200
Let's take a look at that.

140
00:09:21.200 --> 00:09:25.987
ISATAP stands for Intra-Site
Automatic Tunnel Addressing Protocol.

141
00:09:25.987 --> 00:09:28.938
And if I have a technology like
6to4 that does this for me,

142
00:09:28.938 --> 00:09:32.610
you're maybe thinking well, Cherokee,
why would I need another one?

143
00:09:32.610 --> 00:09:34.520
Well, I can't answer
that because they're so

144
00:09:34.520 --> 00:09:38.880
many, but
in certain situations ISATAP is required.

145
00:09:38.880 --> 00:09:42.440
Because I said, hey, 6to4 works for

146
00:09:42.440 --> 00:09:45.880
public addresses, but what if we
don't need to deal with public IPs?

147
00:09:45.880 --> 00:09:48.300
What if we're just trying
to communicate internally?

148
00:09:48.300 --> 00:09:51.645
Well, ISATAP provides a solution for
that, so

149
00:09:51.645 --> 00:09:56.465
it can be configured with both public and
private IP addresses.

150
00:09:56.465 --> 00:10:00.855
And, as a matter of fact, you don't
even need to leave, exit, a network.

151
00:10:00.855 --> 00:10:06.125
You can even just have a mixture,
a combination of both

152
00:10:06.125 --> 00:10:10.555
devices that support and run on IPv4 and
devices that run on IPv6.

153
00:10:10.555 --> 00:10:15.450
And you're ISATAP device, so
you can configure your machine, and

154
00:10:15.450 --> 00:10:19.880
we will configure a server
as an ISATAP router.

155
00:10:19.880 --> 00:10:23.340
And that router acts as a translator so

156
00:10:23.340 --> 00:10:25.830
that those devices can't
communicate with each other.

157
00:10:26.910 --> 00:10:32.330
In most situations, newer operating
systems ever since Vista and

158
00:10:32.330 --> 00:10:36.120
Server 2008,
they support something called Dual Stack,

159
00:10:36.120 --> 00:10:41.470
which allows you to run both IPv4 and
IPv6 addressing schemes.

160
00:10:41.470 --> 00:10:45.324
But for some reason maybe you have
a device that doesn't support one or

161
00:10:45.324 --> 00:10:49.256
the other or maybe you're not allowed
to go ahead and run that version.

162
00:10:49.256 --> 00:10:54.420
So that's where this particular
technology comes into play.

163
00:10:54.420 --> 00:10:57.650
>> Cherokee, I think you make a good point
here when we start taking a look at some

164
00:10:57.650 --> 00:10:58.926
of the reasons.

165
00:10:58.926 --> 00:11:02.077
The tunneling technologies
that you showed us before,

166
00:11:02.077 --> 00:11:06.633
they really are good as long as we're
going from one network to another network,

167
00:11:06.633 --> 00:11:09.332
and going across maybe
an IPv4 address space.

168
00:11:09.332 --> 00:11:13.689
But the very fact is, there are a lot of
companies that are not transitioning over

169
00:11:13.689 --> 00:11:17.000
to IPv6, because there is some
difficulty involved in it.

170
00:11:17.000 --> 00:11:21.810
So in this sense, ISATAP is one of those
transition technologies that help us

171
00:11:21.810 --> 00:11:26.787
to move forward that
migration from IPv4 to

172
00:11:26.787 --> 00:11:30.530
IPv6 as we start to actually
do something like this.

173
00:11:30.530 --> 00:11:35.050
So even though it's actually there and
available for us, it is a technology that

174
00:11:35.050 --> 00:11:38.000
you need to make sure that you're
familiar with on the exam.

175
00:11:38.000 --> 00:11:42.338
And it's funny because I remember reading
some of the Microsoft documentation.

176
00:11:42.338 --> 00:11:47.580
Like look, do not use this unless you have
to, essentially is what it comes down to.

177
00:11:47.580 --> 00:11:49.090
So, that's why you're looking at it.

178
00:11:49.090 --> 00:11:52.920
Because more than likely, especially
on the exam they're gonna call out that

179
00:11:52.920 --> 00:11:56.670
weird technology that Microsoft is saying
don't use it unless you have to and

180
00:11:56.670 --> 00:11:58.260
they're gonna put you in that scenario.

181
00:11:58.260 --> 00:12:03.956
So think about the ideas of transitioning
from you wanna transition your IPv4 over

182
00:12:03.956 --> 00:12:07.970
to IPv6, but you know that there's some
that's not gonna transition very easily.

183
00:12:07.970 --> 00:12:11.450
So ISATAP is gonna be one of those
that you may end up using, or

184
00:12:11.450 --> 00:12:14.050
the situation that Cherokee
was actually mentioning.

185
00:12:14.050 --> 00:12:18.288
Where you have some devices that just
aren't going to be able to handle both

186
00:12:18.288 --> 00:12:19.910
IPv4, IPv6.

187
00:12:19.910 --> 00:12:23.790
So those are kind of some of the scenarios
that you might want to think about

188
00:12:23.790 --> 00:12:27.440
as you choose which particular
type of technology here.

189
00:12:27.440 --> 00:12:29.640
So Cherokee,
what else do we need to know about ISATAP?

190
00:12:29.640 --> 00:12:34.950
>> So you pointed out a really good
note there Ronnie because I mean,

191
00:12:34.950 --> 00:12:37.780
I'm sorry if this is your baby and
you've created ISATAP.

192
00:12:37.780 --> 00:12:39.700
It's not the easiest tool to work with,

193
00:12:39.700 --> 00:12:41.968
I'm just going to be
honest with you right now.

194
00:12:41.968 --> 00:12:45.730
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And that's putting it mildly.

195
00:12:45.730 --> 00:12:46.841
But like Ronnie said,

196
00:12:46.841 --> 00:12:50.890
this is like basically you're putting
a Band-Aid over a particular situation.

197
00:12:50.890 --> 00:12:54.570
So the end goal is to get
everyone on the same page and

198
00:12:54.570 --> 00:13:00.150
to get those devices supported for both or
just moved over to IPv6 all together.

199
00:13:00.150 --> 00:13:04.260
But, until then,
this is the temporary fix or solution.

200
00:13:04.260 --> 00:13:06.810
There are some drawbacks though.

201
00:13:06.810 --> 00:13:12.010
A lot of times we're running network
address translation within our networks,

202
00:13:12.010 --> 00:13:15.940
that's going to pose a problem,
a limitation of ISATAP.

203
00:13:15.940 --> 00:13:20.227
So you may also see another
technology that is called out,

204
00:13:20.227 --> 00:13:22.514
specifically called Teredo.

205
00:13:22.514 --> 00:13:25.895
I like saying Torito,
I guess that's my Southern flare,

206
00:13:25.895 --> 00:13:29.083
kinda sounds like Dorito but
any way you want to say it.

207
00:13:29.083 --> 00:13:31.160
[LAUGH] That's going to be.

208
00:13:31.160 --> 00:13:33.410
There's also, and it's funny guys,
I'm not even joking.

209
00:13:33.410 --> 00:13:37.060
If you did an Internet search for
these transitional technologies,

210
00:13:37.060 --> 00:13:38.520
you'll see a slew of them.

211
00:13:38.520 --> 00:13:41.240
You'll even see something called
Moredo which is gonna be a NIC

212
00:13:41.240 --> 00:13:44.820
based version of this Teredo
implementation as well.

213
00:13:44.820 --> 00:13:48.830
But Teredo is going to
allow the support for Macs,

214
00:13:48.830 --> 00:13:50.960
so just keep that in mind as well.

215
00:13:52.920 --> 00:13:59.070
There are different ways you can configure
Teredo, there are Teredo servers online.

216
00:13:59.070 --> 00:14:01.850
Actually, just let me switch over here and
I'll show you.

217
00:14:01.850 --> 00:14:05.979
Microsoft's address for
their Teredo servers,

218
00:14:05.979 --> 00:14:11.198
their design is going to be
teredo.ipv6.microsoft.com.

219
00:14:11.198 --> 00:14:17.077
And this is the prefix to go ahead and
indicate a teredo address.

220
00:14:17.077 --> 00:14:21.640
I would say that this particular
technology is even more cumbersome than

221
00:14:21.640 --> 00:14:26.576
ISATAP because at least with ISATAP you
have some control over the situation,

222
00:14:26.576 --> 00:14:28.470
it's your devices.

223
00:14:28.470 --> 00:14:32.517
But with Teredo you're actually
relying on that Teredo relay, and

224
00:14:32.517 --> 00:14:35.788
well what happens if you
lose Internet connectivity?

225
00:14:35.788 --> 00:14:37.790
Or that server goes down?

226
00:14:37.790 --> 00:14:40.647
You're relying on someone
else's trust in that capacity.

227
00:14:40.647 --> 00:14:45.170
So again, not a perfect solution,
just be familiar with it.

228
00:14:45.170 --> 00:14:49.979
And I put the steps of how to
configure that In the show notes as

229
00:14:49.979 --> 00:14:54.332
well as the TechNet link for
Teredo, so that you have.

230
00:14:54.332 --> 00:14:59.125
They do provide good documentation for
that, if you have to go that route,

231
00:14:59.125 --> 00:15:00.660
just keep that in mind.

232
00:15:02.130 --> 00:15:07.485
All right, so let me explain to
you what our lab topology will

233
00:15:07.485 --> 00:15:13.265
look at because we're gonna be
setting up an ISATAP server here.

234
00:15:13.265 --> 00:15:16.609
It can get a little confusing because we
are working with a lot of devices and

235
00:15:16.609 --> 00:15:20.350
I wanna make sure you really understand
what we're dealing with first.

236
00:15:20.350 --> 00:15:26.470
So looking at this network,
I have a domain controller PLABDCO1,

237
00:15:26.470 --> 00:15:30.870
I have a domain member PLABDMO1.

238
00:15:30.870 --> 00:15:38.803
And then I also have PLABSA01 which
is going to act as our ISATAP router.

239
00:15:38.803 --> 00:15:43.723
Now all of these three
devices that I just mentioned

240
00:15:43.723 --> 00:15:47.957
are going to be utilizing IPv4, except for

241
00:15:47.957 --> 00:15:53.231
my ISATAP router is going to
be that translator for us.

242
00:15:53.231 --> 00:15:57.392
And what it's going to provide
is the ability for our clients,

243
00:15:57.392 --> 00:15:59.208
we have PLAV-WIN 801.

244
00:15:59.208 --> 00:16:02.799
A machine that's running
Windows 8.1 over here,

245
00:16:02.799 --> 00:16:05.364
which is only an IP version 6 device.

246
00:16:05.364 --> 00:16:09.133
Now, in reality,
Windows 8.1 does support both.

247
00:16:09.133 --> 00:16:14.340
But what I've done is I've disabled
IP version 4 for this demonstration.

248
00:16:14.340 --> 00:16:20.000
And I've also disabled IP version 6
on our domain number over here so

249
00:16:20.000 --> 00:16:22.030
that we can prove this concept.

250
00:16:22.030 --> 00:16:26.990
And just show that this isotope router
should do what it's supposed to do.

251
00:16:26.990 --> 00:16:28.540
So let's go ahead and get that started.

252
00:16:30.340 --> 00:16:31.770
And in practice labs, so

253
00:16:31.770 --> 00:16:36.610
you guys have the ability to follow along,
I have shortened up some of the work.

254
00:16:36.610 --> 00:16:37.770
Like I said, I went ahead and

255
00:16:37.770 --> 00:16:41.480
did some of this configuration,
just to make it shorter for this show.

256
00:16:41.480 --> 00:16:46.044
So if you wanted to go through and look
at their steps compared to my show notes,

257
00:16:46.044 --> 00:16:48.272
hopefully you guys can follow along.

258
00:16:48.272 --> 00:16:53.125
Okay, the first thing I wanna
go here is I want to show you

259
00:16:53.125 --> 00:16:57.268
how I have disabled IP
version 6 on PLABDMO1.

260
00:16:57.268 --> 00:17:00.596
So what I'm gonna do is an IP config all,
just so

261
00:17:00.596 --> 00:17:03.776
we can take a look at
how that's configured.

262
00:17:03.776 --> 00:17:08.175
Now, what I did was I went under
the graphical user interface and

263
00:17:08.175 --> 00:17:11.940
just unchecked that from
my IP version 6 properties.

264
00:17:13.040 --> 00:17:18.190
In real life, there are dependencies
that you'll need to go ahead and

265
00:17:18.190 --> 00:17:23.110
perform registry edits if you wanna
completely axe IPv6 from a device.

266
00:17:23.110 --> 00:17:27.100
It's not really recommended because you do
have dependencies and other technologies.

267
00:17:28.880 --> 00:17:33.810
Microsoft has technologies such as
DirectAccess, as well as third party

268
00:17:33.810 --> 00:17:39.990
technology such as Dropbox that rely
on the way that IPv6 communicates.

269
00:17:39.990 --> 00:17:43.460
So you may inadvertently break
something if you try to go ahead and

270
00:17:43.460 --> 00:17:45.160
just turn it off for no reason.

271
00:17:46.800 --> 00:17:51.320
So what we're looking at here is the way
that your practice labs are configured,

272
00:17:51.320 --> 00:17:56.020
you have one network interface for
communication for the machines themselves.

273
00:17:56.020 --> 00:17:57.880
And in this demonstration,

274
00:17:57.880 --> 00:18:01.290
we will actually be modifying
our secondary adapter.

275
00:18:01.290 --> 00:18:03.970
So we'll be looking at Ethernet II.

276
00:18:03.970 --> 00:18:08.982
So you can see here, Ethernet II
does have an IP version 4 address.

277
00:18:08.982 --> 00:18:14.448
I've went ahead and
set that statically at 192.168.0.20.

278
00:18:14.448 --> 00:18:16.996
But you don't see an IPv6
address noted here, and

279
00:18:16.996 --> 00:18:19.317
that's what I wanted to go ahead and
show you.

280
00:18:19.317 --> 00:18:23.947
Okay, I'd also like to show you how
I did configure the other machine,

281
00:18:23.947 --> 00:18:27.514
our client, so
let's switch over to PLAB WIN 801.

282
00:18:27.514 --> 00:18:29.310
This is going to be our client.

283
00:18:29.310 --> 00:18:31.420
And, oops, did I already run an IP config?

284
00:18:31.420 --> 00:18:32.780
I sure did.

285
00:18:32.780 --> 00:18:37.130
And you can see, here,
on our Ethernet adapter number 2,

286
00:18:37.130 --> 00:18:40.350
actually, you can look at both of them and
it shows a good comparison here.

287
00:18:40.350 --> 00:18:44.110
Because if you look at just Ethernet,
regular Ethernet,

288
00:18:44.110 --> 00:18:49.850
you can see both the IPv6 version of
that address as well as an IP version 4.

289
00:18:49.850 --> 00:18:55.040
Now that FE80, if you recall when we were
talking about the difference between IP

290
00:18:55.040 --> 00:19:02.160
version 4 and 6, FE80 is going to be
comparable to an IPv4 APIPA address.

291
00:19:02.160 --> 00:19:04.910
So that's going to be
our link local address.

292
00:19:04.910 --> 00:19:08.390
And remember, with IP version 6,
we always maintain that link local.

293
00:19:08.390 --> 00:19:13.470
It's not just given to us as a crutch,
okay?

294
00:19:13.470 --> 00:19:16.440
But if we jump down to Ethernet II,
and remember,

295
00:19:16.440 --> 00:19:18.200
that's the adapter that I've modified.

296
00:19:18.200 --> 00:19:20.924
That's what we're really
working with here.

297
00:19:20.924 --> 00:19:24.244
Notice there is no IP version 4, okay?

298
00:19:24.244 --> 00:19:28.880
So I've disabled IP version 4
on our Windows 8 client here.

299
00:19:28.880 --> 00:19:30.970
We'll just see that link
local address right here.

300
00:19:31.990 --> 00:19:34.980
Okay, so now that we've established that,

301
00:19:34.980 --> 00:19:39.160
what we really need to do is to go
ahead and configure that ISATAP router.

302
00:19:39.160 --> 00:19:46.600
Remember, PLABSA01 is going to be
our in-house machine for that.

303
00:19:46.600 --> 00:19:51.840
So what I'm gonna do is actually
run reg edit to go ahead and

304
00:19:51.840 --> 00:19:54.260
launch my registry editor.

305
00:19:54.260 --> 00:19:58.556
I don't know, let's see, can you see that
or should I zoom in a little bit there,

306
00:19:58.556 --> 00:20:00.064
make it a little bit larger.

307
00:20:00.064 --> 00:20:02.790
We're gonna be drilling down quite a bit,
so

308
00:20:02.790 --> 00:20:06.543
you may need to refer back to
the show notes or just hit rewind.

309
00:20:06.543 --> 00:20:11.431
Because the interface sometimes
you have to just make sure

310
00:20:11.431 --> 00:20:16.331
you can see everything and
it can get a little fuzzy there.

311
00:20:16.331 --> 00:20:19.539
So what we're gonna do is look
under our HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE,

312
00:20:19.539 --> 00:20:21.009
go ahead and expand that out.

313
00:20:21.009 --> 00:20:25.310
And we're gonna be drilling down
inside of our systems setting.

314
00:20:25.310 --> 00:20:30.090
And then from there gonna continue
to go to our current control set.

315
00:20:30.090 --> 00:20:33.907
And just by clicking on this little
triangle and expanding it out,

316
00:20:33.907 --> 00:20:37.793
you might already be familiar with
the way that that'll go ahead and

317
00:20:37.793 --> 00:20:40.675
create that directory or
expand that tree there.

318
00:20:40.675 --> 00:20:46.930
Next, we're gonna go ahead and expand out
services and then scroll down to TCP/IP.

319
00:20:46.930 --> 00:20:50.251
Keep scrolling, it'll be a little bit.

320
00:20:53.495 --> 00:20:59.650
I can remember my alphabet, u, r, s,
I think t comes next, there we go.

321
00:20:59.650 --> 00:21:01.252
And so we have TCP/IP,

322
00:21:01.252 --> 00:21:06.160
and what I'm gonna be looking at
next is going to be parameters.

323
00:21:06.160 --> 00:21:07.784
So I can go ahead and expand that out.

324
00:21:07.784 --> 00:21:10.698
But since I'm gonna be
working with my perimeters,

325
00:21:10.698 --> 00:21:13.172
I really wanna click
on the lettering here.

326
00:21:13.172 --> 00:21:16.870
So left-click on top of the letters and
then on the right-hand side,

327
00:21:16.870 --> 00:21:20.570
you'll see those values
that can be modified.

328
00:21:20.570 --> 00:21:26.040
Now the value that I'm looking to modify
here is going to be my IP Enable Router.

329
00:21:26.040 --> 00:21:31.723
So just left-click and highlight it,
then right click and select Modify.

330
00:21:31.723 --> 00:21:35.989
Notice that currently my
value is set to zero.

331
00:21:35.989 --> 00:21:38.918
And if you think like binary, on and off,

332
00:21:38.918 --> 00:21:42.826
currently this particular
function is set to be off.

333
00:21:42.826 --> 00:21:46.750
So what we're gonna do is change that to
a one here, and then we will go ahead and

334
00:21:46.750 --> 00:21:47.790
set OK.

335
00:21:47.790 --> 00:21:51.200
Because if you look at that value,
IP enable router, so

336
00:21:51.200 --> 00:21:54.770
we're basically giving the green light for
this machine to become a router here.

337
00:21:54.770 --> 00:21:58.799
We'll hit OK, all right?

338
00:21:58.799 --> 00:21:59.960
We can just close out of here.

339
00:22:05.122 --> 00:22:07.960
We'll get my size back to normal there,
all right?

340
00:22:07.960 --> 00:22:13.700
The next thing I wanna go ahead and do is
restart this machine, so let's see here.

341
00:22:21.344 --> 00:22:22.550
I'm jumping around a bit,
sorry about that.

342
00:22:32.352 --> 00:22:34.148
And we'll go ahead and give that a second.

343
00:22:34.148 --> 00:22:37.829
I know we're getting close to time for
this particular show, so

344
00:22:37.829 --> 00:22:40.360
why don't we go ahead and
pause right here?

345
00:22:40.360 --> 00:22:41.170
We'll pick back, and

346
00:22:41.170 --> 00:22:44.740
let the machine restart, we'll pick
back up right here on this machine.

347
00:22:45.822 --> 00:22:47.290
>> All right, Cherokee, well again,

348
00:22:47.290 --> 00:22:51.530
thank you for helping us out up until this

349
00:22:51.530 --> 00:22:54.310
You've seen a lot of the different

of course the 70-410 exam,

351
00:22:58.150 --> 00:23:04.040
as well as in real business as people are

00:23:04.040 --> 00:23:06.310
So, of course, that means you

especially on Isotap that Cherokee's

354
00:23:10.270 --> 00:23:13.330
But this is a great place for

00:23:13.330 --> 00:23:17.490
Signing off for ITProTV,

>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on IT Pro.TV.

5

You're watching the MCSA for
Windows Server 2012 show.

6

I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and today

7
00:00:24.069 --> 00:00:26.416
4 and IP version 6 interoperability.

8
00:00:26.416 --> 00:00:27.766
We're in the middle of lab and

00:00:27.766 --> 00:00:30.680
Cherokee Boose is actually
gonna guide us through this.

12

[CROSSTALK] Yeah, so in the last
show we were setting up our ISATAP

13
00:00:37.870 --> 00:00:42.244
router on SAPLABSAL01, and
we were waiting for that reboot.

14
00:00:42.244 --> 00:00:46.700
So if you haven't watched that previous
show, then I would encourage you to do so.

15
00:00:46.700 --> 00:00:49.260
So you just don't feel like
kind of left out here.

16
00:00:50.890 --> 00:00:55.750
Now, what I did was showed you
how to modify the registry there.

17
00:00:55.750 --> 00:00:59.093
There are more ways than just this
particular way to go head and

18
00:00:59.093 --> 00:01:00.066
configure that.

19
00:01:00.066 --> 00:01:01.326
You might have a better way.

20
00:01:01.326 --> 00:01:05.951
I don't know, but just note that there
are other ways to go ahead and do that,

21
00:01:05.951 --> 00:01:09.885
and I have included some other options for
you in this show notes.

22
00:01:09.885 --> 00:01:14.835
You really wanna even pay attention to
that section where I note the PowerShell

23
00:01:14.835 --> 00:01:19.710
command lines there, because you know
how Microsoft loves PowerShell, but

24
00:01:19.710 --> 00:01:23.090
here we'll take a look at
an older tool called Netsh.

25
00:01:24.210 --> 00:01:28.040
But I just wanna verify that what we did
in that last show actually worked, so

26
00:01:28.040 --> 00:01:31.130
let's take a look at my screen and
check that.

27
00:01:31.130 --> 00:01:34.590
So what we're gonna just run
is ipconfig /all here, and

28
00:01:34.590 --> 00:01:39.870
what we're looking for
is going to up here towards the top.

29
00:01:39.870 --> 00:01:42.110
Look for IP Routing Enabled.

30
00:01:42.110 --> 00:01:47.010
Remember, that's what we actually changed
that binary value for to allow that.

31
00:01:47.010 --> 00:01:51.260
And we can see here, yes, we are allowed
to use this machine now as a router.

32
00:01:52.540 --> 00:01:56.774
So what we wanna do is,
now that we've configured that,

33
00:01:56.774 --> 00:02:02.864
if you think about how IPv6 works and
the routing capabilities that it supports,

34
00:02:02.864 --> 00:02:06.418
we need to go ahead and
establish our actual RA.

35
00:02:06.418 --> 00:02:08.799
Okay, we need to go ahead and

36
00:02:08.799 --> 00:02:13.680
set our router advertisement for
our global address.

37
00:02:13.680 --> 00:02:16.770
So we're gonna do that here on PLABSA01.

38
00:02:16.770 --> 00:02:24.650
Let me just clear my screen, and
the first thing I wanna do is go ahead and

39
00:02:24.650 --> 00:02:28.990
launch PowerShell, if you haven't already,
as an administrative user.

40
00:02:28.990 --> 00:02:31.280
And I'm gonna use netsh here.

41
00:02:31.280 --> 00:02:34.330
So I'm gonna type in netsh interface.

42
00:02:35.670 --> 00:02:39.733
And here, remember,
we're gonna be using IP version 6.

43
00:02:39.733 --> 00:02:44.014
And this is going to be,
set interface, and

44
00:02:44.014 --> 00:02:50.517
the ethernet adapter that we're
using is going to be Ethernet 2.

45
00:02:50.517 --> 00:02:54.870
And we're using quotes here just
because we do have that space.

46
00:02:54.870 --> 00:02:58.700
We'll set forwarding =enabled.

47
00:03:01.650 --> 00:03:02.630
And that's going to be.

48
00:03:02.630 --> 00:03:06.060
Also, we need to set our
advertisement as well.

49
00:03:06.060 --> 00:03:15.060
So we'll say advertise =enabled,
And we'll hit enter.

50
00:03:15.060 --> 00:03:17.620
We don't get a lot of notification here,
but

51
00:03:17.620 --> 00:03:21.660
we do see OK, and
like I said, alternatively,

52
00:03:21.660 --> 00:03:26.530
you could use different cmdlets here
to go ahead and set that as well.

53
00:03:26.530 --> 00:03:29.450
The next thing we need to do is go ahead,
and

54
00:03:29.450 --> 00:03:32.790
we need to assign a global address here.

55
00:03:32.790 --> 00:03:36.030
So let's, again, use netsh.

56
00:03:36.030 --> 00:03:38.883
We're gonna, again, type in interface.

57
00:03:38.883 --> 00:03:44.074
This is going to be IPv6,
and we'll hit add route.

58
00:03:44.074 --> 00:03:45.460
Go ahead and set this route.

59
00:03:46.780 --> 00:03:53.974
And the address that we're gonna
use is going to be 2001:db8.

60
00:03:53.974 --> 00:03:57.710
Now, Ronnie,
we were talking about this earlier today.

61
00:03:57.710 --> 00:04:01.101
This address guys,
if you ever notice this db8,

62
00:04:01.101 --> 00:04:05.130
this is going to be used for
documentation purposes.

63
00:04:05.130 --> 00:04:08.065
So in a lot of textbooks and
blogs online and so forth,

64
00:04:08.065 --> 00:04:10.543
and in my notes you'll
see that being noted,

65
00:04:10.543 --> 00:04:15.068
because this is a demonstration here,
so that’s why we’re using that address.

66
00:04:15.068 --> 00:04:17.598
All right, and
just making sure my syntax right here,

67
00:04:17.598 --> 00:04:19.806
you know you got to love
these IPv6 addresses.

68
00:04:19.806 --> 00:04:24.594
[LAUGH] 0:1, and then that’s

69
00:04:24.594 --> 00:04:29.220
going to be ::/ with a 64.

70
00:04:29.220 --> 00:04:35.744
All right, and again,
we’ll specify our Ethernet 2.

71
00:04:35.744 --> 00:04:38.140
And we're gonna go ahead and hit publish.

72
00:04:40.180 --> 00:04:42.120
And I think that is an equals, yes.

73
00:04:42.120 --> 00:04:44.266
Equals, yes.

74
00:04:44.266 --> 00:04:46.490
I didn't mean to say that.

75
00:04:46.490 --> 00:04:50.520
We'll hit enter, and
we'll see that that was okay, as well.

76
00:04:50.520 --> 00:04:55.590
All right Cherokee, you've just shown us
a lot of stuff, but just up in this point,

77
00:04:55.590 --> 00:04:59.200
just kind of review just a little
bit up in this point, and

78
00:04:59.200 --> 00:05:01.710
that will help us to prepare for
what comes next.

79
00:05:01.710 --> 00:05:03.070
>> Right.
So what we just did,

80
00:05:03.070 --> 00:05:07.910
we used Netsh to go ahead and
configure our global address.

81
00:05:07.910 --> 00:05:13.110
Some technologies will require you to
go ahead and do of all this manual.

82
00:05:13.110 --> 00:05:18.180
And you can configure static IP
addresses there, but here with ISATAP,

83
00:05:18.180 --> 00:05:24.720
it does, it utilizes it, it leverages off
of slack or stateless technology there.

84
00:05:24.720 --> 00:05:29.300
So it's more automatic, so we just
use Netsh to go ahead and set that.

85
00:05:29.300 --> 00:05:32.760
But we're not quite finished here,
because we need to hop on over to our

86
00:05:32.760 --> 00:05:37.310
domain controller to go ahead and
provide a quad A record to

87
00:05:37.310 --> 00:05:41.970
indicate that this machine now is
going to be our isotopic router.

88
00:05:41.970 --> 00:05:43.860
So let's go ahead and do that.

89
00:05:43.860 --> 00:05:46.756
If I switch on over to
our domain controller.

90
00:05:46.756 --> 00:05:48.258
Oops, we are not connected.

91
00:05:48.258 --> 00:05:52.800
Here let me get that machine connected.

92
00:05:52.800 --> 00:05:54.000
That's what we're gonna be doing.

93
00:05:54.000 --> 00:05:58.730
This machine, my domain controller,
and this lab is actually running,

94
00:05:58.730 --> 00:06:01.402
facilitating as my DNS server.

95
00:06:01.402 --> 00:06:03.459
So, I'll go ahead and
modify that record here.

96
00:06:07.802 --> 00:06:09.103
It's connecting.

97
00:06:09.103 --> 00:06:10.890
Just give it a second here.

98
00:06:10.890 --> 00:06:12.130
All right.
There we go.

99
00:06:12.130 --> 00:06:16.820
So under Server Manager, go ahead and
pull up your DNS Management Console.

100
00:06:17.850 --> 00:06:19.680
And let me full screen that, so
you can see what we're doing.

101
00:06:19.680 --> 00:06:21.687
From the left-hand side,

102
00:06:21.687 --> 00:06:28.500
let's expand out our PLABDC01 over here
on the left, just click that arrow.

103
00:06:28.500 --> 00:06:31.290
And what we're going to be looking for
is our forward lookup zone.

104
00:06:31.290 --> 00:06:32.990
So go ahead and expand that out as well.

105
00:06:34.930 --> 00:06:39.470
And, again,
to our practicelabs.com over here.

106
00:06:39.470 --> 00:06:43.432
You can expand it out, but
I just wanted to show you, here,

107
00:06:43.432 --> 00:06:48.746
in the center pane that currently we don't
have any ISATAP router configured or

108
00:06:48.746 --> 00:06:52.819
any kind of record that indicates
there is an ISATAP router.

109
00:06:52.819 --> 00:06:55.469
So back over here on the left-hand side,

110
00:06:55.469 --> 00:06:59.635
what we'll do is right-click on
top of practicelabs.com, and

111
00:06:59.635 --> 00:07:03.970
then select new host A or quad A,
and we'll go ahead and set that up.

112
00:07:05.330 --> 00:07:08.840
So for this portion right here,
the part where we indicate a name,

113
00:07:08.840 --> 00:07:10.819
let's go ahead and type in ISATAP.

114
00:07:11.950 --> 00:07:17.008
And the IP address that we're gonna be
using is going to be the IP address

115
00:07:17.008 --> 00:07:21.496
that we just configured for
the other machine for PLABSA01.

116
00:07:21.496 --> 00:07:26.387
So that's going to be 192.168.0.40 here.

117
00:07:26.387 --> 00:07:28.340
And we'll go ahead and add this host.

118
00:07:30.560 --> 00:07:34.680
Now you can see that we've successfully
went ahead and created that host.

119
00:07:34.680 --> 00:07:35.530
Go ahead and hit OK.

120
00:07:38.327 --> 00:07:42.643
All right, now that we've added our
quad A record there, or our excuse me,

121
00:07:42.643 --> 00:07:47.364
A record, or our ISATAP router, you can
see that noted there, let's hop back over

122
00:07:47.364 --> 00:07:51.810
to our router so we can do some
additional configurations here.

123
00:07:51.810 --> 00:07:53.720
Again, we're gonna be leveraging Netsh.

124
00:07:53.720 --> 00:07:57.918
But this time we're gonna be
configuring the router, so

125
00:07:57.918 --> 00:08:00.897
we'll say interface, if I'm typing.

126
00:08:00.897 --> 00:08:01.547
Okay, there we go.

127
00:08:01.547 --> 00:08:06.802
netsh interface, and for the rest of this,

128
00:08:06.802 --> 00:08:10.644
it's going to be IP version 6.

129
00:08:10.644 --> 00:08:17.839
We're gonna type in ISATAP, I-S-A-T-A-P,
make sure I'm writing that correctly.

130
00:08:17.839 --> 00:08:25.068
We're gonna say, set router, and
then specify the IP address for

131
00:08:25.068 --> 00:08:29.726
this router, 192.168.0.4.

132
00:08:29.726 --> 00:08:31.420
And then we'll go ahead and hit Enter.

133
00:08:33.390 --> 00:08:37.502
Now, we need to take some
information that's going to be

134
00:08:37.502 --> 00:08:42.141
identifying our ISATAP router,
so we're gonna run ipconfig.

135
00:08:42.141 --> 00:08:47.348
And I wanna show you how
we can use our Notepad here

136
00:08:47.348 --> 00:08:52.320
to help with this ISATAP
tunnel information.

137
00:08:52.320 --> 00:08:55.930
So if we go ahead and take a look,
what we're gonna do is highlight and

138
00:08:55.930 --> 00:08:59.150
just mark this up from left to right here.

139
00:08:59.150 --> 00:09:03.340
And then, so once we get it highlighted,
up in the top, well, really anywhere.

140
00:09:03.340 --> 00:09:06.573
It's kind of funny, Ronnie,
I always for some reason thought

141
00:09:06.573 --> 00:09:10.416
you had to click on the little PowerShell
logo to get the menu pulled up, but

142
00:09:10.416 --> 00:09:13.349
really you can click anywhere
on the bar and pull that up.

143
00:09:13.349 --> 00:09:19.066
So here we're just gonna hit Edit and
Copy, and let's launch Notepad here.

144
00:09:23.170 --> 00:09:23.982
And then we'll paste that.

145
00:09:27.023 --> 00:09:30.565
Okay, I'm just gonna leave this here
in Notepad, in case, for some reason,

146
00:09:30.565 --> 00:09:34.230
I accidentally close PowerShell or
something, we don't have to do that again.

147
00:09:35.260 --> 00:09:39.235
It should have it in cache, but
I'm going to leverage the copy and

148
00:09:39.235 --> 00:09:42.648
paste function here,
because that is a lot to type out.

149
00:09:42.648 --> 00:09:48.937
So what we're going to do is type netsh,
and we're going to specify interface,

150
00:09:48.937 --> 00:09:53.690
if I'm spelling correctly,
yes, interface ipv6.

151
00:09:53.690 --> 00:09:55.714
And let's set interface.

152
00:09:59.248 --> 00:10:02.605
Now, this is where I can put in a quote,
and

153
00:10:02.605 --> 00:10:07.828
then go up to the top here,
right-click, and then select Edit and

154
00:10:07.828 --> 00:10:12.423
Paste, to go ahead and
paste that information in, okay?

155
00:10:12.423 --> 00:10:13.490
And it didn't go in.

156
00:10:13.490 --> 00:10:17.554
So what I'm gonna do is pull
that here from my Notepad.

157
00:10:17.554 --> 00:10:18.960
Good thing we did that, right?

158
00:10:21.620 --> 00:10:24.312
Copy that, and then we'll paste it in.

159
00:10:27.276 --> 00:10:28.111
Okay.

160
00:10:29.190 --> 00:10:31.680
Specify here with your end quote.

161
00:10:31.680 --> 00:10:34.940
And then, after that, we'll go ahead and
set forwarding, and we'll enable it.

162
00:10:34.940 --> 00:10:39.660
So F-A-R, F-O-R-W-A-R-D-I-N-G.

163
00:10:39.660 --> 00:10:43.393
forwarding=enabled.

164
00:10:43.393 --> 00:10:47.221
And then, also,
we'll need to advertise that, so

165
00:10:47.221 --> 00:10:50.441
we'll say advertise=enabled, as well.

166
00:10:52.629 --> 00:10:54.130
Did I spell that correctly?

167
00:10:54.130 --> 00:10:55.340
Okay, we'll go ahead and hit Enter.

168
00:10:56.870 --> 00:10:58.750
Looks like I added an extra s there.

169
00:10:58.750 --> 00:11:00.900
So we'll just hit our up arrow.

170
00:11:00.900 --> 00:11:02.530
Let me back up and remove that.

171
00:11:02.530 --> 00:11:03.950
I think that's my error.

172
00:11:03.950 --> 00:11:04.667
Let's find out.

173
00:11:09.705 --> 00:11:11.211
Yep, that appears to be the error.

174
00:11:11.211 --> 00:11:15.270
[LAUGH] So we'll go ahead, and
once we have that set here,

175
00:11:15.270 --> 00:11:19.770
we also need to specify the address
that we were using earlier.

176
00:11:19.770 --> 00:11:22.302
So again,
we'll be using the Netsh command.

177
00:11:22.302 --> 00:11:30.959
So we have netsh interface ipv6.

178
00:11:30.959 --> 00:11:35.108
Here we're going to add route, and

179
00:11:35.108 --> 00:11:42.170
we'll specify our global address here,
2001:db8.

180
00:11:42.170 --> 00:11:45.497
It's going to be a :0:

181
00:11:49.078 --> 00:11:56.399
;1, and then another 0, and then ::/64.

182
00:12:01.068 --> 00:12:06.640
Again, let's paste our
actual adapter information.

183
00:12:06.640 --> 00:12:09.160
So you can see that just
went in right there.

184
00:12:09.160 --> 00:12:12.388
And again,
we'll end that with a end quote here.

185
00:12:14.534 --> 00:12:16.557
Let me make sure my cursor
didn't lock up on me.

186
00:12:18.667 --> 00:12:19.601
Looks like that's what happened.

187
00:12:22.248 --> 00:12:23.996
Okay, there we go.

188
00:12:23.996 --> 00:12:31.661
And we'll set this to be published,
so publish=yes.

189
00:12:31.661 --> 00:12:33.510
And we'll go ahead and hit Enter.

190
00:12:33.510 --> 00:12:34.381
And we see OK.

191
00:12:34.381 --> 00:12:37.150
So what we're gonna do is, we're going
to go ahead and restart this machine.

192
00:12:44.376 --> 00:12:49.692
While that machine is restarting,
what we can do is switch back over

193
00:12:49.692 --> 00:12:55.213
to our PLABDM01, and we can configure
a little bit there, as well.

194
00:12:55.213 --> 00:12:56.660
So let's go ahead and do that.

195
00:12:57.970 --> 00:13:02.304
Okay, so while that's rebooting,
we're here on PLABDM01.

196
00:13:02.304 --> 00:13:07.320
Let's just go ahead, and again use
netsh to specify that ISATAP router.

197
00:13:07.320 --> 00:13:13.852
So we'll say interface, I-N-T-E-R-F-A-C-E,

198
00:13:13.852 --> 00:13:19.050
isatap, set router, and then we'll specify

199
00:13:19.050 --> 00:13:24.125
the IP address, 192.168.0.4.

200
00:13:24.125 --> 00:13:26.885
And then we'll hit Enter.

201
00:13:26.885 --> 00:13:30.031
Oops, am I typing crazily?

202
00:13:31.057 --> 00:13:33.131
>> ISATAP.

203
00:13:33.131 --> 00:13:33.742
>> Yeah.

204
00:13:45.718 --> 00:13:52.632
This is going to be isatap set router.

205
00:13:52.632 --> 00:13:57.790
192.168.0.4, Enter, okay.

206
00:13:57.790 --> 00:14:01.400
Now, the next step that we need to do is,
well let's go ahead and

207
00:14:01.400 --> 00:14:05.680
we need to think about that topology that
we looked at at the beginning where we had

208
00:14:05.680 --> 00:14:07.610
those firewalls in place.

209
00:14:07.610 --> 00:14:11.130
So from here if we just type in wf.msc,

210
00:14:11.130 --> 00:14:15.515
this is going to launch
our Windows fires off up.

211
00:14:15.515 --> 00:14:16.123
>> Firewall?

212
00:14:16.123 --> 00:14:16.800
>> Windows firewall.

213
00:14:16.800 --> 00:14:21.280
I was thinking Microsoft for
our configuration there.

214
00:14:21.280 --> 00:14:24.310
So this will go ahead and
pull up our firewall.

215
00:14:24.310 --> 00:14:27.790
What we're gonnabe looking at is
allowing those inbound connections.

216
00:14:27.790 --> 00:14:32.160
So let's go ahead, and it may or
may not already be configured, but

217
00:14:32.160 --> 00:14:33.220
I just wanna verify.

218
00:14:33.220 --> 00:14:35.567
Otherwise, it's not going
to be able to communicate.

219
00:14:35.567 --> 00:14:39.923
So let's check our file and
printer sharing for that.

220
00:14:39.923 --> 00:14:45.680
And let's see here, because that's
going to be allowing that traffic.

221
00:14:45.680 --> 00:14:50.630
So here we have for
a echo request, ICMP version 4,

222
00:14:50.630 --> 00:14:55.210
for our inbound, and currently,
we can see that it is enabled, so

223
00:14:55.210 --> 00:14:59.670
we're good to go there, we don't have to
do anything, I just wanted to verify that.

224
00:14:59.670 --> 00:15:04.004
And the last thing we need to do here,
is actually try to ping our machines and

225
00:15:04.004 --> 00:15:06.870
verify that that connectivity
actually exists.

226
00:15:06.870 --> 00:15:12.490
So from our Windows 8 machine,
let's hop on over to our client here.

227
00:15:12.490 --> 00:15:17.180
So remember,
this is our IPv6 only machine, our client.

228
00:15:17.180 --> 00:15:23.000
What we wanna do is ping PLABDM01.

229
00:15:23.000 --> 00:15:23.636
So let's try that.

230
00:15:27.770 --> 00:15:29.077
If I'm typing, there we go.

231
00:15:29.077 --> 00:15:35.127
Ping, PLABDM01.

232
00:15:38.490 --> 00:15:43.722
Now, we were able to obtain a reply
from a machine that, well, we might

233
00:15:43.722 --> 00:15:49.391
not normally expect to get a reply from,
because if this is an IPv6 machine,

234
00:15:49.391 --> 00:15:54.740
and we're trying to ping an IPv4 client,
well, how does that happen?

235
00:15:54.740 --> 00:15:58.747
Well, we just configured
that ISATAP router that's

236
00:15:58.747 --> 00:16:01.784
allowing this reply to actually occur.

237
00:16:01.784 --> 00:16:04.916
So, the other way we could go ahead and
test this,

238
00:16:04.916 --> 00:16:08.056
is if we wanted to ping
from the actual IP address.

239
00:16:08.056 --> 00:16:12.356
So if we say ping, 192.168.0.2,

240
00:16:12.356 --> 00:16:20.500
we can see that we're actually getting
an IP version 4 reply this time, as well.

241
00:16:20.500 --> 00:16:24.860
So this is one way that you could
actually configure an ISATAP router.

242
00:16:24.860 --> 00:16:29.370
Again, you might wanna take a look at
the notes, just to see other alternatives.

243
00:16:29.370 --> 00:16:32.170
Don't underestimate those
PowerShell cmdlets,

244
00:16:32.170 --> 00:16:34.790
and I think that's about it Ronnie.

245
00:16:34.790 --> 00:16:35.560
>> All right, Cherokee.

246
00:16:35.560 --> 00:16:36.160
Thank you for

247
00:16:36.160 --> 00:16:39.645
showing us that demonstration here
of how to setup the ISATAP router.

248
00:16:39.645 --> 00:16:43.970
Remember at the end, when we actually did
verify everything, Cherokee did show going

249
00:16:43.970 --> 00:16:48.590
from an IP version 6 only client that
we could also, of course, hit somebody

250
00:16:48.590 --> 00:16:52.980
else running IP version 6, which is
something we expect to be able to do.

251
00:16:52.980 --> 00:16:57.023
Since that one machine is running
both IP version 4 and IP version 6,

252
00:16:57.023 --> 00:16:59.810
we got the IP version 6 responding back.

253
00:16:59.810 --> 00:17:02.980
But then when Cherokee went ahead and
pinged the IP address,

254
00:17:02.980 --> 00:17:08.240
which was an IP version 4 address,
from a machine running only IP version 6,

255
00:17:08.240 --> 00:17:10.510
she was still able to get a reply.

256
00:17:10.510 --> 00:17:14.700
And that demonstrates how ISATAP
did function and did work for us.

257
00:17:14.700 --> 00:17:17.450
So remember that even though
this configuration is there,

258
00:17:17.450 --> 00:17:21.130
you wanna make sure you pay attention to
the commands that she ended up using.

259
00:17:21.130 --> 00:17:25.220
And also, take a look at maybe the idea
here of even running it in PowerShell as

260
00:17:25.220 --> 00:17:29.480
well, cuz that may also be viable for
you when you get ready for the exam.

261
00:17:29.480 --> 00:17:30.980
So thank you, Cherokee,
for helping us there.

262
00:17:30.980 --> 00:17:33.900
And thank you also for joining us,
but this a great place for

263
00:17:33.900 --> 00:17:35.660
us to end this episode then.

264
00:17:35.660 --> 00:17:39.277
Signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

265
00:17:39.277 --> 00:17:40.493
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

266
00:17:40.493 --> 00:17:44.521
>> Stay tuned right here for more of
the MCSA Windows Server 2012 shows.

267
00:17:44.521 --> 00:17:52.059
[MUSIC]

268
00:17:52.059 --> 00:17:54.665
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.title: Configure IPv4 and IPv6
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.130 --> 00:00:01.230
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.230 --> 00:00:02.489
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.489 --> 00:00:06.030
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.030 --> 00:00:08.217
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.217 --> 00:00:12.227
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.227 --> 00:00:15.865
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.865 --> 00:00:17.410
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

8
00:00:17.410 --> 00:00:22.434
And today, we're doing our
MCSA Window Server 2012 in preparation for

9
00:00:22.434 --> 00:00:24.760
that 70-410 exam.

10
00:00:24.760 --> 00:00:26.843
And specifically, in this episode,

11
00:00:26.843 --> 00:00:30.694
we're gonna be taking a look at ways
we can configure IPv4 and IPv6.

12
00:00:30.694 --> 00:00:33.890
Here to show us how to do all
the fun stuff is Ms. Cherokee Boose.

13
00:00:33.890 --> 00:00:34.920
Welcome back Cherokee.

14
00:00:34.920 --> 00:00:35.730
>> How's it going today Mike?

15
00:00:35.730 --> 00:00:37.210
>> It's going great, thanks.

16
00:00:37.210 --> 00:00:40.260
>> Thank you for having me, I'm really
excited to be here today because you know

17
00:00:40.260 --> 00:00:44.550
this topic is one that you may have or
have not already been introduced to.

18
00:00:45.660 --> 00:00:50.540
It's important to us here in Server
because we need to understand it at

19
00:00:50.540 --> 00:00:54.110
a fundamental level before we can
actually implement it and configure it.

20
00:00:54.110 --> 00:00:55.370
That's not really the hard part.

21
00:00:55.370 --> 00:00:59.830
Just understanding why we're typing
certain numbers in is the hard part.

22
00:00:59.830 --> 00:01:04.701
So, you may have seen this if you've taken
any kind of prior training usually like

23
00:01:04.701 --> 00:01:06.760
Net Plus is a great place to start.

24
00:01:06.760 --> 00:01:10.847
If this is brand new to you and you have
no clue to what we're talking about here,

25
00:01:10.847 --> 00:01:13.105
then definitely go back and
check that out.

26
00:01:13.105 --> 00:01:16.832
Because there's a lot of ground
level type information that's

27
00:01:16.832 --> 00:01:18.357
shared in those classes.

28
00:01:18.357 --> 00:01:22.847
I know I have done specific
shows on some of these topics,

29
00:01:22.847 --> 00:01:27.268
even in the Server 101 and
we have seen a lot of those.

30
00:01:27.268 --> 00:01:31.140
>> They get covered in a lot of
different classes, it is one of those

31
00:01:31.140 --> 00:01:35.300
fundamental skills that we have to have,
whether you are a help desk technician,

32
00:01:35.300 --> 00:01:39.910
a administrator for
a small network or a global network.

33
00:01:39.910 --> 00:01:42.930
It is a very important skill
to have because we know that

34
00:01:42.930 --> 00:01:46.840
IP addresses that what we use to
communicate back and forth across network.

35
00:01:46.840 --> 00:01:50.390
So obviously, a very important part
of maintaining our environment.

36
00:01:50.390 --> 00:01:55.009
>> Most definitely and if we look at
the actual historical aspect of it and

37
00:01:55.009 --> 00:01:56.964
I have this on my screen here,

38
00:01:56.964 --> 00:02:00.823
this is just a very basic
a simple diagram here of ARPANET.

39
00:02:00.823 --> 00:02:05.826
And if we back in time here to
like circa 1970 we can see that

40
00:02:05.826 --> 00:02:12.030
even here at UCLA where that first
transmission was actually sent from.

41
00:02:12.030 --> 00:02:15.630
At this point and time we just
have a handful of nodes, right?
