491
00:28:00.490 --> 00:28:03.824
I'm gonna be starting here at 0, right?

492
00:28:03.824 --> 00:28:06.064
So 0 plus 32 is?

493
00:28:06.064 --> 00:28:07.890
Do we need the calculator?

494
00:28:07.890 --> 00:28:08.713
>> No, I think we got that one.

495
00:28:08.713 --> 00:28:13.534
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, and then we'll know that

496
00:28:13.534 --> 00:28:19.320
the network ID for
network two is going to be 216.10.1.32.

497
00:28:19.320 --> 00:28:24.270
And we can proceed just
going through this looking

498
00:28:24.270 --> 00:28:26.830
at adding 32 all the way down here.

499
00:28:26.830 --> 00:28:32.110
So we've got 64, 96, 128, and
I went ahead and did an extra,

500
00:28:32.110 --> 00:28:36.510
created an extra network
here just because it's easy.

501
00:28:36.510 --> 00:28:42.000
When you think about well, how do I
define that full range there because

502
00:28:42.000 --> 00:28:46.410
the full range exists by subtracting one.

503
00:28:46.410 --> 00:28:50.457
So, I have not completely lined up here,
and let me just show you.

504
00:28:50.457 --> 00:28:51.470
All right.

505
00:28:54.915 --> 00:28:56.537
There we go, that's correct.

506
00:28:56.537 --> 00:29:00.030
[LAUGH] I'm looking at them
like that's not lined up right.

507
00:29:00.030 --> 00:29:08.320
All right, so for network one,
I have 216.10.1.0.

508
00:29:08.320 --> 00:29:09.995
That's my first IP address.

509
00:29:09.995 --> 00:29:13.380
It's not my first assignable IP address,
but my first IP address.

510
00:29:13.380 --> 00:29:18.457
My last IP address is one less
than the following network,

511
00:29:18.457 --> 00:29:21.679
so I have 216.10.1.31.

512
00:29:21.679 --> 00:29:26.330
Now something special about that first and
the last IP address there.

513
00:29:26.330 --> 00:29:30.360
So our first address is gonna be
referencing that network ID and

514
00:29:30.360 --> 00:29:33.890
the last here is gonna be signifying
the broadcast transmission.

515
00:29:33.890 --> 00:29:37.510
That's the one Mike was talking about
being in that room at that party or

516
00:29:37.510 --> 00:29:39.370
whatever with those 100 people.

517
00:29:39.370 --> 00:29:44.720
So that's how I can send a message to
all of the other 99 people in that room,

518
00:29:44.720 --> 00:29:46.130
so they can all hear me, right.

519
00:29:47.200 --> 00:29:49.800
And that's just why I did
an extra one here for

520
00:29:49.800 --> 00:29:53.990
160 because I can easily see that
159 would be my broadcast there.

521
00:29:53.990 --> 00:29:56.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and just a quick little trick,

522
00:29:56.870 --> 00:29:59.410
I wanted to share this with you also.

523
00:29:59.410 --> 00:30:02.737
Let me get rid of this, it's bothering me.

524
00:30:02.737 --> 00:30:07.369
All right, 2 to the power of x is a quick
little trick that you can use whenever you

525
00:30:07.369 --> 00:30:10.880
wanna find out the number
of available networks here.

526
00:30:10.880 --> 00:30:12.650
So in our situation,

527
00:30:12.650 --> 00:30:17.330
x is going to be equivalent to the number
of new network bits that we've added.

528
00:30:17.330 --> 00:30:20.253
So if you think back to the number
of network bits that we added,

529
00:30:20.253 --> 00:30:21.258
that was gonna be 3.

530
00:30:21.258 --> 00:30:25.695
So 2 to the power of 3 here is
going to be equaling 8, so,

531
00:30:25.695 --> 00:30:30.780
If I needed five networks,
here I have the potential of having 8.

532
00:30:30.780 --> 00:30:35.510
So I'm only wasting 3,
whereas if I were to go back

533
00:30:35.510 --> 00:30:39.710
to my class C, my class full addresses,

534
00:30:39.710 --> 00:30:44.190
I can see class C, the number of
networks I have over 2 million.

535
00:30:44.190 --> 00:30:47.850
So I'm wasting a lot less, I mean for
five networks to go ahead and

536
00:30:47.850 --> 00:30:49.760
assign that full class C.

537
00:30:49.760 --> 00:30:51.580
That's what we're talking
about when we're saving or

538
00:30:51.580 --> 00:30:53.930
preserving those IP addresses here.

539
00:30:55.880 --> 00:30:59.310
And then lastly,
there was one more way you could look at

540
00:30:59.310 --> 00:31:03.520
the number of possible hosts per network
and this was pretty easy as well.

541
00:31:03.520 --> 00:31:07.350
If we take 2 to the power of x minus 2.

542
00:31:07.350 --> 00:31:11.600
Minus 2 signifying that network bit or
that network address,

543
00:31:11.600 --> 00:31:14.370
the first one and the broadcast
address being that second one.

544
00:31:14.370 --> 00:31:17.012
So we subtract 2 because
can't assign those.

545
00:31:17.012 --> 00:31:22.050
But that's going to give us the possible
hosts that we can have per network.

546
00:31:22.050 --> 00:31:27.200
And here x, our variable, is going to
be referencing the number of host bits.

547
00:31:27.200 --> 00:31:32.320
So if I scroll up, I can just count here
that my host bits are going to be one two,

548
00:31:32.320 --> 00:31:34.470
three, four, five.

549
00:31:34.470 --> 00:31:39.960
So if I take 2 to the power of 5,
that would give me 32 minus 2,

550
00:31:39.960 --> 00:31:44.580
meaning I can have 30 end users or
nodes, printers,

551
00:31:44.580 --> 00:31:48.090
servers, whatever,
within each one of these networks here.

552
00:31:48.090 --> 00:31:51.630
So that's why and
how we would go ahead and break those up.

553
00:31:51.630 --> 00:31:55.209
So how does that relate to Server 2012 R2?

554
00:31:55.209 --> 00:31:58.768
Well, when we look at different settings
and we're assigning those IP addresses,

555
00:31:58.768 --> 00:32:02.840
we have to be cognizant of how we're
creating those divisions and separations.

556
00:32:02.840 --> 00:32:06.720
As well as even configuring
other core network services,

557
00:32:06.720 --> 00:32:09.830
like DHCP and creating those scopes there.

558
00:32:09.830 --> 00:32:13.980
So just kind of reminding
you how that happens.

559
00:32:13.980 --> 00:32:16.550
And I'm looking at the time and
I think we're out of time but

560
00:32:16.550 --> 00:32:19.690
we have a lot more to cover here,
so you don't wanna miss out.

561
00:32:19.690 --> 00:32:23.874
>> Fantastic, all right, that means
we'll be coming back for a part two,

562
00:32:23.874 --> 00:32:25.666
configuring IPv4 and IPv6.

563
00:32:25.666 --> 00:32:28.820
Good stuff so far, Cherokee,
looking forward to that next part.

564
00:32:28.820 --> 00:32:30.290
Hope you guys are too.

565
00:32:30.290 --> 00:32:33.240
For now signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

566
00:32:33.240 --> 00:32:34.163
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

567
00:32:34.163 --> 00:32:36.123
>> And we'll see you next time.

568
00:32:36.123 --> 00:32:42.053
[MUSIC]

569
00:32:42.053 --> 00:32:45.328
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.title: Configure IPv4 and IPv6 Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.200
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.200 --> 00:00:07.335
I'm your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.335 --> 00:00:11.599
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.599 --> 00:00:15.390
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.390 --> 00:00:20.390
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and
today we're doing our MCSA Server

6
00:00:20.390 --> 00:00:24.630
2012 in preparation for that 70-410 Exam.

7
00:00:24.630 --> 00:00:28.310
In this episode, we're focusing
in on Configuring IPv4 and v6.

8
00:00:28.310 --> 00:00:32.200
This is a part two, so if you missed part
one make sure you go back and check that

9
00:00:32.200 --> 00:00:37.300
out, so that you can catch up with us
where we are here for this part two.

10
00:00:37.300 --> 00:00:40.640
And back in the studios today is Miss
Cherokee Boose, welcome back Cherokee.

11
00:00:40.640 --> 00:00:41.520
>> Hi, how's it going, Mike?

12
00:00:41.520 --> 00:00:43.110
>> Going fantastic, glad you're here.

13
00:00:43.110 --> 00:00:45.560
Excited to pick up where we left off,

14
00:00:45.560 --> 00:00:50.020
we were talking about subnetting
an IPv4 I think at the end of part one.

15
00:00:50.020 --> 00:00:53.470
>> And so I think that's a great
place to pick back up here because

16
00:00:53.470 --> 00:00:56.330
we need to really look at the IPv4, and

17
00:00:56.330 --> 00:01:00.310
then we'll move on forward to IPv6
come and get timeline there, right?

18
00:01:00.310 --> 00:01:02.032
>> Skip an IP version 5?

19
00:01:02.032 --> 00:01:03.994
>> [LAUGH] What happened to that?

20
00:01:03.994 --> 00:01:06.607
>> It just got folded up and,
yeah [LAUGH].

21
00:01:06.607 --> 00:01:08.040
>> [LAUGH] Anyhoo.

22
00:01:08.040 --> 00:01:11.430
Okay, so we did look at subnetting and
that was a way that we

23
00:01:11.430 --> 00:01:14.800
could logically separate portions
of our network for reasons.

24
00:01:14.800 --> 00:01:18.940
Such as, Mike gave a really good
example about having the hundred people

25
00:01:18.940 --> 00:01:23.160
in the room, and being able to prevent
any kind of collisions there, or

26
00:01:23.160 --> 00:01:25.790
being able to communicate
without being interrupted.

27
00:01:25.790 --> 00:01:31.610
So what if we wanted to perform something
like the transverse of that, and we wanted

28
00:01:31.610 --> 00:01:37.710
to take, maybe we inherited a network
that was already segmented, subnetted.

29
00:01:37.710 --> 00:01:43.440
But we wanted to do something called
supernetting or route summarization,

30
00:01:43.440 --> 00:01:48.020
route aggregation, maybe for
the purpose of reducing the amount of

31
00:01:48.020 --> 00:01:52.540
information that our routers needed to
maintain within those routing tables.

32
00:01:52.540 --> 00:01:53.320
>> I like that.

33
00:01:53.320 --> 00:01:57.870
Yeah, cuz as we add more and more subnets,
each one of those becomes a route in

34
00:01:57.870 --> 00:02:00.850
that routing table and
that's more work on the router.

35
00:02:00.850 --> 00:02:03.578
>> Yeah, so
any time I can remember less information,

36
00:02:03.578 --> 00:02:05.690
that's always going to be a plus for me.

37
00:02:05.690 --> 00:02:06.531
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

38
00:02:06.531 --> 00:02:09.360
I'm thinking the routers feel
the same way, I don't know.

39
00:02:10.400 --> 00:02:14.250
So, I'll just briefly show you kind
of what I'm talking about here.

40
00:02:14.250 --> 00:02:19.170
You're not going to be,
it's one of those things again,

41
00:02:19.170 --> 00:02:22.000
like Microsoft just says hey,
if you're not familiar with it,

42
00:02:22.000 --> 00:02:25.660
you should just kind of revisit that
before getting into the exam booth here.

43
00:02:25.660 --> 00:02:29.340
But the example I just wanted to show, why
we would use that and kind of what that

44
00:02:29.340 --> 00:02:33.270
looked like is if I were to have
different portions of my network here,

45
00:02:33.270 --> 00:02:39.270
maybe a segment for my VOIP phones, I have
my security cameras all on one segment.

46
00:02:39.270 --> 00:02:41.880
My teller machines, as well as,

47
00:02:41.880 --> 00:02:46.790
a separate segment there for
my ATM machines here at a bank.

48
00:02:46.790 --> 00:02:48.310
So that makes sense right?

49
00:02:48.310 --> 00:02:49.750
>> Absolutely, it could be done for

50
00:02:49.750 --> 00:02:53.680
a little bit of security, it could be to
make sure that the VOIP traffic doesn't

51
00:02:53.680 --> 00:02:57.280
affect my teller's ability to
do their job, or ATMs from

52
00:02:57.280 --> 00:03:00.010
processing transaction because there's
too many phone calls going on, right?

53
00:03:00.010 --> 00:03:02.130
So by separating out that traffic,
you know,

54
00:03:02.130 --> 00:03:05.350
we can keep the bandwidth
utilization down.

55
00:03:05.350 --> 00:03:07.199
>> Right, so if we were to look at that,

56
00:03:07.199 --> 00:03:11.202
and say, someone had already separated
the [INAUDIBLE] like a slash 26 there,

57
00:03:11.202 --> 00:03:14.600
then what can I do to aggregate that or
to help out my routers.

58
00:03:14.600 --> 00:03:17.960
So the reason I have it written
out in decimal and binary, is so

59
00:03:17.960 --> 00:03:22.870
you can kind of see where these dividing
lines are happening, and currently,

60
00:03:22.870 --> 00:03:28.810
you can see that with that slash 22 or
excuse me, 26 here.

61
00:03:28.810 --> 00:03:33.410
I'm two network bytes over from that
normal what we would see, if you think

62
00:03:33.410 --> 00:03:37.130
about just the regular slash 24 and
that's what we wanna get back to there.

63
00:03:37.130 --> 00:03:40.400
Or if that's where we
had started originally.

64
00:03:40.400 --> 00:03:43.250
So what you can do is when you write
in out in binary, it does help for

65
00:03:43.250 --> 00:03:46.510
this process, and
you look at that dividing line.

66
00:03:46.510 --> 00:03:49.610
So if I were to see this is
where we are currently, and

67
00:03:49.610 --> 00:03:54.040
I want to kind of change that to a slash
24 for the aggregation purposes,

68
00:03:54.040 --> 00:03:56.890
then I would need to go ahead and
move that.

69
00:03:56.890 --> 00:04:05.200
So with the help of our ANDing process
there I can go ahead and everything that.

70
00:04:05.200 --> 00:04:09.010
Depending on where your dividing line is,
everything to the left is going to be one,

71
00:04:09.010 --> 00:04:11.580
everything to the right
is going to be zeroes.

72
00:04:11.580 --> 00:04:16.280
So I can aggregate them and essentially,
if I were to change that dividing line

73
00:04:16.280 --> 00:04:20.550
over by two, I could go ahead and
have a slash 24.

74
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:25.652
And of course each one of these portions,
these segments would still be part of that

75
00:04:25.652 --> 00:04:30.130
slash 24, but it would just be easier for
the routers to discern that information.

76
00:04:30.130 --> 00:04:31.750
>> Yeah,
I think that's a great example there.

77
00:04:31.750 --> 00:04:34.822
If you move that red
line back over to the /26

78
00:04:34.822 --> 00:04:35.542
>> Mm-hm.

79
00:04:35.542 --> 00:04:39.994
>> Right, we can see that each one of
those is a different network, very easy to

80
00:04:39.994 --> 00:04:44.600
tell the last 2 bits are different for
all four of those routes or the subnets.

81
00:04:44.600 --> 00:04:50.928
But as soon as you move that line 2
bits to the left, now the subnet,

82
00:04:50.928 --> 00:04:55.280
to the left of that line all four of
those subnets, look exactly the same.

83
00:04:55.280 --> 00:04:56.040
>> Yeah.
>> Right?

84
00:04:56.040 --> 00:05:00.570
Which is what allows me to
now use one mask slash 24 to

85
00:05:00.570 --> 00:05:04.160
represent all four of those subnets,
all right?

86
00:05:04.160 --> 00:05:08.436
And again this done on a router,
it's not dissolving the subnets, right?

87
00:05:08.436 --> 00:05:11.900
There's still separate subnets, but
as far as the router's concerned,

88
00:05:11.900 --> 00:05:15.450
if all four these subnets were down
the same path, the router can now have

89
00:05:15.450 --> 00:05:19.510
one route to all four of those networks,
rather than having four routes that

90
00:05:19.510 --> 00:05:23.010
it has to go through, every time
traffic's bound to one of those subnets.

91
00:05:23.010 --> 00:05:24.830
>> Yeah, so
just like a couple different things,

92
00:05:24.830 --> 00:05:28.190
if you're not too familiar with it, then
definitely check that out a little more.

93
00:05:28.190 --> 00:05:30.890
I'm sure we have shows here
in our course library.

94
00:05:32.020 --> 00:05:34.560
But now let's think about moving forward.

95
00:05:34.560 --> 00:05:37.410
So we did say we're gonna go ahead and
skip IP version 5,

96
00:05:37.410 --> 00:05:40.060
but what about in that interim there.

97
00:05:40.060 --> 00:05:43.180
What do we do for these,
you know, transitioning.

98
00:05:43.180 --> 00:05:46.880
And what do those different types
of transmissions look like.

99
00:05:46.880 --> 00:05:50.420
So I just happen to have
transmission types right here.

100
00:05:50.420 --> 00:05:51.930
Some of them are the same.

101
00:05:51.930 --> 00:05:54.180
They share different
types of transmissions.

102
00:05:54.180 --> 00:05:57.270
But some of them are unique
to the different versions.

103
00:05:58.490 --> 00:06:03.960
Unicast, all right, so
Unicast we're gonna see in both IPv4 and

104
00:06:03.960 --> 00:06:08.370
IPv6, so it's gonna be just there
with our wonder one communication.

105
00:06:08.370 --> 00:06:13.210
And so
with IPv4 that Unicast could look like,

106
00:06:14.400 --> 00:06:18.120
it could look like a private address,
it could look like a public address.

107
00:06:18.120 --> 00:06:19.220
Let me zoom in a little bit so that we
can see these a little more specific.

108
00:06:19.220 --> 00:06:20.485
>> Thank you, I was just gonna ask you.

109
00:06:20.485 --> 00:06:22.273
I can't see, I'm old.

110
00:06:22.273 --> 00:06:23.457
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, I am too.

111
00:06:23.457 --> 00:06:25.338
[LAUGH]
>> That's better.

112
00:06:25.338 --> 00:06:26.882
>> I believe this helps you guys, as well.

113
00:06:26.882 --> 00:06:29.907
But a Unicast identifies a single
interface and is used for

114
00:06:29.907 --> 00:06:32.080
host to host communication, all right.

115
00:06:32.080 --> 00:06:33.800
So we see that in both IPv4, IPv6.

116
00:06:33.800 --> 00:06:38.910
And I've just noted some different
examples, as well as their prefix policies

117
00:06:38.910 --> 00:06:44.980
here for different types of addresses that
can utilize Unicast transmissions here.

118
00:06:46.690 --> 00:06:50.820
This is kind of interesting though,
we do have a couple deprecated terms.

119
00:06:50.820 --> 00:06:53.790
If you guys are out on the internet and
you know you are studying and

120
00:06:53.790 --> 00:06:56.840
you come across some kind of
documentation that reference.

121
00:06:56.840 --> 00:07:00.130
And even Microsoft on some of their
sites haven't been fully updated.

122
00:07:00.130 --> 00:07:05.590
But it might says something like,
site local address, which

123
00:07:05.590 --> 00:07:11.400
Is basically going to be referencing
confined to that particular LAN.

124
00:07:11.400 --> 00:07:13.450
But that's not a term
that's really used anymore.

125
00:07:13.450 --> 00:07:15.950
So just know that that's an old
document that you're reading.

126
00:07:15.950 --> 00:07:16.450
As well as,

127
00:07:16.450 --> 00:07:22.350
if you see something like the term
specified is IPv4 compatible addresses.

128
00:07:22.350 --> 00:07:26.740
So if you reference the RFCs then they
can explain that a little bit more and

129
00:07:26.740 --> 00:07:31.220
tell you what the well we'll see here,
what the newer terminology is called.

130
00:07:32.520 --> 00:07:38.540
So again, in IPv4 and IPv6,
we have multicast transmissions.

131
00:07:38.540 --> 00:07:39.930
So if you think about that.

132
00:07:39.930 --> 00:07:45.866
And I was always using this example,
like pay-per-view shows.

133
00:07:45.866 --> 00:07:47.745
So not everyone on that,

134
00:07:47.745 --> 00:07:52.847
not everyone who has cable gets
a particular pay-per-view show.

135
00:07:52.847 --> 00:07:54.496
It’s only whoever pays for it.

136
00:07:54.496 --> 00:07:58.752
So if you’re part of that multicast group
Then you would get to watch that show or

137
00:07:58.752 --> 00:08:03.340
that fight, or whatever kind of sporting
event that you had ordered, right?

138
00:08:03.340 --> 00:08:05.725
So what does that look
like with IP Version 4?

139
00:08:05.725 --> 00:08:10.502
Well, here, we have particular addresses
that are gonna be reserved for

140
00:08:10.502 --> 00:08:12.755
those multicast transmissions.

141
00:08:12.755 --> 00:08:17.155
Whereas IP version six,
we're gonna see that prefix

142
00:08:17.155 --> 00:08:21.785
policy there with that FF to go ahead and
indicate, and there are variants of that.

143
00:08:21.785 --> 00:08:23.640
But just generally speaking you,

144

00:26:41.989 --> 00:26:47.376

IPv6 has something similar to that,

So if we think about that, and

00:28:42.300 --> 00:28:46.171
So for global unicast address,

00:28:50.371 --> 00:28:55.184
But we do have a link local address,

00:28:55.184 --> 00:29:00.348
version 4 address there, and

00:29:00.348 --> 00:29:04.999

00:29:04.999 --> 00:29:06.810

00:29:06.810 --> 00:29:09.930
So I can route it between subnets, but

00:29:14.690 --> 00:29:16.518

00:29:24.583 --> 00:29:29.620

00:29:29.620 --> 00:29:35.276
Things like loopback,

00:29:40.620 --> 00:29:44.234

00:29:55.952 --> 00:30:01.897

00:30:53.025 --> 00:30:55.685

00:30:55.685 --> 00:30:57.785

00:30:57.785 --> 00:31:00.475

00:31:05.272 --> 00:31:08.269

00:31:08.269 --> 00:31:12.504

00:31:12.504 --> 00:31:14.060

00:31:14.060 --> 00:31:17.050
Just kind of like what we would see

00:31:17.050 --> 00:31:18.830

00:31:18.830 --> 00:31:23.970
And preferred means if I had a preference,

00:31:41.590 --> 00:31:45.977

00:31:45.977 --> 00:31:49.570

564
00:31:49.570 --> 00:31:53.153
But let's just go ahead and

565
00:31:53.153 --> 00:31:57.017
If I can go full screen for a moment,
this is really important, guys.

566
00:31:57.017 --> 00:31:58.670
First thing on the list,

567
00:31:58.670 --> 00:32:03.490
IPv4 fragmentation is performed by
both routers and the sending host.

568
00:32:03.490 --> 00:32:04.720
What does that mean?

569
00:32:04.720 --> 00:32:08.504
Well, if you think about your MTUs,
your maximum transmission units,

570
00:32:08.504 --> 00:32:10.935
you can go ahead and
modify them accordingly.

571
00:32:10.935 --> 00:32:13.740
With IPv6, we cannot fragment.

572
00:32:13.740 --> 00:32:19.880
So what that means is our routers,
our devices that are routing our packets,

573
00:32:19.880 --> 00:32:26.580
have to have a high enough MTU to allow
those packets to go through them.

574
00:32:26.580 --> 00:32:31.460
What happens if the MTU is lower
than the size of the packet?

575
00:32:31.460 --> 00:32:35.135
Well just like with ICMPv4,
we'll get a notification,

576
00:32:35.135 --> 00:32:39.414
a message, saying hey there was
a problem with your transmission.

577
00:32:39.414 --> 00:32:42.410
Like when we used PING,
we can check on that and so forth.

578
00:32:42.410 --> 00:32:46.610
Well for whatever reason, if you
feel like hey I'm gonna go ahead and

579
00:32:46.610 --> 00:32:50.290
disable ICMPv6,

580
00:32:50.290 --> 00:32:55.400
you'll never get a notification
that your packet didn't go

581
00:32:55.400 --> 00:33:00.510
through that router if it were
larger than the MTU on that router.

582
00:33:00.510 --> 00:33:03.464
So essentially,
you'd be breaking everything.

583
00:33:03.464 --> 00:33:05.930
>> You're trying to think it can go,
but you wouldn't get a reason why.

584
00:33:05.930 --> 00:33:07.250
>> You would never know, yeah.

585
00:33:07.250 --> 00:33:12.179
So you definitely, if you're gonna
be utilizing IPv6 make sure that

586
00:33:12.179 --> 00:33:17.870
you still allow that ICMPv6 traffic
through your firewalls as well.

587
00:33:17.870 --> 00:33:19.922
Now, we did kinda touch on this so
I'll be brief.

588
00:33:19.922 --> 00:33:27.020
ARP, we see IPv4 can exist in IPv6 because
of no broadcast transmissions, right?

589
00:33:27.020 --> 00:33:32.760
So here with IPv4, we use iGMP,
internet group management protocol.

590
00:33:32.760 --> 00:33:38.297
However, a newer protocol called the
Multicast Listener is gonna be used for

591
00:33:38.297 --> 00:33:42.315

so there's a change.

592
00:33:42.315 --> 00:33:46.971
And again, this is the ICMP that

593
00:33:46.971 --> 00:33:49.455
You do see that there are differences,

00:33:49.455 --> 00:33:54.190
there's a version 4 that typically

819
00:46:40.950 --> 00:46:42.990
everybody on the network uses it.

820
00:46:42.990 --> 00:46:46.490
It's only a number used
internally by that machine

821
00:46:46.490 --> 00:46:50.220
to differentiate between link local
addresses on different networks or

822
00:46:50.220 --> 00:46:53.170
which one is supposed to use for different
networks, just keep that in mind.

823
00:46:53.170 --> 00:46:55.646
Cuz I know people go,
why don't they all say percent well?

824
00:46:55.646 --> 00:46:58.345
Or sometimes it says percent three,
or something like that.

825
00:46:58.345 --> 00:47:01.750
It's just an internal identifier
that the system uses.

826
00:47:01.750 --> 00:47:06.349
>> Yeah and again you have the same
options like we saw with IPv4 for

827
00:47:06.349 --> 00:47:10.720
our subnet here,
the subnet prefix link, excuse me.

828
00:47:10.720 --> 00:47:13.924
As well as our default gateway,
and then setting that statically-

829
00:47:13.924 --> 00:47:15.494
>> I'll tell you this,

830
00:47:15.494 --> 00:47:20.206
when I first saw this window,
this is when I realized because you

831
00:47:20.206 --> 00:47:25.197
look at IP before and the fields
that you're typing in are yea wide.

832
00:47:25.197 --> 00:47:27.311
And then open up IPv6 and
it's a mile wide-

833
00:47:27.311 --> 00:47:28.515
>> [LAUGH]

834
00:47:28.515 --> 00:47:29.064
>> It's so much bigger.

835
00:47:29.064 --> 00:47:32.380
>> And that's when I realized I really
wanna learn about auto configuration.

836
00:47:32.380 --> 00:47:34.884
>> Yeah, realistically-
>> And

837
00:47:34.884 --> 00:47:40.154
there's gonna be times when you gotta
need to statically match certain devices.

838
00:47:40.154 --> 00:47:41.410
>> Yeah, it's true.
>> And you know we tease and

839
00:47:41.410 --> 00:47:42.429
we give a hard time.

840
00:47:42.429 --> 00:47:47.520
But you're gonna have a company prefix,
and it doesn't have to be that long.

841
00:47:47.520 --> 00:47:52.737
Your interface ID is while there's 64 bits
available if you're statically mapping,

842
00:47:52.737 --> 00:47:56.087
there's nothing that says
you have to use all 64 bits.

843
00:47:56.087 --> 00:47:59.640
I mean, I can do ::2 or
whatever I need to do.

844
00:47:59.640 --> 00:48:01.348
So it's not as bad as it looks.

845
00:48:01.348 --> 00:48:03.242
But I tell you,
the first time I saw the window-

846
00:48:03.242 --> 00:48:05.439
>> It can be intimidating, for sure.

847
00:48:05.439 --> 00:48:06.602
>> Yeah, I got a little scared [LAUGH].

848
00:48:06.602 --> 00:48:09.629
>> [LAUGH] Well on that note,
IPv6 is not really scary.

849
00:48:09.629 --> 00:48:13.073
Just spend a little extra time getting
to know it if you're not too familiar.

850
00:48:13.073 --> 00:48:14.850
Definitely take a look at the show notes.

851
00:48:14.850 --> 00:48:16.371
I'll attach those documents.

852
00:48:16.371 --> 00:48:21.257
And remember the different states,
prefixes,

853
00:48:21.257 --> 00:48:26.390
bits, and
ways that you can select those options.

854
00:48:26.390 --> 00:48:29.126
I think that's about as much
advice as I can give you here.

855
00:48:29.126 --> 00:48:30.127
[LAUGH]
>> All right,

856
00:48:30.127 --> 00:48:32.471
well that was a lot of great information.

857
00:48:32.471 --> 00:48:36.487
Dealing with both IPv4 as well as IPv6.

858
00:48:36.487 --> 00:48:38.780
So we thank you for that, Cherokee.

859
00:48:38.780 --> 00:48:40.948
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

860
00:48:40.948 --> 00:48:44.040
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.

861
00:48:44.040 --> 00:48:44.658
>> And I'm Cherokee Boose.

862
00:48:44.658 --> 00:48:45.509
>> And we'll see you next time.

863
00:48:45.509 --> 00:48:52.760
[MUSIC]

864
00:48:52.760 --> 00:48:56.187
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

topics.title: Deploy and configure core network services

episodes.title: Install Domain Controllers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:00.989
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:00.989 --> 00:00:02.213
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.213 --> 00:00:06.533
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.533 --> 00:00:08.148
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.148 --> 00:00:11.734
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.734 --> 00:00:15.408
>> Welcome ladies and
gentlemen to your 70-410 series.

7
00:00:15.408 --> 00:00:17.860
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:17.860 --> 00:00:22.220
In this episode, we'll be taking a look at
well how to install domain controllers.

9
00:00:22.220 --> 00:00:26.050
And with us today in studios, we have Mr.
Mike Rodrick, how's it going today Mike?

10
00:00:26.050 --> 00:00:28.063
>> It's going great Cherokee,
thanks for having me back.

11
00:00:28.063 --> 00:00:28.700
>> Always, yeah.

12
00:00:28.700 --> 00:00:30.637
>> Yes, excited to be here as always,

13
00:00:30.637 --> 00:00:35.450
cuz we're talking about one of my favorite
topics and that is Active Directory.

14
00:00:35.450 --> 00:00:38.380
All right, so
if we're gonna work with Active Directory,

15
00:00:38.380 --> 00:00:42.220
which is what we want to do in the end,
we need to get it installed.

16
00:00:42.220 --> 00:00:44.240
We need to create these
domain controllers, and

17
00:00:44.240 --> 00:00:46.720
I guess that's where we should start.

18
00:00:46.720 --> 00:00:50.610
When we talk about a domain
controller what we're doing is,

19
00:00:50.610 --> 00:00:55.680
we're installing the Active Directory
domain services role on a member server.

20
00:00:55.680 --> 00:00:59.019
We're taking a server,
we install that role, and

21
00:00:59.019 --> 00:01:01.906
that makes it becomes a domain controller.

22
00:01:01.906 --> 00:01:03.521
And we know in our domain environments,

23
00:01:03.521 --> 00:01:07.190
domain controllers are the ones that
are in charge of security, for example.

24
00:01:07.190 --> 00:01:08.631
They are trusted throughout the domain.

25
00:01:08.631 --> 00:01:10.470
They do the authentication process.

26
00:01:10.470 --> 00:01:14.143
They issue the ticket granting tickets and
the service granting tickets.

27
00:01:14.143 --> 00:01:18.829
And they issue or they, what else they-
>> But

28
00:01:18.829 --> 00:01:22.294
basically, I think you have even
explained it this way before,

29
00:01:22.294 --> 00:01:25.899
they're like the yellow pages
of computer network here, right?

30
00:01:25.899 --> 00:01:26.421
>> Yup.

31
00:01:26.421 --> 00:01:29.520
>> So they're housing that information
that we need to know within our networks.

32
00:01:29.520 --> 00:01:31.980
>> They do, they store the database
with all the user accounts,

33
00:01:31.980 --> 00:01:33.380
all the computer accounts.

34
00:01:33.380 --> 00:01:37.280
Responsible for deploying group policy
out to our machines and to our users.

35
00:01:37.280 --> 00:01:41.060
So they are the pivot or
the key component in our domain.

36
00:01:41.060 --> 00:01:43.670
So we need to know how
to install those guys.

37
00:01:43.670 --> 00:01:46.645
And that's what we're gonna do in
these next couple of episodes,

38
00:01:46.645 --> 00:01:49.830
cuz there are really several different
ways to install domain controllers

39
00:01:49.830 --> 00:01:53.600
depending on what you have and
what route you wanna go.

40
00:01:53.600 --> 00:01:56.780
We also have to understand
what we have before we start.

41
00:01:56.780 --> 00:01:58.751
We need to talk about a couple of things.

42
00:01:58.751 --> 00:02:03.659
We need to talk about functional levels
at both the domain and the forest level,

43
00:02:03.659 --> 00:02:08.272
as well as a tool that we would use known
as ADPrep to get everything ready for

44
00:02:08.272 --> 00:02:11.910
our brand new 2012 R2 domain controller.

45
00:02:11.910 --> 00:02:15.258
So let's start out Cherokee talking
about good old functional levels, right?

46
00:02:15.258 --> 00:02:15.936
>> Okay.

47
00:02:15.936 --> 00:02:17.636
>> And when talk about functional levels,

48
00:02:17.636 --> 00:02:19.930
we have to deal with it
at two different scopes.

49
00:02:19.930 --> 00:02:25.130
There's the forest functional level and
then there's the domain functional level.

50
00:02:25.130 --> 00:02:27.220
And when we look at servers, right?

51
00:02:27.220 --> 00:02:29.470
When they roll out a new operating system.

52
00:02:29.470 --> 00:02:32.968
Server 2012, Server 2012 R2,
Server 2016 down the road, right?

53
00:02:32.968 --> 00:02:37.384
When they roll out these new operating
systems, they bring along new features and

54
00:02:37.384 --> 00:02:38.924
new capabilities, right?

55
00:02:38.924 --> 00:02:42.400
They're not just rolling out the same
old operating system and renumbering it.

56
00:02:42.400 --> 00:02:43.610
>> Right, why else would we pay for it?

57
00:02:43.610 --> 00:02:44.357
>> Yeah, exactly.

58
00:02:44.357 --> 00:02:45.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> What's the point?

59
00:02:45.570 --> 00:02:47.230
So we get these new features.

60
00:02:47.230 --> 00:02:51.220
And a lot of times these new features
are understood by that new version of

61
00:02:51.220 --> 00:02:53.370
the operating system, but
not the old ones, right?

62
00:02:53.370 --> 00:02:56.850
They're new features,
they were written after 2008 was put out.

63
00:02:56.850 --> 00:03:01.630
So 2008 doesn't understand group manage
services accounts, for example, or

64
00:03:01.630 --> 00:03:02.880
something like that.

65
00:03:02.880 --> 00:03:05.430
So when we look at functional levels,
really what we're doing is,

66
00:03:05.430 --> 00:03:08.830
we're deciding what features
are going to be available.

67
00:03:08.830 --> 00:03:12.672
Because if I'm installing a 2012 R2
domain controller in an existing domain

68
00:03:12.672 --> 00:03:16.849
that already has a bunch of 2008 main
controllers, that 2012 domain controller

69
00:03:16.849 --> 00:03:20.539
is gonna know how to do things that
those 2008 domain controllers don't.

70
00:03:20.539 --> 00:03:23.467
And there's gonna be some things that
are incompatible between those versions

71
00:03:23.467 --> 00:03:25.313
between those versions
of the operating system.

72
00:03:25.313 --> 00:03:26.453
>> Well, it makes sense,

73
00:03:26.453 --> 00:03:30.215
if Microsoft is putting their developers
on to the new project or the new team,

74
00:03:30.215 --> 00:03:33.820
they're not gonna spend as much effort
on those older operation systems.

75
00:03:34.910 --> 00:03:37.460
They're not abandoning them,
but they phase them out.

76
00:03:37.460 --> 00:03:39.062
And you guys see that with
the different versions.

77
00:03:39.062 --> 00:03:42.405
>> Yeah, eventually support runs out for
2003 or 2008 or whatever,

78
00:03:42.405 --> 00:03:44.162
and eventually for 2012, right?

79
00:03:44.162 --> 00:03:47.210
2012 R2 as 2016 rolls out.

80
00:03:47.210 --> 00:03:51.110
So what we have to do,
we have to prepare our environment for

81
00:03:51.110 --> 00:03:52.610
these new operating systems.

82
00:03:52.610 --> 00:03:55.950
When we were running in an existing
domain, it's been running for years,

83
00:03:55.950 --> 00:04:00.200
let's say we're running 2008 R2 and
we decide it's time to start upgrading

84
00:04:00.200 --> 00:04:04.600
to 2012, or 2012 R2, then we need
to prepare the environment for

85
00:04:04.600 --> 00:04:07.460
that new operating system and
those new capabilities.

86
00:04:07.460 --> 00:04:09.450
And we do that with the functional levels.

87
00:04:09.450 --> 00:04:13.050
Those functional levels really cap or
determine what

88
00:04:13.050 --> 00:04:17.060
features are going to be available to
the Active Director domain service.

89
00:04:17.060 --> 00:04:18.690
>> Now Mike,
you mentioned something earlier,

90
00:04:18.690 --> 00:04:21.580
you said there are two different
functional levels that we should consider.

91
00:04:21.580 --> 00:04:24.010
We have our domain functional level and
our forest.

92
00:04:24.010 --> 00:04:26.952
So if I were brand new to
this terminology here,

93
00:04:26.952 --> 00:04:29.685
what differentiates a forest and a domain?

94
00:04:29.685 --> 00:04:35.320
>> So a domain is a security boundary,
if you will.

95
00:04:35.320 --> 00:04:37.200
We have domain controllers.

96
00:04:37.200 --> 00:04:40.080
We have objects that
exist within that domain.

97
00:04:40.080 --> 00:04:42.400
A forest is a container of domains,

98
00:04:42.400 --> 00:04:46.830
I can have more than one
domain within my forest.

99
00:04:46.830 --> 00:04:49.690
The forest also acts as
a security boundary.

100
00:04:49.690 --> 00:04:51.130
And we look at a domain, for example,

101
00:04:51.130 --> 00:04:54.720
you have the domain admins who have
full control within that domain.

102
00:04:54.720 --> 00:04:57.200
They have no rights
outside of their domain.

103
00:04:57.200 --> 00:04:58.440
But we have a forest, and

104
00:04:58.440 --> 00:05:01.500
we have an enterprise admin
that has forest-wide rights.

105
00:05:01.500 --> 00:05:05.470
So if I had two domains in this forest,
the enterprise admin actually has

106
00:05:05.470 --> 00:05:09.180
administrative rights over
both domains in that forest.

107
00:05:09.180 --> 00:05:11.275
>> Okay, so we always have a forest.

108
00:05:11.275 --> 00:05:15.721
We always have a domain, but we could have
multiple domains inside of my forest.

109
00:05:15.721 --> 00:05:16.257
>> Absolutely.

110
00:05:16.257 --> 00:05:21.515
We have domain trees, we can have
parent-child domains, definitely we can.

111
00:05:21.515 --> 00:05:26.292
It used to be, I'll tell you, I've seen
a shift for all of for 5, 10 years ago,

112
00:05:26.292 --> 00:05:30.620
we saw this thing where creating
multiple domains was the way to go.

113
00:05:30.620 --> 00:05:33.790
Nowadays, really if you look at
Microsoft recommendations of what most

114
00:05:33.790 --> 00:05:35.340
organizations are doing.

115
00:05:35.340 --> 00:05:37.530
We can accomplish what we
need with a single domain.

116
00:05:37.530 --> 00:05:43.110
So it's not as often that we need
multiple domains, but there are times.

117
00:05:43.110 --> 00:05:47.170
When you have a situation where
you've got a control administration.

118
00:05:47.170 --> 00:05:52.920
If I have resources that I need to
protect within a single domain,

119
00:05:52.920 --> 00:05:56.310
the domain admin, I can't control his
access, he has access to everything.

120
00:05:56.310 --> 00:06:00.460
So any domain admin in that domain can
administer any object within there.

121
00:06:00.460 --> 00:06:04.825
If I need separation of that, like let's
say, I've got an office in Europe and

122
00:06:04.825 --> 00:06:06.729
I've got an office here in the US.

123
00:06:06.729 --> 00:06:11.531
And I don't need the European
administrators administering objects in

124
00:06:11.531 --> 00:06:13.710
the US, and vice versus.

125
00:06:13.710 --> 00:06:15.452
Well, if we're all in one domain,

126
00:06:15.452 --> 00:06:18.772
it becomes more difficult to
separate [CROSSTALK] administration.

127
00:06:18.772 --> 00:06:19.733
>> Logically, yeah
>> Cuz now

128
00:06:19.733 --> 00:06:22.620
I've gotta create custom group
it's going to be a pain.

129
00:06:22.620 --> 00:06:24.780
Whereas if I have two different domains,
right?

130
00:06:24.780 --> 00:06:28.520
I can have domain admins in the US office,
domain admins in the Europe office, and

131
00:06:28.520 --> 00:06:29.840
they can't affect each other, rIght?

132
00:06:29.840 --> 00:06:32.930
Only the enterprise admin then
could affect both domains.

133
00:06:34.130 --> 00:06:36.330
All right, so
let's go back to the functional level.

134
00:06:36.330 --> 00:06:40.326
So we have different functional
levels at the domain level, and

135
00:06:40.326 --> 00:06:43.144
at what we call the forest
functional level.

136
00:06:43.144 --> 00:06:48.100
And as I said, they really do just define
what features are gonna be available.

137
00:06:48.100 --> 00:06:50.480
When I go to install, let's say,

138
00:06:50.480 --> 00:06:53.260
we're running a 2008 R2
domain controllers, right?

139
00:06:53.260 --> 00:06:57.270
My domain functional level is
most likely gonna be 2008 R2.

140
00:06:57.270 --> 00:07:00.260
And what that means is,
that's the highest I can go.

141
00:07:00.260 --> 00:07:04.608
I cannot have any domain controllers
above that the domain functional level.

142
00:07:04.608 --> 00:07:08.920
The domain functional level
is determined by the lowest

143
00:07:08.920 --> 00:07:11.310
operating system within that domain.

144
00:07:11.310 --> 00:07:12.160
>> So the oldest?

145
00:07:12.160 --> 00:07:15.145
>> The oldest operating system is
another way to look at it exactly.

146
00:07:15.145 --> 00:07:20.034
So if within my domain,
I have a 2008 domain controller,

147
00:07:20.034 --> 00:07:25.790
a 2012 the main controller, and
a 2012 R2 domain controller.

148
00:07:25.790 --> 00:07:28.670
My domain functional
level can only be 2008,

149
00:07:28.670 --> 00:07:30.710
because I still have
a 2008 domain controller.

150
00:07:30.710 --> 00:07:31.820
It's the oldest one,

151
00:07:31.820 --> 00:07:35.501
therefore that's the highest I can
raise the domain functional level to,

152
00:07:35.501 --> 00:07:39.259
which means I can't take advantage
of some of those 2012 R2 features.

153
00:07:39.259 --> 00:07:43.410
I have to kind of dumb everybody down
to the lowest domain controller.

154
00:07:43.410 --> 00:07:46.441
Now once I get rid of that
2008 domain controller, right?

155
00:07:46.441 --> 00:07:49.350
Now my lowest domain controller's 2012.

156
00:07:49.350 --> 00:07:52.960
I can raise my domain
functional level to 2012, and

157
00:07:52.960 --> 00:07:55.540
start taking advantage of
some of those features.

158
00:07:55.540 --> 00:07:57.590
>> So this is pretty important
when you talking about planning.

159
00:07:57.590 --> 00:08:00.478
You wanna kind of keep that in mind,
so that you're not,

160
00:08:00.478 --> 00:08:03.197
I guess forfeiting any of
those cooler new features.

161
00:08:03.197 --> 00:08:07.222
And you can really work towards
phasing out that older one.

162
00:08:07.222 --> 00:08:10.165
>> Exactly right, and this is something
you would go out to TechNet and

163
00:08:10.165 --> 00:08:12.862
look at their domain function levels and
see what you'd get.

164
00:08:12.862 --> 00:08:17.650
Like going from 2012 to 2012
R2 domain functional level

165
00:08:17.650 --> 00:08:20.850
might not give you that many features.

166
00:08:20.850 --> 00:08:23.810
But it's gonna prevent you, one thing
the domain functional level will do.

167
00:08:23.810 --> 00:08:25.870
Once you raise it to a certain bar.

168
00:08:25.870 --> 00:08:28.170
Let's say we raise it from 2008 to 2012.

169
00:08:28.170 --> 00:08:33.050
I can never go back and I can not install
any 2008 domain controllers in that

170
00:08:33.050 --> 00:08:36.000
domain anymore because
the functional level is too high.

171
00:08:36.000 --> 00:08:39.368
It's set up here so
I cannot install any domain controllers.

172
00:08:39.368 --> 00:08:43.581
And in some organizations they might say,
hey look we need another domain controller

173
00:08:43.581 --> 00:08:46.753
right now and the only machine
I've got available is 2008.

174
00:08:46.753 --> 00:08:49.780
You're in trouble, you're not gonna be
able to make that a domain controller.

175
00:08:49.780 --> 00:08:52.120
Because you raise the domain
functional level.

176
00:08:52.120 --> 00:08:53.360
And maybe you did it for a good reason or

177
00:08:53.360 --> 00:08:55.800
maybe you did it just
because higher is better.

178
00:08:55.800 --> 00:08:58.890
And that's what you don't wanna fall
into because you set that bar and

179
00:08:58.890 --> 00:08:59.930
you can't go back.

180
00:08:59.930 --> 00:09:04.840
>> Which is easy for a lot of people like
us who enjoy tech, and trying the latest

181
00:09:04.840 --> 00:09:09.162
and greatest and sometimes even
going with those beta additions.

182
00:09:09.162 --> 00:09:12.332
But when we're talking about
businesses and being in a production or

183
00:09:12.332 --> 00:09:15.200
corporate environment,
that's not always the best idea.

184
00:09:15.200 --> 00:09:17.477
>> It's not always the best
to be on the edge, right?

185

416
00:20:23.560 --> 00:20:24.180
>> My forest.

417
00:20:24.180 --> 00:20:26.220
>> Your forest, right.

418
00:20:26.220 --> 00:20:29.330
We also create a forest.

419
00:20:29.330 --> 00:20:32.140
Because you have to have a forest
the forest is the outer container

420
00:20:32.140 --> 00:20:33.160
for the domain.

421
00:20:33.160 --> 00:20:37.210
The forest actually gets its
name from the first domain.

422
00:20:37.210 --> 00:20:41.040
Let's send this guy to the back and
see if we can jump on this guy.

423
00:20:41.040 --> 00:20:44.540
I'm going to copy and paste that.

424
00:20:44.540 --> 00:20:48.520
So the forest name,
actually comes from the very first domain.

425
00:20:48.520 --> 00:20:53.950
Now once we have this domain, we can do
a few things, I can have a little server.

426
00:20:53.950 --> 00:20:58.480
Let's send this guy to the back, sorry my
drawing is kind of Goofing up on me here.

427
00:20:58.480 --> 00:21:00.450
>> You know what's kind of interesting,
Mike?

428
00:21:00.450 --> 00:21:01.170
>> What's that?

429

forestry over the weekend, right?

430
00:21:04.055 --> 00:21:05.400
>> Uh-huh.
>> So,

431

it's kind of neat when you think about it.

432
00:21:07.490 --> 00:21:12.450
I was dealing with botanists and
master gardeners and arborists.

433
00:21:12.450 --> 00:21:16.500
They're really, really smart, intelligent
people but I didn't know that trees

434
00:21:16.500 --> 00:21:21.560
can communicate throughout the forest,
and they even actually have mother trees.

435
00:21:21.560 --> 00:21:26.460
They can spread and
increase carbon production

436
00:21:26.460 --> 00:21:31.320
on other trees as well to help them in the
event of any kind of harmful situation.

437
00:21:31.320 --> 00:21:34.680
So its almost like our domain
controllers are like our mother tree,

438
00:21:34.680 --> 00:21:35.570
it's like our forest.

439
00:21:35.570 --> 00:21:37.550
I know it's kind of like weird, but it is,

440
00:21:37.550 --> 00:21:39.590
they all kind of interconnect and
communicate.

441
00:21:39.590 --> 00:21:41.920
>> I see that, yeah absolutely.

442
00:21:41.920 --> 00:21:45.820
Alright, so we have created our domain
which in turn creates a forest.

443
00:21:45.820 --> 00:21:47.310
Now at this point, I have a domain and

444
00:21:47.310 --> 00:21:50.700
then it's just a matter of
joining computers to that domain.

445
00:21:50.700 --> 00:21:52.210
We have established the domain,

446
00:21:52.210 --> 00:21:55.990
the trust, we then can start
adding computers to that domain.

447
00:21:55.990 --> 00:22:00.400
We could when we create this domain
we could also add additional domain

448
00:22:00.400 --> 00:22:02.680
controllers, to the domain.

449
00:22:02.680 --> 00:22:07.230
You always want to lease to the main
controllers per site to per domain

450
00:22:07.230 --> 00:22:11.010
really to the main floor Perceval talk
about that concept here just a minute.

451
00:22:11.010 --> 00:22:14.420
So once I have a domain I can add
to shuttle to make controllers for

452
00:22:14.420 --> 00:22:17.250
fault tolerance right if one goes down.

453
00:22:17.250 --> 00:22:22.070
The other one's still there and
everything continues to work, alright.

454
00:22:22.070 --> 00:22:24.820
I can also create another
domain within my forest.

455
00:22:25.850 --> 00:22:30.370
We could take that and
take another server, and

456
00:22:30.370 --> 00:22:35.190
make another domain within my forest,
so when you install active directory,

457
00:22:35.190 --> 00:22:37.560
we're gonna need to make a decision.

458
00:22:37.560 --> 00:22:40.020
We need to know what we're
getting ready to do.

459
00:22:40.020 --> 00:22:44.340
Are we adding a domain controller,
are we starting out from scratch and

460
00:22:44.340 --> 00:22:46.780
creating the domain and the forest.

461
00:22:46.780 --> 00:22:50.620
Or are we adding a domain
controller to an existing domain.

462
00:22:50.620 --> 00:22:55.110
Or are we creating a new domain
within an existing forest.

463
00:22:55.110 --> 00:22:58.330
Now the wizard we're gonna go through
is gonna ask me that very question, and

464
00:22:58.330 --> 00:23:01.010
now hopefully you're gonna have
an idea of what it's asking you.

465
00:23:01.010 --> 00:23:05.150
And remember too, when you're
creating new domains within a forest,

466
00:23:05.150 --> 00:23:12.390
you're either gonna be creating a new tree
or a child domain in an existing tree.

467
00:23:12.390 --> 00:23:15.820
Remember what that's all
about when we talk about DNS.

468
00:23:15.820 --> 00:23:18.150
For example, I might have
something that looks like this

469
00:23:19.330 --> 00:23:24.600
where the second domain that I just
added doesn't share the same namespace.

470
00:23:24.600 --> 00:23:29.800
So maybe this domain is I don't know,

471
00:23:29.800 --> 00:23:34.340
let's call it something like a test.com,
right?

472
00:23:34.340 --> 00:23:39.000
Same forest, same overall administration,
but a different namespace.

473
00:23:39.000 --> 00:23:44.310
Or I might add a domain that's
a child of an existing domain.

474
00:23:44.310 --> 00:23:48.900
So it would look more like this,
where we have a tree.

475
00:23:50.270 --> 00:23:51.260
Oops.

476
00:23:51.260 --> 00:23:52.681
And get that to lock on there.

477
00:23:55.550 --> 00:24:02.766
In this case that child domain would
share the parent name space Right?

478
00:24:02.766 --> 00:24:08.329
It would be something like child.itpro.tv.

479
00:24:08.329 --> 00:24:11.440
So when you're adding a new
domain to an existing forest,

480
00:24:11.440 --> 00:24:14.053
you've got one additional
question to answer.

481
00:24:14.053 --> 00:24:16.645
Is this going to be a new
tree in the forest,

482
00:24:16.645 --> 00:24:21.482
or is it going to be part of an existing
tree, a child domain of an existing tree?

483
00:24:21.482 --> 00:24:22.776
And it's all a matter of whether or

484
00:24:22.776 --> 00:24:24.881
not it's sharing that
contiguous namespace, right?

485
00:24:24.881 --> 00:24:27.316
Does the name build on an existing domain?

486
00:24:27.316 --> 00:24:32.184
All right, so hopefully that gives us
a good idea of domain functional level,

487
00:24:32.184 --> 00:24:33.827
force functional level.

488
00:24:33.827 --> 00:24:37.920
We know now some of the questions
that are gonna pop up in the wizard.

489
00:24:37.920 --> 00:24:41.272
I guess we should probably go take
a look at it and start installing.

490
00:24:41.272 --> 00:24:42.941
>> All right,
we've got a little bit of time left,

491
00:24:42.941 --> 00:24:44.961
do you think you want to go ahead and
get that going, Mike?

492
00:24:44.961 --> 00:24:46.505
>> I do, well, it's.

493
00:24:46.505 --> 00:24:49.106
>> [LAUGH] We're like
rolling the die here.

494
00:24:49.106 --> 00:24:50.214
[LAUGH]
>> I tell you what,

495
00:24:50.214 --> 00:24:52.817
since we've only got a little big of time
left, let's do a little more lecture,

496
00:24:52.817 --> 00:24:54.412
we'll just get all of
the lecture out of the way.

497
00:24:54.412 --> 00:24:56.871
And then we can come back and
do a full on-

498
00:24:56.871 --> 00:24:59.018
>> Demonstration, okay, I like it.

499
00:24:59.018 --> 00:25:01.962
>> Although now I have nothing to talk
about with the little bar going across.

500
00:25:01.962 --> 00:25:03.875
>> [LAUGH] We'll figure it out.

501
00:25:03.875 --> 00:25:05.731
>> We will figure it out,
we can talk about it.

502
00:25:05.731 --> 00:25:07.230
>> We are never at a lack for words, yeah.

503
00:25:07.230 --> 00:25:11.623
>> One more thing that I want to talk
about then, while we're on the subject,

504
00:25:11.623 --> 00:25:14.926
or learning about this,
is something known as Adprep.

505
00:25:14.926 --> 00:25:18.143
All right, A-D-P-R-E-P,
all one word, Adprep,

506
00:25:18.143 --> 00:25:20.561
short for Active Directory Preparation.

507
00:25:20.561 --> 00:25:26.749
In the past, when we would install
a new operating system into our domain.

508
00:25:26.749 --> 00:25:31.372
We would need to prepare the environment
running a tool from Microsoft on

509
00:25:31.372 --> 00:25:34.348
the installation media for Server 2008.

510
00:25:34.348 --> 00:25:38.787
And at this time, 2008, that we are
prepared, because Active Directory had no

511
00:25:38.787 --> 00:25:41.739
idea about these new features
getting ready to come in.

512
00:25:41.739 --> 00:25:46.094
Let's say we had a 2003 domain,
all of the domain controllers are 2003.

513
00:25:46.094 --> 00:25:49.740
We're getting ready to install
our first 2008 domain controller.

514
00:25:49.740 --> 00:25:55.033
I would run something known as Adprep to
prepare the Active Directory database for

515
00:25:55.033 --> 00:25:56.730
new attributes, right?

516
00:25:56.730 --> 00:26:01.347
You think about like a user account
has attributes, first name, last name,

517
00:26:01.347 --> 00:26:04.988
phone number, department,
password, all those things.

518
00:26:04.988 --> 00:26:07.791
With this new version of
Active Directory coming in,

519
00:26:07.791 --> 00:26:11.794
2008 in this case, it has new attributes,
I need to update the schema.

520
00:26:11.794 --> 00:26:15.050
I need to update
the Active Directory environment.

521
00:26:15.050 --> 00:26:19.124
So that these 2003 machines,
which have never seen this new attribute,

522
00:26:19.124 --> 00:26:21.327
will know what it is, and go, okay.

523
00:26:21.327 --> 00:26:25.797
That's not some mistake,
let's get everybody ready for that.

524
00:26:25.797 --> 00:26:27.200
And that's what Adprep did.

525
00:26:27.200 --> 00:26:31.556
There was Adprep forest prep,
Adprep domain prep,

526
00:26:31.556 --> 00:26:35.618
Adprep GP prep, for
group policy preparation.

527
00:26:35.618 --> 00:26:39.398
And RODC prep for
read only domain controllers.

528
00:26:39.398 --> 00:26:42.309
It's important to understand
which ones we need to run,

529
00:26:42.309 --> 00:26:43.834
who we need to be logged on as.

530
00:26:43.834 --> 00:26:47.502
Where we need to run them,
but I will tell you this.

531
00:26:47.502 --> 00:26:53.150
In 2012, brand new to 2012,
2012 R2 runs it automatically.

532
00:26:53.150 --> 00:26:56.371
When you go to install your
first 2012 domain controller,

533
00:26:56.371 --> 00:27:00.091
it's going to say, the environment
hasn't been prepared for me.

534
00:27:00.091 --> 00:27:02.789
And it will automatically run
these tools in the background.

535
00:27:02.789 --> 00:27:04.947
So honestly, for 2012 R2,

536
00:27:04.947 --> 00:27:09.276
you don't need to know this unless
something goes wrong, right?

537
00:27:09.276 --> 00:27:12.777
Or unless you're logged on with a user
that doesn't have the rights to do this,

538
00:27:12.777 --> 00:27:14.411
and that could very well be the case.

539
00:27:14.411 --> 00:27:19.184
Where I can install this domain
controller, but I can't run forest prep,

540
00:27:19.184 --> 00:27:21.396
cuz I'm not an enterprise admin.

541
00:27:21.396 --> 00:27:25.297
So that step would fail if it tried to
run it automatically in the background.

542
00:27:25.297 --> 00:27:29.752
So while we don't have to do it manually
anymore, I think at this point,

543
00:27:29.752 --> 00:27:31.661
we still need to be aware of it.

544
00:27:31.661 --> 00:27:33.903
And so,
I just wanna go over that real quick,

545
00:27:33.903 --> 00:27:36.742
Adprep forest prep prepares
the entire forest, right?

546
00:27:36.742 --> 00:27:41.817
The entire forest, so any time we do
something that affects the entire forest,

547
00:27:41.817 --> 00:27:43.647
domain admin is not enough.

548
00:27:43.647 --> 00:27:47.505
I know a lot of times we're used to
thinking domain admin is the super user,

549
00:27:47.505 --> 00:27:48.681
there is none higher.

550
00:27:48.681 --> 00:27:52.871
Well, domain admin's writes
end at the domain partition or

551
00:27:52.871 --> 00:27:56.169
at the domain boundary,
not out to the forest.

552
00:27:56.169 --> 00:27:58.254
So to do the Adprep forest prep,

553
00:27:58.254 --> 00:28:01.742
we need to be a member of
the enterprise admins group.

554
00:28:01.742 --> 00:28:04.782
That means we need enterprise-wide
administrative rights.

555
00:28:04.782 --> 00:28:06.696
We're also modifying the schema, and

556
00:28:06.696 --> 00:28:09.658
I'm sure we've talked about
the schema in other episodes.

557
00:28:09.658 --> 00:28:12.918
The schema is the blueprints for
the objects in Active Directory.

558
00:28:12.918 --> 00:28:16.652
And to write to the schema, you have to
be a member of the schema admins group,

559
00:28:16.652 --> 00:28:19.361
even the enterprise admins
can't write to the schema.

560
00:28:19.361 --> 00:28:22.121
They're not in the schema
admins group by default, so

561
00:28:22.121 --> 00:28:25.847
you have to be in the enterprise admins
group and the schema admins group.

562
00:28:25.847 --> 00:28:27.580
And the domain admins group for

563
00:28:27.580 --> 00:28:30.919
the domain you're running it
in to run Adprep forest prep.

564
00:28:30.919 --> 00:28:34.618
So you really have to be in every
super group there is to run this.

565
00:28:34.618 --> 00:28:38.465
You only run it once, and it doesn't
matter what domain you run it from.

566
00:28:38.465 --> 00:28:42.219
If you had a forest with three domains
in there, you could go to any domain.

567
00:28:42.219 --> 00:28:45.736
As long as you remember the enterprise
admins, the schema admins and

568
00:28:45.736 --> 00:28:48.200
that particular domain admins to do it.

569
00:28:48.200 --> 00:28:49.686
I take that back.

570
00:28:49.686 --> 00:28:53.114
You have to be on the schema admin,
you have to be on the schema

571
00:28:53.114 --> 00:28:55.883
infrastructure master
when you run this cache.

00:28:55.883 --> 00:28:58.448
It's been so long since I actually
ran this, and there's a whole,

00:03:24.876 --> 00:03:26.960

00:24:36.998 --> 00:24:41.070
C:\Windows\NTDS, right?

517
00:24:41.070 --> 00:24:44.794
And do I have an ntds.dit and
all the associated files that go with it?

518
00:24:44.794 --> 00:24:46.889
And sure enough, there is my database-
>> Looking at those actual files.

519
00:24:46.889 --> 00:24:49.925
>> Yeah, so
there's my Active Directory database, and

520
00:24:49.925 --> 00:24:52.438
all the log files that
go with that database.

521
00:24:52.438 --> 00:24:53.280
That's good.

522
00:24:53.280 --> 00:24:57.761
We also should see SYSVOL,
C:\Windows\SYSVOL, which is right there,

523
00:24:57.761 --> 00:25:01.051
which is all the information
that my domain controllers

524
00:25:01.051 --> 00:25:06.034
are replicating back and forth, group
policy, staging areas, things like that.

525
00:25:06.034 --> 00:25:09.439
And so again, another indicator
that everything was successful.

526
00:25:09.439 --> 00:25:13.390
I now have an up and
functional domain controller.

527
00:25:13.390 --> 00:25:15.410
All the components seem to be there.

528
00:25:15.410 --> 00:25:16.690
Everything is looking good.

529
00:25:16.690 --> 00:25:20.510
So that's it, we now have a domain that
we can start joining computers to.

530
00:25:20.510 --> 00:25:23.280
And remember, in this case,
we have a very simple one.

531
00:25:23.280 --> 00:25:25.290
Right, if I go back to our drawing,

532
00:25:26.490 --> 00:25:29.913
we'd have to get rid of
all of this other stuff.

533
00:25:31.080 --> 00:25:32.870
So we'll get rid of all that and all that.

534
00:25:34.520 --> 00:25:35.840
Oops, we didn't wanna
get rid of the forest-

535
00:25:35.840 --> 00:25:36.622
>> The triangle.

536
00:25:36.622 --> 00:25:37.960
>> Cuz we do have a forest.

537
00:25:37.960 --> 00:25:40.241
Let's get rid of that and that.

538
00:25:40.241 --> 00:25:45.560
And we created what, corp.itpro.tv.

539
00:25:45.560 --> 00:25:48.934
And I do need to bring one
of those triangles back.

540
00:25:48.934 --> 00:25:51.300
So we'll set that up there like such.

541
00:25:52.430 --> 00:25:55.180
Oops, we'll move that
triangle over a wee bit.

542
00:25:55.180 --> 00:26:01.492
And we'll remember that my forest is
actually the same as my root domain.

543
00:26:01.492 --> 00:26:06.136
So we're gonna have a forest called
corp.itpro.tv, and we have a domain called

544
00:26:06.136 --> 00:26:11.165
corp.itpro.tv with a single domain
controller in it waiting for us to join.

545
00:26:11.165 --> 00:26:11.815
So there you go.

546
00:26:11.815 --> 00:26:13.505
We have done, and we've got more to do.

547
00:26:13.505 --> 00:26:16.885
We still wanna take a look at other
ways we can install Active Directory.

548
00:26:16.885 --> 00:26:22.480
We wanna look at adding an additional
domain controller to an existing domain.

549
00:26:22.480 --> 00:26:25.220
We'll talk about upgrading
a domain controller, and

550
00:26:25.220 --> 00:26:30.190
we need to look at Server Core,
because Core is the up and coming,

551
00:26:30.190 --> 00:26:33.090
is what they want us to run
a lot of our machines with.

552
00:26:33.090 --> 00:26:36.918
And it's definitely gonna be
a testable item for sure.

553
00:26:36.918 --> 00:26:40.898
>> [LAUGH] Well, all of those things sound
great because those are all real life

554
00:26:40.898 --> 00:26:42.868
situations that you may encounter.

555
00:26:42.868 --> 00:26:43.987
So you don't wanna miss that.

556
00:26:43.987 --> 00:26:47.400
You definitely wanna check us out for
that in particular, those upcoming shows.

557
00:26:47.400 --> 00:26:49.350
But Mike, thank you so much for your time.

558
00:26:49.350 --> 00:26:52.904
And thank you for your time as well, but
we are gonna go ahead and sign out for

559
00:26:52.904 --> 00:26:53.476
this show.

560
00:26:53.476 --> 00:26:54.880
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

561
00:26:54.880 --> 00:26:55.640
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

562
00:26:55.640 --> 00:26:57.365
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

563
00:26:57.365 --> 00:27:04.640
[MUSIC]

564
00:27:04.640 --> 00:27:07.674
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.title: Install Domain Controllers Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:00.905
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:00.905 --> 00:00:02.205
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.205 --> 00:00:04.980
[CROSSTALK] Coming to you
live from San Francisco.

4
00:00:04.980 --> 00:00:06.685
[CROSSTALK]

5
00:00:06.685 --> 00:00:08.326
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:08.326 --> 00:00:10.845
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

7
00:00:10.845 --> 00:00:16.079
>> Welcome to your 70-410 series,
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:16.079 --> 00:00:19.847
So this is actually a part three,
a continuation of looking at different

9
00:00:19.847 --> 00:00:22.645
ways we can go ahead and
install domain controllers.

10
00:00:22.645 --> 00:00:25.595
And back with us today in studios,
we have Mr. Mike Rodrick.

11
00:00:25.595 --> 00:00:27.521
Thanks for joining us today,
Mike, how are you?

12
00:00:27.521 --> 00:00:29.426
>> I'm doing great, Cherokee,
thanks for having me back.

13
00:00:29.426 --> 00:00:31.623
And yeah, kinda had to come back-
>> [LAUGH]

14
00:00:31.623 --> 00:00:33.495
>> To finish this long-winded conversation

15
00:00:33.495 --> 00:00:34.956
we are having about installing.

16
00:00:34.956 --> 00:00:35.723
>> You're not gonna leave us hanging,
[LAUGH].

17
00:00:35.723 --> 00:00:36.549
>> Yeah, no, we can't do that.

18
00:00:36.549 --> 00:00:38.179
We've got to get
Active Directory installed,

19
00:00:38.179 --> 00:00:39.653
got to build up these domain controllers.

20
00:00:39.653 --> 00:00:44.430
All right, so, in our previous episodes,
we've laid all the foundation work,

21
00:00:44.430 --> 00:00:46.448
we've got all our knowledge set.

22
00:00:46.448 --> 00:00:50.234
And we saw how to start from
scratch with no domain, no forest.

23
00:00:50.234 --> 00:00:54.862
And create our first domain controller,
which therefore created our first domain,

24
00:00:54.862 --> 00:00:58.087
which also created our forest,
so we're good to go there.

25
00:00:58.087 --> 00:01:01.191
But we also said that that's not
something we see that often, right?

26
00:01:01.191 --> 00:01:01.837
>> Right.

27
00:01:01.837 --> 00:01:04.417
>> In a lab environment, you're
setting up something like that, yes.

28
00:01:04.417 --> 00:01:06.328
Normally, we go get a job and

29
00:01:06.328 --> 00:01:10.799
we are asked to maintain an existing
network, or adopt a network.

30
00:01:10.799 --> 00:01:12.928
But it's already there,
we didn't start from scratch.

31
00:01:12.928 --> 00:01:15.560
So, the next option I want to show you is,

32
00:01:15.560 --> 00:01:19.945
how do you add additional domain
controllers to an existing domain?

33
00:01:19.945 --> 00:01:22.705
So, let's take a look at my screen here,
and I have got a drawing set up.

34
00:01:22.705 --> 00:01:26.536
So, I have got a domain
currently called lab.itpro.tv.

35
00:01:26.536 --> 00:01:30.019
In there,
there's already a domain controller, DC01,

36
00:01:30.019 --> 00:01:33.171
and, of course,
I have my forest, lab.itpro.tv.

37
00:01:33.171 --> 00:01:35.349
And what we're going to do is
we're going to take a server.

38
00:01:35.349 --> 00:01:38.987
I've got a server named Servo1, and
we're going to go ahead and promote him,

39
00:01:38.987 --> 00:01:40.954
we're gonna make it a domain controller.

40
00:01:40.954 --> 00:01:42.917
And now that I use the word promote,

41
00:01:42.917 --> 00:01:46.728
that brings up another topic we
should probably touch on real quick.

42
00:01:46.728 --> 00:01:47.403
>> Okay.

43
00:01:47.403 --> 00:01:51.705
>> Because anybody that's been doing this
a little while might remember dcpromo.

44
00:01:51.705 --> 00:01:55.370
A command we would use to promote
domain controllers, right?

45
00:01:55.370 --> 00:01:58.551
Promote a server to a domain controller,
basically, install Active Directory.

46
00:01:58.551 --> 00:02:00.440
That is no longer around.

47
00:02:00.440 --> 00:02:03.953
It is in Core,
because we don't have the GUI.

48
00:02:03.953 --> 00:02:08.516
But the wizard you're seeing me using
through Server Manager has really

49
00:02:08.516 --> 00:02:09.801
replaced dcpromo.

50
00:02:09.801 --> 00:02:13.839
So you won't see that as
an option in Server 2012 R2.

51
00:02:13.839 --> 00:02:17.003
All right, so
let's see how we can go about this.

52
00:02:17.003 --> 00:02:20.621
We are gonna flip over to, so
here's my domain controller, right?

53
00:02:20.621 --> 00:02:22.362
[COUGH] DC01.

54
00:02:22.362 --> 00:02:27.089
And he's the domain controller for
lab.itpro.tv, and

55
00:02:27.089 --> 00:02:32.020
were going to jump over to Server 1,
who is a member server.

56
00:02:32.020 --> 00:02:36.696
It is a part of the domain already,
lab.itvpro.tv, but he's not running

57
00:02:36.696 --> 00:02:41.531
Active Directory, he's not running
anything, he is just getting started.

58
00:02:41.531 --> 00:02:44.821
And if I opened up a command prompt,
let's just test that out,

59
00:02:44.821 --> 00:02:47.502
I'm gonna run an administrative
command prompt.

60
00:02:50.193 --> 00:02:56.349
And we're gonna type in dcpromo,
all right?

61
00:02:56.349 --> 00:02:59.018
And there you go,
the Active Directory domain service

62
00:02:59.018 --> 00:03:01.697
installation wizard is
relocated in Server Manager.

63
00:03:01.697 --> 00:03:05.204
For more information,
go click on this link.

64
00:03:05.204 --> 00:03:08.018
So dcpromo has disappeared,
except for Core.

65
00:03:08.018 --> 00:03:10.805
All right, so,
that means we're not using dcpromo,

66
00:03:10.805 --> 00:03:14.150
we're going to be using Server Manager,
which is where I am now.

67
00:03:14.150 --> 00:03:17.502
I can go to the dashboard, and
click Add Rules and Features.

68
00:03:17.502 --> 00:03:20.844
I can go to Manage, Add Rules and
Features, either way,

69
00:03:20.844 --> 00:03:25.179
it launches the same wizard, and
we're going to go ahead and click Next.

70
00:03:25.179 --> 00:03:28.447
And you've seen me run
through this wizard before,

71
00:03:28.447 --> 00:03:32.761
so the first three screens are just
what server am I installing it on.

72
00:03:32.761 --> 00:03:35.069
Then I get to the Rules and
Features screen, and

73
00:03:35.069 --> 00:03:38.776
we will choose Active Directory Domain
Services, just like we did before.

74
00:03:38.776 --> 00:03:44.229
I'll click Add Features, I'll click Next,
don't need any additional features.

75
00:03:44.229 --> 00:03:47.210
Gives me some great information
that you should take the time

76
00:03:47.210 --> 00:03:48.852
to read about Active Directory.

77
00:03:48.852 --> 00:03:51.935
I get my confirmation,
and I click Install, so

78
00:03:51.935 --> 00:03:55.952
no different than what we did
on our previous demonstration.

79
00:03:55.952 --> 00:03:58.119
Remember, this isn't
installing Active Directory.

80
00:03:58.119 --> 00:04:00.476
This is just unpacking the role and

81
00:04:00.476 --> 00:04:03.816
getting it ready to become
a domain controller.

82
00:04:03.816 --> 00:04:06.326
So that's why there's not a lot
of decision making process there.

83
00:04:06.326 --> 00:04:09.900
Yes, that's the role I want, yes,
I want to include management tools,

84
00:04:09.900 --> 00:04:11.813
other than that, go ahead and finish.

85
00:04:11.813 --> 00:04:15.367
It's what comes afterwards,
that's where our skill set is involved.

86
00:04:15.367 --> 00:04:18.333
That's where the planning
has to be performed so

87
00:04:18.333 --> 00:04:21.818
that we can make the right
decisions in that next wizard.

88
00:04:21.818 --> 00:04:26.245
So I'll let this guy go, just a second,
shouldn't take too much longer,

89
00:04:26.245 --> 00:04:30.407
although Cherokee, I'm going to
predict that it stops right there.

90
00:04:30.407 --> 00:04:32.657
>> [LAUGH]
>> Look, 64%, how about that?

91
00:04:32.657 --> 00:04:33.178
>> Look at that.

92
00:04:33.178 --> 00:04:34.756
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

93
00:04:34.756 --> 00:04:36.554
>> The things you do when you're bored.

94
00:04:36.554 --> 00:04:39.117
There's a study, I forget what they said,

95
00:04:39.117 --> 00:04:42.738
on how much time an IT person
spends waiting on progress bars.

96
00:04:42.738 --> 00:04:47.537
>> Mm-hm, well, here's the thing, it used
to be, and I know it's kind of crazy if

97
00:04:47.537 --> 00:04:50.820
you think back,
when you actually had physical boxes.

98
00:04:50.820 --> 00:04:53.787
And you would go through and install
these, and I guess maybe not, per se,

99
00:04:53.787 --> 00:04:54.882
with domain controllers.

100
00:04:54.882 --> 00:04:58.161
You might not be installing that often,
but

101
00:04:58.161 --> 00:05:02.157
especially with reinstalls
of regular end user PCs.

102
00:05:02.157 --> 00:05:04.991
You could just line them up on the work
bench and go through and walk through.

103
00:05:04.991 --> 00:05:08.121
Especially with XP,
where it had that interaction and

104
00:05:08.121 --> 00:05:11.736
you could do them in a row,
almost like a little assembly line.

105
00:05:11.736 --> 00:05:14.001
But nowadays, it's just, yeah.

106
00:05:14.001 --> 00:05:14.578
>> All of them.

107
00:05:14.578 --> 00:05:15.816
>> You do have extra time on your hands.

108
00:05:15.816 --> 00:05:16.489
>> Yeah.

109
00:05:16.489 --> 00:05:18.577
>> [LAUGH]
>> Zero rush, yeah, we can go ahead and

110
00:05:18.577 --> 00:05:20.490
get a sandwich,
get some coffee, come back.

111
00:05:20.490 --> 00:05:24.520
So it's almost done, I promise,
we'll get it here in a second.

112
00:05:24.520 --> 00:05:27.348
And then, of course,
once this finishes, you guys know,

113
00:05:27.348 --> 00:05:29.452
because you watched the previous episode.

114
00:05:29.452 --> 00:05:31.631
It's gonna pop up, and
I'm gonna have a link for

115
00:05:31.631 --> 00:05:34.514
promote this server to a domain
controller, like right there.

116
00:05:34.514 --> 00:05:36.383
If I want, I could close the wizard and

117
00:05:36.383 --> 00:05:39.903
then I could click on the little
notification and get to the same place.

118
00:05:39.903 --> 00:05:43.017
So, no domain controller yet,
we've just unpacked all the binaries,

119
00:05:43.017 --> 00:05:43.994
everything it needs.

120
00:05:43.994 --> 00:05:46.686
So I'll click the link this time,
we'll go a different route.

121
00:05:46.686 --> 00:05:50.682
That does leave the other wizard
behind open, and if you're like me,

122
00:05:50.682 --> 00:05:51.570
that bugs you.

123
00:05:51.570 --> 00:05:52.092
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

124
00:05:52.092 --> 00:05:54.353
you can always reach back there and
close it, it doesn't matter.

125
00:05:54.353 --> 00:05:57.262
All right, now this is where
we've got to make our decisions.

126
00:05:57.262 --> 00:06:02.247
And it's the same one we saw prior, so
the last time we chose Add a new forest,

127
00:06:02.247 --> 00:06:05.797
and it wanted my root domain name,
there's nothing.

128
00:06:05.797 --> 00:06:07.629
So I get to create
everything from scratch.

129
00:06:07.629 --> 00:06:11.085
Now we're going to be adding a domain
controller to an existing domain.

130
00:06:11.085 --> 00:06:14.988
And it wants to know then,
what domain are you trying to add it to?

131
00:06:14.988 --> 00:06:19.085
In my forest, there's only one domain,
so it's not that big of a decision.

132
00:06:19.085 --> 00:06:21.324
But in your forest,
you might have multiple domains, and

133
00:06:21.324 --> 00:06:24.078
you've got to know which one you're
adding the domain controller to.

134
00:06:24.078 --> 00:06:29.026
The full name, not just lab,
lab.itpro.tv, in my case.

135
00:06:29.026 --> 00:06:33.620
If I was adding a new domain
to an existing forest, well,

136
00:06:33.620 --> 00:06:36.124
that changes my choices here.

137
00:06:36.124 --> 00:06:41.256
All of sudden, I need to know, well,
is this a child domain or a tree domain?

138
00:06:41.256 --> 00:06:44.261
Now remember I showed you in my drawing,
it could be a subordinate or

139
00:06:44.261 --> 00:06:45.647
a child of an existing domain.

140
00:06:45.647 --> 00:06:48.327
Or it could be a separate name space
in my forest, it could be a tree.

141
00:06:48.327 --> 00:06:52.025
>> Like that lateral movement or
that equal level of the hierarchy there.

142
00:06:52.025 --> 00:06:54.354
>> Yeah, because they don't have
a contiguous name space, so

143
00:06:54.354 --> 00:06:55.366
they are a separate tree.

144
00:06:55.366 --> 00:07:00.829
And if I choose Child, well,
what domain is the parent, right?

145
00:07:00.829 --> 00:07:03.205
What one was it under with
that line we were showing?

146
00:07:03.205 --> 00:07:06.609
Cuz I might have multiple domains,
and that could make a child of

147
00:07:06.609 --> 00:07:09.460
any one of them, and
then what is the new domain name?

148
00:07:09.460 --> 00:07:12.930
If it's a new tree, well,
it's not the child of anything.

149
00:07:12.930 --> 00:07:16.112
So just wants to know what
is your new domain name and

150
00:07:16.112 --> 00:07:18.341
what forest is it going in, right?

151
00:07:18.341 --> 00:07:23.240
Credential wise, if you are creating
a new domain in an existing forest, well,

152
00:07:23.240 --> 00:07:25.195
let's start at the beginning.

153
00:07:25.195 --> 00:07:28.178
If you are creating a brand new
domain in a brand new forest,

154
00:07:28.178 --> 00:07:30.398
there's no credentials to check, right?

155
00:07:30.398 --> 00:07:32.289
There is nothing, so
you're starting it out, so

156
00:07:32.289 --> 00:07:34.324
you're going to have
the appropriate credentials.

157
00:07:34.324 --> 00:07:37.735
You just need the local admin
on the machine you are using.

158
00:07:37.735 --> 00:07:42.251
If you are adding a new domain to
an existing forest, forest wide,

159
00:07:42.251 --> 00:07:44.443
remember, we talked about it.

160
00:07:44.443 --> 00:07:48.498
Anything that affects the entire forest
is gonna be an enterprise admin.

161
00:07:48.498 --> 00:07:52.176
So in order to create a new
domain in an existing forest,

162
00:07:52.176 --> 00:07:54.933
you would need enterprise admin rights.

163
00:07:54.933 --> 00:07:59.744
If we're adding a domain controller to
an existing domain, like we are here Now I

164
00:07:59.744 --> 00:08:03.944
only need domain admin rights,
cuz I'm not messing with the forest.

165
00:08:03.944 --> 00:08:07.430
Everything I'm doing is gonna be
contained within my domain, right?

166
00:08:07.430 --> 00:08:09.190
So that's the one I'm gonna choose.

167
00:08:09.190 --> 00:08:13.190
I'm already currently logged on as
somebody that is a member of the domain

168
00:08:13.190 --> 00:08:14.570
admin's group.

169
00:08:14.570 --> 00:08:17.240
If I needed to change that,
I could click Change.

170
00:08:17.240 --> 00:08:17.960
We'll click Next.

171
00:08:19.180 --> 00:08:21.221
It's gonna verify my credentials.

172
00:08:21.221 --> 00:08:24.100
It also has to check and
see if it can find the domain.

173
00:08:24.100 --> 00:08:28.020
Right, make sure that it's reachable and
look for an existing domain controller.

174
00:08:29.710 --> 00:08:32.845
If it was a brand new domain
in an existing forest,

175
00:08:32.845 --> 00:08:36.505
we'd have to verify that
the name wasn't in use already,

176
00:08:36.505 --> 00:08:39.885
it actually uses the domain
naming master to do that.

177
00:08:39.885 --> 00:08:42.658
Here we go, so
we have gone on to the next screen, well,

178

created when we install Active Directory.

00:20:37.160 --> 00:20:38.980
It can change the group policies and

407
00:20:38.980 --> 00:20:42.720

Active Directory uses for replication.

408
00:20:42.720 --> 00:20:46.340
We can include that in the backup
of the Active Directory database.

409
00:20:46.340 --> 00:20:49.020
And then when we set up
our new domain controller,

410
00:20:49.020 --> 00:20:52.550
it's one less thing it has to
replicate across the network.

411
00:20:52.550 --> 00:20:57.000
I will tell you that I typically
don't include SYSVOLl,

412
00:20:57.000 --> 00:21:00.270
it's usually one not that big,
not that much replication.

413
00:21:00.270 --> 00:21:04.980
And if you are gonna include SYSVOL,
when we move this special backup,

414
00:21:04.980 --> 00:21:08.710
I have to use a special
tool called Robocopy.

415
00:21:08.710 --> 00:21:13.687
Because the access control lists on
the SYSVOL folder have to be maintained

416
00:21:13.687 --> 00:21:14.877
during the move.

417
00:21:14.877 --> 00:21:18.651
So that all domain controllers have
read access to that SYSVOL folder, read,

418
00:21:18.651 --> 00:21:20.850
write access to that SYSVOL.

419
00:21:20.850 --> 00:21:27.870
So keep that in mind if you're gonna
use ifm, and you wanna include SYSVOL.

420
00:21:27.870 --> 00:21:31.650
You're gonna have to use
Robocopy to move that back up

421
00:21:31.650 --> 00:21:35.720
to maintain the access control
lists on that SYSVOL folder.

422
00:21:35.720 --> 00:21:39.380
I find it much easier not to worry
about that, leave SYSVOL out, and

set up the domain controller.

the bulk of the replication
