00:31:59.189 --> 00:32:02.116
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.title: Install Domain Controllers Part 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.190 --> 00:00:01.120
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.120 --> 00:00:02.960
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.960 --> 00:00:07.437
Coming at you live from San Francisco,
California,

4
00:00:07.437 --> 00:00:12.070
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.070 --> 00:00:14.773
>> Welcome back to your 70-410 series.

6
00:00:14.773 --> 00:00:19.103
I say welcome back because if you haven't
noticed, this is actually a part four,

7
00:00:19.103 --> 00:00:23.434
a continuation, of a topic that we were
discussing different ways so that we could

8
00:00:23.434 --> 00:00:27.530
go ahead and install and set up our
Active Directory domain controllers.

9
00:00:27.530 --> 00:00:31.200
And back with us today in studios
we have Mr. Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:31.200 --> 00:00:32.340
How's it going today Mike?

11
00:00:32.340 --> 00:00:33.590
>> It's going great, Cherokee.

12
00:00:33.590 --> 00:00:36.880
Thanks for having me back and thanks for
putting up with all of my parts.

13
00:00:36.880 --> 00:00:39.680
It's a lot of stuff to installing
in Active Directory, all right?

14
00:00:39.680 --> 00:00:40.920
>> There is a lot to think about.

15
00:00:40.920 --> 00:00:44.120
And we're just kind of getting
started here on our journey.

16
00:00:44.120 --> 00:00:48.830
So hopefully you'll be able to hang out
here with us and go through all of that.

17
00:00:48.830 --> 00:00:52.630
>> I'm looking forward to it cuz Active
Directory is one of my favorite topics.

18
00:00:53.850 --> 00:00:56.570
Directory D and SNL,
all the infrastructure, the core services,

19
00:00:56.570 --> 00:00:58.450
that's where it's at.

20
00:00:58.450 --> 00:01:03.000
In our previous episodes, we talked about
Active Directory, understand what it is,

21
00:01:03.000 --> 00:01:06.850
we looked at setting up a A brand
new domain and a brand new forest.

22
00:01:06.850 --> 00:01:09.510
We also looked at adding a domain,

23
00:01:09.510 --> 00:01:12.133
adding a new domain controller
to an existing domain.

24
00:01:12.133 --> 00:01:17.460
I showed you the option for creating a
child or a new tree in an existing forest.

25
00:01:17.460 --> 00:01:21.258
We also got to look at
the install from media option.

26
00:01:21.258 --> 00:01:25.429
Took a look at that, it helps save us some
bandwidth on that replication as well

27
00:01:25.429 --> 00:01:28.793
as choosing what domain controller
we're replicating from.

28
00:01:28.793 --> 00:01:31.300
So we got some good options done there.

29
00:01:31.300 --> 00:01:34.656
The next one I wanna do is Server Core.

30
00:01:34.656 --> 00:01:38.230
All right, and this is something
that you're gonna see more and

31
00:01:38.230 --> 00:01:40.700
more of if you're not used
to working with Server Core,

32
00:01:40.700 --> 00:01:45.630
you should definitely start,
Microsoft is definitely pushing core.

33
00:01:45.630 --> 00:01:50.197
If you're unfamiliar with what it is just,
I know we've talked about this in past

34
00:01:50.197 --> 00:01:52.724
episodes so
you guys are familiar with Core.

35
00:01:52.724 --> 00:01:55.050
And all the reasons we should use it.

36
00:01:55.050 --> 00:01:56.220
So let's just take a look.

37
00:01:56.220 --> 00:01:57.000
How do I work with it.

38
00:01:57.000 --> 00:02:01.840
How do I get active directory installed
on a core when there is no wizard?

39
00:02:01.840 --> 00:02:06.226
There is no little clicky add roles and
features.

40
00:02:06.226 --> 00:02:07.630
So let's take a look at that.

41
00:02:07.630 --> 00:02:11.950
Now one way I could do it, is if
the server was a member of my domain,

42
00:02:11.950 --> 00:02:15.150
which it's going to be,
I could actually manage it remotely.

43
00:02:15.150 --> 00:02:18.340
If I had already set all that up,
we could add it here, and

44
00:02:18.340 --> 00:02:21.480
I could right click in here,
and add roles and features.

45
00:02:21.480 --> 00:02:22.950
So let's do it remotely.

46
00:02:22.950 --> 00:02:27.670
And honestly this is probably the way
most people are going to work with it

47
00:02:27.670 --> 00:02:29.640
because it's what it's designed for.

48
00:02:29.640 --> 00:02:31.320
We don't manage it locally.

49
00:02:31.320 --> 00:02:34.000
We don't remote desktop into it
because there is no desktop.

50
00:02:34.000 --> 00:02:35.284
We just manage it remotely.

51
00:02:35.284 --> 00:02:38.463
>> Right, why would I wanna
tax that particular server and

52
00:02:38.463 --> 00:02:43.130
utilize that processing in the CPU power
when I can go ahead and manage remotely?

53
00:02:43.130 --> 00:02:47.000
>> Yeah, I'm sitting on my Windows 10 box
and I'm managing everything from there,

54
00:02:47.000 --> 00:02:49.450
or Windows 8.1 I guess at the-
>> Server 2012?

55
00:02:49.450 --> 00:02:51.375
>> Yeah, that server 2012, yeah.

56
00:02:51.375 --> 00:02:54.078
>> [LAUGH]
>> Into the future you can see.

57
00:02:54.078 --> 00:02:57.990
[LAUGH] All right, so
let me flip over to my core.

58
00:02:57.990 --> 00:02:59.270
So we're not gonna do it that way.

59
00:02:59.270 --> 00:03:01.510
That way would be too easy.

60
00:03:01.510 --> 00:03:02.340
>> Of course it would.

61
00:03:02.340 --> 00:03:06.270
>> We're going to, yeah,
we're gonna make Mike really struggle, and

62
00:03:06.270 --> 00:03:08.830
work on Core itself.

63
00:03:08.830 --> 00:03:10.880
So I've already got Core installed.

64
00:03:10.880 --> 00:03:11.885
And I forgot,

65
00:03:11.885 --> 00:03:16.730
it's joined to the domain, which is
one of the first things you can do.

66
00:03:16.730 --> 00:03:18.290
I use S Config.

67
00:03:18.290 --> 00:03:20.710
It's my favorite thing to do.

68
00:03:20.710 --> 00:03:22.195
>> That's what Mike does on the weekends.

69
00:03:22.195 --> 00:03:24.810
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, it's my hobby.

70
00:03:24.810 --> 00:03:28.970
S Config, if you're not familiar with it,
and it might be going away eventually.

71
00:03:28.970 --> 00:03:33.887
So I wouldn't get too dependent on it,
learn your Power Shell commands but

72
00:03:33.887 --> 00:03:38.645
it's like a menu, a little number
driven menu system that allows me to do

73
00:03:38.645 --> 00:03:42.960
some configuration,
some basic configuration on Server Core.

74
00:03:42.960 --> 00:03:44.700
Because there are some
things I'm gonna need to do.

75
00:03:44.700 --> 00:03:48.440
If I'm gonna add this as an additional
domain controller to an existing domain,

76
00:03:48.440 --> 00:03:51.380
it needs to be part of the domain,
so I've joined it to the domain,

77
00:03:51.380 --> 00:03:52.690
using S config, here.

78
00:03:52.690 --> 00:03:56.500
I also need to go ahead and name it,
right, give it the appropriate name.

79
00:03:56.500 --> 00:04:00.184
I could rename that DCO3 or
something like that.

80
00:04:00.184 --> 00:04:02.510
But it needs to be part of the domain.

81
00:04:02.510 --> 00:04:03.670
I should turn on updates.

82
00:04:03.670 --> 00:04:04.980
My guys don't have internet access.

83
00:04:04.980 --> 00:04:09.340
I don't want them updating in the middle
of a show, so I've left that turned off.

84
00:04:09.340 --> 00:04:12.100
But network settings and date and time,

85
00:04:12.100 --> 00:04:13.958
these are two that I
really need to configure.

86
00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:14.540
>> Important, yes.

87
00:04:14.540 --> 00:04:17.660
>> Yeah, before I go and
join this guy to the domain.

88
00:04:17.660 --> 00:04:21.930
So, what I would do is that you'd hit
number 8, to get in network settings.

89
00:04:21.930 --> 00:04:27.260
And it shows you a list of all your IP-
your network adapters in your machine,

90
00:04:27.260 --> 00:04:28.674
tell it which one you wanna work with.

91
00:04:28.674 --> 00:04:33.530
Mine is index 10 all right,
so I type 10 and I hit enter.

92
00:04:33.530 --> 00:04:37.160
And it shows me my current information,
all of which I've already set.

93
00:04:37.160 --> 00:04:41.110
But if I didn't, I could say,
set network adapter address.

94
00:04:41.110 --> 00:04:41.610
Number one.

95
00:04:42.875 --> 00:04:44.730
Do I want a static DHCP?

96
00:04:44.730 --> 00:04:46.580
I want static.

97
00:04:46.580 --> 00:04:47.809
Right, what is your address?

98
00:04:47.809 --> 00:04:51.700
Let's do 10.10.8.199.

99
00:04:51.700 --> 00:04:56.983
What's your subnet mask,
255, 255, 255, 0 and

100
00:04:56.983 --> 00:05:02.682
my default gateway 10, 10,
8.2 if I remember correctly.

101
00:05:03.710 --> 00:05:05.390
And there we go, all right?

102
00:05:05.390 --> 00:05:08.780
What you really wanna pay attention
to here, and an easy gotcha is,

103
00:05:08.780 --> 00:05:12.880
unlike in the GUI,
when you're setting your TCP/IP settings,

104
00:05:12.880 --> 00:05:15.765
you've got IP subnet,
default gateway, right?

105
00:05:15.765 --> 00:05:18.545
Below that preferred an alternate DNS.

106
00:05:18.545 --> 00:05:21.085
And here,
it asked me about those first three.

107
00:05:21.085 --> 00:05:22.585
But not DNS, and
it's an easy one to forget.

108
00:05:22.585 --> 00:05:26.245
>> So you have to make sure you take
the extra effort to go ahead and set that.

109
00:05:26.245 --> 00:05:31.055
>> Exactly, because that will prevent you-
if my machine can't contact an existing

110
00:05:31.055 --> 00:05:33.625
domain controller,
I will not be able to join the domain.

111
00:05:33.625 --> 00:05:36.035
I would not be able to make
a new domain controller.

112
00:05:36.035 --> 00:05:38.683
Now I've already joined
the domain which means I probably

113
00:05:38.683 --> 00:05:40.475
already have access to the DNS server.

114
00:05:40.475 --> 00:05:42.785
But just understand,
that DNS has to be correct,

115
00:05:42.785 --> 00:05:45.510
you have to be able to find
that domain controller.

116
00:05:45.510 --> 00:05:50.830
So my DNS is already set to
my other domain controller,

117
00:05:50.830 --> 00:05:52.650
if it wasn't, there's another option.

118
00:05:52.650 --> 00:05:55.090
Number two, set DNS server.

119
00:05:55.090 --> 00:05:56.000
Enter your new preferred.

120
00:05:56.000 --> 00:06:00.220
Ten ten eight dot two hundred.

121
00:06:00.220 --> 00:06:02.220
And it says it was set.

122
00:06:02.220 --> 00:06:05.520
Enter your alternate, I don't have
an alternate so I'll just blank for none.

123
00:06:05.520 --> 00:06:09.090
And now all of my TCP IP settings are set.

124
00:06:09.090 --> 00:06:11.870
Four, back out to the main menu.

125
00:06:11.870 --> 00:06:15.140
Date and time again, is also important.

126
00:06:15.140 --> 00:06:17.170
You wanna make sure you're
on the right timezone.

127
00:06:18.500 --> 00:06:19.860
And when things happen and

128
00:06:19.860 --> 00:06:23.970
I have got to start correlating log
files between different machines.

129
00:06:23.970 --> 00:06:25.870
This can be kind of important.

130
00:06:25.870 --> 00:06:29.160
So make sure that you have
the appropriate date and time set.

131
00:06:29.160 --> 00:06:31.045
Not to say you can't change
that after the fact.

132
00:06:31.045 --> 00:06:34.562
It's just you know- might as well get
everything while you are in here.

133
00:06:34.562 --> 00:06:36.920
All right,
then 15 to get back out of S config and

134
00:06:36.920 --> 00:06:39.800
back to my normal command prompt.

135
00:06:39.800 --> 00:06:43.030
All right, so we've got all of our
basics set, it's part of the domain,

136
00:06:43.030 --> 00:06:45.760
our TCP/IP settings are correct,
I've named it.

137
00:06:45.760 --> 00:06:48.950
Now, it's time to actually make
this guy a domain controller.

138
00:06:48.950 --> 00:06:53.434
For that, we're gonna use PowerShell,
all right?

139
00:06:53.434 --> 00:06:55.740
And so I just typed powershell, all right?

140
00:06:55.740 --> 00:07:00.010
From Server Core, all I have is this
CMD interface, type PowerShell,

141
00:07:00.010 --> 00:07:03.930
notice my prompt changes and
I have a PS out in front of it and

142
00:07:03.930 --> 00:07:05.358
I can use my PowerShell commands.

143
00:07:05.358 --> 00:07:09.250
So even though the background's not blue
like we're used to, this is PowerShell.

144
00:07:09.250 --> 00:07:14.973
I can do get-windowsf.

145
00:07:14.973 --> 00:07:17.760
Maybe, once it takes it's time here.

146
00:07:18.910 --> 00:07:22.412
First time you tab out of fields,
it's gonna kinda build everything up.

147
00:07:22.412 --> 00:07:25.720
But there you go,
it's running through get Windows feature.

148
00:07:25.720 --> 00:07:28.263
I picked the longest running
command to show you-

149
00:07:28.263 --> 00:07:28.865
>> [LAUGH]

150
00:07:28.865 --> 00:07:30.677
>> That it was actually PowerShell.

151
00:07:30.677 --> 00:07:34.408
Next time, git dash that IP address,
and that will work even better.

152
00:07:34.408 --> 00:07:37.455
>> And you know what we didn't
really mention in the last show,

153
00:07:37.455 --> 00:07:41.280
when we showed this particular cmdlet
here, was the indentations there for

154
00:07:41.280 --> 00:07:44.167
the differentiation between the role and
the features.

155
00:07:44.167 --> 00:07:45.406
So you see, you can actually
see that in this output here.

156
00:07:45.406 --> 00:07:47.142
>> Yeah, you were telling me about that.

157
00:07:47.142 --> 00:07:50.230
Yeah, that is very true.

158
00:07:50.230 --> 00:07:53.056
>> Yeah, so like,
the indented sections there.

159
00:07:53.056 --> 00:07:57.495
Those are gonna be your features and the
ones that are further out to the left of

160
00:07:57.495 --> 00:07:59.965
the margin are gonna be your actual goals.

161
00:07:59.965 --> 00:08:00.813
>> Got you, got you.

162
00:08:00.813 --> 00:08:02.084
See, you learn something new everyday.

163
00:08:02.084 --> 00:08:04.259
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so

164
00:08:04.259 --> 00:08:08.660
we can see that Active Directory
Domain Services is not installed.

165
00:08:08.660 --> 00:08:10.630
That is what we're going to install.

166
00:08:11.740 --> 00:08:15.840
So let me clear up that screen,
Install-windowsFeature.

167
00:08:15.840 --> 00:08:18.612
So just like we used Get to retrieve them,

168
00:08:18.612 --> 00:08:23.485
Install is what we're gonna use
to install one of those features.

169
00:08:23.485 --> 00:08:28.000
Install-windowsFeature, and
then the name of the feature.

170
00:08:28.000 --> 00:08:30.950
You could do a -name or
you could leave that out.

171
00:08:30.950 --> 00:08:36.205
It's kind of optional, I should do a -name
because we are doing this as a demo.

172
00:08:36.205 --> 00:08:45.980
ad-domain-services And
it's no longer case-sensitive.

173
00:08:45.980 --> 00:08:46.990
At least I'm pretty sure it's not.

174
00:08:46.990 --> 00:08:48.980
We're gonna find out as
I type this command.

175
00:08:48.980 --> 00:08:50.820
It used to be case-sensitive.

176
00:08:50.820 --> 00:08:56.810
And then this is an important one,
-IncludeManagementTools, all right?

177
00:08:56.810 --> 00:09:02.208
I wanna make sure I include those,
I get my consoles, right.

178
00:09:02.208 --> 00:09:04.700
Well, this is a GUI list, so
I guess it that doesn't really matter.

179
00:09:04.700 --> 00:09:07.260
But my modules for
PowerShell, things like that.

180
00:09:07.260 --> 00:09:11.140
So we're gonna include that,
we'll hit Enter.

181
00:09:11.140 --> 00:09:15.260
And just like when we did it in the GUI,
this is like the first wizard, right.

182
00:09:15.260 --> 00:09:20.145
This is unpacking the role and
getting all the components ready, but

183
00:09:20.145 --> 00:09:23.110
it's still not gonna be a domain
controller when we're finished.

184
00:09:23.110 --> 00:09:25.740
It's just gonna have all the gears and
levers and

185
00:09:25.740 --> 00:09:28.270
all the pieces ready to
make a domain controller.

186
00:09:28.270 --> 00:09:30.140
We still have to go
through the configuration.

187
00:09:30.140 --> 00:09:31.797
But you guys knew that, right?

188
00:09:31.797 --> 00:09:34.211
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because we didn't answer anything like

189
00:09:34.211 --> 00:09:37.313
is these the first domain
controller in a new forest, or

190
00:09:37.313 --> 00:09:40.367
is this a new domain controller
in an existing domain?

191
00:09:40.367 --> 00:09:43.210
None of that was there, so-
>> And we don't have like a chip

192
00:09:43.210 --> 00:09:46.800
implanted for telepathy or
anything with our servers yet.

193
00:09:46.800 --> 00:09:49.478
>> No, no, no, no, no, that's coming,
soon, I'll be the first in line.

194
00:09:49.478 --> 00:09:51.480
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right, so

195
00:09:51.480 --> 00:09:52.740
we'll let this finish up.

196
00:09:52.740 --> 00:09:55.660
What can we talk about while
we're waiting for that?

197
00:09:56.780 --> 00:09:58.250
Let's see what else.

198
00:09:58.250 --> 00:10:00.304
While this is going,
why don't we flip over,

199
00:10:00.304 --> 00:10:03.580
cuz we got a couple of other
things that we need to talk about.

200
00:10:03.580 --> 00:10:06.610
One is the global catalog, right?

201
00:10:06.610 --> 00:10:09.370
And the global catalog, really I think for

202
00:10:09.370 --> 00:10:14.360
this exam, it's gonna be a lot about how
do I make it a global catalog or not?

203
00:10:14.360 --> 00:10:17.890
But I think you need to know what the
global catalog is and the way this works.

204
00:10:17.890 --> 00:10:20.230
Active Directory is a database, right?

205
00:10:20.230 --> 00:10:23.160
And we can have multiple
domains in a forest.

206
00:10:23.160 --> 00:10:28.600
And If we take domain A, for example,
let's say we've got domain A and domain B.

207
00:10:28.600 --> 00:10:31.790
Well, if I'm a user in domain A,
I can search

208
00:10:31.790 --> 00:10:36.370
domain A's Active Directory database and
find other objects like other users.

209
00:10:36.370 --> 00:10:41.730
I want Cherokee's public certificate so
that I can verify a digital signature or

210
00:10:41.730 --> 00:10:45.680
send her some encrypted data,
or I need to find a printer.

211
00:10:45.680 --> 00:10:47.600
I can browse Active Directory.

212
00:10:47.600 --> 00:10:51.170
I'm browsing domain A's Active Directory.

213
00:10:51.170 --> 00:10:57.228
What if I wanna find a user in domain B,
or a printer in domain B?

214
00:10:57.228 --> 00:11:01.100
Well when I search Active Directory,
I'm only searching domain A, right?

215
00:11:01.100 --> 00:11:04.940
Because that's the Active Directory
database that my domain is in charge of

216
00:11:04.940 --> 00:11:06.030
and knows about.

217
00:11:06.030 --> 00:11:07.820
I won't ever find users in domain B.

218
00:11:09.690 --> 00:11:11.811
The same thing for domain B,
they all find domain B stuff,

219
00:11:11.811 --> 00:11:14.370
they won't know anything
about domain A stuff.

220
00:11:14.370 --> 00:11:20.760
A global catalog is an index for objects
throughout the entire forest, all right?

221
00:11:20.760 --> 00:11:23.530
Now we've got a catalog, a phonebook,

222
00:11:23.530 --> 00:11:28.870
if you will, of all the objects in the
entire forest, both domain A and domain B.

223
00:11:28.870 --> 00:11:30.650
That's what a global catalog is.

224
00:11:30.650 --> 00:11:32.920
It contains all the objects in the forest.

225
00:11:32.920 --> 00:11:37.070
Well, it contains all the objects and
a subset of the attributes.

226
00:11:37.070 --> 00:11:39.410
It actually doesn't contain every
attribute for every object,

227
00:11:39.410 --> 00:11:43.510
cuz then it would be too big, but
that's for a more detailed conversation.

228
00:11:43.510 --> 00:11:45.990
But what the global catalog
allows me to do is find objects.

229
00:11:45.990 --> 00:11:51.030
Because if my domain controller is also
a global catalog server, not only does

230
00:11:51.030 --> 00:11:56.005
it know about all of domain A's stuff,
it also knows about domain B objects.

231
00:11:56.005 --> 00:12:00.265
And so when I search, I can now
find that printer in domain B, or

232
00:12:00.265 --> 00:12:03.235
I can find that user in domain B.

233
00:12:03.235 --> 00:12:05.815
Or if there's a domain C or
domain D or domain E,

234
00:12:05.815 --> 00:12:10.300
right, they're all gonna be part of
that global catalog within my forest.

235
00:12:10.300 --> 00:12:14.900
So each domain has their own
database that has their own objects.

236
00:12:14.900 --> 00:12:19.120
A global catalog is an index of
the objects across the entire forest and

237
00:12:19.120 --> 00:12:22.650
allows me to search for
objects throughout the entire forest.

238
00:12:22.650 --> 00:12:24.755
How do I know if my server's
a global catalog server?

239
00:12:24.755 --> 00:12:29.910
One, domain controllers are global catalog
servers, but they don't have to be.

240
00:12:29.910 --> 00:12:30.850
They are by default,

241
00:12:30.850 --> 00:12:33.740
we saw that little check mark when
we went through the wizard, right?

242
00:12:33.740 --> 00:12:39.020
If I go into Active Directory Sites and
Services, this is where I can change.

243
00:12:39.020 --> 00:12:42.629
If I want, maybe I don't want this
guy to be a global catalog anymore,

244
00:12:42.629 --> 00:12:44.782
the replication is just too much for him.

245
00:12:44.782 --> 00:12:46.530
Cuz that is something to think about.

246
00:12:46.530 --> 00:12:49.420
Now the domain controller,
if it's a global catalog server,

247
00:12:49.420 --> 00:12:52.980
it's replicating its own database for
its domain.

248
00:12:52.980 --> 00:12:55.530
And it's also replicating
the domain partitions for

249
00:12:55.530 --> 00:12:57.430
every other domain in your forest.

250
00:12:57.430 --> 00:13:01.410
So there's a lot of extra replication
going on in global catalog servers, And

251
00:13:01.410 --> 00:13:02.990
more disk space being used for

252
00:13:02.990 --> 00:13:07.240
that database,
which could potentially be an issue.

253
00:13:07.240 --> 00:13:12.200
So for example, if you had two domain
controllers out in a branch office,

254
00:13:12.200 --> 00:13:14.820
maybe you don't want both of them
being global catalog servers, or

255
00:13:14.820 --> 00:13:16.000
maybe you don't want any.

256
00:13:16.000 --> 00:13:18.390
You really need one, but maybe you don't.

257
00:13:18.390 --> 00:13:19.110
So how do you do it?

258
00:13:19.110 --> 00:13:22.261
You come into Active Directory Sites and
Services,

259
00:13:22.261 --> 00:13:25.983
you find the site that your
domain controller's located in,

260
00:13:25.983 --> 00:13:30.075
you find your domain controller,
and you go down to NTDS settings.

261
00:13:30.075 --> 00:13:31.970
You can right-click over here.

262
00:13:31.970 --> 00:13:33.690
Or if I select the server,

263
00:13:33.690 --> 00:13:37.450
I can right-click over here and
choose Properties.

264
00:13:37.450 --> 00:13:40.440
And there's the check mark,
right there, for Global Catalog.

265
00:13:40.440 --> 00:13:44.404
If it's not a global catalog server,
check the check mark and click OK.

266
00:13:44.404 --> 00:13:46.388
It is now a global catalog server, and

267
00:13:46.388 --> 00:13:50.250
it'll begin replicating all those
other domains, domain partitions.

268
00:13:50.250 --> 00:13:53.910
If you uncheck it, It will no longer
be a global catalog server, and

269
00:13:53.910 --> 00:13:57.610
it will no longer replicate those
additional partitions, all right?

270
00:13:57.610 --> 00:13:58.910
So that's global catalog.

271
00:13:58.910 --> 00:14:02.600
How we can determine which domain
controllers are global catalog servers,

272
00:14:02.600 --> 00:14:04.860
and how we can change it if we need to.

I can't go from data
center back to standard.

463
00:23:24.000 --> 00:23:25.284
So I can't go down,

464
00:23:25.284 --> 00:23:28.416
I can go up because I'm gonna-
>> Think about the licensing

00:23:28.416 --> 00:23:31.051
there too because-
>> Yeah I wanna get features that I didn't

So upgrades, I think what I would
leave it at is, yes you can,

active directory will still be there when

>> Backup first.

>> Back up first,
>> But honestly, is it worth it?

Well, it's gonna depend on your scenario.

472
00:23:51.780 --> 00:23:56.582
It's just as easy in my opinion to,
especially if it's virtualized,

473
00:23:56.582 --> 00:24:00.993
build it brand new from scratch via,
install 2012 R2 on it.

474
00:24:00.993 --> 00:24:04.505
Bring it up, let it replicate from

475
00:24:04.505 --> 00:24:08.420
And at least if I have to troubleshoot,

476
00:24:08.420 --> 00:24:11.310
It's not even a possibility that,
that's causing a problem.

477
00:24:13.330 --> 00:24:17.190
That's my personal opinion,
I would stay away from upgrades.

478
00:24:17.190 --> 00:24:18.430
But like I said, it can be done.

479
00:24:18.430 --> 00:24:21.573
So for the exam,
understand, you can do it.

480
00:24:21.573 --> 00:24:23.713
And you don't have to
reinstall Active Directory,

481
00:24:23.713 --> 00:24:25.540
everything should still be there.

482
00:24:25.540 --> 00:24:31.020
Data files, the Active Directory database,
all of that stuff should be just fine.

483
00:24:31.020 --> 00:24:33.870
So I guess you can and should you do it?

484
00:24:33.870 --> 00:24:35.170
I'll leave that one up to you.

485
00:24:36.340 --> 00:24:38.200
All right, so core has rebooted.

486
00:24:38.200 --> 00:24:39.620
Let's see what we got here.

487
00:24:40.630 --> 00:24:43.800
Notice now I'm being asked
to log in to the domain,

488
00:24:43.800 --> 00:24:45.480
which actually it was
a domain member already.

489
00:24:46.670 --> 00:24:52.270
So let's go ahead and log in,
and we'll run that little

490
00:24:52.270 --> 00:24:57.018
command just to make sure we are good and
we will check one more place as well.

491
00:24:57.018 --> 00:25:03.845
We'll do PowerShell,
that is not how you spell it.

492
00:25:03.845 --> 00:25:08.721
And we do get-windowsFeature,
l can spell it

493
00:25:08.721 --> 00:25:13.734
out before the tab fill complete,
there we go.

494
00:25:13.734 --> 00:25:17.508
And we just give it a second, and
let's see if Active Directory is listed.

495
00:25:20.770 --> 00:25:23.412
Sorry, I get impatient when I
start messing with my mouse wheel.

496
00:25:23.412 --> 00:25:24.375
>> [LAUGH] I was gonna say,

497
00:25:24.375 --> 00:25:27.945
this time we could have use the wild cards
though to kind of narrow that filter down.

498
00:25:27.945 --> 00:25:29.579
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, we should have.

499
00:25:29.579 --> 00:25:33.233
And there we go, Active Directory
Domain Services is installed.

500
00:25:33.233 --> 00:25:35.864
>> [LAUGH]
>> We can also do what we did on our other

501
00:25:35.864 --> 00:25:37.053
machines, right?

502
00:25:37.053 --> 00:25:43.664
I could go into C:\Windows\NTDS,

503
00:25:43.664 --> 00:25:48.007
and I could look in here.

504
00:25:48.007 --> 00:25:49.882
And I could see that I
have my NTDS database.

505
00:25:49.882 --> 00:25:51.447
I could go into.

506
00:25:51.447 --> 00:25:53.342
I can make sure those are there as well.

507
00:25:53.342 --> 00:25:57.582
I can go back over to my other,
my domain controller with a GUI, right?

508
00:25:57.582 --> 00:26:00.506
And I can open up Active Directory
users and computers.

509
00:26:00.506 --> 00:26:05.574
And I can see that core is now
in my domain controllers OU,

510
00:26:05.574 --> 00:26:09.320
so we are good to go there, all right?

511
00:26:09.320 --> 00:26:12.590
So there even small Active Directory
on a domain controller.

512
00:26:13.950 --> 00:26:15.230
Last but not least, and

513
00:26:15.230 --> 00:26:18.500
then I promise we'll give up
the ghost of Active Directory here.

514
00:26:18.500 --> 00:26:20.279
>> DNS records, yeah?

515
00:26:20.279 --> 00:26:20.980
>> Yes, DNS records.

516
00:26:20.980 --> 00:26:21.940
>> All right.
[LAUGH]

517
00:26:21.940 --> 00:26:23.720
>> So we've got these domain controllers.

518
00:26:23.720 --> 00:26:26.690
They are doing all the authentication,
when you log on you have to contact

519
00:26:26.690 --> 00:26:29.860
a domain controller to verify
you've typed in the right password,

520
00:26:29.860 --> 00:26:33.550
get your tokens, so you can access
resources, all that good stuff.

521
00:26:33.550 --> 00:26:35.410
We have to be able to find
the domain controllers.

522
00:26:35.410 --> 00:26:37.910
When domain controllers talk to
each other, when they replicate,

523
00:26:37.910 --> 00:26:39.470
they have to find each other.

524
00:26:39.470 --> 00:26:43.390
They know the name of their replication
partner, but they've gotta use DNS to look

525
00:26:43.390 --> 00:26:47.760
up the IP address, so they can make the
connection and do the replication, right?

526
00:26:47.760 --> 00:26:51.800
So as I said, DNS and Active Directory
tightly, tightly integrated.

527
00:26:51.800 --> 00:26:55.970
When you create a domain controller it
creates several DNS records above and

528
00:26:55.970 --> 00:27:00.600
beyond the normal A record, the host
record, or the quantity record for IPv6.

529
00:27:01.870 --> 00:27:06.330
We also get what's known as SRV records,
service locator records.

530
00:27:06.330 --> 00:27:10.400
These are records that publish or
advertise the fact that, hey,

531
00:27:10.400 --> 00:27:13.436
this is my name and
I'm providing this service.

532
00:27:13.436 --> 00:27:15.108
So when you go to log on to your machine,

533
00:27:15.108 --> 00:27:17.260
it doesn't just contact
the domain controller.

534
00:27:17.260 --> 00:27:20.265
When you sit down at
your Windows 8.1 box and

535
00:27:20.265 --> 00:27:24.272
you control all delete to log in,
it queries DNS and says hey,

536
00:27:24.272 --> 00:27:29.750
I need to find a server that's running
Kerberos, so that I can authenticate.

537
00:27:29.750 --> 00:27:34.508
Can you tell me the IP address of
any server that's running Kerberos?

538
00:27:34.508 --> 00:27:36.789
DNS looks at the SRV records and says,

539
00:27:36.789 --> 00:27:40.149
which servers have told me
they're running Kerberos.

540
00:27:40.149 --> 00:27:43.960
And then returns a list of IP addresses of
all the servers that are running Kerberos.

541
00:27:43.960 --> 00:27:47.300
And that could be modified slightly
with sites and things like that, but

542
00:27:47.300 --> 00:27:49.890
that's the basic process.

543
00:27:49.890 --> 00:27:53.320
If my domain controller doesn't
create those records properly,

544
00:27:53.320 --> 00:27:54.640
we're gonna have a problem.

545
00:27:54.640 --> 00:27:56.810
Nobody can find it to
authenticate with it.

546
00:27:56.810 --> 00:27:58.220
Nobody can replicate with it.

547
00:27:58.220 --> 00:28:01.170
We're gonna have all kinds
of replication errors that

548
00:28:01.170 --> 00:28:03.090
we're gonna have to go through and
troubleshoot.

549
00:28:03.090 --> 00:28:07.580
So it's very important that we verify
that my domain controllers create

550
00:28:07.580 --> 00:28:09.320
the appropriate records, and

551
00:28:09.320 --> 00:28:13.740
know how to fix it If they don't,
or if something goes wrong.

552
00:28:13.740 --> 00:28:16.780
So we can do this, we got enough time.

553
00:28:16.780 --> 00:28:20.856
I'm gonna open up DNS, And

554
00:28:20.856 --> 00:28:24.599
I'm gonna navigate into
my Forward Lookup Zone.

555
00:28:24.599 --> 00:28:27.894
And I'm gonna take a look at,
it doesn't matter where really,

556
00:28:27.894 --> 00:28:30.470
we'll use TCP I guess for this example.

557
00:28:30.470 --> 00:28:32.210
These are all the SRV records.

558
00:28:32.210 --> 00:28:36.010
Now I have, did you guys count,
when I was over there?

559
00:28:36.010 --> 00:28:39.060
I have four domain controllers.

560
00:28:39.060 --> 00:28:42.100
DC01, DC08, Server 1, and Core 1,

561
00:28:42.100 --> 00:28:47.240
which is why you're seeing four for
each of these.

562
00:28:47.240 --> 00:28:49.210
Notice there's a global catalog record.

563
00:28:49.210 --> 00:28:53.100
Hey, my name's DC01 and
I'm global catalog server if you need me.

564
00:28:53.100 --> 00:28:57.930
There's a Kerberos SRV record,
there's a kpasswd record, and

565
00:28:57.930 --> 00:29:01.220
an LDAP record, Lightweight
Directory Access Protocol record.

566
00:29:01.220 --> 00:29:06.290
So these are being registered, so like for
example, if I sort these by data.

567
00:29:06.290 --> 00:29:07.900
Let's see if I can get the names.

568
00:29:07.900 --> 00:29:12.620
I can't, it's all done by,
it's got those codes down in front, so

569
00:29:12.620 --> 00:29:16.200
I can't really sort it by name,
in this particular view.

570
00:29:16.200 --> 00:29:19.110
But anyway,
these are the records that creates, so

571
00:29:19.110 --> 00:29:24.180
that other machines can find the machines
that are running as domain controllers.

572
00:29:24.180 --> 00:29:27.569
So the question then is,
what happens if these don't get created or

573
00:29:27.569 --> 00:29:29.005
something happens to them?

574
00:29:29.005 --> 00:29:33.858
For example, I am going to take all of
the DC1 records, not all the records,

575
00:29:33.858 --> 00:29:38.293
I could just take all of them,
what the heck, no, let's not do that.

576
00:29:38.293 --> 00:29:41.000
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'll take all the DC1 records, right?

577
00:29:41.000 --> 00:29:45.300
All four of these records and no,

578
00:29:45.300 --> 00:29:48.576
I just deleted them,
whatever am I going to do Cherokee?

579
00:29:48.576 --> 00:29:51.943
And that would,
seriously it would not be good day, right?

580
00:29:51.943 --> 00:29:55.272
Because now other machines
are not gonna be aware,

581
00:29:55.272 --> 00:29:58.769
that this domain controller
is a domain controller.

582
00:29:58.769 --> 00:30:01.040
All its SRV records are gone.

583
00:30:01.040 --> 00:30:05.431
What creates these records is
the Net Logon service, all right?

584
00:30:05.431 --> 00:30:10.297
Net Logon is responsible when you start
up a domain controller, there's actually

585
00:30:10.297 --> 00:30:14.814
a file that it reads and it tells it what
records it should register with DNS and

586
00:30:14.814 --> 00:30:17.815
it goes to the process
of registering those.

587
00:30:17.815 --> 00:30:22.688
So really restarting this domain
controller would fix my problem, okay?

588
00:30:22.688 --> 00:30:26.414
Because it would do it's normal thing,
it would boot up,

589
00:30:26.414 --> 00:30:30.383
then it would run the Net Logon
service and it would register.

590
00:30:30.383 --> 00:30:32.248
But if this is a production environment,

591
00:30:32.248 --> 00:30:35.555
the ability to restart the domain
controller is gonna be determined by one

592
00:30:35.555 --> 00:30:38.490
what others services that
are a running on it, availability.

593
00:30:38.490 --> 00:30:41.300
There's a lot of things that
can prevent me from just

594
00:30:41.300 --> 00:30:44.250
willy nilly rebooting a domain
controller in the middle of the day.

595
00:30:44.250 --> 00:30:49.980
So if I need to,
what I can do is net stock net logon.

596
00:30:51.948 --> 00:30:55.630
And it will tell you that you need
to be an administrator to do that.

597
00:30:55.630 --> 00:30:59.413
So we'll close that command prompt,
and we'll run it as an administrator.

598
00:30:59.413 --> 00:31:02.186
>> I'm still trying to
get over the willy nilly.

599
00:31:02.186 --> 00:31:02.694
>> I'm sorry.

600
00:31:02.694 --> 00:31:04.294
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

601
00:31:04.294 --> 00:31:06.614
>> And we'll do net stop,

602
00:31:06.614 --> 00:31:11.370
net logon I don't know why
I just like that word.

603
00:31:11.370 --> 00:31:12.818
>> [LAUGH] It's crazy.
>> It's just fun to say,

604
00:31:12.818 --> 00:31:14.477
say it with me everybody willy nilly.

605
00:31:14.477 --> 00:31:16.786
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I think my mom used to say it,

606
00:31:16.786 --> 00:31:18.093
and you're running around willy nilly.

607
00:31:18.093 --> 00:31:20.427
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I don't know where it

608
00:31:20.427 --> 00:31:21.077
came from.

609
00:31:21.077 --> 00:31:24.074
All right, and there we successfully
stop to the Net Logon service.

610
00:31:24.074 --> 00:31:25.737
And now I'm just gonna restart it.

611
00:31:25.737 --> 00:31:28.370
I'm gonna do net start.

612
00:31:31.070 --> 00:31:33.300
If I could type Net Logon.

613
00:31:34.480 --> 00:31:36.640
All I'm doing is restarting
that log on service.

614
00:31:36.640 --> 00:31:40.065
I could go into the service's console,
right-click on Net Logon and

615
00:31:40.065 --> 00:31:41.600
choose restart, right?

616
00:31:41.600 --> 00:31:44.420
The important thing is for
you to remember,

617
00:31:44.420 --> 00:31:49.140
Net Logon is the service responsible for
generating those DNS records.

618
00:31:49.140 --> 00:31:50.780
That's really what you gotta remember.

619
00:31:50.780 --> 00:31:53.430
It would be helpful to
know how to restart that.

620
00:31:53.430 --> 00:31:55.990
Like I said, it's a good thing.

621
00:31:55.990 --> 00:31:58.972
So I restarted it,
let's see if it fix my problem.

622
00:31:58.972 --> 00:32:06.020
Well, I refresh my TCP and look at there,
DC1 has four records again.

623
00:32:06.020 --> 00:32:09.663
Because once that service restarted,
it did its job, and it went out and

624
00:32:09.663 --> 00:32:11.160
registered those records.

625
00:32:11.160 --> 00:32:15.872
So that my friends, I think,
is what we need to know for this exam for

626
00:32:15.872 --> 00:32:19.275
installing Active
Directory Domain Services.

627
00:32:19.275 --> 00:32:21.587
All in our nice little bow in four parts.

628
00:32:21.587 --> 00:32:23.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

629
00:32:23.300 --> 00:32:24.910
>> All right, Mike, thank you so much for

630
00:32:24.910 --> 00:32:26.290
that, for being with us today.

631
00:32:26.290 --> 00:32:27.642
And thank you for joining us as well.

632
00:32:27.642 --> 00:32:30.470
We covered a lot of information,
but we still have a lot to go.

633
00:32:30.470 --> 00:32:33.912
You don't wanna miss out on this,
so stay tuned for the next show.

634
00:32:33.912 --> 00:32:35.395
For this show we'll go ahead and sign out.

635
00:32:35.395 --> 00:32:36.960
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

636
00:32:36.960 --> 00:32:37.681
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

637
00:32:37.681 --> 00:32:39.620
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

[LAUGH] All right, so let's talk about,

we've spent a few days getting
Active Directory installed, or

a few episodes getting it installed,
getting it all configured.

00:01:13.280 --> 00:01:14.744
And now what do we do with it, right?

We've gotta work with the objects

And one of the primary object types of

Directory that's gonna represent a user or

When you log in, right, you're mapping.

You're basically you're saying, I am that

A good question, I guess, to start

Why do we even have to have user accounts?

Why don't we just have machines

All of them have, I don't know,

What's the worst that could

a nuclear weapons launch, I don't know.

Who knows what could happen at that point,
delete the entire directory, yeah,

00:02:07.810 --> 00:02:08.940
not a good thing, right?

47
00:02:08.940 --> 00:02:16.100
We use user accounts to help us administer
and control our users' access, right?

48
00:02:16.100 --> 00:02:19.214
And this is something that you guys
can relate to even if you're not in

49
00:02:19.214 --> 00:02:21.213

00:02:21.213 --> 00:02:22.375
Think about your home computer.

00:02:22.375 --> 00:02:25.875
How many of you out there have a machine
at home that just stays logged in?

52
00:02:25.875 --> 00:02:29.255
And everybody in the family just
sits down and uses the computer.

53
00:02:29.255 --> 00:02:32.250
And that's fine in your house where
you've got physical security, right?

54
00:02:32.250 --> 00:02:36.125
Not too many people can get into
your house and access your computer.

55
00:02:36.125 --> 00:02:41.225
But the downside of doing a scenario like
that is you have no accountability, right?

56
00:02:41.225 --> 00:02:42.945
What if a file turns up missing?

57
00:02:42.945 --> 00:02:44.750
Or somebody deleted a picture?

58
00:02:44.750 --> 00:02:45.610
Who did it?

59
00:02:45.610 --> 00:02:46.999
Was it you or you?

60
00:02:46.999 --> 00:02:48.394
You're pointing at the kids.

61
00:02:48.394 --> 00:02:51.235
You have no way of knowing because
everybody's logged on with the same

62
00:02:51.235 --> 00:02:53.820
account so
there is no accountability with that.

63
00:02:53.820 --> 00:02:55.850
And I can't control any levels of access.

64
00:02:55.850 --> 00:02:56.510
I can't say,

65
00:02:56.510 --> 00:03:00.280
Billy can't be on the computer after
9 PM because he's got homework to do.

66
00:03:00.280 --> 00:03:04.046
Because there's no way to differentiate
Billy from anybody else in the family when

67
00:03:04.046 --> 00:03:05.297
they access that machine.

68
00:03:05.297 --> 00:03:08.700
And that's the same concept when
we come into a workplace, right?

69
00:03:08.700 --> 00:03:12.360
We have user accounts so
that we have that accountability.

70
00:03:12.360 --> 00:03:15.500
And we have that ability
to control access.

71
00:03:15.500 --> 00:03:17.720
When you log on with your user account,

72
00:03:17.720 --> 00:03:22.300
your user account is given a certain set
of permissions and rights over different

73
00:03:22.300 --> 00:03:26.633
objects throughout the enterprise
based on that user account, all right?

74
00:03:26.633 --> 00:03:30.236
And I can now control whether or not
you're allowed to access this resource or

75
00:03:30.236 --> 00:03:31.320
that resource.

76
00:03:31.320 --> 00:03:35.080
And because Justin, for example, has
a different user account, I can allow him

77
00:03:35.080 --> 00:03:39.580
access but still deny me access because
we have different accounts there.

78
00:03:39.580 --> 00:03:40.750
When I go to look at log files,

79
00:03:40.750 --> 00:03:44.750
if we're doing auditing,
I can see who modified that file.

80
00:03:44.750 --> 00:03:48.220
I can see who accidentally deleted that
folder and didn't wanna tell anybody.

81
00:03:48.220 --> 00:03:51.040
Because I could look in the log files and
I can see,

82
00:03:51.040 --> 00:03:56.680
Jay Dennison deleted this resource at
8:42 AM, right, I can see that in there.

83
00:03:56.680 --> 00:03:59.210
That's because we have
those user accounts.

84
00:03:59.210 --> 00:04:03.340
>> And Mike, correct me if I'm wrong, but
also this keeps me, let's say, I have

85
00:04:03.340 --> 00:04:07.880
a particular role, I have a database
administrator role or something like that.

86
00:04:07.880 --> 00:04:12.320
So I have access to those resources, but
I'm trying to do some kind of manipulation

87
00:04:12.320 --> 00:04:15.540
and as a byproduct,
I mess with another resource.

88
00:04:15.540 --> 00:04:18.780
But having a user account that
has that resource limited to me

89
00:04:18.780 --> 00:04:20.730
kind of keeps things from, whoops,

90
00:04:20.730 --> 00:04:24.380
I accidentally deleted some stuff that
Mike needed for his particular role.

91
00:04:24.380 --> 00:04:25.890
And then we don't have to
worry about that, correct?

92
00:04:25.890 --> 00:04:26.800
>> Exactly right.

93
00:04:26.800 --> 00:04:31.910
We got that control where we
can be as granular as we want

94
00:04:31.910 --> 00:04:33.910
with their level of access.

95
00:04:33.910 --> 00:04:34.885
All right so now,

96
00:04:34.885 --> 00:04:38.981
we've gotta we understand a general
idea of what these user accounts are,

97
00:04:38.981 --> 00:04:43.807
their objects, and Active Directory, why
we have them and why they're so important.

98
00:04:43.807 --> 00:04:46.451
The computers have accounts
just like users do.

99
00:04:46.451 --> 00:04:48.161
We're gonna focus on users first and

100
00:04:48.161 --> 00:04:50.490
probably come back around
to computer accounts.

101
00:04:50.490 --> 00:04:53.350
But understand the computers have
accounts and Active Directory as well.

102
00:04:53.350 --> 00:04:57.400
When you join a computer to the domain,
what you're really doing is creating

103
00:04:57.400 --> 00:05:00.910
an object that represents that
computer in Active Directory.

104
00:05:00.910 --> 00:05:04.990
I now know that that computer is part
of my domain and I have the same thing,

105
00:05:04.990 --> 00:05:06.240
I have accountability.

106
00:05:06.240 --> 00:05:10.940
I can see what computer Justin used when
he accidentally deleted that folder.

107
00:05:10.940 --> 00:05:14.930
I can see what workstation he was
sitting at or I can control access,

108
00:05:14.930 --> 00:05:19.110
those laptops are allowed to
remote in from the outside.

109
00:05:19.110 --> 00:05:22.080
Or you can only access
these certain resources

110
00:05:22.080 --> 00:05:25.000
if you're at a desktop that's
in the finance office.

111
00:05:25.000 --> 00:05:28.180
If you go anywhere else, you're not
allowed to access those payroll reports,

112
00:05:28.180 --> 00:05:29.230
or whatever the case may be.

113
00:05:29.230 --> 00:05:32.340
So it's just as important that we
understand that computers have accounts in

114
00:05:32.340 --> 00:05:35.080
Active Directory as well, all right.

115
00:05:35.080 --> 00:05:37.860
So now, how do we create this accounts?

to work with manage this user and

Computers is our access to

Right, this is our interface that

Cuz remember,
all of this is stored In that NTDS.DIT,

Cuz that plays a big part in the way we

But for now,
let's just kind of ignore that and

00:25:13.610 --> 00:25:18.490
All right, all the other options
that we saw in the wizard.

508
00:25:18.490 --> 00:25:22.280
User must change password at next log on,
or if I don't want that,

509
00:25:22.280 --> 00:25:25.970
User can't change password or
Password never expires, all right.

510
00:25:25.970 --> 00:25:28.080
So all the same options are there,

511
00:25:28.080 --> 00:25:32.020
you can scroll down through this screen
to get to all the different sections.

512
00:25:32.020 --> 00:25:35.460
You can also use their little
navigation tree to jump

513
00:25:35.460 --> 00:25:37.950
to a particular section
over there if you want.

514
00:25:37.950 --> 00:25:41.830
But in the end,
you fill in the information, you click OK,

515
00:25:41.830 --> 00:25:45.550
and you've got a new user sitting there,
right.

516
00:25:45.550 --> 00:25:48.829
And if I go back over to Active Directory,
the other console,

517
00:25:48.829 --> 00:25:52.425
now this doesn't refresh automatically,
but if I click refresh,

518
00:25:52.425 --> 00:25:54.980
I want the hosts OU, I click Refresh.

519
00:25:54.980 --> 00:25:56.384
There's my test user, right.

520
00:25:56.384 --> 00:25:58.790
So you see that we're
manipulating the same database.

521
00:25:58.790 --> 00:26:03.517
There is no difference here
depending on which console you use,

522
00:26:03.517 --> 00:26:07.290
everything really works the same way,
all right.

523
00:26:07.290 --> 00:26:11.636
So lets do this, I had all these
lab steps laid out, Justin,

524
00:26:11.636 --> 00:26:14.970
[LAUGH] I don't think I
did a single one of them.

525
00:26:14.970 --> 00:26:18.240
I made your account, and I made test,
and let's go take a look.

526
00:26:18.240 --> 00:26:20.620
Actually, you know what, there is one more
thing, I know we're getting short on time.

527
00:26:20.620 --> 00:26:24.010
One more thing I wanna show you
before we run out of time here.

528
00:26:24.010 --> 00:26:26.327
Another cool thing about
the Administrative Center,

529
00:26:26.327 --> 00:26:28.098
remember I said it's PowerShell based.

530
00:26:28.098 --> 00:26:32.222
So, when I went through that wizard and
clicked OK to create that new user,

531
00:26:32.222 --> 00:26:36.155
it actually executed a PowerShell
command in the background.

532
00:26:36.155 --> 00:26:38.280
Wouldn't it be cool if we
could see that command?

533
00:26:38.280 --> 00:26:43.076
>> Yeah, that would handy because,
I'm sitting here thinking, man I'm lazy,

534
00:26:43.076 --> 00:26:45.940
I would be trying to figure
out how to automate some this.

535
00:26:45.940 --> 00:26:49.190
And I you said that's possible,
but I don't know PowerShell.

536
00:26:49.190 --> 00:26:52.516
So, [SOUND] it'd be nice
if it'd just give it to me.

537
00:26:52.516 --> 00:26:55.052
>> All right, well let's see here,
if we take a look at this console,

538
00:26:55.052 --> 00:26:56.743
you might wanna go full
screen on this just for

539
00:26:56.743 --> 00:26:59.080
a second cuz I'm gonna go way
down here in this bottom corner.

540
00:26:59.080 --> 00:27:02.470
We see this little chevron,
says Expand when I hover over it.

541
00:27:02.470 --> 00:27:04.880
It says WINDOWS POWERSHELL HISTORY.

542
00:27:04.880 --> 00:27:07.530
It's kind of hidden down there,
you wouldn't even notice at first but

543
00:27:07.530 --> 00:27:11.140
when I click on that,aAnd I'm
gonna drag this up a wee bit.

544
00:27:11.140 --> 00:27:13.525
Here's the commands that
were actually executed.

545
00:27:13.525 --> 00:27:18.990
New-ADUser, -DisplayName Test User,
-GivenName Test, all right.

546
00:27:18.990 --> 00:27:23.000
All the information that we
filled in in that wizard.

547
00:27:23.000 --> 00:27:27.450
Where I right clicked new user or
selected new user was in that host OU.

548
00:27:27.450 --> 00:27:29.280
So it knows where to put the account.

549
00:27:29.280 --> 00:27:31.140
So even though we're in the GUI,

550
00:27:31.140 --> 00:27:35.200
we're actually running PowerShell commands
when we use the new Administrative Center.

551
00:27:35.200 --> 00:27:38.815
And then you'll see it ran a second
command to set the account password,

552
00:27:38.815 --> 00:27:43.290
then it went back and ran another command
to enable the account, all right.

553
00:27:43.290 --> 00:27:46.680
Then it set the account control and

554
00:27:46.680 --> 00:27:50.580
set the properties, for some of
the different properties that we set.

555
00:27:50.580 --> 00:27:52.150
So really, what four different commands?

556
00:27:52.150 --> 00:27:55.860
One, two three four, five different
commands that it ended up executing

557
00:27:55.860 --> 00:27:57.500
in order to create that user account.

558
00:27:57.500 --> 00:28:01.210
But as Justin was saying,
if I'm wanting to get used to PowerShell,

559
00:28:01.210 --> 00:28:02.660
start doing things.

560
00:28:02.660 --> 00:28:04.862
Maybe I wanna start getting
into scripting and automation.

561
00:28:04.862 --> 00:28:07.670
I've gotta learn my PowerShell,
here's a great way to do it right?

562
00:28:07.670 --> 00:28:11.660
I can do something in the GUI, go delete
an OU, I shouldn't say go delete and OU,

563
00:28:11.660 --> 00:28:12.740
do be careful with that.

564
00:28:12.740 --> 00:28:15.234
But go do your work in the new console,
but

565
00:28:15.234 --> 00:28:19.240
pay attention to what shows up
in PowerShell history down here.

566
00:28:19.240 --> 00:28:23.436
Look I can copy it, all right, I can
select this command, I can copy it out and

567
00:28:23.436 --> 00:28:27.710
I can take it right over to PowerShell and
I can paste it in there, right.

568
00:28:27.710 --> 00:28:31.100
That wouldn't work, I'd need to
create some unique information here.

569
00:28:31.100 --> 00:28:35.266
But the point is it's really easy
to start grabbing this stuff and

570
00:28:35.266 --> 00:28:38.611
running over to PowerShell and
implementing that.

571
00:28:38.611 --> 00:28:41.990
Whoops, didn't mean to open
that back up again, all right.

572
00:28:41.990 --> 00:28:48.370
So, that's a look at the GUIs and
how we can at least create objects.

573
00:28:48.370 --> 00:28:51.690
I know we're out of time here, last thing
I wanna show you, deleting objects.

574
00:28:51.690 --> 00:28:58.134
Right click, Delete, it's going to warn
you, and that's it, it's gone, right.

575
00:28:58.134 --> 00:29:02.150
There are some big, big warnings I need
to throw in with deleting user accounts.

576
00:29:02.150 --> 00:29:05.200
But that's gonna come when we
start talking about groups, so

577
00:29:05.200 --> 00:29:06.570
I'll hold off on that.

578
00:29:06.570 --> 00:29:09.280
Here's another test user we created,
different interface,

579
00:29:09.280 --> 00:29:10.810
now I'm in Users and Computers.

580
00:29:10.810 --> 00:29:16.010
I click Delete, and it can't delete
the object, because I already deleted

581
00:29:16.010 --> 00:29:19.810
it from the other console, and this
doesn't refresh, right, automatically.

582
00:29:19.810 --> 00:29:24.058
So if I click refresh I'll see that's gone
and I could do Justin, we're gonna create

583
00:29:24.058 --> 00:29:27.834
him again later, so I'll go ahead and
delete him now, Yes and there you go.

584
00:29:27.834 --> 00:29:31.270
So deleting it, either consul,
works the same way.

585
00:29:31.270 --> 00:29:35.360
>> So Mike, are we kind of
finished within the GUI space, or

586
00:29:35.360 --> 00:29:37.490
are there still some other things,
we're definitely out of time.

587
00:29:37.490 --> 00:29:41.410
But are there some other things that
we need to come back in a part two, and

588
00:29:41.410 --> 00:29:42.320
worry ourselves with.

589
00:29:42.320 --> 00:29:44.660
>> Yep, there are,
we definitely got a little bit more to go,

590
00:29:44.660 --> 00:29:48.800
cuz we wanna look at working
with multiple objects,

591
00:29:48.800 --> 00:29:51.120
we need to understand bulk
operations in Active Directory.

592
00:29:51.120 --> 00:29:55.590
And we also wanna take a look at a couple
of tools that we can at least start to use

593
00:29:55.590 --> 00:29:56.620
to automate this.

594
00:29:56.620 --> 00:30:01.520
Because user creation is one of those
jobs that's somebody gets stuck with,

595
00:30:01.520 --> 00:30:03.995
[LAUGH] and it's kinda tedious, right.

596
00:30:03.995 --> 00:30:06.235
So if we can do anything to
speed that process up it's good.

597
00:30:06.235 --> 00:30:08.405
And I got a few tricks I want to show you.

598
00:30:08.405 --> 00:30:12.545
>> Well, I'm' definitely excited for that,
I tend to be a lazy individual by nature.

599
00:30:12.545 --> 00:30:15.780
So automating as much as possible
is definitely at my wood house.

600
00:30:15.780 --> 00:30:19.750
And well hopefully you'll come back as we
continue looking at Active Directory Users

601
00:30:19.750 --> 00:30:20.580
and Computers.

602
00:30:20.580 --> 00:30:23.780
But we are unfortunately out of time,
join us back for part two.

603
00:30:23.780 --> 00:30:27.340
But for now, signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison

604
00:30:27.340 --> 00:30:28.150
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

605
00:30:28.150 --> 00:30:30.439
>> And we'll see you next time.

606
00:30:30.439 --> 00:30:36.357
[MUSIC]

607
00:30:36.357 --> 00:30:38.950
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.title: Active Directory Users and Computers Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.448
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.448 --> 00:00:07.978
>> [CROSSTALK]
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.978 --> 00:00:10.938
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:10.938 --> 00:00:14.734
>> Greetings everyone and welcome back
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:14.734 --> 00:00:18.418
I'm your host, Justin Dennison and we're
continuing on in Windows Server 2012.

6
00:00:18.418 --> 00:00:23.366
In particular, we're back with a part two
in Active Directory users and computers.

7
00:00:23.366 --> 00:00:29.430
And I know that Mike promised us some
niceties in the previous episode.

8
00:00:29.430 --> 00:00:33.390
So hopefully he will deliver, and well in
the studio today, Mister Mike Rodrick.

9
00:00:33.390 --> 00:00:34.120
How are you doing today Mike?

10
00:00:34.120 --> 00:00:35.600
>> Wow, pressure's on now right?

11
00:00:35.600 --> 00:00:36.446
Niceties it is [LAUGH].

12
00:00:36.446 --> 00:00:38.628
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm doing great, Justin thanks for

13
00:00:38.628 --> 00:00:41.230
having me back and excited as always.

14
00:00:41.230 --> 00:00:43.790
And yeah, we saw how we could
create user accounts but

15
00:00:43.790 --> 00:00:46.146
it was a very manual process, right?

16
00:00:46.146 --> 00:00:47.596
It was right click new user,

17
00:00:47.596 --> 00:00:50.679
fill in all the information no
matter which console we used,

18
00:00:50.679 --> 00:00:54.436
we still had to fill out that information
and we were doing it one at a time.

19
00:00:54.436 --> 00:00:57.300
Which occasionally,
that's not a bad way to do it.

20
00:00:57.300 --> 00:01:03.420
But if you have to do this often,
you might be looking for ways, maybe speed

21
00:01:03.420 --> 00:01:06.340
that up a little bit and that's what we
are gonna take a look at in this episode.

22
00:01:06.340 --> 00:01:10.080
There's a couple different ways where we
can start being a little more efficient

23
00:01:10.080 --> 00:01:12.000
with creating these objects
in Active Directory and

24
00:01:12.000 --> 00:01:14.620
in particular, user accounts.

25
00:01:14.620 --> 00:01:17.740
So, the first one we are gonna look
at Justin is a pretty simple one, and

26
00:01:17.740 --> 00:01:20.616
this one has been around for
a long time, they all have actually.

27
00:01:20.616 --> 00:01:23.698
I'm gonna open up Active Directory,
users and

28
00:01:23.698 --> 00:01:27.100
computers and
I wanna make a new user in operations.

29
00:01:27.100 --> 00:01:30.050
You can see I've already got
a couple listed here and

30
00:01:30.050 --> 00:01:32.830
we've hired a new person
that we need to put in here.

31
00:01:32.830 --> 00:01:37.470
Now, I could just click New User and
fill the information in.

32
00:01:37.470 --> 00:01:41.280
But we wanna think about ways that we
can be a little bit more efficient.

33
00:01:41.280 --> 00:01:45.850
And one of the things about user accounts
is that users typically end up in groups.

34
00:01:45.850 --> 00:01:48.030
Groups or membership lists that
we haven't talked about yet,

35
00:01:48.030 --> 00:01:49.650
we'll come back to that concept.

36
00:01:49.650 --> 00:01:52.100
But that's how we usually
assign rights and permissions.

37
00:01:52.100 --> 00:01:57.262
Right, if I have a sales users group and
that group is being given access to all

38
00:01:57.262 --> 00:02:02.600
the different resources that a normal
sales person needs to do their job.

39
00:02:02.600 --> 00:02:05.840
And so what I have to do is when I create
that account for that new sales person,

40
00:02:05.840 --> 00:02:07.680
I have to put them in that group.

41
00:02:07.680 --> 00:02:11.590
And a lot of times, we have to add
a user account to multiple groups.

42
00:02:11.590 --> 00:02:15.490
10, 15 different groups and
it's every time I have to

43
00:02:16.900 --> 00:02:19.620
create a new sales user,
gotta go through that process.

44
00:02:19.620 --> 00:02:23.410
All the sales people have the same
manager, they're all in the same

45
00:02:23.410 --> 00:02:27.360
department, they all have the same
work address a lot of times.

46
00:02:27.360 --> 00:02:31.250
There's a lot of information that's
really duplicated across those users.

47
00:02:31.250 --> 00:02:34.310
There's still some unique stuff like
their first name and their last name,

48
00:02:34.310 --> 00:02:36.700
their log on name,
their password things like that.

49
00:02:36.700 --> 00:02:39.190
But there are some things
that are duplicated, and

50
00:02:39.190 --> 00:02:42.150
that's where we can start to
be a little more efficient.

51
00:02:42.150 --> 00:02:45.920
What we're gonna do is create what
Microsoft is gonna call a template.

52
00:02:45.920 --> 00:02:49.500
And then all we need to do is make
sure all the attributes are filled out

53
00:02:49.500 --> 00:02:51.120
properly on that template.

54
00:02:51.120 --> 00:02:55.670
Then when I need to create a new user,
I can just copy the template.

55
00:02:55.670 --> 00:03:00.200
And Windows Active Directory knows that
some of those things can't copy and

56
00:03:00.200 --> 00:03:01.400
it'll make me fill those in.

57
00:03:01.400 --> 00:03:05.640
But the rest of the stuff, it'll allow
me to copy over from that template.

58
00:03:05.640 --> 00:03:09.560
And we can create as many templates as
I need, I might have a sales user's

59
00:03:09.560 --> 00:03:15.210
template, a sales manager's template,
an operation's template, whatever I need.

60
00:03:15.210 --> 00:03:17.184
So let's look at creating a template.

61
00:03:17.184 --> 00:03:21.660
They call template, I tell you it's
just a user account, so all it is right?

62
00:03:21.660 --> 00:03:25.260
So we'll just gonna create a New User, and

63
00:03:25.260 --> 00:03:29.370
I am gonna call this one
my Operations Template.

64
00:03:30.680 --> 00:03:33.865
And you don't have to do that,
you can call it whatever you want.

65
00:03:33.865 --> 00:03:36.950
I'm gonna give it a log
on name of apptemplate,

66
00:03:38.280 --> 00:03:40.805
cuz I do have to give it a log
on name to create the account.

67
00:03:40.805 --> 00:03:43.120
We're not gonna log in using this account.

68
00:03:43.120 --> 00:03:44.640
We gonna click Next.

69
00:03:45.670 --> 00:03:47.030
I'll assign a password.

70
00:03:47.030 --> 00:03:51.070
And here you would definitely wanna
use a good long strong password,

71
00:03:51.070 --> 00:03:52.320
because you're not using this account.

72
00:03:52.320 --> 00:03:54.297
You're probably not gonna
change this account.

73
00:03:54.297 --> 00:03:57.834
In fact, I'm gonna most likely
choose password never expires,

74
00:03:57.834 --> 00:04:01.450
because I don't wanna worry about
the password expiring on this.

75
00:04:02.850 --> 00:04:07.090
I'm gonna say user must
change password next logon

76
00:04:07.090 --> 00:04:10.460
because that property is gonna
copy over to the new users.

77
00:04:10.460 --> 00:04:13.750
But I'm also going to
disable this account.

78
00:04:13.750 --> 00:04:15.660
So hopefully, again,
that's another security measure.

79
00:04:15.660 --> 00:04:17.260
Have a good strong password, but

80
00:04:17.260 --> 00:04:21.175
also disable the account cuz I don't want
people using this template as an account.

81
00:04:21.175 --> 00:04:26.360
And both of these properties will
copy over to the new user, all right?

82
00:04:26.360 --> 00:04:30.681
We'll click Next, and Finish, and
I now have an operations template.

83
00:04:30.681 --> 00:04:32.320
But we're not gonna stop there.

84
00:04:32.320 --> 00:04:36.470
Let's open that up and let's fill in
a few of these attributes, right?

85
00:04:36.470 --> 00:04:45.560
For an address, I don't know,
let's put 3925 Northwest, 60 seconds.

86
00:04:45.560 --> 00:04:46.980
I'm making stuff up here, right?

87
00:04:46.980 --> 00:04:48.022
We'll say, Gainesville.

88
00:04:48.022 --> 00:04:50.718
Oops, well, let's make that look pretty.

89
00:04:50.718 --> 00:04:52.839
Gainesville, Florida.

90
00:04:53.956 --> 00:05:00.140
32653, something like that, United States.

91
00:05:01.480 --> 00:05:02.510
Somewhere in, there we go.

92
00:05:03.890 --> 00:05:09.500
Account information, again, this is unique
stuff except for things like log on hours.

93
00:05:09.500 --> 00:05:11.580
Now in my case,
I probably don't wanna use log on hours.

94
00:05:11.580 --> 00:05:12.530
But let me just show you.

95
00:05:12.530 --> 00:05:15.890
Let's find out if this is one of
those properties that copies over.

96
00:05:15.890 --> 00:05:21.540
So I'm gonna say, yeah, we'll go 8 eight
to 5 again or something like that.

97
00:05:21.540 --> 00:05:24.830
Monday through Friday, 8 to 6, 8 to 5,
whatever, I end up clicking on there.

98
00:05:26.290 --> 00:05:30.583
Right, maybe we say log onto just
the following computers, client01.

99
00:05:30.583 --> 00:05:33.150
And you can add as many as you want,
right?

100
00:05:33.150 --> 00:05:36.490
Down in that operations department I've
got two computers up at the front desk.

101
00:05:36.490 --> 00:05:43.320
They sit at client01 typing skills today,
searching for them.

102
00:05:43.320 --> 00:05:44.770
Add and we'll click OK.

103
00:05:44.770 --> 00:05:46.580
So we add a couple things there.

104
00:05:46.580 --> 00:05:48.380
So we can set profile information,

105
00:05:48.380 --> 00:05:53.110
organization information their
department is Operations.

106
00:05:53.110 --> 00:05:57.710
Their title, maybe I don't have a title,
let me go get a manager.

107
00:05:57.710 --> 00:06:01.719
We'll put, I'll be their manager [LAUGH].

108
00:06:01.719 --> 00:06:05.891
>> [LAUGH] I don't know,
that might not be the best of choices.

109
00:06:05.891 --> 00:06:11.210
But I do wanna bring up something in,
I think it's under stated a lot of times.

110
00:06:11.210 --> 00:06:13.941
You're using this user account that
is disabled, it has a password on it.

111
00:06:13.941 --> 00:06:18.560
And you're setting up these properties to
be copied over as part of the template.

112
00:06:18.560 --> 00:06:24.520
However, you name the template Operations
template, you can name another things.

113
00:06:24.520 --> 00:06:29.750
I would go further and say, I recommend
strongly you pick names such as that.

114
00:06:29.750 --> 00:06:33.708
Mainly because now, if your user list
grows, what's that template name?

115
00:06:33.708 --> 00:06:35.075
Don't call it Napoleon or
something like that.

116
00:06:35.075 --> 00:06:37.924
>> Right [LAUGH].
>> I've actually had individuals go,

117
00:06:37.924 --> 00:06:39.916
can you help me with this?

118
00:06:39.916 --> 00:06:42.354
And they picked this kind of a witty,
tongue in-cheek names.

119
