have a department of sales.

350
00:18:21.390 --> 00:18:24.040
Or I just need the objects that are users,
not the groups and

351
00:18:24.040 --> 00:18:26.310
not any computers that
might be in that OU.

352
00:18:26.310 --> 00:18:28.333
So -r allows me to filter.

353
00:18:28.333 --> 00:18:33.930
Search scope lets me search just
that OU or just that container.

354
00:18:33.930 --> 00:18:36.799
Or do I want to nested
containers just one level down?

355
00:18:36.799 --> 00:18:38.761
Or the entire sub-tree?

356
00:18:38.761 --> 00:18:41.587
And then dash-l is what attributes.

357
00:18:41.587 --> 00:18:45.880
When we look at a user account, there's
hundreds of attributes to describe a user.

358
00:18:45.880 --> 00:18:48.081
We typically do not want all of those.

359
00:18:48.081 --> 00:18:51.690
So -l allows me to list
just the attributes I want.

360
00:18:51.690 --> 00:18:56.080
Or if you want most of them, you can do
a -o and then omit certain attributes.

361
00:18:56.080 --> 00:18:58.200
And then give me the rest of them.

362
00:18:58.200 --> 00:19:01.885
Those are probably the most commonly
used parameters with this command.

363
00:19:01.885 --> 00:19:07.520
And then the -k helps me get around
what Justin was talking about, -cases.

364
00:19:07.520 --> 00:19:10.193
Ignore errors and continue on.

365
00:19:10.193 --> 00:19:13.590
And you might think, well,
why would I ever wanna ignore an error?

366
00:19:13.590 --> 00:19:18.764
Well, sometimes if I've got a list
of 100 users I'm trying to import.

367
00:19:18.764 --> 00:19:22.614
If the second one in there has a typo,
a missing value or

368
00:19:22.614 --> 00:19:26.770
it's a duplication of something,
it's gonna fail.

369
00:19:26.770 --> 00:19:28.773
And then the entire process stops.

370
00:19:28.773 --> 00:19:32.152
Whereas if I do a -k,
it'll fail on that one, but

371
00:19:32.152 --> 00:19:35.387
it'll still do the 97, 98 user accounts.

372
00:19:35.387 --> 00:19:38.780
And then I can go back and troubleshoot
the one that didn't work, right?

373
00:19:38.780 --> 00:19:41.375
So that's what that -k is for.

374
00:19:41.375 --> 00:19:44.530
All right, so let's take a look
at how we can do some of this.

375
00:19:44.530 --> 00:19:46.937
We are gonna start with doing an export.

376
00:19:46.937 --> 00:19:50.890
So CSV DE is gonna be
the start of my command.

377
00:19:50.890 --> 00:19:55.889
Remember export's the default mode,
so I just need to

378
00:19:55.889 --> 00:20:01.115
tell it where I wanna put this,
and I'm gonna do a c:\.

379
00:20:01.115 --> 00:20:03.753
What I did I make that folder,
ldif I think yeah.

380
00:20:03.753 --> 00:20:08.950
And we'll call it export,
let's export that host.

381
00:20:08.950 --> 00:20:10.590
I've got a bunch of users in that host.

382
00:20:10.590 --> 00:20:12.700
And the file format is gonna be ldf.

383
00:20:14.770 --> 00:20:19.255
So I'm calling it where I wanna export
this information, and then I wanna limit,

384
00:20:19.255 --> 00:20:23.870
I don't want everything, so I 'm gonna do
a -d and give it the distinguished name of

385
00:20:23.870 --> 00:20:26.740
the OU that I want the export
the user accounts from.

386
00:20:26.740 --> 00:20:33.810
So my OU is called hosts, which is
nested inside an OU called employees.

387
00:20:33.810 --> 00:20:38.514
I can't talk and type at the same time,
which is in my do, root of my domain.

388
00:20:38.514 --> 00:20:45.014
And my domain components
break down into lab.

389
00:20:45.014 --> 00:20:48.640
Domain component equals IT pro.

390
00:20:48.640 --> 00:20:51.377
And domain component equals TV.

391
00:20:51.377 --> 00:20:52.780
And then I'll end my quote.

392
00:20:52.780 --> 00:20:56.165
You don't technically need the quotes
unless you got a space in one of those,

393
00:20:56.165 --> 00:20:57.372
but I find it always helps.

394
00:20:57.372 --> 00:21:00.240
And hopefully you're familiar with
distinguish names at this point.

395
00:21:01.340 --> 00:21:05.583
Remember, distinguish name is the path
to the object in the database.

396
00:21:05.583 --> 00:21:09.783
In this case, I'm looking for
objects that are inside the host OU,

397
00:21:09.783 --> 00:21:15.033
which is nested inside the employee's OU,
which is at the root of lab.itpro.tv.

398
00:21:15.033 --> 00:21:17.131
If you look over here behind me or

399
00:21:17.131 --> 00:21:21.719
behind this screen you can kinda see
here's the host OU which is nested

400
00:21:21.719 --> 00:21:26.040
inside the employees OU which
is nested inside lab.itpro.tv.

401
00:21:26.040 --> 00:21:28.256
So, I've got my path.

402
00:21:28.256 --> 00:21:34.216
And then my lab.itpro.tv, each part of my
domain name becomes a domain component.

403
00:21:34.216 --> 00:21:39.099
So if I had east.training.lab.itpro.tv,
I've have to do each one.

404
00:21:39.099 --> 00:21:42.804
DC east, DC training, DC lab, and

405
00:21:42.804 --> 00:21:47.160
all of the way out, all right, uh-huh.

406
00:21:47.160 --> 00:21:48.468
>> Now Mike,
I got a real quick question for you.

407
00:21:48.468 --> 00:21:50.497
>> Sure.
>> And then, admittedly so,

408
00:21:50.497 --> 00:21:51.919
I'm not a Windows guy.

409
00:21:51.919 --> 00:21:56.854
But since we're using CSVDE to export,
is the ldf-

410
00:21:56.854 --> 00:21:57.375
>> [LAUGH]

411
00:21:57.375 --> 00:21:58.870
>> Extension, is that what we need,

412
00:21:58.870 --> 00:22:00.891
cuz that might cause some confusion,
right?

413
00:22:00.891 --> 00:22:04.795
>> That is great point Justin,
I'm glad you noticed that.

414
00:22:04.795 --> 00:22:09.856
>> I had moved on to ldif before
we even finished good old CSVDE.

415
00:22:09.856 --> 00:22:11.410
So let's switch that up a little bit.

416
00:22:11.410 --> 00:22:15.063
I have another folder for
CSV files [LAUGH] and

417
00:22:15.063 --> 00:22:18.724
we'll call this one again, export hosts.

418
00:22:18.724 --> 00:22:21.700
And let's call it a .CSV, how's that?

419
00:22:21.700 --> 00:22:22.618
Little bit better?

420
00:22:22.618 --> 00:22:24.190
All right, so now we're yeah.

421
00:22:24.190 --> 00:22:28.188
That was good catch man, I would have
been going that was a silly mistake.

422
00:22:28.188 --> 00:22:29.230
All right, so there we go.

423
00:22:29.230 --> 00:22:32.468
We got my path of the file that
I wanna export this out to.

424
00:22:32.468 --> 00:22:38.100
I told it where I wanna look in the
directory for the objects I wanna export.

425
00:22:38.100 --> 00:22:41.974
I also wanna limit what
I'm going to export.

426
00:22:41.974 --> 00:22:45.206
I'm gonna do a -l to list
the attributes that I want.

427
00:22:45.206 --> 00:22:51.018
And I want to distinguish name, object
class, and none of this is case sensitive.

428
00:22:51.018 --> 00:22:55.246
I do the case just for readability.

429
00:22:55.246 --> 00:22:58.316
Given name, we’ve got surname in there.

430
00:22:58.316 --> 00:22:59.650
We’ve got given name.

431
00:22:59.650 --> 00:23:03.978
Let’s do Sam, account name, and

432
00:23:03.978 --> 00:23:09.361
let’s also get that userPrincipal name.

433
00:23:12.761 --> 00:23:16.490
All right, so there's my list of
attributes that I wanna export.

434
00:23:16.490 --> 00:23:18.478
We'll go ahead and hit Enter.

435
00:23:18.478 --> 00:23:22.040
And what we see connecting
to log in as current user.

436
00:23:22.040 --> 00:23:23.476
I ran this as admin.

437
00:23:23.476 --> 00:23:25.590
Exporting to directory that I gave it.

438
00:23:25.590 --> 00:23:26.576
Writing out entries.

439
00:23:26.576 --> 00:23:28.450
Seven entries exported.

440
00:23:28.450 --> 00:23:30.015
Command completed successfully.

441
00:23:30.015 --> 00:23:31.700
So let's see what we got.

442
00:23:31.700 --> 00:23:32.852
Let's switch over to that folder.

443
00:23:32.852 --> 00:23:35.553
And I won't have to use
the path the whole time here.

444
00:23:35.553 --> 00:23:37.736
We'll do a little CSV.

445
00:23:37.736 --> 00:23:39.187
See what we got in there.

446
00:23:39.187 --> 00:23:41.447
And there's my export hosts.

447
00:23:41.447 --> 00:23:44.800
So there's a low pad with export hosts.

448
00:23:46.280 --> 00:23:47.365
And there we go.

449
00:23:47.365 --> 00:23:50.216
Looks just like my other file,
very similar.

450
00:23:50.216 --> 00:23:55.306
Where I've got my attributes right
across the top separated by commas,

451
00:23:55.306 --> 00:23:59.895
and then I've got all of my objects
with their distinguish name,

452
00:23:59.895 --> 00:24:04.829
their class, their Surname,
given name, all the way down through.

453
00:24:04.829 --> 00:24:09.231
So you might export objects out of
Active Directory to have a record of it,

454
00:24:09.231 --> 00:24:13.278
maybe to use with some other application,
like Justin was saying,

455
00:24:13.278 --> 00:24:17.694
CSV file is a very common format that
most applications will understand.

456
00:24:17.694 --> 00:24:20.702
So I can turn around,
if I've got dissimilar systems,

457
00:24:20.702 --> 00:24:22.840
I can export that data out of database.

458
00:24:22.840 --> 00:24:25.810
Give them a CSV file,
they can now import it, write reports,

459
00:24:25.810 --> 00:24:30.150
or do whatever it is they need
to do with that information.

460
00:24:30.150 --> 00:24:34.945
But we really started this conversation
wanting to create new objects.

461
00:24:34.945 --> 00:24:36.837
So let's see how we can do that.

462
00:24:36.837 --> 00:24:39.225
In that same location that we
already looked at this, but

463
00:24:39.225 --> 00:24:40.580
let's look at it one more time.

464
00:24:40.580 --> 00:24:45.681
We'll do notepad importDev.csv,
and so what I've got is I have

465
00:24:45.681 --> 00:24:50.689
my attributes across the top,
and then I've got my objects that

466
00:24:50.689 --> 00:24:55.810
I want to create, one on each line,
values separated by commas.

467
00:24:55.810 --> 00:25:01.890
So that's gonna be my input file for my
import process, and, oops, you know what?

468
00:25:01.890 --> 00:25:03.130
Let's look at that one more time.

469
00:25:04.380 --> 00:25:09.360
I'm putting them in the Developer's OU.

470
00:25:09.360 --> 00:25:10.800
I've changed the path up a little bit.

471
00:25:10.800 --> 00:25:12.530
So I've got that employee, oops.

472
00:25:12.530 --> 00:25:14.030
Got that Employees OU.

473
00:25:14.030 --> 00:25:18.230
Inside the Employees OU
is my Developers OU.

474
00:25:20.480 --> 00:25:24.480
So and we're gonna see what Justin was
asking about earlier right here in

475
00:25:24.480 --> 00:25:29.690
this example, cuz notice when I exported,
I didn't specify users.

476
00:25:29.690 --> 00:25:35.048
I just exported all of the objects out of
that OU, and one of them is the OU itself.

477
00:25:35.048 --> 00:25:37.750
I can seeOU=Developers.

478
00:25:37.750 --> 00:25:39.150
Now when I turn around and import this,

479
00:25:39.150 --> 00:25:42.680
well that was on the export,
not on this one, but same principle.

480
00:25:42.680 --> 00:25:45.910
If I turn around and import this,
this OU already exist.

481
00:25:45.910 --> 00:25:48.740
So let's see what happens
when we fire this up?

482
00:25:48.740 --> 00:25:52.840
We're gonna do csvde, we're gonna do a -i,

483
00:25:52.840 --> 00:25:57.255
to import, -f, and
I'll give it the file name,

484
00:25:57.255 --> 00:26:02.642
which is gonna be importhost.csv,
and really that's it.

485
00:26:02.642 --> 00:26:03.559
That's all I have to tell.

486
00:26:03.559 --> 00:26:07.096
I don't need to tell it what it already
has in the file, what attributes,

487
00:26:07.096 --> 00:26:08.018
things like that.

488
00:26:08.018 --> 00:26:11.552
So we'll hit enter, and here we go,

489
00:26:11.552 --> 00:26:16.022
we got an error on line 2: Already exists.

490
00:26:16.022 --> 00:26:20.330
An attempt was made to add an object
with the name that's already in use.

491
00:26:20.330 --> 00:26:23.850
I can see 0 entries modified successfully.

492
00:26:23.850 --> 00:26:30.760
All right, so let's try adding a -k to the
end of that command, and see what happens.

493
00:26:32.550 --> 00:26:36.740
Now, I've got 4 entries
modified successfully.

494
00:26:36.740 --> 00:26:40.228
We'll go take a look at that
Development OU, or Developers OU.

495
00:26:40.228 --> 00:26:41.610
There we go.

496
00:26:41.610 --> 00:26:42.990
There's your account, Justin.

497
00:26:42.990 --> 00:26:44.069
No, that's not you, sorry.

498
00:26:44.069 --> 00:26:45.184
[LAUGH] I saw Justin in there.

499
00:26:45.184 --> 00:26:46.321
>> It's a common mistake.

500
00:26:46.321 --> 00:26:47.064
>> Yeah.

501
00:26:47.064 --> 00:26:48.681
[LAUGH]
>> When I hear that name, I'm like,

502
00:26:48.681 --> 00:26:49.730
yeah, no, it's not me.

503
00:26:49.730 --> 00:26:50.947
So, it's okay.

504
00:26:50.947 --> 00:26:51.817
I'll let this one slide now.

505
00:26:51.817 --> 00:26:53.294
>> Okay, thank you.

506
00:26:53.294 --> 00:26:55.680
[LAUGH] All right, so,

507
00:26:55.680 --> 00:27:00.950
there we can see how CSVDE is allowing
me to import multiple objects,

508
00:27:00.950 --> 00:27:04.940
or create multiple objects, with one
fell swoop, right, one nice command.

509
00:27:04.940 --> 00:27:09.320
You might have maybe HR,
as they hire people, you've given

510
00:27:09.320 --> 00:27:13.650
them a spreadsheet that they use, and it's
got the appropriate columns in there, and

511
00:27:13.650 --> 00:27:17.890
the appropriate headers, and as they hire
people they just fill in this spreadsheet,

512
00:27:17.890 --> 00:27:20.110
and then they save that
spreadsheet as a CSV.

513
00:27:20.110 --> 00:27:24.059
And they hand it over to you, and now
you go and you just import that CSV, and

514
00:27:24.059 --> 00:27:28.418
you call them right back, and all their
accounts are created, we're good to go.

515
00:27:28.418 --> 00:27:31.193
Now a couple of things of
importance we need to note here.

516
00:27:31.193 --> 00:27:33.906
If we look at these accounts,
I know I can't really zoom in,

517
00:27:33.906 --> 00:27:37.060
but you see that little downward-pointing
arrow on there, Justin?

518
00:27:37.060 --> 00:27:37.650
>> Yep.

519
00:27:37.650 --> 00:27:41.210
>> That is indicating that
those accounts are disabled.

520
00:27:41.210 --> 00:27:45.868
One of the limitations of CSVDE is it
cannot import passwords, because it

521
00:27:45.868 --> 00:27:50.915
doesn't do secure connections of any kind,
so it won't work with passwords.

522
00:27:50.915 --> 00:27:54.476
Any account that gets created in Active
Directory in our modern operating systems

523
00:27:54.476 --> 00:27:57.190
is going to be disabled if
it doesn't have a password.

524
00:27:57.190 --> 00:27:58.990
So they're created.

525
00:27:58.990 --> 00:28:03.364
I'm still gonna have to come back in
here and set a password, all right,

526
00:28:03.364 --> 00:28:04.305
on an account.

527
00:28:06.987 --> 00:28:10.820
And then I will have to
enable this account.

528
00:28:12.170 --> 00:28:15.270
Now the account is good to go,
Tyler can login,

529
00:28:15.270 --> 00:28:19.290
it'll ask him to change his password that
first time, and we're off to the races.

530
00:28:19.290 --> 00:28:22.892
And all those attributes,
I didn't go that far, but

531
00:28:22.892 --> 00:28:26.815
we could use the department,
the company, the manager,

532
00:28:26.815 --> 00:28:32.195
we could do those attributes as well,
just have to specify them in our CSV file.

533
00:28:32.195 --> 00:28:37.000
So that's our first tool, CSVDE, and
I think I talked a little too much there,

534
00:28:37.000 --> 00:28:38.100
didn't I?

535
00:28:38.100 --> 00:28:40.840
>> Well you know, sometimes we just
get excited about topics, Mike,

536
00:28:40.840 --> 00:28:43.230
and there's nothing that
we can do about it.

537
00:28:43.230 --> 00:28:47.426
But I think I know where you're going,
because as it stands, CSVDE,

538
00:28:47.426 --> 00:28:51.902
it automates some of the things, but
then when you told me I had to go back and

539
00:28:51.902 --> 00:28:56.382
right-click, and modify passwords,
and maybe it's not the best tool or

540
00:28:56.382 --> 00:29:00.183
maybe that's always what we have to do,
but I'm interested.

541
00:29:00.183 --> 00:29:03.340
Are there other tooling,
like tool choices that we can make,

542
00:29:03.340 --> 00:29:05.779
that maybe well allows to
be a little more lazy?

543
00:29:05.779 --> 00:29:06.684
>> Absolutely.

544
00:29:06.684 --> 00:29:09.442
There's one called LDIV DE
that we're gonna look at, and

545
00:29:09.442 --> 00:29:11.483
it still doesn't let me do the passwords.

546
00:29:11.483 --> 00:29:15.155
I'm still gonna have to set a password and
enable them, but

547
00:29:15.155 --> 00:29:18.620
it will let me do some other
things that CSVDE won't do.

548
00:29:18.620 --> 00:29:23.056
It lets me modify existing objects and
even remove objects, and

549
00:29:23.056 --> 00:29:27.985
then when we make our way to PowerShell,
that's where we're gonna get

550
00:29:27.985 --> 00:29:32.358
the full power in the ability
to totally automate the process.

551
00:29:32.358 --> 00:29:35.717
>> So, MIke, it looks like we're
gonna have to come back for

552
00:29:35.717 --> 00:29:37.582
a part three to look at the lDIV?

553
00:29:37.582 --> 00:29:39.719
lDIV, well, there you have it,
ladies and gentlemen.

554
00:29:39.719 --> 00:29:43.195
We're gonna have to come back with a part
three to figure out how to continue

555
00:29:43.195 --> 00:29:47.125
managing our users using, well, a few more
tools that Mike's got queued up for us.

556
00:29:47.125 --> 00:29:49.273
But for this episode we're
gonna go ahead and wrap it up.

557
00:29:49.273 --> 00:29:50.689
But definitely stay tuned.

558
00:29:50.689 --> 00:29:54.276
So for now, signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

559
00:29:54.276 --> 00:29:55.194
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

560
00:29:55.194 --> 00:29:56.192
>> And we'll see you next time.

561
00:29:57.481 --> 00:30:03.309
[MUSIC]

562
00:30:03.309 --> 00:30:06.440
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:01.200
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:01.200 --> 00:00:08.267
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.267 --> 00:00:11.822
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.822 --> 00:00:15.283
>> Greetings everyone, and welcome to
another exciting episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.283 --> 00:00:19.743
I'm your host Justin Dennison and
we're back with a part three in our active

6
00:00:19.743 --> 00:00:24.006
directory users and computers kind of
I guess mini series at this point.

7
00:00:24.006 --> 00:00:30.280
And we're back to talk about a final set
of pooling to help administer our users.

8
00:00:30.280 --> 00:00:33.690
And luckily we have the man that is going
to lead us to the promised land, Mr.

9
00:00:33.690 --> 00:00:34.390
Mike Roderick.

10
00:00:34.390 --> 00:00:36.559
>> Yeah, Justin we'll see
about the promised land, but

11
00:00:36.559 --> 00:00:39.069
we are going to be taking a look,
at another one of those tools.

12
00:00:39.069 --> 00:00:42.387
That we can use to start automating
the creation of objects within

13
00:00:42.387 --> 00:00:43.760
Active Directory.

14

This one is LDIFDE,
